title: For Many Germans, Pilots Walkout Crosses a Line
description: FRANKFURT  As with so many situations in Germany, there is an orderly way to do things and then there are ways that are not socially acceptable. That principle, it turns out, applies even to labor strikes.

title: Normcore Street-Style
description: Joan Smalls and other street style examples of normcore.

title: Jeff Bezos, Please Call Your Office
description: Amazons news conference on Wednesday solved one of the biggest riddles in technology  when would Amazon ever introduce one of the devices it has been endlessly rumored to be working on?

title: The New Normal
description: Normcore (noun) 1. A fashion movement, c. 2014, in which scruffy young urbanites swear off the tired street-style clichs of the last decade  skinny jeans, wallet chains, flannel shirts  in favor of a less-ironic (but still pretty ironic) embrace of bland, suburban anti-fashion attire. (See Jeans, mom. Sneakers, white.)

title: Moving a Slab of Museum Wall, Artfully
description: A handful of art-and-dance lovers dodged cranes on Friday afternoon while making their way to the West Village construction site of the future Whitney Museum of American Art to watch a performance piece as part of the Whitney Biennial. Hard hats were passed out; release forms were signed.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: She Can Remember Everything, Even Her Shows Various Time Slots
description: Unforgettable is a well-made cop show on CBS that could have easily been a distant memory by now. Instead, it begins the second half of its second season on Friday night, a case study in how to give more chances to a decent show that didnt find its natural home immediately.

title: Seen on the Street | Outside the Fall/Winter 2014 Kiev Womens Shows
description: A glimpse at what the gals are wearing this season.

title: The Many Classes of Google Stock
description: The price of Google shares is going to be cut in half on Thursday.

title: Two Stolen Paintings Are Found in Italy
description: In 1975, a factory worker at Fiat, the Italian carmaker, bought two colorful paintings for about $70 at an auction in Turin of objects left unclaimed by train passengers. For years, they hung on his kitchen wall. One was a still life with fruit and a small dog, the other showed a woman in white seated in a verdant garden.

title: Carters Return to Capital, Onstage
description: WASHINGTON  Jimmy Carter was never a creature of Washington, and so after he lost re-election in 1980  I was involuntarily retired, he often says  he seldom looked back. But on Thursday night, Mr. Carter will return to the capital in the strange role of spectator to his often-maligned presidency.

title: In Dallas, Echoes of an Olympiad
description: DALLAS  On Sunday night, the last day of the Spring North American Championships here, three major titles were decided.

title: Peabody Awards Honor News Coverage, Scandal and Foreign Dramas
description: The annual Peabody Awards, more plentiful than ever, were announced on Wednesday with winners honored for everything from news coverage of typhoons in the Philippines to the guilty pleasure of the ABC drama Scandal.

title: Paris St.-Germain Beats Chelsea but Loses Ibrahimovic
description: PARIS  The ball had barely settled in the back of the net, and Jos Mourinho, Chelseas unpredictable manager, was already on his way to the Paris St.-Germain bench. While the P.S.G. players and coaches celebrated Javier Pastores last-minute goal, Mourinho somewhat bizarrely walked around shaking hands with the ecstatic home side, too.

title: Dean Wareham, Longtime New Yorker, on Why L.A. Is the Land of Milk and Honey
description: For as long as indie rock has been a genre, Dean Wareham has been a part of it. Galaxie 500, the band the New Zealand-born singer and guitarist formed with a pair of Harvard classmates in the late 80s, informed a generation of shoegazers and remains a make-out-session staple today. Equally beloved is his 90s dream-pop band Luna, through which he met his wife, the singer and bassist Britta Phillips. Together, theyve spent the last decade or so writing and touring as Dean & Britta. Theyve also been regular collaborators of the director Noah Baumbach, scoring The Squid and the Whale and playing the co-hosts of an awkward dinner party in last years Frances Ha.

title: State Actions on the Minimum Wage
description: President Obamas proposal to increase the federal minimum wage to $10.10 from $7.25 is unlikely to pass through Congress, but several states have been tackling the issue on their own.

title: Deals at Rizzoli, Modani, Pollack and Treillage
description: During Pollacks warehouse sale, through Monday, fabrics including sheers, velvets, silks and embroideries are up to 90 percent off (Peachy upholstery fabric in a color called Carrot Cake, originally $155 a yard, is $20 a yard); 629 Grove Street (16th Street), Jersey City; 212-627-7766, pollackassociates.com.

title: Homes Worth Aspiring To
description: Ron Broadhursts new book The Urban House (Rizzoli, $45), is a sensory splash of 25 pristine dwellings in cities around the world. Nearly half are in New York and 11 were designed by women, including Andre Putman, Annabelle Selldorf and Jeanne Gang. Richard Meier wrote the foreword and is represented by a floor-through white palace in the Sherry-Netherland.

title: Cozy Up to the Campfire With Color and Ease
description: Tae Kim, the founder of Alite Designs, a San Francisco company specializing in stylish camping equipment, had the molded fiberglass chairs of Charles and Ray Eames in mind when he designed Bison ($200). Even the four colors of the new chairs water-resistant removable sling seat (black, Tiburon blue, Presidio green and Jupiter orange) are out of the midcentury-modern playbook. But Bison is nothing if not evolutionary.

title: If Cherry Trees Came with Gold Dust
description: Lindsey Adelmans Cherry Bomb lighting fixtures, to be introduced next week at the Nilufar Gallery in Milan, were inspired by cherry trees she admired in Japan. The lights, which resemble brass vines that creep up walls or across ceilings, are also named after the fireworks that are illegal in many states.

title: Making a Scene, Onstage and Off
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  For years, the crystal chandelier that Eugene Lee salvaged back in the 1980s, when the original Helen Hayes Theater in Times Square was being demolished, presided over Studio 8H at Rockefeller Center, adding a little elegance to the rarefied air around Saturday Night Live cast members like Eddie Murphy and Dennis Miller.

title: Loving Trees, Even the Messy Ones
description: In 1993 Enzo Enea, a landscape architect, bought out his fathers garden ornament business in Switzerland. Today he has nearly 200 employees who have landscaped corporate headquarters, churchyards, rooftop gardens, vacation homes and condominium projects in Miami, where Mr. Enea, 49, has a satellite office. His next Florida project, the Oceana Bal Harbour condominium building, designed by the architect Bernardo Fort-Brescia, is on a 5.5-acre oceanfront site that sits across Collins Avenue from the Bal Harbour Marina and will be home to two giant outdoor Jeff Koons sculptures. (This interview was edited and condensed.)

title: Should I Add Lighting to Closets?
description: Q. My home has deep, dark closets. Should I add lighting to make them more of a selling feature?

title: Ticking and Tocking in Playful Ceramics
description: Heath Ceramics is venturing into wall clocks in partnership with House Industries, a Delaware design firm best known for its vintage-inspired typefaces. Their clock called Stencil features numbers in a newly created font that Andy Cruz, a House Industries founder, said was inspired by 19th-century French stencils, Shaker tin stencils and your standard American G.I. stencil. The Ornament clock has a pattern one might expect to see on a Nordic ski sweater.

title: A Painter Stretches
description: Its hard to believe, but there was a time when being a starving artist in New York could have real estate advantages. Tom Levine is proof.

title: Gathering Moss
description: BREVARD, N.C.  Look up, Mossin Annie Martin told me, look up on the tin roof of the bulimia treatment center. Can you see the rust-green clump waiting to be rescued by a loving hand? Thats Entodon seductrix: what she, and no one else, refers to as shiny, sexy moss.

title: Iraq Veteran at Fort Hood Kills 3 and Himself in Rampage
description: KILLEEN, Tex.  A soldier who was being evaluated for post-traumatic stress disorder opened fire at Fort Hood on Wednesday, killing three people and wounding 16 before killing himself, the authorities said. The shooting set off a huge police response and shut down the sprawling Army base, the same facility where a deadly rampage by an officer resulted in 13 deaths in 2009.

title: Stone Furnishings: Petrified, in a Good Way
description: Gregory Buntain and Ian Collings, partners in the Brooklyn design firm Fort Standard, love materials with a sense of permanence and age: thick white oak, like the wood they use for the oversize legs on their Column tables, for instance, or the rough cast-bronze they chose for their chunky Sprue candelabra.

title: NBC Sports Isnt Paying Elliott to Be on the Bench
description: Josh Elliott joined NBC Sports on Wednesday and compared himself to being the last man on the bench of the Showtime Lakers with the best seat in the house.

title: Mets Fall as Their Pitching Concerns Grow
description: The Mets are often asked what reasons they have to be optimistic. Lately, their unequivocal response has been starting pitching. It is their obvious strength, now and for the future. They consider Matt Harvey, Zack Wheeler, Noah Syndergaard and Rafael Montero precious assets. The Mets plan to be cautious with them, bring them along at the right pace and eventually ride them to relevance.

title: An Illness, Inherited?
description: EDINBURGH  I spent many months, as a fetus, in a mental institution, listening to the world shuffling outside. I dont know what meds were administered to me in that developing stage. I lived in the belly of a woman I would never know. But my relationship with something dubiously entitled mental health was already established.

title: Lofty Newspaper Project Is Closed After Two Years
description: It started as a way to solve one of the thorniest problems in the newspaper industry  how to transition from the high margins yet declining circulation of print to the less profitable but fast-growing readership of the web.

title: New Mexico: Albuquerque Seeks Police Monitoring
description: Mayor Richard J. Berry of Albuquerque asked the Justice Department on Wednesday to monitor the citys police force, roiled by a rash of shootings resulting in 23 deaths and 14 injuries in four years. In a news conference, Mr. Berry also announced plans to certify all of the departments 426 field officers in crisis intervention so they can better handle calls involving people with mental illness, who made up the majority of the victims in the shootings, and implement an evaluation system for the officers. The changes depend on extra funding, as well as approval by the police union and the Justice Department, which has been investigating allegations of civil rights violations by the police for 16 months.

title: Irans Choice for U.N. Post Fuels Tension With U.S.
description: UNITED NATIONS  Six months after President Obama made a groundbreaking telephone call to his Iranian counterpart, Hassan Rouhani, the administration has made clear that expectations of a complete thaw in relations between Iran and the United States are premature.

title: Ex-Contractor Sentenced for Leak to Fox News
description: A federal judge on Wednesday sentenced a former State Department contractor to 13 months in prison for leaking information about North Korea to a Fox News reporter. The former contractor, Stephen J. Kim, pleaded guilty in February in exchange for a deal that would limit his prison time to that duration. Mr. Kim is the sixth person to be convicted under the Obama administration after being accused of leaking information to the public, and two other cases remain open.

title: Updates on the Fort Hood Shooting
description: As our colleagues Manny Fernandez and Ashley Southall report, four people were shot and killed, including the gunman, and 16 others were injured in a shooting at Fort Hood in Texas on Wednesday, stirring memories of a mass shooting at the same base almost five years ago. Authorities said the gunman died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound. The Lede followed media coverage of the event in the first hours after the news broke.

title: E.P.A. Faulted for Failure to Report Risks
description: The Environmental Protection Agency failed to consistently disclose health risks, including possible cancer risks, to research study participants who were exposed to dangerous pollutants, an agency watchdog report has found. An E.P.A. inspector generals report released Wednesday said that when the agency exposed 81 people to soot and diesel exhaust emissions in studies in 2010 and 2011, the risks were not always consistently represented and did not include information on cancer risks associated with long-term exposure. The E.P.A. said risks associated with cancer in the study, which only briefly exposed participants to the pollutants, were so minimal that they were not included on consent forms obtained from the subjects.

title: A Union Aims at Pittsburghs Biggest Employer
description: PITTSBURGH  For decades, United States Steel was this citys dominant employer, but now the biggest employer is the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, with its 22 hospitals and 62,000 workers.

title: Early Warning
description: Someone at the Supreme Court got an assignment last week: start drafting a majority opinion to answer the question whether a for-profit company can claim a religious exemption from the federal requirement to include particular products in any employee insurance plan.

title: Upfront Season Swells as Media Companies Compete for Ads
description: THERE are so many upfront presentations these days, as media companies compete for advertising dollars ahead of the 2014-15 television season, it often seems as if you cant tell the players without a program.

title: Report Finds Hispanics Faring Better Than Blacks
description: Hispanics generally fare better than blacks in rankings of inequality in American life, according to a new report by the National Urban League to be released on Thursday.

title: The Price of a Slur
description: MINNEAPOLIS  THE idea of the Indian giver has always been deeply ironic, since its Indians who have been on the receiving end of some very bad gifts indeed. Last weeks offering from Daniel Snyder, the owner of the Washington Redskins, was only the latest.

title: War and Unrest Provide for a Scarred Campaign Trail in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  There is much about Afghanistans presidential campaigns that Americans would probably find familiar. Chartered jets carry candidates to corners of the country where they would ordinarily never set foot, political operatives try to spin skeptical reporters, and rich men hand over bundles of cash to curry favor with their next potential president.

title: Tax the Childless to Help Parents?
Were Not No. 1! Were Not No. 1!
description: We in the United States grow up celebrating ourselves as the worlds most powerful nation, the worlds richest nation, the worlds freest and most blessed nation.

title: Fake Meats, Finally, Taste Like Chicken
description: Last May, Whole Foods recalled two types of curried chicken salad that had been sold in some of its stores in the Northeast.

title: Health Enrollment Numbers Lift Democratic Hopes
description: WASHINGTON  After months of pummeling by Republicans and with a grim election season approaching, Democrats on Tuesday had a rare bright day. President Obamas announcement that the new health care plan had enrolled 7.1 million Americans coincided with the release by Representative Paul D. Ryan of a new Republican budget that proposes changes in Medicare and deep cuts in spending.

title: Campaign of Resilience
description: Afghans voted in the first election in the nations modern history with the potential to bring a peaceful change of leadership.

title: Surprise! The Rich Won One
description: Today, we are going to discuss the Supreme Court decision on political donations. Already, we have run into a terrible problem, which is the difficulty in having a fun conversation about campaign finance laws.

title: In Florida, Bid to Cut Voter Rolls Is Set Back
description: MIAMI  Gov. Rick Scotts effort to remove voters who are not American citizens from voter registration rolls, a subject of continuing political controversy, has suffered a one-two punch in the past week.

title: Afghan Candidates Make Final Pitches
description: Before Saturdays presidential election, Afghan candidates campaigned under tight security amid worries of violence and voter fraud.

title: Washingtonians Get to Know Democrat They Picked Over the Mayor
description: WASHINGTON  Four days before the vote, a worker hurrying into the Anacostia Metro station during the morning rush said he was unhappy with Mayor Vincent C. Gray and would vote for his leading rival. I kind of like that one, he said, fumbling for a name. The lady. Shes real good.

title: The Court Follows the Money
description: The Supreme Court on Wednesday continued its crusade to knock down all barriers to the distorting power of money on American elections. In the courts most significant campaign-finance ruling since Citizens United in 2010, five justices voted to eliminate sensible and long-established contribution limits to federal political campaigns. Listening to their reasoning, one could almost imagine that the case was simply about the freedom of speech in the context of elections.

title: At Trial, Queens Doctor Is Accused of Recklessly Prescribing Drugs
description: One patient was found dead in his bed from an overdose, with a prescription for painkillers from a Queens doctor on the night stand. Another was discovered lifeless and slumped over in his car, a pill bottle naming the same doctor under his body.

title: Measuring the Success of Health Reform
description: More than seven million people have signed up for insurance on the new federal and state health exchanges, President Obama said this week. Millions more could be added to that total once insurers tally up the people who bought policies directly from them and when those who tried to apply on balky websites are able to complete the process.

title: Whats Next for Health Care
description: WASHINGTON  The first open enrollment period for health insurance under the Affordable Care Act has just ended, and consumers, insurers and federal officials now face many immediate chores and challenges that will help determine if the law works as intended.

title: NASA Breaks Most Contact With Russia
description: NASA said Wednesday that it was suspending most contacts with Russian space agency officials, underscoring just how rapidly the Russian-American relationship is deteriorating in the wake of the Kremlins annexation of Crimea and hinting at further ramifications that will go beyond previous rifts.

title: Risky Games in the South China Sea
description: Undaunted by Chinas aggressive rhetoric and expansionist claims to nearly all of the South China Sea, the Philippines has filed a legal case against Beijing with an international arbitration tribunal in The Hague. This is an appropriate venue to resolve a major dispute peacefully and in accord with global norms. The strategy of the Philippines has implications for others with similar claims against China  Vietnam, Malaysia, Brunei and Taiwan  and thus deserves support from the international community.

title: As He Cultivates a Star Prospect, Ovechkin Shows His Own Growth
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  A banner that hangs from a balcony overlooking the ice at the Washington Capitals practice complex here reads, Congrats Evgeny  1st NHL Goal.

title: Medicare to Share Information on Pay for Physicians
description: Medicare said on Wednesday that it planned to make available to consumers and others detailed information on what it pays individual physicians as soon as next week, despite the long-term resistance by the American Medical Association and other groups. The information will include data on the $77 billion paid by Medicare in 2012 to more than 880,000 health care professionals for 6,000 types of services and procedures. Patient information will remain private. Data like these can shine a light on how care is delivered in the Medicare program, said Jonathan Blum, principal deputy administrator at the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, in a blog post. They can help consumers compare the services provided and payments received by individual health care providers. Businesses and consumers alike can use these data to drive decision-making and reward quality, cost-effective care. Medicare, the federal insurance program for the elderly, was prevented from releasing information on individual physicians until a ruling last year by a federal judge in Florida. In a statement issued by the A.M.A., the medical group raised concerns that Medicares broad release of the payment information could mislead the public and recommended that doctors be allowed to review and correct any information before it was made public.

He knew his fellow Berliner Niels Giffey and had played on a club team with the brother of another German player on the roster, Enosch Wolf, but relating to his peers from Brooklyn or Chicago was a new experience.

title: In Bullet-Ridden Afghan Districts, Free Vote Seems an Empty Promise
description: CHARKH, Afghanistan  One of the few polling centers in this part of Logar Province is the governments district headquarters, a building so devastated by rocket attacks and Taliban gunfire that it looks more like a bomb shelter than an administrative office.

title: True to Kentucky, a Fan Base Wields Its Own Megaphone
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Kentucky lost to a middling Arkansas team at home on Feb. 27 and, two days later, fell on the road to lowly South Carolina. The preseason No. 1 team in the country, the Wildcats were 21-8, and they soon dropped out of the top 25.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 2, 2014
description: April 2, 2014

title: Facing the Skepticism in Adoption, in Qatar and in the U.S.
description: In the United States, when others voice their confusion about why parents adopt, it is simple enough to smile and ignore it. In other cultures, that gap in understanding may not be so easily handled. I read the story of Matthew and Grace Huang, the Los Angeles couple sentenced last week in Qatar to three years in prison after being found guilty of killing their 8-year-old adopted daughter, with familiar sorrow. In January 2013, the Huangs rushed their daughter, Gloria, to a hospital in Qatar, where they lived with their three African-born children. After her death, the couple was arrested and accused of withholding food and water from the girl for four days, which they deny.

title: Bringing Big Money Out of the Shadows
description: Once again, a narrow majority of the Supreme Court has knocked down a campaign finance limit, and, once again, court watchers have gone ballistic. Yet for those who worry about the polarizing effect of money on politics, the McCutcheon decision gives us a little hope. A world in which individuals can give limited, disclosed amounts of money to an unlimited number of politicians is preferable to one in which large chunks are given only to super PACs and other unaccountable outside groups.

title: How Not to Enforce Campaign Laws
description: WASHINGTON  THE Federal Election Commission is failing to enforce the nations campaign finance laws. Im in a position to know. Im the vice chairwoman of the commission.

title: Chorus Starter
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Oh, this one hits my sweet spot. Perhaps a bit easy for a Thursday, but the theme highlights one of my favorite songs by David Bowie, CH-CH-CH-CH-CHANGES. But thats not all.

title: A Doctor, and a Conflicted Soldier
description: Over time, Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan grew more religious and more outspoken against the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, according to relatives and acquaintances.

title: Cuomo Drops Plan to Use State Money to Pay for College Classes for Inmates
description: In an important speech at a gathering of black and Latino lawmakers in February, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo unveiled what he billed as a bold plan to attack the problem of high rates of recidivism: The state would pay for college classes for prison inmates.

title: A Student of the Game, on the Golf Course and Off
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  The week of the Founders Cup in Arizona, Karrie Webb sat for an interview with filmmakers for a feature-length documentary on the 13 women who started the Ladies Professional Golf Association. The project intrigued Webb, a seven-time winner of major tournaments and a World Golf Hall of Fame member whose excellence in the game is surpassed only by her encyclopedic knowledge of its history.

title: Greece: Immunity Lifted for Lawmakers
description: As part of a widening effort to clamp down on the activities of Golden Dawn, a party widely condemned as neo-Nazi and violent, Greeces Parliament on Wednesday voted to lift the immunity of another four of the partys lawmakers so they can face trial on charges of setting up a criminal organization. Of the partys 16 legislators, 13 now face prosecution. Meanwhile, in a potentially serious blow to the coalition of Prime Minister Antonis Samaras, a close aide to Mr. Samaras resigned after a video posted online appeared to show him accusing the prime minister of influencing an investigation into Golden Dawn in order to gain votes. In a note announcing his resignation on Wednesday, the aide, Panagiotis Baltakos, said he made the comments, which were secretly recorded, to relieve pressure on him by Golden Dawn. He said the party officials had accused him of conspiring against the party.

title: Israel: Foreign Ministry Strike Ends
description: Employees of Israels Foreign Ministry on Wednesday announced the end of a general strike over pay and working conditions that had shut down the ministrys offices and the countrys 103 missions abroad for more than a week. The labor dispute disrupted visits of Israeli officials abroad and visits of foreign dignitaries to Israel and left hundreds of Israelis who had passport problems stranded in foreign countries. It ended with the signing of a document of principles that will serve as the basis of an agreement pledging an improvement in conditions, including financial incentives for diplomats serving abroad in countries considered hardship postings.

title: China Extends Tax Break Program to Spur Economy
description: HONG KONG  The Chinese government on Wednesday announced a modest package of economic stimulus measures, the latest sign of concern by Beijing that growth may be slowing more than expected.

title: Woman Mauled by Chimp Cant Sue Connecticut
description: A woman who was mauled and blinded by a 200-pound chimpanzee in 2009 will not be able to sue the State of Connecticut, a legislative judiciary committee in Hartford ruled on Wednesday.

title: Japan Says It Will Abide by Whaling Ruling
description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said on Wednesday that he would comply with an international court order to halt Japanese whale hunts off Antarctica. Separately, officials in the Agriculture and Fishing Ministry said Japan would cancel that annual hunt in the Southern Ocean this year, which had been conducted within a loophole in a moratorium on commercial whaling that allowed killing for research purposes. However, the ministry left open the possibility that it might restart the hunt in the future under a different legal reasoning. The international courts ruling said that the scientific output from Japans whaling program to date appears limited and suggested that the hunt was continued because of politics and logistics, rather than science.

title: Playing Like a Playoff Team, the Knicks Move Into Eighth
description: Madison Square Garden has been the site of so much sadness this season. So much flimsy defense. So much losing. So many boos.

title: On the First Stop of a Farewell Tour, Jeter Does a Ceremony in a Flash
description: HOUSTON  As Derek Jeter stepped into the batters box Wednesday evening, the members of the Houston Astros who were not on the field emerged from their dugout and applauded him in the first of what will surely be many gestures by opposing teams to honor him throughout the season. Jeter has announced that this will be his final season, and most teams are expected to honor him during pregame ceremonies.

title: De Blasio Naming Ex-Banker as Economic Development Corp. Chairman
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio has a complicated relationship with New York Citys business elite, many of whom view his populist agenda with skepticism and, in some cases, disdain.

title: Deposed Ukrainian Leader Calls Crimea Annexation a Tragedy
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Viktor F. Yanukovych, the deposed president of Ukraine, called Russias annexation of Crimea a tragedy on Wednesday and said he would try to negotiate the regions return from President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

description: Shortly after the first group of Washington Nationals finished batting practice, Manager Matt Williams casually asked outfielder Bryce Harper if he was feeling well. Harper nodded and continued running into the dugout.

description: A worker died after he fell onto scaffolding at the Dream New York hotel in Midtown Manhattan on Wednesday, the police said.

description: A contractor revamping New York Citys 911 system billed the city $147 an hour for tasks that included opening an office door and having a large bug killed in the bathroom. A company hired to build an online procurement system for school principals bolstered profits by hiring low-paid programmers in India and Turkey, though it was supposed to employ only New Yorkers.

title: After Jeter Is Honored, Yankees Suffer Indignity: Another Loss to Astros
description: HOUSTON  As Derek Jeter stepped into the batters box in the first inning at Minute Maid Park on Wednesday, the members of the Houston Astros not on the field emerged from their dugout and applauded him in the first of what is destined to be many gestures of homage by opposing teams throughout the season.

title: Whats on Thursday
description: 6:15 P.M. (MoreMax) MUNICH (2005) Steven Spielberg ventures beyond this storys historical impetus  the 1972 Olympics, at which 11 Israeli athletes and coaches were killed by members of a Palestinian group known as Black September  to create a philosophical thriller about its aftermath: Israels apparent campaign of vengeance, using five agents who crisscrossed Europe to hunt suspects for years. Eric Bana portrays the films moral center, a former Mossad agent sent on a mission to eliminate those responsible for the deaths. Daniel Craig, Ciaran Hinds, Hanns Zischler and Mathieu Kassovitz (above left with Mr. Zischler) play his team. Tony Kushner and Eric Roth wrote the screenplay, based on a book by George Jonas. An unsparingly brutal look at two peoples all but drowning in a sea of their own blood, Munich is by far the toughest film of the directors career and the most anguished, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. But more than anything, she added, Munich is a slammin entertainment filled with dazzling set pieces and geometric camerawork.

title: Mon Levinson, 88, Op Art Sculptor, Dies
description: Mon Levinson, who used plexiglass and other nontraditional materials in becoming a prominent Op Art sculptor, creating work that actively affects the viewers perception, died on March 25 in Manhattan. He was 88.

title: Cuomo Played Pivotal Role in Charter School Push
description: It was a frigid February day in Albany, and leaders of New York Citys charter school movement were anxious. They had gone to the capital to court lawmakers, but despite a boisterous showing by parents, there seemed to be little clarity about the future of their schools.

title: Priscilla Morgan, Cultural Matchmaker, Dies at 94
description: Priscilla Morgan, a doyenne of international culture, longtime official of the Spoleto arts festival and all-around facilitator for artists of many stripes  including the painter Willem de Kooning, the theater composer Jerry Herman and the sculptor and designer Isamu Noguchi, who was also her longtime romantic partner  died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 94.

title: Zoo Teams Up to Highlight Animal Mistreatment at Shows
description: A mace-wielding clown lashes at a bear cub. An elephant stands on its rear legs on the point of a stun gun, electric arcs running through its body.

title: Japan Cancels Whale Hunt Off Antarctica After Ruling
description: TOKYO  Japan has canceled this years whale hunt off Antarctica, just days after an international court ruled against the killings, which had drawn worldwide criticism.

As a person who was officially classified as poor, he knew to use the Mukhyamantri Amrutum Yojana, Gujarats state health insurance plan, when seeking care at the government V.S. Hospital here.

title: Hunt for Jets Black Boxes Is a Race Against Time
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  With only a few days left before the batteries on the data and voice recorders of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 are set to die, a multinational search force resumed its hunt on Thursday with 10 aircraft and nine ships sweeping a patch of the Indian Ocean about 1,050 miles west of Perth, Australia, and a British nuclear submarine preparing to join the hunt.

title: Chinese Tech Company Kingsoft Seeks U.S. Listing for Mobile Subsidiary
description: HONG KONG  The latest Chinese technology company to seek a stock market listing in the United States comes with heavyweight backers and is a rare attempt at an offering by a parent company already listed in Hong Kong.

title: China Leans Toward More Stimulus Measures
description: HONG KONG  Chinas leaders are issuing increasingly clear signals that they plan another round of economic stimulus programs, as evidence accumulates that the economy is slowing more than expected this year.

title: Israel Halts Prisoner Release as Talks Hit Impasse
description: ALGIERS  Israel said on Thursday that it would not go through with an already delayed release of Palestinian prisoners and was considering further sanctions against the Palestinians as the threat to the peace talks deepened further despite Secretary of State John Kerrys concerted efforts to keep the process alive.

title: Pakistani Ex-Leader Narrowly Misses Blast
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A bomb apparently directed at Pervez Musharraf, the former Pakistani military ruler, went off early Thursday, minutes after his convoy had passed an intersection in Islamabad, the capital, police officials said.

title: Out of Work, Out of Benefits, and Running Out of Options
description: BOSTON  Abe Gorelick has decades of marketing experience, an extensive contact list, an Ivy League undergraduate degree, a masters in business from the University of Chicago, ideas about how to reach consumers young and old, experience working with businesses from start-ups to huge financial firms and an upbeat, effervescent way about him. What he does not have  and has not had for the last year  is a full-time job.

title: The Campaigns for Kabul
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Most politicians homes I have visited here are heavy on fake gilt and rococo furniture, but Ashraf Ghani, one of the leading candidates in Saturdays presidential election, is known as a technocrat and a sophisticate. Its a beautiful house, I said, looking around at the exquisite Nuristani carved chests and Persian miniature paintings that decorated his living room. It is, replied Naseem Sharifi, one of Mr. Ghanis campaign managers, beaming. Then he frowned. The other day, they collected three or four kilos of human flesh off the roof.

title: TV Duel in Britain Is Seen to Favor Anti-European Party
description: LONDON  Heated and sometimes ill-tempered exchanges in the second of two television debates about whether Britain should leave the 28-nation European Union were judged on Thursday to have favored the United Kingdom Independence Party, further polarizing Britains discussion on the matter.

title: Ukraine Implicates Ex-President and Russia in Protesters Deaths
description: KIEV, Ukraine  The Ukrainian authorities said Thursday that former President Viktor F. Yanukovych and Russian security agents were involved in plans for elite police units to open fire on antigovernment protesters in February, killing more than 100 people in the days immediately before the downfall of his government.

title: Investcorp Joins Rush to Invest in European Distressed Debt
description: Investcorp, an investment firm based in Bahrain, made a splash investing in European luxury brands like Gucci and George Jensen.

title: The Founder of Reputation.com Answers Reader Questions
description: Last week, The Times publisheda conversation with Michael Fertik, who foundedReputation.com, a reputation management company that helps businesses and people play down their negative search results, protect their personal information, gather positive reviews for their businesses and in general buff their images online.

title: From Online News Alert to the Front Page
description: Editors of The Times meet every morning at 10 for about a half-hour to discuss the days news. On some days there is more news than others.

title: Daily Report: Amazons Fire TV Is a Bid to Take Over the Living Room
description: The streaming media device that Amazon began selling on Wednesday, Fire TV, is part of the companys multibillion-dollar effort to move from selling goods produced by others, which is traditionally a low-margin business, to presiding over the entire process of creation and consumption, David Streitfeld reports. Physical formats such as books, CDs and DVDs are disappearing, replaced by downloads and streaming.

title: 2 Women Are Kidnapped From a Resort in Malaysia
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  Gunmen kidnapped a Chinese tourist and a Filipino hotel worker, both women, from a beach resort on an island off the coast of Malaysian Borneo, the Chinese and Malaysian authorities said Thursday, spurring an international manhunt.

title: Missing Some Stars, Davis Cup Has Plenty of Sparkle
description: The tennis band still known as the Big Four is split in two this week. Roger Federer and Andy Murray are playing in the Davis Cup quarterfinals, while Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic are resting for the clay-court tussles soon to come.

title: Qualcomm Muscles Up in the Home
description: The airwaves are getting too crowded  in your living room. By treating the home the way it treats outdoor cellphone networks, Qualcomm hopes to make big business from your problem.

title: Imgur, the Image-Sharing Site, Raises $40 Million From Andreessen Horowitz
description: If you spend any measurable amount of time on the Internet, youve likely visited  or at least looked at  an image hosted on Imgur (pronounced image-er).

title: Shadows Over Citigroup
description: Federal authorities have opened a criminal investigation into a recent $400 million fraud involving Citigroups Mexican unit, according to people briefed on the matter, one of a handful of government inquiries looming over the giant bank, Ben Protess and Michael Corkery write in DealBook. The investigation, overseen by the F.B.I. and prosecutors from the United States attorneys office in Manhattan, is focusing in part on whether holes in the banks internal controls contributed to the fraud in Mexico.

title: E.U. Lawmakers Approve Tough Net Neutrality Rules
description: LONDON  European lawmakers approved new rules on Thursday aimed at guaranteeing equal access to the Internet and cutting cellphone charges across the 28-member European Union.

title: European Central Bank Hints at Bond-Buying Program
description: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank gave its strongest signal yet that it was considering action to stimulate the euro zone economy. But the bank immediately faced criticism that talk of large-scale bond purchases  the same method used by the Federal Reserve to help restart the United States economy  was little more than a bluff.

title: Political Cacophony Challenges Musicians
description: On Feb. 12, the charismatic Venezuelan conductor Gustavo Dudamel led a youth orchestra in Caracas to celebrate the 39th anniversary of El Sistema, the government-supported program that has organized hundreds of thousands of children across Venezuela into instrumental ensembles, serving as a model of using music education for social uplift. As the performance was underway, a crackdown on peaceful demonstrations was being enforced in the streets. People were protesting the policies of President Nicols Maduros government, along with the pervasive crime, crippling inflation and scarcities that plague Venezuela today.

title: Chasing the Money for Families of Passengers on Missing Flight
description: Growing up in Peru in the 1970s, Monica R. Kelly, who specializes in aviation accidents, dreamed of becoming a diplomat and traveling the world.

title: India Ranks 102nd on Social Development Index
description: NEW DELHI As the worlds largest democracy heads to the polls in less than a week, and as politicians vying for a governing coalition tout their plans for economic and social development, a report published by an American nonprofit shows that India performs poorly on a range of social development indicators, ranking 102nd among the 132 countries surveyed.

title: Player Ratings: United States (2) vs. Mexico (2)
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  In its final exhibition game before the opening of next months World Cup training camp, the United States national team played to a 2-2 draw with arch-rival Mexico on Wednesday night before a pro-Mexico crowd at the University of Phoenix Stadium.

title: Fort Hood Gunman Was Being Treated for Depression
description: KILLEEN, Tex.  The commanding general of Fort Hood said on Thursday that the soldier who killed three people and wounded 16 others during a shooting the previous day might have argued with at least one other soldier shortly before the attack.

title: As Narendra Modi Rises, His Grip Over His Party Tightens
description: NEW DELHI  On Monday, Lal Krishna Advani, the doyen and one of the founders of Indias opposition Bharatiya Janata Party, spoke at a rally in the western Indian state of Maharashtra. Mr. Advani observed that Narendra Modi, the partys prime ministerial candidate and thrice-elected chief minister of Gujarat, was not the only one who has scored a hat trick in elections.

title: Liberty Media Will Sell Most of Its Investment in Barnes & Noble
description: Updated, 7:55 p.m. | Nearly three years ago, Liberty Media had grand ambitions to acquire Barnes & Noble, before settling for a big stake. Now it appears that the media conglomerate has had enough.

title: Air and Space Museums Main Hall to Be Renovated and Renamed
description: The Smithsonians National Air and Space Museum in Washington is overhauling its central exhibition space with the help of a $30 million donation from the Boeing Company. This main hall, now called Milestones of Flight, is currently home to the superstars of aviation and spaceflight history like the Wright Brothers plane, the 1903 Wright Flyer; Charles Lindberghs Spirit of St. Louis; and John Glenns Mercury capsule, Friendship 7.

description: Simon Wren-Lewis asks,

title: Research on Children and Math: Underestimated and Unchallenged
description: We hear a lot about how American students lag behind their international peers academically, especially in subjects like math. In the most recent Program for International Student Assessment, commonly known as PISA, students in the United States ranked 26th out of 34 countries in mathematics. On the surface, it would seem that were a nation of math dullards; simply no good at the subject. But a spate of new research suggests that we may be underestimating our students, especially the youngest ones, in terms of their ability to think about numbers.

title: Brookstone Files for Bankruptcy and Plans to Sell Itself
description: Brookstone, the struggling retailer known for its consumer gadgets, massage chairs and other home furnishings, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Thursday, with plans to sell itself to the owner of the Spencers retail chain for about $147 million.

title: The Fifth Freedom
description: Never mind freedom of speech, freedom of religion, freedom from want, freedom from fear. What Americas embattled billionaires are demanding, as their birthright (and I mean that pretty much literally), is something much more important: freedom from criticism. Making a desperate stand in the maquis the Wall Street Journal, heroic, oppressed men like Tom Perkins and now Charles Koch have been telling it like it is: anyone who says anything negative about them is just like the Nazis, or maybe Stalin.

title: Yorgen Edholm of Accellion, on the Motivation of Passion
description: This interview with Yorgen Edholm, chief executive of Accellion, a developer of software for mobile file sharing, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Obama on Fort Hood Shooting
description: The president delivered a statement on Wednesday following a shooting at Fort Hood.

title: On Beauty | The Poetry of Powder
description: As women have known for centuries, theres a kind of magic behind something so fine and so fleeting.

title: Poetry Pairing | Paschal
description: This weeks Poetry Pairing features Paschal by Robert Pinsky and the article Put Yourself in the Story of Passover by Edward Rothstein.

title: Hand-Held Treatment for Overdoses Is Approved
description: Federal health regulators approved a drug overdose treatment device on Thursday that experts say will provide a powerful lifesaving tool in the midst of a surging epidemic of prescription drug abuse. Similar to an EpiPen used to stop allergic reactions to bee stings, the easy-to-use injector  small enough to tuck into a pocket or a medicine cabinet  can be used by the relatives or friends of people who have overdosed.

title: Kerry Pushes Leaders on Peace Talks
description: Secretary of State John Kerry delivered a pointed warning on Thursday to Israeli and Palestinian leaders, saying they must lead if they want to preserve the chances for a historic Middle East peace.

title: From Lao Tzu to Layups, 1,682 Pages of Phil Jackson
description: Sometimes he sounds like Paulo Coelho: Before me, I saw forever, nothing and everything  mountain ranges, canyons, sagebrush, the simple life at last. Elsewhere he channels Bram Stoker: The basketball gods can sometimes be most cruel.

title: The Phil Jackson Bookshelf
description: Maverick

title: Times Minute | Afghan Elections Preview
description: Today on the Minute, a preview of the presidential elections taking place in Afghanistan on Saturday.

title: Times Minute | Afghan Elections
description: In the Video

title: This Time, Jim Jarmusch Is Kissing Vampires
description: The filmmaker Jim Jarmusch is old school. He writes all his scripts out by hand and then dictates them to a typist. Ideas are jotted down in small, color-coordinated notebooks and, despite the presence of an iPad and iPhone in his life, he doesnt have email. I dont have enough time as it is to read a book or make music, or see my friends, he said. People dont believe me, too. They think Im just saying that because I dont want to give it to them. But no, I do not have email.

title: Today in Small Business: What to Pay Yourself
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: The Hospital-Dependent Patient
description: Hes back? my colleague asked, eyes widening as she passed the patients room. Hes in the hospital again?

title: Co-Stars Again, but Hardly Strangers
description: It was love at first rehearsal, or so the story goes. In the spring of 2000, Megan Mullally, then at the start of her fame as the acerbic millionairess Karen Walker on the sitcom Will & Grace, was kicking off her hiatus from the TV season in an unlikely venue: a sawdust-floored warehouse near downtown Los Angeles, where the Evidence Room, a theater company, was opening a cavernous new space with an ambitious staging of Charles L. Mees Berlin Circle.

title: D.I.Y. Accountability
description: Here is the story so far on the Central Intelligence Agencys interrogation program: The C.I.A. illegally detained terrorism suspects, tortured and abused them at secret prisons, denied that it was happening and then destroyed videotaped evidence. It misled lawmakers about what happened, stonewalled Congressional inquiries, withheld the results of its own investigation from Congress, and interfered in various ways with a Senate probe  even breaking into Senate staffers computers and deleting files.

title: New Jerseys Largest Newspaper Announces Big Staff Cuts in Reorganization
description: The Star-Ledger of Newark, New Jerseys biggest newspaper by print circulation and among the largest in the nation, announced on Thursday that it would cut 167 jobs, including 40 newsroom positions.

title: The Second Issue of a Truly Great International Magazine
description: Read all about it! The second issue of ZEITmagazin  the Berlin State of Mind is out today. Culling a half-years worth of editorial highlights from ZEITmagazin  which comes out with Die Zeit, Germanys biggest weekly newspaper  the semiannual journal of culture, politics and art has a print run of 10,000 and is available in just about any international city where you can get an Uber. With a 28-page spread of Instagram photos curatedby Ai Weiwei and pictures of surreal Tuscan food taken by Juergen Teller, the Teutonic glossy clocks in at 260 pages. Michael Douglas talks post-cancer life and of an adolescent encounter with Liberace; Franois Hollande and Angela Merkel take to bed with a plate full of pretzels; and a cadre of stars including Boy George, Juliette Binoche and Stephen King recount their dreams. Photographic subjects run the gamut from Berlin teenagers to Brad Pitt to a Chinese burial ritual. Ja, bitte.

title: Letters: Among the Bombed
description: Among the Bombed

title: Behind the Cover Story: Michael Lewis on Complexity and the Rigging of Wall Street
description: This weeks cover story is an adaptation from Michael Lewiss new book, Flash Boys: A Wall Street Revolt. Lewis is the author of several books about financial markets, including Boomerang and The Big Short.

title: A Vacant Chair for Blythe Masters
description: Blythe Masterss exit from JPMorgan Chase with the sale of its physical commodities business could solve Glencores longstanding search for a chairman.

title: Elephants and Pajamas: Its the Marxfest of Course
description: An excuse for a festival devoted to the Marx Brothers should probably not be necessary. But a group of Marxophiles (they were going to call themselves Marxists, but they thought better of it, a spokesman said) have banded together to present Marxfest, an eclectic series of screenings, talks, concerts and events of other sorts (a trip to the Bronx Zoo to look at elephants, for example), to be presented from May 1 to 31 at sites all over New York City. And they have an occasion to commemorate: 2014 is apparently the centenary of the poker game at which the comedian Art Fisher coined the nicknames by which the brothers became known  Groucho, Harpo, Chico and, in those days, Gummo, who was soon replaced in the family act by Zeppo.

title: An Artist on His First Exhibit: Wow, George Bush Is a Painter
description: WASHINGTON  If George W. Bush, budding artist, has learned one lesson about his newfound passion, it is this: Dont paint your wife.

title: TV Fandom in Red, Bad and Blue
description: In the latest New Yorker, Emily Nussbaum has a provocative piece linking the phenomenon shes dubbed the bad fan  the kind of prestige-TV viewer inclined to justify every crime their favorite TV anti-hero commits, to explain that Walter Whites shrew of a wife just doesnt appreciate him, to gripe that The Sopranos featured too many dreams and not enough whackings, etc.  to an earlier era of television controversy, and the famous case of Archie Bunker:

title: Image of the Day: April 3
South Sudan Urgently Needs Help to Stave Off Famine, U.N. Warns
description: GENEVA  South Sudan needs $230 million in international aid in the next 60 days or it will face the worst starvation in Africa since the 1980s, when hundreds of thousands of people died in Ethiopias famine, the United Nations official coordinating humanitarian aid in South Sudan warned on Thursday.

title: I Refuse to Be Busy
description: Im not busy.

title: MF Global Customers to Be Paid Back in Full
description: Ever since the collapse of MF Global, the search for $1 billion of the brokerage firms customer money evoked one ominous metaphor after another, including uphill battle and magical mystery tour.

title: Jeremy Stein to Resign From Fed Board to Return to Harvard
description: WASHINGTON  Jeremy C. Stein, a member of the Federal Reserves board who has raised concerns about its stimulus campaign, will resign at the end of May and return to his previous role at Harvard.

title: Pimcos Gross, Facing Skeptical Investors, Discusses His Dead Cat
description: William H. Gross, the founder of the giant asset manager Pimco, is contending with skeptical investors and a choppy bond market, not to mention a stream of negative publicity after the resignation of his heir apparent.

title: Industrial Revolution
description: Tucked behind the citys rail yards, the many charms of Milans burgeoning Isola neighborhood are little known, even to the most design-savvy locals.

title: Britain Shows Support for Tougher Cigarette Laws
description: LONDON  The British government took a step Thursday toward imposing a ban on branding for cigarette packs, indicating that it was likely to go ahead with sweeping new restrictions on the marketing of tobacco.

title: The Gun Report: April 3, 2014
description: For the second time in five years, there has been a mass shooting at the Fort Hood military base in Killeen, Tex. In 2009, in what some consider an act of terrorism, Nidal Malik Hasan, a U.S. Army Major and psychiatrist, opened fire, killing thirteen people and wounding thirty others. Yesterday, after a dispute with another soldier, Specialist Ivan Lopez, 34, a National Guardsman, opened fire in two locations, killing three people and wounding 16 others. When a soldier confronted him, he shot and killed himself.

title: Money, Voting and the Meaning of First Sentences
description: Amid all the recriminations and counter-recriminations that follow a very controversial Supreme Court ruling, it can help to step back and get a little perspective.

title: A Sisterhood of the Snow in Alaska
description: The loud, industrial buzz of the helicopter dulled down to a steady purr through my thick headphones. Wedged tightly between three seatmates in the back of the AStar, I was outwardly calm, but inwardly I was having an Oh, my God, I cant believe Im actually doing this moment. We were being shuttled to a remote spot among the seemingly endless peaks of the Chugach Mountains in southeast Alaska where, ultimately, nine of us, all women, would click into fat powder skis or strap into snowboards for descents wed been dreaming about all winter. Ranging in age from early 30s to mid-40s, we had come together to Valdez for this ultimate bucket-list ski trip.

title: Hotel Review: Refinery Hotel in Manhattan
description: Rates

title: Restaurant Report: Xiao Bao Biscuit in Charleston, S.C.
description: Though only two miles from tourist-trodden Charleston, with its colonnaded mansions and crab cakes, Xiao Bao Biscuit feels airdropped in from the bustling streets of Asia  perhaps with a stopover in Brooklyn.

title: Will Durants Lost Final Book to Be Published
description: Will and Ariel Durants 11-part series, The Story of Civilization, published between 1935 and 1975, sold millions of copies and turned the couple into household names (though Ariel was not credited as a coauthor until Volume 7).

title: In the Keys, New Plans for an Old Bridge
description: In the Florida Keys, the Old Seven Mile Bridge has been given new life in the form of a $77 million restoration program, approved in late March.

title: Under Icy Surface of a Saturn Moon Lies a Sea of Water, Scientists Say
description: Inside a moon of Saturn, beneath its icy veneer and above its rocky core, is a sea of water the size of Lake Superior, scientists announced on Thursday.

title: Salsa, Flirting With Bok Choy
description: Who seeks nuance in a side of rice and beans? Yet here it is at Lucky Luna, the rice faintly marine from an overnight soak and simmer in a broth of kombu and shiitake stems. The beans, too, are not the usual congealing muddle, but discrete drops of heirloom yellow-eyes, scented with coriander.

title: Soldiers Attack at Base Echoed Rampage in 2009
description: KILLEEN, Tex.  In the aftermath of a deadly rampage at Fort Hood here in November 2009 that left 13 people dead, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates announced a Pentagon review of the shooting to help ensure, he said, that nothing like this ever happens again.

title: Turkey Lifts Twitter Ban After Court Calls It Illegal
description: ISTANBUL  The Turkish government unblocked Twitter on Thursday, a day after the countrys highest court ruled that the two-week ban on the social media site violated freedom of expression.

title: Rulings Breadth Hints That More Campaign Finance Dominoes May Fall
description: WASHINGTON  The sweeping language and logic of Wednesdays Supreme Court decision on campaign finance may imperil other legal restrictions on money in politics.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Under the Skin
description: Jonathan Glazer narrates a sequence from his film.

title: The Repercussions
description: (This book was selected as one of The New York Times Book Reviews 10 Best Books of 2014. For the rest of the list, click here.)

title: Epic Fail
description: Books about failure put both their authors and their readers in awkward positions. Writers are at pains to abase themselves somewhat, to show that they know the terrain by sacrificing some dignity without losing all credibility. Many readers, meanwhile, may be willing to ponder how they fail or why they fear it, but few will pick up a book for people who think of themselves as failures. Add to this the fact that all books fail to be everything their authors hoped and that almost all books fail to sell, and it becomes clear why books about failure remain few and far between.

title: The Case Against Savings Accounts (but Not Savings)
description: My 8-year-old daughter saves money in a jar in her bedroom. As her goals got bigger (and relatives started giving her money for birthdays and holidays), I wondered whether it was time for her to have an actual savings account at a real bank or credit union.

title: U.N. and Syrians on Refugees in Lebanon
description: Amid a flood of Syrian war refugees, Lebanon now has the highest concentration of refugees as a percentage of population in the world.

title: Jazz Festival to Honor Eric Dolphy
description: Fifty years after his death, the multi-instrumentalist and composer Eric Dolphy, one of the most original improvisers and composers in the history of jazz, will have a major two-day festival in his honor. Eric Dolphy: Freedom of Sound will take place at Montclair State University in Montclair, N.J., on May 30 and 31; the festival was announced this week by Seed Artists, its producer.

title: Lebanon Hosts Over a Million Who Fled Syria, U.N. Reports
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The number of registered Syrian war refugees who have flooded into Lebanon exceeded one million on Thursday, the United Nations said, describing it as a devastating milestone in a humanitarian crisis that has overwhelmed this small country and severely taxed the ability of the government and aid organizations.

title: Amid Cheers, Union Bid Stirs Concern for Women
description: Gary Blair, who coached Texas A&M to a national basketball title in 2011, was asked recently about how unionization of college athletes might affect womens sports.

title: New York City Can Block Religious Services in Public Schools, Appeals Court Says
description: A federal appeals panel ruled on Thursday that New York City can bar religious groups from holding services in school buildings, reversing a lower-court decision.

title: Talk of Freeing a Spy for Israel Stirs Old Unease for U.S. Jews
description: WASHINGTON  Each year, just before Passover, Malcolm Hoenlein writes a letter to President Obama requesting that he grant clemency to Jonathan J. Pollard, the American sentenced to life in prison in 1987 for passing suitcases stuffed with classified documents to Israel.

title: First Blush
description: The edges of modern design are softening this season with delicate hues in the palest of pinks.

title: Senate Panel Votes to Reveal Report on C.I.A. Interrogations
description: WASHINGTON  The public will soon get its first look at a voluminous report on the C.I.A.s detention and interrogation practices during the George W. Bush administration, after the Senate Intelligence Committee voted on Thursday to declassify key sections of it.

title: Bryan Cranston to Write Memoir of His Breaking Bad Years
description: Bryan Cranston, the veteran actor and celebrated star of Breaking Bad, has agreed to write a memoir of his life and work, his publisher said on Thursday.

title: Officials on Base Shooting
description: The secretary of the Army, John M. McHugh, and the White House press secretary, Jay Carney, provided some detail about the soldier accused of killing three people at Fort Hood on Wednesday.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of Under the Skin
description: In this video, the director Jonathan Glazer narrates a sequence from his film Under the Skin, about a predatory extraterrestrial played by Scarlett Johansson. In this sequence, that character walks down a street in Glasgow where she trips and falls. The sequence was shot with hidden cameras on a street in Glasgow, Scotland. A photo that was snapped during one of the takes eventually became a meme last fall. Here, Mr. Glazer discusses his ideas behind the scene and how it came together.

title: Jack White Plans to Record and Produce a Single on Record Store Day
description: Record Store Day  April 19, this year  has typically brought stacks of collectible rarities and limited-edition pressings, made available just for the day, usually on vinyl only, and only at physical record stores, an endangered species these days. Collectors snap these discs up, and so do speculators: it often seems as if most items find their way to eBay before the day is out.

title: Celebrate Shakespeare on His 450th Birthday: Seven Ideas for Teaching and Learning
description: Alan Cumming plays Lady Macbeth in a scene from a reimagining of Shakespeares tragedy Macbeth. Related Review

title: Brooklyn Housing Court, Like Many City Renters, Cant Find a New Home
description: Like much of New York, Brooklyn Housing Court is having housing issues.

title: Parsing Big Ears
description: Ben Ratliff and Christopher R. Weingarten, a critic for Rolling Stone, discuss the free-form music festival in Knoxville, Tenn.

title: Treasures and Trivia of the Romanov Era
description: JORDANVILLE, N.Y.  Artifacts as ordinary as coat hangers that were owned by czars and members of their inner circle, are re-emerging at museums, stores and auction houses. The greatest concentration will appear next month in a new museum at a Russian Orthodox monastery in this hamlet near Utica.

title: Dicey Language in The Times, a View from Venezuelas President and Coverage of Womens Basketball
description: Im following up here on a few subjects raised in earlier posts, on subjects as far afield as Venezuelan politics, womens basketball and the use of profane and vulgar language in The Times.

title: Anadarko Pays Billions in Settling Toxins Case
description: HOUSTON  A giant Texas oil company, Anadarko Petroleum, has agreed to pay $5.1 billion for a vast environmental cleanup, a sum the Justice Department said was the largest it had ever won in such a case.

title: On Car Safety, Congress Should Check the Mirror
description: At hearings in the House and Senate earlier this week, lawmakers went all out to show that they cared about auto safety by beating up on the chief executive of General Motors and, to a lesser extent, the head of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. What they didnt do was acknowledge their own culpability.

title: Tech Start-Ups Are Targets of Ransom Cyberattacks
description: Scott Heiferman and Gary Burns had less than four minutes to decide whether to pay up or go down.

title: Mozillas Chief Felled by View on Gay Unions
description: Updated | In Silicon Valley, where personal quirks and even antisocial personalities are tolerated as long as you are building new products and making money, a socially conservative viewpoint may be one trait you have to keep to yourself.

title: A Master of Texture Conjures the Sky and the Sea
description: Look at him, a man muttered behind me at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday evening when the Spanish conductor Pablo Heras-Casado walked out onstage for his debut appearance with the New York Philharmonic. Another child.

title: Popcast: Parsing Big Ears
description: Big Ears, the extraordinary music festival in Knoxville, Tenn., had its third edition this past weekend.

title: U.S. Ordered to Return Assets Held in Crackdown of Luxury Cars Exported to China
description: Federal authorities were dealt a setback this week in their yearlong crackdown on a growing niche business of buying luxury cars in the United States for quick resale in China at markups of as much as triple the initial purchase price.

title: A Musical Mr. Fixit for the Soul
description: Its quite nonintellectual and nonverbal; its just  feeling. Thats how Bruce Springsteen describes his songwriting process at the beginning of Bruce Springsteens High Hopes on Friday night on HBO. So then, of course, he spends the rest of the short film talking about it.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 70
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: blood pressure, smoking bans and weight gain. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Wisconsin, a Love Song
description: Nickolas Butler, author of Shotgun Lovesongs, discusses writing, Wisconsin winters and the stirring influence of Bon Iver.

title: A Vegetarian and Gluten-Free Guide to Paris
description: Vegetarians in France are odd ducks. Culinary deprivation is neither sexy nor patriotic here. Regional specialties like the pulpy oysters of Isigny, the velvety foie gras of Prigord, the textured andouillette sausage of Lyon and the black-and-white Coucou chickens of Rennes are meant to be savored, not censured. And although there is no European consensus on exactly what the word vegetarian means, less than 2 percent of the French identify themselves as such (compared with four times as many Britons and Germans). Rare is the French host who asks guests before they come to dinner if they have dietary preferences or restrictions. Explain that youre a pescatarian, vegan or even gluten-free and youre likely to be met with confusion, bewilderment and a pile of raw vegetables on your plate.

title: Mets Find Woes Growing and Crowds Dwindling
description: The Mets offense was anemic, their bullpen was tattered, and it was only the third game of the season. Their starting pitching would have to carry them, it seemed.

title: Citibank Executive Drafted to Help Bank Regain Feds Confidence
description: Citigroup has drafted one of its stalwarts, who was on the verge of retiring, to help the bank regain the confidence of the Federal Reserve.

title: After 3 Decades, Letterman Says He Will Sign Off
description: David Letterman, the longest-running host in the history of late-night television, will retire from his CBS show next year, the latest shake-up in a roiling talk-show lineup.

title: A Hotel Suite With a Museums Touch
description: Guests staying in the Made in the USA Suite at the Park Hyatt Washington will be surrounded by art and design inspired by the Phillips Collections newest exhibit, Made in the USA: American Masters from the Phillips Collection, 1850-1970, featuring American art, design and furnishings.

title: Rebellion in South Sudan
description: South Sudans former vice president, Riek Machar, speaks about plans for his rebels to attack oil fields that supply revenue to the government of Salva Kiir.

title: A Soulful Safari, Stalking the Spiritual
description: Boyd Varty was not the kind of child who did his learning in the classroom. He was raised in Kruger National Park in South Africa, where his family has operated the Londolozi Game Reserve for more than 80 years. He still lives and works there.

title: At Quiet Rebel Base, Plotting an Assault on South Sudans Oil Fields
description: NASIR, South Sudan  There are only four bullets in the rifle that Liep Wiyual plans to use against government troops on the front lines in South Sudan.

title: Reunion Tour
description: Sometime after Charles Dickens and before Jonathan Franzen, the heart on the shirt sleeve seems to have gone out of style in the literary world, replaced by irony, satirical remove and a more subdued, presumably cleareyed, emotional palette. But once in a while, its nice to get your eyes wet and your heart beating rapidly to a nostalgic tune. Nickolas Butlers Shotgun Lovesongs is a good old-fashioned novel, a sure-footed and unabashedly sentimental first effort that deserves to be among the standouts in this years field of fiction debuts.

title: Open Marriage Trying to Induce Same
description: A sex comedy can sometimes get by, even if it is deficient in one of the two things that term promises. But a sex comedy that is short on both sex and comedy is unlikely to please anyone.

title: Taking Time and Earning Trust
description: The shutter became a lot less heavy once Carolyn Van Hooten realized she had earned the confidence of her subjects.

title: Borrowing the Maximum
description: With property values rising in many markets, and the threat of higher interest rates on the horizon, some borrowers might think the best strategy is to buy the most home they could afford. After all, why not max out on a mortgage while values are headed upward and interest rates still relatively low.

title: West Village Mansion in the Rough
description: A formidable limestone-and-brick building on a historic West Village corner that had been used as a Catholic elementary school, as a nursing school affiliated with St. Vincents Hospital, and most recently as a locus for child-abuse and protection services administered by the New York Foundling, one of the citys oldest charities, is about to enter the market at $47.5 million.

title: Improv Night At The Oligarchs Ball
description: OK, it was pretty funny when Fix the Debt tried to make itself hip by hiring a flash mob to promote deficit scoldery. But this  which is either real or a very subtle spoof  is cosmically weird:

title: Upper East Side Block of Genuine Interest
description: So maybe you think youre pretty good at Wheres Waldo. But can you spot the impostors on East 80th Street between Park and Lexington? Mostly its a block of demure 1920s high-style mansions and private houses unchanged since 1930.

title: The Fashion World as a Good Neighbor
description: Next month, some big names in fashion will host a fund-raiser at Highline Stages on West 14th Street for the Meatpacking District Improvement Association. Diane von Furstenberg and Andrew Rosen, the chief executive of Theory, are presiding over the event, along with the hotelier Andr Balazs.

title: 36 Hours in Hood River, Ore.
description: Hood Rivers multifaceted climate is a little like Sochis  only without palm trees. Popularized as a windsurfing destination in the 1980s, this waterfront town in the Columbia River Gorge is blessed with mild to balmy temperatures nine months of the year, while nearby Mount Hood never runs out of snow. The result is an outdoor adventurers playground, and the saying the Gorge is my gym has inspired a blog of the same name, featuring daily wind and snow reports. The ultimate workout is the hat trick  a sport on snow, water and earth in the same day. It could be ski, paddleboard and bike; or snowboard, windsurf/kiteboard and hike. Or perhaps Nordic ski, white-water kayak and rock climb. And dont forget fly fishing for steelhead. Once youre hooked, the hardest part is the decision.

title: Steve Coogan on Alan Partridge
description: The actor discusses the character he has played for more than two decades.

title: Glimpses of the Past and a High-Tech Future
description: Walking around SoHo on a sunny weekend, when the shoppers are out, you may find it hard to remember that the neighborhood once belonged to artists. But between the boutiques are little oases of contemporary art and reservoirs of local history. Artists Space and the Drawing Center, two nonprofit sites, have been renovated and revitalized; Walter de Marias New York Earth Room, at 141 Wooster Street, and his Broken Kilometer, at 393 West Broadway, are still under Dias meticulous care. Best of all, last years transformation of Donald Judds home and studio at 101 Spring Street into a public museum has given us a time machine to the SoHo of the 1970s.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: Comedy Listings for April 4-10
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Afghanistan, Syria, Spain and Rwanda.

title: Winning Style Points on the Street
description: Flex Is Kings, a documentary about a street dancing style  from East New York, Brooklyn  reminiscent of vogueing, break dancing, and miming, concentrates on two performers. One is Flizzo, who says in the film that his grandmother described these dancers as looking as if they were having strokes.

title: Musical Tributes for Mexicos Dead
description: In Iztapalapa, a violent Mexico City neighborhood, two musicians with a guitar and an accordion are hired to ease the strains of grief, celebrate the dead and remind mourners of more festive memories.

title: With Instruments and Odes, Comforting Mexican Mourners
description: MEXICO CITY  The gravediggers tossed dirt onto the gray coffin, the dust adding tears to weepy eyes. A young man in a T-shirt poured out a little beer for his cousin, who died at just 27. Then came the surge of music.

title: The Power Grid
description: When Chris Davis hit 53 home runs in 2013, he filled one of the few blanks in the arc that stretches from 1 to 73. Only one home run number now remains untaken from 1 to 60; more gaps exist from 61 to 73. Heres a closer look at all the numbers, and some stories behind them.

title: Theater Listings for April 4-10
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Pointing Fingers Over Bulging Bellies
description: Is there nothing for which Richard M. Nixon cannot be blamed?

title: Courage, Loyalty, Honor, Kablooey
description: Its a bird, its a plane  oh, wait, its Captain America.

title: Hard Times Take Their Toll on a Singapore Family
description: Ilo Ilo, Anthony Chens small, wonderful first feature film, is an acutely perceptive examination of middle-class life in Singapore during a 1997 financial crisis that sent tremors of panic through Asias developing countries. Its semi-autobiographical story focuses on a family of three, with a baby on the way, suddenly facing uncertainty.

title: Chasing a Dream and an Unalloyed Ethos
description: ARRIVE in Brooklyn, and youve entered the belly of contemporary art. Its our 19th-century Paris or 18th-century Rome, with one of the largest concentrations of artists in the world. Here, youll find both commercial galleries and nonprofit and artist-run spaces  and thousands upon thousands of places you can visit during open-studio weekends scattered throughout the year.

title: A Much Darker Hitchhikers Guide
description: Scarlett Johansson as an extraterrestrial femme fatale cruising the streets of Glasgow in Jonathan Glazers cerebral sci-fi horror fantasy Under the Skin is an indelible personification of predatory allure. Wearing a dark wig and a fake-fur jacket, her character, an alien with a sinister agenda, is as fetishized an object of desire as Marlene Dietrich admired through the lens of Josef von Sternberg. You may also think of Ava Gardner, as perfect a female specimen as Hollywood ever produced, coldly working her wiles.

title: Movie Listings for April 4-10
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for April 4-10
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Jazz Listings for April 4-10
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Opera & Classical Music Listings for April 4-10
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: An Island Idyll Turns Sinister
description: Free Gina Carano! This former mixed-martial artist has plummeted from the heights and all-star cast of Haywire  Steven Soderberghs delightful 2012 revenge thriller  and now, after a supporting role in Fast & Furious 6, appears trapped in B-film depths. Witness In the Blood, an action trifle from John Stockwell that offers Puerto Rico locations and brief appearances by vivid actors (Treat Williams, Stephen Lang) but squanders Ms. Carano.

title: Pluralism, With Bug Zappers and Doll People
description: WHEN the New Museum announced plans in 2002 to move from SoHo to the Bowery, on the Lower East Side, it caused much head scratching in the New York art world.
