description: Dr. David Eisenberg of the Harvard School of Public Health and the Samueli Institute,a nonprofit research organization, demonstrated along with his daughter, Naomi, a whole-wheat couscous salad that is the inspiration for this one at the Healthy Kitchens, Healthy Livesmedical education conference in Napa Valley this year. You can use a variety of dried fruits and nuts, as well as a mix of herbs. Chop the larger dried fruits small so that the pieces are uniform.

title: The Peoples Palaces at the Beach
description: On a raw spring day, John T. Krawchuk, the director of historic preservation for the citys parks department, led a tour through the fenced-off pavilion at Orchard Beach, where cracks snaked up the walls and the marine-blue terra-cotta that graces the facade was chipped or missing.

title: The Campaign Against Mozillas Brendan Eich
description: You know weve come a long way in a short time when a chief executive of a prominent company can be forced to resign for holding the view that gays and lesbians should not be allowed to marry each other. As recently as 2010, a majority of Americans believed that the government should not recognize same-sex marriage, according to Gallup.

title: Movie Review: Under The Skin
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews Under The Skin.

title: Red and Basmati or Jasmine Rice With Peanuts, Asian Dressing and Baked Tofu
description: You can cook the two kinds of rice together for this spicy Asian salad if you soak the red rice for an hour first. The antioxidant-rich pigment from the red rice will bleed into the white rice, turning it an attractive pale rusty color.

title: Ukraine Releases Shooting Video
description: Video released from the Ukrainian Interior Ministry purportedly shows police officers shooting at protesters in deadly February clashes.

title: Movie Review: The Unknown Known
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews The Unknown Known.

title: Middle Eastern Black Rice and Lentil Salad on a Bed of Spinach
description: Black rice is inky, as black as squid ink, and glistens against a bed of spinach. The pigments provide anthocyanins, flavonoids that are high in antioxidants. I was inspired to cook the rice with lentils by a pilaf that I ate recently at the Healthy Kitchens, Healthy Lives conference at the Culinary Institute of America in Napa Valley. In addition to the familiar green or black lentils, Ive thrown in uncooked split red lentils, which contribute their own soft salmon color and crunch; they are soaked for a few hours to soften them, and thats all they need. Prepare the ingredients for the salad while the rice and lentils are cooking.

title: Finding Ways to Market an E-Commerce Business
description: A reader,Laura Araujo, recently posted a comment in which she expressed some frustration with her efforts to market a small, e-commerce business. Ms. Araujo, 27, has a full-time job as a financial analyst but to earn extra money she opened a franchise business on the side in December. I was looking for a franchise that I can do primarily evenings and weekends and operate by myself, Ms. Araujo said.

title: Movie Review: Captain America
description: The Times critic Manhola Dargis reviews Captain America: The Winter Soldier.

title: Law Lifts Enrollment in Medicaid by Millions
description: WASHINGTON  Enrollment in Medicaid has increased by three million people, to a total of 62 million, largely because of the Affordable Care Act, the Obama administration said Friday.

title: Image of the Day: April 4
Book Review Podcast: Akhil Sharmas Family Life
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Sonali Deraniyagala reviews Akhil Sharmas new novel, Family Life. Ms. Deraniyagala writes:

title: Turning Up the Heat on Fruit
description: Fruit compotes make great compromise desserts; theyre sweet, but not as sweet as sorbets, and like sorbets they dont require flour, butter or pastry skills. I didnt develop any kind of knack for pastry until I began collaborating with pastry chefs on their cookbooks, but for years I managed to round out my dinner parties with fruit-based desserts (though the children of my friend Clifford Wright used to roll their eyes when I brought dessert  She doesnt bring dessert, she brings fruit, theyd say).

title: Loeb Steps Up Pressure on Sothebys Board
description: The activist investor Daniel S. Loeb fired his latest salvo at Sothebys on Friday, calling on shareholders to overthrow members of the auction houses lackadaisical board.

title: Clip: Watermark
description: A scene from the documentary directed by Jennifer Baichwal and Edward Burtynsky.

title: Michael Schumacher Is Said to Have Moments of Consciousness
description: LONDON  After more than three months in a coma, Michael Schumacher, the most successful Grand Prix driver in racing history, is showing moments of consciousness and awakening in the intensive care ward where he was taken after suffering brain injuries in a skiing accident in the French Alps on Dec. 29, his spokeswoman said in a statement Friday.

title: Tea Party Aims at Incumbents, but Falls Short
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, ought to be a prime target for a Tea Party challenge. He helped write the Senate overhaul of immigration laws that provided for a pathway to citizenship for illegal immigrants, backed President Obamas Supreme Court nominees and expressed a willingness to raise taxes as part of a larger deal to address the nations fiscal health  all perilous positions in a deeply conservative state.

title: G.O.P. Incumbents on the Ballot
description: Eleven Republican senators are up for re-election this fall, and more than half of them face opposition in the primaries.

title: In Spain, a Family Reunion, Centuries Later
description: At twilight, I roamed a honey-colored labyrinth of brick houses in Segovias medieval Jewish quarter, walking a cobblestone path in the footsteps of my distant ancestor from 16 generations ago.

title: After Earthquakes, a Creative Rebirth in Christchurch
description: On the afternoon of Feb. 22, 2011, as the C1 Espresso cafe in Christchurch was in the midst of a busy lunch rush, the walls and tables suddenly began shaking, windows started popping out of their frames, and the lights flickered out. The region had been experiencing aftershocks from a large earthquake that had struck six months earlier, but this one was different. In a span of minutes, the entire city center was devastated, including the cafe, which was eventually demolished. Nearly 200 people across the city died.

title: NYT Now: Kerry Calls for Reality Check
description: Amid growing frustration with the Israelis and Palestinians on the stalled peace talks, Secretary of State John Kerry said it was reality check time.

title: Dispute Over Leave Agitated Ft. Hood Soldier Before Shooting
description: KILLEEN, Tex.  The Army specialist at Fort Hood who killed three and wounded 16 of his fellow soldiers on Wednesday had an angry dispute over a leave request shortly before the shooting rampage, a law enforcement official said Friday.

title: Microsoft Office for the iPad: Its Delightfully Familiar
description: The plan sounded simple: Get an iPad. Get a keyboard for the iPad. Get Office for iPad. Then, finally, review Office for iPad.

title: 2 Giant European Cement Makers Are in Merger Talks
description: PARIS  Holcim and Lafarge, two giant European cement makers, said Friday that they were in advanced discussions about a merger of equals that would create the industrys leader, if the deal survives regulatory scrutiny.

title: Audio Editing in iMovie
description: Q. In iMovie 11 for the Mac, how do you lower or remove the original audio from a clip so that the selected background music is the only sound?

title: The War Between Our States
description: Who are you at your best?

title: Talking Shoots and Leaves
description: The Indoor Outdoor Gardener in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, has two types of repeat customers. Robin Green, 56, is in one category: a steady presence for 10 years who stops in just to say hello to the owner, Helena De Paola, and walks out with yet another plant. Then there is Brian Schnabel, who made his first visit on a recent Sunday morning but was so entranced he was back shopping later that afternoon, buying a small trellis on Ms. De Paolas recommendation.

title: Looking Glass Complications
description: Who the heck is manufacturing all these superpowered mirrors? Theres the one in Snow White that knows who is fairest of them all. Theres the one in Beauty and the Beast that has Google Earth-like abilities. The Harry Potter stories have both the Mirror of Erised, which shows the user his deepest desires, and the two-way mirror, a person-to-person communication device.

title: A Bold Bid to Combat a Crisis in Legal Education
description: Brooklyn Law School is hardly alone in facing a crisis in legal education. Five law schools have closed in the last two years, more than at any other time in American history.

title: One Word That Should Never Follow I Love You
description: I dont remember the exact day, or the exact reason, or even the exact words, but I know it started with I love you, but

title: The American Woodcocks Love Song at 300 Feet
description: The American woodcock is one of the Northeasts most peculiar birds, with a humble, lovable beauty that has inspired myriad nicknames. Bogsucker, mudbat, Labrador twister and timberdoodle all describe a shy brown bird only 10 to 12 inches long. Incredibly well camouflaged, woodcocks are almost invisible by day, resting and feeding among the bristling, messy shrubs of old fields, meadows and young woodlands. But in early spring, as the suns fleeting warmth fades into the chill night, the bird performs one of natures most curious courtship displays.

title: Peninsula Hotel Will Open in Paris
description: Peninsula Hotels, the Hong Kong-based luxury brand, enters Europe for the first time, with its 10th location scheduled to open in Paris this August.

title: C.E.O. of The Times Co. to Publish a Book on Language
description: Mark Thompson, the president and chief executive of The New York Times Company, is writing his first book, an examination of language in the digital age, his publisher, St. Martins Press, said. The book, to be titled Enough Said, draws from a series of lectures at Oxford that Mr. Thompson delivered in 2012 as a visiting professor at the university.

title: In L.A., a Group Show Explores the Art of the Obscured
description: As its name suggests, Veils  a 40-artist group exhibition opening Saturday in the West Adams neighborhood of L.A.  offers interpretations of the physical act of concealment. But the shows curators, Jhordan Dahl and Ariana Papademetropoulos, also made a point to stretch the concept, exploring ideas about public personas and the occult. The works on display range from Jeffrey Vallances 1992 series of clown makeup imprints on linen handkerchiefs to an eerie watercolor self-portrait by the artist (and occultist) Marjorie Cameron to Long-Banged Angel, an eight-foot-high Eric Yahnker drawing of Farrah Fawcett in her glory days, lustrous feathered hair completely obscuring her eyes.

title: The Gun Report: April 4, 2014
description: Thanks to National Rifle Association-backed legislation, the commanding officers of the Fort Hood shooter were barred from asking him about the privately owned handgun he used to carry out this weeks shooting, Media Matters reports.

title: Investors Return to Anadarko After Record $5.1 Billion Settlement
description: Stock investors seem to have a firm grip on Anadarko Petroleums toxic waste settlement. The record $5.15 billion settlement on Thursday, covering years of environmental claims, was at the low end of a court-defined range, which had a midpoint of $9.8 billion. The 15 percent jump in the oil companys market capitalization after the settlement was announced is mostly explained by those numbers. And it brings Anadarkos 12-month stock performance nearly back in line with the Standard & Poors 500 Index after a bumpy ride.

title: Three Soldiers Killed at Fort Hood Are Identified
description: Updated, 5:04 p .m.When Specialist Ivan Antonio Lopez opened fire at Fort Hood late Wednesday afternoon, Sgt. First Class Danny Ferguson leaned up against a door to prevent the gunman from entering a room packed with military personnel.

title: Why Mozillas Chief Had to Resign
description: What conclusions should we draw about Silicon Valley from what happened at Mozilla?

title: Just the Facts, With Tweaks
description: I think here there are two kinds of truths: dramatic truth and documentary reporting, the trailblazing French filmmaker Jean Rouch once said in an interview. But pure documentary is very rare, and maybe its inevitable that a film have some drama in it. He was talking in 1977, giving context for films hed made in the 1950s.

title: Osteoporosis
description: This animation begins by showing a hip fracture due to osteoporosis. The bone then dissolves into a frontal section to compare the bony interior of a normal femur to that of an osteoporotic femur.

title: In a Tale of the Nations First Spy Ring, a Spotlight on Colonial New York
description: Before it was the wonder city of eight million stories, New York in the autumn of 1776 was just 25,000 strong. Under indomitable British occupation  indeed, New York was the colonial headquarters of the British military  it was at a hinge in its history.

title: Struggling to Film in Americas Chokehold
description: MEXICO CITY  In Hollywood terms, it was small change. But for Miguel Coyula, a Cuban filmmaker accustomed to working on a tiny budget, the $5,200 he raised on the crowdfunding site Indiegogo.com last year would have bought some lighting equipment, a Steadicam and a tripod, all crucial for his science-fiction feature, Blue Heart.

title: After Playing, Parting Is Such Sweet Sorrow
description: When people learn that Im a music critic, they often ask what my instrument is. Ive always answered, I play the cello. If Im feeling expansive, I say Im a cellist.

title: Trading Flaming Skull for Inner Dad
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  After playing, among other characters, a one-eyed dad who drinks beer out of his enemys skull (Drive Angry) and a motorcyclist from hell who can make his head burst into flame (Ghost Rider: Spirit of Vengeance), Nicolas Cage had gotten a reputation as a guy whose love of action pictures had, over the last decade, pulled him away from what he does best, namely, act. Quirky comedies and thoughtful indies were set aside for films heavy on bloodletting and explosions. Critics, even longtime champions like Roger Ebert, yearned for the Nic of old.

title: 50 Years of the Ford Mustang
description: It was love at first sight for Fred Glazier, who saw the Ford Mustang at the 1964 Worlds Fair. Soon after, he bought his own, and he still drives it today.

title: Chocolate Caramel Macarons
description: Melissa Clark takes the best parts of a French macaron and an American macaroon and creates a sweet sandwich cookie for Passover.

title: Seeking College Application Essays About Money From This Years Seniors
description: Last year, I put out an open call for college application essays about money, work and social class and hoped that high school seniors would send them in. Several dozen young men and women did, and we featured the best of the essays in a Your Money column. I particularly enjoyed getting to know Lyle Li, now a New York University freshman, whom we featured in a video.

title: A Pizza Party
description: For Yosuke Masuko, the goal of operating a pizza company in Vietnam is delivering wow and happiness.'

title: Books, and Compassion, From Birth
description: Last year, when I was visiting a public school in Sunset Park in Brooklyn for teenagers with boundless difficulties, my host, a poet who teaches at various city schools, mentioned a student who had become pregnant. Hoping to start a library for the child soon to arrive, the poet told the young woman embarking on motherhood that she would like to give her some books  books of the kind her own grandchildren growing up in a very different Brooklyn had by the dozens. The offer was met skeptically. I already have one, the girl said.

title: Closing the Seder With Something New
description: Heres the secret to the best Passover desserts: stick to recipes that never relied on flour to begin with. Why make a chocolate cake with matzo flour when a flourless chocolate torte is going to be so much better anyway? This is why flourless tortes, candies and nut- or coconut-based cookies are the usual end to many a Seder.

title: Wheelies: The Kia People Mover Edition
description: Kia announced Thursday that it would unveil an all-new eight-passenger vehicle at the New York auto show this month. Details were scant, but the new model would probably take the place of the Kia Sedona minivan, which was scheduled for replacement. (Kia)

title: My Little Pony, 50 Years Later
description: When the Ford Mustang was introduced 50 years ago this month, it was first to break from the gate in a market class that would come to be known as pony cars.

title: A Ford Mustang Thats Not a Mustang
description: If a dump truck can be a Mustang, can a Mustang be a T5? That conundrum can be answered in the positive, the result of a German manufacturer of trucks having copyrighted the Mustang name long before Fords pony car was released in the 1960s.

title: Five Injured After Bus Smashes Into Upper Manhattan Building
description: A New York City Transit bus collided with a minivan and then smashed into a building in Upper Manhattan on Friday morning, injuring five people, according to fire officials.

title: Federal Panel Rejects Design for Eisenhower Memorial
description: In the latest setback for a memorial to Dwight D. Eisenhower planned for Washingtons National Mall, Frank Gehrys current design was rejected and sent back for revisions on Thursday by the panel that oversees the nations monuments.

title: Prosecutor on India Rape Case Sentencing
description: Ujjwal Nikam, the special prosecutor in a Mumbai gang rape case, spoke to the news media Friday after three men were sentenced to death.

title: When the Final Curtain Isnt So Final
description: On a frigid February day in 1999, I gave my final performance as Radioman Harold Bride in the Broadway musical Titanic. Id been offered a new role in a downtown play. It was harder than I ever imagined saying goodbye to the company; to the beloved duet Id performed nightly with the ships stoker, played for most of the run by Brian dArcy James, who sang a message of love to his landlocked girl while I, a Marconi geek, waxed poetic over my telegraph. I stepped downstage for the last scene of the show, tears streaming, as we all waved farewell to the doomed ship and belted out the final notes of Maury Yestons luscious score: Fortunes winds sing Gods Speed to thee! A few weeks later, after more than 800 performances, Titanic closed.

title: Corporate Profits Grow and Wages Slide
description: CORPORATE profits are at their highest level in at least 85 years. Employee compensation is at the lowest level in 65 years.

title: Is That Jesus in Your Toast?
description: TAKE a close look at your breakfast. Is that Jesus staring out at you from your toast?

title: Activists Seen as Possibly Circling Symantec
description: Symantec is close to hiring JPMorgan Chase to defend the enterprise technology company against activist investors, people briefed on the matter said on Friday.

title: Big Ticket | At $30 Million, Its All About the Views
description: A vista-infused apartment near the peak of the south tower at the Time Warner Center with unencumbered Central Park views to the east and Hudson River scenes to the west sold for $30 million after a brief bidding war and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Should I Swap My Rent-Stabilized Apartment?
description: Ask Real Estate is a new weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: Ophira Eisenbergs Walk-Up Cave
description: There are certain people who simply dont understand the concept of apartment buildings without elevators. It just so happens that some of those baffled individuals share a last name with Ophira Eisenberg.

title: Syria Ships Out More Chemicals After a 2-Week Lapse
description: GENEVA  Syria has delivered a consignment of chemical weapons materials for export and destruction overseas for the first time in more than two weeks, a delay that revived concerns about the countrys readiness and ability to meet newly extended deadlines for completing the task this month.

title: The Weight of Executives Personal Beliefs
Music Writers Opus, Now With Sound
description: As a college classics major, the music historian, writer and critic Peter Guralnick once submitted a paper comparing the Roman poet Catulluss Little Bird, Delight of My Girl to Robert Johnsons Stones in My Passway. It was not well received, he recalled recently, but it helped establish a template that has served Mr. Guralnick superbly in writing groundbreaking books on blues, country and soul music, and biographies of pop music figures like Elvis Presley and Sam Cooke.

title: A Long Way From South Dakota
description: On the cover of her new album, The Futures Void, the South Dakota-raised noise-rocker EMA sports an Oculus Rift virtual reality headset, but the photograph was shot before that companys recent $2 billion purchase by Facebook. And she wrote the song Satellites, which rages against government surveillance, months before the National Security Agency scandal broke.

title: Q. and A. | Kelis Explains How She Got from Milkshake to Her Own Cooking Show
description: Kelis Rogers, who broke out in 2003 with her booty-popping come-on Milkshake, has a history of surprising her fans. The Harlem natives 2006 album, Kelis Was Here, staged a rebellion against the pop sound that established her, forgoing the signature Neptunes production of her first three albums in favor of an eclectic sound with a wide-ranging cast of collaborators. She followed up four years later with yet another new direction, the boundary-pushing electro-dance riot Flesh Tone. If that wasnt enough to prove her restlessness, somewhere in the middle she also attended culinary school, becoming a Le Cordon Bleu-certified chef; she even hosts her own Cooking Channel show, Saucy & Sweet.

title: A Dual Review of Whats New, Starring Kelis and Alejandro Jodorowsky
description: Alejandro Jodorowsky, surrealist Chilean-born director and self-described psychoshaman whose new autobiographical film, The Dance of Reality  his first in 23 years  opens in May, takes on Kelis, Grammy-nominated pop star and Le Cordon Bleu-certified chef whose sixth album, Food, comes out later this month. She also has a line of sauces in the works.

title: From Slavery and Shiloh to the Post-Bellum World
description: Civil War: The Untold Story delivers on the promise of its title only intermittently.

title: NYT Now: India Rape Case Sentencing
description: The special prosecutor in a Mumbai rape case, Ujjwal Nikam, discussed the sentencing of three men.

title: Turns From a Gospel Singer and a Jazz Saxophonist
description: Erica Campbell

title: Review: 2015 Subaru WRX STI
description: Budget conscious automotive enthusiasts who worship at the altar of performance know the Subaru WRX STI is an answered prayer.

title: Weekend Reading: High-Frequency Reading
description: This week we take an ultrafast look at the financial headlines.

title: Think Like a Doctor: Running in Circles Solved!
description: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to solve the mystery of a 23-year-old man with episodes of aggressive, manic behavior that couldnt be controlled. Nearly 1,000 readers wrote in with their take on this terrifying case. More than 300 of you got the right class of disease, and 21 of you nailed the precise form of the disorder. Amazing!

title: Another High-Speed Trading Investigation
description: The list of federal and state agencies investigating the practice of high-frequency trading continues to grow.

title: Irans Reformers Include More Than One Former Hostage-Taker
description: Updated, Saturday, 2:44 p.m. | As my colleagues Somini Sengupta and Thomas Erdbrink reported, there has been discomfort and anger in Washington since Iran applied for a visa to let a veteran diplomat who played a part in the 1979 hostage crisis move to New York and serve as its ambassador to the United Nations.

title: Kazuo Ishiguro Readies First Novel in 10 Years
description: Alfred A. Knopf will publish The Buried Giant, Kazuo Ishiguros seventh novel and his first in nearly a decade, in spring 2015. Mr. Ishiguros British publisher, Faber & Faber, announced the forthcoming novel in advance of the London Book Fair, which starts Tuesday.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: Buzz From Tokyo to Toronto Evokes Another Yankee Debut
description: Across the Yankees universe on Friday night, all eyes were on Toronto, where the teams prized off-season acquisition from Japan, pitcher Masahiro Tanaka, made his major league debut against the Blue Jays. Battalions of Japanese reporters were on hand to document the milestone, and baseball fans in Japan, coffee mugs in hand, woke up early on Saturday to watch the game live.

title: Come Here, Look Back, Move Forward
description: The choreographer Stephen Petronio does not like to go backward. He says that moving in reverse  say, on a train  makes him feel mentally disturbed and physically ill. Nevertheless, there is a lot of backward in his life these days.

title: Stripper With a Heart of Gold
description: TESTED 2014 Volkswagen Jetta SE

title: Still a Wild Child After Reform School
description: Let the other guys worry about self-steering cars, blind-spot beepers and onboard Wi-Fi connections.

title: Subarus Blue Streak
description: The 2015 WRX and its track-ready STI version deliver unmitigated driving pleasure at a relatively affordable price.

title: Keeping Tabs, Just in Case
description: Most histories trace antiterrorism squads to the Haymarket bombing in Chicago in 1886, after which American police departments devoted a new zeal to gathering intelligence.

title: A Peace Process in Which Process Has Come to Outweigh Peace
description: JERUSALEM  The crisis that engulfed the ailing Middle East peace process this week was much more about preserving the process than finding a path to peace.

title: Fabric Art, Made From the Fighting
description: Building on last years touring exhibitions of Civil War art and photography, Homefront & Battlefield: Quilts & Context in the Civil War reminds us that textiles were also a big part of wartime culture (and, not incidentally, one in which women played a major role). Organized by the American Textile History Museum in Lowell, Mass., the show has just arrived at the New-York Historical Society. (It will travel to the Shelburne Museum in Vermont next fall and the Nebraska State Historical Society in the winter of 2015.)

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 69
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: How the Centuries Will Play Out
description: For music lovers, Thursday brings a clear choice between older and newer, both options tantalizing. Uptown, the repertory could hardly be more classic, as the eminent conductor Christoph von Dohnanyi leads the New York Philharmonic in Schumanns stirring Symphony No. 2. But the main event may well end up being the performance of Brahmss galvanic Piano Concerto No. 1, with the exhilarating British pianist Paul Lewis. (7:30 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center,212-875-5030,nyphil.org.)

title: NYT Now: Perry on Fort Hood Shooting
description: Governor Rick Perry of Texas addressed the media about the deadly Fort Hood shooting on Wednesday.

title: Tappers, Striking New Ground
description: The rhythm of tap expresses itself aurally when metal slaps and strikes the ground. For many, this dance is still associated with Broadway-style showmanship or fluttering jazzlike improvisations. But tap today has a broader theatrical scope and emotional range. This week the pioneers of a new age of tap bring their vision to Rhythm in Motion, presented by the American Tap Dance Foundation and featuring some furiously inventive women, like Brenda Bufalino, Michelle Dorrance and Chloe Arnold, among other innovators. (Tuesday through Sunday, Theater at the 14th Street Y, 344 East 14th Street, Manhattan, 212-780-0800, atdf.org.)

title: Festival Offers a Fuller Brubeck
description: Long before his death in 2012, the legacy of the jazz pianist Dave Brubeck was often reduced, in popular conversation, to his biggest album, Time Out, and its ageless hit, Take Five. Jazz at Lincoln Center will offer a broader, richer portrait with its Dave Brubeck Festival, from Monday through next Sunday in the organizations home, Frederick P. Rose Hall.

title: Ruling Spurs Rush for Cash in Both Parties
description: Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, the Democratic leader in the House, wasted little time on Thursday blasting the Supreme Courts latest decision freeing donors to spend more money on campaigns. The founding fathers, Ms. Pelosi said at a news conference on Thursday morning, had fought for a government of the many, not a government of the money. Democrats, she said, will not unilaterally disarm.

title: The Journey to Humanity
description: When the paleobiologist Neil Shubin looks at his fellow humans, he sees ghosts of animals past. The way we grip with our hands? We can thank our primate forefathers. Our ability to hear so many sounds? Distant ancestors the size of a shrew. And the further back we venture, the stranger things get. We dont describe our skin as scaly for nothing.

title: For Photography, the Biggest Show on Earth
description: Eighteen years ago four Toronto art dealers decided to whip up a little excitement around photography. Dismayed that the city had no museum devoted to the subject, and that curators at the big arts institutions seemed slow to embrace it as an art form, they issued an open invitation to museums, galleries, art centers and coffee houses to take part in a monthlong festival they called Contact 97. To their surprise, 50 exhibitors responded. Stephen Bulger, the owner of the citys only gallery showing photography year-round, predicted, In five years, this will be an international event.

title: Friday Night Music: Figaro
description: Yes, I know its only Friday afternoon. But my friend Emily Mann, artistic director at the McCarter Theater, has invited me to the opening of the first part of McCarters production of the Figaro plays, starting with dinner tonight. Strictly speaking I have the wrong play here  tonights play is The Barber of Seville  but Im much more of a Mozart guy than a Rossini guy, so what the heck:

title: Immigration Bill Splitting House G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON  A push to give legal status to young undocumented immigrants who serve in the military is roiling the immigration debate in the House, dividing Republicans and reviving some movement toward substantive immigration legislation this year.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Fish With Morocco in Mind
description: In Morocco, fish is fried, grilled or simmered, just as it is everywhere else, but there is this essential difference: The first step in nearly every Moroccan fish recipe requires the fish to be slathered, anointed or rubbed with a mixture of herbs, spices and olive oil.

title: High Line Chief Does Her Relaxing Uptown
description: Jenny Gersten, 45, who became executive director in January of Friends of the High Line, which runs the elevated park in Manhattan, had been the artistic director of the Williamstown Theater Festival in Massachusetts. Theater runs in her family: her mother, Cora Cahan, is the president of the New 42nd Street, which revitalized theaters in the area, and her father, Bernard Gersten, recently retired as executive producer of Lincoln Center Theater. Ms. Gerstens husband, Willie Reale, 56, writes musical theater with his brother Robert and is a supervising producer of Blue Bloods, the CBS police drama. They live in the West 80s with their sons, Augustus, 15, and Leonardo, 11, and their black Labrador retriever, Penny.

title: Parting Glance: Anja Niedringhaus
description: Anja Niedringhaus, 48, an internationally known German photographer, was killed while on assignment in eastern Afghanistan on Friday. Some of her closest colleagues offered deeply personal accounts of her life and career.

title: Golden Corral
description: Among the fans who will be celebrating the Mustangs 50th birthday will be some owners who bought the car when it first went on sale.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: On the Market in New York City
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: Week in Pictures for April 4
description: .media.slideshow.in-page-player .headline { display: none; }

title: Perry and Cruz on Base Shooting
description: Gov. Rick Perry and Senator Ted Cruz delivered remarks after meeting with military personnel wounded Wednesday in the shooting at Fort Hood in Texas.

title: Inside Prison With Ponte
description: Joseph Ponte, New Yorks newly appointed correction commissioner, has plans for reform. But Rikers will be a far bigger challenge than Maines jail system, where he instituted key changes.

title: Grandmas Diamond Is Forever
description: Ian Ross paycheck as a freelance EMT wasnt enough for bills and an engagement ring. So like many millennials, he turned to a family heirloom when he asked Madlyn Wendell to marry him.

title: No Spring Thaw in the Job Market
description: One of the many good things about the arrival of spring is that politicians, economists and other policy makers can no longer blame the winter weather for the slow economy and the grinding pace of job growth.

title: Weinstein Releases 2 French Films Without Fanfare
description: LOS ANGELES  As others roll out blockbusters, the movie mogul Harvey Weinstein is serving up seasonal fare that has become almost as rare as a good croque madame: French films.

title: Ryans Plan: To Balance the Budget, Hurt the Poor
description: The House leadership is trying to muscle Paul Ryans 2015 budget plan through the Republican caucus, and the amount of effort required is revealing. The budget is full of breathtakingly unfair spending cuts, but many Republican House members dont like it because they think it doesnt go far enough.

title: Brazilian Firm Magnifies Focus on Distressed Debt
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  The investment firm Jive Investments Holding, which acquired some of Lehman Brothers Brazilian assets in 2010, is raising a new $100 million distressed-debt fund focused on nonperforming corporate loans, according to people briefed on the firms plans.

title: Under a Shiny Shroud, Cloaked in Mystery
description: Otro Teatro, the Spanish title of Luciana Achugars latest work, translates as other theater or another theater, with the possible connotation of an alternative one. The New York premiere on Wednesday took place in the conventional setting of the theater at New York Live Arts, but Ms. Achugar has some unconventional notions of what might transpire there for performers and audience. A handout suggests a project to grow ourselves a new body, a utopian body, an anarchic body, a body in pleasure.

title: Saying Yes Before a Studio Audience
description: After exchanging emails and briefly talking on the phone, Sanjeev Sirpal knew it was time to meet a woman he had first encountered on Match.com.

title: Weibo Seeks to Raise More Than $380 Million in I.P.O.
description: If all goes according to plan, the biggest of Chinas Twitter-like microblogging services will raise more than $380 million in its coming initial public offering.

title: A Quick Take on an Unusual Book Review
description: On Thursday, The Times published a rare review of a digital-only book. The book, Sleep Donation, by Karen Russell, was reviewed positively by Michiko Kakutani. In 2012, the book critic Dwight Garner reviewed 15 journalistic minibooks published for digital readers.

title: David Lettermans Legacy
description: Bill Carter, a media reporter for The Times, discusses David Lettermans late-night legacy.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Afghanistan, Kenya, South Africa and England.

title: Lusty Warriors, Panting Anew
description: Television shows that deal routinely with death usually get it out of the way early: Someone dies at the beginning of the episode, and everyone else spends the rest of the hour talking about it. Game of Thrones turns that formula around. In the early weeks of this HBO hits fourth season, which begins on Sunday, people mostly talk for an hour  reminding us of who they are, which family they belong to, what castle they call home  until the episode ends with an operatic, in one case game-changing, killing.

title: Understanding Particulars of G.M.s Safety Recall
description: If you drive one of the 2.6 million General Motors cars recalled because of a faulty ignition switch, youre probably eager for the part to be replaced. Dealerships say they are gearing up to schedule the work as soon as the necessary parts become available  which is expected to happen starting Monday, according to G.M. But it could take months to repair all the affected cars.

title: Classical, as It Meets Club Scene
description: When the Unsound Festival, a highly regarded annual experimental-music series that started in Poland in 1993, first planted its flag in New York in 2010, it arrived with a vaguely precise mandate. Advanced music, Mat Schulz, the festival founder, put it in an interview in The New York Times that year: a kind of approach to making music rather than strict definitions. Accordingly, of-the-moment electronica jostled against outlier strains of classical music.

title: TPG and Others Said to Agree to Invest in Airbnb
description: Updated April 5, 9:58 a.m. |

title: Slain Photographer Had Covered Several War Zones
description: Some of the scenes captured by Anja Niedringhaus, a Pulitzer Prize-winning photographer who was killed by a police officer in Afghanistan on Friday.

title: Why That Sharp Wit Stood Out on Late Night
description: Life as we know it is over, and late-night television will never be the same.

title: In Colorado, Cannabis Cup Time
description: With Colorados recent legalization of the recreational use of marijuana, ticket sales for Denvers fifth annual Cannabis Cup this month are expected to double, according to event organizers.

title: Vanderbilt Knockout Teams in Dallas
description: DALLAS  We are looking at the final of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams, the premier event at the Spring North American Championships here.

title: Lupitas Lancme Gig, the Armys Hair-Raiser and Christy Turlingtons Comeback
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: Affluent Wine Buyers in Asia Find Their Confidence
description: HONG KONG  Six bottles of 1990 Romane-Conti Burgundy sold to an Asian buyer at a Christies auction in Hong Kong last month for 980,000 Hong Kong dollars ($126,345). A case of wine from the Cros Parantoux vineyard in Burgundy, France, fetched $82,333 in a sale held by the American auction house Acker Merrall & Condit at a restaurant overlooking Hong Kongs harbor.

title: With Grandmas Ring, I Thee Wed
description: Nervous yet hopeful, Ian Ross knew what he wanted to ask, but he wasnt sure just how to say it. He stared into her eyes, knowing that the whole proposal was riding on this moment.

title: Hedge Fund Advertising Off to a Slow Start, Survey Finds
description: Hedge funds have not exactly rushed to take advantage of their new ability to advertise.

title: Stand Up, Theyre Rocking the Boat, Like 1950 Again
description: For most people, the term fugue evokes a very sober, complex form of contrapuntal instrumental music. But then there is the Fugue for Tinhorns, the song that opens the classic 1950 musical Guys and Dolls, in which three small-time gamblers in New York argue over their picks to win a big horse race. Here was the great composer and lyricist Frank Loesser wresting the fugue form from classical music and turning it into a charming, clever, but no less musically ingenious opener for a show about some lovable denizens of the New York underworld, as vivid as ever in the brilliant book by Jo Swerling and Abe Burrows. And what better setting for that song, and Loessers inspired score, than Carnegie Hall, which on Thursday night hosted an exhilarating, one-time-only, ready-for-Broadway performance of Guys and Dolls, with Rob Fisher conducting the Orchestra of St. Lukes, no less.

title: A Petticoat as Spy Signal
description: Turn could mean a lot of things. The Turn is what survivors on The Walking Dead call their zombie apocalypse. Repeated three times, its the title of a folk song, and its the first half of turncoat, as in traitor, or turndown, as in turndown service in a fancy hotel, or maybe just turnip, the root vegetable.

title: So Far Away. No, Shes in Row K.
description: It had become a confounding mystery of the Broadway season: Why hadnt Carole King come to see the Carole King musical? Did it mean that she didnt like the show and was trying to distance herself from it? Was she just a recluse holed up in Idaho who didnt like crowds? Then why did she perform at the Grammys and make regular appearances on Morning Joe?

title: What, Me Old?
description: Twenty-five years ago, when the twin daughters of a childhood friend were 7 and I was 41, I told them that someday, when they were grown, Id babysit for their children.

title: Carlotta Gall on Fear and Hope in Afghanistan
description: In 2006, while reporting in Quetta, Pakistan, about the possible connection between Pakistan and the Taliban resurgence in Afghanistan, Carlotta Gall was attacked in her hotel room by four plainclothes agents of the I.S.I., Pakistans main intelligence service. Gall was punched twice in the face and temple, and her computer, notebooks and cellphone were seized.

title: A Con Artist, a Librarian, Love and 76 Trombones
description: Hope is a major theme of The Music Man, and the opening number of the show at the John W. Engeman Theater at Northport raises hopes for a sterling production throughout. Meredith Willsons heartwarming 1957 musical, which won the Tony Award for Best Musical over West Side Story, begins in a railway car filled with traveling salesmen who complain about a flimflam man in their trade named Harold Hill. Their fast-paced patter song, Rock Island, is set to the beat of their bouncy ride through the Iowa countryside. Tightly choreographed and precisely sung in this production, it is a delightful introduction to a clever musical that celebrates the joys of rhythm, rhyme and syncopation.

title: Video: Nickolas Butlers Wintry Place on Earth
description: EAU CLAIRE, Wis.  As Nickolas Butler explains it, he actually began Shotgun Lovesongs, his debut novel about the gravitational pull of a small Wisconsin town on a group of friends, in Iowa, with a fit of homesickness. He was in his first semester at the University of Iowa Writers Workshop, in a class with James Alan McPherson.

title: Last Bohemian Turns Out the Lights
description: At the end of March, Clayton Patterson, the outlaw artist, was sitting in the window of his storefront home on Essex Street complaining about New York. Its something Mr. Patterson does well. He is an accomplished ranter, whose disputes with the city are numerous and varied but tend to revolve around the ruination of the Lower East Side by luxury apartments, ugly corporate chain stores, overpriced parking meters, pretentious restaurants and college students who vomit on the street.

title: Scrambling for a New Site
description: The moment Lisa Goldstein walked into the grand old former synagogue that is the Angel Orensanz Foundation for the Arts on the Lower East Side, she was in love. Ms. Goldstein, 33, said, I always joked I picked the venue before the groom. She and her fianc, Keith Helman, 34, had booked the space for April 5, 2014. Invitations were sent. A Monique Lhuillier dress was picked out. Peter Callahan, the celebrity caterer, was booked.

title: For Lettermans Job, Dueling 10-Best Lists
description: It is now officially the most coveted job in television: successor to David Letterman. Let the maneuvering begin.

title: New Yorks Police Department Has Been Watching
description: New York Citys Department of Records and Information Services released Friday thousands of newly digitized images, including ones collected in the 30s and 40s by the Bureau of Criminal Alien Investigation.

title: The Few, the Brave: Men in Tights
description: Given the winters crazy cold, it was hardly surprising to see men layering black sports tights under shorts for their workouts and outdoor runs  sensible, even. What was more of a shock was to see some of those men take the look out of the gym, incorporating it into their daily street wear.

title: Parting Glance: Anja Niedringhaus
description: Anja Niedringhaus, a Pulitzer Prize-winning photographer for The Associated Press, was killed in Eastern Afghanistan today when an Afghan policeman approached her vehicle at a security checkpoint and opened fire with a Kalashnikov assault rifle. The German native was 48 years old.

title: Who Are You on Facebook Now?
description: On his drivers license and passport, at his doctors office and insurance company, for online dating and social media, and on every application or document that requires checking a box for gender, 24-year-old Ryley Pogensky is a male. But to his friends on Facebook, he is now a trans man.

title: Banking on My Future as a Father
description: When are you going to have one of these? a friend asked a few months ago, referring to the 10-month-old crying baby in her arms.

title: Apple and Samsung Fight Over Who Was the Follower
description: Last year, a member of Apples sales team prepared a research document expressing concern about the growth in sales of smartphones with larger screens, while sales in the segment of phones including the iPhone were slowing down.

title: Corrosion Risk Prompts Ford Recall, and Spiders Clog Mazdas
description: Ford is recalling nearly 386,000 Escape sport utility vehicles from the 2001-4 model years because a corrosion problem could result in a loss of steering. The company is also recalling 49,000 vehicles from the 2013-14 model years because the seat backs are not strong enough, the automaker said in a news release on Friday.

title: A Power Lunch, Times Two
description: Talk about a high-concept lunch date: bring Nancy Pelosi, who from 2007 until 2011 was the first woman to serve as speaker of the House (she is now the minority leader), together with Julia Louis-Dreyfus, the actress who plays the vice president (and as-yet-unannounced presidential candidate) on the HBO comedy Veep, whose third season begins Sunday. Of course, Ms. Louis-Dreyfus has real-life rank, too, having won four Emmy Awards for her work on three television comedies: Seinfeld and The New Adventures of Old Christine as well as Veep.

title: Master Drawings as Springboard for Invention
description: It was only in the last century that drawing became a respectable, stand-alone medium. Before that, it was treated as an educational tool or as preparation for larger works. Drawings were often discarded and rarely signed, creating problems for curators and opportunities for enterprising forgers.

title: Death of a Pied Piper
description: Frankie Knuckles, the veteran club D.J. who died Monday at the age of 59 of complications from diabetes, may have ruled the underground club scene, but his death was mourned very publicly.

title: The No More Tears Formula for Yoga Wear
description: The moment of tears in the clothing-store dressing room has started at least a million diets. But for Alissa Benishai, a real estate developer, it started a business.

title: Its My Birthday. Id Like That Shirt in Blue.
description: When Jordan Weinstein turned 32, he did not send out invitations, host a party or even have a few friends over for cake. That all struck him as unnecessary and indulgent. What he did do, however, was register for gifts at REI, the sporting goods store, and then distribute the link to his mother, fiance and brother to pass around.

title: The Found Art of Thank-You Notes
description: When Jimmy Fallon sits down to write his weekly thank-you notes on The Tonight Show, he is both ribbing and breathing life into a custom many felt was headed the way of the dodo. Thank you, cotton candy, Mr. Fallon scribbles on a correspondence card, for making my grandmothers hair look delicious. Thank you, bowling, for giving me an excuse to drink with somebody elses shoes on.

title: Under Cover: Taking On Wall Street
description: This weeks cover story tells how a small group of Royal Bank of Canada employees uncovered and then set out to counter the unfair advantages of high-frequency trading in the stock market. Brad Katsuyama, a former trader at the bank, is one of the main players in Michael Lewiss story and is featured on this weeks cover.

title: Nineties Nostalgia Propels Coogi Brand Resurgence
description: Ugly sweater party? Please. For another example of how 90s nostalgia is propelling street wear and high-end fashion, consider Coogi knitwear, instantly recognizable for its rainbow of snarls and swirls.

title: Student, Athlete and Employee?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Truth About Venezuela, as Marco Rubio Sees It
description: To the Editor:

title: Starting Duda Pays Off as Mets Win Their First
description: In the midst of a miserable first week of the season, the Mets tried to eliminate at least one potential controversy by naming Lucas Duda as the starting first baseman on Friday. The protracted battle between Duda and Ike Davis threatened to be a distraction to a team fraught with bullpen, hitting and attendance issues.

title: Sign of Spring on Pay: Real Wage Growth
description: Jeff Dworkin, a Dallas builder, was surprised to find someone he didnt recognize inside a half-finished house this winter where crews were about to texture the homes drywall.

title: The Dieting Supremacist. Hate Her.
description: Ive lost almost 20 pounds in the last year  you still reading?  and I cannot tell you the contempt I feel when I see lesser beings stuffing their mouths with French fries and T-bone steak and pain au chocolat. Pain au chocolat is my favorite thing on earth. If I am ever sentenced to death for, say, kicking a teenage boy on Rollerblades in front of a truck, I will be requesting it as my last meal.

title: Money Wins, Peace Loses
description: This was a week for cynics to shrug their shoulders. In Washington, the conservative majority on the Supreme Court struck down aggregate limits on individual campaign contributions, arguing in effect that these denied the very rich their right to participate fully in the political process. And in the Middle East, John Kerry became the latest in a long line of secretaries of state to watch his or her peace process founder in the deep fog of Israeli-Palestinian recriminations and distrust.

title: Airport Workers March on a Symbolic Day
Iran: Border Guards Released by Pakistani Militants
description: Four of five Iranian border guards seized by Pakistani militants along the volatile Iran-Pakistan frontier two months ago have been released, Iran state media reported Friday. The captors claimed to have executed one of the border guards. Irans government-run Press TV website quoted Esmail Kosari, deputy chairman of a parliamentary committee on national security and foreign policy, as saying that the other four had been handed over to Iranian officials in Pakistan. It was not immediately clear why they had been released, and there was no confirmation from Pakistans government. The abductions on Feb. 6 caused deep strains in relations between Iran and Pakistan, and the Iranians had threatened to send troops into Pakistani territory to rescue the captives. The border area, in Sistan-Baluchistan Province in southeastern Iran, is a hotbed of Sunni militant resistance to Irans Shiite authorities. In October, Iran executed 16 Sunni insurgents in retaliation for an attack by armed men who crossed the border from Pakistan and killed 14 Iranian border guards near the city of Saravan.

title: Bill Cunningham | At Face Value
description: The fact is, fashion is commerce. But it can also be wearable art.

title: Judge Loath to Permit TV Testimony on Islamist
description: The testimony of a key prosecution witness in the terrorism trial of a radical Islamic cleric has been thrown into doubt because a federal judge in Manhattan is balking at allowing him to testify from Britain via closed-circuit television.

title: Bill Cunningham | At Face Value
description: The fact is, fashion is commerce. But students (above) waiting to get into a show in Paris have yet to discover that it is not an art form, although some looks at the shows there resemble walking sculptures that perhaps should be shown at the Venice Biennale: Issey Miaykes Tree Ring pleated dresses, Gareth Pugh, Rick Owens and Junya Watanabe. Comme des Garons has completely abandoned wearable clothes for wearable sculptures. That labels work resembles that of Chakaia Booker, an American artist. Around Paris, other examples of fashion as art include, bottom row, faces in color.

title: Evening Hours | Bring On the Greenery
description: Protecting the oceans, animals and art.

title: Lingering Hope vs. Onset of Grief Over Lost Flight
description: BEIJING  Steve Wang has not slept at his home in Beijing since Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 vanished with his mother on board. His days are a blur of rooms at the Lido Hotel: his suite on the 13th floor; the capacious ballroom, where Malaysian officials hold briefings; quiet corners where he has anguished meetings with other passengers relatives also living at the hotel. There are meals in between, though he said he no longer felt hunger.

title: Wheel of Fortune: A New Way to Play Ivy Roulette
description: To the Editor:

title: Safety Labels on Generic Drugs
Beer Franchise Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Believe Boy, 16, Killed Deliveryman
description: A 16-year-old and two older teenagers were arrested on Friday on murder charges in the fatal shooting of a deliveryman on a desolate street on the north shore of Staten Island, the police said.

title: Before Joining a Board, Size Up the Job and the Mission
description: IN the last five years, Keith T. Banks, the president of U.S. Trust, a private wealth management division of Bank of America, has done what many of the firms wealthy clients do: He has joined nonprofit boards. Hes up to four. Yet the boards he sits on are not only different in mission, but also in size and expectations for trustees.

title: Viewing Video Games From Another Level
description: A benchmark for video games as cultural artifacts came in 2012 when the Museum of Modern Art in New York announced it had acquired 14 games for its collection. Depending on your perspective, the museum might be a little late in acknowledging the significance of video games  or early, compared with other art institutions. (The games were acquired by the museums department of architecture and design, putting them in the design category rather than alongside painting and sculpture.) Now, an ambitious survey of video games organized by the Smithsonian American Art Museum, and previously on view there, is at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers.

title: A Resolution at Last for a Fathers Unsettling Legacy
description: DOBSON, N.C.  Sometime in late 2012, feeling his mortality after two heart attacks, Joseph Corsbie realized that the moment had come to tell the story of the ashes. He had first heard it nearly 30 years earlier from his father, Walter. And only in the face of imminent death had Walter finally spoken, keeping his promise to never forget.

title: Second Maker of Car Seats Cites Buckle Flaw in Recall
description: The Evenflo Company is recalling almost 1.4 million child restraints because a balky buckle could make it hard to free the child in an emergency. But the manufacturer is refusing to recall rear-facing infant seats that use the same buckle, according to a report from Evenflo posted on Friday on the website of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: U.S. Eyes Afghan Vote, Seeking Amenable Ally
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has watched cautiously from the sidelines in the months leading up to Saturdays elections in Afghanistan, focusing instead on new crises in the Middle East and Ukraine, and no longer on the country that was a foreign policy priority when President Obama first entered office.

title: In Bid for Revote, Union Claims Tennessee Officials Frightened Workers
description: The United Automobile Workers has seized on leaked documents from Gov. Bill Haslam of Tennessee in its efforts to persuade the National Labor Relations Board to order a new unionization election at the Volkswagen plant in Chattanooga.

title: Charter School Refugees
description: LAST week, the New York State Legislature struck a deal ensuring that charter schools in New York City would have access to space, either in already crowded public school buildings or in rented spaces largely paid for by the city. Over the next few years, charters are expected to serve an increasing proportion of city students  perhaps as much as 10 percent. Which brings up the question: Is there a point at which fostering charter schools undermines traditional public schools and the children they serve?

title: Curtis Bill Pepper, Author, Reporter and Traveler, Is Dead at 96
description: Curtis Bill Pepper, an author and reporter who roamed Europe and the Middle East for more than 40 years writing about politics, film, art, the Vatican, Leonardo da Vinci and more, died on Friday at his home in Todi, Italy. He was 96.

title: Michael Lewiss Crusade
description: There is always something just a little frustrating about reading a Michael Lewis book. On the one hand, Lewiss core point  whether it is that left tackle has become the second most important position in football (The Blind Side), or that the stock market has become rigged by high-frequency traders, as his new book, Flash Boys, claims  is almost always dead-on. His ability to find compelling characters and tell a great story through their eyes is unparalleled. He can untangle complex subjects like few others. His prose sparkles.

title: Personality and Change Inflamed Mozilla Crisis
description: Mozilla is not your typical Silicon Valley company.

title: All in the Family, Sort Of
description: Heres the latest life lesson from the campaign trail: If you are, say, making a home movie about how great your family is, try to remember to use pictures of your actual relatives, and not random attractive strangers.

title: Grandstanding on Prisons in Texas
description: Rick Perry, the Republican governor of Texas, is gearing up for the 2016 presidential elections by bellowing about imaginary overreach from Washington and refusing to comply with the Prison Rape Elimination Act of 2003.

title: Army Base Shooting Highlights Difficulty in Identifying At-Risk Soldiers
description: The case of the Army specialist who opened fire with a .45-caliber Smith & Wesson handgun at Fort Hood on Wednesday is casting light on the difficulties the military has had in identifying soldiers at high risk of violence and deciding whether to restrict their access to firearms.

title: Brooklyn Tough
description: Heather Hardy, 5 feet 5 inches of determination, began boxing in 2010 and is on a roll, undefeated after nine professional fights..

title: Judge Says Ohio Must Recognize Same-Sex Marriages Performed Out of State
description: A federal judge in Cincinnati declared Friday that he would require Ohio to recognize same-sex marriages performed legally in other states, the latest in a series of court decisions around the country overturning restrictive state marriage laws and amendments.

title: Applications Fall and Admission Rate Rises as Cooper Union Charges Tuition
description: The results are in for the first big test of Cooper Unions new era  the era in which students actually pay to attend  and the university appears to have scored about 80 percent.

title: Polarizing Wildcats Find Their Way Together
description: RICHMOND, Tex.  On a cul-de-sac in a leafy residential subdivision in this booming oil town 30 miles west of Houston, Andrew and Aaron Harrison were raised to look out for each other, as perhaps only identical twins could.

title: 3 Soldiers Identified as Victims of Shooting
description: The Army on Friday identified the three people killed in a shooting rampage at Fort Hood as decorated soldiers who had served multiple tours of duty overseas.

title: Grand Jury Questions Christie Aide in an Inquiry
description: The chief spokesman for Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey appeared before a grand jury in Newark on Friday to answer questions in the federal inquiry into the George Washington Bridge lane closing scandal.

title: Hand-to-Hand Coordination
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Ive never had a crossword puzzle make me think of the actor Keanu Reeves right off the bat, but thats exactly what Ashton Andersons and James Mulherns grid did for me. The WHOA at 1 Across, made even more Keanu-y by the Bill and Teds Excellent Adventure clue Thats crazy, dude! got Mr. Reeves stuck in my head while I tackled the northwest corner.

title: Saturdays Highlights: From 4 to 2
description: If top-seeded Florida is to win its third national title in nine seasons, it must first topple No. 7 Connecticut, which dealt the Gators their last loss, on Dec. 2, before defeating either No. 2 Wisconsin, the only other team to beat the Gators this season, or No. 8 Kentucky, which has lost all three matchups with Florida this season.

title: French Push U.N. to Seek War Crimes Case in Syria
description: UNITED NATIONS  France has taken the first steps toward proposing a Security Council resolution that would refer Syria to the International Criminal Court for the prosecution of war crimes, diplomats said Friday, an action long sought by rights advocates.

title: We Were Just Laughing: Days With Anja Niedringhaus and Kathy Gannon
description: It is heartbreaking to call friends and colleagues in Kabul on a day like this. The connection from the United States is bad and I can barely catch their words. I was just there with them all earlier this week, laughing and swapping stories with two veteran journalists, Anja Niedringhaus and Kathy Gannon of The Associated Press, longtime fellow chroniclers of events in Afghanistan.

title: Waiting for the Markets to Blink
description: HEADING into the second quarter, investors seem to have little conviction about the direction of stock and bond markets. Both ended the first three months of 2014 barely changed, despite a big change in Federal Reserve policy.

title: My Bitcoin Befuddlement
description: AM I the only person in the world who doesnt have Bitcoin jangling in a cryptographic wallet? Sometimes it seems that way.

title: Complaints Build as a Cathedral Project Begins Its Rise
description: Laurie Frey heard jackhammers one morning this week and raced down the block to find demolition workers preparing to cut down the tall trees on the lot next to the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine. She realized what the power saws meant: A project to build a second apartment complex on the cathedral grounds was finally beginning.

title: Seeking Silver Linings in Emerging Markets
description: IN a quarter in which most stock funds eked out small gains, emerging-market equity portfolios couldnt even manage that much.

title: When Bond Funds Think Outside the Box
description: UNCONSTRAINED bond funds can own debt instruments of any type  long- or short-term, high- or low-quality, corporate or government or whatever, in any country and currency  to try to enhance returns. With interest rates near record lows and investors eager to bolster yields, enthusiasm for these portfolios, also known as nontraditional funds, seems boundless too.

title: Technology That Transforms Life (and Mutual Funds Returns)
description: TECHNOLOGY that transforms industries or consumers lives is an important investing theme these days. The managers of three mutual funds  Fidelity OTC Portfolio, Lord Abbett Micro Cap Growth and Driehaus Micro Cap Growth  have all focused on it, and their approach put them among the performance leaders in the first quarter.

title: How E.T.F.s Have Gained Momentum
description: MUTUAL funds in the United States held $15.2 trillion in February. Exchange-traded funds were tiny by comparison, with only $1.7 trillion.

title: Retirement Advice, Without the Sugarcoating
description: THERE are two overwhelmingly appealing things about Carrie Schwab-Pomerantzs new personal finance book, which is aimed at those 50 and over.

title: The Biggest Dividends Arent Necessarily the Best
description: RISK-AVERSE investors seeking steady income have had little to cheer about in recent years.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 4, 2014
description: April 4, 2014

title: Dreaming of a Maserati, but Staying the Course
description: I GAINED access to a windfall the other day. And after fantasizing briefly about all the things I could buy, Ive decided not to touch the money.

title: New Global Aids Chief for U.S. Assumes Post
description: Dr. Deborah Birx, a former chief for global AIDS for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, was sworn in on Friday as the nations global AIDS coordinator. The post puts Dr. Birx, a former Army colonel, in charge of the Presidents Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief and American participation in the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria. A vast majority of all funds spent on global health come from those two organizations. Dr. Birx is the fourth to hold the post, which was created under the George W. Bush administration. It is in the State Department and carries ambassadorial rank. Dr. Eric Goosby, the last coordinator, resigned in November. His predecessor, Dr. Mark Dybul, is now executive director of the Global Fund, which is based in Geneva.

title: Lawmakers Deserve More Pay, Congressman Says
description: Representative James P. Moran says members of Congress cannot live decently in Washington on their $174,000 salary and deserve more money. Their pay has been frozen since 2010, and Mr. Moran, a Virginia Democrat who is not seeking re-election, told Roll Call that he would introduce a measure that would provide members with a per diem allowance. The fact is that this is the board of directors for the largest economic entity in the world, Mr. Moran said.

title: Pros Example Keeps Connecticuts Foul Shooting Sharp
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Whether Connecticut has better 3-point shooters than Florida, or better rebounders or ball handlers, is up for debate. This much about their matchup Saturday night, though, is unassailable: The Huskies are the superior free-throw shooting team.

title: Judge Dismisses Suit Against Administration Officials Over Drone Strikes
description: WASHINGTON  A federal judge on Friday dismissed a lawsuit against top Obama administration officials that was filed by the parents of three United States citizens whom the government killed without trial in drone strikes, including Anwar al-Awlaki, a radical Muslim cleric.

title: Creatures Great, Small and Imagined
description: Nearly 700 pounds and 15 feet long, the blue marlin lay on the deck of a fishing boat off the coast of Cape Verde as James Prosek snapped photographs, made sketches and took measurements. Awe-struck and moved, he watched the giant fishs colors fade from their living vibrancy to the muted tones of death.

title: Mouse Infestation Closes Birthplace of the Cronut
description: New York City residents and tourists are apparently not alone in their love of Cronuts, those croissant-and-doughnut hybrids that have people lined up for blocks before dawn outside a SoHo bakery.

title: Knicks Fall to Washington, and Drop Behind Atlanta
description: Carmelo Anthony was able to string together so many good days and nights for the Knicks that it almost came to be taken for granted. But when the Knicks desperately needed Anthony, facing a must-have game against the Washington Wizards with the schedule dwindling to a handful of dates, he struggled to play through an injury to his right shoulder and was ultimately unable to provide another big effort.

title: Rocked at Start, Tanaka Finds Rhythm and Lifts Yankees to Win
description: TORONTO  Three pitches into Masahiro Tanakas major league career, one thing was clear on Friday. As good as he may be, and as much faith as the Yankees had in him to commit $175 million for his services, Tanaka is not unhittable.

title: Fewer Pupils Qualify for Gifted Programs
description: The numbers of children qualifying for seats in gifted programs in New York City public schools declined this year, the Education Department said on Friday, though they were still far higher than when citywide admissions testing began a few years ago.

title: As Critics Vent, Maple Leafs Take Deep Breaths
description: TORONTO  The fading playoff hopes of the Toronto Maple Leafs rest with the backup goaltender James Reimer, who was vilified by some frustrated, overzealous fans two weeks ago in a series of nasty messages sent to his wifes Twitter account.

title: James Benkard Dies at 76; Defended Inmates in Death Penalty Cases
description: James W. B. Benkard, a prominent New York corporate lawyer who was honored for his extensive pro bono work in cases involving the death penalty and prisoners with mental illness, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 76.

title: Rough Start Aside, an Elite Debut
description: Masahiro Tanakas adjustment period to Major League Baseball appeared to last about three innings.

title: Corrections: April 5, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 9 P.M. (HBO) MAN OF STEEL (2013) The director Zack Snyder traces the path of Clark Kent, portrayed by a ripped Henry Cavill, above, from boy to man  and superhero status  in this newfangled origin story. Russell Crowe and Ayelet Zurer play Jor-El and Lara Lor-Van, the birth parents of Clark, who was born Kal-El on the doomed planet Krypton; Diane Lane and Kevin Costner are Martha and Jonathan Kent, the Kansas couple who adopt him after hes rocketed to Earth; Amy Adams is his romantic interest, Lois Lane; and Michael Shannon is General Zod, his alien foe. At once frantically overblown and beautifully filigreed, Man of Steel will turn on everyone it doesnt turn off, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. If you wave away all the computer-generated smoke and see past the pulverized buildings, its possible to remain hooked on the resonant origin story that wends through Man of Steel  that of the immigrant. And while Mr. Snyder isnt capable of mythmaking, she added, in his sometimes poetic, sometimes crude way, he has given Superman a new lease on franchise life by affirming that this most American hero is also an alien yearning to breathe free.

title: 4 Killed After Car Plunges Into Creek, Police Say
description: Four people died on Friday night after the car they were riding in veered off a rain-slicked road, hit a curb and flipped into a creek off the East River, authorities said.

title: Afghan Turnout Is High as Voters Defy the Taliban
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Defying a campaign of Taliban violence that unleashed 39 suicide bombers in the two months before Election Day, Afghan voters on Saturday turned out in such high numbers to choose a new president and provincial councils that polling hours were extended nationwide, in a triumph of determination over intimidation.

title: U.S. Response to Crimea Worries Japans Leaders
description: TOKYO  When President Bill Clinton signed a 1994 agreement promising to respect the territorial integrity of Ukraine if it gave up its nuclear weapons, there was little thought then of how that obscure diplomatic pact  called the Budapest Memorandum  might affect the long-running defense partnership between the United States and Japan.

title: Minding the Minders of G.M.
description: There is a truism in Washington that was confirmed last week in Congress: Even less popular than government regulation is a regulator suspected of not doing its job.

title: Analytics: Taking Sides
description: The following Analytics appears on the letters page in the April 6 issue of the magazine.

title: Ship Reports Getting Signal That Could Be Black Box of Missing Jet
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  Australian authorities coordinating the multinational search for the missing Malaysia Airlines plane in the southern Indian Ocean said Sunday that they were investigating three reports by ships in the search flotilla that underwater sensors had picked up signals that could be from the planes data and voice recorders.

title: Detroit and Its Art Treasures
description: Detroit and Its Art Treasures

title: The Frustrations of a Part-Timer
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: Paid for Playing Games
description: David Hanson,28, is a game app developer at Concrete Software in Eden Prairie, Minn.

title: An Economic Gauge, Imperfect but Vital
description: In G.D.P.: A Brief but Affectionate History, Diane Coyle, a British economist, conveys a sophisticated understanding of an economic standby, the quarterly measure of gross domestic product. A vital gauge of any nations prosperity, the G.D.P. has its strengths and its limitations, which are well explained in Dr. Coyles rich and engaging little book.

title: Automation Alone Isnt Killing Jobs
description: Although the labor market report on Friday showed modest job growth, employment opportunities remain stubbornly low in the United States, giving new prominence to the old notion that automation throws people out of work.

title: The Oracle of Omaha, Lately Looking a Bit Ordinary
description: Warren Buffett is probably the most famous investor of his generation, and for good reason: His track record over the long term is a thing of beauty.

title: Kim Bowers of CST Brands, on Managing Up vs. Managing Down
description: This interview with  Kim Bowers, chief executive of CST Brands, a gas-station and convenience-store retailer, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: I Had a Nice Time With You Tonight. On the App.
description: Last Sunday, I spent a lazy afternoon with my boyfriend. We chatted while I made brunch, discussed the books we were reading, laughed at some cat pictures and then settled down with dinner, before bidding each other good night.

title: The Wallet as Ethics Enforcer
description: There is a lot we dont yet know about the disastrous decisions made by General Motors after it became aware of faulty ignition switches in its Chevrolet Cobalts more than 10 years ago.

title: Space Chips for the Common Man
description: Moores Law is taking over space.

title: 2 Italian Priests and a Canadian Nun Are Abducted in Cameroon
description: ROME  Two Italian priests and a Canadian nun were abducted early Saturday from their mission in northern Cameroon, the Italian government and Vatican officials said.

title: Journeyman on the PGA Tour Downsizes His Life and Upgrades His Game
description: Last Sunday in San Antonio, as Will MacKenzie played into contention at the Texas Open, he tried to keep thoughts of the Masters out of his head. He was tied for second after a final-round 70, and then waited for the leader, Steven Bowditch, to finish.

title: For Soprano, From Butterfly to Bohme, in a Flash
description: Last-minute cast changes at opera houses are always full of drama, but the one that took place in Saturday afternoons performance of Puccinis La Bohme at the Metropolitan Opera promises to go down in the annals of day-of-the-performance substitutions.

title: Variety: A Well-Furnished Acrostic
description: Administrivial New Acrostic Web Game Alert! Have you noticed that the New York Times Acrostic game has had a facelift? Its not dependent on Java, and is really easy and fun to play! You can give it a try here.

title: Vivendi Chooses to Sell Mobile Phone Unit to Altice, Ending Noisy Bidding War
description: After a bidding war, the French media conglomerate Vivendi said Saturday that it would sell its mobile phone unit, SFR, to Altice in a deal worth as much as 17 billion euros, or about $23.3 billion.

title: As Their Numbers Fall, College Basketballs Black Coaches Face a Conundrum
description: Sometime around 1989, a small group of black coaches and writers began a Final Four tradition. We would meet, at coffee houses, snack shops, dimly lit restaurants, and talk into the hours of the morning about issues affecting young black athletes.

title: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 68
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Despite Support in Party, Democratic Governors Resist Legalizing Marijuana
description: LOS ANGELES  California voters strongly favor legalizing marijuana. The state Democratic Party adopted a platform last month urging California to follow Colorado and Washington in ending marijuana prohibition. The states lieutenant governor, Gavin Newsom, has called for legalizing the drug.

title: The Chatter for Sunday, April 6
description: The recovery still feels like a recession to many Americans and it also looks that way in some economic statistics.

title: For Knicks, Mediocrity Is No Bar to Postseason
description: Carmelo Anthony and his teammates represent the 68th Knicks team. Surprisingly, they still have a chance to become the 43rd to make the playoffs. Of those 43, they would be the seventh to have a losing record. And of those with losing records, they almost certainly would be the worst of the bunch.

title: First Reviews Confirm Replay as a Strategy, Not a Cure-All
