description: The least shocking news of the first full week of the baseball season should be this: The new instant replay system did not reverse every missed call. That was not the intent.

title: Family Connection Breaks Ground at Masters
description: For Craig Stadler and his firstborn, Kevin, golf is the multivitamin that renews their father-and-son relationship. Like countless others, the Stadlers will converge on a golf course this week from different states and different stages of their careers to play a few rounds and catch up on each others hectic lives.

title: War Pain Yields to New Anxiety Inside Ft. Hood
description: KILLEEN, Tex.  Pastor Randall Wallace of the First Baptist Church of Killeen has watched thousands of troops head off to war and then come home to Fort Hood, the mammoth military base that shares this patch of Central Texas with an unpretentious jumble of pawn shops, fast food joints and vinyl-sided bungalows.

title: In Womens Final Four, Jousting Before the First Jump Ball
description: NASHVILLE  Not long after Muffet McGraw won her first and only national championship in 2001, she was cold-called by Paul Gullifor, a Notre Dame loyalist, womens basketball aficionado, college professor and author.

title: O Caddie! My Caddie!
description: Tempo, rhythm and timing.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: For the Devils, Shootouts Become a No-Win Mind Game
description: The Devils have a case of the yips. Not your garden variety, as with a golfer losing his putting touch. This one runs through the whole team and has been going on all season.

title: Encouraging Debut and Frustrating Loss for Yankees
description: TORONTO  The return of Michael Pineda after two years of rehabilitation was supposed to be the final sign that the Yankees had recovered their health and that the numerous injuries that plagued them in 2013 were a thing of the past.

title: John Caliparis Trip to the Final, Step by Agonizing Step
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  John Calipari descended five steps from the court at AT&T Stadium, passed a marching band, 14 rows of seats and a towering stanchion of stands before lurching into a tunnel. He banked right, shuffled down a long, curved corridor and then, only then, did he reach the door to the Kentucky Wildcats locker room.

title: A Fairer Pay System?
description: Readers discuss the huge disparity in pay

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 6
description: Fort Hood, Tex., suffered a devastating blow this week when Specialist Ivan Antonio Lopez opened fire at the Army base, killing three and wounding 16 of his fellow soldiers, then taking his own life. Five years ago, another soldier went on a similar shooting rampage at Fort Hood, killing 13 people. On Thursday, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel struggled to explain why new security measures had not been effective.

title: Her First, and Last, Book
description: TWO years ago, Marina Keegans life brimmed with promise. She was graduating with high honors from Yale University, already a precocious writer about to take up a job at The New Yorker.

title: The Trauma of Being the Also-Ran
description: IT was March 1997. I unlocked my apartment door, petted the dog and hit play on my answering machine.

title: Hypocritical Tax Cuts
description: On Thursday, a strong bipartisan majority in the Senate Finance Committee voted to reinstate dozens of temporary tax breaks that had expired at the end of 2013. The package, mainly tax cuts for businesses, included sensible items like tax credits for the production of wind energy and other alternative fuels, and for research and development. It also included special-interest giveaways and some silly stuff like bigger write-offs for racehorses. But whats particularly outrageous is that the bill calls for the government to borrow the entire $85 billion cost of the two-year reinstatement.

title: The Trick of Life
description: SEVEN years into writing a novel, I started to lose my mind. My thirty-seventh birthday had just come and gone, the end of 2008 was approaching, and I was constantly aware of how little I had managed to accomplish.

title: Policing the Sport of Kings and Knaves
description: The abuse and doping of thoroughbred horses has become so pervasive at racetracks that the Jockey Club, the sports most influential voice, is endorsing federal legislation to put the United States Anti-Doping Agency in charge of cleaning up the industry.

title: Note to Republicans: Channel Jack Kemp
description: WHEN Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, delivered a speech last month outlining proposals for economic growth, his sponsor was the Jack F. Kemp Foundation, a Beltway organization set up in memory of the Republican politician who died in 2009 and has recently been cited as a hero by some of the partys most prominent figures.

title: Sheldon: Irans Best Friend
description: IT occurred to me the other day that the zealously pro-Israel billionaire Sheldon Adelson and Irans supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, actually have one big thing in common. They are both trying to destroy Israel. Adelson is doing it by loving Israel to death and Khamenei by hating Israel to death. And now even Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey inadvertently got drawn into this craziness.

title: Sanjit (Bunker) Roy
description: Sanjit (Bunker) Roy is an Indian social reformer and founder of Barefoot College, an organization that trains the poor, particularly poor women, to become self-sufficient through education and training. He has trained grandmothers, from sub-Saharan Africa to the Himalayas, to be solar engineers so they can both literally and figuratively be the source of power in their remote villages.

title: When Coziness With Sources Is a Conflict
description: IN theory, most serious journalists can agree on this principle: Its a bad idea to get too close to your sources. Cordiality, yes; coziness, no.

title: Health Care Without End
description: SO you think its finished? So you think now that enrollment has hit seven million, now that the president has declared the debate over repeal over, now that Republican predictions of a swift Obamacare unraveling look a bit like Republican predictions of a Romney landslide, were going to stop arguing about health care, stop having the issue dominate the conversation, and turn at last to some other debate instead?

title: As Vermont Goes, So Goes the Nation?
description: WHEN most liberals hear the words third party, they have nasty flashbacks to Ralph Naders spoiler campaign in 2000. The history buffs among them might think of the populist Greenback Partys feckless protests against the gold standard in the 19th century or the five presidential campaigns of the Socialist Eugene V. Debs  the last of which, in 1920, he ran from prison.

title: Bring Me My Dragons!
description: WASHINGTON  ID been hoping to get the flu.

title: The New Gay Orthodoxy
description: TO appreciate how rapidly the ground has shifted, go back just two short years, to April 2012. President Obama didnt support marriage equality, not formally. Neither did Hillary Clinton. And few people were denouncing them as bigots whose positions rendered them too divisive, offensive and regressive to lead.

title: A Rationalists Mystical Moment
description: MY atheism is hard-core, rooted in family tradition rather than adolescent rebellion. According to family legend, one of my 19th-century ancestors, a dirt-poor Irish-American woman in Montana, expressed her disgust with the church by vehemently refusing last rites when she lay dying in childbirth. From then on, we were atheists and rationalists, a stance I perpetuated by opting, initially, for a career in science.

title: What Life in the Real World Costs
description: I APPLIED to college sitting on the carpeted stairway of our apartment, yelling down questions to my mother. Mom, am I anything?

title: Capitalize Workers!
description: Raising the minimum wage has justifiably captured policy makers attention, but if the goal is to materially raise living standards for every American worker, we should also be calling for a minimum pension. Done right, this would not only create real wealth for the middle and working classes, it would use the power of financial markets to reduce wealth disparity instead of widening it.

title: Like, Degrading the Language? No Way
description: IF there is one thing that unites Americans of all stripes, it is the belief that, whatever progress our country might be making, we are moving backward on language. Just look at the crusty discourse level of comments sections and the recreational choppiness of text messages and hit pop songs.

title: One Afghan Womans Voice
description: Despite Taliban threats, Afghans turned out across the country Saturday to vote for a new president. Shukria Barakzai, one of the female members of the Afghan Parliament, prepared to vote.

title: Yes He Can, on Immigration
description: If President Obama means what he says about wanting an immigration system that reflects American values, helps the economy and taps the yearnings of millions of Americans-in-waiting, he is going to have to do something about it  soon and on his own. It has been frustrating to watch his yes-we-can promises on immigration reform fade to protestations of impotence and the blaming of others. All Mr. Obama has been saying lately is: No, in fact, we cant, because Republicans and the law wont let me.

title: In Europe, Echoes of America as Concussions Spur Debate
description: LONDON  The debate over how to respond to the growing research linking brain trauma to injuries sustained in sports has spread to Europe, with many of the same dynamics seen in recent years as the issue gained momentum in the United States.

title: Points for Product Placement: N.C.A.A. Cashes In, but Not the Players
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The new champions of mens college basketball, whoever they may be, will cut down a net here Monday night. And when they do, they will climb to the basket on a blue-and-yellow Werner ladder, and they will clip the cords with a pair of orange Fiskars scissors.

title: Stanford Star Makes Campus Her Stage
description: STANFORD, Calif.  Chiney Ogwumike was not yet a year old, standing contentedly in a baby walker next to her father, who was eating pizza while they watched television. Except that Ogwumike was not watching television. She was watching the slice of pizza in her dads hand.

title: Under Revised Quake Estimates, Dozens of Nuclear Reactors Face Costly Safety Analyses
description: WASHINGTON  Owners of at least two dozen nuclear reactors across the United States, including the operator of Indian Point 2, in Buchanan, N.Y., have told the Nuclear Regulatory Commission that they cannot show that their reactors would withstand the most severe earthquake that revised estimates say they might face, according to industry experts.

title: U.N. Leader Urges Action in Central African Republic
description: The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, arrived in the Central African Republic on Saturday in an effort to drum up world support for an effort to stanch the widening sectarian conflict there.

title: If Tiger Woods Were Healthy, Oh, the Places He Could Go
description: When golfers win consistently or play well on a certain course, they like to say it fits my eye, meaning that the shape of the fairways and the nuances of the greens blend with their swings and their senses. And for Tiger Woods, stalled at 14 for six years in his passionate pursuit of Jack Nicklauss record 18 major victories, this was supposed to be the year when the stars were aligned for him to win another major or two, when the course for each of the four major tournaments fit his eye.

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking: April 4, 2014
description: General Motors says it has connected 13 deaths and dozens of accidents to a defective ignition switch. The company, led by a new C.E.O., is now recalling millions of Chevy Cobalts, despite reports that the problem has stretched back more than a decade.

title: Even Small Medical Advances Can Mean Big Jumps in Bills
description: MEMPHIS  Catherine Hayley is saving up for an important purchase: an updated version of the tiny digital pump at her waist that delivers lifesaving insulin under her skin.

title: Having Close to 50 Wins May Not Be Good Enough in West
description: LOS ANGELES  Brandan Wright says he remembers how good the Golden State Warriors felt about themselves when he was a rookie in the 2007-8 season. They were the N.B.A.s top-scoring team. They had won 48 games  the franchises best record in 14 seasons and a six-game improvement over the previous one, when they had upset the top-seeded Dallas Mavericks in the Western Conference playoffs.

title: Voices Emerging Against a Union
description: EVANSTON, Ill.  Northwesterns football coach, Pat Fitzgerald, has urged players to vote no in a secret ballot union election scheduled for later this month, he said Saturday.

title: To Strike at Kochs, Democrats Revive Tactic That Hurt Romney
description: WASHINGTON  After months of wincing in the face of negative ads funded by the industrialists David and Charles Koch, Democrats believe they have finally found a way to fight back: attacking the brothers sprawling business conglomerate as callous and indifferent to the lives of ordinary people while pursuing profit and power.

title: When Money Talks, Game Is Drowned Out at Big Stadiums
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  When Steve Anderson arrived at AT&T Stadium on Saturday for the Final Four, he entered on the ground floor, then went up and up and up  and up again  to his seat in the upper tier.

title: Few Answers After 4 Die When Car Plunges Into Creek in Queens; Driver Survives
description: A car carrying five young friends returning from a birthday party plunged into a creek in Queens after the driver lost control on a rain-slicked road Friday night.

title: Grand Slam by Davis Seals Mets Ninth-Inning Rally Over Reds
description: After Lucas Duda, Ike Daviss competition to be the Mets first baseman, earned the starting job Friday, Davis watched him hit two home runs that night to stake a firm hold on the position.

title: Apathy and Fear of Taliban Combine to Keep Rural Voters Away From the Polls
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  While polling centers across Kabul and other Afghan cities were celebrating record turnouts on Saturday, Tahir Khan, a tribal leader in rural Nangarhar Province, experienced a very different Election Day.

title: A Posthumous Triumph
description: My Sunday column looks about the messageof seeking meaning and fulfillment in lifefrom a young woman who graduated from Yale two years ago, Marina Keegan. Marinas first book will be published this coming week, and its a call to life life to the fullest, to be idealistic when youre young and can be. Its a spirit I see in a lot of young people, and Im a big fan of this generation of young people. I think they have more idealism than many previous generations, but also more of a practical sense of how to actually get things done rather than engage in largely symbolic gesturesa very practical idealism, if you will. Marina embodied that. And I write of her in the past tense for reasons that become obvious in the column.

title: Technologys Man Problem
description: Elissa Shevinsky can pinpoint the moment when she felt that she no longer belonged.

title: Blast Near Falluja Kills 17 Iraq Troops
description: BAGHDAD  An explosion in a house west of Baghdad on Saturday killed 17 Iraqi soldiers who had sought cover during a clash with militants, officials said.

title: At Times
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Sundays are the only day that The New York Times crossword puzzle runs with a title and, the title is there in part to punnily help us figure out what were in for when we solve. Today, the title of this puzzle by Patrick Berry is fairly literal.

title: The Victims of Fort Hood
description: A gunman killed three people and wounded 16 others before killing himself at Fort Hood, the same sprawling Army base in Texas where in 2009 an officer went on a shooting rampage that left 13 people dead.

title: Tasting Early Success, Only to Walk Away
description: A victory at the World Junior Chess Championships can open the door to a life on the elite competitive circuit, as a list of past winners shows: Boris Spassky, Anatoly Karpov, Garry Kasparov, Viswanathan Anand, Levon Aronian.

title: Afraid It Was Missing the Boat, a City Tries to Catch the Bus
description: Arlington has long been among the largest American cities without public transportation. Since 1980, the citys voters have rejected transit proposals three times, with opponents citing fears ranging from costs to worries about an increase in crime.

title: Now in Drivers Seat, Patrick Credits Grass Roots
description: Almost eight years ago, before he became a state senator, Dan Patrick was known around the Texas Capitol as the Houston talk radio host who had shouted down a powerful committee chairman in the middle of a legislative hearing.

title: Civil Rights Sins, Curated by One of the Sinners
description: HATTIESBURG, Miss.  In the woods off Monroe Road, a truck is so rusted that it is melting into the earth. It was Vernon Dahmers truck, the one that he drove and that his family continued to use after his death, the circumstances of which can be inferred from the three penny-size holes in the back panel.

title: A Military Town: Bonded to Fort Hood
description: The town of Killeen, Tex., is adjacent to the Fort Hood military post. The towns economy and culture are closely connected to the base.

title: Delays in Effort to Refocus C.I.A. From Drone War
description: WASHINGTON  In the skies above Yemen, the Pentagons armed drones have stopped flying, a result of the ban on American military drone strikes imposed by the government there after a number of botched operations in recent years killed Yemeni civilians. But the Central Intelligence Agencys drone war in Yemen continues.

title: Log Jams Create Problems for Searchers
description: Gov. Jay Inslee of Washington and Lt. Richard Burke of the Bellevue Fire Department discussed the search in Oso, Wash., and explained how log jams have delayed the effort.

title: Finding Fellowship After Deadly Washington Mudslide
description: DARRINGTON, Wash.  The landslide on March 22 in the high slope above the community of Oso mowed down a forest. Trees great and small, splintered and tumbling, became part of the slides signature, in killing 30 people and leaving 13 others still missing.

title: For Center, 20 Years of Creating Vegetables
description: In 1983, after more than 10 years of research, a Texas A&M University horticulturist named Leonard Pike created an onion that did not make people cry. This alone was revolutionary, but Dr. Pike also conferred another attribute upon his plant progeny: a single center.

title: A Long Shot Nears Its Goal: UConn Topples Florida
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  During the singing of the national anthem Saturday, Connecticuts players stood in silence, heads down, arms around one another, lost in their thoughts. They swayed from side to side, as if at a revival  their own. All wore the same white long-sleeve T-shirt. It read, UConn Pride.

title: Sales-Tax Plan Would Redefine District Wealth
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Peter Matthiessen, Lyrical Writer and Naturalist, Is Dead at 86
description: Peter Matthiessen, a roving author and naturalist whose impassioned nonfiction explored the remote endangered wilds of the world and whose prizewinning fiction often placed his mysterious protagonists in the heart of them, died on Saturday at his home in Sagaponack, N.Y. He was 86.

title: As Town Mourns an Educator, It Celebrates a Close-Knit Community
description: DARRINGTON, Wash.  The long procession of funerals for victims of the Oso landslide began here and in the neighboring town of Arlington on Saturday.

title: A Change in Atmosphere in Central Syria
description: The boom of shelling no longer dominates the days and nights.

title: Relative Calm in Parts of Syria Is Deceptive
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  The change of atmosphere here in the Syrian capital is unmistakable. The boom of shelling no longer dominates the days and nights. Tensions over security are draining from the city like air from a balloon. Checkpoints remain ubiquitous but sentries are relaxed, even jocular, teasing strangers, Any bombs?

title: Citizenship-for-Cash Program in Malta Stirs Security Concerns in European Union
description: PARIS  A program in Malta that offers citizenship for cash is raising concern among officials who fear it could open a back door into Europe and the United States for swindlers, criminals or terrorists who can afford the price tag of up to $1.57 million.

title: Election in Hungary Tests Nations Tilt to the Right
description: BUDAPEST  While Europe was enmeshed in its years of euro crisis, Viktor Orban, Hungarys popular but controversial prime minister, tilted his countrys politics rightward, to a chorus of foreign and domestic criticism but little censure from the European Union.

title: With Upset at Wood Memorial, Wicked Strong Ensures Spot in Derby
description: Last fall, Jimmy Jerkens thought he had a horse that would take him to the Kentucky Derby, a colt by the name of Wicked Strong. This was the one that would make him forget about the last time he had circled the first Saturday of May at Churchill Downs  five years ago with a tender-footed runner named Quality Road.

title: Lawyer Sees No Revenge in an Arrest in New Delhi
description: The lawyer for a New York police officer arrested in India last month for having rounds of ammunition in his luggage said Indian officials were following the law in detaining his client, and not retaliating for the arrest of an Indian diplomat in New York last year.

title: Tending Their Wounds, Vowing to Fight On
description: KOBLENZ, Germany  Shot twice at the bloody denouement of Ukraines revolution, Yuri Kravchuk spends his days in the most pristine of hospital wards, gazing out the window at this orderly German city, churning images of battle through his mind.

title: Brazil Sends In Armed Forces to Assist in Policing Poor Area
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  About 2,700 members of Brazils security forces on Saturday occupied a slum complex that sits along two highways connecting Rios international airport to its main tourist zone.

title: Richard Brick, Who Drew Films Back to New York, Dies at 68
description: Richard Brick, a filmmaker and teacher who as the film commissioner of New York City in the early 1990s helped repair the citys strained relationship with Hollywood and bring film crews back from Toronto and other faux-New York locations, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 68.

title: Barbara Gibbons, 79, Writer of Slim Gourmet Cookbooks, Dies
description: Barbara Gibbons, the author of The Slim Gourmet syndicated column and cookbooks  and the original 208-pound customer for their low-calorie recipes  died on March 26 at her home in Dallas. She was 79.

title: Jesus Lives, but Should He Live in My Front Yard?
description: As I drove home from church, I eyed the bright foam sign my 6-year-old daughter held. Jesus is Alive it read in kid scrawl. Were supposed to put them in our yards! Noelle beamed, eyeing her creation proudly through pink-rimmed glasses.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 5, 2014
description: April 5, 2014

title: With a Spirited Garnett Back, the Healthy Nets Edge the 76ers
description: PHILADELPHIA  Kevin Garnetts coach and teammates were teasing himSaturday morning, calling him a rookie. It had been so long since Garnett, 37, had joined them on the court that he seemed like a new player on the Nets.

title: Zuccarello Provides Spark, but Clinching Must Wait
description: Mats Zuccarellos performance encapsulated a lot of what went right and what went wrong for the Rangers in their 3-2 loss to the Ottawa Senators on Saturday at Madison Square Garden. He scored twice, but he was also on the ice for all of the Senators goals.

title: With Late 3-Pointer, Kentucky Edges Wisconsin to Advance to Final
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Wisconsin Coach Bo Ryan had a player once who wanted to leave college early and go to the N.B.A. It was Devin Harris, in 2004, and he was a junior.

title: Judith Orlando and John Tamagni
description: Judith Sapadin Orlando and John Searle Tamagni were married Saturday afternoon at the Heights Casino, a private squash, tennis and social club in Brooklyn. The ceremony was led by Arnold L. Lehman, a Universal Life minister and the director of the Brooklyn Museum, where the groom is the chairman of the board of trustees.

title: Janna OShea and Michael Zagari
description: Janna Elizabeth OShea and Michael Richard Zagari are to be married Sunday at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in Manhattan. Carissa Templeton, a minister affiliated with Rose Ministries, is to perform a nondenominational ceremony.

title: Aviva Berman and Ezra Billinkoff
description: Aviva Jaclyn Berman, a daughter of Gita Guttman Berman and Steve Berman of Atlanta, is to be married Sunday to Ezra Lewin Billinkoff, a son of Dr. Sharon Lewin and Donald Billinkoff of New York. Rabbi Robert N. Levine is to officiate at Summerour Studio, an event space in Atlanta, where Rabbi Dr. Analia Bortz is to take part in the ceremony.

title: Nancy Costello and Katherine Rodway
description: Nancy Jane Costello and Katherine Linda Rodway were married Saturday at St. Peters Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. John Magisano, a minister of the Metropolitan Community Church, officiated.

title: Hilary Cloos and Jeffrey Feinsod
description: Hilary Robinson Cloos and Jeffrey Marc Feinsod were married Saturday evening at Helsinki Hudson, an event venue in Hudson, N.Y. Brian C. Fox, the brides brother-in-law, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Marjorie Galler and Steven Horn
description: Marjorie Fran Galler, a daughter of Roberta I. Galler and Marvin Galler of Boca Raton, Fla., is to be married Sunday to Steven Jared Horn, a son of Carol S. Horn and Lawrence A. Horn of Bethesda, Md. Rabbi James Ponet will officiate at the Four Seasons Hotel in Boston.

title: Julia Balduzzi, Ryan May
description: Julia Alexandra Balduzzi and Ryan Patrick May were married Friday evening at the Henry Morrison Flagler Museum in Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Eddie Rodriguez, a Universal Brotherhood minister, officiated.

title: Aliza Balog, Scott Goodside
description: Aliza Jordana Balog and Scott Bradley Goodside were married Saturday evening at Tappan Hill Mansion in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi David E. Fass officiated.

title: Samantha Beinhacker, Scott Anderson
description: Samantha Langbaum Beinhacker and Scott Edward Anderson were married Saturday at the Green Building, an events space in Brooklyn. Lori Hanau, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Doreen Lee, Eric Kushins
description: Dr. Doreen Formosan Lee and Eric Ross Kushins were married Saturday at the Eliza Thompson House, a historic inn in Savannah, Ga. Adam F. Kushins, the grooms brother who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Richard Forde, David Foushe
description: Dr. Richard James Forde and David Russell Foushe were married Saturday at the couples home in Yountville, Calif. Jan Chapman Lanterman, a friend of the couple and a deputy marriage commissioner in the County of Napa, Calif., officiated.

title: Seraphim Reycraft, Henry Hoffman
description: Seraphim Yoo Reycraft, a daughter of Seraphim D. Reycraft and Thomas C. Reycraft of Pelham, N.Y., was married Saturday to Henry Maxwell Hoffman, a son of Erika V. Hoffman and Dr. Byron Jay Hoffman Jr. of Chapel Hill, N.C. The Rev. Michael Greco, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church in Pelham.

title: Whitney White, Peter Van Steemburg
description: Whitney Anne White and Peter Dixon Van Steemburg were married Saturday evening at the Parker, a hotel in Palm Springs, Calif. Margaret Grey Fairchild, a minister of the American Marriage Ministries, officiated at a nondenominational ceremony that was led by Rebecca Linder Blachly, a former divinity student.

title: Mark Anderson, Keith Bucklew
description: Mark Chenoweth Anderson and Keith Elden Bucklew were married Thursday at the Cannon House Office Building in Washington. Susan C. Bucklew, a senior United States judge for the Middle District of Florida and the sister-in-law of Mr. Bucklew, officiated in the office of Representative Kathy Castor, Democrat of Florida.

title: Jacqueline Waldman, Stephen Wax
description: Jacqueline Cheryl Waldman and Stephen Brian Wax were married Saturday evening at the New York Palace hotel in Manhattan. Cantor Neil Ben-Isvy officiated.

title: Carly Lindauer, Cliff Hamilton
description: Carly Heather Lindauer and Dr. Cliff Scott Hamilton were married Saturday evening at Millesime, a restaurant in New York. Rabbi William I. Kuhn officiated.

title: Elizabeth Ford, Christopher Keaney
description: Elizabeth Scott Ford and Christopher Patrick Keaney were married Saturday at the Stonehouse Villa, an event space in Driftwood, Tex. Spike Gillespie, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Rachel Wasserman, Lonnie Greenberg
description: Rachel Jana Wasserman and Lonnie Greenberg were married Saturday evening at the PGA National Resort and Spa in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. Cantor Bruce Benson officiated.

title: A Match Made in Kickball
description: Emily Samantha Schneider, a daughter of Susan E. Greenberg and Evan B. Schneider of Manhattan, is to be married Sunday to William Alexander Scheer, a son of Carole A. Scheer and Alex W. Scheer of Bulls Head, Staten Island. Rabbi Janet Roberts is to officiate at Giando on the Water, a restaurant in Brooklyn.

title: Inauguration Day, in More Than One Way
description: Tiffany Melen Hall and John Brandon Rhea were married Saturday at the Chevy Chase United Methodist Church in Chevy Chase, Md. The Rev. Kirkland Reynolds, a Methodist minister and the churchs pastor, officiated. Bishop Gregory G. M. Ingram, who presides over the First Episcopal district of the African Methodist Episcopal Church, participated.

title: Corrections: April 6, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Search Crews Detect Signals They Say May Be From Missing Malaysian Jet
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  The chief of the Australian team coordinating the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 said Monday that an Australian vessel had detected transmissions consistent with flight data and cockpit voice recorders, possibly from the missing jet.

title: ECO 348, The Great Recession: Inflation or Deflation?
description: Slides here (pdf).

title: Israel Warns Palestinians but Stays Open to Talks
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu threatened Sunday that Israel would take its own unilateral steps in response to the Palestinians move last week to join international conventions and reiterated that a Palestinian state could be created only through direct negotiations, not through empty statements and not by unilateral moves.

title: 1914: Sir Herbert Tree To Star in Bernard Shaws Pygmalion
description: LONDON  Mr. Bernard Shaws Pygmalion, to be produced by Sir Herbert Tree at His Majestys Theatre on Saturday, will be the feature of the week, which otherwise would be uneventful, especially as many managers are taking advantage of Holy Week to give their companies a rest.

title: Whats On Sunday
description: 10 P.M. (HBO) SILICON VALLEY In this new comedy created by Mike Judge, a group of socially stunted programmers shares the home  or, as they call it, the incubator of a dot-com billionaire who lets them live rent-free in exchange for a 10 percent stake in their ventures. The shows mockery of obscene wealth and the grandiosity that comes with giving back is badly needed, Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. A new cultural revolution is at hand, and many of its leaders are even more smug and self-righteous than the counterculture activists who, back in the 1960s, also thought they could change the world. She added, Silicon Valley isnt making the world a better place, it is putting the real Silicon Valley in its place, one Tesla at a time. Above, from left, Kumail Nanjiani, Martin Starr, Thomas Middleditch, Zach Woods and T. J. Miller star in the show. The season opener of Game of Thrones leads in at 9; Veep follows at 10:30.

title: Concert Versions of Broadway Musicals Appear Beyond Theaters
description: Rosie ODonnell sat in a booth at the Broadway supper club 54 Below, sipping red wine and getting teary as she watched members of the original cast of Taboo, the flop she produced on Broadway a decade ago, power through the score.

title: Qatar Museums Authority Leader to Leave Post
description: Edward Dolman is stepping down as the executive director and acting chief executive of the Qatar Museums Authority, a job he held for three years, the authority announced on Sunday. But he will remain a member of the authoritys international advisory board.

title: Guarded Optimism After Breast Cancer Drug Shows Promising Results
description: SAN DIEGO  Researchers say that a new type of drug can help prevent advanced breast cancer from worsening, potentially providing an important new treatment option for women and a blockbuster product for Pfizer.

title: The Worlds Biggest Tetris Game
description: The Drexel University professor Frank Lee and his team hacked into the lighting system of a 29-story skyscraper in Philadelphia to play Tetris on the buildings facade.

title: Making a Game Larger Than Life
description: After a 20-hour Tetris marathon on his Macintosh SE/30 desktop computer, Frank J. Lee drove across the Bay Bridge from Berkeley to San Francisco, his mind still stuck on the game. He was an undergraduate majoring in cognitive science, and the year was 1990.

title: Apples Deep Pockets: What $159 Billion Could Do
description: Big technology companies have a problem anyone would love to have: They are sitting on vast amounts of cash.

title: New Yorks Paid Sick Leave Law Quietly Takes Effect
description: Shiv Puri gathered his employees together after the lunchtime rush last week to deliver the big news: This year, the cook and kitchen staff at the Bombay Sandwich Company on West 27th Street will receive paid sick leave for the very first time.

title: In Our Pages: April 7
description: 1889: Fires on the Prairie

title: In a Test of Wills With China, U.S. Sticks Up for Japan
description: TOKYO  On his first trip to China as the secretary of defense, Chuck Hagel is finding himself in the middle of a spat that would not be out of place in Mean Girls, a movie about social cliques in high school.

title: Captain America: The Winter Soldier Has a Huge Opening
description: The Marvel movie machine can even bring summer early. Captain America: The Winter Soldier broke industry records for an April opening by taking in about $96.2 million at North American theaters over the weekend, an astounding 48 percent increase over the three-day opening for its series predecessor in 2011. The movie has already taken in an additional $207 million overseas.

title: Two Officers Critically Injured While Responding to Brooklyn Blaze
description: Two veteran police officers, partners out on patrol around lunchtime on Sunday, rushed to the 13th floor of a high-rise housing development in Coney Island, Brooklyn, after a report of a fire was called in.

title: Oligarchy and Monetary Policy
description: Ive been thinking about how we talk about  or dont talk about  the desirability of low inflation targets. As I noted the other day, the lates IMF World Economic Outlook makes a compelling case for raising the target above 2 percent  but avoids saying so explicitly, resorting to coded euphemisms. Meanwhile, inflation paranoia is very much a partisan thing. In my class notes for tomorrow I list the signatories of the economists letter warning about dollar debasement from quantitative easing; its obvious that everyone on the list is a highly committed Republican, and some people with the right ideological credentials are on board even though they have no relevant professional credentials. (William Kristol and Dan Senor, monetary experts?)

title: UConns Center Adds Fitness to Her Ebullience
description: NASHVILLE  It was yet another Connecticut-Stanford game, and as usual, something weighty in womens basketball rested on the outcome.

title: Young, Rich and Ruling Radio, Country Walks a Broader Line
description: NASHVILLE  On the radio, it has displaced Top 40 as Americas most popular musical format.

title: Attuned to the Money
description: Was Bernard L. Madoff ever tempted to sing about his pyramid scheme? Did Martha Stewart contemplate an insider-trading tap dance? Their efforts might have enlivened Greed: A Musical for Our Times, a revue by Michael Roberts at New World Stages.

title: The Kentucky Derby Dartboard: Week 2
description: Last year, Churchill Downs adopted a points system to determine the field for the Kentucky Derby, replacing the use of graded-stakes earnings. Points are earned by the top four finishers in designated Derby prep races. The odds are from the Churchill Downs futures pool, and the records are starts-win-place-show. An article on Saturdays Wood Memorial and Santa Anita Derby can be found here.

title: Cement Makers Holcim and Lafarge Are Said to Agree on Merger Plan
description: PARIS  The boards of Holcim and Lafarge, two of the worlds largest construction materials companies, have agreed to merge, a person close to the discussions said on Sunday.

title: Jeb Bush Talks Approach If He Runs for President
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex.  With eyes increasingly on him, Jeb Bush signaled on Sunday the kind of campaign he would mount if he runs for president, one arguing against ideological purity tests while challenging party orthodoxy on issues like immigration and education.

title: In His Return From Injury, Niese Feels Good, but Reds Feel Better
description: Jon Niese sat alone in a booth at a sports bar in Port St. Lucie, Fla., last Monday, ordered a turkey burger topped with a fried egg and watched the Mets season opener on television. He probably would have started that game if his spring training had not been derailed by shoulder discomfort and elbow inflammation.

title: John
description: John

title: Smith Tries but Cannot Carry the Knicks
description: MIAMI  Carmelo Anthonys right arm, by his own description, felt dead by the second half Sunday afternoon. It was not an ideal situation for the Knicks, who were seeking to remain viable (or at least marginal) candidates for the postseason against the Miami Heat.

title: French Film Goes Viral, but Not in France
description: PARIS  The main character is a harried parent just trying to slog through the routine of the day: dropping off the toddler at day care, picking up the mail, running errands.

title: Unrest in Eastern Ukraine
description: In Donetsk and Lugansk, crowds bearing Russian flags clashed with the police and stormed government buildings on Sunday.

title: My So-Called Opinions
description: I.

title: Telling Victim From Villain at Duke
description: This again? We were blitzed with the Duke University lacrosse scandal in 2006. And, it seems, were still not done with it.

title: Powerhouse Theater Summer Season
description: Among the highlights of the summer season for the Powerhouse Theater will be In Your Arms, a collection of wordless dance vignettes written by playwrights like Terrence McNally, Christopher Durang, Carrie Fisher, Douglas Carter Beane and Lynn Nottage, with music by Stephen Flaherty (Ragtime) and choreography by Christopher Gattelli (Newsies). Produced by New York Stage and Film and Vassar College, the season is also to include new plays by Richard Greenberg (Take Me Out) and John Patrick Shanley (Doubt) and is scheduled to begin on June 20 in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

title: Museum Director to Be Commissioner of Cultural Affairs
description: Tom Finkelpearl, the president and executive director of the Queens Museum, is scheduled to be named the cultural affairs commissioner by Mayor Bill de Blasio on Monday, the mayors office confirmed, putting Mr. Finkelpearl in charge of a $156 million budget and making him the point person on the arts for a city widely considered the cultural capital of the world.

title: An Unusual Family Legacy With Heavy Responsibility
description: In Ajmal Zaheer Ahmads Jinn, the supernatural beings of the title have good and evil versions. But theres good and evil, and theres just plain bad. Most of the time, this incoherent thriller resembles an overheated trailer for itself: a glaringly rough assembly of ill-staged computer-generated action sequences and portentous moments.

title: For UConn, as Well as the Huskies, a Golden Opportunity to Impress
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Halfway through a private brunch Saturday, as Connecticuts biggest donors finished their all-you-can-eat French toast and sausages, the universitys president, Susan Herbst, put down her glass and made her way to the center of the room.

title: Good and Evil, Ritual and Nightmare, in Sight and Sound
description: Concealed, by the British electronic-music duo Demdike Stare and the filmmaker and animator Michael England, is an audiovisual project, no more or less aural than visual, about dread and dreams, what happens in the world when the conscious mind isnt noticing.

title: A Homely Nymph, Wooed by a God to Rouse His Wifes Jealousy
description: The conductor William Christie appeared onstage at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night to apologize to the audience that had packed the place for a performance of Rameaus comic opera masterpiece Plate. He explained that he was still recuperating from a recent surgical procedure and would not be able to conduct Les Arts Florissants, the vocal and instrumental ensemble he founded in France 35 years ago, a group that has set the standard for the performance of French Baroque opera. He also regretted, he said, that the audience would not be seeing the director Robert Carsens staged production, which had recently played to acclaim in Vienna and Paris. This would be just a concert performance, the buskers version, Mr. Christie said.

title: Proclaiming Joy, in Concert, on His 75th Birthday
description: When Hugh Masekela celebrated his 75th birthday on Friday night, with a Jazz at Lincoln Center concert at Rose Theater, he recalled pivotal advice from Harry Belafonte, who was in the audience. In 1960, Mr. Masekela left the brutal apartheid of his birthplace, South Africa, to become a trumpeter in New York. He recalled that Mr. Belafonte, an early supporter, urged him to put some of that stuff from your home into what you do.

title: Full-Throttle Emotions and Blind Faith
description: The soprano Renata Scotto, a celebrated interpreter of the tragic teenage heroine of Puccinis Madama Butterfly, found that being too emotionally invested in the character was problematic because you suffer and you cant sing. The soprano Kristine Opolais said in a recent interview on Latinos Post that because she doesnt hold back emotionally, she finds the role so psychologically taxing that she might have to limit future performances.

title: The Faces of Power, From the Portraitist in Chief
description: DALLAS  Former President George W. Bush is something of a natural when it comes to making oil paintings, a decent amateur. Although he picked up a brush only in 2012, this naturalness emerged as a definite possibility barely a year later. Thats when images of two strange, seemingly introspective paintings by Mr. Bush went viral, hacked from the email of a Bush relative, very discreetly showing the former president bathing.

title: Bolshois Giselle, Geared to Virtuosity and a Vocal Audience
description: MOSCOW  Of all the surviving 19th-century ballets, Giselle, with its narrative nexus of love and dance and death, is the one that can most be relied upon not to disappoint. Unlike other ballet classics from that era, it seldom loses narrative tension; its technical and acting challenges keep stimulating individual casts. And yet the Bolshoi Ballet performance I saw on Wednesday was the dullest account in my entire experience of this war horse (nearly 40 years). While the one on Thursday was considerably better, both were drearily routine affairs.

title: The Superpredator Scare
description: After a surge of teen violence in the early 1990s, some social scientists predicted the future was going to be a whole lot worse. Reality proved otherwise.

title: A Couple of Couples
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  This is a Monday puzzle that goes above and beyond, in my opinion.

title: When Youth Violence Spurred Superpredator Fear
description: As the police and prosecutors in Brooklyn tell it, Kahton Anderson boarded a bus on March 20, a .357 revolver at his side. For whatever reason  some gang grudge, apparently  he pulled out the gun and fired at his intended target. Only his aim was rotten. The bullet struck and killed a passenger who was minding his own business several rows ahead: Angel Rojas, a working stiff holding down two jobs to feed his family of four.

title: Pornography, Children and Parents
description: To the Editor:

title: Its Root, Root, Root for the Umpires ...
description: To the Editor:

title: A Guide for Employers
description: To the Editor:

title: The Job Skills Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: More Accessible Subways
description: To the Editor:

title: Election Time in Afghanistan
description: But the threat of disruption from the Taliban is always present.

title: Vox Takes Melding of Journalism and Technology to a New Level
description: WASHINGTON  Ask Ezra Klein what prompted him to leave a high-profile position at The Washington Post to start a new website, and the answer is a little wonkish, even for the founder of the newspapers Wonkblog, a mix of politics, economics and domestic policy that had become must reading in the Beltway.

title: Neither Female Nor Male
description: SYDNEY, Australia  PRETTY much the No. 1 question you are asked when youre pregnant is: Girl or boy? If you choose not to find out, but to be deliciously surprised at birth, as I did, then you will be asked to guess: What do you feel it is? I used to scrunch up my eyes and try hard to draw on what people told me was an age-old female intuition: Which genitals were sprouting in my round belly? I could never tell, though.

title: Final Round at the Jacoby Open Swiss Teams
description: DALLAS  March 30 was the final day of the Spring Nationals here. When the last round of the Jacoby Open Swiss Teams began that evening, Roy Welland of New York City, Sabine Auken and Christina Madsen from Denmark, and Josef Piekarek and Alex Smirnov from Germany were two victory points ahead of Martin Fleisher, Zia Mahmood and Chris Willenken of New York City; Steve Garner of Chicago; Chip Martel of Davis, Calif.; and Michael Rosenberg of Cupertino, Calif.

title: Senate Set to Pass Bill Extending Jobless Aid
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate is expected to easily approve legislation Monday restoring unemployment benefits to nearly three million people, throwing the bill to a divided House where Republicans favor starkly different approaches to the issue.

title: Traveler Magazine Learns Luxury Service at Hotels
description: Like most of the staff at the opulent Carlyle Hotel in Manhattan, Bill Wackermann was busy. He attended an early morning meeting to prepare for the days guests. He inspected a room under renovation. He answered phones at the concierge desk.

title: Turning 40, But Infused With Youth And Vigor
description: As with so many dance companies, Ailey II, the junior ensemble of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, exhilarates and disappoints at the same time. The dancers are tremendous. The choreography, not so much.

title: Look Up! All Signs Point to Art
description: Can the likes of Jasper Johns, Edward Hopper and Cindy Sherman help jump-start the struggling billboard business?

title: Margalit Fox Answers the Question: Why That Life?
description: Margalit Fox has written more than 1,000 obituaries for The Times.

title: Indias Next Prime Minister?
description: Narendra Modi of the Bharatiya Janata Party could become Indias next prime minister. Heres a look at his controversial past and his economic promises.

title: Timeline of the Riots in Modis Gujarat
description: Explore key developments in the 2002 riots in Gujarat that shadowed Narendra Modis ascent to the prime ministers office.

title: Eight (No, Nine!) Problems With Big Data
description: BIG data is suddenly everywhere. Everyone seems to be collecting it, analyzing it, making money from it and celebrating (or fearing) its powers. Whether were talking about analyzing zillions of Google search queries to predict flu outbreaks, or zillions of phone records to detect signs of terrorist activity, or zillions of airline stats to find the best time to buy plane tickets, big data is on the case. By combining the power of modern computing with the plentiful data of the digital era, it promises to solve virtually any problem  crime, public health, the evolution of grammar, the perils of dating  just by crunching the numbers.

title: Jeter, With His Final Home Opener Up Next, Climbs Career Hits List to No. 8
description: TORONTO  A year ago, when the Yankees opened their season in the Bronx against the Boston Red Sox, there was a noticeable void. It was felt during the pregame introductions when players like Kevin Youkilis and Travis Hafner were announced over the public-address system, but Derek Jeter was not.

title: Discovery Blitz, Including a Daredevil and Oprah
description: WHAT began with a sales pitch, ended with Oprah Winfrey  and in between featured two hours and 20 minutes of attractions like reality television stars, Ron Howard, Roseanne Barr, a marching band and one of the Wallendas, the daredevil circus performers?

title: Bronx Neighborhood Fights for Its Spot on the Map
description: Allerton residents know where they live. It is everyone else they have to worry about.

title: The Capitalism of Catastrophe
description: TULSA, Okla.  Disasters happen. It is a fact as certain as income taxes. And when a solar flare erupts or a flu pandemic hits, there is only one question that will matter: Are you, or are you not, prepared?

title: Atlanta Archbishop Says Hell Sell Mansion
description: After an uproar over the cost of a $2.2 million residence, the archbishop of Atlanta said over the weekend that he would sell the mansion.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 67
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: BlackRock Elevates Executives in Succession Planning Move
description: BlackRock, the giant investment management firm, announced a series of executive shifts on Sunday aimed at grooming a number of potential successors to its founder and leader, Laurence D. Fink.

title: SAC Capital Plea and JPMorgan Earnings
description: SAC CAPITAL FADES AWAY AS JUDGE CONSIDERS ITS PLEA

title: Departing White House Counsel Held Powerful Sway
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama selected Kathryn Ruemmler to be White House counsel in June 2011, it was something of a surprise: As a younger, relatively obscure lawyer, and one with no personal ties to the president, she did not fit the mold of predecessors.

title: State Visit of Irelands President to Britain, a First, Underlines Evolution of Relations
description: LONDON  In a sign of the warmth of relations between two countries with a troubled history, Irelands president, Michael D. Higgins, is to arrive here Monday for the first state visit to Britain by an Irish president.

title: Questions for Comcast as It Looks to Grow
description: It is hard to say how rugged the questions will be when Comcast goes before the Senate Judiciary Committee on Wednesday to defend its proposed megamerger with Time Warner Cable.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Fashion District Robberies Turn Heads, and Some Cant Help Smirking
description: PARIS  Since the reign of Frances Sun King, the historic Place Vendme has served as this citys capital of luxury, home to high-end fashion boutiques and diamond shops, Coco Chanels mansion, and the palatial Htel Ritz Paris. Lately, though, this quarter snug in the heart of Paris has turned into the hub of a decidedly more low-rent form of plunder: smash-and-grab robberies.

title: Toledo Blade Sues Over Detention of Journalists at Tank Plant
description: The Toledo Blade newspaper has filed a lawsuitagainst six government officials, including Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, claiming that two of its journalists were detained unlawfully while taking pictures outside a tank plant in Lima, Ohio.

title: A Community Mourns Soldiers Killed in Fort Hood Rampage
description: KILLEEN, Tex.  Even before a gunman killed three soldiers last week at Fort Hood, the homily for Sundays noon Mass at St. Joseph Catholic Church here was always going to be about death, a consequence of the years liturgical calendar two weeks before Easter.

title: Oligarchs and Money
description: Econonerds eagerly await each new edition of the International Monetary Funds World Economic Outlook. Never mind the forecasts, what were waiting for are the analytical chapters, which are always interesting and even provocative. This latest report is no exception. In particular, Chapter 3  although billed as an analysis of trends in real (inflation-adjusted) interest rates  in effect makes a compelling case for raising inflation targets above 2 percent, the current norm in advanced countries.

title: Weil Hires Senior Goldman Bankruptcy Specialist for London Office
description: A month and a half ago, Barry Wolf sat down for dinner at Babbo in Londons upscale Mayfair district with two of his partners at the law firm Weil, Gotshal & Manges.

title: Waiting, Fittingly, for a Catcher to Bloom
description: Six games into their season, the Mets have the fewest hits in the majors and the most strikeouts a game in the National League. They also just took two of three from the Cincinnati Reds  a playoff team last season  and came within an opening-day strike of a .500 homestand.

title: A Rush to Overbuild Downtown
description: The developer Larry Silverstein and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the World Trade Center site, feuded for years about how to rebuild the area after Sept. 11, 2001. Then, in 2010, they made a deal that gave Mr. Silverstein nearly $2 billion in financing and incentives to build two towers adjacent to the museum and memorial.

title: Surgery Will Shelve Mets Parnell for Season
description: Closer Bobby Parnell will have Tommy John elbow surgery Tuesday, the Mets said after their 2-1 loss to Cincinnati on Sunday. Parnell, who learned last week that he had a partly torn ulnar collateral ligament, is expected to miss the rest of this season, and his availability for the start of the 2015 season could be in jeopardy.

title: Expressway to Amazon in a Box
description: OSTENSIBLY, the new Amazon Fire TV is a streaming media set-top box  an Internet-connected device that lets you watch video from Amazon Instant Video, Netflix, Hulu, YouTube, Crackle or a few other outlets and play games with or without a controller, which is sold separately.

title: Sun Pharmaceuticals of India to Buy Ranbaxy, a Smaller Rival
description: Sun Pharmaceutical Industries, the Indian drug maker, said on Sunday that it would pay about $4 billion in stock for Ranbaxy Laboratories, a smaller Indian rival.

title: Abusive and Frivolous Patent Suits
description: Abusive and frivolous lawsuits brought by holders of patents are costing the American economy billions of dollars. Fortunately, Congress is on the case. A large bipartisan majority in the House approved a bill last year that would reduce such litigation; the Senate, where a similar bill is being negotiated, may soon follow.

title: Business Titans Too Rich to Bribe Seek to Ease Fears in East Ukraine
description: DNIPROPETROVSK, Ukraine  Two months ago, Hennadiy Korban, a millionaire businessman, fled to Israel to escape retribution for siding with opponents of Ukraines president, Viktor F. Yanukovych. After Mr. Yanukovychs ouster, he flew home in triumph aboard a private plane to begin a new life  as a harried civil servant.

title: U.S. Tries Candor to Assure China on Cyberattacks
description: WASHINGTON  In the months before Defense Secretary Chuck Hagels arrival in Beijing on Monday, the Obama administration quietly held an extraordinary briefing for the Chinese military leadership on a subject officials have rarely discussed in public: the Pentagons emerging doctrine for defending against cyberattacks against the United States  and for using its cybertechnology against adversaries, including the Chinese.

title: Behavior Detection Isnt Paying Off
description: A multiyear experiment in behavior detection is only worsening the Transportation Security Administrations reputation for wastefulness. Since 2007, the T.S.A. has trained officers to identify high-risk passengers on the basis of mostly nonverbal signs, like fidgeting or sweating, which may indicate stress or fear. The total price tag: nearly $1 billion.

title: The Mentally Ill, Behind Bars
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio and his new correction commissioner, Joseph Ponte, have inherited a city jail system in which nearly 40 percent of the 12,000 inmates have mental illnesses  up from about a quarter just seven years ago. Yet despite the stark shift, the system has not been redesigned to serve the complex needs of inmates with mental illnesses.

title: What It Means if the Death Penalty Is Dying
Even Missing Star, Irish Are Unstoppable
description: NASHVILLE  That other undefeated womens college basketball team, the one apparently without the luck of the Irish, nonetheless steamrollered its way to the national championship game on Sunday night.

title: More Deportations Follow Minor Crimes, Records Show
description: With the Obama administration deporting illegal immigrants at a record pace, the president has said the government is going after criminals, gang bangers, people who are hurting the community, not after students, not after folks who are here just because theyre trying to figure out how to feed their families.

title: Early Tallies Indicating Afghan Vote a Success
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  After enduring months of Taliban attacks and days of security clampdowns, Afghans reveled Sunday in the apparent success of the weekends presidential election, as officials offered the first solid indications that the vote had far exceeded expectations.

title: With a Holler, Homers Make N.C.A.A. Broadcasts Fun
description: Was that a devilish cackle from Rex Chapman when Aaron Harrison sank the 3-pointer that lifted Kentucky over Wisconsin on Saturday? Or was it the laugh of an announcer hired to be an unrepentant homer?

title: France Curtails Role at Genocide Services After Rwanda Leader Casts Blame
description: PARIS  Stung by critical remarks from Rwandas president that laid some of the blame for that countrys 1994 genocide at the door of France, the French government has scaled back its planned participation in the 20th anniversary commemoration of the massacres.

title: Glaxo Starts Investigating Possible Iraq Misconduct
description: The British drugmaker GlaxoSmithKline said on Sunday that it was investigating claims of improper conduct related to its business in Iraq, less than a year after China accused Glaxo of engaging in a bribery scheme aimed at increasing drug sales there.

title: Comptroller to Opt Out of Public Financing System
description: ALBANY  Thomas P. DiNapoli, the state comptroller, is the first to admit that what he plans to do is hypocritical.

title: Calipari Credits a Mysterious Tweak With Turning Kentuckys Season Around
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Kentucky Coach John Calipari was sitting at home one night in early March when an idea popped in his mind.

title: A Star Candidates Support for Secession Undercuts Quebecs Governing Party
description: BUCKINGHAM, Quebec  With his media holdings and celebrity, Pierre Karl Pladeau is a combination of Rupert Murdoch and Silvio Berlusconi, so his decision to run as a candidate in Quebecs legislative elections has drastically altered the campaign. But the commotion he has caused was not what his party, the Parti Qubcois, had hoped for when it introduced Mr. Pladeau as its star candidate last month.

title: Costa Rica Set for Lopsided Victory
description: MEXICO CITY  With his opponent in the race for president of Costa Rica on the sidelines, a history professor seemed poised to win a lopsided victory on Sunday.

title: Toughened by Hardship, Day Is Relishing His Challenges
description: BRADENTON, Fla.  The two-story grand foyer in the 5,462-square-foot home opened to a formal living room with toys strewn on its tile floor. The golfer Jason Day, bathed in sunlight streaming in from the French doors, was talking about rooting through a junkyard for his own toys, including his first club, as a child. He had to raise his voice at times to be heard above the thwacking sound made by his 22-month-old son, Dash, who was hitting a giant plastic golf ball across the room.

title: Cities Advance Their Fight Against Rising Inequality
description: SEATTLE  In January, Teresa Fuentess employer told her she could work no more than 30 hours a week preparing burgers and passing out food at the drive-through for about $9.50 an hour.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Surge of Violence Across Syria Kills Over Two Dozen
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Violence flared across Syria on Sunday, as an explosion killed more than two dozen antigovernment fighters in the central city of Homs and shells struck areas of Damascus, the capital, killing at least two people. On Saturday, a man died after a riot broke out in the crowded Zaatari refugee camp in Jordan.

title: Arts Prize to Betye Saar
description: The assemblage artist Betye Saar, above, will receive the 55th annual Edward MacDowell Medal for lifetime achievement in the arts, which is given by the MacDowell Colony, an artists retreat in New Hampshire. The honor is to be presented to Ms. Saar, 87, by the author Michael Chabon and others at a ceremony on Aug. 10 in Peterborough, N.H. In a statement, Mr. Chabon praised Ms. Saars work for building scale models of a world that is intensely personal and yet instantly, inescapably recognizable as our own broken world. Previous winners include Robert Frost, I. M. Pei, Georgia OKeeffe and Stephen Sondheim.

title: Plugging Away at Living, Come What May
description: Plays as funny and moving, as wonderful and weird as The Realistic Joneses, by Will Eno, do not appear often on Broadway. Or ever, really. Youre as likely to see a tumbleweed lolloping across 42nd Street as you are to see something as daring as Mr. Enos meditation on the confounding business of being alive (or not) sprouting where only repurposed movies, plays by dead people and blaring musicals tend to thrive.

title: Art Supplies From Heaven
description: Dear Diary:

title: Ex-Chief of Kaplan Aims to Build a Rival Digital Learning Company
description: For 14 years, Jonathan N. Grayer helped build Kaplan from a small test preparation company into one of the giants of the education business and the crown jewel of what once was The Washington Post Company.

title: Game of Thrones Recap: Slicing and Dicing Two Swords
description: Here be spoilers, and a roomful of tasty chickens.

title: Credit Suisse Is Said to Be Facing Double-Barreled Inquiries
description: After years of false starts and stops, the Justice Department is nearing the end of an investigation into the role Credit Suisse played in hiding American wealth offshore. But at the same time, a new investigation is beginning, threatening to entangle the giant Swiss bank for even longer.

title: Reverse Auctions Draw Scrutiny
description: It is like an eBay of Washington, a well-appointed and well-connected online marketplace for lucrative government contracts.

title: The Two Underdogs Left Standing Hail From Different Schools of Thought
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Ever since March Madness began, Connecticut and Kentucky have embraced the role of underdog, and with good reason: Few believed either team had what it took to reach the N.C.A.A. title game.

title: Catholic Schools in U.S. Court Chinas Youth, and Their Cash
description: WAYNE, N.J.  When she arrived at DePaul Catholic High School to join the class of 2014, Di Wang hardly lacked for international experience. The daughter of a Chinese petroleum executive from Shaanxi, she had attended an elite summer camp in Japan. She knew firsthand the pleasures of French cuisine. Her favorite movie was The Godfather.

title: Facing His Torturer as Spain Confronts Its Past
description: MADRID  Jos Mara Galante was a leftist college student when he was handcuffed to the ceiling of a basement torture chamber, his body dangling in the air. A police inspector laughed and taunted him, striking martial arts poses before repeatedly kicking and beating his face and chest.

title: Snowden to Receive Truth-Telling Prize
description: The Ridenhour prize for truth-telling will be given to Edward J. Snowden and Laura Poitras, the filmmaker and journalist who helped Mr. Snowden disclose his trove of documents on government surveillance.

title: Gravity Hits Highflying Tech Stocks
description: For much of the past year, Tesla Motors seemingly could do no wrong in investors eyes.

title: Connecticuts Shrink-Wrap Defender
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Ryan Boatright watched Aaron Harrison shoot Kentucky into the national championship game against his Connecticut Huskies, watched him make the same darn 3-pointer from the same darn spot on the court, with about as much time left as his game-winning shot last week against Michigan, and it bothered him. Not the shot, really, so much as Wisconsins defense on the play.

title: Train Engineer in Fatal Derailment Is Said to Have Sleep Apnea
description: The National Transportation Safety Board will announce this week that the Metro-North Railroad engineer at the controls last year during a fatal derailment in the Bronx had an undiagnosed sleep disorder, according to a person with knowledge of the planned announcement.

title: N.C.A.A. Planning to Address Benefits for Some of Its Players, Officials Say
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  For the last few months, football players at Northwestern have been pushing to be recognized as a union, which they hope will eventually force universities to further limit practice time and to provide them with benefits like better medical coverage.

title: Corrections: April 7, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Popular Demand
description: Liberty Media, the investment company, said last week that it would sell most of its stake in Barnes & Noble, partly because the Nook tablet failed to meet long-term expectations. Meanwhile, Amazons Kindle is competing well with the iPad, and last week Amazon introduced Fire TV, a set-top box.

title: Queens Community Mourns 4 Friends Killed in Crash
description: As Nancy Leader left for church on Sunday morning, her eyes turned to the five candles along the front steps of her familys home. One for her granddaughter, Jada. One for Darius. One for Jaleel. One for Crystal. And one for Andrew.

title: Cost Among Hurdles Slowing New York Citys Plan to Phase Out Dirty Heating Oil
description: Outside Alicia Barksdales living room, high above Upper Manhattan, the brick chimney atop the building next door belches black smoke all winter long, and even into the spring.

title: Lucy Hood, Innovative TV Executive, Dies at 56
description: Lucy Hood, a television industry executive who made audience participation a staple in American living rooms when she introduced text voting to American Idol, the Fox megahit singing contest, died on Wednesday in Los Angeles. She was 56.

title: Two Rivals. Zero Losses. One Trophy.
description: NASHVILLE  It was widely expected that the semifinals of the womens Final Four would serve as thin-crust appetizers for the deep-dish main course whipped up by undefeated Connecticut and Notre Dame in the championship game.

title: India Election Digest: April 7
description: As Indian voters head to the polls, India Ink will be compiling a daily digest of the top election-related news from local media.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 6, 2014
description: April 6, 2014

title: The Hour of the Chronograph Watch
description: At last weeks Baselworld watch fair in Basel, Switzerland, the chronograph  an elaborate stopwatch of sorts, popular in aviation and sporting events  proved its here to stay. But unlike the crop we spotted at Genevas Salon International de la Haute Horlogerie (SIHH) watch fair earlier this year, this new set consistently favors a more classic aesthetic. With pared-down dials, uncomplicated indices and timeless rose gold or stainless-steel cases, these 10 vintage-inspired chronographs are functional for any racing event and handsome enough for more formal affairs.

title: Colleges Increasing Spending on Sports Faster Than on Academics, Report Finds
description: Even as their spending on instruction, research and public service declined or stayed flat, most colleges and universities rapidly increased their spending on sports, according to a report being released Monday by the American Association of University Professors.

title: Life With a Dog: You Meet People
description: As I approached four years as a widow, the loneliness of a one-person household began to drag me down. Acquiring a four-legged companion, rather than a two-legged one, appealed to me.

title: Word of the Day | hoodwink
description: hoodwink\hud-wiNk\ verb

title: The Front-Runners of Wall Street
description: Nancy Folbre is professor emerita of economics at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

title: Arts Education Lacking in Low-Income Areas of New York City, Report Says
description: New York Citys comptroller plans to release a report on Monday quantifying what student advocates have long suspected: that many public schools in the city do not offer any kind of arts education, and that the lack of arts instruction disproportionately affects low-income neighborhoods.

title: Photo Replay: March 31-April 6
description: Facing up to a challenge and coming to grips with the competition by relying on an extra measure of physicality.

title: Kansas Legislature Passes Education Finance Bill
description: Facing a Kansas Supreme Court ruling that funding disparities between school districts violated the State Constitution, Kansas lawmakers agreed late Sunday to direct more money to poorer districts.

title: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Westbrook Is Key as Thunder Face a Strong Conference Foe
description: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

title: Fire vs. Police: Charity Game Leads to Fight
description: Firefighters and police officers playing in a charity hockey game on Sunday wound up trading blows in a bench-clearing brawl that recalled the intense rivalry between their departments.

title: Mickey Rooney, Master of Putting On a Show, Dies at 93
description: Mickey Rooney, the exuberant entertainer who led a roller-coaster life  the worlds top box-office star at 19 as the irrepressible Andy Hardy, a bankrupt has-been in his 40s, a comeback kid on Broadway as he neared 60  died on Sunday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 93.

title: Thomas Polgar, C.I.A. Officer, Dies at 91; Helped Lead U.S. Evacuation of Saigon
description: Saigon was falling and the United States was fleeing, desperately evacuating the last of its embassy staff and C.I.A. officers in the final, chaotic hours of April 1975. With the airport under siege by the North Vietnamese, helicopters landed on rooftops to ferry away Americans and some South Vietnamese.

title: Whats On Monday
description: 9 P.M. (13) IN PERFORMANCE AT THE WHITE HOUSE: WOMEN OF SOUL Tessanne Chin, Melissa Etheridge, Aretha Franklin, Ariana Grande, Patti LaBelle (above), Janelle Mone and Jill Scott pay homage to the foremothers of music in this concert taped last month in the East Room and hosted by President Obama and his wife, Michelle. In Brothers Hypnotic (2014), presented by Independent Lens at 10, the director Reuben Atlas trails the Hypnotic Brass Ensemble, founded by the Chicago jazz trumpeter Kelan Phil Cohran. The ensemble grapples with Mr. Cohrans ideals of black consciousness while performing on New York streets, at Lincoln Center and in recording studios. The fearless streak displayed by the Hypnotic Brass Ensemble deserves its equivalent in a bolder movie technique, Nicolas Rapold wrote in The New York Times. But Mr. Atlas delivers a rousing finale with a shiver-inducing studio session involving father and sons thats at once a glimpse at deeply felt family dynamics and a moving bridge across generations.

title: Times Minute | Cybersaber Rattling
description: Cyber relations between Washington and Beijing. Also on the Minute, new tensions 20 years after Rwandas genocide, and survivalists meet at a convention in Tulsa.

title: Times Minute | Cybersaber Rattling
description: In the Video

title: Vera to Veruschka: A Journey in Photos
description: LONDON  The old negatives, hidden inside a dusty trunk, finally revealed their secret: a vibrant vision of Italy at the dawn of the 1960s Dolce Vita era.

title: Sweeping Graves the Party Way
description: Qingming is here, filling our hearts with longing, read the text message signed by the Ministry of Civil Affairs that popped up, unsolicited, on the mobile phones of many Chinese as the traditional Tomb Sweeping Festival got underway over the three-day weekend, which included a public holiday on Monday.

title: Hunt for Malaysian Jet Tests Technical Limits
description: HONG KONG  The metronomic pings that may signal the flight data recorders from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 emanate from stygian depths in the eastern Indian Ocean, 2.8 miles below the waves, where the water pressure is more than three tons per square inch. The bottom is a quarter-mile deeper than even the sandy plain near the Mid-Atlantic Ridge where the black boxes of Air France Flight 447 were found off the coast of Brazil nearly three years ago.

title: Apologetic and Sobbing, Pistorius Testifies He Killed His Girlfriend by Mistake
description: PRETORIA, South Africa  Tearful, tremulous, speaking so softly that he was nearly inaudible at times, the Paralympic athlete Oscar Pistorius took the stand in his murder trial on Monday, maintaining that he shot and killed his girlfriend, Reeva Steenkamp, last year because of a tragic mistake.

title: India Begins Worlds Largest Democratic Exercise
description: Updated, 8:11 p.m. |

title: Antitrust Hurdles Loom Large for Giant Cement Merger
description: Updated, 3:09 p.m. |

title: Standoff in Taiwan Legislature Appears Close to Resolution
description: Demonstrators in Taiwan said Monday that they will end their occupation of the legislature on Thursday, more than three weeks after they took over the building to protest the governments handling of a trade pact with China.

title: The Big Data Challenge to Legacy Data Management Companies
description: Scott Gnau, president of Teradata Labs, seemed a little irritated by all the attention being showered on the big data marketplace. Big-data exuberance has surged with the recent news about how much money was raised by Cloudera, the frontrunner among start-ups distributing Hadoop, open-source software used for storing and parsing huge volumes of data. The total mainly from Intel, but also venture capital firms was $900 million, putting a value of $4.1 billion on the young company.

title: Test Yourself | E.L.L. Practice, April 7, 2014
description: Take the Quiz

title: Israelis and Palestinians Ask U.S. Envoy for New Meeting
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli and Palestinian negotiators planned to meet with an American mediator on Monday for the second straight day in an effort to salvage the Middle East peace talks, which were pushed to the brink of breakdown last week.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Worlds Largest Game of Tetris Played in Philadelphia
description: In the video The Worlds Biggest Tetris Game and blog post Making a Game Larger Than Life, Axel Gerdau describes the worlds largest game of Tetris.

title: An Anointing in Shadows and Light
description: John Edmonds is the founder of About-Face, a blog that focuses on portraiture from a variety of artists. Mr. Edmonds, 24, born and raised in Washington where he still lives, graduated in 2012 with a B.F.A. in photography from Corcoran College of Art and Design. He is attending Yale University in the fall to pursue an M.F.A. in photography. His conversation with Alessandra Malito has been edited.

title: Why Do So Many People Say Like and Totally All the Time?
description: We all know people who overuse words and phrases like totally, like and you know in conversation. You might even be one of them. Have you ever tried to break the habit of saying certain things over and over?

title: Lawyers Say They Were Tortured After Protesting Black Jail
description: Three lawyers who were detained for more than two weeks in Heilongjiang Province, where they had tried to draw attention to an extrajudicial black jail holding Falun Gong adherents, have returned to Beijing saying they were tortured.

title: Hagel Receives Tour of Carrier in China Visit
description: QINGDAO, China  Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel got a long-awaited look at Chinas only aircraft carrier on Monday, taking a two-hour tour of the vessel at a naval base near this port city, in the first such visit by a foreign defense official, Pentagon officials said.

title: Bharatiya Janata Party Emphasizes Infrastructure and Jobs in Manifesto
description: NEW DELHI  After several days of repeated delays, the Bharatiya Janata Party released its national manifesto on Monday, focusing on what it called the five Ts: tradition, talent, technology, tourism and trade.

title: Altice to Expand Numericable Stake Before SFR Merger
description: LONDON  After prevailing in a bidding war for Vivendis mobile phone unit this weekend, Altice said on Monday that it would prepare for the acquisition by buying a 34.6 percent stake in its Numericable unit from the private equity firms Carlyle Group and Cinven.

title: In East Ukraine, Protesters Seek Russian Troops
