description: MOSCOW  Under the attentive eye of Russian state television, several hundred pro-Russian demonstrators in the city of Donetsk, in eastern Ukraine, declared on Monday that they were forming an independent republic and urged President Vladimir V. Putin to send troops to the region as a peacekeeping force, even though there was no imminent threat to peace.

title: New York Today: Pinstripe Preview
description: Good Monday morning to you.

title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: Diamonds New Venture Agrees to Second African Investment
description: The investment company Atlas Mara Co-Nvest, backed by a former Barclays chief executive, Robert E. Diamond Jr., has agreed to a second investment deal in the African financial sector.

title: Roche to Buy Testing Equipment Maker for Up to $450 Million
description: The Swiss drug maker Roche Group said on Monday that it had agreed to pay up to $450 million to acquire IQuum, a maker of medical testing equipment based in Massachusetts.

title: Alfa Laval in $2.17 Billion Deal for Norwegian Pump Maker
description: Alfa Laval of Sweden said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire the Norwegian pump maker Frank Mohn for 13 billion Norwegian kroner, or about $2.17 billion.

title: Though Sad to See Him Go, Yankees Fans Support Jeters Decision to Leave
description: Yankees shortstop Derek Jeter is usually judged by the number of hits or World Series rings he has, but it is his sky-high favorability rating that is of note in the latest New York Times/NY1/Siena College poll of New York City residents.

title: Ezekiel Emanuel Further Explains His Prediction That Employers Will Drop Health Insurance
description: Our recent interview with Dr. Ezekiel J. Emanuel about his provocative prediction that most employers will abandon health coverage by 2025 struck a nerve with Youre The Boss readers.

title: Viktor Orban Wins a Second Term in Hungary
description: BUDAPEST  Voters in Hungary have re-elected Viktor Orban and his conservative political alliance in parliamentary elections, according to preliminary election results released on Monday.

title: 20 Years After, Rwanda Pauses to Recall Carnage
description: LONDON  Rwanda on Monday commemorated the 20th anniversary of the genocide there with a fusion of tears, recrimination and regret at the killing of more than 800,000 people in 100 days that shocked the world, redrew regional battle lines and continues to  shape the debate over how nations should respond to mass atrocities.

title: Daily Report: Gravity Hits Highflying Tech Stocks
description: For much of the last year, Tesla Motors seemingly could do no wrong in investors eyes. A nearly unbroken string of quarterly losses, ambitions to build a huge battery factory: no matter. Shareholders kept pushing the companys stock up, by about 50 percent this year.

title: Credit Suisses Growing Headache
description: After years of false starts and stops, the Justice Department is nearing the end of an investigation into the role Credit Suisse played in hiding American wealth offshore. But at the same time, a new investigation is beginning, threatening to entangle the giant Swiss bank for even longer, Ben Protess and Alexandra Stevenson write in DealBook.

title: Channels of Oligarchic Influence: An Example
description: Ive been suggesting that inflation paranoia has a lot to do with the interests, or at any rate the perceived interests, of the 0.1 percent; the same goes for other policy arenas. But how does that influence work? Well, there are multiple channels. In some cases we have crude buying of influence through the promise of campaign contributions or the threat of backing someone else  hence the pilgrimage of GOP would-be presidents to Las Vegas to abase themselves before Sheldon Adelson. Some of it involves financing think tanks and media organizations. But an important channel, I believe, is personal: oligarchs quite literally wine and dine people who go along with their views and interests  and when billionaires are doing the wining and dining, well

title: Mallinckrodt Pharmaceuticals to Buy Questcor for $5.6 Billion
description: Updated, 8:22 p.m. | Questcor Pharmaceuticals has been criticized for steadily raising the price of its most valuable product  a 60-year-old immune system drug  to more than $28,000 a vial from $40 in just a decade. Critics have said the price increases were excessive, and short-sellers have predicted the companys business and stock price would collapse.

title: Laclede to Buy Alabama Gas Corp. in $1.6 Billion Deal

title: Internet Choice Will Be Crucial Battlefield in Big Cable Merger

title: 2nd Claim Will Delay Return of Matisse Painting From Trove of Looted Art

Chappelle Adds Radio City Shows
description: After staying away from scheduled performances on New York stages for a decade, the comedian Dave Chappelle announced on March 27 that he would make his return at Radio City Music Hall on June 19. By the time tickets went on sale, on Friday, the run had been extended to four shows (though June 22), and on Monday, with only premium tickets remaining (official platinum seats for up to $495, compared with the standard top price of $96.30), a fifth show has been added  on June 18. If Mr. Chappelles comeback is a test of show business proverbs  the audience is fickle and will forget you if youre not out there versus absence makes the heart grow fonder  the absence one appears to be winning.

title: Document | On a Lark
description: What began as a simple idea  taking portraits of caged birds against blank, colored backdrops  has turned into something of an obsession for the British photographer Luke Stephenson, whose images are compiled in a new self-published book. To access his feathered finds, he tapped into a network of quirky avian fanciers  from a vicar with an affinity for lovebirds to a hipster with an unironic collection of rare breeds  venturing into their homes with his miniature, portable studio. Save for a few dust specks, his images of budgerigars, conures, siskins and, yes, canaries arent retouched. He simply chooses complementary backgrounds, letting each subject get comfortable before taking its picture. Stephenson discovered that birds are generally well-behaved subjects. Humans, on the other hand, he says, are a lot less predictable. An Incomplete Dictionary of Show Birds; incompletedictionary.com.

title: Raymond Pettibons Surf Paintings Ride Into Manhattan
description: Just in time for the winter thaw, the uptown gallery Venus Over Manhattan has opened Are Your Motives Pure?, a show of surfer paintings by the artist and cult punk-rock illustrator Raymond Pettibon. The gallerist Adam Lindemann has painstakingly amassed more than 40 greatest hits  from small works embellished with the artists usual comic-book-style riffs to bold, monumental paintings  from a rarefied group of collectors all over the world. Having a Pettibon surfing painting is like having a Richard Prince car hood, Lindemann says. Theyre a slick and sunny slice of American pop culture. But while Pettibon examines the trappings of surf culture in the paintings, the artist  who despite living in Venice Beach, Calif., has never ridden the waves himself  is also dealing with universal truths. These works are about the solitary surfer against the vast ocean, man against nature. You get a sense that nature is going to swallow him up, Lindemann notes. You could see them as disaster paintings.

title: Deal for Questcor May Create More Headaches for Acquirer

title: Broad Art Museum Acquires Kusamas Infinity Mirrored Room
description: LOS ANGELES  Yayoi Kusamas Infinity Mirrored Room, the LED-studded walk-in installation that inspired eight-hour lines and countless selfies when shown at the David Zwirner Gallery in Manhattan last fall, is now heading to Los Angeles. The collectors Eli and Edythe Broad have bought the room-size installation for the Broad, their new art museum, for an undisclosed price.

title: Digestion
description: This animation highlights the major parts of the digestive system and follows the breakdown of celery from consumption to excretion.

title: A Magical Season for the Huskies, and a Title to Boot
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Shabazz Napier had spent the last few days trying to keep his Connecticut teammates emotions in check. Do not become wrapped up in the teams success at this N.C.A.A. tournament, he said. Do not celebrate too soon.

title: Getting to Know Your Inner Fish
description:
When Neil Shubin unearthed Tiktaalik, a 375-million-year-old fish, he knew he had found an animal with more than just fins. Inside it lived the bony foundations of all vertebrates yet to walk the earth. He talks about the discovery, and the new PBS miniseries, starting April 9, that it spawned.
Subscribe to the Podcast

title: Many Drug Prescriptions Go Unfilled
description: A Canadian study has found that almost one-third of patients never fill the prescriptions for the medicines they are told to take.

title: Ted Hearne Awarded New Voices Residency for Composers
description: Ted Hearne, a singer and composer known for his topical, politically sharp-edged works  The Katrina Ballads, about the inadequacy of the governments response in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, for example, and Ripple, based on documents made public by WikiLeaks  has been named the third annual New Voices composer by the San Francisco Symphony, the New World Symphony and the music publisher Boosey & Hawkes, which jointly administer the program.

title: Debating Which Perks Best Motivate Employees. Free Lunch?
description: At the most recent She Owns It business group meeting, the owners talked about retaining and motivating employees. Katie Finnegan said she realized the importance of this task soon after her company, Hukkster, made its first hires. To get ideas, she and Hukksters co-owner, Erica Bell, spent an afternoon at the San Francisco office of Twitter, where one of Ms. Finnegans friends works.

title: CSF oligoclonal banding  - series
CSF oligoclonal banding  - series
Unhappiness With Direction of U.S. Womens Team Led to Coachs Dismissal
description: Tom Sermanni awoke Sunday morning as the coach of the United States womens national team, preparing one of the best teams in the world for next years World Cup in Canada. By that night, the team had an impressive victory and a vacancy on its bench.

title: Complete blood count - series
Complete blood count - series
Next for Brodys Daughter: A Stage Role Opposite Cherry Jones
description: These have been some difficult months for Dana Brody, the brooding, trouble-making young woman played by Morgan Saylor on the Showtime thriller Homeland: she spent some time in an in-patient at a mental facility; a very bad thing happened to her father, Sgt. Nicholas Brody, in the season finale; and then it was reported that her character would no longer be a regular on the series. But life goes on for Ms. Saylor and her acting career: shell be joining the cast of Manhattan Theater Companys coming production of When We Were Young and Unafraid, the theater announced on Monday.

title: Growth hormone stimulation test - series
Amid Bids for Deoleo, Spains Government Seeks to Protect Olive Oil Sector
description: MADRID  A takeover battle for Deoleo, Spains biggest olive oil company, is testing the Spanish governments willingness to allow foreign investors control over one of its main agricultural sectors.

title: Ultrasound
description: This animation demonstrates how an ultrasound identifies the solid and hollow areas of structures within a fetus.

title: Robots Teach Robots to Beat Them at Pac-Man
description: Computer scientists at Washington State University have created robots that can teach other robots  in this case, to play the 1980s video-game sensation Pac-Man  and ultimately to outperform their teachers.

title: The New Ceramicists
description: A group of young artists is redefining the formerly folksy medium with sleeker, more sophisticated forms.

title: Gas Exchange
description: This animation illustrates the passage of air and exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide within the lungs on both a gross and microscopic level.

title: Rich Versus Middle-Class Donors
description: In a discussion on ABCs This Week the other day about the Supreme Court decision eliminating aggregate limits on contributions that individuals can make to political campaigns, Newt Gingrich suggested that the court should take one more step and eliminate caps on contributions to individual candidates.

title: Vidalia Onions: A Crop With an Image to Uphold
description: VIDALIA, Ga.  Like the rush to be the first to get bottles of Beaujolais nouveau to Paris or an Alaska Copper River king salmon to Seattle, the pressure to sell the first Vidalia onions of spring is intense. The identity of this town rests on the squat, sweet onion. This time of year, just before the first of the Vidalias are pulled from the sandy soil, the green tops farmers call quills cover nearly every field.

title: Nerve Conduction
description: This animation provides a general overview of the nervous system and shows the process in which nerve impulses are transmitted.

title: Obama Announces Grants in Maryland
description: President Obama spoke at Bladensburg High School in Maryland, one of three schools in Washingtons Maryland suburbs that received a grant for implementing innovative education programs.

title: Lasik eye surgery - series
Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 66
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Long a Survivor in Syria, a Dutch Priest Is Slain
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Rev. Frans van der Lugt, a Dutch Jesuit priest who became a symbol of suffering and compassion in the war-ravaged Old City district of Homs, Syria, was shot to death Monday morning by a lone gunman, according to members of his order. The killing came amid growing disputes between Syrian insurgents blockaded in the Old City  those who want to accept an amnesty from the government in exchange for laying down their arms, and those who do not.

title: Judge the Rebel Heart Sailboat Parents, or Envy Them?
description: My closest colleague here and I have had to agree to disagree on this one.

title: Discounts for Starwood Suites in New York
description: Starwood Hotels in the New York City area will hold the first Suite Week April 15 to 29, offering 30 percent off the best available rates in suites at all of its hotel brands.

title: Annenberg Fund Awards Fellowships to Seven Young Artists
description: The Leonore Annenberg Fellowship Fund for the Performing and Visual Arts, a 10-year program that is now in its seventh year, will award fellowships to seven young artists from diverse backgrounds, including a violinist who grew up in rural Kentucky and has won several important classical music prizes, but also doubles as a bluegrass fiddler, and a dancer with American Ballet Theater who began his career path when, as a 14-year-old in Florida, he auditioned for a performing arts high school on a whim.

title: Inside the Mind of a Child With Autism
description: Therapists who specialize in autism often use a childs own interests, toys or obsessions as a way to connect, and sometimes to reward effort and progress on social skills. The more eye contact a child makes, for example, the more play time he or she gets with those precious maps or stuffed animals.

title: Answers to Tough Questions About Dying
description: Lots of people want to encourage you to have the Conversation with aging family members about their wishes at the end of life, and then to help you document those preferences in an advance directive.

title: Egg Production
description: All of the immature egg cells (oocytes) a woman will ever produce are stored in the ovaries by the time she is born. The average age that girls begin to menstruate is 12 years old. Each menstrual cycle occurs approximately every 28 days. During each cycle, hormonal messages from the brain cause the ovaries to develop a single mature egg cell for potential fertilization, even as other hormones instruct the uterine lining to thicken in preparation for nourishing the fertilized egg cell.

title: Artistic Director Named for Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet
description: It has been almost a year since Benoit-Swan Pouffer left the position of artistic director of Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet, and rumors have swirled about potential candidates for the enviable task of running a well-funded, New York-based operation with an extensive repertory of work by big-name choreographers.

title: Comcast Shares Are Down, but Time Warner Cable Deal Is Still Safe
description: On Wednesday, lawmakers on Capitol Hill will ask Comcast to defend its proposed takeover of Time Warner Cable, a deal that would merge the two largest cable operators in the country. The Senate Judiciary Committee is expected to ask Comcast executives tough questions about competition and scrutinize how much choice consumers have when it comes to high-speed Internet.

title: Greta Gerwig Replaces Maggie Gyllenhaal in The Village Bike
description: Greta Gerwig has found time in her increasingly busy schedule for the stage: shell star as a pregnant, sexually adventurous young wife in Penelope Skinners The Village Bike for MCC Theater, the theater announced on Monday.

title: Salamanders, Natures Climate-Protecting Vacuum Cleaners
description: Small and slippery, these amphibians live humble lives in the forest. But salamanders may play an outsize role in slowing climate change.

title: A Hungry Butterfly Is a Hurting Butterfly
description: Monarch butterflies that go without food may end up with smaller, paler wings, according to new research in the journal PLOS One. To study the effect of food on growth, researchers deprived monarch larvae of milkweed. They found that two days of food restriction had a small but clear effect on wing size and coloration.

title: Salamanders Hefty Role in the Forest
description: If someone asked you to name the top predator in North American forests, you might think of bears, or maybe great horned owls. But heres another answer to think about: woodland salamanders.

title: Before the Silk Road, the Grain Road
description: Nomadic shepherds in the high plains of Central Asia used grain imported from China and southwestern Asia more than 5,000 years ago, according to a new study  perhaps to sprinkle over bodies in funeral rituals.

title: Chinas Dominance in Cement Has Little Effect on European Suppliers
description: HONG KONG  In the cement industry, as with so much else in global commerce, China is a dominant force.

title: Interest in a Property Grows With One Key Addition: An Architecture Prize
description: When he won the Pritzker Prize on March 24, the Japanese architect Shigeru Ban had a very busy day. As the 37th winner of architectures biggest prize  the professions Nobel  Mr. Ban made all the major papers, had appearances on CNN and NPR, and even sat down with Charlie Rose.

title: Heroic Figures From the Bible, Writ Large and Sparely
description: Stravinsky could be prickly and selfish, but he also had a generous streak. When the Swiss playwright Ren Morax, who was looking for a composer to provide incidental music for his King David, asked for his opinion of Arthur Honegger, Stravinsky gave a warm recommendation, and Morax and Honegger joined forces.

title: Minimalist Leather Goods from a Harvard-Trained Architect
description: The accessories designer Albert Chu likes to cite his grandfather  a mathematician who proved the Gauss-Bonnet Theorem in 1944 in just a few well-edited pages  as a formative influence. After all, why do something in a zillion steps when you can do it in a sentence? he says. It may be harder, but to me, the end result is so much more satisfying and beautiful. The same principle applies to Otaat, Chus L.A.-based line of mostly unisex leather bags and wallets. A rigorous thought process  Chu is a Harvard-trained architect and approaches designing bags as he does buildings  results in shapes that are easy, elegant problem-solvers. A sac called the Ninja Pouch flips and flops into multiple configurations; rectangular bags have dual handles that allow for horizontal or vertical orientation; softly structured box bags function as either. Theres a whiff of playful humor to the designs, underscored by the fact that Chu also sells conical party hats, made with the same premium leather and high-end stitching as the bags. As for the lines name? Its an acronym for One Thing at a Time, but its hard not to want all of it at once.

title: Weekend Gun Report: April 4-6, 2014
description: A federal judge has blocked Florida from enforcing a new law that banned doctors from discussing gun ownership with their patients. U.S. District Judge Marcia Cooke said the legislation was so vague it violated physicians right to free speech.

title: Colder Can Mean Older
description: Q. Does a lower body temperature mean a longer life?

title: Crossing Borders With Allure
description: Making new music approachable without pandering has long been of keen interest to the American Composers Orchestra, especially in the eight years that Derek Bermel has been involved  first as a composer in residence, and now as its artistic director. Border Vanguards, presented at Zankel Hall on Friday night, showed how this ensemble has become unusually adept at assembling menus of complementary courses, mixing the savory with the sweet in a manner palatable to almost anyone.

title: The 16th Centurys Line of Fire
description: Bertrand Russell once wrote that mathematics had a beauty cold and austere. In this new book, the historian Amir Alexander shows that mathematics can also become entangled in ugliness hot and messy.

title: For Space Projects, Zero Gravity
description: Opportunity, NASAs resilient rover, just keeps rolling across Mars even though it landed a decade ago. It has survived mechanical malfunctions, computer glitches, tricky sand traps, ferocious dust storms and long, frigid Martian winters.

title: If/Then Opens Well at the Box Office
description: Idina Menzels fans are following her to If/Then, the Broadway musical which drew lackluster reviews but earned a healthy $931,268 at the box office in its first full week of post-opening performances.

title: Puerto Rico Hires Bankruptcy Lawyers
description: Puerto Ricos fiscal agent has hired another well-known restructuring law firm, raising the specter that the financially troubled island is preparing to revamp its finances.

title: Lawyers for a Guantnamo Detainee Cite Failing Health in Seeking His Release
description: WASHINGTON  Lawyers for the last former British resident imprisoned at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, asked a federal judge on Monday to order his release because he has post-traumatic stress disorder and other mental and physical ailments.

title: Beaujolais, Freed From Clichs
description: Updated | May 5, 2014

title: Derek Jeters Colleagues Figure Prominently in a Victory
description: As the ball flew off Derek Jeters bat and into the left-field corner, Brian Roberts and many of his teammates thought they were about to witness another signature Jeter moment. Here was his final home opener, and as the ball zoomed closer to the wall, it appeared Jeter would again put his indelible stamp on Yankee history, just as he had with his famous flip, his dive into the stands, his World Series home runs and his 3,000th hit.

title: Smallpox and Murder Come to a Sweltering City
description: Emma Donoghues new novel is based on a very peculiar historical incident: a murder that took place in San Francisco in 1876 and was never conclusively solved. It does not speak well for Ms. Donoghues elaborately fictionalized narrative to say that her no-nonsense factual afterword is a more interesting telling of the story.

title: Showtime Series Aims to Engage Sleepy Public on Global Warming With Celebrity Guides
description: Early in 2011, two longtime 60 Minutes producers, David Gelber and Joel Bach, met with me to describe their ambitious plan to create a television series on global warming that, they hoped, would break through the enduring public apathy and haze of disinformation surrounding the subject. I wished them luck, while warning that the scale and complexity of the problem would make it hard to be both engaging and accurate.

title: Bach Is on the Spring Syllabus
description: Juilliard415, the orchestra of the historical performance program at the Juilliard School, has been enjoying quite a spring. Last month, it collaborated with the Choir of Trinity Wall Street in a performance of Bachs St. Matthew Passion, conducted by Gary Thor Wedow at Alice Tully Hall, that caught fire and magic.

title: Bordeaux, Decanted
description: Bordeaux is not the kind of wine most people fall for instantly. It lacks the sweet come-on that can be so seductive initially, but soon grows tiring. Instead, its a little austere, a bit reticent, especially when its young. But with time, Bordeaux reveals its many wonderful attributes. Its a wine you learn to love.

title: The Unintended Consequences of Treating College Athletes Like Employees
description: The head of an institution with a vested interest in maintaining the current college sports business model is unhappy about recent attempts to change it. Who could have predicted such a thing?

title: Asymmetric Stupidity
description: Ezra Kleins new venture Vox is up, and so far, so OK  some fairly interesting pieces, and nothing like Nate Silvers lamentable decision to make a professional concern troll his chief writer on climate. I am troubled by Ezras big inauguratory think piece, but thats because I think the piece raises a genuine intellectual puzzle.

title: Website Collects Online Information for Road Trips
description: The days of doing battle with folding state maps while driving across the country are fading, but even the latest route-finding technology can be cumbersome. Travel websites, smartphone apps and GPS units are great, but their specificity can lead to a technology pileup as each is put to its particular use.

title: Studios File New Lawsuit Against Megaupload and Its Founder
description: LOS ANGELES  Hollywoods major film studios on Monday added a new civil lawsuit on copyright infringement to the legal challenges facing the owners of the now-closed entertainment website Megaupload.com.

title: Reactions
description: PSYCHOLOGY

title: Email From Steve Jobs Hints at How Apple Ticks
description: .story-body-text strong { color: #444444; font-family: nyt-cheltenham, Georgia, serif;} .DC-note .DC-note-title { display: none !important; }

title: Few Frills, but Free Wi-Fi
description: Forget the kale in the minibar and a turned-down bed. For many business travelers, a clean, affordable room without all the frills, and in the right location, will do just fine.

title: Racking Up the Miles, But Still Chasing Elite Status
description: MICHAEL SOMMER and his friend Tom Mayo were on the ski slopes in Park City, Utah, on a sunny morning last Friday, passing a cellphone back and forth while they discussed with me how airline service for loyal fliers is going downhill fast.

title: Panel Urges Low-Dose Aspirin to Reduce Pre-eclampsia Risk
description: Pregnant women should take low-dose aspirin daily to reduce their chance of developing pre-eclampsia if they are at high risk for the life-threatening disorder, an influential government panel said on Monday.

title: Gauging the Intelligence of Infants
A Transformed Theater in a Transformed Land
description: MOSCOW  Thirty years ago, during my first trip to Russia, I bought a ticket for the Bolshoi Ballet. Though I paid an excessive amount by 1984 Soviet standards for a restricted-view seat all the way on the side of the sixth, uppermost ring, I didnt care: I was in the Bolshoi Theater for the first time. It was the world premiere of Yuri Grigorovichs new production of the three-act ballet Raymonda (1898). To see better, I switched to a slightly more central place. To steady myself, I sometimes placed my hand on the ceiling.

title: Albums From Sohn, Oran Etkin and Pedro Luis Ferrer
description: SOHN

title: Look for Cancer, and Find It
description: Mammography has become a fighting word in recent years, with some researchers questioning its value and others staunchly defending it.

title: Highbridge Capital Hires a Trader in London
description: The hedge fund Highbridge Capital Management, which recently hired away two portfolio managers from Steven A. Cohen, has picked off a portfolio manager in London from Claren Road Asset Management, a division of the Carlyle Group.

title: In Ethiopia, the Children Call Her Grape
description: I AM the deputy director of the Center for Health Logistics at John Snow Inc., a public health consulting firm. We work in dozens of countries, and manage logistics for the Agency for International Developments health supply chain. Basically, that means we work with governments to make sure that health products are available across health care systems in each country.

title: Fearing Punishment for Bad Genes
description: About 700,000 Americans have had their DNA sequenced, in full or in part, and the number is rising rapidly as costs plummet  to $1,000 or less for a full genome, down from more than $1 million less than a decade ago.

title: The Kills Alison Mosshart Reveals Her Artistic Side
description: Alison Mosshart has spent more than a decade pulling rock-star moves as the frontwoman for the blues-punk duo the Kills. But when shes not onstage, shes usually making art. Right now, the singer is exhibiting what she calls an oddball mix of works on paper, canvas and fabric from the last few years as part of Push It, a 21-person group show devoted to female artists, on view at ArtNowNY through April 26. Its the first time Mosshart has ever shown her art in public, but she doesnt plan on letting it be her last. She hopes to stage a solo show later this year in her hometown of Nashville,Tenn.  if she can steal enough time from recording the next Kills album in London, that is. Here, she reflects on her art-making and how it relates to her music.

title: Early Stephen King Novels to Be Reissued in Special Editions
description: Six of Stephen Kings early novels, all originally published by Doubleday between 1974 and 1983, are being given the deluxe treatment by Cemetery Dance Publications, a publisher that specializes in horror and suspense, and has published lavish editions of several of Mr. Kings later books.

title: Pictures of the Day: Rwanda and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Afghanistan, Bosnia, South Africa and Ukraine.

title: Game of Thrones Settles Into Hit Status
description: Its now official: HBO has its biggest hit since The Sopranos.

title: San Diego Couple Rescued in Ocean Defend Decision to Sail Across Pacific
description: A California couple, rescued from their 36-foot sailboat in the Pacific Ocean on Sunday after their infant daughter became ill, defended their decision to sail into open seas with two young children, as my colleague, Jennifer Medina reported.

title: Germany Announces Deal on Art Looted by Nazis
description: BERLIN  The German government on Monday announced an agreement with Cornelius Gurlitt, the son of a Nazi-era art dealer, that would pave the way for the possible restitution of art wrongfully taken from Jewish owners and held in his private collection for decades.

title: Monday Motorsports: Hamilton Prevails in Bahrain Thriller
description: Updated, 1:35 a.m.: Lewis Hamilton and Nico Rosberg, drivers for the Mercedes Formula One team, waged an often side-by-side duel at Sundays event in Bahrain. Hamilton held on for victory by a margin of one second.

title: Sidestepping the Biopsy With New Tools to Spot Cancer
description: For people with cancer or suspected cancer, the biopsy is a necessary evil  an uncomfortable and somewhat risky procedure to extract tissue for diagnosis or analysis.

title: A Strad? Violinists Cant Tell
description: Its a foregone conclusion in the violin world: The best violins were made 300 years ago by Italian masters like Stradivari and Guarneri del Ges.

title: The Road to Hell and Back Is Paved With Surprises
description: WASHINGTON  The Dutch composer Louis Andriessen, whose 75th birthday is being celebrated with a weeklong festival at venues across the Washington area, has built a reputation for writing accessible music. And it is, with orchestration as colorful and bold as a Hawaiian shirt and with a knack for keeping listeners engaged through unexpected twists that might include a violinist singing, an electric guitar lurking near the woodwinds or a brass chorale morphing into a bebop band.

title: Highlights and Analysis: UConn Beats Kentucky for Title
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The Connecticut Huskies had seen this script before, but they decided on a different ending.

title: Gay Marriage and Corporate America
Flash Boys Fuels More Calls for a Tax on Trading
description: Its not every day that you find a fan club for new taxes, especially among economists and legal experts.

title: Interview With William Rockefeller
description: A transcript of the National Transportation Safety Boards interview with William Rockefeller, the Metro-North Railroad engineer at the controls last year during a fatal train derailment in the Bronx.

title: In Performance: Emerson String Quartet
description: The Emerson String Quartet performs an excerpt from Beethovens Quartet No. 9 in C (Op. 59, No. 3).

title: What Fish Teach Us About Us
description: To Neil H. Shubins long rsum  paleontologist, molecular biologist, dean and professor of anatomy at the University of Chicago School of Medicine, best-selling author  can now be added television host. Dr. Shubin, 53, who helped discover the 375-million-year-old fish called Tiktaalik, hailed as a missing link between sea and land animals, will preside over Your Inner Fish, a three-part series on evolution (based on his book of the same title) that makes its debut Wednesday on PBS.

title: Masiello Will Keep Manhattan Job
description: The Manhattan mens basketball coach, Steve Masiello, will be allowed to return after he finishes his bachelors degree, the university announced Monday.

title: Medical Factual Report for William Rockefeller
description: A report from the National Transportation Safety Board on the medical history of William Rockefeller, the Metro-North Railroad engineer involved in the fatal train derailment in the Bronx last year.

description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

description: To the Editor:

title: Army Releases Detailed Account of Base Rampage
description: KILLEEN, Tex.  In a little more than eight minutes, Specialist Ivan. A. Lopez fired at least 35 rounds at his fellow troops at Fort Hood, unleashing panic and bloodshed over two blocks on foot and from inside his vehicle as he killed three unarmed soldiers and wounded 16 others while they were sitting at desks, driving in a car and standing outside buildings, an Army official said Monday.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: Q. Can the Microsoft Surface tablet run iTunes?

title: A 45-Second Test Flight
description: A test flight of a consumer aerial drone with a stabilized camera, the DJI Phantom 2 Vision Plus, ends when a moveable object meets an unyielding surface.

title: Reaction to Jailing of Egypt Activists
description: The brother of the detained activist Ahmed Douma, Mohamed Douma, and a human rights activist spoke out after an Egyptian appeals court upheld the jailing of leaders in the 2011 pro-democracy uprising.

title: Jimmy Van Bramer Is City Councils Arts Champion
description: He played drums as a teenager for the St. Josephs Brigade, a Catholic fife, drum and bugle corps. He fondly recalls singing along to his mothers 45s while he and his seven siblings cleaned their childhood home in Astoria, Queens. (Top of the World, by the Carpenters was a favorite.)

title: Court Rejects Appeal by Imprisoned Leaders of Egyptian Revolt
description: CAIRO  The prison sentences of three liberal leaders of the 2011 uprising in Egypt were upheld by an appeals court on Monday as the families of two other detainees  an Egyptian journalist and an American citizen  released an exchange of letters about the hunger strike they were conducting.

title: Where the Streets Have No Children
description: A chance mention of an Ecuadorean town with no children and a handful of old residents set Santiago Arcos on a mission to document its dwindling life.

title: Trisha Brown Dance Attains Half of Fund-Raising Goal
description: As the Trisha Brown Dance Company nears the halfway point of a three-year farewell tour, it plans to announce on Tuesday that it has raised half of the $5 million that it is seeking to preserve Ms. Browns legacy through educational initiatives and occasional performances.

title: A Troupe, Now 10, Has Its Routines
description: The most unusual thing about New Chamber Ballet is its regularity, its systematic schedule of performances. What other company presents new work with such consistency, and under such consistent circumstances?

title: After EMI Debacle, Guy Hands Finds Solace in Gardening
description: Guy Hands tried to make money from the likes of Katy Perry and Coldplay when he bought the music giant EMI in 2007. But he has had much more success selling resin garden animals and bedroom slippers to retirees in garden centers across Britain.

title: Rein In Shady Tax Preparers
description: WHEN you hear the words tax preparer, you may imagine a calculator-clutching accountant, carefully scrutinizing receipts beneath a green eyeshade. But the reality is that in most states nearly anyone can be a tax preparer. Theres no test to pass or code of ethics to follow. Walk around a low-income community and youll notice that check cashers, payday lenders, pawnbrokers and even furniture retailers offer tax-preparation services.

title: Billboard Names Tony Gervino as Editor
description: Billboard, the music industrys premier trade publication for more than a century, named Tony Gervino as its editor on Monday, the latest in a series of changes to remake the magazine in a more general-interest direction.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: A poll by The New York Times, NY1 and Siena College consisted of telephone interviews with 1,190 adult residents throughout New York City from March 29 to April 3.

title: Are Court Stenographers Necessary?
Mixed Marks for the Mayors First 100 Days
description: The New York Times, NY1 and Siena College asked New York City residents to assess Mayor Bill de Blasio and how he has been dealing with issues that range from education to unemployment.

title: 49 Percent of New Yorkers Approve of de Blasios Performance, Poll Says
description: Nearly half of New Yorkers approve of Mayor Bill de Blasios job performance so far in City Hall, and his high-profile effort to provide free prekindergarten has attracted wide support, according to a poll conducted by The New York Times, NY1 and Siena College.

title: Full Results of The New York Times/NY1/Siena College Poll
description: Forty-nine percent of New Yorkers approved of Mayor Bill de Blasios job performance, according to the poll.

title: Video Notebook: Brian McCann
description: The Yankees new catcher talked about his first home game with the team and being a part of Derek Jeters final opening day at Yankee Stadium.

title: Country Music Awards Nod to Young and Old
description: The 49th annual Academy of Country Music Awards on Sunday night split the difference between young and old: The show opened with a splashy, poppy performance by the Band Perry, and the 25-year-old Kacey Musgraves, left, won the album of the year award for Same Trailer Different Park. But some of the biggest shows of respect went to veterans like Merle Haggard, Garth Brooks and, especially, George Strait, who won for entertainer of the year, the top prize. The three-hour show, broadcast by CBS from two casinos in Las Vegas, also rewarded Miranda Lambert with single of the year, for Mamas Broken Heart, and best female vocalist. Jason Aldean was male vocalist of the year; Florida Georgia Line took home best vocal duo; and the Band Perry was best vocal group. Jessi Alexander, Connie Harrington and Jimmy Yeary, the songwriters behind Lee Brices hit I Drive Your Truck, won song of the year, and Justin Moore was named new artist of the year.

title: The Water Cooler Runs Dry
description: If youre closing in on 50 but want to feel much, much older, teach a college course. Im doing that now, at 49, and hardly a class goes by when I dont make an allusion that prompts my students to stare at me as if I just dropped in from the Paleozoic era.

title: What Suffering Does
description: Over the past few weeks, Ive found myself in a bunch of conversations in which the unspoken assumption was that the main goal of life is to maximize happiness. Thats normal. When people plan for the future, they often talk about all the good times and good experiences they hope to have. We live in a culture awash in talk about happiness. In one three-month period last year, more than 1,000 books were released on Amazon on that subject.

title: Equity Fund Buys Maker of Matzos
description: This year, Passover will be brought to you by private equity.

title: Polio Spreads From Syria to Iraq, Causing Worries
description: Syrias polio outbreak has now officially spread to Iraq, the first neighbor of the war-ravaged country to be hit by the crippling virus despite an ambitious Middle East inoculation effort, and global health officials warned Monday that dozens of vulnerable Iraqi children could potentially be infected.

title: Student Deaths, One After the Other, Unsettle a Close-Knit Campus
description: WASHINGTON  Three deaths at a single dormitory this semester, two of them last week, have shaken the campus of George Washington University. The first death has been confirmed as a suicide. One last week is thought to have been a suicide, while the cause of the other is still unknown.

title: Dangerous Game for a Writer
description: In The Writing Life, Annie Dillard points out that [a writer] is careful of what he reads, for that is what he will write. Ive encountered versions of this adage  along with the more extreme, dont read anything while writing, lest you contaminate your voice  from a variety of sources and have often wondered how it could possibly be true. After all, Ive spent my share of time with Dostoyevsky and Camus and Im still waiting. Such admonishment always struck me as one more of those superstitions writers cultivate for the sake of it, like never discussing a work in progress or stopping only when you know what happens next.

title: Sweep of Heat by Nets Would Be Striking, if Not Substantive
description: MIAMI  No team has beaten the Miami Heat four times during a single regular season since LeBron James arrived in 2010. The Nets have a chance to do just that on Tuesday night.

title: Prisoner in Israel Is Linked to Talks
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  He is the single most popular Palestinian politician, and he is serving five consecutive life sentences plus 40 years in an Israeli prison for crimes including murder. He is an ardent supporter of both the two-state solution and what Palestinians call the resistance against Israeli occupation. He is considered the top contender to become the next Palestinian president, and perhaps the only figure who can reunite the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

title: Operatic Drama Swells in Labor Talks at the Met
description: Labor strife at the Metropolitan Opera has been known to reverberate from the opera house to the White House. President John F. Kennedy helped salvage the 1961 opera season by asking his labor secretary to intervene in negotiations. President Jimmy Carter sent telegrams urging management and labor to keep talking in 1980, but a long lockout still truncated the season.

title: Ten Cents a Bag? Thats About Right
description: Theres something ridiculous about the life of a two-handled plastic shopping bag. The 20 minutes it spends cradling your groceries home is bracketed by two vast gulfs of time. First, thousands of years beneath the earth, in a natural-gas deposit, and then, after its conversion to a disposable polyethylene product, a second eternity as all-but-indestructible trash.

title: As Kayla McBride Boldly Goes, Notre Dame Follows Suit
description: NASHVILLE  It was not her numbers in the box score, though they were impressive enough. It was the look on Kayla McBrides face, adamant, fearless, that described how thoroughly Notre Dame dominated Maryland, 87-61, on Sunday in the semifinals of the womens Final Four.

title: Afghanistans Vote
description: That an estimated 60 percent of 12 million eligible voters in Afghanistan faced down Taliban threats and cast ballots in Saturdays presidential election is good news, suggesting civic resilience, a certain faith in democratic processes and a maturing political system in a war-torn country. It is a further sign that the time has come to end Americas combat role there after 13 years of conflict.

title: As Obama Spotlights Gender Gap in Wages, His Own Payroll Draws Scrutiny
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Tuesday will call attention to what he has said is an embarrassment in America: the fact that women make, on average, only 77 cents for every dollar that a man earns.

title: A Familiar Script in Ukraine
description: The events taking place in Donetsk and elsewhere in eastern Ukraine are very similar to those that led up to the Russian annexation of Crimea. In fact, the pro-Russian secessionists who seized the local administration building in Donetsk, the center of the industrial Donets Basin, are following the script laid down in Crimea to the letter. They have declared the regions independence from Ukraine and called for a referendum by May 11 on joining Russia.

title: NBC Expects to Strike Gold in a Late-Night Renaissance Led by Fallon
description: TOP executives of NBCUniversal took a victory lap of sorts on Monday, briefing a roomful of reporters on recent healthy ratings  practically round the clock  for their NBC television network and suggesting they would seek healthy increases in advertising rates when the upfront market for the 2014-15 season begins next month.

title: G.M.s Cobalt Crisis
description: The Chevrolet Cobalt is in many ways the perfect representation of the bad, old days of General Motors, when quality didnt much matter, market share was more important than profitability, and financial decisions came before design and even safety decisions.

title: Officials on Unrest in Ukraine
description: On Monday, officials from the United States, Russia and Britain discussed the growing unrest and violence in the Ukrainian cities of Donetsk, Kharkiv and Luhansk.

title: School Funding Deal in Kansas Complicates Governors Campaign for Re-election
description: Kansas lawmakers agreed over the weekend to send more money to the states poor school districts, addressing a State Supreme Court ruling last month that school financing had to be equalized around the state.

title: Mickey Rooneys Quietest Role
description: Forget Andy Hardy. Set aside, for the moment, the rest of his MGM highlight reel, the hoofing and crooning with Judy Garland, in his double-breasted suit with his pomaded hair swooped back, or in Western get-up or (yuck) blackface. Forget, too, the turbulent personal life of the problem gambler who went through the ladies like a hot knife through fudge, as Ava Gardner (Wife No. 1 of 8) put it.

title: Pacers Reliable Lineup Shows Signs of Overuse
description: Too much of a good thing can be bad, and the Indiana Pacers have found that their overused starting lineup is wearing down at the worst possible time.

title: Pressing Obamas Agenda, Maryland Lawmakers Raise Minimum Wage
description: Maryland embraced President Obamas call to raise the minimum wage to $10.10 an hour on Monday, the second state to do since Connecticut acted last month.

title: Concession Offered, Taiwan Group to End Protest of China Trade Pact
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  Yang Shih-wei admits he is an unlikely opponent of a trade deal with China. A 27-year-old Taiwanese banker who spent a year working at a trading company in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou, he has seen firsthand how quickly Taiwans giant neighbor is growing. And he says that if Taiwan wants to compete economically, it cannot shun China.

title: Tech Firms May Find No-Poaching Pacts Costly
description: It is the talk of the Valley.

title: John Pinette, 50, Stand-Up Comic and Actor, Dies
description: John Pinette, a stand-up comic whose Falstaffian figure provided him with no shortage of subject matter, died on Saturday in Pittsburgh. He was 50.

title: Irans Choice for U.N. Post Denied Entry Into the U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate voted unanimously on Monday night to bar Irans newly named ambassador to the United Nations from entering the United States, charging that he was involved in the hostage-taking at the United States Embassy in Tehran in 1979.

title: Charlotte Names New Mayor Amid Scandal
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  In a city left reeling after its mayor resigned in a federal corruption sting two weeks ago, the City Council on Monday chose a successor, Daniel G. Clodfelter, a state senator in his eighth term who is a former member of the Council.

title: Hackers Lurking in Vents and Soda Machines
description: SAN FRANCISCO  They came in through the Chinese takeout menu.

title: Drivers in New Jersey to Lose Link as Pulaski Skyway Route Closes
description: NEWARK  Here is the view of New Jersey transportation from an eight-acre tow yard on the edge of the city:

title: U.S. Gas Tantalizes Europe, but Its Not a Quick Fix
description: HOUSTON  As congressional pressure builds on the Obama administration to quicken gas exports to Europe to reduce its dependence on Russia, it may be tempting to gaze upon a marshy, alligator-infested Louisiana inlet of the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Air National Guard on Baby Rescue
description: Maj. Mark Bomann, the flight doctor who treated a sick baby who was rescued from a family boat in the Pacific Ocean, said the 1-year-old girl was in stable condition.

title: Chuck Stone, a Fiery, Trusted Columnist in Philadelphia, Dies at 89
description: Chuck Stone, whose columns for The Philadelphia Daily News denouncing racism, political corruption and police brutality inspired such trust that wanted criminals sometimes surrendered to him rather than to the police and the authorities called on him to mediate prison crises, died on Sunday in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 89.

title: In Switch, Development Agency Welcomes Business and Technology to Poverty Fight
description: JOHANNESBURG  Civic leaders recently broke ground on a lush cricket field here for the Nelson Mandela Childrens Hospital, a nearly $100 million state-of-the-art pediatric facility that is to provide care for youth throughout Southern Africa. Donations are pouring in, but not enough.

title: 2 Tots, a Sailboat and a Storm Over Parenting
description: LOS ANGELES  As her family began what was supposed to be a monthslong journey in a 36-foot sailboat from Mexico to New Zealand, Charlotte Kaufman wrote openly of her misgivings about taking her two daughters  ages 1 and 3  to sail the South Pacific, with her husband as captain and herself as the crew.

title: Succeed and Proceed, to Instant Riches
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Throughout the course of an intriguing N.C.A.A. tournament, John Calipari spoke about the transformation that took his team of freshmen from midseason mediocrity to the N.C.A.A. championship game, where it lost to a veteran Connecticut team. But the most compelling change was how Calipari has transformed his pregame and postgame interview sessions into small revivals and prayer meetings, promoting and preaching the gospel of Kentucky basketball, defending and explaining a recruiting system praised and vilified as one and done.

title: Wish for Change Animates Voters in India Election
description: NEW DELHI  Over the last several years, as the yearning for a strong leader began to deepen and swell in the Indian electorate, one politician was systematically preparing himself to be the answer to that demand.

title: Two World War II Veterans Honor 19 Soldiers Who Disappeared 70 Years Ago
description: EAST FARMINGDALE, N.Y.  On Monday morning, two World War II veterans held bouquets of roses and boarded an old warplane at Republic Airport here. Both men  Frank Kittle, 90, and Jack McMullen, 91  narrowly escaped death while serving on such planes over Europe during the war.

title: Dogs and Scoundrels, Well Dressed
description: An English bulldog plays a minor role in the new production of The Threepenny Opera that opened at the Atlantic Theater Company on Monday. Romeo is his name, and he acts very naughty in the tableau that opens the show, slobbering away at the leg of a streetwalker whos passed out flat on the ground. Still, Romeo is as cute as can be and looks as if he wouldnt have a mean bite, even if, say, you slapped a tiara on his head and asked him to do his best impression of Queen Victoria.

title: Thats Enough!
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  We started off the week with a terrific debut by Douglas Taillon, and we continue the fun with a really nice puzzle by Ian Livengood. This one was another one that felt like it was over too soon.

title: Sharpton Is Linked to Spying on the Mafia
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton was an F.B.I. informer who had extensive dealings with Mafia figures in New York in the 1980s and secretly recorded their conversations using a briefcase modified with hidden electronic equipment, a report said on Monday.

title: At Google, Bid to Put Its Glasses to Work
description: SAN FRANCISCO  At the 500 Club bar in the heart of the Mission district here, patrons are banned from wearing Google Glass. Two miles up the hill at the hospital at the University of California, San Francisco, a lung surgeon wears Glass to assist him as he operates.

title: Conferences Snub Haunts UConn
description: NASHVILLE  Warde Manuel had a few minutes  but only a few  to say a few words. He had another rush to an airport to make, another plane to catch.

title: Somalia: 2 U.N. Advisers Slain
description: A security guard in Somalias semiautonomous Puntland region shot to death two consultants working for the United Nations shortly after they had landed at the Galkayo airport on Monday, officials said. Nicholas Kay, the United Nations special representative for Somalia, said the two victims were advising the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime. One victim was British and the other was French, The Associated Press reported, citing British and French officials. The president of the Puntland region, Abdiweli Mohamed Ali, confirmed that the gunman was a security guard and said that he had been arrested, along with an accomplice, another guard. Mr. Ali said an investigation was underway.

title: Sleep Disorder and Schedule Change Cited as Possible Factors in Train Derailment
description: For the last two and a half years, William Rockefeller worked nights. And on most of those nights, he was operating a Metro-North Railroad train along the Hudson line, the scheduled stops as familiar to him as the exit signs a driver sees day after day along a highway.

title: Intersection: Elmhurst Style Ease
description: In the Queens neighborhood of Elmhurst, locals like to keep their style casual.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 7, 2014
description: April 7, 2014

title: UConn Battles Kentucky
description: The Connecticut Huskies took on the Kentucky Wildcats in Mondays N.C.A.A. championship game.

title: Canada: Parti Qubcois Seen Losing Power in the Province
description: An attempt to secure power in Quebec by calling a snap election turned against the separatist Parti Qubcois on Monday. Based on early returns, four television networks forecast a victory for the Liberal Party. The results are likely to be viewed as a severe rebuke of the movement for Quebec independence. Before the election, the Parti Qubcois played down the likelihood that it would seek a third referendum on separation if re-elected. For years, polls have shown that a firm majority of Quebeckers oppose leaving Canada. Yet the partys attempt to avoid the issue, which was the basis of its founding, fell apart last month when its star candidate, Pierre Karl Pladeau, a media magnate, immediately vowed to make Quebec a nation in a rousing speech that concluded with a raised fist.

title: Another Injury Shelves David Robertson
description: The last time David Robertson was named to replace Mariano Rivera was in 2012 after Rivera had sustained a season-ending knee injury. Robertson made only a handful of appearances before he suffered a strained oblique muscle, and the job of closer went instead to Rafael Soriano.

title: UConn Defeats Kentucky for Mens Title
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  All week, Shabazz Napier was asked about the Connecticut team of 2011, the team that began March as outsiders before rumbling through the N.C.A.A. tournament. He was a freshman on that team, as old as the five players in Kentucky blue joining him Monday for the opening tip-off in the national championship.

title: Food Banks Tax Service Puts Money in the Hands of Those in Need
description: Single mothers and fathers, unemployed workers and retirees on lean budgets were all following the signs for the Food Bank for New York City to the basement of a senior center in the Bronx.

title: A School Board That Overlooks Its Obligation to Students
description: SPRING VALLEY, N.Y.  A principal leans across the table at a pizza parlor and, with whispered intensity, totals up the damage done to the East Ramapo Central School District in recent years.

title: For Derek Jeter, Awkward Play and Trademark Cool
description: This was his day, the first at home of his 20th and final season, and there stood Derek Jeter, in the hallway outside the Yankees locker room, utterly helpless. Like a magician backstage, eager for his act but missing his magic wand, Jeter fiddled with the locks on his case of Louisville Sluggers. It would not open.

title: Rookie Answers Yankees Needs, if Not Fans Chants
description: In the moments before the Yankees took the field during Mondays home opener, the backup catcher Francisco Cervelli approached Yangervis Solarte in the dugout to remind him of the traditions at Yankee Stadium.

title: A New Twist on the Iconic Maralunga Sofa
description: Cassinas founder Cesare Cassina and the visionary furniture designer and architect Vico Magistretti crafted an enduring design legacy together, one to which even the most dedicated of couch potatoes are forever indebted. Legend has it that when Cassina first saw Magistrettis prototype for the now-iconic 1974 Maralunga sofa, he disliked it so much that he punched it  hard. His frustration split the back of the model, which fell back over itself so that it resembled a headrest. This serendipitous series of events eventually resulted in the design for the Maralunga, the first upholstered sofa to incorporate movement  the back transforms into an actual headrest  for ultimate comfort. To mark the 40th anniversary of its bestseller, the company collaborated again with design visionaries to develop a new version of the sofa, this time tapping 20 students from the Swiss art and design school ECAL for the task. Just in time for Milans annual design week, Salone Internazionale del Mobile, the results are on view at the Cassina showroom in the city beginning tomorrow.

title: The Shape of Things
description: For a certain set of artists and thinkers, Legos are not mere childs play, but objects of both abstract and formal perfection.

title: After the Jobs Report, a Look at Three Critical Labor Market Trends
description: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: Teenager Tells Police Boredom Led Him to Start Fire That Injured 2 Officers
description: A Brooklyn teenager said boredom had led him to set fire to a mattress in his apartment building on Sunday, setting off a blaze that critically injured two New York City police officers, the authorities said after he was arrested on Monday.

title: Times Minute | Hacking the Soda Machine
description: Also on the Minute, labor troubles at the Metropolitan Opera and the rescue of a 1-year-old sailor.

title: Chevrolet Equinox and GMC Terrain Lead Their Class in Small-Overlap Crash Test
description: Only two of nine 2014 model-year midsize utility vehicles evaluated in the most recent small-overlap frontal crash test conducted by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, an insurance industry-financed organization, earned the highest rating of Good: the Chevrolet Equinox and its GMC twin, the Terrain.

title: An Ex-Councilman Upstages the Mayor at His Own Event
description: It is one thing for the mayor to be heckled at a news conference. It is another for him to be heckled by someone speaking from his own lectern.

title: After Pines Removal, Fans Miss a Tree That a President Often Didnt
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  The gates opened Monday at the Masters and a race-walk event broke out. Once on the grounds of Augusta National Golf Club, many patrons purposefully made their way to the par-4 17th hole to ogle at or take photographs of a fairway that has healed beautifully, though a circular scar remains visible from the removal in February of a very large, distinctive beauty mark.

title: A Primer on Indias Parliamentary Elections
description: Over the next five weeks, Indians will take part in what is considered the worlds largest democratic exercise. Malavika Vyawahare, a reporter for India Ink, answers some basic questions about the election:

title: Quebecers Reject Separatists, Handing Power to Liberal Party
description: OTTAWA  An attempt to secure power in Quebec by calling a snap election turned against the separatist Parti Qubcois on Monday. In a reversal of early campaign expectations, the Liberal Party, which supports remaining in Canada, emerged with a strong victory.

title: Larry Brown, Ex-Coach of Knicks, Criticizes Franchise
description: Being back in Madison Square Garden last week to coach his Southern Methodist team in the National Invitation Tournament must have put Larry Brown in a New York state of mind.

title: Hockey Brawl Is Old Story of Policemen vs. Firemen
description: It is rare these days, but it happens. The tension between the Fire Department and the Police Department erupts in public, leaving an old rivalry newly exposed.

title: Whats on Tuesday
description: 8 P.M. (13) THE DAVE CLARK FIVE AND BEYOND  GLAD ALL OVER This Great Performances Special Event celebrates the 50th anniversary of the British Invasion with footage from some of the 18 appearances on The Ed Sullivan Show by the Dave Clark Five and its 2008 induction into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, as well as clips featuring the Beatles, the Rolling Stones, the Who, Dusty Springfield, Stevie Wonder, the Supremes, Martha Reeves and the Vandellas, Marvin Gaye, Otis Redding, Freddie Mercury  and Laurence Olivier. Among those sharing memories are Paul McCartney, Elton John, Bruce Springsteen, Ozzy Osbourne, Gene Simmons, Whoopi Goldberg, Dionne Warwick, Twiggy and Ian McKellen.

title: India Election Digest: April 8
description: As Indian voters head to the polls, India Ink will be compiling a daily digest of the top election-related news from local media.

title: Rangers Wonder if Home Is Advantage
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The Rangersclinched a playoff spot Mondaywhen the Devils lost, so now they are playing solely to hold on tosecond place in the Metropolitan Division.If they do finish second, they willhave home-ice advantage in the first round of the playoffs. But isthat something they really want?

title: For Randle and Wildcats, Dream Ending Is Stymied by the Huskies Defense
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  In a corner of Kentuckys locker room, Julius Randle was surrounded by cameras, boxed in, not unlike how he looked during the previous 40 minutes of basketball.

title: Tennessee Votes to Eliminate Special Tax for Professional Athletes
description: Lawmakers in Tennessee voted Monday to repeal the states so-called jock tax, levied on athletes.

title: Two More Sets of Signals Detected, Australian Officials Say
description: SYDNEY, Australia  An Australian search vessel has detected two more sets of signals that might originate from black box flight recorders from the Malaysia Airlines jetliner missing for more than a month, an Australian official coordinating the search for the plane said on Wednesday.

description: Take the Quiz

title: Jury Awards $9 Billion in Damages in Drug Case
description: In one of the biggest damages verdicts ever imposed, a jury in Louisiana has ordered a Japanese drug maker and its American partner to pay a combined $9 billion in punitive damages over a diabetes drug that has been linked to cancer.

title: Warburg Pincus Takes Majority Stake in Aviation Technology Firm
description: LONDON  The private equity firm Warburg Pincus said on Thursday that it had acquired a majority stake in mercator, an information technology services provider to the airline industry.

title: Diamond Taps Barclays Executive to Head Atlas Mara
description: LONDON  Robert E. Diamond Jr., a former chief executive of Barclays, did not have to look far to choose the top executive of his new investment company, Atlas Mara Co-Nvest.

title: How Not to Seem Rich While Running for Office
description: Like many seekers of higher office, Ann Callis doesnt know financial hardship. But thats O.K. Her elders did.

title: Where the Streets Have No Children
description: The tail end of a radio report stayed with Santiago Arcos from the moment he heard it one groggy morning five years ago. It was about a village in his native Ecuador, La Cinega, a place that had no children.

title: Should the United States Stop Using the Death Penalty?
description: Room for Debate recently asked if the death penalty is dying in the United States, and if that is a bad thing. After all, 18 states already outlaw capital punishment, with New Hampshire possibly becoming the 19th. Last year the United States executed 39 people, down from its post-1976 peak of 98 executions in 1999.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

description: Good morning on this soggy (but eventually sunny) Tuesday.

description: DONETSK, Ukraine  As the government in Kiev moved to reassert control over pro-Russian protesters across eastern Ukraine, the United States and NATO issued stern warnings to Moscow about further intervention in the countrys affairs amid continuing fears of an eventual Russian incursion.

title: Tearful Drama as Pistorius Says He Panicked
description: PRETORIA, South Africa  It was bold, splashy and theatrical, the kind of flourish more often seen in courtroom dramas than in real-life murder trials. In the middle of his emotional and harrowing testimony on Tuesday, the champion sprinter Oscar Pistorius stood up in full view of the packed courtroom, removed his prosthetic legs and demonstrated in a few ungainly steps how very vulnerable and exposed he can be with only his stumps to depend on.

title: Civil Society Activists Face Trial in Beijing
description: A lawyer considered a key figure in the New Citizens Movement went on trial Tuesday in Beijing, the latest person to face the prospect of prison time for involvement in a group that called for government transparency and equal rights for Chinas rural residents.

title: U.S. Contractor Held in Cuba Begins a Hunger Strike
description: WASHINGTON  Alan Gross, a former contractor for the United States Agency for International Development who has been imprisoned in Cuba for four years, plans to announce today that he has begun a hunger strike to help him win his freedom, a spokesman for Mr. Gross said.

description: HONG KONG  Samsung Electronics is finding little to revel in these days.

description: In UConn Defeats Kentucky for Mens Title, Ben Shpigel writes about Mondays N.C.A.A. championship game.

description: Companies scrambling to seal up their systems from hackers and government snoops are having to look in the unlikeliest of places for vulnerabilities, Nicole Perlroth reports.

description: Aaron Levie, the chief executive of Box, is preparing to take his cloud storage company public.

title: When a Job Does Not Guarantee a Paycheck
description: ATHENS  Having a job provides scant security if you are not sure when you will be paid.

title: Europes Many Jobless See Little Light Yet From Glimmers of a Recovery
description: ATHENS  When Kostas Polychronopoulos lost his high-paying marketing position at a telecommunications company at the height of Europes financial crisis in 2010, he exhausted himself for more than a year trying to find work.

title: Hagel Spars With Chinese Over Islands and Security
description: BEIJING  The United States and China clashed over Japan on Tuesday as the Chinese defense minister asserted that Beijing had indisputable sovereignty over a group of islands in the East China Sea and that his countrys military stood ready to protect its interests in territorial disputes.

title: In Our Pages: April 9
description: 1939: Man in the Moon Hurt in Fall

title: The Case of Who v. Whom
description: We stumble regularly over who and whom. And as Ive noted before, our most common problem seems to be using the objective-case whom when who is needed. Most often this occurs when an attribution phrase separates the relative pronoun from the verb and misleads us.

title: 10 Courses With a Twist
description: Why are so many nonmajors taking Introduction to Computer Science at Harvard or Introductory Oceanography at Cornell? Why is Temple Grandins livestock course at Colorado State always filled, and not just with students at home on the range?
