description: The Emerson String Quartet performs an excerpt from Beethovens Quartet No. 9 in C (Op. 59, No. 3).

title: Inventive Teaching
description: Some professors can make a subject sing, and their courses are not just a credit but an event.

title: Questioning the Valleys No-Poaching Pacts
description: A high-stakes negotiation is taking place in Silicon Valley among some of the biggest names in the industry  Apple and Google among them  over accusations that they were involved in a collusion to prevent their employees from being hired at rival companies, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column. The employees have filed a class-action lawsuit contending that the illegal hiring practices cost them $9 billion in lost wages. The companies are hoping to settle the case in the next several weeks.

title: No Easy Comeback
description: Despite signs of economic recovery, many in Europe are struggling to recover from the harsh downturn, straining government safety nets.

title: A Cream Cheese Type of Flirtation
description: Dear Diary:

title: After Slide, Rich Nations Now Lifting Growth, I.M.F. Reports
description: WASHINGTON  The rich countries whose property bubbles and collapsing banks plunged the world into recession in 2009 are now helping to lead the still-halting recovery out of it.

title: A Makeover at Universal Studios Hollywood Aims at Disney
description: UNIVERSAL CITY, Calif.  Now Comcast is mouse hunting on both coasts.

title: Comcast Gears Up to Persuade Regulators
description: WASHINGTON  Comcast presented regulators on Tuesday with 650 pages of reasons to approve its takeover of Time Warner Cable, saying a merger of the two largest cable television companies would spur rather than inhibit competition by encouraging rivals to improve their cable and high-speed Internet service.

title: Notes Found in Review of Police Work Could Exonerate 2 Convicted in Killing
description: A review of homicide convictions stemming from the work of Louis Scarcella, a Brooklyn detective accused of framing suspects, has turned up a stash of old handwritten police notes that could exonerate two men convicted of a murder in 1985. One of the men served 21 years in prison; the other died behind bars.

title: Charting Roseland in the 1990s
description: In the early 1990s the Roseland Ballroom, which closed Monday night after Lady Gagas final performance there, was one of the best places in New York to see bands from the newly minted alt-rock scene. Here the artist Andrew Kuo charts 23 shows he saw at Roseland from 1992 to 1995, when he was a high school music fan, including Nirvana, the Beastie Boys, Pavement and Hole.

title: How Has Fiction Handled the Theme of Money?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Pankaj Mishra and Rivka Galchen discuss how fiction writers have approached the subject of money.

title: Senate Panel Approves Nominees to Futures Trading Commission
description: Updated, 3:39 p.m. | The Senate Agriculture Committee on Tuesday approved the nomination of Timothy G. Massad, a former corporate lawyer, as chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, one of Wall Streets toughest watchdogs.

title: Comments by Modis Top Aide Reveal Religions Role in Party Strategy
description: Last week, Amit Shah, the general secretary of Indias opposition Bharatiya Janata Party and widely seen as the lieutenant of Narendra Modi, the partys prime ministerial candidate, spoke at a private meeting near Muzaffarnagar in the northern Indian state of Uttar Pradesh.

title: A Little to the Imagination
description: The seasons strategically worn bandeau tops and shoulder-baring dresses are a sharp and sexy complement to masculine dressing.

title: Riverdale Just Wont Be the Same: Archie Will Die
description: CNN broke the news today about the impending death of Archie Andrews, the happy-go-lucky redhead from Riverdale and star of various Archie comics. But the truth of his demise is complicated.

title: Zuni Ask Europe to Return Sacred Art
description: PARIS  Octavius Seowtewa, an elder of the Native American Zuni tribe from New Mexico, was sitting in a Paris cafe late last month, scrolling through his iPhone pictures of Ahayuda, carved and decorated wooden poles that are considered sacred to the Zuni. They were taken at his recent meetings with representatives of major European museums, whom he is hoping he can persuade to return the artifacts.

title: Measuring Motherhood, One Preschool Application at a Time
description: At last Id completed Zees preschool applications, and was feeling positive about my mothering. Which was a good thing, because we were meeting my dear friend Jamie, one of those moms who magically knew all the tricks.

title: Choice to Oversee Cohen Fund Has Link to It
description: Updated, 9:28 p.m. | The degree of separation between Steven A. Cohen and Bart M. Schwartz, the consultant selected last week to monitor the operations of the former SAC Capital Advisors, is closer than previously known.

title: Private Equitys New Kind of Club Deal
description: Trendy new buyout clubs may disappoint their eager would-be patrons. The Blackstone Group is enlisting some of its fund investors to help buy the auto parts maker Gates for $5.4 billion. Such collectives are increasingly displacing teams of private equity firms in bigger deals. Returns from so-called co-investing, though, could make it a passing fad.

title: South Beach Meets Sioux Falls in D-League
description: SIOUX FALLS, S.D.  Not long after he was released by the Oklahoma City Thunder in September, DeAndre Liggins learned that the N.B.A. Development League affiliate of the Miami Heat had acquired him. Liggins, a shooting guard, figured the team was in Florida. He was wrong.

title: Rhode Island Settles Case on Jobs for the Disabled
description: The Justice Department on Tuesday announced a landmark agreement with the State of Rhode Island to free people with developmental disabilities from a decades-old system that kept them unjustly segregated in sheltered workshops and adult day programs, removed from the competitive workplace and the broader community.

title: Times Minute | Why Pistorius Fascinates
description: The former Johannesburg bureau chief Lydia Polgreen on why South Africans cant look away from the Oscar Pistorius murder trial.

title: Times Minute | Why Pistorius Fascinates
description: In the Video

title: Crashing DJIs New Drone Into Water and Land
description: Updated. | Expanded explanation of DJIs new camera stabilization.

title: Catherine Hardwicke, Lake Bell to Help Judge  Tribeca Film Festival
description: The director Catherine Hardwicke, the actress Lake Bell and the director Ben Younger will be among the 33 jurists for this years Tribeca Film Festival, which runs from April 16 to 27, festival organizers announced Tuesday.

title: In Mississippi, a Long-Time Republican Senator Isnt Regressive Enough
description: If you care deeply about the distinctions between various types of Republicans  not a hobby Id recommend for those without professional training  you might be aware that Thad Cochran of Mississippi is not a particularly conservative senator.

title: For Car Thieves, the Older and Heavier the Ride, the Better
description: Of all the crime declines in New York over the past two decades, the virtual eradication of car theft has been among the most complete: They are down 94 percent from the 1990s, when blaring multitune car alarms served as the citys after-hours soundtrack.

title: The Case of Brendan Eich
description: Ive written a fair amount about pluralism lately, in the context of debates about what kind of accommodations might be made for religious institutions and communities in a public-policy landscape thats likely to become increasingly hostile to some of their beliefs. That discussion offers an interesting background to the defenestration of Brendan Eich, briefly the CEO of Mozilla, for his past donation to the ballot initiative that (temporarily) re-established the conjugal/opposite-sex definition of marriage in California. I say interesting because while Eichs ouster has been cited (by some liberals as well as conservatives) as a kind of left-wing escalation in the culture war, there are some ways in which his fate might be reasonably seen asless troubling, to principled pluralists and religious conservatives both, than some of the other cases and controversies currently in the news.

title: Oscar Pistorius Breaks Down
description: The Paralympic athlete Oscar Pistorius broke down on the stand during his murder trial in Pretoria, South Africa.

title: Twitter Gives a New Look to User Profiles
description: Twitter began the rollout Tuesday of a new look for its profile pages that is meant to highlight each users best tweets.

title: Taking a Taxi': Remembering Mickey Rooney on Broadway
description: Glen Roven, the original musical director of Sugar Babies, shared this reminiscence of working with Mickey Rooney on Broadway in what became the actors late-in-life comeback triumph. Mr. Rooney died on Sunday at 93.

title: Underwater Pings
description: The sounds from a Teledyne Benthos ELP-362A, a device similar to the pinger believed to be affixed to the black boxes aboard Flight 370, as recorded off headphones a diver searching for a device might use. The depth of the black box in icy ocean waters and other variables may affect the devices actual sound.

title: Samsung Edges HTC in New Android Phones
description: IN a rare bit of cosmic alignment, two Android phone stars drop into orbit at the same time this week.

title: Congress Picks Local Legislator to Face Heavyweight Rivals in Varanasi
description: NEW DELHI  The Indian National Congress said Tuesday that it had nominated Ajay Rai, a legislator from the Varanasi constituency of Uttar Pradesh, to run against Narendra Modi of the Bharatiya Janata Party and Arvind Kejriwal of the Aam Aadmi Party.

title: Mideast Frustration, the Sequel
description: WASHINGTON  For those who suspect that the Middle East peace process has become a diplomatic drama, playing on an endless loop, Secretary of State John Kerrys testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Tuesday could serve as Exhibit A.

title: Hospitals Safer Than Homes for Births
description: A new analysis suggests that giving birth in a hospital is considerably safer than having a baby at home or in a birthing center.

title: NYT Now: Ukraine Parliament Brawl
description: A fistfight erupted in the Ukrainian Parliament as lawmakers debated unrest in the countrys east.

title: Pastor Is Convicted of Trying to Sell Counterfeit Art
description: A Florida pastor who dabbles in art dealing was convicted on Tuesday of trying to sell five fake Damien Hirst paintings to an undercover police officer.

title: Cuba Social Media Project Was No Plot, Agency Says
description: WASHINGTON  A Twitter-like social media site created and financed by the United States Agency for International Development for use in Cuba was an attempt to promote open communications among citizens on the island nation, not a covert attempt to overthrow the government, the agencys top official told members of Congress during a hearing on Tuesday.

title: Stedelijk Museum in Amsterdam Names New Director
description: The Stedelijk Museum in Amsterdam, a mecca for modern and contemporary art fans, has named Beatrix Ruf to be its new director, The Art Newspaper reported Tuesday. Ms. Ruf has been director of the Kunsthalle Zurich for the last 13 years. She is succeeding Ann Goldstein, who announced her resignation in August after having led the institution since 2009.

title: Ayad Akhtar Play Among Highlights of New York Theater Workshop Season
description: The New York premiere of The Invisible Hand, a work by the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Ayad Akhtar, is the centerpiece of the New York Theater Workshops 2014-15 season, which the company announced on Tuesday.

title: Today in Small Business: The Cost of a Bad Hire
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: A Bird Walks Into a Bar ...
description: On the concise drinks menu for the downstairs bar at Celeste, a cocktail den that opened in Chicago in February, theres a small section titled Classics. The four drinks under that heading are the manhattan (of course), the Negroni (natch), the Brown Derby (a little more arcane, but a classic) and the Jungle Bird.

title: Image of the Day: April 8
A Writerly Life, Beneath the Surface
description: His high school friends called him Uppie, as if he were a drug. Hed claim the back booth in Stephens Luncheonette, in Shillington, Pa., his hometown, and amuse everyone by blowing smoke rings and French inhaling. He was gawky and shy but almost sexy.

title: Philip Roth to Be Honored With Yaddo Medal
description: Yaddo, the artists colony in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., has chosen the Pulitzer Prize-winning author Philip Roth to be the first recipient of a new medal it is awarding artists.

title: Dianne Feinstein Accused of Deep Emotional Feeling
description: If Michael Hayden, the former Director of the Central Intelligence Agency, wanted to say something ridiculous about a member of Congress, he succeeded. During an appearance on Fox News Sunday, where Republicans go to trash Democrats without fear of follow-up questions, he said that Senator Dianne Feinsteins deep emotional feeling had tainted the Senate Intelligence Committees report on the C.I.A.s abuse of prisoners after the 9/11 attacks.

title: Maazel Withdraws From Two Carnegie Hall Concerts
description: Lorin Maazel, who was to have led the Munich Philharmonic Orchestra on Friday and Saturday at Carnegie Hall, has withdrawn from the performances because of illness, the hall said. Valery Gergiev will conduct the Friday evening program, and Fabio Luisi will take over on Saturday. The programs Mr. Maazel, 84, was to conduct were both devoted fully to the works of Richard Strauss, and are unchanged.

title: For Passover, Fried Artichokes
description: ROME  I have always loved artichokes fried in the Jewish style, or carciofi alla giudia, a traditional dish of the Roman Seder. So on a recent trip to Rome, I hunted for them. Every chef I queried had the same answer, delivered with the same slightly weary shrug: You have to go to the ghetto for that.

title: Obama Signs Measures to Help Close Gender Gap in Pay
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Tuesday signed two executive measures intended to help close longstanding pay disparities between men and women as Democrats seek to capitalize on their gender-gap advantage at the ballot box in a midterm election year.

title: Among Ukraines Jews, the Bigger Worry Is Putin, Not Pogroms
description: DNIPROPETROVSK, Ukraine  From his office atop the worlds biggest Jewish community center, Shmuel Kaminezki, the chief rabbi of this eastern Ukrainian city, has followed with dismay Russian claims that Ukraine is now in the hands of neo-Nazi extremists  and has struggled to calm his panicked 85-year-old mother in New York.

title: Wheelies: The Car Tipping Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Best, Brightest and Rejected: Elite Colleges Turn Away Up to 95%
description: Enrollment at American colleges is sliding, but competition for spots at top universities is more cutthroat and anxiety-inducing than ever. In the just-completed admissions season, Stanford University accepted only 5 percent of applicants, a new low among the most prestigious schools, with the odds nearly as bad at its elite rivals.

title: Imax Selling 20 Percent of Its China Business
description: LOS ANGELES  China Media Capital, a state-run entertainment investment fund that has already done business with Time Warner, DreamWorks Animation and 21st Century Fox, added Imax to its deal portfolio on Tuesday.

title: The Stars Remain Aligned
description: Jean-Georges is still a four-star restaurant. That is all. Thank you for your time.

title: Tech-Focused Hedge Fund to Return $2 Billion to Investors
description: As investors nurse steep losses from technology stocks, one hedge fund has decided to return money to investors and turn its focus to companies not listed on the stock market.

title: A New Line | Talons Boho-Chic, West Coast-Inspired Jewelry Collection
description: The Brooklyn designer Emily Hirsch creates jewelry with a talismanic quality. She began her line Talon in 2009 with glass and metal amulet necklaces that contained vials of blended essential oils that reminded her of her California childhood. Now, she is expanding to a full range of pieces steeped in the feeling of 1970s West Coast Americana, including rings, earrings, cuff bracelets etched with detailed feather and flower motifs and a pendant necklace in opal, carnelian, onyx or Indian garnet, each stone set in recycled silver or gold.

title: Inquiry Implicating Rowland, Ex-Connecticut Governor, Offers Look at a 2012 Race
description: Last week he was holding forth as usual on hot-button topics like Benghazi and big government, and bantering with on-air guests who addressed him by his former title, Governor.

title: New Ferry Service Between Maine and Nova Scotia
description: Beginning May 15, Nova Scotia-bound travelers have a new transit option from Maine: getting there by cruise-ship-style ferry.

title: Three Legs Good, One Leg Bad
description: The good news for Obamacare just keeps coming in. Via Charles Gaba, the Rand Survey  which was the subject of a report in the LA Times, but which wasnt publicly available  is now in. And it says that as of mid-March  that is, before the final enrollment surge  the Affordable Care Act had already produced a net gain of 9.3 million insured adults. Again, thats a net gain; so much for claims that more people are losing insurance than gaining it.

title: Banks Ordered to Add Capital to Limit Risks
description: Updated, 9:08 p.m. | Federal regulators on Tuesday approved a simple rule that could do more to rein in Wall Street than most other parts of a sweeping overhaul that has descended on the biggest banks since the financial crisis.

title: Comcast Gives a Nod to a Future Apple Set-Top Box
description: Inside a document published by Comcast on Tuesday, the company gives a nod to a future Apple set-top box, even though Apple hasnt introduced one yet.

title: Share Your Favorite Travel Ritual in Europe
description: We invite you to send us photos of a place in Europe youve visited repeatedly that is meaningful to you.

title: The Gun Report: April 8, 2014
description: With just one signature, it will be legal to openly carry firearms in Kansas, nullifying city and county gun regulations across the state.

title: Beautique Opens Next to the Paris Theater
description: Headliner

title: Germany Moves Forward on Renewable Energy Plan
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkels government approved legislation on Tuesday revamping Germanys sweeping plan to generate more than 40 percent of its energy needs through renewable resources by 2025 by slowing the rapid expansion of solar and wind parks in an effort to hold down spiraling prices.

title: Man Wrongfully Convicted in 1989 Brooklyn Murder Is Set Free
description: A timeworn phone bill from a Quality Inn in Orlando, Fla., turned out to be one of the most valuable pieces of paper Jonathan Fleming owns.

title: Astier de Villattes Collaboration with a Countess
description: Ivan Pericoli and Benoit Astier de Villatte of Astier de Villate, known for their scents and ceramic accessories, are presenting two new ceramics collections created in collaboration with the Countess Setsuko Klossowska de Rola, a painter and the widow of Balthus (and the subject of some of his most famous paintings). The first collection is inspired by the architecture of the Grand Chlet of Rossinire, the home Klossowska de Rola shared with Balthus beginning in the the 70s and where she still lives today. The second includes playful ceramics modelled by the countess herself, including a candlestick tree and an incense burner in the form of a cat.

title: Bomb on Train in Pakistan Kills 14
description: LONDON  A bomb ripped through a stationary train in western Pakistan on Tuesday, killing 14 passengers and wounding at least 40, half of them seriously, in a new escalation of the long-running conflict in Baluchistan Province.

title: Trying to Make a Character Move as Easily as You Do
description: Motion-controlled gaming has never worked as well as advertised.

title: Family Disaster Preparedness
description: Eighty percent of the population would not survive the first 100 days of the apocalypse, Bob Gaskin, who served in the Marines and is the founder of the Black Dog Survival School, told an assembled crowd at the Third Annual National Preppers and Surivalist Expo in Tulsa, Okla. If you dont know now what youre going to do then, he said, you arent going to make it.

title: Captain and Design Faulted in East River Ferry Crash
description: WASHINGTON  A ferry crash on the East River that injured 80 people last year was caused by captains error and a poor design on the ferrys high-tech bridge, the National Transportation Safety Board said on Tuesday.

title: Unusual Seder Plates, a Traditional Neapolitan Tart, Singani and More
description: To Observe: From Four Questions to Four Corners

title: Jean-Georgess Classic Asparagus
description: Jean-Georges Vongerichten discusses one of his signature dishes at Jean-Georges: asparagus under morels in hollandaise.

title: Westerleigh, S.I., Built on Temperance
description: Followers of the temperance movement late in the 19th century created a place called National Prohibition Park, where they could escape the stresses and bad influences of the city. The community, on Staten Islands North Shore, is now known as Westerleigh.

title: In San Francisco, Staying True to an Areas Roots
description: The newly coined Mission Creek neighborhood in San Franciscos northeast Mission District has long been home to light industrial manufacturing. But lately Mission Creek has become a creative hub for local goods, and unlike in many fast-changing areas of the city, the new arrivals here have so far stayed true to the areas roots: Its a place where people make things.

title: The Kentucky Derby as a Rite of Passage
description: Native Dancer, the thoroughbred that won race after race in the 1950s, was unlike the stocky draft horses Carl Myers knew as a boy growing up in Amish country in Lancaster County, Pa. The colt was lean and elegant and, with its gray coat, stood out among the other thoroughbreds on his familys black-and-white television set.

title: Hotel Review: Hotel Santo Toribio in Cartagena, Colombia
description: Rates

title: Restaurant Report: Burnt Ends in Singapore
description: New restaurants are a dime a dozen in Singapore, but novel concepts are still a rarity  which probably explains why Burnt Ends, a gourmet barbecue joint, has been packed since it debuted last May.

title: Improving the User Experience of Automated Integration Testing
description: The New York Times Test Infrastructure Development team has been working on a reporting system with a new front end to present results for our functional test suites. Weve decided to open source our projects as we continue to work on them.

title: 30 Seconds With Jim Palmer
description: Jim Palmer, the Hall of Fame pitcher for the Baltimore Orioles, grew up a Yankees fan in New York. One of his fondest memories is of his father taking him to his first game at Yankee Stadium in 1954. The Indians were playing the Yankees. He was amazed at how the field glowed.

title: Jeters No. 2 Is No. 1
description: At Mondays home opener in the Bronx, Deter Jeter shirts were everywhere, welcoming back the Yankee captain as he begins his final season.

title: A Few Notes to Hear All
description: At the risk of hyperbole, it seemed likely that fewer notes were played during a 110-minute performance of Peckinpah Trios, a 2004 piece by the Dutch composer Antoine Beuger, on Saturday night, than might have been contained in a single ringtone on an audience members smartphone. No one present could make the comparison the hard way, thanks to the standard cautionary announcement.

title: Those Fish Fins You Call Hands and Other Evolutionary Quirks
description: The club of scholars named Neil who are good writers and also telegenic is fairly small, with Neil deGrasse Tyson (see Cosmos: A Spacetime Odyssey) sometimes seeming to be its only member. But lets not overlook Neil Shubin, a paleontologist who makes an appealing guide to our evolutionary history on Your Inner Fish, a three-part exploration, based on his books, that begins on Wednesday on PBS.

title: Damien Hirst to Tell His Story
description: The British artist Damien Hirst has signed a deal to publish his autobiography with Viking Penguin, the publisher announced on Tuesday. The autobiography, due out in Britain in fall 2015, will be written with James Fox, who worked with Keith Richards on his 2010 memoir, Life. The book is to be published in the United States by Penguin Press, also in fall 2015. (Viking Penguin and Penguin Press are imprints of Penguin Random House.)

title: Oxygen Shifts Focus to Millennial Viewers
description: In another sign of the growing influence of the millennial generation on Madison Avenue, the Oxygen cable channel will be revamped to appeal to a modern young woman, offering several new series with a multicultural focus.

title: Text to Text | Bangladesh Factory Safety and the Triangle Shirtwaist Fire
description: Can disasters make life better for future generations?

title: Scene City: A Spy Thriller in Heels
description: Vogue and Cinema Society host screening of BBCs Turks and Caicos.

title: How to Make Great Pizza Dough
description: Anthony Falco of Robertas in Bushwick, Brooklyn, shows Sam Sifton how to make restaurant-style pizza dough at home.

title: After 09 Fraud, Afghanistan Reports a Cleaner Election
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan presidential election on Saturday appeared to be substantially cleaner than the widely discredited 2009 election, according to complaint figures released Tuesday by the authorities here.

title: Underwater Search
description: Officials designated an underwater search area around the two locations where they have estimated the missing plane may have entered the water.

title: A Little Pizza Homework
description: There is pizza dough in my refrigerator right now. I made it last night in about 20 minutes, 15 of which were spent reading a magazine while it rested. Ill bake it tomorrow night under mozzarella, then put a small arugula salad on top, an homage to the Green and White pizza available at Robertas in Brooklyn.

title: Obama Pushes Equal Pay for Women
description: Lilly M. Ledbetter, left, watched as President Obama signed two executive measures aimed at increasing transparency about womens pay.

title: Unearthing Lost Gems in Career of Lyricist
description: A fantasy that tantalizes many music theater aficionados is the dream of unearthing a lost masterpiece from the trove of shows that flopped on Broadway or were never produced. Tastes change, after all, and work considered too avant-garde back in the day may suddenly be rediscovered and retrospectively deemed ahead of its time.

title: Ts Toast to Salone
description: To kick off Salone Internazionale del Mobile and celebrate Ts spring design issue, which is out this weekend, some of the worlds best-known architects and designers gathered at the Villa Necchi Campiglio last night in Milan. Video art by Derrick Adams set the scene for the fete, where Ts editor in chief, Deborah Needleman, and the Italian art curator Francesco Bonami hosted a range of design and fashion luminaries: Tom Dixon, Francesco Vezzoli, Daniel Libeskind, Ambra Medda, Joseph Dirand, Laura Sartori Rimini, Ts Tom Delavan and the house of Missonis leading ladies, from Rosita and Margherita to Angela and Teresa.

title: You Cant Always Get What You Want
description: Numbers suggest that the difference between need-blind and need-aware admissions is fuzzy.

title: Weakness in Infield Leaves Yankees Vulnerable
description: The Yankees infield will undergo a drastic makeover after shortstop Derek Jeter retires at the end of the season. But even now, the four players who take the infield these days for the Yankees are hardly recognizable.

title: Experts Find a Door Ajar in an Internet Security Method Thought Safe
description: Updated | A flaw has been discovered in one of the Internets key security methods, potentially forcing a wide swath of websites to make changes to protect the security of consumers.

title: Irans Choice of Envoy Not Viable, U.S. Says
description: The Obama administration intensified its objections on Tuesday to Irans nomination for United Nations ambassador, a former translator whose role in the 1979-81 Tehran hostage crisis has touched American political nerves, asserting that the choice was not viable in what seemed as close as possible to ruling it out.

title: An Editorial Cartoon on Native American Mascots Comes to Life in Cleveland
description: Last week, a die-hard fan of the Cleveland Indians named Pedro Rodriguez expressed his love for the baseball club as he has each year for the past decade, by attending the first game of the new season dressed in homage to Chief Wahoo, the clubs Native American mascot, in a feathered headdress with his skin painted bright red.

title: If the Devil Taps You, Pretend You Didnt Feel It
description: When Stravinsky wrote The Soldiers Tale, his 1918 dramatic work that combines spoken text with a seven-piece chamber ensemble, he had in mind the touring puppet shows and playing troupes he encountered in the Russia of his youth. Over the years, when The Soldiers Tale has been presented as a staged drama or a ballet, it has often been updated or mythologized. It is probably best known as a concert work, without its spoken text.

title: The Lives of Animals, Disabled and Otherwise
description: Fans of the PBS series Nature are used to having their breath taken away by the photography, but theyre less accustomed to having their heartstrings tugged. Wednesdays installment, My Bionic Pet, about animals with disabilities, goes for the emotions. Its one of three programs this week that prove that television about nonhuman creatures can be more than mere pretty pictures or idiotic turtle wrangling.

title: Youth Movements, Glittering if Not Yet Totally Polished
description: Seeing back-to-back programs of the same company can reveal a lot about its dancers. Do they become more or less complex, the more you get to know them? Do you want to keep spending time with these people, or have you had enough?

title: Embracing Ambiguity in Israel
description: Frederic Brenner looks at his complex identity through the lens of Israels ambiguities and contrasts.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 65
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Your Homework Assignment: Sue the Federal Government
description: Some law school students send the Justice Department rsums and references. At the University of Virginia School of Law, one class is sending document requests and lawsuits.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, Romania, Central Africa Republic and India.

title: TripAdvisor Expands Environmental Rating Program
description: International travelers looking for a certain amount of green in their accommodations can now turn to TripAdvisor for help.

title: Target to Stock More Environmentally Friendly Products
description: When Eric Ryan helped start Method Products in 2001, the market for environmentally friendly soaps and cleaning products, he recalled, was a niche of a niche of a niche.

title: For Injured Bolshoi Director, a Time to Judge
description: Sergei Filin, the artistic director of the Bolshoi Ballet who was partly blinded last year in a brutal acid attack that stunned the dance world, paused for some eye drops then put on his brown-tinted wraparound sunglasses before making his way to the theater.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: ARTnews Sold to Private Company
description: Talked-about sales in the art world usually involve a painting or sculpture. On Tuesday, the big item in the shopping basket was ARTnews, which describes itself as the worlds oldest and most widely circulated art magazine. Milton Esterow and Judith Esterow, the owners of the magazine since 1972, said in a statement that they sold the 112-year-old publication to Skate Capital, a private asset management firmowned by a Russian, Sergey Skaterschikov.

title: Kerry and McCain on Foreign Policy
description: Secretary of State John Kerry and Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, exchanged harsh words over the Ukraine crisis and foreign policy on Russia at a Senate hearing.

title: The Art of Collaboration, in Action
Threes a Trend | Concrete Sculpture at the SP-Arte fair in So Paulo
description: Last week, So Paulo played host to the 10th annual SP-Arte fair, held in the gargantuan Ciccillo Matarazzo pavilion in Ibirapuera Park, a sinuous structure of concrete, steel and glass designed by Oscar Niemeyer for the 1957 So Paulo Biennial. Perhaps the setting explains the preponderance of minimalist concrete sculpture trotted out by several hometown galleries at this years event, which closed on Sunday. At Galeria Jaqueline Martins, So Paulo-based Ana Mazzeis Et Nous, Nous Marchons Inconnus (which translates to And We, We Walk Unknown) was a procession of gray geometric forms marching from wall to floor. David Batchelor, a Scotsman, placed a number of cement bricks on plinths at the booth of Galeria Leme, adorning them with shards of broken, colored glass. Meanwhile, at the upstart gallery Emma Thomas, a buffet of drinking glasses (water, Margarita, shot, Champagne) were spread across a table and filled to the brim with cement by the local artist Lucas Simes. Called Bebado Samba (or Drunken Samba), its a punning rejoinder to Brazils midcentury Concrete and Neo-Concrete art movements, which spiraled off into a plurality of aesthetics and a scene impossible to read as a single movement, according to the artist. The final view can be seen as a party where the drunken conversations happen.

title: Weather Channel Returns to DirecTV
description: The Weather Channel will return to DirecTV Wednesday after a nasty three-month dispute, with the cable network getting a small price increase but agreeing to substantial concessions, including an alteration of its daily national programming schedule to accommodate the demands of the satellite service.

title: Legacy Evolving at a Presidential Library
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  There are few conferences that could have lured President Obama and three former presidents  Jimmy Carter, Bill Clinton and George W. Bush  as the Civil Rights Summit is doing this week at the LBJ Presidential Library here. This three-day gathering to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Civil Rights Act, which began on Tuesday, includes Mr. Obama as the keynote speaker on Thursday morning, with the former presidents speaking successively each night. Mr. Carter was to speak Tuesday night; Mr. Bush will conclude the summit on Thursday.

title: McClatchy to Sell Anchorage Daily News to Alaska Dispatch Publishing
description: Business moguls continue to shake up the world of newspapers, this time to the far north.

title: Investors Appetite for I.P.O.s Seems to Ebb
description: Companies are rushing to the public markets on Wall Street to sell their shares, and this week is expected to be the busiest for initial public offerings in more than seven years.

title: Over 50 and Underappreciated
description: Not long ago, the cosmetics industry veteran Andrea Robinson was in her Park Avenue apartment, showing off a newly built home office with white walls and a monochrome animal print rug. The sparse aesthetic contrasted with the lush textiles of the living room, where a fire was roaring.

title: In Womens Game, Its Not Just Basketball, Its Family
description: NASHVILLE  Until Connecticut left no doubt in its superiority in an unprecedented championship showdown of unbeaten teams with Notre Dame on Tuesday night, the N.C.A.A. womens tournament was almost a rumor compared with its all-consuming mens counterpart.

title: Officials Remarks Attacking S.E.C.s Timidness Cause Stir
description: A textbook retirement speech blends beloved anecdotes with tired clichs. James Kidney, a trial lawyer at the Securities and Exchange Commission who recently departed the agency, offered a different style: an airing of grievances.

title: Powerful, Disruptive Shareholders
description: THE season is starting for annual meetings, when shareholders have the chance to attend gatherings of companies in which they own stock to tell chief executives whats on their mind.

title: HBO Signs Game of Thrones to Two More Seasons
description: A day after receiving news that Game of Thrones had shattered its previous ratings records, HBO announced that it had ordered two more seasons of the program, a fantasy drama.

title: Global Warming Scare Tactics
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  IF you were looking for ways to increase public skepticism about global warming, you could hardly do better than the forthcoming nine-part series on climate change and natural disasters, starting this Sunday on Showtime. A trailer for Years of Living Dangerously is terrifying, replete with images of melting glaciers, raging wildfires and rampaging floods. I dont think scary is the right word, intones one voice. Dangerous, definitely.

title: Syrias Shrine of Sayeda Zeinab
description: As Syria convulsed in conflict, the fear that the Sayeda Zeinab shrine could be destroyed alarmed the faithful across the region, particularly Shiites.

title: Magazines Coordinate Their Content in Version of TVs Crossover Episodes
description: Crossover episodes of television series are a popular method to stimulate ratings, as viewers are encouraged to watch cast members from one show turn up on another. Crossovers date to the early days of the medium and there was one as recently as March 26, when cast members from two TV Land series, Hot in Cleveland and The Soul Man, exchanged appearances on each others programs.

title: Bard College Applicants Trade 10,000 Words for Two: Youre In
description: Helen Chen, a senior at a small public high school in San Francisco, is the kind of student who tries teachers patience.

title: European Court Rejects Data Retention Rules, Citing Privacy
description: BRUSSELS  A top court on Tuesday struck down a European Union law, adopted in response to deadly terrorist attacks, that required telecommunications companies to retain information about calls and emails for up to two years.

title: A Cappuccino for Public Safety
description: In New York, many things are referred to as jokes. The Van Wyck Expressway, for example, a coarsely paved road that has been under repair for as long as anyone can remember, is a joke. Compared with those of other world capitals, our mass transit system is a joke. And every now and then were reminded that underground is a bewildering mess of pipes, wires and fibers, the stuff that keeps the whole semi-anarchic mess running. Thats a joke, too, one that The Times called a glaring example of Americas crumbling infrastructure.

title: Search for Malaysian Jet to Be Costliest in History
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  As the intensive hunt for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 entered its second month on Tuesday, the only certainty was that it would become the most expensive search and recovery effort in aviation history, with an international fleet of ships and planes scouring the Indian Ocean at a cost of millions of dollars a day.

title: At Fort Hood, Wrestling With Label of Terrorism
description: KILLEEN, Tex.  In the hours and days after a deadly shooting at Fort Hood last week, Army officials have not shied away from talking about terrorism  to contrast it with the 2009 attack and to ease fears about the motive behind the second mass shooting on the base in nearly five years.

title: Playing Hockey With Putin
description: Shortly before the Sochi Olympics, Russian President Vladimir Putin played in an exhibition hockey game there. In retrospect, he was clearly warming up for his takeover of Crimea. Putin doesnt strike me as a chess player, in geopolitical terms. He prefers hockey, without a referee, so elbowing, tripping and cross-checking are all permitted. Never go to a hockey game with Putin and expect to play by the rules of touch football. The struggle over Ukraine is a hockey game, with no referee. If were going to play  we, the Europeans and the pro-Western Ukrainians need to be serious. If were not, we need to tell the Ukrainians now: Cut the best deal with Putin that you can.

title: Details of Sharptons Time as Informer Shed Light on a Life With Many Chapters
description: It was the early 1980s, and the Rev. Al Sharpton was seeking a foothold in the music business. He called news conferences and said he would schedule demonstrations and boycotts if black promoters were not given a role in Michael Jacksons Thriller tour.

title: U.S. Fines General Motors $28,000 for Not Cooperating With Ignition Flaw Inquiry
description: Federal safety regulators fined General Motors $28,000 on Tuesday, saying it had not provided much of the information requested for an investigation into a recall of about 2.6 million cars with an ignition switch defect that G.M. has linked to 13 deaths.

title: Keeping Track: Unemployment Insurance and a Financial Tax
description: Jobless Benefits, Withheld

title: In Montana, Cutthroat Trout Are Hungry Trout
description: WEST GLACIER, Mont.  When A River Runs Through It was released 21 years ago, moviegoers who had never seen a fly rod descended upon tackle shops. Once outfitted, they made a beeline to Montana for a chance to cast to oversize brown and rainbows like those Brad Pitt seemed to land on every other cast. Those anglers probably did not realize that like themselves, the browns and rainbows were relatively recent arrivals, shouldering into the historical domain of Montanas state fish.

title: Closing Ports to Stolen Fish
description: The oceans are vast and humans are small  as the monthlong hunt for a vanished Malaysian jetliner demonstrates. Think of the challenge, then, for law enforcement and fisheries managers in going after fleets of shady boats that engage in illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. These criminals ply the seas and sell their catches with impunity, making off with an estimated 11 million to 26 million metric tons of stolen fish each year, a worldwide haul worth about $10 billion to $23.5 billion. Many use banned gear like floating gillnets, miles long, that indiscriminately slaughter countless unwanted fish along with seabirds, marine mammals, turtles and other creatures.

title: Illinois Moves to Ease Chicago Pension Woes
description: CHICAGO  The Illinois legislature on Tuesday approved a plan to start easing Chicagos crippling pension problems by requiring some city workers to pay more for their retirement benefits and by granting smaller increases in those benefits.

title: Gov. Cuomo Drops the Ball
description: Less than two months ago, Gov. Andrew Cuomo announced a plan to provide public financing for basic college-education programs in state prisons  a tried and true way to reduce recidivism at a fraction of the cost of keeping people behind bars.

title: Number of Mothers in U.S. Who Stay at Home Rises
description: BOSTON  Likely driven in part by economic factors and changing demographics, the number of stay-at-home mothers in the United States has risen since 2000 after decades of decline, a report released Tuesday by the Pew Research Center shows.

title: After Rwandas Genocide
description: On Monday, Rwanda commemorated the victims of a genocide unleashed 20 years ago by Hutu extremists in power then. More than 800,000 people, mostly Tutsi men, women and children, were systematically hunted down and brutally murdered over a period of just 100 days. The world stood by and let the blood bath happen.

title: Democrats Use Pay Issue in Bid for Womens Vote
description: WASHINGTON  Democrats, trying to recast the midterm election focus away from health care, are reaching out to the constituency that has delivered them the last two presidential elections, the Virginia governors race and a bevy of close Senate contests: women.

title: Ford Forges Into China
description: A late entrant into China's booming car market, Ford Motor's joint venture is now enjoying surging sales while regulators ponder different rules for international automakers.

title: Heartbleed Security Flaw Emphasizes the Need to Change Passwords
description: Wait a day or so. Then change the passwords on the web services you use.

title: Arthur Smith, Musician Who Wrote Dueling Banjos, Dies at 93
description: Arthur Smith, a country musician known for the hit Guitar Boogie and for Feuding Banjos, a bluegrass tune that became Dueling Banjos in the film Deliverance, died on Thursday at his home in Charlotte, N.C. He was 93.

title: Chinas Embrace of Foreign Cars
description: CHONGQING, China  For more than a decade, Chinese automakers have been talking about starting large-scale exports to North America and Europe, prompting periodic worries in the West that companies like General Motors, Ford and Volkswagen might be crippled by Chinese competition the way they were by Japanese imports a generation ago.

title: Jeb in the Vortex
description: WASHINGTON  The epic sibling drama of the Republican Party is finally coming to a climax.

title: China's Coming Economic Crisis?
Zeituni Onyango, Obamas Aunt From Kenya, Dies at 61
description: BOSTON  Zeituni Onyango, President Obamas Kenyan-born aunt, who received asylum in the United States in 2010 after years of living illegally in Boston, died on Tuesday in a rehabilitation home here. She was 61.

title: Redwood Poaching in California
description: At Redwood National and State Parks, thieves have been stealing burls, protrusions on trees that are prized for their intricately patterned wood.

title: Inspired by Countrymans Victory, Australians Follow Adam Scotts Lead to Augusta
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Adam Scotts shout of Cmon Aussie after he drained a long putt that vaulted him into a playoff at the Masters last year echoed a late 1970s cricket jingle that became a countrys rallying cry. Little did Scott know then that his countrymen would treat it as an exhortation.

title: ECO 348, The Great Recession:Quantitative Easing
description: Slides here (pdf).

title: Poachers Attack Beloved Elders of California, Its Redwoods
description: REDWOOD NATIONAL AND STATE PARKS, Calif.  It was an unlikely crime scene: a steep trail used by bears leading to a still, ancient redwood grove. There, a rare old-growth coast redwood had been brutally hacked about 15 times by poachers, a chain saw massacre that had exposed the trees deep red heartwood.

title: Rounding Up Suspects, Pakistan Charges a Baby
description: LONDON  Pakistans troubled criminal judicial system has failed to prosecute several notorious figures living there over the years, including Hafiz Saeed, the militant leader with a $10 million American reward on his head, and Osama bin Laden.

title: For Phil Mickelson, Emotions Dont Fade, Even 10 Years and 3 Green Jackets Later
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Ten years ago, no one knew or cared how high Phil Mickelson could jump. Back then, Mickelson was considered the worlds best known golfer without a major championship. How he would react to his first major victory mattered not at all because it might never happen.

title: For Obama Presidency, Lyndon Johnson Looms Large
description: WASHINGTON  Two days before joining other presidents in Texas to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Civil Rights Act, President Obama tackled enduring inequality himself on Tuesday, in this case economic disparity based on gender.

title: Edwin F. Kagin Dies at 73; Battled Religious Displays
description: Edwin F. Kagin, the son of one minister and father of another, who saw religiosity creeping into the public domain and fought against it in a dual role as head lawyer and jester-provocateur for one of the countrys most militant atheist organizations, died on March 28 at his home in Union, Ky. He was 73.

title: Masters Field Grappling With Void Left by Tiger Woods
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  During Phil Mickelsons news conference with reporters on Tuesday, Tiger Woods was mentioned indirectly. Mickelson launched into an unsolicited explanation of how Woodss absence is affecting the 2014 Masters tournament.

title: Hillary Clintons High-Tech Marketing Message
description: If Hillary Rodham Clinton doesnt run for president, she could always get a job in marketing, particularly around testing messages and evangelizing new technology.

title: Marine Shoots Fellow Guard at North Carolina Base
description: A guard at a Marine Corps base in North Carolina was in custody Tuesday night after he shot and killed another guard in an isolated incident, officials said.

title: In New Tack, I.M.F. Aims at Income Inequality
description: What happened to the I.M.F.?

title: Parti Qubcois Failed to Renew Mandate, Analysts Say
description: OTTAWA  Two obituaries may be written in the  crushing defeat of the Parti Qubcois in Mondays election: for separatism as a political force in Quebec in the foreseeable future, and for the party itself, whose aging leaders were brought down by the very issue on which it was founded.

title: Ken Forsse, Who Brought a Toy Bear to Life, Dies at 77
description: Talking toys have been around since Edison made a doll that recited nursery rhymes by means of a small hand-cranked phonograph. Now there are dolls that reply emotively to a child, by name.

title: Gas Prices for Summer Projected to Hold Steady, Reflecting Sufficient Supply
description: HOUSTON  Just a few years ago, American families faced uncertainties when planning their summer vacations, fearing that rising gasoline prices would blow their budgets. Then came the 2008-9 economic downturn, sending fuel prices lower.

title: Hidden Agendas Laid Bare in a Debate
description: A fight over an arts funding grant causes a kerfuffle the size of Kansas in The Most Deserving, a frisky but inconsequential new comedy by Catherine Trieschmann that opened at City Center on Tuesday night under the auspices of the Womens Project Theater. Kansas is actually where the big set-to takes place, when a meeting of a county arts council turns testy, resulting in a series of events that leaves just about everyones feathers permanently ruffled.

title: Like a Kid on Christmas
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  We have another debut today, and John E. Bennett poses a question for us: WHATS IN THE BOXES?

title: Coffee and Tea Company to Start Selling Recyclable Single-Serving Pods
description: One concern expressed by consumers considering the adoption of a single-serve hot beverage system is whether the pods that contain coffee or tea can be recycled.

title: Pre-K Victory Ad With Mayor de Blasios Family Aims to Help Him Regain His Footing
description: The commercial begins with a photograph of Mayor Bill de Blasios smiling children as toddlers. As a piano plays softly, his wife, Chirlane McCray, appears on the screen, extolling the education initiatives her husband has spearheaded in City Hall.

title: New York City Settles Lawsuit by Detective Called a Rat
description: A former Brooklyn police detective who claimed his career was ruined after he was labeled a rat by other detectives in his squad will receive a $280,000 settlement from New York City.

title: Aleksandra Scepanovic
description: Ms. Scepanovic, 44, is a founder and the managing director of the Ideal Properties Group, a brokerage firm based in Brooklyn that focuses on residential and commercial property in the borough. Ms. Scepanovic, a native of Serbia, started the company in 2007 with her partner, Erik Serras.

title: Red Herrings and Overlooked Clues in Plane Search
description: More than a month after the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, searchers pledged to scour the ocean for the planes black boxes. But as the batteries powering the data and voice recorders sonic beacons fade, so do the chances that the airliners wreckage and the 239 bodies of the passengers and crew on board will be found. Several missteps, red herrings and bureaucratic delays have thwarted the search.

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: De Blasio Picks Immigrants to Lead Two City Agencies
description: Jacques Jiha moved to East Flatbush, Brooklyn, from Haiti at age 21 and paid his way through college and graduate school working as a parking lot attendant. Feniosky Pea-Mora moved to Washington Heights at the same age from the Dominican Republic, with a degree in engineering but speaking no English.

title: Updated Q. and A. on Malaysia Airlines Flight 370
description: The disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 has led to a multinational air and sea search across a vast area of the Indian Ocean. Recently, after weeks of debris sightings that turned out to be irrelevant, sounds have been heard that may be coming from the missing plane, but thus far there has been no confirmation. As the search narrows and the international inquiries into the disappearance continue, Matthew L. Wald, a correspondent for The New York Times, answers some basic questions.

title: As a Hospital Rises, So Do Hopes for a Neighborhood
description: DALLAS  On the edge of downtown Dallas, the sleek, 17-story tower that is the new Parkland Hospital punctuates the pancake-flat Texas landscape like a gleaming exclamation point.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 8, 2014
description: April 8, 2014

title: UConn Wins Womens N.C.A.A. Title
description: NASHVILLE  His record ninth N.C.A.A. title secured, Geno Auriemma climbed a ladder Tuesday night, snipped the final strands of the net and pumped it in his fist, literally standing above everyone in womens basketball.

title: The Birth of the 13th Amendment
description: The climax of Steven Spielbergs film Lincoln  the passage of the 13th Amendment in the House of Representatives  vividly captures the culmination of a dramatic yearlong legislative battle that mixed skillful behind-the-scenes maneuverings with high-minded constitutional debate, internecine party politics, personal animosities and the polarizing dynamics of a presidential election. Approval in the House on Jan. 31, 1865, trailed the amendments passage in the Senate on April 8, 1864, by almost 10 months. Its adoption by 27 states the following December introduced the word slavery into the Constitution for the first time.

title: Drexel Works to Build Up Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA  The northward view from John F. Kennedy Boulevard near 30th Street Station here features only a parking lot bordered by a sagging chain-link fence and overshadowed by the rusting trestles of an elevated freight railroad.

title: Secret Service Employees Reassigned
description: The Secret Service has reassigned several employees in the wake of alcohol-related misbehavior in the Netherlands before President Obama arrived there for meetings last month, an agency spokesman said Tuesday. The spokesman, Ed Donovan, said the reassigned employees were part of the Special Operations Division, which provides emergency response should the president be attacked while traveling. The reassignments were first reported by The Washington Post. Mr. Donovan added, Policies that would affect the entire work force are currently under review by leadership. Three agents were sent home from the Netherlands for disciplinary reasons in connection with their drinking. One was found passed out in a hallway.

title: Japans Foreign Minister Says Apologies to Wartime Victims Will Be Upheld
description: TOKYO  In one of the clearest signals that Japan is trying to allay fears that it is whitewashing wartime atrocities  and to repair somewhat frayed relations with the United States  the foreign minister said on Tuesday that his government would not try to push revisions of that history.

title: A Weakening Currency Could Mean Strength For Turkish Exporters
description: ISTANBUL  In a country where the exchange rate is considered a key barometer of economic health, almost nobody is happy about the Turkish liras decline in the last year.

title: Brandeis Cancels Plan to Give Honorary Degree to Ayaan Hirsi Ali, a Critic of Islam
description: Facing growing criticism, Brandeis University said Tuesday that it had reversed course and would not award an honorary degree to Ayaan Hirsi Ali, a campaigner for womens rights and a fierce critic of Islam, who has called the religion a destructive, nihilistic cult of death.

title: Claims of French Complicity in Rwandas Genocide Rekindle Mutual Resentment
description: PARIS  Is it possible to commemorate a world tragedy without opening old wounds?

title: Speaking at Rights Event, Carter Deplores Disparity
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Former President Jimmy Carter on Tuesday targeted the mistreatment of women for the next front in the civil rights movement, calling for a multifaceted attack against abuses from pay discrimination in the workplace to rape on college campuses and global sex-trafficking of women and girls.

title: The High Cost of Free Speech
description: After the so-called Sheldon primary, when four potential candidates for the Republican presidential nomination went to Las Vegas over the last weekend in March to court the casino owner Sheldon Adelson, it took a heavy dose of audacity on the part of Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. to claim on April 2 that ingratiation and access . . . are not corruption.

title: Jos Mourinho Delivers a Victory for Chelsea in the Champions League
description: LONDON  He returned to Chelsea from Real Madrid last summer declaring himself to be no longer the Special One he had declared himself to be on arrival for his first spell as Chelseas manager in 2004.

title: Muslim Shrine Stands as a Crossroads in Syrias Unrest
description: SAYEDA ZEINAB, Syria  This cinder-block town near Damascus, once a hub of prayer and commerce open to the world, seems like a tightly guarded military zone.

title: Governments Abuses Far Outweigh Syrian Rebels, Rights Chief Says
description: The United Nations human rights chief said Tuesday that abuses by the Syrian government far outweigh the atrocities committed by opposition forces, prompting the Syrian envoy to refer to her actions as lunatic. The comments of the high commissioner for human rights, Navi Pillay, were likely to fortify French efforts to push the Security Council to refer Syria to the International Criminal Court. Her office, as well as a commission of inquiry, have repeatedly cited rights violations on both sides. But you cannot compare the two, she said. Clearly the actions of the forces of the government far outweigh. The violations, killings, cruelty, persons in detention, disappearances far outweigh, so you cannot compare the situation. Its the government thats mostly responsible for the violations. The Syrian envoy, Bashar al-Jaafari, denounced Ms. Pillay for bias and said she was acting irresponsibly.

title: Russia: Court Upholds Registration Law
description: The Constitutional Court said Tuesday that it had upheld a law requiring nongovernmental organizations that engage in political activity and receive funds from abroad to register as foreign agents. In a decision on Sunday, the court reduced fines associated with the law. Critics of the law, which was passed in 2012 with support from President Vladimir V. Putin, have said it was being used to clamp down on civil society groups, like the election-monitoring organization Golos, that had been critical of the Kremlin. Thousands of organizations have been investigated under the law since its introduction and four have been fined, Russias prosecutor general said last year.

title: Britain: A Moment of Contrition Compounds Problems for a Minister
description: Ordered to repay about $9,600, Culture Secretary Maria Miller had a moment of contrition last week in Parliament, where she made a formal apology after over-claiming her expenses. That it was just a moment  she spoke for 32 seconds  has prompted an avalanche of criticism and a mini-crisis for Prime Minister David Cameron. Five days later, Ms. Millers expenses still dominated British newspaper headlines on Tuesday while organizers of an online petition, calling on her to repay more money or quit.

title: China: Suicide Victim Linked to Official
description: A senior police official linked to the disgraced Communist Party official Bo Xilai hanged himself in a hotel room last week, the state news media reported Monday. The police official, Zhou Yu, whose body was discovered Friday, played a prominent role in the strike black campaign under Mr. Bo, the former Chongqing party chief. The campaign was portrayed as a crackdown on organized crime but also targeted lawyers and businesspeople considered to be enemies of Mr. Bo or his allies. Mr. Bo was removed from his post in 2012, convicted on corruption charges and sentenced to life in prison. It is unclear if Mr. Zhous suicide was related. The microblog of a district department in the Chongqing police force said Mr. Zhou had diabetes and had recently received a diagnosis of severe liver disease that led to depression.

title: N.C.A.A. Womens Title Game
description: Connecticut defeated Notre Dame in the first meeting of unbeatens in the womens championship.

title: Venezuela: President and Leaders of the Opposition Agree to Hold Talks
description: President Nicols Maduro and the leaders of a coalition of opposition political parties agreed on Tuesday to take part in talks that could help defuse tensions that have arisen during two months of anti-government protests. The agreement was brokered by a group of South American foreign ministers meeting in Caracas, Venezuelas capital, and the talks will be carried out with the participation of the foreign ministers of Brazil, Colombia and Ecuador, along with a representative of the Vatican. It was not clear when the talks would begin, but an opposition leader said the first meeting would occur in public. Venezuela is marked by a bitter political division, and the agreement to talk is a promising shift, although there appears to be little willingness on either side to give ground.

title: Cuba Project Defended at Senate Hearing
description: The administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, Dr. Rajiv Shah, defended his agencys social media project in Cuba to Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont.

title: At the Milan Furniture Fair, Two British Designers Reinvent Pass Materials
description: At the Salone del Mobile in Milan this week, two of Londons biggest design talents have shacked up with each other to offer side-by-side takes on semi-outdated materials. Occupying one half of the gallery Project B, the furniture designer Max Lamb has lined an entire room  furniture included  in his new twist on terrazzo, the speckled composite material which will remind many Americans of airport flooring, but which for Lamb served as a reference to classic Italian vestibules. While the pattern is currently trending in design and fashion (see Carvens recent terrazzo-print sweatshirts), Lamb says hes been experimenting with it since 2011, after his frequent work with stone led him to visit an old-school terrazzo maker in Yorkshire, near where he grew up. He then went a completely different route, he says. His version  the first product in a new line of designer architectural surfaces called Dzek, launched by the former Phillips de Pury retail director Brent Dzekciorius  embeds chunks of marble in resin instead of cement, making the material much more durable. And unlike the terrazzo of yore, which was usually poured on-site, its pre-cast and sold by the square foot. It has endless applications, he says. It can be used on walls, floors, ceilings. You can even C.N.C.-mill a bathtub out of it.

title: Times Minute | College Rejection Boom
description: Acceptance rates at top universities hit a record low. Also on the Minute, President Obama to pay his respects at Fort Hood, and Yankees fans on Jeters last season.

title: Word of the Day | limpid
description: limpid\lim-pd\ adjective

title: As Braves Honor Hank Aaron, Mets Rain on the Parade
description: ATLANTA  It was a long nights work, which was perhaps why, at the end of each inning, Bartolo Colon took his time walking from the mound to the dugout. He always seems at ease, which makes it appear all the more remarkable when he controls and suppresses an offense the way he did the Atlanta Braves on Tuesday night.

title: The Power of Sebelius
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.

title: Are You Programmed to Enjoy Exercise?
description: Its possible that some of us are born not to run. According to an eye-opening new genetics study of lab rats, published in The Journal of Physiology, the motivation to exercise  or not  may be at least partly inherited.

title: Study Finds Sicklier Enrollees in Earliest Stage of Health Law
description: People who signed up early for insurance through the new marketplaces were more likely to be prescribed drugs to treat pain, depression and H.I.V. and were less likely to need contraceptives, according to a new study that provides a much-anticipated look at the population that signed up for coverage under the new health care law.

title: India Election Digest: April 9
description: What you need to know about Indias elections on Wednesday: Parts of Arunachal Pradesh, Manipur, Meghalaya and Nagaland go to the polls, while the vote in a fifth northeastern state, Mizoram, was postponed to Friday.

title: Times Minute | College Rejection Boom
description: In the Video

title: Sliver of Medicare Doctors Get Big Share of Payouts
description: A tiny fraction of the 880,000 doctors and other health care providers who take Medicare accounted for nearly a quarter of the roughly $77 billion paid out to them under the federal program, receiving millions of dollars each in some cases in a single year, according to the most detailed data ever released in Medicares nearly 50-year history.

title: Nets Sweep Heat as Plumlee Blocks Jamess Dunk in Final Seconds
description: MIAMI  The laughter and exaggerated shouting began, as if on cue, as soon as reporters encircled the rookie Mason Plumlee inside the visitors locker room at American Airlines Arena late Tuesday.

title: Month Later, Trade Pays Off for the Rangers
description: The combination the Rangers were awaiting for more than a month finally clicked Tuesday. Martin St. Louis assisted on both of Brad Richardss power-play goals and, for good measure, set up Derek Stepan for an even-strength goal, as the Rangers beat the Carolina Hurricanes, 4-1, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Gen. Carl E. Mundy Jr., Outspoken Marine Corps Leader, Dies at 78
description: Gen. Carl E. Mundy Jr., who as commandant of the Marine Corps was an outspoken opponent of allowing people who are openly gay to serve in the armed forces and joined other military leaders in shaping the dont ask, dont tell policy as a compromise, died on April 2 at his home in Alexandria, Va. He was 78.

title: Corrections: April 9, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: How Much Medicare Pays For Your Doctors Care
description: Use the form below to find a doctor or other medical professional among the more than 800,000 health care providers that received payments in 2012 from Medicare Part B, which covers doctor visits, tests and other treatments. Payments may also cover overhead, such as staff salaries and drug costs. In some cases, when doctors work as salaried employees of group practices, the payments that show up under their names go to their institutions.

title: Whats On Wednesday
description: 2:45 P.M. (Starz) AMOUR (2012) An elderly French couple, portrayed by Jean-Louis Trintignant and Emmanuelle Riva, above, find their love tested when she has a stroke and he becomes her caretaker in this Oscar winner for best foreign-language film, directed by Michael Haneke. Isabelle Huppert plays their self-centered daughter  like her parents, a musician  whose questions about what she can do to help as her mother becomes increasingly incapacitated ring hollow. Manohla Dargis, writing in The New York Times, called this film a masterpiece about life, death and everything in between. And while some viewers may find the movie cold and even cruel, she added, theres another point to be made here, namely that all the violence in Amour is crucial to Mr. Hanekes rigorous, liberatingly unsentimental worldview, one that gazes on death with the same benevolent equanimity as life. All of which is to say: Bring hankies. This is a film that will make you weep not only because life ends but also because it blooms.

title: Political Ties of Top Billers for Medicare
description: MIAMI  Two Florida doctors who received the nations highest Medicare reimbursements in 2012 are both major contributors to Democratic Party causes, and they have turned to the political system in recent years to defend themselves against suspicions that they may have submitted fraudulent or excessive charges to the federal government.

title: Deutsche Bank Economist to Join Chinas Central Bank
description: HONG KONG  Deutsche Banks chief China economist is taking up a new role at Chinas central bank.

title: Early Count in Indonesia Favors Largest Opposition Party
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Out of power for 10 years, Indonesias largest opposition party was leading unofficial vote tallies from Wednesdays national legislative elections, as the countrys focus now quickly turns to a presidential election in July.

title: Toyota to Recall 6.4 Million Vehicles
description: Weeks after agreeing to pay the largest criminal penalty ever by an automaker for hiding safety defects from the public, Toyota on Wednesday announced a wide-ranging recall of nearly 6.4 million vehicles worldwide for problems with air bags that may not deploy or seats that could move in a crash.

title: Deadly Blast at Fruit Market Shatters Calm in Pakistans Capital
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  In the deadliest attack on the Pakistani capital in more than five years, a powerful explosion ripped through a crowded market in Islamabad on Wednesday, killing at least 22 people and suggesting that, after a long stretch of relative calm, the city was back in the firing line of the countrys militants.

title: Leader Tightens Hold on Power in North Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Koreas leader, Kim Jong-un, was re-elected as head of his countrys top governing agency as its rubber-stamp Parliament met in Pyongyang on Wednesday to help consolidate his power by filling top leadership posts vacated in recent purges.

title: British Culture Secretary Quits Amid Uproar Over Expenses
description: LONDON  Politicians rarely like saying sorry, and generally try to put the unpleasant business behind them as quickly as possible. But 32 seconds, it seems, is a bit too quick.

title: Test Yourself | Math, April 9, 2014
description: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

title: Nigerias Seplat Raises $500 Million in I.P.O.
description: LONDON  Seplat, an independent Nigerian oil and gas company, said Wednesday that it raised 300.9 million pounds, or about $500 million, in its initial public offering, a dual listing in London and in Nigeria.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Inventive College Courses
description: In 10 Courses With a Twist, Laura Pappano writes about professors teaching in inventive new ways.

title: Gasps in Court as Prosecution Prods Pistorius
description: PRETORIA, South Africa  The prosecutor in Oscar Pistoriuss murder trial, Gerrie Nel, had just begun his cross-examination, and he was doing everything he could to goad Mr. Pistorius into losing his composure and his temper.

title: U.N. Ignores South Sudan Camp Crisis, Charity Says
description: The United Nations peacekeeping operation in South Sudan was severely criticized on Wednesday by Doctors Without Borders, the emergency medical charity, over what it called a shameful indifference to the squalid living conditions of 21,000 displaced people forced to shelter in a flooded portion of a peacekeeping base in the capital, Juba.

title: A Taste of Spring
description: April is a transitional season, not only for weather but also for cooking. More produce begins to appear at farmers markets, and even supermarket asparagus begins to come from places closer than Peru. In most of the country, though, its not yet time for hot-weather eating; we still crave more than a light salad.

title: How to Think Like the Dutch in a Post-Sandy World
description: In December 2012, Shaun Donovan, the secretary of Housing and Urban Development, was on vacation in Berlin when he decided to detour to the Netherlands. He wanted to get a firsthand sense of the famed Dutch approach to water management. Hurricane Sandy struck six weeks before, and in the aftermath, President Obama asked him to lead a task force, whose objective was not just to rebuild but also to radically rethink the regions infrastructure in light of climate change.

title: Embracing Ambiguity in Israel
description: Frdric Brenner has spent his adult life deciphering his own complex identity.

title: To Whom, or What, Would You Like to Write a Thank-You Note?
description: A much-emailed Times article about the art of the thank-you note suggests that the handwritten note showing gratitude is making a comeback in the era of digital communication.

title: Race for a Top Job in Europe Hits the Road
description: NIVELLES, Belgium  Jean-Claude Juncker, the former prime minister of Luxembourg who helped steer Europe through its currency crisis, sought to strengthen his bid to become the next president of the European Commission this week by taking to the road in an American-style campaign tour bus.

title: Graft Inquiry Fells Another Ally of Former Security Chief
description: A former aide to Zhou Yongkang, until recently the head of Chinas internal security forces and said to be the subject of a corruption investigation, has been expelled from the ruling Communist Party for accepting huge bribes and referred to the criminal justice system for prosecution.

title: China Waits for an Apology
description: BEIJING  In 1970, when China was in the grip of the Cultural Revolution, Zhang Hongbing, a 16-year-old in Guzhen, a county in Anhui Province, made a fateful decision. During a family debate that year, his mother, Fang Zhongmou, had criticized Mao Zedong for his cult of personality. Her son and his father, believing her views to be counterrevolutionary, decided to inform on her. She was arrested that same day.

title: New York Today: Cherries Bloom in Brooklyn
description: Good Wednesday morning to you.

title: Ebola Virus: A Grim, African Reality
description: Theres nothing like an outbreak of Ebola virus disease to bring a small, struggling African nation to international notice. One week we couldnt place it on a map; the next week, after Ebola virus disease strikes, we know the body count and the name of the capital and whether its airport has closed.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: Vienna Orchestra to Receive $1 Million Birgit Nilsson Prize
description: The Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra played on many of the most celebrated recordings of the Swedish soprano Birgit Nilsson, including the classic set of Wagners Ring cycle conducted by Georg Solti that immortalized her Brnnhilde. Citing her countless musical high points, the orchestra voted unanimously to make her an honorary member in 1999.

title: Beijings Neighbors Resist Transfer of Its Polluting Industries
description: Beijings latest effort to move energy-intensive, polluting businesses out of the Chinese capital has run into resistance from regional governments who are unenthusiastic about taking more industrial castoffs.

title: In Our Pages: April 10
description: 1914: Woman Gets Wireless Divorce

title: How a Start-Up Can Compete With the Big Boys for Talent
description: Everything about running a tech start-up is tough. We know what were trying to achieve but dont know how long it will take or how much it will cost. We do everything on the cheap because precious investor funding is hard to come by. At the same time, we have to compete with the big boys for everything, most critically talent. But we cant afford big salaries and bonuses, in-house chefs, trips to inspiring conferences in exotic locations, or an office with floors connected by slides. How can we compete?

title: Authorities Release German Art Trove
description: BERLIN  The private art collection that sparked an international debate  over Germanys willingness to address restitution claims for Nazi-looted artworks will be returned to Cornelius Gurlitt, German prosecutors said Wednesday. The release will allow a team of international experts to begin a yearlong examination of the works in the collection in order to help determine their provenance.

title: Once Around the Diamond With Tyler Kepner
description: Tyler Kepner, the national baseball correspondent, travels the country, hunting the sports best stories. Tyler gives us a glimpse of life as a baseball columnist, how he works and what hes keeping an eye on this season. Our conversation has been condensed and edited.

title: Daily Report: Samsungs Earnings to Decline as Smartphone Sales Slow
description: Samsung Electronics is finding little to revel in these days, Tom Sims and Su-Hyun Lee report.

title: An Order for Banks to Hold More Capital
description: Federal regulators on Tuesday approved a simple rule that could do more to rein in Wall Street than most other parts of a sweeping overhaul that has descended on the biggest banks since the financial crisis, Peter Eavis writes in DealBook. The rule increases to 5 percent, from roughly 3 percent, a threshold called the leverage ratio, which measures the amount of capital that a bank holds against its assets. The rule is scheduled to take effect at the start of 2018.

title: Questions About Financial Aid?
description: With financial aid award letters in hand, families are struggling to make sense of it all by colleges May 1 deadline. To supplement his article What You Dont Know About Financial Aid (but Should), Richard Prez-Pea, a national correspondent covering higher education for The Times, and Mark Kantrowitz, a nationally recognized expert on financial aid and publisher of Edvisors, answered readers questions.

title: Helping Hands
