description: An array of free resources can help families navigate the financial aid process.

title: All the Way Fan Base: Capitol Hill
description: WASHINGTON  Discharge petition. Cloture. Waiving second reading.

title: What You Dont Know About Financial Aid (but Should)
description: Marilyn Ferreira has solved her share of financial puzzles  running a business, buying a home and arranging a mortgage, raising six children as a single mother. But none of that compared to the challenge of understanding the cost of sending her brood to college.

title: Stagnation Without End, Amen (Wonkish)
description: In 1938 Alvin Hansen, who did more than anyone else to bring Keynesian economics to America, gave a landmark speech to the American Economic Association. (The speech is behind a paywall, but Tim Taylor has a good summary here.) In it, he made the case for secular stagnation  a persistently depressed economy. His arguments were pretty good, too: slow population growth and slow technological progress, he argued meant low investment demand  and even very low interest rates wouldnt be enough to make up for the shortfall.

title: Police Policy on Fires Is Questioned Amid Grief at Death of a New York Officer
description: From the outside, there were few signs of a serious high-rise fire. No smoke pouring from windows, no commotion outside the Brooklyn apartment building on Sunday as two New York City police officers rushed inside, grabbing an elevator for the 13th floor.

title: Student Stabs 21 People at a High School Outside Pittsburgh
description: As classes began at a high school in suburban Pittsburgh on Wednesday morning, a 16-year-old student walked through the hallway stabbing and slashing students with two large knives, the authorities said.

title: The Uphill Climate Challenge in Years of Living Dangerously
description: Joe Romm, the Center for American Progress climate blogger whos also one of two chief science advisers for the forthcoming Showtime climate series, Years of Living Dangerously, sent a query last night after seeing a Twitter note I posted. My note was about an Op-Ed article in The Times by Michael Shellenberger and Ted Nordhaus of the Breakthrough Institute.

title: Israel Says It Is Deeply Disappointed by Kerrys Remarks on Peace Talks
description: JERUSALEM  In an unusually pointed rebuke of an ally, Israel said on Wednesday that it was deeply disappointed by Secretary of State John Kerrys remarks a day earlier that appeared to lay primary blame on Israel for the crisis in the American-brokered Middle East peace talks.

title: Instagram Likes and Losers
description: Dear Diary:

title: Clash of the Androids
description: The HTC One (M8) and the Samsung Galaxy S5 are two of the most powerful Android phones coming onto the market. But which one is better? Molly Wood gives her verdict.

title: Legacy | A Love Eternal
description: The New York loft where the sculptor Hanna Eshel lived and worked under the radar for more than 30 years stands as a testament to her undying devotion to art.

title: Question-and-Answer Site Quora Raises $80 Million
description: Quora, the question-and-answer website, has raised $80 million in a new venture capital round meant to spur its growth and protect its independence.

title: Readers Respond: How Should Apple Spend Its Billions?
description: So much money, so many options.

title: What Did Medicare Pay Your Doctor?
description: A small number of doctors, about 2 percent, accounted for nearly a quarter of Medicare spending in 2012, according to a new analysis by The Times. Just one-quarter of the doctors billing Medicare accounted for three-quarters of its payments that year. Read the full story, and search for your doctors billings with our online tool.

title: Student Survey on Academic Advising
description: Statistics examine students experiences with academic advising.

title: Greece Dives Back Into the Bond Market
description: ATHENS  Europes leaders have been preaching austerity for years, arguing that only deep budget cuts will revive the economy and inspire the necessary confidence among investors.

title: Again, Obama Offers Comfort at Fort Hood After Soldiers Are Killed
description: KILLEEN, Tex.  Five years later, President Obama was back Wednesday on the same field in front of the same building on the same Army post in the same state, with some of the same faces again grieving for soldiers killed in an act of senseless violence.

title: Russia Plotting for Ukrainian Influence, Not Invasion, Analysts Say
description: MOSCOW  The separatist demonstrations again churning through eastern Ukraine have raised fears of a Crimean-style invasion by the 40,000 Russian troops coiled just over the Russian border. But Moscows goals are more subtle than that, focused on a long-range strategy of preventing Ukraine from escaping Russias economic and military orbit, according to political analysts, Kremlin allies and diplomats interviewed this week.

title: Rash of Suicides Underlines Maharashtra Farmers Discontent
description: DHANORA, India  In this sleepy village in eastern Maharashtra, about 50 miles south of Nagpur, the sense of desperation is palpable. The dirt road that leads to the village passes through desolate fields, where the winter plantings of cotton, soybean and legumes have been ruined by unseasonal rains, harsh winds and an unusual hailstorm that hit this state and several others in February.

title: To Slim Down, Procter & Gamble Sells Most of Its Pet Food Brands to Mars
description: Since A. G. Lafley returned last year for a second stint as chief executive of Procter & Gamble, investors have been waiting for him to make a big move. On Wednesday, they got a small but significant first step.

title: More Mayhem? You Betcha
description: CALGARY, Alberta  The first question about Fargo the television series is: What is it?

title: Mark Morris Bringing a Handel Work to Mostly Mozart Festival
description: Mark Morriss new staging of Handels Acis and Galatea will have its New York premiere this summer as part of the 48th Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center.

title: Parents Should Coach Academics as Seriously as They Do Sports
description: It sometimes seems that the American success ethic stops at the schoolhouse door. We encourage ambition in youth sports and entrepreneurial enterprise, but our families are often suspicious of the value of scholastic competition.

title: Senate Panel Expresses Caution on Merger of Cable Giants
description: WASHINGTON  Members of the Senate Judiciary Committee expressed concern on Wednesday that the proposed $45 billion merger of Comcast and Time Warner Cable would raise the prices consumers pay for cable television and high-speed Internet service while leaving them with fewer choices for video programming.

title: Today in Small Business: Yelp Has Been Struggling
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: In Eastern Ukraine, a One-Building, Pro-Russia Realm Persists Despite Criticism
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  Nikolai Solntsev, the self-declared commissar of the Eastern Front and a founding father of the newly proclaimed Donetsk Peoples Republic, has been waiting 22 years, three months and 14 days for this moment.

title: Bunny Swap
description: As Easter approaches, its officially bunny season, and there are some endearing examples of the species out this year (one looks a little different from the others, but more about that later). Both Found, written and illustrated by Salina Yoon, and Here Comes the Easter Cat, by Deborah Underwood with illustrations by Claudia Rueda, would be sweet, sugar-free additions to a childs Easter basket. Theres no reason, however, to restrict their consumption to springtime, because both books concern a perennial childhood issue: balancing the desire to do right with the impulse to do just what you want.

title: Architecture | Striking a Balance
description: The fervently followed architects Karl Fournier and Olivier Marty of Studio KO imbue their rigorous modernism with a subtle blend of history and culture.

title: La Quinta Shares Little Changed on Debut
description: Updated, 4:19 p.m. |

title: No Comment Necessary: Replacing the A.C.A. Withthe A.C.A.?
description: According to Talking Points Memo, there is internal dissent on whether the Republican Party should come up with an alternative to the Affordable Care Act. One congressional aide explained that its difficult to come up a replacement, because it would probably end up looking a lot like the A.C.A.:

title: New Home for a Mural That Reads Like a Menu
description: HYDE PARK, N.Y.  Crisp and white as a chefs toque, the newest artwork at the Culinary Institute of America made its debut last month as the perfect backdrop for commencement snapshots. Graduates and family members almost instinctively posed before the mural, a sculptural mlange of food-related words and objects.

title: Low Inflation and Structural Illusions (Wonkish)
description: The suggestion that only the short-term unemployed matter for wage determination, that the long-term unemployed have been written off, is rapidly congealing into orthodoxy. And it might be true. But Im with Mike Konczal here: its far from being a well-established fact. Mike argues that to the extent it was true at all, it was a temporary phenomenon, and that more recent data dont support the claim. Id make a different (although not necessarily conflicting) argument: a lot of the supposed evidence comes from applying Phillips curves estimated over periods of moderate to high inflation, and there are good reasons to believe that such estimates misbehave at low inflation.

title: Times Minute | Voices From Gaza
description: Also on the Minute, looking at Medicare reimbursement and the genetics of exercise.

title: Times Minute | Voices From Gaza
description: In the Video

title: Senate Republicans Block Bill on Equal Pay
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Republicans on Wednesday blocked legislation meant to close the pay gap between men and women, framing an election-year fight between the parties over whose policies are friendlier to women.

title: Prosecutor Cross-Examines Pistorius
description: The Paralympic athlete Oscar Pistorius was cross-examined by the state prosecutor, Gerrie Nel, in the third day of the defendants testimony in Pretoria, South Africa.

title: Nets Flexible Attack Baffles Heat, but Playoffs Pose a Stiffer Test
description: When the Nets lost Brook Lopez for the season in December, they found themselves without the best low-post scorer in the N.B.A. Or so they thought. This season, the leagues most efficient post scorer, according to the statistics company Synergy Sports, is actually Nets guard Shaun Livingston.

title: Wheelies: The Focus Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: A Green Revolution, This Time for Africa
description: Last month was the 100th anniversary of the birth of Norman Borlaug, the father of the Green Revolution.

title: Aftermath of Pakistan Market Blast
description: Survivors combed through the debris after an explosion at a vegetable market in the outskirts of Islamabad, Pakistan.

title: When L.B.J. Came to Lunch
description: Today, The Times published two articles related to Lyndon B. Johnson. In one, Peter Baker sets up President Obamas address on Thursday to the Lyndon B. Johnson Presidential Library and Museum in Austin, Tex., to commemorate the 50th anniversary this year of the Civil Rights Act. In the other, Carl Hulse writes about the Washington politicians traveling to New York to see All The Way, the Broadway play portraying the first year of the Johnson presidency.

title: Latin American E-Commerce Giant to Acquire 2 Real Estate Sites
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  The Latin American e-commerce giant MercadoLibre has acquired VMK, a holding company that owns two major real estate websites, the companies are expected to announce on Wednesday.

title: How to Study the Numinous
description: In an op-ed in the Sunday edition of this newspaper, Barbara Ehrenreich, card-carrying liberal rationalist, writes about her own mystical experiences (the subject of her new book), and argues that the numinous deserves more cutting-edge scientific study:

title: Alibabas Deal-Making Raises a Red Flag
description: Powerful insiders are the norm at Internet companies. Alibabas tie-up with a digital-TV company adds an extra twist. The Chinese e-commerce group, which is planning a listing in the United States, has signed a three-step deal with Wasu Media of China that looks a little too clever for comfort.

title: Detroit Creditor Shows Court Four Offers for Citys Art
description: DETROIT  With city and state officials pushing to keep Detroits bankruptcy moving quickly toward a resolution, a bond insurer threw an obstacle into the proceedings on Wednesday: four potential offers for the treasures in the citys art museum, which Detroit does not want to sell.

title: In Cape Town, Local Color Comes in Bright Shades
description: Its perhaps the most recognizable of Cape Towns neighborhoods: a warren of rainbow-bright houses at the foot of Signal Hill, their indigo, fuchsia and lavender facades brightening even the gloomiest days. Bo-Kaap has long been home to Cape Towns vibrant Muslim community, the Cape Malays, but in recent years, others have been moving into this tight-knit enclave. Young professionals looking for affordable apartments in the city center and gay couples priced out of nearby De Waterkant have been slowly buying up Technicolor real estate.

title: Michael Cera and Kieran Culkin to Star in This Is Our Youth on Broadway
description: This will do nothing for Michael Ceras on-screen reputation as a young slacker without peer: this summer, he will make his Broadway debut in a new production of Kenneth Lonergans This Is Our Youth, one that he and his co-star, Kieran Culkin, have been trying to bring to the stage for nearly five years.

title: UMass Guard Joins List of Openly Gay Athletes
description: Derrick Gordon, a University of Massachusetts guard, revealed that he is gay, joining a fast-growing list of publicly gay male college and professional athletes.

title: Do the Courts Have a Role to Play in Drone Strikes?
description: History will not look kindly on the succession of federal court rulings since the 9/11 attacks that have bowed to government claims of national security to deny meaningful judicial review for extraordinary acts, like rendition and torture.

title: Two More Pings Detected in Plane Search
description: Australias chief search coordinator, Angus Houston, and the United States team commander, Capt. Mark Matthews, spoke about new signals detected in the hunt for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

title: Best-Laid Plans for Starry Revival
description: Many of us read John Steinbecks 1937 novella Of Mice and Men in high school, but it has been a lot harder to see it on Broadway, until now. The show, getting a starry revival at the Longacre Theater, was last on Broadway in 1975, and then for only two months. In the new production, James Franco, whose rsum includes jobs as an actor, poet, professor, filmmaker and more, makes his Broadway debut as George, and Chris ODowd (Bridesmaids), also on Broadway for the first time, is the simple-minded Lennie in Steinbecks Depression-era tale of struggling migrant workers.

title: Jimmy Beans Wool Decides to Get Back to Knitting
description: Last week, we published a case study about Jimmy Beans Wool, a yarn and fabric retailer owned by Laura and Doug Zander. Hoping to transform Jimmy Beans into a $100-million company, the Zanders made several hires and introduced numerous costly marketing initiatives that pulled Ms. Zander, the chief executive, from her role guiding operations. The efforts backfired, however, and the companys sales growth stopped.

title: A Must-Have List Changes in Midstream
description: A few years after his arrival in New York in 2005, Nakul Chaturvedi bought a large alcove studio in Midtown East. He met Courtney Yates at a Halloween party, and they were married two years ago.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 64
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Sothebys Responds to Loeb, With Visual Aids
description: In his battle for control of the auction house Sothebys, the activist investor Daniel S. Loeb has focused much of his attention on what he calls the inadequacy of its board members.

title: A First Look at a New Documentary About the Master Gardener Piet Oudolf
description: I think its the journey in your life to find out what real beauty is, of course, but also discover beauty in things that are at first sight not beautiful, says Piet Oudolf in this trailer for the forthcoming documentary Piet Oudolf: Fall, Winter, Spring, Summer, Fall. The Dutch garden designer from Hummelo, the Netherlands, has risen to international acclaim thanks to the many private and public parks he worked on, including the High Line in Manhattan, the Lurie Garden in Chicagos Millennium Park and Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park in London, which was home to the 2012 Olympic Games and just opened to the public last week. These projects bring the quality of home gardening to public spaces, creating organic environments that feel as though theyve been growing there, on their own, for years. For his latest undertaking, Oudolf is designing the grounds of the new outpost of Hauser & Wirth gallery, a remodeled 18th-century farmhouse in the rolling hills of the English county of Somerset that is set to open in July. This film, produced by the filmmaker Thomas Piper and Checkerboard Film Foundation, will offer an intimate view of Oudolfs process, from landscape blueprints to theories on beauty, when it hits the big screen toward the middle of next year.

title: This Old House
description: A powerhouse gallery bucks the trend toward important architecture in big cities and sets up an outpost in English farm country.

title: Go Daddy Said to Pick Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan for I.P.O.
description: The Go Daddy Group, the Internet registrar best known for cheeky, controversial ads, is moving full speed ahead with plans for an initial public offering.

title: Los Angeles Museum Grants to Promote Art and Technology
description: When the Los Angeles County Museum of Art unveiled the results of its original art and technology program in an exhibition in 1971, many visitors were struck by what was missing: women. Of the 46 artists and technology experts pictured on the catalog cover, all were men. Protests ensued.

title: Impac Dublin Literary Award Narrows Field to 10
description: The International Impac Dublin Literary Award has winnowed its very long list of nominees for the 2014 prize to 10 finalists.

title: Eat, Stay, Buy Locally: Treading Lightly on the Road
description: Between the intricate shrines of Angkor Wat, the diverse landscapes of the countryside and the kindness of its people  and despite the horrors of its recent history  Cambodia knocks a lot of people off their feet. It certainly had that effect on me when I first visited a few years ago and then again when I returned this winter. Yet it was impossible not to notice the school-age children begging barefoot at the major tourist sites, underage local women escorting Western men on sex tours, and the proliferation of seemingly unsustainable large-scale resorts being built on the pristine southern coast.

title: A 10-Month Family Trip Around the World
description: Its much more impacting to learn about the Khmer Rouge in Cambodia than in class, said Miles Maurer, 15, who instead of attending the ninth grade in Flagstaff, Ariz., this year is traveling around the world. Its difficult to disagree.

title: $772 Million Penalty for Bank of America Credit Card Practices
description: Bank of America has been ordered to pay roughly $772 million in refunds to customers and fines to federal regulators to settle allegations that the bank used deceptive marketing and billing practices involving credit card products.

title: Nuclear Talks With Iran Need Intensive Work, Envoys Say
description: Iran and the group of six major powers negotiating a permanent agreement to resolve the Iranian nuclear dispute concluded a two-day round of talks in Vienna on Wednesday, asserting that a lot of intensive work remained to complete a draft accord by their self-imposed deadline in three months.

title: Pain Relievers Tied to Heart Rhythm Disorder
description: A new study found that the popular pain relievers known as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, or Nsaids, may increase the risk for the most common type of irregular heartbeat, atrial fibrillation.

title: Germans Loosen Their Purse Strings
description: FRANKFURT  When Europe seemed to be falling apart in 2010, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund annoyed Germans by suggesting they should stop hoarding so much of their wealth and instead buy more things from their ailing European neighbors.

title: Britain Increasingly Invokes Power to Disown Its Citizens
description: LONDON  The letter informing Mohamed Sakr that he had been stripped of his British citizenship arrived at his familys house in London in September 2010. Mr. Sakr, born and raised here by British-Egyptian parents, was in Somalia at the time and was suspected by Western intelligence agencies of being a senior figure in the Shabab, a terrorist group linked to Al Qaeda.

title: A New Album From Billy Corgan, but Only 250 Copies
description: Billy Corgan, the imaginative singer and lead guitarist for the Smashing Pumpkins, has undertaken some unusual side projects in recent times, including evenings devoted to synthesizer music inspired by Herman Hesses Siddhartha and the 13th-century poet Rumi, both at Madame Zuzus Teahouse, in Highland Park, Ill., which Mr. Corgan owns. At the moment, Mr. Corgan and his band are at work on two new Smashing Pumpkin albums, which are due to be released in 2015.

title: When the Criticisms Never End
description: Five nights a week, Amanda H. and her husband drove to her parents upscale continuing care retirement community in suburban Boston. She could feel her anxiety build as they rode the elevator upstairs.

title: Image of the Day: April 9
G.O.P. Seeks Investigation of Ex-Official From I.R.S.
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans on Wednesday formally asked Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. to begin a criminal investigation of Lois Lerner, the former Internal Revenue Service official caught up in the scandal over political targeting of Tea Party groups.

title: Fed Recognized Change in Unemployment Goal Could Be Misunderstood
description: WASHINGTON  When the Federal Reserve changed the guidelines for its stimulus campaign last month, it did not change its commitment to supporting the economy, according to an account of the decision that the Fed published on Wednesday.

title: Through a Lens Sharply
description: Recently, I unpacked a box that had been in storage for a long time. It was full of postcards. Hundreds of them. Postcards from every trip I had ever taken. Postcards of famous monuments, famous museums, famous mosques, famous mountains, famous red phone booths. I gazed at my stash  I must have saved them for good reason  and felt ... nothing. They werent my London, my Paris, my Istanbul. They were pictures of places that belonged to everyone.

title: Classical Playlist: Jeffrey Mumford, Mozart, Brahms and More
description: MUMFORD: Through a stillness brighteningMiranda Cuckson, violinist; Wendy Richman, violist; Julia Bruskin, cellist; Winston Choi, pianist; Argento Chamber Ensemble, conducted by Michel Galante; and others(Albany) Jeffrey Mumford, a distinguished American composer who studied with Elliott Carter and Bernard Rands, among others, has an unerring knack for fashioning rigorous works as changeable as cloudscapes, bursting with color, nuance and poetry. Those qualities are abundantly present in this generous Kickstarter-financed collection of chamber pieces spanning 30 years; sources and sonorities vary, but inspiration and expert advocacy are consistent. Two of the performers involved, the violinist Miranda Cuckson and the cellist Julia Bruskin, will perform works from the collection with the pianist Steve Beck on Sunday at Spectrum on the Lower East Side.(Steve Smith)

title: Reader Idea | Using the Who Made That? Column to Teach Reading Strategies
description: Occasionally we publish ideas from readers in lieu of our own lesson plans, and, as with the simple, versatile activity we feature below, they often make us wish we were still in the classroom ourselves so we could try them out IRL, as the kids say.

title: Q. and A. on Heartbleed: A Flaw Missed by the Masses
description: This week, security researchers publicized a significant security flaw, named Heartbleed, which could expose the personal information that people plug into websites, like passwords and credit card numbers.

title: Hillary Clintons Latest Memoir to Be Released in June
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons much-anticipated memoir of her time as secretary of state will be released on June 10, her publisher said Wednesday.

title: Heres a Story ... of a Mashed-Up Family ...
description: The first shock is that Shirley Partridge has married Reuben Kincaid, the bands seemingly undesirable manager. Young Danny is distraught, like Hamlet when his mother married his uncle. Then little Cindy Brady is hiding behind the arras when Danny unsheathes his dagger.

title: App Smart: Off the Beaten Path
description: Many apps available for mobile devices can feel like tools on a Swiss Army knife, but there are also many weird and surprising apps that can captivate you.

title: A Collection of Wonderful and Weird Amusements
description: MOBILE apps can seem a bit like the tools on a Swiss Army knife. Many of them are useful, but some are just fun.

title: The Obama Deportation Debacle
description: President Obama has been spent the last five years deporting the wrong people. The evidence is pretty clear.

title: Recipes for Kids:  Congee
description: Congee is a thick Chinese soup made with rice, which expands and breaks apart as it cooks. In China congee is eaten for breakfast, but it is delicious for lunch and dinner, too. It is also known as jook.

title: The Gun Report: April 9, 2014
description: Last week, Nathan Trapuzzano, a 24-year-old software engineer and newlywed with a baby on the way, went out for an early morning walk in his Indianapolis neighborhood. He was approached by two people who attempted to rob him, surveillance video shows. One of the would-be thieves pulled out a handgun and shot him in the stomach, killing him.

title: Video From Fort Hood Memorial Service
description: As our colleague, Manny Fernandez and Alan Blinder report, President Obama returned on Wednesday to Fort Hood for a memorial service for three soldiers killed in a mass shooting at the base last week.

title: Notable Deaths of 2014
description: Remembering Maya Angelou, Philip Seymour Hoffman, Shirley Temple Black, Nadine Gordimer, Ruby Dee, Howard Baker, Elaine Stritch, Mickey Rooney, Robin Williams and others who died this year.

title: Knives, Not Guns, at a School Near Pittsburgh
description: As we hear and read more about the violence at Franklin Regional High School in Murrysville, Pa., where authorities say a 16-year-old student walked from classroom to classroom randomly stabbing and slashing 19 students as well as a security guard before being tackled and subdued by a principal and a police officer, the same words keep coming up again and again in different contexts.

title: European Official Urges Say on Pay Requirement for Boards
description: BRUSSELS  A European Union official renewed his efforts to curb excessive pay by introducing a plan on Wednesday that would require a shareholder vote on salaries for directors of publicly traded companies.

title: Times Should Have Nodded to Wall Street Journal in Medicare Story
description: The New York Times led its print edition today with an extensive treatment of an important story: that a small fraction of doctors get a huge share of the billions of dollars paid out under Medicare.

title: What You Get for ... $900,000
description: BOISE, IDAHO

title: AT&T to Switch Its Advertising Message
description: Take a look at these three words: Mobilizing your world. They could soon become almost as familiar to you as your name or Social Security number.

title: The Return of a Very Tall Roadside Attraction
description: A now-defunct roadside attraction in remote Baker, Calif., named the worlds tallest thermometer, may be restored. LaRae Harguess, a high school guidance counselor whose family owns the 134-foot-tall concrete tower, said in a telephone interview that the family was working to refurbish it.

title: Executives Discuss Comcast Merger
description: An executive vice president of Comcast, David L. Cohen, and the chief executive of Public Knowledge, Gene Kimmelman, argued their cases before Congress on the proposed merger with Time Warner.

title: Mac DeMarcos Appetizing Salad Days
description: As a slacker-child of the 1980s, I heard Mac DeMarcos brand-new album Salad Days for the first time and thought: Yes. I get this. The laid-back grooviness, the moments of introspection undermined by cheeky apathy and hints of lenfant terrible.

title: Photos: Baseball, Anyone? Anyone?
description: Attendance at ballparks can be pretty spotty this time of year, when its often cold and rainy in many big-league towns. But the first week and a half of the 2014 major league season has produced some especially bleak scenes.

title: Thanks for the Flair, Mom
description: Whether you order Vietnamese noodles, Taiwanese bubble tea or Chinese pastries, one way to experience the diversity of Elmhurst is through the restaurants that line the streets. Thats precisely what drew Nora Li, who moved to New York from China three years ago, to the Queens neighborhood on a recent afternoon. She was buying groceries that included shrimp crackers and instant noodles. Ms. Li, an art student, was wearing an oversize coat with suede details, a beanie and cropped pants exposing her socks and loafers. She described her personal style as saggy.

title: In Sicily, Greek History by Bike
description: Travelers can get a double hit of culture with a new biking trip from the Bristol, Vt.-based travel outfitter VBT Bicycling and Walking Vacations, which focuses on Greek civilization in Sicily.

title: New Dallas Festival Teams Symphony With Artists
description: Over the last three decades Dallas has invested billions in its arts district, a one-stop-shopping location for visual art, dance, classical music and theater. And beginning next year, the various creative disciplines will start trying to get together and experiment more often. The Dallas Symphony Orchestra is set to announce the founding of a new annual arts festival, to be called Soluna, that intends to recruit established visual artists to collaborate with the symphony and with other Dallas-based musical companies and ensembles.

title: A Director Takes on a World of Nefarious People
description: Some directors make movies hoping for awards and accolades. Others for money. David Hare, who wrote and directed the new BBC spy thriller Turks and Caicos, had a different objective: to bring down the British government and, while hes at it, Uncle Sam, too.

title: Officials on Murrysville School Stabbing
description: The chief medical officer at Forbes Regional Hospital, Dr. Mark Rubino, and the Murrysville, Pa., police chief, Thomas Seefeld, provided updates after a student stabbed at least 20 at a high school.

title: Frozen and Happy Reign, While Music Sales Continue to Plunge
description: Theres not much news at the top of the music charts this week. The Frozen soundtrack is the No. 1 album for a ninth time, with 149,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and Pharrell Williamss Happy is the top single yet again. That lineup has not changed for a month.

title: House Hunting on ... the Costa del Sol, Spain
description: A VILLA IN A GATED COMMUNITY ON THE COSTA DEL SOL

title: Leave Rochelle Out of It, a New Lower East Side Bar
description: As bar names goes, Leave Rochelle Out of It wins points for originality. Named after a mutual ex-girlfriend of two of the proprietors, Brett David and Stephen Yorsz, the bar is a celebration of bro-culture that would make Robert Bly proud. There are more than 150 types of whiskeys, deafening music and racy films.

title: An Evening Full of Bach, the Father and the Sons
description: The final, agitated movement of Johann Christian Bachs Symphony in G minor, written in 1770, does not so much end as kind of check out. A twisting melodic line in the strings spins delicately upward and trails off. On Tuesday night at Zankel Hall, when the acclaimed period-instrument chamber orchestra Akademie fr Alte Musik Berlin finished its fleet, incisive performance of this work, there were gasps of delighted surprise from people in the audience, including one audible Oh, gee!

title: Shift From Paper Complicates Giving Treasury Bonds as Gifts
description: Reginna Peckens, a child care provider in Marietta, Ohio, uses the federal governments online TreasuryDirect system to buy digital savings bonds for herself. But she hasnt been able to persuade her mother, who is not computer savvy, to use the system to buy savings bonds to give as gifts, something she used to do regularly. Now, there are extra steps, Ms. Peckens said.

title: Fashion in the Age of Instagram
description: In the Dries Van Noten exhibition at the Muse des Arts Dcoratifs in Paris is a video that stitches together sequences from 20 years of his runway shows  a supercut, in online argot. On a tour of the show not long ago, Mr. Van Noten nodded along as memorable moments flashed: male models pedaling bicycles, women stalking the length of an enormous dinner table. But what stood out most were the ghostly points of light illuminating the audiences faces in the recent shows.

title: A Reporter Analyzes the Driving Role of Pakistan in the Afghan War
description: On July 7, 2008, insurgents detonated a huge suicide car bomb outside the Indian Embassy in Kabul, Afghanistan, killing 54 people, including an Indian defense attach. The attack destroyed the embassys protective blast walls and front gates, and tore into civilians waiting outside for visas.

title: He Sees Dead People, but Through a Stoned Haze
description: Tyler Labine first made an impression on television as the funny guy in a couple of underrated hourlong shows, the science-fiction drama Invasion and the ghostbusters comedy Reaper. But since then he has become a sitcom guy, one of those who show up about once a year  Animal Practice (NBC, 2012), Mad Love (CBS, 2011), Sons of Tucson (Fox, 2010)  and go away 9 or 13 episodes later, looking for the next pilot.

title: Reconciliation Held Together With Bleeding Stitches
description: As Rwanda and the world note the 20th anniversary of the genocide in that country, much of the focus has been on reconciliations between the Hutu killers who slaughtered Tutsis and the victims family members and friends. Coexist, a documentary by Adam Mazo, at first seems as if it is merely going to be another effort to draw feel-good stories out of an impossibly ugly moment in history. But it ultimately proves itself much smarter than that, exploring whether forgiveness that is mandated by the government can be genuine.

title: A New Line | Lou & Greys Soft, Laid-Back Staples Debut With a Dreamy Video
description: Loft, Ann Taylors spinoff brand, has hatched a cool little sister: Lou & Grey, featuring a range of soft, lounge-y layers designed to transition from the sofa to the streets. To commemorate the launch of the line, which will be sold online and at 500 Loft store-in-stores, the brand enlisted the model, illustrator and girl-about-town Langley Fox Hemingway as its muse. Here, T premieres a video, shot by the artist Mark Borthwick in his signature hazy style, of Hemingway cavorting along the coastline in Rio de Janeiro.

title: A Young Star, Poised and Grounded
description: While audiences are taking their seats for The Library, a new play at the Public Theater written by Scott Z. Burns and directed by Steven Soderbergh, its lead actress, Chlo Grace Moretz, is already onstage.

title: The Three-Seat Strollers
description: A few years ago, Brian Berger, the founder of Mack Weldon, an online purveyor of mens socks and underwear, saw a close friend surrounded by three siblings at a birthday party. It was just an amazing experience watching the four of them, and to have all those siblings to go through life together with, recalled Mr. Berger, 40.

title: Theres Brightness When the Fog Clears
description: Fog machines in dance performances are usually signs of bad taste. But the fog in Trisha Browns 1980 work Opal Loop/Cloud Installation #72503 is something else. It rolls in as if from the sea, a floating and evanescent cloud of water molecules that is somehow under artistic control.

title: Now Turning Heads: The Sales Staff
description: THE SCRUFFY YOUNG MAN in the Nike sweatpants is there to help you with that Greg Lauren one-of-a-kind $1,250 cape.

title: As Comfortable as ...
description: On a recent morning, a friend sent me an email with the subject Rod Lavers are back in stock. A link inside the email opened to a page on the Adidas website that prominently featured, from five different angles, the familiar white-mesh and green-soled sneakers, or Lifestyle Shoes, as the company calls them. They cost $65. The question was not whether to buy a pair but how many to buy.

title: The Many Alternative Computing Worlds of Linux
description: HAVE you ever wondered what happened to Linux? Linux is the free software created through the open source development process that many technology enthusiasts had predicted would revolutionize the world of computing.

title: Artists Try to Prick Conscience of Drone Operators With Giant Portrait of Orphan in Pakistani Field
description: While a series of deadly bombings in Pakistan this week threatens to undermine peace talks between the government and the Taliban, a group of rights activists and artists have started a campaign to draw attention to the human cost of another sort of violence  American drone strikes aimed at militants, which have reportedly killed hundreds of civilians in recent years.

title: What Awaits Banks After the Leverage Ratio
description: Mayra Rodrguez Valladares is managing principal at MRV Associates, a capital markets and financial regulatory consulting and training firm based in New York. She is also a faculty member at Financial Markets World and the New York Institute of Finance.

title: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art to Expand Photography Center
description: The San Francisco Museum of Modern Art has long been renowned for its photography collection. Now it will have galleries whose size and scope will match the ambitions of that collection.

title: Can China Cast Off Despotism?
description: Its no longer politically correct to use the word Oriental in the West. But nowhere has the word despotism fallen out of favor.

title: In a Fight for Everything Brooklyn
description: Williamsburg is a middle-aged Italian couple with good scarf game buying coffee and strolling by the water in Bushwick Inlet Park. Williamsburg is a dude in head-to-toe Rick Owens thumbing through techno CDs at the new Rough Trade record shop. Williamsburg is a glass-and-steel tower housing a bunch of 30-something marketing executives proud they avoided buying in Dumbo.

title: Coming Up Big at the Whitehead Womens Pairs
description: DALLAS  Ran Jingrong and Wang Wenfei, a relatively new partnership from China, won the Whitehead Womens Pairs here at the spring North American Bridge Championships on March 28. They finished more than three boards ahead of Kitty Cooper of Lakeside, Calif., and Lynne Feldman of San Diego. Third were Maritha Pottenger of San Diego and Prudence Saunders of Palo Alto, Calif.

title: Masters Spots Will Tell IBMs Story in a New Way
description: AS a sponsor of the Masters last year, IBM did what most sponsors did and introduced a few new commercials that ran in heavy rotation during the golf tournament. But this year, in the advertising equivalent of a driving range, IBM is teeing up about 50 commercials that will run just once.

title: With Declines Slowing, PC Sales Still Struggle
description: The personal computer markets fever has broken, but the business is still sick.

title: For an Hour, Dancing Like Beyonc
description: With its hardwood floors, big windows and mirrored walls, Chelsea Studios looks like a typical dance rehearsal space. One recent night, about 35 people, mostly 20-something women in Lululemon athletic wear, were loosening up and waiting for the music to start.

title: Volkswagen Halts Sales of Some Cars Over Transmission Leak
description: Volkswagen said on Wednesday that about 25,000 of its 2014 models may leak transmission fluid, and that it had told dealers to stop selling them while it discusses a possible recall with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: Judge Allows Christie Aides to Withhold Bridge Emails
description: In a major setback to the legislative investigation into the George Washington Bridge lane closings scandal, a New Jersey judge ruled on Wednesday that two of Gov. Chris Christies former aides do not have to comply with subpoenas seeking emails and other communications about the closings and attempts to cover them up.

title: The Woman and the Giant (No Fable)
description: When Diane Arbus and Eddie Carmel met in 1960, each had embarked on a career that seemed willfully disreputable. Carmel, who in adolescence had a wild growth surge as a result of an inoperable pituitary-gland tumor, was exhibited as a giant in circuses and sideshows. For a young New Yorker who had attended City College, it was a louche way to make a living.

title: The Pleasure Is in the Details
description: Schuberts hourlong Octet in F for Winds and Strings can have a pleasantly narcotic effect on the listener, each one of its amply proportioned six movements warping sensations of time and purpose like a carefree summer afternoon. So I didnt think too much of it at first when I found my mind wandering during Saturday evenings performance of the work by Musicians From Marlboro, an ensemble from that Vermont-based festival, as part of the Peoples Symphony Concerts.

title: Shopping in Your Closet for Coachella Music Festival
description: Music festival season kicks off this weekend with the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival. And even though the haters are huffing, and the hoopla around festival fashion is excessive, there are good reasons to be excited this year. For one, Outkast is headlining many of the festivals. For another, assembling your rock-fest look will be a piece of cake. Free-floating dresses, folky prints, fringe, tie-dye  a Coachella undercurrent so infected the spring collections that, come festival time, youre already there. No need to head to the shops; just come as you are.

title: Corporate Design: An Energizer Versus an Eyesore
description: The rivalry between the South Korean tech giants Samsung and LG isnt just played out over sales of smartphones and curved television screens. Both companies are building new American headquarters, Samsung in north San Jose, Calif.; LG in Englewood Cliffs, N.J. And on this score, the contest isnt close. Buildings are corporate symbols and advertisements, after all. Samsung comes across as a good citizen here; LG as a lousy neighbor.

title: An Artist Demands Civility on the Street With Grit and Buckets of Paste
description: ATLANTA  With a lick of wheat paste, a roller and a stepladder, Tatyana Fazlalizadeh, a painter and illustrator from Brooklyn, introduced herself to the South, in an unusual way.

title: Deadly Wave of Blasts Hits Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  The Iraqi capital, Baghdad, experienced a series of violent attacks on Wednesday when eight car bombs and two mortar shells killed as many as 25 people in episodes around the city, according to security personnel.

title: Weathering a Technical Glitch With Puckish Spirit and Catchy Songs
description: Neil Finns concert on Tuesday night at Town Hall wasnt the smoothest show of a long career. But technical glitches only underscored the strength of his songwriting and the puckishness of his spirit. His two-and-a-half-hour set included most of the songs from his new album, Dizzy Heights, along with a generous retrospective from his bands Split Enz and Crowded House in the 1980s and his other solo and collaborative projects since the 1990s.

title: Hit and Run at Day Care in Florida Kills a Child
description: MIAMI  A hit-and-run crash sent a car barreling through the wooden wall of a crowded day care center on Wednesday in a suburb of Orlando, killing one girl and injuring 15 people, at least 12 of them children, some of them grievously, the authorities said. One adult was also hospitalized.

title: Massaging Applicators
description: The latest gimmick in skin care? Products with massaging applicators. Like the vibrating mascara wand before them, they are fun to use, even if the result is indistinguishable from one achieved with your fingertips.

title: Personalities Beyond Fists and Faces
description: Beyond the classic poses of boxers with fists at the ready, Holger Keifel found a spirit that lingered beyond the ring.

title: A Big Job Might Ruin a Good Thing
description: It took one week to go from cancel Colbert to coronate him.

title: As Ally Prepares for Offering, Government Cuts Stake
description: Updated, 8:26 p.m. | The federal government is close to shedding the last remnants of its crisis-era bailouts.

title: New Kids on the Magazine Rack
description: Walk into any magazine store in New York City these days, and prepare to be flummoxed by a wall of unfamiliar fashion publications. Once-obscure titles like the Gentlewoman and 032C, which pioneered an indie print resurgence, now share shelf space with dozens of newer and even more obscure magazines, each offering its own niche perspective on fashion  from the irreverent to the fearless. Heres a guide to seven fashion magazines on the cutting edge of print.

title: Jamie Dimon Writes of Nerve-Racking 2013
description: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, has reflected in his annual shareholder letter on a year that was marked by the bank pulling out its checkbook to mend frayed relationships with the federal government  a reconciliation that has already cost around $20 billion.

title: Despite Doubts, a Vote Worth Casting
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  It would be easy for me to say I had no fear going into Election Day. But it wouldnt be true.

title: Taking on Art Looters on Twitter
description: Monica Hanna stood inside the Malawi National Museum in Minya, Egypt, last August, armed only with a cellphone and her Twitter account, as looters ran rampant. Nearly all the objects she had loved since childhood  mummies and amulets, scarabs and carved ibises  were gone. In their place lay shattered glass, shards of pottery, splintered wood and the charred remains of a royal sarcophagus.

title: Hall of Fame Decides Who Rocks, Officially
description: In the beginning, it was obvious who should be inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. Elvis Presley, Chuck Berry, Ray Charles, the Beatles, the Rolling Stones, Little Richard, James Brown, Bob Dylan: All were giants whose selection no one could quarrel with.

title: What She Did for a Warm Towel
description: When designers need inspiration for a new product, some simply look around their own homes and consider whats missing.

title: Discounts from Sferra, Marimekko, Intrieurs and Rech!
description: Sferras sample sale runs through Sunday at Chelsea Market, with up to 70 percent off prices on bed, bath and table linens (a set of four Crest embroidered linen dinner napkins, originally $75, is about $22); 75 Ninth Avenue (West 15th Street), sferra.com.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Syria, Kenya, India and Central Africa Republic.

title: The Name on the Digital Door
description: Sasha Lord has never met the residents of Hell or Namaste, Om shanti, but she has spent a lot of time thinking about them. For a while, every time Ms. Lord, a 32-year-old band promoter in Arlington, Va., posted a photograph on Instagram from her studio apartment, she was reminded of their existence.

title: Add Seeds and Soil, Then Stir
description: The Plant Recipe Book (Artisan, $24.95), by Baylor Chapman, is a follow-up to The Flower Recipe Book, and like its successful predecessor offers an ingredient-by-ingredient approach to gardening  container gardening, in this case. The suggested chefs pantry includes a small trowel, coated wire, a watering can, pruning shears and even actual kitchen tools like a skewer and a turkey baster.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: All Thats Missing Is a Necktie
description: The Oriole Mill was founded eight years ago by Bethanne Knudson, a textile artist, and Stephan Michelson, a statistical analyst and musician. The couple, who took over a 72,000-square-foot former food processing plant in Hendersonville, N.C., produce jacquard fabric and make most everything to dress a bed (they dont do sheets). They recently introduced four collections. Two (Cape Cod and Colorado Plateau) are in whats-not-to-like neutrals, and a third (Charleston) has a cheery blue-and-white pattern. The last, Brooklyn, is a dark departure. Its a masculine, urban bed that was inspired by a fabric we make that is reminiscent of mens wear, Ms. Knudson said. Prices are $150 for a 20-inch-square pillow to $1,350 for a king-size duvet. Information: 828-693-5500 or theoriolemill.com.

title: Openings, Events and Sales for the Week of April 10
description: Openings and Events

title: Squirrels Are Reading This Now
description: Almost nothing can come between squirrels and the birdseed they gorge on, not even Led Zeppelin music and mild electrical shocks. For three decades, the humor writer Bill Adler Jr., 57, has collected tips for keeping the rodents away from avian meals. He has updated his 1988 volume, Outwitting Squirrels: 101 Cunning Stratagems to Reduce Dramatically the Egregious Misappropriation of Seed From Your Birdfeeder by Squirrels (Chicago Review Press, $16.95), for a new, third edition. (His other books include advice for coping with cranky toddlers, ravenous deer, litigious neighbors and incompetent home contractors.) The field has made some technological advances, he reports, but squirrels still have little else to do all day but strategize.

title: A Gentleman Returns, With Art
description: The Lord Baltimore, yet another down-at-the-heels grand hotel, has been returned to its former elegance, thanks to a renovation that was completed in March.

title: Should I Fix Those Little Hairline Cracks in My Walls?
description: Q. Should I fix those little hairline cracks in my walls before selling my home?

title: Its Mourning in America
description: Growing up in Uniontown, Pa., the Hurley twins, Tracy and Tonya, spent most weekends attending funerals with their grandmother. In our hometown, Sundays were either for funerals or a Steelers game, said Tracy, who is now Tracy Martin. And our grandmother was a funeral fly.

title: Egg Cups for the Occasion
description: When youre shopping for egg cups, it makes sense to bring some eggs along with you. How else would you try out the egg cups for size?

title: Womens Rights Activist Criticizes Brandeiss Decision to Cancel Her Honorary Degree
description: Ayaan Hirsi Ali, a womens rights advocate and critic of Islam, said in a statement on Wednesday that Brandeis University had betrayed the principles of freedom of expression and religion by rescinding an invitation to her to receive an honorary degree.

title: Photo Diary | Milan Design Week 2014: Boffi
description: Scenes from the Milan Design Week photo diary of Danilo Scarpati.

title: Prepping the Mower
description: What to do before cutting the grass.

title: Homeowners, Start Your Engines
description: Every November there comes a day when I race into the shed with my trusty lawn mower, fling it into a corner and let loose a fist pump that would give Tiger Woods chills. Is it the final cut of the year? Yup. But you never truly know, so it seems like a good idea not to drain the gas, change the oil or do whatever it is the read-the-manual folks do.

title: I.M.F. Warns of Risk From Emerging-Market Corporate Debt
description: WASHINGTON  As fears mount about emerging markets, American mutual fund investors with significant exposure to bonds issued by indebted companies in fast-growing economies may be at risk, the International Monetary Fund warned in a report published on Wednesday.

title: New York City Reducing Role of Tests in Advancing Students to Next Grade
description: New York Citys Education Department, in a break with the data-driven policies of former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, moved on Wednesday to reduce the role of standardized exams in deciding which students to hold back each year.

title: We Need to Talk About the Test
description: ID like to tell you what was wrong with the tests my students took last week, but I cant. Pearsons $32 million contract with New York State to design the exams prohibits the state from making the tests public and imposes a gag order on educators who administer them. So teachers watched hundreds of thousands of children in grades 3 to 8 sit for between 70 and 180 minutes per day for three days taking a state English Language Arts exam that does a poor job of testing reading comprehension, and yet were not allowed to point out what the problems were.

title: Former S.E.C. Official to Join K.K.R. as Compliance Chief
description: Bruce Karpati, a former Securities and Exchange Commission official, is joining the giant private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company as its chief compliance officer, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.

title: Weighing Lifes Risks, on Land and Sea
description: To the Editor:

title: Refugee Crisis in Syria
Cooks Do It All on Snowboard Expeditions
description: During expeditions to Alaska, Jeremy Jones and Teton Gravity Research look for team members who are as versatile as they are dependable. No one embodies this better than the crews camp cook.

title: Chiding an F.E.C. Colleague
description: To the Editor:

title: Health Goal Met, White House Reviews Missteps
description: WASHINGTON  Days after hitting their target of signing up more than seven million people for health insurance, Denis R. McDonough, the White House chief of staff, and other top aides to President Obama gathered last week on the patio just outside Mr. McDonoughs West Wing office.

title: Video: Cooks Do It All on Snowboard Expeditions
description: Higher Unplugged looks at the making of the film Higher, which follows the snowboarder Jeremy Jones and the Teton Gravity Research crew as they ascend and ride peaks in Alaska, Wyoming, California and Nepal. Jones is a professional snowboarder who has been named big mountain rider of the year 10 times by Snowboarder magazine.

title: Trade, Taiwan and China
description: To the Editor:

title: A Move to Adjust Pensions?
description: To the Editor:

title: Massimo Tamburini, Sculptor of Shapely Motorcycles, Dies at 70
description: They were objects of unalloyed lust.

title: Los Angeless Future at Risk
description: A report on the civic health of the city said that it was barely treading water while the rest of the world was moving forward.

title: Ready for Frozen Four, Gophers Star Goalie Is Inviting the Pressure
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Like so many things involving hockey in Minnesota, Adam Wilcoxs story began with a couple of youngsters playing in a basement.

title: Obama Mourns Victims at Fort Hood
description: President Obama delivered remarks at the base in Texas and mourned with the families and uniformed comrades of those killed in the shooting last week.

title: Benefits of Fake Meats
description: To the Editor:

title: College for Criminals
description: IN February, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York announced plans to underwrite college classes in 10 state prisons, building on the success of privately funded and widely praised programs like the Bard Prison Initiative. Mr. Cuomo pointed out that inmates who got an education had a much better chance of finding a job and were much less likely to menace their neighbors after release. He noted that the cost  $5,000 per inmate per year  would be a bargain compared with the $60,000 it costs to incarcerate a prisoner for a year.

title: Even New York Drivers Wowed by a White, Winged Commuter
description: I had an extraordinary moment on the Palisades Parkway leaving New York City. In medium traffic moving about 50 miles per hour, with end-of-day sun slanting from the west, I could see something white and, seemingly, winged, flitting and darting within the flow of cars up ahead.

title: M.L.B. Report Highlights Sobering Number of Black Players
description: Dave Dombrowski is the head of baseballs on-field diversity task force, but he is also the president of the Detroit Tigers. In the last year, as he studied ways to give better opportunities to African-Americans, Dombrowski realized the challenge demanded more than a committee of experts with day jobs.

title: Parenting the Non-Girlie Girl
description: There are many possible explanations for why my 5-year-old daughter has yet again asked if she can change her name to Sam. Sam can also be a girls name, I explain hopefully. No, she clarifies, sighing at the dullard she has been given for a mother. She wants to be Sam the boys name.

title: Designing an Eco-Friendly Honeymoon
description: Cayuga Sustainable Hospitality, a Central American eco-lodge operator with eight properties, is looking for newlyweds to help perfect the eco-honeymoon experience.

title: We Should Be in a Rage
description: Voter apathy is a civic abdication. There is no other way to describe it.

title: Wayne Henderson, a Founder of the Jazz Crusaders, Dies at 74
description: Wayne Henderson, a trombonist and composer who was a founding member of the Jazz Crusaders, which played straight-ahead bebop beginning in the 1950s and then morphed into leading performers of jazz-funk, died on April 5 in Culver City, Calif. He was 74.

title: Layers of Mystery for a Steinway Grand
description: This is a mystery story, but not a conventional whodunit. It has no dead bodies. No smoking guns. No hard-boiled detectives in trench coats and fedoras.

title: Mary Cheever, a Central Figure in a Literary Family, Dies at 95
description: Mary Cheever, a central figure in a family of prominent American writers whose most notable member was her husband, John, with whom she had a relationship as complex as those he wrote about in his prizewinning short stories and novels, died on Monday at the home they had shared in Ossining, N.Y. She was 95.

title: James Hellwig, Wrestlings Ultimate Warrior, Dies at 54
description: James Hellwig, a professional wrestler known in the 1990s as the Ultimate Warrior  a frenzied mountain of muscle and face paint who was billed as the heir apparent to Hulk Hogan, but who then fell out of favor  died on Tuesday in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 54.

title: Russia Didnt Share All Details on Boston Bombing Suspect, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  The Russian government declined to provide the F.B.I. with information about one of the Boston Marathon bombing suspects that would most likely have led to more extensive scrutiny of him at least two years before the attack, according to an inspector generals report.

title: Northwestern Requests Review of Labor Ruling
description: CHICAGO  Northwestern on Wednesday formally requested a review of the ruling that its scholarship football players are employees and able to form a union.

title: Where the G.O.P. Gets It Right
description: Republicans may seem like ultimate Scrooges. Many want to slash food stamps, unemployment benefits and just about any program that helps the needy.

title: In a Land of On-Time Arrivals, a Tour of Anything But
description: BERLIN  In the early days of aviation, it was common for people to visit airports simply to stand on observation decks and watch the planes come and go. This citys new airport is attracting tourists for the opposite reason: a conspicuous lack of passengers and planes after a series of delays and bungles that have driven its cost billions of dollars over budget and pushed its opening back indefinitely.

title: Report Finds Los Angeles at Risk of Decline
description: LOS ANGELES  From the 73-story skyscraper that just broke ground downtown (the tallest in the West), to the blizzard of office, shopping and apartment complexes rising from there to the Pacific, construction is bustling in Los Angeles. Home prices are up, and the foreclosure rate is declining. Crime is down. There is a new mayor in City Hall. In many ways, Los Angeles, like many once-beleaguered cities across the nation, seems on the upswing.

title: U.S. Pair Cant Leave Qatar Amid Appeal
description: Matthew and Grace Huang, an American couple entangled in Qatars criminal justice system over the death of their adopted daughter, have been denied permission to fly home while the appeal of their three-year prison term is pending, and their lawyers said they might be incarcerated as early as Friday.

title: Free-for-All in the Cafeteria
description: More than a million children attend public schools in New York City. About 780,000 of them are poor enough to qualify for a free or reduced-price lunch. Getting into the program requires some paperwork, which is a burden but not a terrible one; the application is just one page. So why do so many eligible children  about 250,000  not participate?

title: Banks Ease Hours for Junior Staff, but Workload Stays Same
description: The biggest investment banks recently signaled a sea change in their corporate culture, telling their most junior employees to ease up a bit on their hard-charging work schedules.

title: Where Does the G.M. Recall Rank?
description: Automakers have a long history of trying to maintain their reputations in the face of major recalls.

title: A Risk to Indias Nuclear Doctrine
description: With Indias national elections in full swing, the campaign promises of the Bharatiya Janata Party, the presumed front-runner to lead the next government, are drawing more scrutiny. Among the more troubling proposals in the partys election manifesto is one to revise and update the countrys nuclear doctrine.

title: Debate Over Risk of Driving G.M.s Recalled Cars
description: There was nothing but the car key on Jacob Hughess key ring.

title: Missteps Aside, de Blasio Looks to Focus Anew on Activist Style
description: He regrets his public-relations headaches, saying he and his team could have done a better job speaking to the public.

title: Capital in the Twenty-First Century
description: My NYRB review of Piketty is up.

title: Mechanics of the Plane Search, Explained
description: How the multinational team off the coast of Australia is continuing the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

title: Users Stark Reminder: As Web Grows, It Grows Less Secure
description: It was the computer programming equivalent of misspelling Mississippi  an error at once careless, inevitable and hard for most human eyes to spot.

title: An Easy Hole? Only for Those Who Play It Perfectly
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  The 15th hole at Augusta National Golf Club is statistically one of the easiest in the Masters, a 530-yard par 5 whose green can be reached in two shots, with the field routinely averaging a better-than-par score.

title: Amid Exploding Houses and a Wave of Mud, a Maternal Instinct Flared
description: SEATTLE  What Amanda Skorjanc saw on the morning of the landslide in Oso, Wash., looking out her window with her 22-week-old baby in her arms, was the stuff of nightmares.

title: Flaw Calls for Altering Passwords, Experts Say
description: A programming mistake from two years ago has forced countless websites to make fixes to protect the sensitive personal information of consumers.

title: Winning Powerball and Lottery Numbers for April 9, 2014
description: April 9, 2014

title: After Optimism of More Pings, Reality of Long Jet Search Settles In
description: In the excitement of detecting four bursts of signals that might have originated from the flight recorders of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, missing for more than a month, Australian officials have waxed optimistic.

title: Eye Doctors Say Their Profits Are Smaller Than Data Makes Them Look
description: Although consumers and health experts will be poring over the newly released Medicare data for months, maybe years to come, one startling piece of information has already emerged, demonstrating some of the complexity inherent in the long-fought-over information on 880,000 health care providers across the country.

title: Syria: Deadly Car Bomb Blasts Hit Homs
description: Two car bombs exploded minutes apart near a shop in the central Syrian city of Homs on Wednesday, killing at least 25 people, state news media and an antigovernment monitoring group reported.

title: Medicares Most Reimbursed Ophthalmologists
description: Nearly 3,000 ophthalmologists fell in the top 2 percent of Medicare Part B recipients, each receiving more than $470,000 in payments in 2012.

title: The Medicare Datas Pitfalls
description: The release on Wednesday of Medicare payment data is getting mixed reviews from doctors. Many say they favor sharing information but worry that the data presented by Medicare omits important details and may mislead the public and paint an unfairly negative picture of individual doctors.

title: A Bagful of Memories of a Home in Augusta
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Before the Masters began, four caddies carved out a quiet moment to lift their bottles of beer in a toast to their favorite former nun, a Southern woman whose hospitality survived her death.

title: Sharptons Group Seems Undaunted by His F.B.I. Role
description: As new details emerged about his four-year stint in the 1980s as a confidential informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Rev. Al Sharpton thought enough of the attention to hold a news conference to address what became front-page fodder for New York tabloids for two days this week.

title: The Truth About the Pay Gap
description: Women are the primary or co-breadwinner in 6 out of 10 American families. That makes the economic imperative of addressing the wage gap between women and men important, as is every step President Obama can take in that direction.

title: Last Criminal Trial Stemming From Occupy Wall Street Is Underway
description: By most accounts, Occupy Wall Streets moment in the cultural spotlight has passed, and headlines about disaffected New York idealists protesting the wide gap between rich and poor have become scarce.

title: In Houston, Bush 41 Greets Obama, Who Later Assails G.O.P.
description: HOUSTON  President Obama came to this Texas metropolis on Wednesday to raise money for Democrats, but the first person to welcome him to town was the citys most prominent Republican, the first President George Bush.

title: Playing 15 Can Play With Your Head
description: The 15th hole at Augusta often plays a crucial role in determining the Masters champion.

title: Japan Pushes Plan to Stockpile Plutonium, Despite Proliferation Risks
description: TOKYO  Just weeks after Japan agreed to give up a cache of weapons-grade plutonium, the country is set to push ahead with a program that would produce new stockpiles of the material, creating a proliferation risk for decades to come.

title: Hes Old, Rich and Dying, and Wants His Nephews Girl
description: This place is fun! A wondrous mess! I wish my every day knew such excess!

title: Day Trip Destination
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  I thought this one was relatively easy for a Thursday puzzle and there wasnt much of a trick to the theme, but I did enjoy all the FLAGS waving at me. The theme hangs together very well, and the cluing is tricky.

title: De Blasio Is Urged to Alter Housing Plans at Brooklyn Park
description: Brooklyn Bridge Park, which stretches 1.3 miles along the East River waterfront, was a creation of the administration of Michael R. Bloomberg, with a novel  and contentious  financing mechanism in the form of luxury housing in the park.

title: In Maryland, a Political Drama Befitting the Show at Its Center
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md.  Where was Frank Underwood when he was really needed?

title: U.S. Attorney Criticizes Cuomos Closing of Panel
description: Less than two weeks after Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo abruptly shut down a commission he had formed to investigate political corruption in New York State, the United States attorney in Manhattan is sharply questioning the governors decision and is taking possession of all of the panels case files, according to letters sent to the commissions members on April 3 and again on Wednesday afternoon.

title: On Civil Rights Act Anniversary, Bill Clinton Challenges Lawmakers to Be Bold
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Bill Clintons political awakening came against the backdrop of the civil rights movement and the Vietnam War. Fifty years later, Mr. Clinton observed the anniversary of the passage of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 with a strong reminder about the sacrifices lawmakers must make to advance sweeping and controversial legislation.

title: Flight 370 Search Brings Satellite Company an Unaccustomed Bit of Fame
description: LONDON  On an enormous electronic map of the globe in the modernist headquarters of a satellite company here, two green hexagons the size of dinner plates hovered off the west coast of Australia, revealing signals from an armada of ships and planes converged in the hunt for any remains of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

title: Injury and Math Dim Hopes for Knicks
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Another day as a member of the Knicks meant conditioning work and shooting drills, a focus on the immediate future (four remaining games) and a sad reassessment of the teams playoff odds (slim to none).

title: Energy Panel Faulted on Information Safeguards
description: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission may not have adequate controls to protect information that could be used to sabotage the power grid, the Energy Departments inspector general said on Wednesday. The inspector general, Gregory H. Friedman, issued a management alert that was a veiled slap at a former chairman of the commission, Jon Wellinghoff, who has been arguing that an attack last year on a California substation was an act of terrorism, a conclusion that the F.B.I. and local law enforcement officials have refused to endorse. Mr. Friedman said that the commission staff had created a presentation that should have been classified and protected from release. The commission generated a memo, later described by The Wall Street Journal, that said that simultaneous attacks on a handful of substations around the country could cripple the power grid. The inspector general said he was acting after a complaint from the Energy Departments ethics officer and letters from the chairwoman and ranking minority member of the Senate Energy Committee. He recommended establishing a classification system, a step he said the current chairwoman of the commission had promised to implement promptly.

title: Tanaka Has Highs and Lows, but the Yankees Bullpen Has Only the Latter
description: After a solid but unspectacular major league debut last week, Masahiro Tanaka examined video of his outing to determine what he might have done wrong. He found a slight mechanical flaw, which he declined to identify but aimed to correct.

title: Profiling Rules Said to Give F.B.I. Tactical Leeway
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr.s long-awaited revisions to the Justice Departments racial profiling rules would allow the F.B.I. to continue many, if not all, of the tactics opposed by civil rights groups, such as mapping ethnic populations and using that data to recruit informants and open investigations.

title: The Americans Recap: Spy Games Are Exciting, Until Theyre Deadly
description: Charles Duluth, the K.G.B. agent posing as a conservative journalist whom Philip calls upon for help from time to time, is a very strange character. He has a stiff, patrician voice but is a die-hard Marxist. One imagines him growing up among crusty WASP bankers and thus handily learning to despise capitalism. At any rate, hes not a particularly great spy, and as Episode 7 begins, Philip cant get a hold of him, and he desperately needs his help in placing a large bug  the size of a rat, Philip complains to the new handler, Kate  on a computing system to gather data from the Arpanet, an Internet prototype.

title: Wheeler and Mets Offense Are No Match for Santana in His Braves Debut
description: ATLANTA  Eight games into the season, the Mets were already counting moral victories. They had been blanketed for eight innings, held to three hits by Ervin Santana in his Braves debut. But once Santana left the game, they rallied to score three runs in the ninth, before falling short, 4-3, at Turner Field on Wednesday night.

title: De Blasio: You Cant Be Passive in a Role Like This
description: Following are edited excerpts from an interview with Mayor Bill de Blasio conducted on Wednesday by The New York Times:

title: Lost Season at Least Provides Seasoning for Islanders
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  With three games remaining in a disappointing season, the Islanders cannot be blamed for mulling what might have been.

title: Already, Nets Rookie Has Signature Moment
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Mason Plumlee, the Nets 24-year-old rookie center, was reclining at his locker here Wednesday afternoon, shaking his head and laughing about the previous night.

title: Different Sort of Dog Run: Beside Train, Between Boroughs
description: The urban dog has long lived a singular life. Apartment hallways double as exercise hubs. Sidewalks teem with potential snacks, discarded from bodegas on high.

title: India Election Digest: April 10
description: What you need to know about Indias elections on Thursday: Voters in 11 states and three union territories go to the polls  Bihar, Chhattisgarh, Haryana, Jammu and Kashmir, Jharkhand, Kerala, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Odisha, Uttar Pradesh and the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, Chandigarh, Lakshadweep and Delhi.

title: Chinese Exports and Imports Unexpectedly Fell in March
description: HONG KONG  Chinas exports unexpectedly fell in March, and its imports dropped even more sharply, but the significance of the data for the Chinese economy was clouded by uncertainty over the extent to which exporters and importers were timing shipments to profit from currency market shifts.

title: Putin Warns of Restricting Natural Gas Supply to Ukraine
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin and other senior Russian officials threatened on Wednesday to restrict supplies of natural gas to Ukraine, and they reiterated the Kremlins contention that Ukraine owes Russia more than $16 billion in unpaid gas bills and other debts.

title: The Importance of Being Nicky
description: The legendary Nicky Haslams exuberant interiors are the mark of an audaciously unparalleled man. When it came to decorating his own new home, he threw out all the rules of good taste and embraced the phoniest of fakes.

title: Vintage Studio Portraits of Indian Women From the Peak of British Colonialism
description: In this weekly series, Ts photo editors share the most compelling visual projects theyve discovered.

title: In Milan, Martino Gampers Clever Scheme to Showcase Italian Craft Traditions
description: People have been talking about the London-based Italian designer Martino Gamper since the opening of his playful, shelving-focused exhibit Design Is a State of Mind at the Serpentine Gallery. This week he also brought his irreverent touch to Milan, where visitors to Salone di Mobile can find his latest work at Nilufar Gallery or admire his windows for the department store Rinascente. Gamper also presented a third project, the exhibition FROMTO, in which he was involved less as a designer, and more as a curator.

title: The Reinvention of Minimalism
description: In his elegantly spare Paris apartment, architect-of-the-moment Joseph Dirand introduces sensuous materials and classical elements to sublime effect.

title: A Code Death for Dying Patients
description: Sadly, but with conviction, I recently removed breathing tubes from three patients in intensive care.

title: Heroes of Banking Reform
description: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz professor of entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.

title: Word of the Day | dross
description: dross\drs, dros\ noun

title: Orioles Are Impressed, if Not Overly So, by Tanaka
description: Nelson Cruz smirked at the question, more irritated than amused by the suggestion that he might have been curious to see Masahiro Tanaka in person. The hype of a $155 million contract and another pinstriped sensation from Japan did not do much for Cruz, the Baltimore Orioles left fielder.

title: Walmart to Sell Organic Food, Undercutting Big Brands
description: Walmart plans to announce on Thursday that it is putting its muscle behind Wild Oats organic products, offering the label at prices that will undercut brand-name organic competitors by at least 25 percent.

title: Pro Bowl to Join Super Bowl in 2015
description: The N.F.L. Pro Bowl will be played in Glendale, Ariz., next year, a week before the Super Bowl is held there. It is the first time the Pro Bowl and Super Bowl will be played in the same city since 2010, when both games were held in Miami Gardens, Fla. The N.F.L. said the Pro Bowl would return to Hawaii in 2016, but the league did not say where the game would be after that.

title: J & R Closes Manhattan Store for a Redesign
description: J & R Music and Computer World, a mainstay music and electronics store in Lower Manhattan for 43 years, closed its doors on Wednesday to redesign its space on Park Row.

title: Times Minute | Why L.B.J. Still Matters
description: Today on the Minute, commemorating 50 years since President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the Civil Rights Act.

title: Golfers Hoping for Winning Introduction to Masters
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Twenty-four Masters rookies are in this years field, a modern-era record, increasing the chances that someone will become the fourth player to win in his inaugural Augusta National Golf Club appearance.

title: Whats on Thursday
description: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE BIG BANG THEORY Sheldon (Jim Parsons, above) has a meltdown after deciding that he is wasting his time on string theory.
