That cache, followed by a second from Virginia, caused the restaurant to issue an ecstatic Twitter post two weeks ago: First ramps of the season! (The message was concluded by the only-in-the-New-York-food-world hashtag of #omgramps.) So far, Mr. Welch has used his ramps in entrees like the hand-rolled garganelli pasta he was serving the other night with fiddlehead ferns, crushed red pepper and a ramp pesto ($19,) and in appetizers like the one a party of three was enjoying while waiting for a missing fourth person to arrive.

title: Testimony Still Sought on Shut Lanes at George Washington Bridge
description: Legislative investigators in New Jersey say they will begin calling witnesses to testify about the lane closings at the George Washington Bridge last fall, proceeding even though a judge ruled that two former aides to Gov. Chris Christie did not have to comply with a subpoena seeking records related to the scandal.

title: Answers to Questions About the Con Edison Clock Towers Lights and Bingo
description: Q. I am used to seeing the top of the Con Edison clock tower, off Union Square, lighted up. On April 1, the lights went out and stayed out for quite a while. Was that an April Fools joke?

title: The Chanteuse and the Gun Are Loaded
description: Some things were never meant to be shouted through megaphones. On the basis of Bullets Over Broadway: The Musical, the occasionally funny but mostly just loud new show that opened at the St. James Theater on Thursday night, that would include the wit of Woody Allen.

title: Things Worn at Home
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  This one was challenging, as Friday puzzles tend to be, but wow, was it worth it. There is so much good stuff in todays puzzle by Peter Wentz. I just had to work hard to establish a toehold in order to find it.

title: Patrons of 2 Stores Ponder a Loss of Music and Color
description: It was where Vincent Moore went to buy Led Zeppelin, Jimi Hendrix and Donna Summer on LPs in the 1970s. It was where he went to buy the first Die Hard movie on VHS in the 1980s, and countless compact discs. Later still, it was where he bought his first digital camera.

title: Partnerships Old, New and Stage-Managed
description: Pico Alexander, the 22-year-old actor playing George Gibbs in the production of Our Town opening at George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick later this month, has sometimes had trouble focusing during rehearsals.

title: Three Honorary Starters at the Masters, With 13 Green Jackets
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Tiger Woods is not playing in the Masters for the first time since 1994 because of a back injury, but he has not forgotten about the tournament, which he has won four times. Woods took to Twitter on Thursday after the honorary starters, Arnold Palmer, Gary Player and Jack Nicklaus, hit the first tee shots to open the 78th Masters.

title: An Arkin Brothers Standing Commitment
description: Bob Arkin had just arrived at the gig, and already the boss was starting in.

title: Officials Rule Boys Death as Homicide
description: The death of a 4-year-old boy, who prosecutors say was tortured and starved to death by a family friend, has been ruled a homicide by the New York City medical examiners officer, paving the way for murder charges to be filed in the case.

title: Three Aggressive Young Golf Stars Are More Old School Than Not
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  The young and the restless grouping of Rory McIlroy, Jordan Spieth and Patrick Reed arrived at the par-4 17th hole a combined four under par in the first round of the Masters. All three hit approaches that looked suitable for posing, but two of the balls rolled like tears off the green.

title: Venezuelan Leader and Opposition Meet in Bid to Ease Tensions
description: President Nicols Maduro of Venezuela and leaders of a coalition of opposition political parties held a dramatic televised meeting on Thursday in a first step aimed at defusing tensions that have escalated during more than two months of antigovernment protests.

title: Culture Minute | A Weekend Jump-Start
description: Some ideas for your off hours. Last chance for the Trisha Brown Dance Company in New York, the final season of Mad Men begins, and a Woody Allen-inspired Broadway show.

title: Culture Minute | A Weekend Jump-Start
description: In the Video

title: Italian Court Weighs Community Service for Berlusconi
description: ROME  A court in Milan held a sentencing hearing on Thursday for former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, who was convicted of tax fraud in 2012.

title: In a Queens School, an Early Start on Preparing Responsible Digital Citizens
description: Janet Elias refers to her students as digital natives, children who have never known a world without computers. She teaches them to search the Internet and create slide-show presentations, and this year she has also added a theme on social media: its applications, its effect on real-world events and the importance of using it safely.

title: Settlement Ends Dispute Over Rooneys Remains
description: LOS ANGELES  Mickey Rooney can finally rest in peace, as a dispute over disposition of his remains was settled on Thursday, according to The Wrap. The settlement came shortly before a court hearing that was to have addressed the matter on Friday morning.

title: Rangers, in Their Home Finale, Slip Past the Last-Place Sabres
description: The sign of a confident team, Rick Nash was saying in the Rangers locker room Thursday night, is winning the bad games.

title: Yankees Win in Style, but Most of Focus Is on a Substance
description: After all the money spent, after the Yankees poached a star Boston outfielder and the Red Sox brought his World Series ring to Yankee Stadium, after all this, the story line in the first meeting of 2014 belonged to Michael Pinedas right hand.

title: Rangel and Challengers Meet in First Debate of Primary Campaign
description: The grizzled incumbent trumpeted his experience, pounding on the table for emphasis while insisting, to laughter, that he wouldnt cling to his seat till I drop dead.

title: House Votes to Deny Visa to Iranian Envoy Linked to 79 Hostage Crisis
description: The House on Thursday unanimously passed legislation approved by the Senate aimed at denying a visa to Irans choice for United Nations ambassador. The vote sent what sponsors called a blunt rejoinder to the Iranian government for having selected a nominee who played a role, however minor, in the 1979 American hostage crisis in Tehran.

title: Steven A. Shaw, 44, Founder of an Early Blog About Food, Dies
description: Steven A. Shaw, a founder of the influential online culinary discussion forum eGullet and one of the first writers to start his own food blog, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 44.

title: Newcomer and Powerhouse Reach Final
description: PHILADELPHIA  Daniel Ciampini scored a hat trick to lift Union College over Boston College, 5-4, on Thursday at Wells Fargo Center. The Dutchmen (31-6-4) advanced to their first N.C.A.A. final, where on Saturday they will face Minnesota, the No. 1 seed.

title: Times Minute | The New Stephen Colbert
description: Bill Carter on the news that Stephen Colbert will leave his satirical right-wing character behind for a fresh start at CBSs Late Show.

title: Times Minute | The New Stephen Colbert
description: In the Video

title: Diamond in the Rough
description: From hawking his wares on the sidewalks of SoHo to showing them at the Whitney Biennial, the sculptor Alma Allen has taken the road less traveled to art world stardom.

title: Three Storied Design Brands Venture Into New Territory
description: At this years Salone del Mobile in Milan, the Finnish tableware company Iittala expanded into housewares; the Italian housewares maker Kartell moved into tableware; and the German furniture line e15 got serious about lighting.

title: Classic Rock
description: From monoliths to mosaics, marble has been a staple of regal artistry since the days of ancient Egypt. Now, a new group of designers are carving out their own models.

title: Itinerary | Joshua Trees Artful Excursions
description: Whether or not you can score a personal invite to the sculptor and designer Alma Allens home and studio in Joshua Tree, Calif., the desert respite offers plenty of other sources of art, culture and inspiration (and makes for an ideal escape from the nearby madness that is the Coachella festival). Here, a few highlights.

title: Ask Well: Walking vs. Elliptical Training
description: Question:

title: Congress and the Belief That Human Life Is Priceless
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

title: Word of the Day | remunerative
description: remunerative\ri-my-n-r-tiv, -ra-\ adjective

title: Corrections: April 11, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: 9 Dead and Dozens Injured in California Crash
description: A tour bus carrying high school students on a college visit collided with a FedEx 18-wheeler in a fiery crash on Thursday in Northern California that left nine people dead and dozens injured, according to the authorities.

title: Showing Value at the Plate and on the Bases, Young Leads the Mets to a Win
description: ATLANTA  Just before the season, Eric Young Jr. seemed to be the odd man out in the Mets outfield, behind Curtis Granderson, Chris Young and Juan Lagares. His speed was his most notable trait, and he was the Mets only natural leadoff hitter, but to play, he had to show that the team could not thrive with just anyone leading off.

title: India Election Digest: April 11
description: What you need to know on Friday about Indias elections: Voter turnout was high during the first big phase of the elections, Narendra Modis estranged wife expresses hope that he will win, and candidates look for ways to exceed their legal campaign spending limit.

title: N.B.A. to Play Abroad in Preseason
description: The N.B.A. on Thursday announced a slate of international preseason games to be played in October. There will be five games across four countries, including two Nets games in China. The Nets and the Sacramento Kings will play Oct. 12 in Shanghai and Oct. 15 in Beijing. The Nets previously visited China in 2010, playing exhibition games in Beijing and Guangzhou. The San Antonio Spurs will play exhibition games against local clubs in Berlin and Istanbul, and the Miami Heat and the Cleveland Cavaliers will face off in Rio de Janeiro.

title: Leee Black Childers, Portraitist of a Downtown Demimonde, Dies at 68
description: Leee Black Childers, whose photographs of Warholians, punk musicians, club kids, drag queens and other denizens of late-night downtown life told an inside story of a vibrant musical era in New York City and elsewhere, died on April 6 in Los Angeles, where he had gone to attend a retrospective of his work. He was 68 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Welcomes Its Newest Members
description: The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame inducted its new members at a full-scale arena concert on Thursday night at Barclays Center, with its largest live audience by far. It would have been an ideal setting for the band that didnt perform: Kiss, the hard-rock arena-spectacular showmen in makeup who, until this year, had been snubbed by the hall since becoming eligible in 1999. After Kiss was accepted, its members, past and present, had squabbled with the Hall of Fame and among themselves over which of its lineups, original or current, would perform; no one did.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 12:45 P.M. (HBO) GLORIA: IN HER OWN WORDS (2011) After making headlines as a journalist in the 1960s in New York City with an expos on the working conditions of Playboy Bunnies, Gloria Steinem felt her political ideals expanding when she covered an abortion hearing for New York magazine in 1969 and learned of the horrifying experiences women had endured. (Ms. Steinem, above in 1969, kept secret the abortion shed had at 22.) On Aug. 26, 1970, she helped lead the Womens Strike for Equality on the 50th anniversary of the passage of the 19th Amendment, giving women the right to vote. In 1972 she helped found Ms. Magazine, beginning her ascent as a public face of feminism. This documentary from Peter W. Kunhardt chronicles the life of Ms. Steinem, who turned 80 last month, from her childhood in Toledo, Ohio, and the inspiration for her work, to her battle with breast cancer, her late-in-life marriage and subsequent widowhood. Barbara Walters, Helen Gurley Brown, Phil Donahue and Larry King weigh in.

title: This Weeks Movies: April 11, 2014
description: The New York Times film critics on Joe, Draft Day and Only Lovers Left Alive.

title: Beijing Court Upholds Legal Scholars Sentence
description: A Beijing court has upheld a four-year prison sentence for Xu Zhiyong, the legal scholar who inspired a campaign for civic participation and social justice in China. Mr. Xu was convicted in January of gathering a crowd to disturb public order, in connection with a series of small protests in 2012 and 2013 calling for government officials to disclose their assets.

title: Panda Transfer Falls Victim to Fallout Over Missing Plane
description: China is not shy about using panda diplomacy as a tool of soft power. It has a long tradition of bestowing nations with the bamboo-chomping mammals, most famously in the early 1970s, when Beijing sent two pandas to the National Zoo in Washington amid President Richard M. Nixons groundbreaking diplomatic opening to China.

title: In London, Museum Adds Fashion Conservation Space
description: LONDON  Scientific advances and technological innovations continue to change textile conservation, but most specialists say the craft still depends on three things: agile hands, good sight  and space.

title: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, April 11, 2014
description: Use the following question for practice or just for fun.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Colbert to Succeed Letterman on Late Show
description: In Colbert to Succeed Letterman on Late Show,  Bill Carter reports on CBSs announcement of the next host for its flagship late-night program.

title: When You Are Old Enough to Vote, Will You?
description: Young people, ages 18 to 24, are significantly less likely to vote than those over age 35. People who make more than $75,000 a year are much more likely to vote than those making less than $50,000. That means older and wealthier Americans have a greater say in who is running our government  especially during midterm elections like the ones coming up this year. Do you think voting is important? Is it a civic duty?

title: Look Again, With Love and Liebling
description: Jerome Lieblings lyrical vision of everyday life permeates a body of work that combines passionate idealism with sometimes brutal realism. It is a style shaped by a destitute childhood in Depression-era Brooklyn and forged by horrific firsthand experiences during many of the most violent battles of World War II.

title: New York Today: Their First 100 Days, Too
description: Good morning on this warm, cloudy Friday.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: Looking for America Beyond Its Borders
description: Academic politics are so vicious because the stakes are so small.

title: Sony Warns Some New Laptop Batteries May Catch Fire
description: HONG KONG  Sony on Friday warned of the potential for batteries to burn or catch fire in some of its new Vaio laptop computers and asked owners of the units in question to stop using them immediately.

title: Co-operative Bank Cancels Bonuses as It Posts Steep Loss
description: LONDON  The Co-operative Bank said on Friday that it would cancel 4.97 million pounds, or about $8.38 million, in bonuses for current and former executives and other employees as the British lender reported a 1.3 billion pretax annual loss.

title: Why No One Goes to Naples
description: NAPLES, Italy  Spring is here. In southern Italy, the sun is shining, the sky is blue and the weather is balmy. Orange blossom fragrances mingle with wafts of jasmine. The food is good, the wine is inexpensive, the locals are friendly and beauty is all around. But where are the tourists?

title: Daily Report: Security Flaw Could Extend to Digital Devices, Experts Say
description: When the Heartbleed bug was disclosed on Monday, the attention focused on the fallout for major Internet companies like Yahoo and Amazon. But security experts said the potential for harm could extend much further, to the guts of the Internet and the many devices that connect to it, Nicole Perlroth and Quentin Hardy report.

title: Prosecutor Targets Pistoriuss Claims of Safety Fears
description: Oscar Pistorius appeared flustered, agitated and tired at his murder trial on Friday, the third day of cross-examination by a relentless prosecutor who accused him of shooting his girlfriend in the head during an argument.

title: What Limiting the Employer Mandate Would Mean for Small Businesses
description: The Save American Workers Act of 2014, which seeks to limit the reach of the Affordable Care Acts employer mandate, has led a charmed life, for a bill. Most of its fellow legislation languishes in committee and never gets a public airing. But the Save American Workers Act was in and out of the House in a matter of months.

title: Alessandra Stanley: Even the Snobs Say Im Lucky
description: Alessandra Stanley, once a co-bureau chief for The Times in Moscow and a bureau chief in Rome, has been the chief television critic for The Times since 2003. In her columns, she interprets the latest prime-time obsessions, reality-TV guilty pleasures and major television news events, from debates to awards shows. She spoke with us about her approach to her work. Our conversation has been condensed and edited.

title: Raising a Moral Child
description: What does it take to be a good parent? We know some of the tricks for teaching kids to become high achievers. For example, research suggests that when parents praise effort rather than ability, children develop a stronger work ethic and become more motivated.

title: As Trading Hurts JPMorgan, Auto Loans Aid Wells Fargo
description: Updated, 9:11 p.m. | The contrasting fortunes of two of the nations biggest banks  JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo  at first glance point to the ascendancy of Main Street over Wall Street.

title: Are Iran and Israel Trading Places?
description: STANFORD, Calif.  Although the Israeli and Iranian governments have been virtually at war with each other for decades, the two countries have much in common.

title: Ukraine on the Brink
description: With Moscow bearing down, Kiev seeks an economic rescue.

title: U.S. Markets Quiet After Global Sell-Off
description: European stocks joined a global slide on Friday after a big drop in Tokyo that followed a sharp sell-off in Internet and biotechnology shares in the United States a day earlier.

title: 10 Ways to Teach and Learn About Spring (While The Learning Network Is on Vacation)
description: Like many school districts around the country, were taking next week off to celebrate Passover, Easter and the return of weather that no longer requires outfits like this.

title: In Our Pages: April 12
description: 1939: Service for Autograph Chasers

title: A Miss for JPMorgan
description: JPMORGAN EARNINGS FALL 18.5% | JPMorgan Chase reported an 18.5 percent slump in first-quarter earnings on Friday, as the nations largest bank grappled with dual challenges: sluggish revenue from trading and lackluster mortgage lending, Jessica Silver-Greenberg writes in DealBook. Both issues, broadly buffeting the banking industry, damped profits at JPMorgan.

title: Laemmles List: A Moguls Heroism
description: Among the pioneering moguls of Hollywood, Carl Laemmle, who commanded Universal Pictures for more than 20 years and who died 75 years ago, was not only less recognizable than the rest, he was also different from the rest. For one thing, he was older than the others and the first to emigrate from Europe to America. For another, he was less autocratic. Laemmle, an elfin man, was informal, unpretentious and cheery. Everyone, including his own son, called him Uncle Carl, and, according to one witness, he would roam the lot at Universal City with a pail in which he would urinate when he felt the urge. Most of the others made a point of declaiming their American-ness. Laemmle kept close ties to his native Germany  he visited Europe each year  and called the country his fatherland.

title: Unlocking Android With a Glance
description: Q. Is the face-recognition feature on the Nexus tablet safer than using a password to unlock the tablets screen?

title: Wells Fargo Posts Strong Earnings
description: Updated, 10:00 a.m. | Wells Fargos first-quarter results beat Wall Street expectations, as the bank posted stronger-than-expected profits, fueled by lower loan losses and decreasing expenses.

title: Total Taxes on Wages Are Rising
description: AFTER the financial crisis, many countries cut taxes to stimulate their economies. But since 2010, with concerns about government debt rising, the trend has gone the other way.

title: Italian Asset Manager Raises $961.5 Million in I.P.O.
description: LONDON  The Italian asset manager Anima said on Friday that it raised 692.5 million euros, or about $961.5 million, in an initial public offering.

title: Google Glass Available to Anyone in U.S.  for One Day Only
description: Google Glass! On sale! One day only! Just $1,500! Get em while theyre hot!

title: In an Instant, a Bus to College Was a Fiery Trap
description: LOS ANGELES  Harley Hoyt, an 18-year-old senior at Valhalla High School in San Diego County, was listening to his headphones to pass the time during the 12-hour bus ride up Californias Interstate 5 when he was catapulted forward, his face smashing against the seat in front of him.

title: They Died With the Camera On
description: The Hollywood combat films produced during World War II were almost entirely heroic and celebratory. No American died in vain; a better world could be glimpsed beyond the storm clouds. The combat movies made during and soon after the Korean War were scarcely so optimistic.

title: A Monstrous Wrong Undone in a Blaze of Pastoral Passion
description: LONDON  In the Bohemia scene in the Royal Ballets new full-length The Winters Tale, the very air feels abundantly fresh. The young lovers Perdita and Florizel, high on waves of mutual enchantment, dance both impetuously and experimentally, part of a community whose celebrations have an extraordinary folk vitality. Behind these two sweethearts is a vast greenwood tree laden with strange fruit harvested by the corps onstage, and the range of costumes suggests an eastern Mediterranean idyll, both contemporary and traditional. The music travels from a slow, exotic flute melody to tunes that trip with complex meters and orchestration of changing colors.

title: The Return of Expansionary Austerity
description: Here we go again. Theres now a full-court press of the usual suspects claiming that the recovery in the UK proves that fiscal austerity isnt contractionary after all, that the IMF had it all wrong, and so on.

title: Bayern Munich and Real Madrid to Meet in Champions League Semis
description: The two favorites to win the UEFA Champions League, Bayern Munich and Real Madrid, were matched against one another in the semifinals in a draw held Friday in Nyon, Switzerland.

title: Gone in 0.001 Seconds
description: For Brad Katsuyama, then a young equities trader at Royal Bank of Canada, a life-changing revelation about the stock market began in June 2007 with a mystery: Why, when he tried to buy stocks at the offered prices on his computer screen, did the offers instantly vanish and the prices pop higher?

title: Adding Insult to Gun Injuries, Police Often Handcuff Victims
description: Two days after he was shot, Andre Daly woke in a haze with a police officer standing by his hospital bed in Brooklyn.

title: One Baby, Five Nationalities
description: We opted not to find out our babys sex before he was born. The annoyance of not being able to shop for pink or blue clothes, leaving the baby room neutrally white and having have two separate naming discussions was far outweighed by what seemed to be the much more traditional way of doing things: We wanted, like virtually everyone in human history, to learn the gender at the same time we found out whether our baby was hairy and plump or gawky and bald, or whether it had its mothers toes or its fathers weak chin.

title: Big G.O.P. Donors Stir Senate Runs
description: Democrats in races that will help determine control of the Senate are rapidly burning through their campaign cash, whittling away their financial advantage over Republican opponents as they fend off attacks from conservative groups, according to figures released through Friday.

title: View From the Top
description: THE HARD THING ABOUT HARD THINGS Building a Business When There Are No Easy AnswersBy Ben Horowitz Harper Business/HarperCollins, $29.99.

title: The Bottom Line From Both Sides
description: The Wall Street-Main Street divide is not just for political slogans. Its also useful for categorizing literature.

title: Editors Choice
description: FAMILY LIFE,  by Akhil Sharma. (Norton, $23.95.) Sharmas novel, deeply unnerving and tender at the core, charts a young mans struggles to grow within a family shattered by tragedy and disoriented by its move from India.

title: Paperback Row
description: SON OF A GUN: A Memoir,  by Justin St. Germain. (Random House, $16.) In late 2001, St. Germains mother  a former Army paratrooper, the toughest woman Ive ever known  was shot and killed in Arizona, apparently by her fifth husband, a wrecked ex-cop. This tale of personal loss and grief drives St. Germains searing memoir, but its bigger story concerns the culture of guns, violence and manhood in the American West.

title: Leaning In Without Falling Over
description: Joan C. Williams has been a longtime laborer in the trenches of womens work. The founding director of the Center for WorkLife Law at the University of Californias Hastings College of the Law, she boldly attacked the male-dominated workplace in Unbending Gender and, with her co-author, Cynthia Thomas Calvert, provided a blueprint for increased labor flexibility in law firms in Solving the Part-Time Puzzle. Now, in collaboration with her daughter, Rachel Dempsey, Williams has turned to a different kind of book. Deftly combining sociological research with a more casual narrative style, What Works for Women at Work offers unabashedly straightforward advice in a how-to primer for ambitious women.

title: For All Its Worth
description: Most people are used to owing money to others, but few think about what money may owe us: an equitable society, a functioning political system, a peaceful economy that can stay off the exhausting roller coaster of financial booms and crashes.

title: The Banker, the Visitor, His Wife and Her Lover
description: Another month, another bright young star in the firmament of Indian writing.

title: Analyze That
description: The first half of Jean Hanff Korelitzs novel about a New York therapist is less than revelatory, although that turns out to be for excellent reason. Grace Reinhart Sachs, an affluent Upper East Side mother with a thriving couples practice, frets almost generically about such privileged concerns as how much to push her son to continue with his violin lessons. She offers loving descriptions of an ideal husband  a pediatric oncologist  who somehow never gels into either a recognizable type or an intriguingly unique character. The absence of key friends and family members feels underexplained.

title: Debt Trap
description: We cannot mortgage the material assets of our grandchildren without asking the loss also of their political and spiritual heritage. So said President Dwight Eisenhower in his 1961 farewell address.

title: Home Improvement
description: When my family moved to Accra, Ghana, in 1990 just as I was about to start high school, we landed in a country whose G.D.P. was less than one-quarter the size of Delawares, despite its plentiful deposits of gold and other precious minerals. A military dictator had ruled it for almost a dozen years. Poverty, hunger and disease stalked the countryside. It felt like a place cut off from the rest of the world. If we wanted to call my grandparents in Wisconsin or Addis Ababa, all five of us would squeeze into a phone booth at the post office. We didnt have a home phone, and the waiting list to get one was decades long.

title: Kamikaze Strategy
description: The mountain of Purgatory haunts the cover of Peter Mountfords arresting second novel, The Dismal Science. The image, which calls to mind the second volume of The Divine Comedy, leads the reader into the book, the stark path curling its way up toward Terrestrial Paradise, symbolized by one lonely but verdant tree.

title: How Banks Fail
description: Five years after the drama that began in 2008  the failure of one bank after another, the decline in the stock market and the freezing up of finance  we still cannot seem to agree about the causes of the crisis. There are some who like to pin all the blame on the corrupt business practices of Wall Street and the greed of bankers. Then there are those who think it was just one more example of the sort of irrational mass hysteria that gives rise to boom-and-bust cycles in financial markets. Still others focus on the inherent characteristics of banks that seem to make them especially vulnerable to investor panics  the fact, for example, that their loans and investments cannot be liquidated in a hurry, while depositors can withdraw their cash with the click of a mouse.

title: Statistically Speaking
description: In the dark days of the Great Depression, the economist Simon Kuznets set about calculating the total national income of the United States. It was a case of a demand creating its supply, the demand by Congress and citizens to understand the scale of the economic calamity the nation was then experiencing. The same demand for understanding helps explain the publics interest these days in what might otherwise seem to be dry, uninviting economic statistics. How secure is the recovery from the impact of the 2008 financial crisis? What good is a recovery that benefits only the wealthy minority? Do our children have any hope of seeing their living standards rise as ours did over the late 20th century  or is that dream of progress over?

title: Inside the List
description: Wilderness Adventure: The crime novelist Nevada Barr is a write-what-you-know success story  when she began her Anna Pigeon series, about a National Park Service ranger who frequently stumbles across dead bodies, Barr was herself working as a law enforcement ranger in the park system. I had a lot of time in the backcountry to think, she told The Times-Picayune of New Orleans in 2008. There were a couple of people in the park that needed killing, and I thought about how to get away with it. (Perhaps unsurprisingly, Barr quit that job once her books started to catch on.) How did Park Service employees respond to the series? Guardedly at first, to judge from a 1995 profile in National Parks magazine that cited Barrs perceived disregard for both the agency and the people who worked in the parks. I enjoy the stories, one employee acknowledged, but some of the cynicism about the Park Service makes me feel like Im at work. Things have gotten better since then: In 2011, the National Parks Conservation Association presented Barr with an award for enhancing public understanding of national parks and drawing attention to the invaluable work of National Park Service staff. The 18th Anna Pigeon mystery, Destroyer Angel, enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 8.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Money Issue
description: This week, Chris Hayes talks about Kevin Rooses Young Money; Parul Sehgal and John Williams discuss the book business; Timothy Noah on Matt Taibbis The Divide; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Money Issue
description: This week, Chris Hayes and Timothy Noah.

title: Highway Patrol on California Bus Crash
description: A California Highway Patrol spokeswoman, Lacey Heitman, gave updates following a deadly collision between a FedEx tractor-trailer and a chartered bus carrying high school students in Orland, Calif.

title: Book Review Podcast: The Money Issue
description: In The New York Times Book Reviews Money Issue, Chris Hayes reviews Kevin Rooses Young Money: Inside the Hidden World of Wall Streets Post-Crash Recruits. Mr. Hayes writes:

title: Detroit Wins Judges Nod for Contract Settlement
description: Updated, 7:38 p.m. | A federal judge on Friday approved this bankrupt citys latest attempt to extricate itself from some long-term financial contracts that have been costing it tens of millions of dollars a year, holding up its settlement as an example of the very spirit of negotiation and compromise that he hoped other creditors would follow.

title: Inside Baseball
description: Most views of a major-league baseball game are as traditional as the game itself, the cameramen sidelined in pens next to the dugouts. To see the game from some new angles, Mike Escamilla, a photographer and an athlete, went to the Los Angeles Dodgers spring-training camp in Glendale, Ariz., and mounted cameras to players bats, umpires chests, catchers face masks and even remote-controlled drones. Some players, who tend to be skittish and superstitious even by the standards of professional athletes, were reluctant to take part. Getting close to the players on the field was clearly not something photographers did, but after some slow introductions, a few players agreed to help us out, Escamilla says. Once we showed them the photos, they were like, Wow, this is rad.  Julie Bosman

title: Reply All: The 3.30.14 Issue
description: THE CHEF AT 15

title: What Kelis and Paul Newman Have in Common
description: In recent years, you studied to be a chef. You have a new show on the Cooking Channel called Saucy & Sweet, and your new album is called Food. How would you describe your philosophy on cooking? As much as my music is very much who I am, so is my cooking. Food has become such a way of life, sort of like what you listen to, who youre with, what youre wearing. My character comes through in my cooking.

title: Can I Spy?
description: Is it unethical to infiltrate a group, through employment or other means, to learn more about them in order to expose what they do if you dont agree with their stated aims? The F.B.I., for example, has undercover agents who pretend to be drug dealers. Recently, it has become illegal in some states for animal rights activists to pretend to be prospective employees at livestock farms and slaughterhouses because some were secretly videotaping the conditions. When is it ethical to pretend to be someone youre not to learn information that could be beneficial to society? TIM DE VALROGER, HOBOKEN, N.J.

title: Breakfast of Champions
description: Plus: Alicia Silverstones son is clueless about Clueless, and Judge John Hodgman rules on Game of Thrones spoilers.

title: Spice of Life
description: Each time my husband, Ismail, returns from visiting relatives in Libya, his suitcase is lined with yellow powder in plastic baggies: the spice mix of his mother, Hajja. As a child, he watched her fill an iron pan with desiccated cloves, fenugreek seeds, withered black peppercorns, cinnamon bark, gnarled turmeric and ginger roots. Using a palm brush over an open fire, she swept the pan with one hand and drew the aroma in with the other. Her nose told her when her spices were ready. She once ground them herself, but now she takes her roasted spices to the mill.

title: Who Made That Contact Lens?
description: In 1887, a German doctor named Theodor Samisch saw a patient whose lower eyelid had been destroyed by carcinoma, leaving his cornea exposed and desiccated and his lashes curling inward. To preserve the patients vision, Samisch contracted with two brothers who specialized in artificial eyes. They made a protective shell of handblown glass, transparent in the middle and opaque around the edge, with reddish threads for blood vessels. I have worn the glass supplied by you continuously, day and night, the patient wrote the brothers 21 years later, and my eye has always felt very well with it.

title: Elementary School Concert Draws Billy Joel
description: It is not unheard of for composers to turn up at concerts of their music, at least in the classical music world. When the composer is a rock star, the likelihood of an appearance drops considerably, and when the concert is at 9:30 a.m., and the performers are kindergarten through second-grade students, well, the odds drop to near zero.

title: French Bath and Beauty Goods With an Old-World Touch
description: In 1803, the perfumer Jean-Vincent Bully established a distillery on Rue Saint-Honor in Paris. His signature scented skincare vinegars went on to become the toast of 19th-century Europe, and he even inspired the character ofCsar Birotteau, the titular hero of Balzacs novel. Now, his legacy is being revisited by Ramdane Touhami, a former co-owner of Cire Trudon, the French luxury candle manufacturer. LOfficine Universelle Buly, as the line has been re-christened, embodies the originals Old-World elegance and emphasis on natural ingredients. The range of exquisitely packaged, paraben-free products  perfumes, oils, creams, marble-encased candles, scented matches  can be found in the brands new Saint-Germain-des-Prs apothecary alongside accouterments like sponges, combs and crystals sourced from Morocco.

title: Above the Brooklyn Heights Promenade
description: A perfectly positioned and expertly renovated historic townhouse perched high above the Brooklyn Heights Promenade with idyllic views of the Manhattan skyline, the Brooklyn Bridge, the Statue of Liberty and beyond, is about to enter the market at $16 million.

title: In France, a Move to Limit Off-the-Clock Work Emails
description: PARIS  Given Frances 35-hour workweek, generous vacations and persistent, if not altogether accurate, reputation for indolence, it may come as a surprise that the French are only now considering limits on the work emails and phone calls that come at all hours of the day and night.

title: Incendiary Words in Campaigns Draw Ban on Rallies for Two Politicians
description: Updated, 12:50 a.m. | NEW DELHI The Election Commission of India has banned two politicians, Amit Shah of the Bharatiya Janata Party and Azam Khan of the Samajwadi Party, from holding rallies in the state of Uttar Pradesh for their highly inflammatory speeches, the news channel NDTV reported late Friday.

title: Today in Small Business: Paying Employees to Quit
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Obama Names Health Pick, Veteran of Fiscal Battles
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Friday that he was nominating his budget director, Sylvia Mathews Burwell, to lead the Department of Health and Human Services, as the administration tries to move beyond its early stumbles in carrying out Mr. Obamas health law.

title: They Thought Their Son Was Bipolar. They Were Wrong.
description: Desperate parents search for a doctor who can explain why their son goes out of control.

title: New York Boomers on Hipster Turf
description: Lenore Berner, born at the very tail end of the baby boom generation, turned 50 in February. (Her husband, Dan, had hit the half-century mark the previous year.) A few weeks later, the Berners moved from a two-bedroom apartment in Park Slope, Brooklyn, which they were renting for $4,500 a month, to a 39th-floor waterfront rental in Long Island City, Queens  the price tag a more modest $3,850.

title: Class Action Complaint Against the N.H.L.
description: The complaint by nine retired players said the N.H.L. failed to take adequate steps to warn the players of the dangers of the sport and deliberately promoted violence for profit.

title: A Chance for a Markets Wallflowers to Bloom
description: In January, Seth Klarman, a billionaire who runs the Boston-based Baupost Group investment partnership, warned in his annual letter to clients that a skeptic would have to be blind not to see bubbles inflating and cited the nosebleed stock market valuations of companies like Netflix and Tesla Motors.

title: The Aesthetes | Expats in Tangier
description: A group of eccentric expats living in Tangier open their extraordinary homes and share what lured them to the city and kept them hooked.

title: A Dutchmans Opinion: Henk Ovink Weighs in on Post-Sandy Proposals
description: Following my profile of Henk Ovink and his work to bring Dutch water-management ideas to bear in the Northeastern United States, I asked Henk to briefly describe each of the 10 proposals that the Hurricane Sandy Rebuilding Task Force has highlighted for possible implementation. Each was spearheaded by a multidisciplinary team in conjunction with local community groups. The next step in the process will see Shaun Donovan, the H.U.D. secretary and chairman of the task force, make a final selection from these visionary approaches.

title: A Creative Approach to Adjusting to Life in China
description: My company, iPai, doesnt offer bonuses for being stationed overseas to any of our executives.

title: Your Street Style: Dressed for Spring in Winter
description: Readers showed us how they stylishly tried to usher in spring weather through their clothes.

title: Customers Can Lose When Banks Shuffle Payments
description: THE proverbial $35 cup of coffee that can result from overspending a bank account hasnt disappeared yet.

title: Turkish Court Overturns Part of Law on Judiciary, Loosening Governments Grip
description: ISTANBUL  Turkeys highest court on Friday overturned the provision of a new law that gave the government of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan greater control over the judiciary, a law that critics said harmed the countrys separation of powers and was part of a broader effort on the part of Mr. Erdogan to push back against a corruption investigation.

title: Floyd Cardoz Exits North End Grill
description: Floyd Cardoz, the executive chef at North End Grill in Battery Park City, said Friday that he was leaving the restaurant and its parent company, the Union Square Hospitality Group, where he has worked for nearly 17 years for the restaurateur Danny Meyer.

title: Muslim, Gay, and Making No Apologies
description: PARIS  HE was born inside the public library of Rabat in Morocco where his dad worked as a janitor and where his family lived until he was 2. For most of his childhood, he hid his sexuality as best he could, but his effeminate demeanor brought mockery and abuse, even as it would later become a source of artistic inspiration.

title: Witchcraft on the West Side
description: Dear Diary:

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Facts & Figures: The Death of the Mall
description: Malls have been closing their doors, and teenagers are to blame.

title: Times Minute | Next Steps After Sebelius
description: The White House correspondent Michael D. Shear on whats next for the Obama administration with Kathleen Sebelius, the health and human services secretary, ending her five-year tenure.

title: Times Minute | Next Steps After Sebelius
description: In the Video

title: In Las Vegas, Shopping Souk-Style
description: Grand Bazaar Shops, a collection of more than a 150 stores, is scheduled to open this fall in Las Vegas.

title: Ukrainian Prime Minister Visits Donetsk
description: Ukraines acting prime minister, Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk, said if protesters occupying a government building leave peacefully that they wont be arrested.

title: Pro-Russia Ukrainians Are Promised More Power, but Remain Dubious
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  Ukraines acting prime minister on Friday abandoned threats to forcibly evict pro-Russian demonstrators from government buildings, and assured political and business leaders in the countrys rebellious east that they would get more power to run their own affairs.

title: Wheelies: The Moab Jeeps Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Childhood Dreams Can Inspire Rewarding Second Careers
description: EVER since Sandra Colony was a child, when she was spellbound by the glossy photographs of exotic places in the pages of National Geographic, she has been driven by the desire to explore the world.

title: News Alert: The News Alert Is Changing
description: Ian Fisher is an assistant managing editor at The Times. Since coming to the paper in 1990, he has served as bureau chief in Rome, deputy editor on the foreign desk and the day editor on the home page.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: Ryan McDonagh, Rising Star for Rangers, Sweeps Team Honors
description: Defenseman Ryan McDonaghs breakthrough season was capped with two laurels Friday, as his teammates and reporters covering the Rangers awarded him the teams top honors.

title: Im 52, but I Identify as Heidi Klum
description: I cannot tell you how delighted I was to read that Facebook is now offering a greatly increased range of user ID labels.

title: An Addict With Friends
description: The night the police came for Robert Aaron, he was at home in the Mott Street apartment where he has lived for the last quarter century, making a coconut pudding called tembleque. Mr. Aaron, whose legal name is Robert Aaron Vineberg, is a 57-year-old musician who has played with David Bowie, Wyclef Jean, Mick Jagger and Amy Winehouse, among others, a genial man with a pencil-thin mustache and a grasp of half a dozen languages. He is also a heroin addict who has sometimes sold the drug. On this night, Mr. Aaron said, his visitors did not ring the bell.

title: Mike Daisey Will Present Dreaming of Rob Ford Onstage in Toronto Festival
description: When the directors of Crows Theater in Toronto invited the monologist Mike Daisey to create a show for the East End Performance CRAWL, the companys new festival of site-specific solo shows, he settled on an idea quickly and perhaps inevitably,given the festivals nature and location, and his own passion for topicality. The world premiere of Dreaming of Rob Ford, Mr. Daiseys meditation on the exploits of Torontos mayor, will open the festival, which runs from May 21 to June 1.

title: Great Grain Salads
description: For the next few weeks youll be hearing a lot from me about a conference I attended in March at the Culinary Institute of America in Napa Valley. Called Healthy Kitchens, Healthy Lives, this conference, presented by the Culinary Institute of America, the Harvard School of Public Health and the Samueli Institute, brings together medical professionals with chefs and nutrition researchers to explore food and its relationship to health. Now in its 10th year, the conference has inspired hospitals to install teaching kitchens. Surgeons whose knowledge of knives had been limited to the scalpel have learned to wield a chefs knife as they participate in kitchen workshops run by chefs from the Culinary Institute and chefs presenting at the conference.

title: Irish Republican Ordered Held Without Bail in 1998 Bombing Case
description: DUBLIN  A dissident Irish Republican charged with 29 counts of murder in the 1998 car bombing in Omagh, Northern Ireland, was ordered held without bail on Friday.

title: The Aesthetes
description: For the legendary expats of Tangier, a life devoted to beauty reaches full flower in this North African hothouse of history and hedonism.

title: For Afghan Journalists, Election Brings a Sense of National Duty
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  As the raucous news outlets of Afghanistan  and there are hundreds of them  have come into their own in recent years, they have taken to criticizing government officials and institutions with an enthusiasm that borders on glee. And despite attempts by the powerful to rein in reporters, much of the news media has thrived with an occasionally adversarial approach.

title: Kentucky Students Catch Breath to Cheer a Derby Hopeful
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.  The University of Kentucky is renowned for its eight mens basketball national championships and its three Final Four appearances in the last four years. But the university now finds itself in the unfamiliar, and unlikely, position of having fostered a Kentucky Derby prospect.

title: Alibaba to Acquire Chinese Mapping Firm as Buying Spree Continues
description: The Alibaba Group, a Chinese e-commerce juggernaut, will buy the portion of the mapping and navigation company AutoNavi Holdings that it does not already own, the latest move in an acquisition spree before Alibabas expected stock listing in the United States.

title: Image of the Day: April 11
Popes Request for Abuse Victims to Forgive Church Draws Calls for Action
description: Pope Francis said in remarks broadcast on Friday that he was personally asking for forgiveness for the damage that priests have done in the sexual abuse of children.

title: In Sydney, Lively Culture Amid Natural Beauty
description: The late, great Australian art critic Robert Hughes once complained that Crocodile Dundee is still regarded by many Americans as a work of social realism. A rhetorical exaggeration, of course, but he had a point. As an Australian living in New York, Ive long been puzzled at the dominance of charming clichs about the country as a sun-dappled frontier. Advertising campaigns still promote the ocker image  Australian for redneck  depicting beer-swilling, happy-go-lucky folk barbecuing steak at the beach.

title: Wounded by the Language of War
description: When did the language we use to talk about death start to resemble a Pentagon briefing, full of military references and combat analogies?

title: Pink Dolphins and Sunsets Along the Amazon
description: Sitting on the deck of a small cruise ship called the Aqua, I listened to the never-ending sounds of the Amazonian rain forest. Beside me was a retired executive, a fellow passenger whom I had just met the day before. As the sinking sun bled into the darkening sky and the riverbanks along this tributary of the Peruvian Amazon turned from green to black, he told me of his days in Lagos in the 70s and Dubai in the 90s, then lapsed into silence. The moment was all the sweeter because we were playing hooky from an outing to view nocturnal birds, opting for perfectly chilled white wine over mosquitoes.

title: Video Reviews of Joe, Draft Day and Only Lovers Left Alive
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on the Texas thriller Joe, the sports film Draft Day and the vampire drama Only Lovers Left Alive. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Israeli Military Takes Over Seminary in West Bank Settlement
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli military on Friday took over a seminary known for extremism in the Jewish settlement of Yitzhar in the West Bank, moving in a company of border police troops after radical settlers clashed with soldiers and destroyed army property there over the last week.

title: Obama Nominates Chairman for Humanities Endowment
description: William Adams has led liberal arts programs and institutions for most of his career, slowly training for an opportunity that finally came on Thursday, when President Obama nominated him to be chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities.

title: Rizzoli Bookstore May Be Better Off Elsewhere
description: On Wednesday afternoon, two days before its scheduled closing, Rizzoli Bookstore was crowded with the sort of people who, never especially populous in Midtown Manhattan, appear even more like icicles in the desert: gray-haired women with Mohawks or turbans, students, men with indifferent facial grooming, older citizens. Some of them did not know that the building, which has housed the bookstore on West 57th Street for the past 29 years, was slated to be demolished, along with two adjoining buildings. When they were told by a salesperson they expressed the requisite shock and lament.

title: The Fading Honor Code
description: The campus tour for prospective Middlebury students stops in a corridor outside a much-frequented eatery at the student center. Here, the guide directs their attention to a glass case exhibiting signatures of every freshman who has signed the honor code, a pledge made during orientation. To high school students fresh out of the SAT and A.P. grind, these signatures suggest that the competition for high scores is over; learning would now be fuller and more meaningful. Lowering their gaze, however, they might notice three trash bins lined up under the display. This juxtaposition looks to be a fitting metaphor for Middleburys attitude toward its honor code.

title: Fast Cash: Work a Reunion
description: One sign of spring: older folks whizzing around campus in golf carts. Reunion season kicks in on the heels of commencement (and again at homecoming), and somebody has to drive those carts, give directions and tend bar  with an assist from a laminated sheet of cocktail recipes.

title: Pomp From the Past
description: Its almost over. The first spring graduates will be walking next week. We share inspiration from commencements of the last half-century.

title: Steven Pinkers Mind Games
description: The Harvard professor culled exam questions from his course Psychological Science. Test your knowledge.

title: What Makes a Positive College Experience?
description: After a decade of research, Daniel F. Chambliss, an organizational sociologist at Hamilton College, believes he knows what most determines how students feel about their time at college. It comes down to factors like dorm design, friends and extracurricular involvement more than what happens in the classroom. In their new book, How College Works, Dr. Chambliss and Christopher G. Takacs describe the findings from an ambitious study of Hamilton students and alumni, using interviews, surveys and even an analysis of academic writing samples to tease out how college has affected them. Although Hamilton, a small, selective, expensive liberal arts college in upstate New York, has little in common with the large state universities and community colleges that most students attend, Dr. Chambliss said the lessons learned could apply everywhere.

title: Ivy League Ups and (Yes) Downs
description: Its not really a popularity contest, but among the Ivies, is anything not competitive? Applications to the University of Pennsylvania rose by more than 14 percent this year and fell by as much at Dartmouth.

title: Because Ze Said So
description: Gender-neutral terms are catching on at more liberal campuses. Here, an essential glossary:

title: Models With Doctorates
description: The old joke about the value of higher education  What do you call a Ph.D. in philosophy? Oh, waitress!  is getting a new punch line courtesy of Betabrand, based in San Francisco. The clothier has asked women who are Ph.D.s or doctoral candidates to model smart new spring fashions (get it?). So far, 120 have applied and 30 are being featured, said Chris Lindland, the chief executive.

title: Who Advises Best, Pros or Profs?
description: Academic advising has always been one of those intractable problems on college campuses. Students rarely think about it until that frantic moment when they need someone to sign the registration form for next semesters classes.

title: The Power Broker of N.Y.U.
description: Martin Lipton, chairman of the board of New York University, recently took a trustee to lunch at San Pietro, a pricey Manhattan restaurant frequented by the citys C.E.O.s. Over a meal that lasted several hours, they discussed Mr. Liptons plans to step down next year, after 16 years at the helm. Marty wants his own replacement there a year in advance, recalled Evan R. Chesler, chairman of Cravath, Swaine & Moore, a leading New York law firm. The reason, he said: The new chairman would be responsible for the process that selects the president who will replace John Sexton.

title: Who Am I?
description: Creative self-portraits by student photographers.

title: Happenings | A New York Pirate Radio Station for the Art Underground Takes Texas
description: Since 2012, the artist, gallerist and publisher Aaron Bondaroff (known to some as the Downtown Don) and Al Moran, his partner in the Los Angeles gallery Ohwow, have been broadcasting Know-Wave, an online radio station that provides a platform for the members of the downtown and L.A. art communities to express themselves, promote their work and interact with each other. Its a free-form affair: hosts go on-air whenever they want and play whatever they like, be it French gangster rap, underground hip-hop or noise-rock bands youve never heard of. Occasionally, they bring in art world personalities for interviews. (Past guests have included Chan Marshall, Rodarte, Dan Colen, Glenn OBrien and Mykki Blanco.)

title: Movie Review: Only Lovers Left Alive
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Only Lovers Left Alive.

title: Movie Review: Joe
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews Joe.

title: An Uproar Over a Diabetes Article, With a Back Story
description: Many Times readers, some of whom have Type 1 diabetes, are upset over an article last Sunday in which Elisabeth Rosenthal explored the often extraordinary expense of treating the disease. It was an installment in her series, Paying Till It Hurts, about the high cost of medical care in America.

title: Can a Pop-Up Service Fix It? Probably
description: Last Sunday, Adam Sobel approached the Pop Up Repair table at the Greenmarket next to Columbia University, cradling his black espresso machine. A couple of months ago, the steamer wand had started leaking slightly, and Mr. Sobel, a Columbia professor who teaches applied math and earth science, decided to take matters into his own hands. He consulted online instructions and ordered new parts, but found it difficult to properly screw them into the appliances hard-to-reach interior nooks and crannies. After his efforts, the machine leaked everywhere.

title: Movie Review: Draft Day
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Draft Day.

title: Tough Tests Looming in 2016 Raise Stakes for G.O.P. in Midterm Elections
description: WASHINGTON  To understand the Republican imperative to capture the Senate in the midterm elections, look toward 2016, when a narrow victory this year could well be swept away.

title: Round and Round They Go
description: Gifts for bicyclists.

title: Diplomat Who Led Secret Talks With Iran Plans to Retire
description: WASHINGTON  William J. Burns, a career diplomat who led the Obama administrations back-channel negotiations with Iran, plans to step down as the State Departments second-ranking official in October, administration officials said on Friday.

title: The Gender Wage Gap, by State
description: On Wednesday Senate Republicans blocked consideration of the Paycheck Fairness Act, which would help narrow the persistent wage gap between men and women. A dissection of that vote reveals an even bigger betrayal of womens economic interests than immediately apparent.

title: There Goes Tokyo, Stomp by Stomp
description: Sad and stately are probably not the words that come to mind when you think of Godzilla. But the Japanese original, restored for its 60th anniversary and playing at Film Forum beginning Friday, should make you think again. The American version, Godzilla: King of the Monsters!, released in 1956, was chopped up (40 minutes were cut), rearranged, dubbed and fitted out with new footage with Raymond Burr. The original, a disaster movie and cautionary tale, feels like a different animal, or monster, altogether.

title: The Great Moderation Is Back
description: Perhaps you remember the Great Moderation, the comforting term economists pinned on the period of relatively steady growth that began in the early 1980s.

title: After the Squall, Chop Remains for JPMorgan Chase
description: JPMorgan Chases clean sheet already looks off-white. For the first time in years, its quarterly earnings werent cluttered with special items like big trading losses or legal costs. The banks $5.3 billion profit in the three months ended in March fell short of expectations anyway.

title: Sebelius and Burwell on New Health Roles
description: President Obama, the secretary of Health and Human Services, Kathleen Sebelius, right, and the nominee to succeed her, Sylvia Mathews Burwell, discussed the new administration changes.

title: For Falcone, No Joy in the Sale of Manischewitz
description: At Seder tables next week, many Passover celebrants will nosh on matzo and gefilte fish made by the Manischewitz Company.

title: Marcelo Gomes as Romeo
description: American Ballet Theatres production of Kenneth MacMillans Romeo and Juliet. Video courtesy of American Ballet Theater

title: Brooklyn Dance Parties Coming to Waterfront Park
description: As a prelude to Celebrate Brooklyn!, the free summer performing arts festival at Prospect Park, the festivals producer, BRIC, is presenting three dance parties, also free, at Brooklyn Bridge Park. The parties, at Pier 1 on consecutive Thursday evenings (May 8, 15 and 22, at 7 p.m.), will include performances by bands that draw on popular and folk styles from around the globe, as well as D.J. sets and dance lessons.

title: Appeals Court Overturns Conviction of AT&T Hacker Known as Weev
description: A federal appeals court on Friday reversed the conviction of Andrew Weev Auernheimer, a hacker and self-described Internet troll, who was accused of stealing the personal data of 114,000 Apple iPad users in 2010.

title: Iran Secretly Convicted Former Marine, Lawyer Says
description: TEHRAN  Amir Hekmati, a former Marine incarcerated here in August 2011 and sentenced to death on espionage charges that were overturned, was secretly retried by a revolutionary court in December, convicted of practical collaboration with the American government and given a 10-year prison term, his new lawyer said this week.

title: Stars of Their Own Screenplay
description: Four years ago, Daniel Grossman was convinced that his fellow New Yorkers Sofia Alvarez, a playwright and screenwriter, and Adam Squires, a graphic designer, would hit it off. They just needed a nudge, or two or three, that he would be only too happy to provide.

title: Asparagus, Spanish-Style
description: Once, while traveling in Andalusia, I experienced asparagus Spanish-style.

title: Marcelo Gomes, the Dancer at Home in Hells Kitchen
description: Not long after Marcelo Gomes moved with his dachshund, Lua, into a subcompact (475 square feet) condo in Hells Kitchen two and a half years ago, he gave a housewarming party. And as he had done on other break-out-the-champagne occasions, such as his 30th birthday, the Brazilian-born Mr. Gomes, 34, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, gave the guests a gift-buying directive. In this particular instance they were asked to show up with a blue or white vase.

title: Sweet Tale of Friendship (Sex, Too)
description: Ask John Turturro about his newest project, Fading Gigolo, and he will excitedly tell you about the streetwalker films, like The Life of Oharu or Midnight Cowboy, that helped inspire the idea; the Isaac Bashevis Singer short stories that helped him settle on a tone for the script; and the filmmakers, like Michael Cimino, Spike Lee and the Coen brothers, who helped him develop his own directorial style.

title: A Filmmakers Progressive Pathway
description: For nearly 50 years, Marco Bellocchio has been one of the cinemas great poets of rebellion and escape  from family, from the Italian bourgeoisie and from the conformism and hypocrisy they represent. His most recent film, Dormant Beauty, plays a variation on this theme: Opportunistic politicians try to keep an accident victim from being taken off life support, preventing her from escaping a 17-year coma.

title: Big Ticket | A Home in the Sky for $30.5 Million
description: A three-bedroom unit on the 60th floor of One57, the Extell Development Companys 90-story spike of bluish glass that does not scrape the Midtown sky as much as puncture it, sold for $30,551,000 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Pay the Babysitter Over $1,900 This Year? You Owe It to Her to Put Her On the Books
description: If you pay a babysitter more than $1,900 in a calendar year, youre classified as a household employer. That means you have the responsibility to administer the payroll and tax process for your babysitter. We dont have a full-time babysitter, but it doesnt take anything close to a full time schedule to hit $1,900. At $20 an hour, a parent owes taxes at 95 hours, or less than 2 hours a week.

title: A Freewheeling Pursuit of Spontaneity on Film
description: Many a director has stumbled while chasing after a sense of spontaneity through improvisation. But in a few short years, the Brooklyn filmmaker Nathan Silver, 30, has already made lively attempts at capturing the flickering, uncertain energies among people in a room  pushing boundaries or just sharing space  with his freely made yet nuanced movies. Stumbles and messes along the way are only part of the action, and part of what make up his garrulous, willful characters.

title: A Mayor of Sorts Meets His Public
description: Harvey Fierstein had just finished watching a preview on Wednesday night of his new play, Casa Valentina, when he tried, without much success, to make his way to the exit.

title: Hasidim See Things Through a New Lens
description: FailedMessiah.com, the muckraking blog written by the once-Hasidic Jew Shmarya Rosenberg, is best known (and, in some quarters, loathed) for posts exposing crimes suspected of being perpetrated by Hasidic and other highly observant Jews.

title: Weekend Reading: The Other Michael Lewis Backlash
description: When Michael Lewis rolled out his new book with an appearance on the CBS show 60 Minutes and an excerpt in The New York Times magazine, the author was praised by literary critics and panned by high-frequency traders.

title: Last Night to Bend the Rules
description: Dina Litovsky has been photographing bachelorette parties, where brides-to-be confront the tricky rituals of the last night of single life.

title: Corvette Number Eight Pulled From National Corvette Museum Sinkhole
description: The chasm that opened beneath the National Corvette Museum in Bowling Green, Ky., in February  swallowing eight of its prized cars  has at last been emptied of all of its valuable contents. A few of the cars pulled from the sinkhole were in decent condition and others were in worse, albeit salvageable shape.

title: The Gun Report: April 11, 2014
description: On the morning of January 30, Shawn Harrington, a 38-year-old assistant basketball coach at a high school in Chicago, was stopped at a red light in the Humboldt Park neighborhood when two men opened fire on his car. Harrington shielded his 15-year-old daughter, whom he was driving to school, and was hit by two bullets, one of which passed through his upper back and cracked his vertebrae, leaving him paralyzed from the waist down. Another bullet lodged in the headrest of the seat in which his daughter was sitting.

title: Syrias Lost Generation
description: SOMETHING about the boy was not right. He seemed disoriented, detached from his surroundings. He barely spoke, and when he did, it was in flat monosyllables, his eyes unfocused and downcast, as if too heavy to roll up from the weight of all they had seen. He was the picture of quiet devastation, of a childhood forever splintered.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 62
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Quinoa Salad for a Crowd
description: Melissa Clark makes a quinoa salad with soft roasted carrots and crunchy fried leeks that can serve as a side course or a main dish.

title: Give Your Heart to Quinoa
description: It took me a while to give my heart to quinoa.

title: Kathleen Sebelius Was Too Cool and Too Patient
description: Kathleen Sebelius was known for her patience and cool under savage attack by Republicans, who treated her as a stand-in for the health law. She sat through hearings calmly reciting talking points while they fumed and fulminated for their audience.

title: Police Clash With Squatters in Rio de Janeiro Slum
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Violent clashes broke out on Friday between police officers and squatters here when the authorities dislodged thousands of families from a newly formed favela, or slum, in a complex of abandoned commercial buildings, focusing attention on the rising tension over surging rents and housing shortages.

title: Review: 2014 Nissan Rogue SV
description: Nissan brings a new Rogue to the compact crossover wars.

title: G.M. Documents Reveal Years of Talks on Defect
description: Last month, Mary T. Barra, the new chief executive of General Motors, told a panel of stern and dubious House members that she first became aware of a serious safety issue with the Chevrolet Cobalt in December, two months before the company announced a recall that would eventually cover 2.6 million cars.

title: When Cars Ruled the Worlds Fair
description: From its humble origins as a Queens garbage dump  inspiration for the valley of ashes in The Great Gatsby  Flushing Meadows Corona Park emerged as the site of two worlds fairs, in 1939-40 and 1964-65.

title: 1964 Worlds Fairs View of the Future
description: The Worlds Fair in New York promised visitors a glance into the future of automobiles. Automakers like General Motors, Ford and Chrysler put on elaborate displays of their predictions.

title: Adapting to a New Environment
description: For those of the mammalian persuasion, evolution has tended to be a leisurely process. This has not been the case among compact crossover utility vehicles, which in the last half-dozen years have made leaps in sophistication while adapting to a changing high-tech environment.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, India, Spain and Italy.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: On the Market in the Region
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: The Sixth Stage of Grief: Buying a Puppy
description: Last fall, I received a puppy for my birthday. The gift, from my wife, Cynthia, was welcome, even if it came around 50 years too late.

title: Texas Monthly Sues Times Co. Over New Hire
description: The publisher of Texas Monthly filed a lawsuit on Friday against The New York Times Company related to The Timess hiring of the magazines departing editor in chief, Jake Silverstein.

title: California School Officials on Bus Crash
description: Earl Perkins and Tom Waldman of the Los Angeles Unified School District discussed the steps the district will take following the bus crash.

title: He Tells the Clintons How to Lose a Little
description: Nine years ago, on their 30th wedding anniversary, Hillary Rodham Clinton gave her husband a gift she hoped would ensure many more years together: Dr. Mark Hyman.

title: The Mellon Lifestyle as a Brand
description: Its a good story. Do you want me to start, love? Nicole Hanley Mellon asked her husband, Matthew Mellon, on a recent Friday. The couple were seated in the living room of their apartment in the Pierre hotel, telling how they met in 2006 at a wedding in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: He Walked by Night
description: New York at night is a Rorschach blot: What you see depends on your state of mind. Maybe that street scene in front of you looks like La Dolce Vita; maybe its Taxi Driver.

title: U.S. Says Irans Pick for U.N. Envoy Wont Get a Visa
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Friday said it would bar an Iranian diplomat nominated as United Nations ambassador from entering the country, in a rebuke to Iran at a time when the United States is engaged in delicate negotiations with Tehran over its nuclear program.

title: Kanye Teams Up With Adidas, John Galliano and Oscar De la Renta Break Up and The Met Announces Its Gala Theme
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: A Caribbean Resort Goes Solar
description: Blessed by year-round tropical sunshine, the Caribbean seems like a natural candidate for solar power.

title: Bill Cunningham | Coats Off
description: Bill Cunningham reporting on the first truly spring week in New York City.

title: Belafonte Settles Dispute Over Martin Luther King Documents
description: Harry Belafonte and the family of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. have settled their differences over the ownership of documents that Mr. Belafonte said had been given to him by Dr. King; his widow, Coretta Scott King; and a close aide, Stanley Levison. According to a joint statement by Jonathan S. Abady, Mr. Belafontes lawyer, and Michael W. Tyler, the lawyer for Dr. Kings estate, the parties have reached a compromise, the terms of which are confidential and have resulted in Mr. Belafonte retaining possession of the documents.

title: Tips to Manage Spending in Retirement
description: ADVISERS put a considerable amount of effort into talking to clients about accumulating a life savings. But advisers and their clients tend to devote less thought to how to spend that money when its time.

title: Offshore and Underground
description: I had lunch with Gabriel Zucman today, co-author of the startling new paper (pdf) showing that the concentration of wealth at the very top  the 0.1%  is fully back to Gilded Age levels.And he pointed me to another paper that flew under my, and I suspect other peoples, radar: his demonstration that a lot of wealth at the top is held in offshore tax havens (pdf).

title: Bill Cunningham | Coats Off
description: Hunt and Gather Finally, spring arrived, in a galvanized bucket of tulips at Union Square and planters full of tulips, daffodils and hyacinth. People stripped off coats for a first peek at spring fashion. And Saturdays Tartan Day Parade, the citys shortest (10 blocks, 20 minutes), was alive with tartans, bagpipes and Scotties. Faberg held an egg hunt: 250 artist-designed eggs placed across the city to be auctioned on April 22 as a benefit for Studio in a School, an arts education group, and the Elephant Family, a global conservation organization.

title: Tap Universe Shrugs Off Any Notion of Borders
description: If you had to define tap dancing, Rhythm in Motion would be a difficult place to start. This celebration of (mostly) new tap choreography, presented by the American Tap Dance Foundation, shows that despite the common denominator of percussive feet, tap today defies easy categorization. Program B, seen on Thursday at the Theater at the 14th Street Y, exhibited the many functions of the form: tap as pure music, as political statement, as nonverbal narrative.

title: Comedians in Two Realms
description: These days, TV stars routinely do making-of videos while their hit shows are still on the air. Their predecessors didnt have that luxury, but their recollections are being captured by programs like PBSs Pioneers of Television, which begins a new season on Tuesday (check local listings) with a particularly entertaining episode, Standup to Sitcom. The episode includes Jerry Seinfeld, Roseanne Barr, Tim Allen and Bob Newhart, who describe how their sitcoms came about and how they made the transition from doing stand-up to acting on TV. These stars made it look easy, but its a challenge. The difference between the stand-up and the sitcom is youre going from the least collaborative medium there is to the most collaborative, Mr. Seinfeld says. The reason you become a comedian is youre not a good collaborator, youre not good with people, youre not good in social situations or professional situations.

title: Global Groove and a Throwback
description: Born in the Democratic Republic of Congo and raised in Belgium, the rapper and singer Baloji makes chameleonic African music. His most recent album, Kinshasa Succursale, revisited Congolese music past and present. But he also draws on grooves worldwide. His songs and rhymes (largely in French) address political and cultural matters with multilayered wordplay and unmistakable conviction, even as the party continues. (7:30 p.m. Thursday, Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts, Pace University, 3 Spruce Street, Lower Manhattan; 212-346-1715.)

title: Madness and Movement
description: Having a theater to call your own  on the Upper West Side, no less  is practically unheard-of for a choreographer in New York. The rare exception is David Parker, whose company, the Bang Group, has been at the West End Theater for more than a decade. Mr. Parker is generous with the real estate, opening the space to Soaking WET, an eclectic dance series.

title: Enticing Choices in One Afternoon
description: The brilliant British pianist Stephen Hough plays an adventurous program on Sunday at Alice Tully Hall. Liszts visionary Piano Sonata and Brahmss Fantasies (Op. 116) are the best-known works he will play. But how often do you get to hear piano pieces by Wagner and Bruckner? (5 p.m., Lincoln Center, 212-721-6500, lincolncenter.org.)

title: 3,200 Crabs, 1 Unstoppable Man
description: Despite being prevented from leaving China, Ai Weiwei manages to maintain a healthy international career. If one were to judge by news media attention alone, one might think him the only Chinese contemporary artist in existence. His most innovative work has been through various forms of social media, in what might be called a continuing digital version of performance art. (A book of his blog posts, published in 2011, remains his magnum opus.)

title: I Like to Be Crazy on the Stage
description: If youre a certain kind of soprano, you end up learning a lot about going insane. Young, agile voices like Olga Peretyatkos earn mad scene after mad scene.

title: Machlin Womens Swiss Teams
description: DALLAS  The winners of the Machlin Womens Swiss Teams on the final day of the Spring Nationals here last month were Gan Ling, Huang Yan, Hu Wen, Wang Hanyong, Li Lixuan and Li Yiting, all from China. They finished 0.75 victory points ahead of their countrywomen Lu Yan, Wang Hongli, Ran Jingrong, Wang Wenfei, Shen Qi and Zhou Lihua.

title: A Climate of Complexity
description: All this angst about climate change, and the answers been there all the time: Indiana Jones.

title: A Venerable Tapestry, Woven Anew
description: The stringent harmonies of Shostakovichs broody String Quartet No. 12 filled the living room of Eugene Druckers Upper West Side apartment on a recent morning as the Emerson String Quartet rehearsed.
