Mr. Drucker and Philip Setzer, the quartets founding violinists, sat on one side of the room opposite the violist Lawrence Dutton. With his back to the window, the cellist Paul Watkins had a view of a bookcase lined with nine Grammy Awards and side tables bristling with framed photographs of musicians paying handwritten tributes to the quartets reign in the chamber music pantheon: Bernstein, Levine, Rostropovich.

title: In Poignant Paeans, Lost Players Live On
description: An eerie tapping sound accompanies parts of Shostakovichs String Quartet No. 13, which the Emerson String Quartet will perform on April 23 at Alice Tully Hall. Players take turns striking the body of their instruments with the wooden tips of their bows, with the steady, precise motion of someone hammering a small nail. The spooky effect is part of Shostakovichs bleakly beautiful tribute to Vadim Borisovsky, the longstanding violist of the Beethoven Quartet, who retired from the ensemble in 1964 because of ill health.

title: Ex-Connecticut Governor Pleads Not Guilty to Campaign-Related Charges
description: NEW HAVEN  Ten years after he resigned in disgrace from Connecticuts highest office, former Gov. John G. Rowland pleaded not guilty on Friday to an indictment on campaign-related charges that could send him back to prison.

title: Health Reform and Affinity Fraud
description: Over at Talking Points Memo, they seem bemused by the violent reaction on the right to any suggestion that Obamacare is working as well as all the evidence suggests it is. Josh Marshall and Ezra Klein both made a fairly obvious point: Kathleen Sebeliuss resignation was almost surely timed to follow good news, so that her departure wouldnt be easy to spin as part of a narrative about failed reform. The right, however, went ballistic  not so much expressing skepticism over the good enrollment numbers and the encouraging survey data as expressing total outrage and bewilderment that anyone believes the good news. On the right they know, just know, that its a total disaster.

title: In the Air | Classic Rock
description: Marble emerges as the material of choice in contemporary design.

title: Wet Spring Weather Requires More Attentive Driving
description: The rain that tends to arrive in April often makes roads slick and dangerous. Mark Cox, director of the Bridgestone Winter Driving School in Steamboat Springs, Colo., said in a telephone interview that with snow and ice absent from roads, motorists can be lulled into a false sense of security when it is raining.

title: Friday Night Music: Carolina Chocolate Drops
description: Saw them last night at Brooklyn Academy of Music. Totally amazing. Every time you thought they couldnt surprise you any more with their range, they pulled something else out  and not just by singing in Gaelic. When Rhiannon Giddens kicked off her shoes and starting dancing, the whole audience lost it.

title: Key to Tougher Teslas: Titanium
description: A cloud of doubt lingering over Tesla Motors parted on March 26, when the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration closed an investigation of the Model S begun in response to two cars that were destroyed by fires after striking objects on the highway.

title: Formula Ones New-Age Hybrids Find Their Footing
description: Lewis Hamilton, the 29-year-old Englishman who won it, called it a racers race, perhaps the best ever of his 24 victories, and by the measure of how many others in the sport described it, that was no boast.

title: Highlighting the Classical, Hitting the Mystical, Flirting With the Demonic
description: Almost every season at the New York Philharmonic, gifted artists in their 20s, sometimes even younger, are soloists in concertos. So it was surprising that it took until Thursday night for the superb British pianist Paul Lewis, 41, to make his Philharmonic debut at Avery Fisher Hall. He played a majestic and insightful performance of Brahmss Piano Concerto No. 1 in D minor with the revered maestro Christoph von Dohnanyi conducting.

title: Obama, Citing New Laws, Says the G.O.P. Is Moving to Restrict Voting Rights
description: President Obama deplored on Friday what he called a Republican campaign to deny voting rights to millions of Americans as he stepped up efforts to rally his political base heading into a competitive midterm campaign season.

title: Capitalizing on Her Leap to Stardom
description: It goes without saying that when youre handed the part of a lifetime, you play it to the hilt. In the case of Lupita Nyongo, the 31-year old Oscar winner  born in Mexico, raised in Kenya, educated at Yale and vaulted to what seemed like overnight fame  the part of the slave Patsey in 12 Years a Slave was just a preamble for a far larger role.

title: The Body as Helix in an Infinite Cosmos
description: Open your joints, the choreographer Shen Wei quietly exhorted his troupe recently in a large, airy studio at the Mark Morris Dance Center. Drop your weight, stretch and go down even deeper, so your body is completely free. Mr. Shen was preparing the dancers for a run of performances of his 2005 work Map, opening on April 29 at Judson Memorial Church, a stately neo-Romanesque pile on Washington Square

title: Amid Flames and Flowers, She Dashes Through Time
description: In Orlando, a monologue presented by Peak Performances at Montclair State University, the Scottish actress Judith Williams plays a boy, a young man, a male ambassador and several women, too. Of course, theyre all the same person.

title: 2 Kenyans Kidnapped in Somalia in 2011 Are Found Alive
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Two Kenyan aid workers who were abducted by the Shabab militant group in 2011 were rescued on Thursday evening by Kenyan troops who are part of a peacekeeping mission in Somalia, officials said Friday.

title: A Lucky Strike, Indeed
description: Mad Men made its debut on AMC in the summer of 2007, the creation of a former writer of The Sopranos whose pilot script was rejected by HBO, starring an unknown leading man and residing on a network best known as a second-tier movie channel, one that didnt cost extra.

title: East Meets West, Over Cocktails
description: LOS ANGELES  During its heyday in the 1940s, the Forbidden City in San Francisco billed itself as the worlds most famous Chinese nightclub. A jacketed doorman greeted visitors outside, drawing them into the clubs grand interior, with its rich tapestries and Mandarin-collared bartenders. On the bandstand sat a large gold Buddha looking down on the audience, which often included celebrities like Bob Hope, Rita Hayworth and Lauren Bacall. Tourists from the Midwest were there, too, lured by articles in Life and Look magazines, and by promises of the clubs exotic splendor and all-star Chinese floor show.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: Katty Kay and Claire Shipman: Learning to Dispense With the Negative
description: Katty Kay and Claire Shipman hardly seem like victims of self-doubt. Between them, they have covered the Clinton White House and the fall of the Soviet Union (Ms. Shipman), anchors BBC World News America (Ms. Kay) and learned to kiteboard at nearly 40 (Ms. Kay again). And yet both say they have had to work to overcome fears of inadequacy, tendencies to defer to male colleagues and tortured cycles of useless self-recrimination. In The Confidence Code, to be published on Tuesday, they lay out a path for women to become more self-assured. In phone conversations and at a lunch date (served by Sidra Forman, a Washington chef), Ms. Kay and Ms. Shipman discussed how to swat away creeping negative thoughts and what they are really thinking when theyre on television. (This interview has been edited and condensed.)

title: Introducing Corporate to Cool
description: On a chilly night not long ago, Katie Longmyer sat behind the D.J. in the Living Room Bar at the W New York Downtown hotel and surveyed her creation: fashion-industry denizens, purveyors of high art and Lower East Side hipsters, all dancing with gleeful abandon.

title: A Niche No Longer
description: Theres a lot to appreciate about the new Nissan Rogue: more room, good fuel economy, impressive crash protection and a zestful approach to a mountain road.

title: Al Jazeera Series Depicts U.S. Problem
description: It turns out that there is a reason to watch Al Jazeera America.

title: Youll Go Far, My Pet
description: Not to brag, but we may have a little genius on our hands. Our 6-month-old is up before dawn playing brain games. She knows her way around an iPad and practically devours puzzles, and Im teaching her to read. Just recently, she mastered an advanced chess toy.

title: An Eye on the Ball, Even in Tax Season
description: All you people who havent filed your taxes yet, John R. Liebermans got your number. A certified public accountant and personal financial specialist who has talked about tax issues on The Daily Show and on CNN, he likens April 15 to Christmas Day: There are people who shop early in September, and there are people who show up on Dec. 24. Mr. Lieberman, 55, who is managing director at Perelson Weiner in New York and does a lot of international work, lives on the Upper East Side with Dr. Andrea P. Thau, 54, an optometrist. The couple has two sons, Evan, 24, in his third year at the Sackler School of Medicine in Tel Aviv, and Richard, 21, graduating from Binghamton University this year. Sunday is typically a work day for Mr. Lieberman, especially this time of year, but he tries to get in some tennis; he once aspired to the pro circuit.

title: Killing Inmates the Old-Fashioned Way
description: On Wednesday, the Tennessee state senate voted 23-3 to allow execution by electrocution if drugs for lethal injection  the method of choice around the country  are unavailable.

title: A Perfect Place to Hunt the Living Dead in Queens
description: As the inhuman shrieks drew near, six survivors of the zombie apocalypse huddled together, scanned the blacklit maze of the asylum and gripped their assault rifles. When a severed arm flew out from around the corner, they screamed and unloaded their weapons into the darkness.

title: Herbalife Shares Decline on Criminal Inquiry News
description: Herbalife shares plunged late Friday afternoon after a news report linked the diet supplements company to a criminal investigation.

title: Vienna Philharmonic Finds Owners of a Nazi Gift
description: It is a simple oil painting, showing a sailing ship moored in a harbor, an early work by the French artist Paul Signac, made in 1883. For decades it lay hidden away in a storage space of the august Vienna Philharmonic, a 172-year-old institution that is one of the cultural pillars of Europe.

title: April Is the Cruelest Month
description: Brooklyn Ballet, which includes classical and street dancers, is an ambitious enterprise. Thats a gentle way of saying its all over the map. For Vectors, Marys, and Snow, the companys spring program, seen last weekend at the Actors Fund Arts Center, Brooklyn Ballet unveiled a handful of works, including excerpts from its forthcoming Brooklyn Nutcracker. Its true that there was a bracing chill in the air, but Tchaikovsky in April is just cruel.

title: Help for the Big Guys
description: Even those among us who are doing the best can use a little help now and then.

title: Trying to Regain Childhoods Magic
description: NEW HAVEN  Im sick of my rational existence in the real world, the elderly man grumbles to his grandson. I want to live once again in one full of mystery and magic and shadows I can play with.

title: Whose Picture Is It, Anyway?
description: Last fall, while on a family bike ride around Central Park, I took a photo of my 9-year-old son. His cheeks were flushed, his big brown eyes were lit with happiness and the golden sun made his light-olive skin appear to glow. It was a great picture and one I wanted to share with my friends online.

title: Mentally Ill, in Prison and Outside
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeing Asian Cultures, Through an Indigo Lens
description: A 57-foot-tall blank wall under a skylight beckoned to Jinyoung Jin last fall, when she became associate director of cultural programs at the Charles B. Wang Center at Stony Brook University. I felt I had to show something on it, said Ms. Jin, who had a similar impulse about other vast expanses in the Wang Center, the 120,000-square-foot center for Asian and Asian-American arts and culture that she now oversees. My purpose is to fill up the whole space, she said recently as she stood on a second-floor bridge that offers a panoramic view of the sunlit white wall, which is no longer empty.

title: Deciding Where to Set the Limits on Surveillance
description: To the Editor:

title: Persons of Interest
description: This issue is about style and rooms that are intensely personal. Yet the term personal style (like the term lifestyle) is now so overused in the decorating and design sphere as to be essentially meaningless. The homes, studios and work featured in this issue are personal in the sense that they are intimate  each seems like an organic extension, expressed through space and objects, of their makers. They dont aim to be expressions of personal style; rather they just possess great style, which is always sui generis and, at least in the case of all the places we feature here, from the heart.

title: Auto Nirvana
description: The 1964 New York Worlds Fair reflected a world where the automobile had reached the pinnacle of its power and prestige.

title: Screening Air Passengers
Tax-Preparer Licensing
description: To the Editor:

title: The Week in Pictures for April 11
description: .media.slideshow.in-page-player .headline { display: none; }

title: Moments From Pistoriuss Testimony
description: A look back at the most dramatic moments from Oscar Pistoriuss testimony as he took the stand in his murder trial in Pretoria, South Africa.

title: House G.M. Hearing Documents
description: Reference documents compiled as part of an investigation by the House Energy and Commerce Committee into why it took General Motors more than a decade to publicly disclose a dangerous flaw in a small-car ignition switch and to order a recall of the vehicles with the defective switch.

title: Cups With Hitlers Image Are Investigated in Germany
description: BERLIN  Some people think they see statues of saints weeping or an image of Jesus in their toast. A woman in western Germany recently thought she saw Adolf Hitler on a cup, nestled between rose petals and gaudy English writing. It turns out she was not imagining the profile of the man with a toothbrush mustache.

title: And Now, Kosher Cheeses
description: Its tough for those obsessed with poisses and other fine cheeses to understand. How is it that, for generations, many ancient, runny or stinky cheeses were not available to those orthodox Jews who adhere to strict kashrut dietary law? Perhaps because those laws forbid meat and milk from being served together and, as a result, dairy products often get short shrift. But now people like Brent Delman, who is known as the Cheese Guy, are letting observant Jews in on a wide world of cheeses.

title: A Latin Heart Beats Anew
description: When I reviewed the Cuban Crocodile in Long Beach in 2012, it was the only Cuban restaurant I knew of on Long Island. It was damaged by Hurricane Sandy, and Corazon de Cuba opened in its former quarters less than four months ago.

title: Jesse Winchester, Writer and Singer of Thoughtful Songs, Dies at 69
description: Jesse Winchester, a honey-voiced singer who wrote thoughtful songs with deep Southern roots, died on Friday at his home in Charlottesville, Va. He was 69.

title: Spring Design Issue
description: In our spring design issue, T celebrates risk takers. Leading the way is the architect-of-the-moment Joseph Dirand, whose elegantly spare Paris apartment, with its towering windows and generous slabs of marble, puts a new spin on minimalism. We travel to Tangier  long a refuge for adventurers and free-thinking outsiders  where a merry band of eccentric expats are letting their freak flags fly. We step into the homes of a pair of visionaries: the self-taught sculptor Alma Allen, whose journey as an art star has taken him from the streets of SoHo to the wild borderland of Joshua Tree, Calif., and the madcap designer Nicky Haslam, whose new London flat reflects his flair for the unconventional, and must be seen to be believed. Elsewhere, David Netto makes the case for personality and practicality in interior design; the international art gallery Hauser & Wirth bucks convention by opening an outpost in English farm country; the legendary French fabric house Le Manach gets a new lease on life; and the surrealist director Alejandro Jodorowsky as well as the surprisingly-nimble-in-the-kitchen pop star Kelis snack on gold popcorn while considering the future and blinged-out Louboutins. See all stories from the issue >>

title: Remember Fort Pillow!
description: On April 12, 1864  the third anniversary of the firing on Fort Sumter  a Confederate force led by the brilliant and brutal Nathan Bedford Forrest attacked Union troops holding Fort Pillow, an obscure post in West Tennessee. What happened after Forrests men captured Fort Pillow remains one of the most notorious and controversial incidents of the Civil War.

title: U.S. Denies It Knew of Heartbleed Bug on the Web
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration denied Friday that the National Security Agency or other parts of the federal government had known about the Heartbleed security vulnerability that has created widespread fears that passwords and other sensitive information belonging to millions of Internet users may have been revealed over the past two years.

title: Journalists Who Broke News on N.S.A. Surveillance Return to the U.S.
description: The journalists had been threatened, cajoled and condemned by the British and American governments. Their work together had set off a hunt for their source and a debate on both sides of the Atlantic about government surveillance.

title: Local Views, Bucolic and Serene
description: Step into the new show at the Bruce Museum these days, and you are instantly transported to a soothing, bucolic world where water burbles, crickets chirp, and calm reigns. And that is before you even look at a single one of the 29 paintings in Pasture to Pond: Connecticut Impressionism.

title: Financial Advice for People Who Arent Rich
description: For a couple of years now, a number of entrepreneurs have been racing to solve the same problem: the financial services industrys persistent inability to provide personalized advice and appropriate investments at a reasonable price to customers who are not rich.

title: Mystery Surrounds Death of Ukrainian Activist
description: BARMAKY, Ukraine  For more than 20 years, Oleksandr Muzychko battled and somehow survived Russian power, taking up arms against Moscow-backed rebels in Georgia and Moldova, against Russias army in Chechnya and finally against Ukraines pro-Russia president, Viktor F. Yanukovych.

title: Samsung Calls on Google Executive to Defend Innovation
description: In Apples latest patent fight with Samsung Electronics, lawyers on both sides are relying on the power of a good story to sway a jury. And Samsung is borrowing one from Google.

title: Tax Returns Show Drop in Obamas Earnings
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama and the first lady, Michelle Obama, released their 2013 tax returns on Friday, showing a sharp decrease in their personal income since filing their 2012 returns.

title: Former Ranger Traces Troubles to 2004 Fight
description: Dan LaCoutures troubles began, he said, on Jan. 5, 2004, when one of his Rangers teammates got into trouble at Madison Square Garden.

title: Canos Fresh Start
description: The baseball experience of my childhood led me to believe in the stability of the baseball family. Even though free agency was alive and well in those years, my favorite players were mainstays. Mike Schmidt, Steve Carlton and Garry Maddox were Philadelphia Phillies legends who showed me that once you are granted the golden ticket to play professional baseball, you can enjoy a long career and be identified mainly with one team.

title: Idea of New Attention Disorder Spurs Research, and Debate
description: With more than six million American children having received a diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, concern has been rising that the condition is being significantly misdiagnosed and overtreated with prescription medications.

title: Pope Francis Asks for Forgiveness
description: The pope personally asked for forgiveness for the damage that priests have done for having sexually abused children.

title: Pope Takes Responsibility in Priests Abuse Scandal
description: VATICAN CITY  Pope Francis said on Friday that he took personal responsibility for the harm done by priests who sexually abused children, and he pledged that the Roman Catholic Church would confront the issue unflinchingly and impose sanctions when necessary.

title: In an Excruciatingly Hip Neighborhood, a Bloody Encounter
description: The manager of a Mobil station in Manhattans meatpacking district shrugged and shook his head.

title: Rules Violation at Augusta: Unauthorized Quesadilla
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Bode Miller, a six-time Olympic medalist in ski racing, was just another face in the gallery at Augusta National Golf Club on Friday. He did, though, look slightly out of place initially, having arrived with a light ski parka to combat the morning chill and a baseball cap promoting not a golf entity but Slden, an Austrian ski resort.

title: Blast Survivor Thanks Her Rescuers
description: In the devastation that followed a gas explosion in East Harlem last month, firefighters found a woman through a break in the smoke: a flash of color amid the debris that was once 1644 Park Avenue.

title: An Italian Menu to Feed Everyone
description: Some restaurants just feel great to walk into. Casual but stylish, Sorella occupies a big, high-ceilinged room decorated with sepia photos of the owners and employees ancestors from the old country and offers views of Hartfords Old State House. The tripartite floor plan accommodates a lively bar scene, couples dining intimately, and families, in a cozy back space anchored by a colorfully tiled potbellied wood-burning pizza oven.

title: Battle for the Bigger Screen
description: LOS ANGELES  On the surface its just an old-fashioned game of Hollywood tit for tat: Cinemark, the nations No. 3 theater chain, has been promoting the growth of its network of extra-large movie screens, and Imax, the standard-bearer in the format for decades, has reacted with popped claws.

title: Bookstores in Seattle Soar, and Embrace an Old Nemesis: Amazon.com
description: SEATTLE  A love of books and bookstores runs deep in the sinews of this city, where gray skies and drizzle can drive a person to drink, or read, or both. A long-running annual survey ranks Seattle the countrys second-most literate big city, behind Washington, D.C., as measured by things like the number of bookstores, library resources, newspaper circulation and education.

title: In Brazil, Usual Olympics Worry With Unusual Validity
description: The smash-hit London Olympics were nearing a close in August 2012, and I found myself in an elevator at the main news media center with a small delegation of observers from the next Summer Games, in Rio de Janeiro.

title: The Apple Chronicles
description: So theyre at it again, Apple and Samsung, fighting over patents in a courtroom in San Jose, Calif. They had a similar fight in 2012, in the same courtroom, which Apple won. Samsung has also won its share of these legal battles, including in Australia.

title: Stage Is Her Playground: Jump-Rope, Fuzzy Tube and Windup Toy
description: In her new solo Forested, the second piece in a trilogy exploring the ways an audiences gaze can be guided and controlled, the dancer and choreographer Amanda Loulaki uses her body as a vessel. Her compact frame has been on trips like this before. Ms. Loulaki, a New York artist born in Crete, is enamored of the choreographic potential of stringing together fragments of movement, gestures and emotions to create an ambiguous whole.

title: Tom Petri, G.O.P. Congressman From Wisconsin, Is Retiring
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Tom Petri, Republican of Wisconsin, said Friday that he would not seek re-election after 35 years in Congress.

title: Hoofing It Into the Future
description: Ask tap dancers what inspires them, and the conversation will probably turn to teachers, mentors, artistic ancestors. Perhaps more than any other, this is a dance form that knows where it came from, reveres its roots and doesnt relegate its history to the past.

title: Evoking Creation, Occasionally With a Big Bang
description: According to a line of Kabbalistic commentary, Genesis  Bereshit in Hebrew  begins not with the letter bet, the second of the alphabet, but with an invisible aleph, a letter that is inaudible on its own and here represents the sublime and translucent state that preceded the worlds creation. On Tuesday evening the German composer Matthias Pintscher conducted the formidable Juilliard Orchestra at Alice Tully Hall in the New York premiere of his own bereshit, a mesmerizing and sophisticated work that grew out of a whispered harmonic played high on a double bass and the barely-there hum of a gong  sounds as amorphous as an aleph.

title: Utopian Vision Born of a Harsh Truth
description: The exhibition Aljira at 30: Dream and Reality, at the New Jersey State Museum in Trenton, starts with a video revisiting the 1967 Newark riots, titled 5 Days in July, by Chuck Schultz and Esther Podemski. Made in 2007, it was shown that year at Aljira, an alternative exhibition space in Newark for emerging and underrepresented artists. The two-screen piece shows the city on fire and footage of the National Guard overrunning the rebellion of the African-American community after the arrest and beating of a cabdriver for a traffic infraction.

title: Japan: New Energy Strategy Approved
description: Japans cabinet approved a new national energy strategy on Friday that designates nuclear power as an important energy source and calls for restarting idled nuclear plants that meet new safety standards. The new strategy, first proposed by the government of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe two months ago, scraps a promise made by a previous government after the 2011 Fukushima nuclear disaster to phase out atomic energy. Under the new plan, Japan could start as early as August to restart at least some of its 48 operable commercial reactors, which were stopped after the Fukushima accident spread nuclear radiation across northern Japan.

title: Murder Charge for Teenager in Fire That Killed an Officer
description: A teenager who the authorities say set a fire in the hallway of a Brooklyn high-rise last week was charged with second-degree murder on Friday, two days after the death of one of the two New York City police officers who were critically injured in the blaze.

title: Sebeliuss Slow-Motion Resignation From the Cabinet
description: WASHINGTON  Everyone knew it was a disaster. After Kathleen Sebelius appeared on The Daily Show with Jon Stewart last October, she and her staff at the Department of Health and Human Services felt she had been sandbagged by Mr. Stewart. At the White House, President Obamas top aides were aghast at her wooden performance.

title: Chinese Fireball Mystery
description: Chinas largest energy company has made the countrys first commercially viable shale gas discovery, but the path to energy independence is fraught with risks, as one town has seen first-hand.

title: Derailed by Masters Win, Bubba Watson Seeks Another
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Bubba Watson, the 2012 Masters champion, concedes his mind was not on golf last year.

title: China Takes On Big Risks in Its Push for Shale Gas
description: JIAOSHIZHEN, China  Residents of this isolated mountain valley of terraced cornfields were just going to sleep last April when they were jolted by an enormous roar, followed by a tower of flames. A shock wave rolled across the valley, rattling windows in farmhouses and village shops, and a mysterious, pungent gas swiftly pervaded homes.

title: Doubly Disabled in Life
description: Americans with intellectual and developmental disabilities historically have been shuttled far from societys mainstream into segregated lives and workplace serfdom, earning wages as low as pennies per hour for the most repetitive and menial jobs. The Supreme Court in 1999 pronounced this kind of treatment a civil rights violation under the Americans With Disabilities Act, but abuse and isolation from society have continued to this day.

title: Inching Forward With Iran
description: There is no doubt that the negotiations between the major powers and Iran over its nuclear program have been productive. All the nations involved  the United States, Britain, France, China, Germany, Iran, even Russia  appear committed to reaching a deal that will go beyond Novembers interim agreement and produce a permanent one. The chief negotiators completed a third round of talks in Vienna on Wednesday and plan to meet again on May 13, after which they expect to begin drafting actual text. They hope to wrap it all up by July 20.

title: Its Leaving 57th Street, but Rizzoli Bookstore Vows Sequel
description: Lea Noring of Acworth, Ga., had a destination in mind for her first trip to New York, and it was not one of those crowded places like Times Square or the Empire State Building that the locals disdain as tourist traps.

title: At Phillips Exeter, a World of Religious Diversity
description: EXETER, N.H.  Money, prestige, success  they have become slave masters, Milton Syed, a slight 18-year-old from the Bronx, told his audience. He was wearing a necktie with his collared shirt, as required by the dress code here at Phillips Exeter Academy, alma mater of Daniel Webster and Franklin Pierce, of Gore Vidal and Facebooks Mark Zuckerberg. Mr. Syed, a senior, was preaching a khutbah, the Friday sermon after Muslim prayers, to a group of 10, including several fellow Muslim students, a Muslim math teacher and a blond girl who was not Muslim, just curious.

title: The Self-Sort
description: This week, four presidents journeyed to Austin, Tex., to address the Civil Rights Summit and remark on President Lyndon B. Johnsons legacy on the 50th anniversary of the passage of the Civil Rights Act.

title: Torturing Children at School
description: Federal investigators have opened an inquiry into the tragic case of a high school student in Bastrop County, Tex., who suffered severe brain damage and nearly died last fall after a deputy sheriff shocked him with a Taser, a high voltage electronic weapon.

title: A Tour of the Heavens Gets an Upgrade
description: The Hudson River Museum, in Yonkers, is already reaping the benefits of its eight-month, $1.5 million planetarium renovation, completed in February. Since the March 8 reopening, school group bookings are up, and so are weekend ticket sales.

title: Canadian Bankruptcy Court Clears the Way for Furniture Executive to Buy Bike Share Company
description: OTTAWA  A businessman from Quebec has received a courts approval to purchase the company that provides the bicycles and technology for several major bike-sharing systems, including Citi Bike in New York and Barclays Cycle Hire in London.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 11, 2014
description: April 11, 2014

title: Lobby for Small Brewers, Concerned Over Rule, Finds Friends in Washington
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Susan Collins wanted to talk about beer.

title: Alternative to Shoots
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  By my count, there were seven entries in this puzzle by Mel Rosen that I had to look up, but thats O.K. I know I have to put in my time to get through a Saturday grid, and this was tough but doable. And the result was an enjoyable solve, so that makes it worthwhile in my book.

title: Salvadoran General Accused in Killings Should Be Deported, Miami Judge Says
description: An immigration judge has found that a former defense minister in El Salvador, a close ally of the United States during a civil war there in the 1980s, should be deported because of his involvement in a number of human rights violations, including the assassination of an archbishop and the massacre of more than 1,000 peasants.

title: Frankens Campaign Against Comcast Is No Joke
description: WASHINGTON  For Senator Al Franken, the political became personal at a Saturday Night Live cast party, of all places.

title: Take In the Hudson View, Cosmo in Hand
description: Edgewater Harbor, the sprawling residential development across the Hudson River from the Upper West 90s of Manhattan, feels a bit like a place waiting to happen, with gleaming new high-rises cheek by jowl with construction sites, leasing signs in windows and new retail businesses popping up on the ground level.

title: Student Crossing a Street is Hit by 2 Cabs and Killed
description: A college senior who was visiting New York City for job interviews was struck by two taxicabs and killed as she crossed a street on the Upper East Side, the authorities said on Friday.

title: Excitement Turns Into Exasperation, Even for Stars
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  After signing his scorecard and speaking to the news media, the South African Branden Grace considered a quick stop in the pro shop Friday to buy six Masters folding chairs. He was going to need them for camping out during the weekend at one of the holes on the back nine at Augusta National.

title: The Ruling on Gen. Jos Guillermo Garca
description: The decision by a Miami judge, issued on Feb. 26, said that the former Salvadoran defense minister should be deported because of his involvement in a number of human rights violations.

title: Greenwald and Poitras Land in New York
description: The journalists Glenn Greenwald and Laura Poitras spoke to reporters after arriving at Kennedy Airport.

title: Hailing Farmers, Fishermen and Legends Past
description: On the website of Restaurant North, just beneath the headings for Our Menu and Our Wine is an unexpected category labeled Loves, which includes slide show shout-outs to the Mets catcher Gary Carter, the cookbook author James Beard, Jerry Garcia of the Grateful Dead, and the exterior of the Peter McManus Cafe, the enduring tavern in Manhattan.

title: Amid Storm Over Slurs, Fire Chief Plans Exit
description: A fire chief in Westchester County whose firefighters disclosed that on several occasions he had used anti-Semitic slurs to deride a town supervisor has decided to retire at the end of the year.

title: A Yankees Pitchers Hand Revives Arguments Over Pine Tar
description: It is used to heal horses hooves and to soothe skin ailments on farmyard hens. It has also been used to preserve the wood and rigging on boats in Scandinavia, for hundreds of years, no less. And for almost that long, it seems, it has been used by pitchers to get a grip on the baseball in cold weather.

title: The World Goes to the Polls
description: If the first week of April was one that favored cynics, this past week was more attuned to optimists. There were the extraordinary images of Afghans defying Taliban threats and bombs to exercise their hard-won right to transfer power through the ballot. Then Indians embarked on what was billed as the biggest election ever held, followed by Indonesians in what must be the worlds most complicated election, with half a million polling places scattered among 17,000 islands.

title: City Accused of Dragging Its Feet on Settling Suit in 89 Jogger Rape Case
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio has long said that his administration would swiftly settle the lawsuit by five men convicted in the 1989 rape of a jogger in Central Park. We will settle the Central Park Five case because a huge injustice was done, he said in December.

title: With Hands Spotless and Pitches Filthy, Red Sox Lester Shines
description: A night after Yankees starter Michael Pinedas dirty right hand overshadowed his effective outing against the Boston Red Sox, Jon Lester made certain the focus remained on his pitching and only his pitching. Lester held the Yankees to two runs and six hits in a 4-2 victory Friday at Yankee Stadium, continuing his recent success against them.

title: Desperation and Two Stars Fuel Much-Needed Win for the Knicks
description: TORONTO  The Knicks may now only be delaying the inevitable. They can only keep trying to eke out victories and keep hoping that the Atlanta Hawks undergo some seismic collapse to cede the Eastern Conferences final playoff spot.

title: Coming Soon to MoMA, Lots of Knocking Next Door
description: The Museum of Modern Arts controversial decision to demolish a neighbor, the former American Folk Art Museum, is about to become reality.

title: Terry Collins Shows Mets How to Compete, and to Endure
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Terry Collins used to have a bet every day with Barry Bonds. When he was the bullpen coach with the Pittsburgh Pirates, Collins would throw Bonds batting practice, and they wagered on the number of home runs Bonds could hit.

title: Citys Doormen Reach New Labor Agreement
description: Averting what would have been their first strike in nearly 25 years, the union representing 30,000 building service employees said on Friday that they had reached a tentative labor deal with the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations, which represents building owners.

title: Hawks End Nets Home Streak and Move Closer to Playoff Berth
description: The Nets did the Knicks no favors Friday night. The Nets did themselves no favors, either.

title: Sweet Lou Hudson, Jump Shot Master With the Hawks, Dies at 69
description: Lou Hudson, a six-time N.B.A. All-Star who was one of the most reliable scorers in the league in a 13-year career, most of it with the Atlanta Hawks, died on Friday in Atlanta. He was 69.

title: A Finish Rarely Seen on the Ice Is Followed by Elation and Disbelief
description: PHILADELPHIA  In a sport unaccustomed to buzzer-beaters, the reverberations from a game-winning, last-second goal late Thursday were still resounding hours later at Wells Fargo Center.

title: A Roller-Coaster Season for the Devils Hits Another Low Point
description: NEWARK  Devils Coach Pete DeBoer could only laugh.

title: Mobilizing Against a Common Core Test
Whats on Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (Showtime) DJANGO UNCHAINED (2012) Dr. King Schultz (Christoph Waltz), a German bounty hunter, teams up with Django (Jamie Foxx, above right, with Mr. Waltz), a former slave turned gun for hire, to rescue his wife (Kerry Washington) from a plantation owner (Leonardo DiCaprio) in this action-adventure directed by Quentin Tarantino. Samuel L. Jackson plays a house slave who assists his master. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called this film, which also earned Mr. Tarantino an Oscar for best original screenplay, crazily entertaining, brazenly irresponsible and also ethically serious in a way that is entirely consistent with its playfulness. He added: Mr. Tarantino is a virtuoso of bloodshed, that is for sure, and also more enamored of a particularly toxic racial slur than any decent white man should be. But decency in the conventional sense is not his concern, though in another sense it very much is. When you wipe away the blood and the anarchic humor, what you see in Django Unchained is moral disgust with slavery, instinctive sympathy for the underdog and an affirmation (in the relationship between Django and Schultz) of what used to be called brotherhood.

title: Russian Conductors Carnegie Appearance Draws Protests
description: As long as the Russian conductor Valery Gergiev maintains his friendship with the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, it appears, protesters will have reason to dog his steps.

title: Corrections: April 12, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Mets Hit Batter in 11th, Sending Angels to Victory
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  By some quirk in the baseball schedule, the Mets had played a night game in Atlanta on Thursday. They had left as soon as they could and had arrived here, bleary-eyed, around 3 a.m. local time. Now, late Friday night, they were locked in an intense game with the Los Angeles Angels, and it was dragging on, into the 9th, the 10th and beyond.

title: Police Drop Charges Against Baby in Pakistan
description: A 9-month-old Pakistani boy will not be going to prison on attempted murder charges.

title: The Ballad of Geeshie and Elvie
description: On the trail of the phantom women who changed American music and then vanished without a trace.

title: The Ballad of Geeshie and Elvie
description: On the trail of the phantom women who changed American music and then vanished without a trace.

title: The Most Dangerous Word in Tech
description: The most important word in the technology industry is innovation. It is also the most dangerous.

title: Outkast at Coachella
description: I know its kind of weird, said the rapper and singer Andre 3000 of Outkast, dressed in overalls and a hoodie and standing with his partner Big Boi. But thank yall for coming.

title: Coachella 2014  day 1
description: The first day of this years Coachella festival featured performances by Ellie Goulding, Broken Bells and OutKast.

title: A 17-Year-Old, Living in New York
description: Dear Diary:

title: A Talk With Simon Head, Author of Mindless: Smarter Machines Are Making Dumber Humans
description: Simon Head thinks the world has become good for computers, but bad for most humans.

title: A Whole New Meaning for Food to Go
description: Top chefs have been known to open satellite restaurants worldwide. Now a few of the worlds most respected chefs are moving abroad for limited culinary residencies.

title: Analytics: Housing Authority
description: The following Analytics appears on the letters page in the April 13 issue of the magazine.

title: Wall Street, The City, And Austerity
description: Noah Smith, Simon Wren-Lewis, and I have in effect been having an intermittent, long-distance conversation about the role of the finance industry in promoting a view of our economic problems  one that emphasizes the dangers of deficits and monetary expansion  that has had a seriously damaging effect on policy. The question is why so many people in finance gravitate toward that view, and cling to it despite what is at this point overwhelming evidence that its wrong.

title: Thought Secure, Pooled Pensions Teeter and Fall
description: The pensions of millions of Americans are being threatened because of trouble in a part of the retirement world long considered so safe that no one gave it a second thought.

title: 1939: Goldfish Arent Safe in Bowls As College Boys Gulp Em Alive
description: NEW YORK  The silly season has arrived with the advent of a craze far outdoing flagpole-sitting, marathon dancing, chain letter-writing and non-stop beer guzzling for dizziness.

title: Pay for Performance? It Depends on the Measuring Stick
description: Year after year, as executive pay continues its inexorable climb, its amusing to watch corporate directors try to justify the piles of shareholder money they throw at the hired help. Check out any proxy filing for these arguments, which usually center on how closely and carefully the executives incentive compensation is tied to the performance of company operations.

title: How Badly Did the Knicks Lose This Season? Let Us Count the Ways
description: The Knicks needed two games to absorb their first loss of the season, and it was an excruciating finish as the Chicago Bulls Derrick Rose sank a baseline runner for the go-ahead basket in the waning moments. It was Oct. 31, back when the Knicks were still flush with optimism, but the result left them feeling disappointed. It fast became a theme, one that culminated Saturday with their elimination from playoff contention when the Atlanta Hawks defeated the Miami Heat.

title: Armed Men Seize Police Station in Eastern Ukraine City
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  Pro-Russian militants attacked police stations and other security facilities in the most populous part of eastern Ukraine on Saturday, in a brush fire of violent unrest that the government in Kiev immediately denounced as Russian aggression.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  I have to remember not to drink any beverages when Im solving one of Mel Taubs Puns and Anagrams puzzles. Some of his PandAs are on the corny side, but todays had a good amount of really clever stuff that almost made me spray my monitor from all the giggling.

title: Brad Smith of Intuit: Follow the Fastest Beat of Your Heart
description: This interview with  Brad Smith, chief executive of Intuit, the software company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: A Crack in the Laptops Screen (and in Customer Service)
description: Email haggler@nytimes.com. Keep it brief and family-friendly, include your hometown and go easy on the caps-lock key. Letters may be edited for clarity and length.

title: In Their Hearts and Hopes
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  After the Rangers won the 1994 Stanley Cup, the teams first championship in 54 years, they fulfilled the words of their coach, Mike Keenan: Win this, and youll walk together forever.

title: How a Bicycle Maker Saw the Light, and Found Its Balance
description: Cyclists have more ways than ever to make themselves conspicuous when on the road: fluorescent-orange helmets, reflective trench coats, bike horns that mimic car horns, and lighting systems with red lasers that project downward to create a virtual bike lane. Until recently, however, there wasnt an effective method of illuminating the entire bike frame.

title: A Rapidly Shifting Philosophy of Infield Play
description: Chris Tillman pitches for the Baltimore Orioles, which means he can never assume the location of the infielders behind him.

title: In the Workplace, Leaders Who Arent Always Followed
description: Who really makes the changes in an organization? Its not always the people with the highest executive titles. A growing body of research has pointed to the importance of informal leaders known to researchers as brokers, who have the gift of connecting employees in productive new ways.

title: For the Newest Yankee, Reaching the Majors Was a Family Affair
description: More than 20 years later, his aunts and uncles still talk about the way Yangervis Solarte cried the day he watched his uncle get on that plane.

title: In Jordan Town, Syria War Inspires Jihadist Dreams
description: ZARQA, Jordan  Late one night, Abu Abdullah left his whole life behind.

title: From the Vision to the Gallery
description: Stephanie M. Heydt, 43, is the curator of American art at the High Museum of Art in Atlanta.

title: Want Teamwork? Encourage Free Speech
description: Is there anyone whos not ready for me to sign this contract?

title: Better Insurance Against Inequality
description: Paying taxes is rarely pleasant, but as April 15 approaches its worth remembering that our tax system is a progressive one and serves a little-noticed but crucial purpose: It mitigates some of the worst consequences of income inequality.

title: Still No. 1, and Doing What He Wants
description: It is good to be the king. It is even better to be Larry Ellison.

title: Executive Pay: Invasion of the Supersalaries
description: Corporate Americas well-oiled compensation machine is running like a dream.

title: How the Pay Figures Were Calculated
description: To measure the amounts that chief executives were paid last year, Sunday Business asked Equilar Inc., an executive compensation data firm, to compile and analyze pay data from corporate filings.

title: The Pay at the Top
description: The list of 100 of the highest-paid chief executives in American business from the Equilar 100 C.E.O. Pay Study for 2013.

title: A Vote Against Congress in India?
description: Times correspondents report on the incumbent Congress party and the key players in the fight to lead the worlds largest democracy.

title: In 3-Hour Show on Palmer, Golf Channel Joins His Army
description: The opening words of Arnie, a three-part testimonial to Arnold Palmer on Golf Channel, set the direction of this extravaganza.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 61
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Coalition-Building Season in India
description: COIMBATORE, India  As a potential political partner, the chief minister of the southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu has some drawbacks.

title: 25 Years After Stadium Disaster, Liverpool Still Mourns
description: LIVERPOOL, England  In the middle of the bustling city center last week, not far from the merriment of the famed Albert Dock, a man set up a makeshift kiosk to peddle Liverpool F.C. scarves. Over the course of a lunch hour it seemed he always had a customer or two, and to understand the emotions that drive most fans here, one needed to look only at the three scarves displayed prominently across the top of the mans tent.

title: The Chatter for Sunday, April 12
description: Heartbleed is further evidence that we dont have our house in order when it comes to Internet security.

title: Anaheim Ducks and Their Coach Grow Together
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  His label as hockeys Everyman has worn a bit thin, but Anaheim Ducks Coach Bruce Boudreau continues to produce results that are anything but ordinary.

title: In California, Saving a Language That Predates Spanish and English
description: EUREKA, Calif.  Sitting in a circle in a classroom at Eureka High School here, Tenayah Norris and a half-dozen other students were learning how to express direction in Yurok, a Native American language that nearly became extinct a few years ago. Growing up on the Yurok reservation about 90 minutes north of here, she sometimes heard her grandfather speak it to his contemporaries, and she studied it, on and off, in the community.

title: Buyers Find Tax Break on Art: Let It Hang Awhile in Oregon
description: EUGENE, Ore.  The Jordan Schnitzer Museum of Art, tucked into a quiet corner of a college campus here in the hills of the Pacific Northwest, is hardly the epicenter of the art world. Yet major collectors, fresh from buying a Warhol or a Basquiat or another masterpiece in New York, routinely choose this small, elegant redbrick building at the University of Oregon to first exhibit their latest trophy.

title: Durant Adds Steady to Spectacular
description: To say that Kevin Durant has had a breakout season for Oklahoma City would seem ridiculous, given that he led the league in scoring in three of the last four seasons and is a perennial All-Star. But offered less help than he had in the past, he proved up to the task of being a one-man team. His consistently high production has him entering a new stratosphere as a player.

title: Doing Chinas Bidding in Nepal
description: A Human Rights Watch report released this month shows how far Nepal has gone in capitulating to Chinese pressure in cracking down on Tibetan residents and refugees. It details a long list of shameful actions against Tibetans in Nepal, including restrictions on their activities and movements, surveillance and intimidation, arbitrary detention and forcible return to China.

title: Bankruptcy Beyond the Potholes
description: Congress is lurching toward its standard emergency, edge-of-the-cliff deal for the federal Highway Trust Fund, which could run short of money as early as August. The fund pays for the nations vitally needed road and transit projects and has operated on an 18.4-cents-per-gallon federal gasoline tax that hasnt been raised since 1993. Now it is running on fumes, raising about $39 billion a year but facing shortfalls of close to $20 billion annually as more efficient cars pay less into the fund while infrastructure repair costs rise.

title: My Mothers Keepers
description: WEST SHOKAN, N.Y.  IF my mother had been aware enough to know what we were spending on her care, she would have been aghast. Shed always been frugal. I once noticed the remains of the Easter ham in the refrigerator two months later. Dont you think its time to throw that out? I asked. Ham doesnt go bad, she explained. She could make a piece of tinfoil last clear into the next decade. She once made an old corduroy jumper of mine into a seat cover for the rocking chair  perfectly good material, not to be wasted.

title: Reclaiming the Words That Smear
description: AMES, Iowa  UNBECOMING. Miss Congeniality. Not sufficiently ladylike. In politics, these words and phrases have long been used to belittle female candidates. But now, female politicians are increasingly trying to rethink and reclaim how language shapes how they are perceived.

title: Mark My Words. Maybe.
description: MY tattoo kept getting delayed by other peoples weddings: a bachelorette party in Vegas, cliff-top vows in Zion, a ceremony in Westchester. I wasnt just attending the ceremony in Westchester, I was officiating at the ceremony in Westchester. I couldnt picture giving my blessing in front of 200 people while my left arm glistened under Saran Wrap. I felt the slightest twinge of resentment. My life seemed perpetually tucked into the pockets of time created between the milestones of other lives.

title: Diversity and Dishonesty
description: EARLIER this year, a column by a Harvard undergraduate named Sandra Y. L. Korn briefly achieved escape velocity from the Ivy League bubble, thanks to its daring view of how universities should approach academic freedom.

title: Womens Unequal Lot
description: I DROPPED in on my sister last week. As usual, I was amazed.

title: Max Levchin
description: Max Levchin is a Ukrainian-born computer scientist and serial entrepreneur who co-founded PayPal and Yelp. He is currently president of HVF (Hard Valuable Fun), which is a hybrid think tank/venture capital firm that focuses exclusively on data-driven projects.

title: Jazz and Real Estate
description: CLEVELAND HEIGHTS, Ohio  I WISH my father, a landlord, were alive to read the news about the rental boom. He always liked numbers, particularly when they went up.

title: The Killers Underfoot
description: SAN FRANCISCO  IN just over a month, life-giving rains will soak India during the annual monsoons. As welcome as these rains are, they also bring with them injury and death from snakebite. As they do each year, venomous snakes seeking dry ground will slide into peoples homes, gardens and fields; they will curl up in woodpiles, latrines and play areas. Hundreds of thousands of snakebites will cause an estimated 40,000 deaths over the course of the monsoon season.

title: A Wit for All Seasons
description: WASHINGTON  I DONT remember much about being on Stephen Colberts show.

title: High-Priced Treatments
description: Readers discuss how to weigh the costs and benefits of medical innovations.

title: Providing the Balm of Truth
description: What if we gave her some aloe vera gel?

title: Parental Involvement Is Overrated
description: Most people, asked whether parental involvement benefits children academically, would say, of course it does. But evidence from our research suggests otherwise. In fact, most forms of parental involvement, like observing a childs class, contacting a school about a childs behavior, helping to decide a childs high school courses, or helping a child with homework, do not improve student achievement. In some cases, they actually hinder it.

title: Recovery for Whom?
description: The Federal Reserve, increasingly optimistic about the economy, is dialing back its stimulus efforts. The International Monetary Fund has raised its forecast for growth in the United States. Congress has long since reduced aid to the economy, with many lawmakers, mostly Republicans, adamant that the economy is better off with less government involvement.

title: Accusation in Montana of Treating Rape Lightly Stirs Unlikely Public Fight
description: MISSOULA, Mont.  For nearly three years, this college town in the hills of western Montana has lived under the shadow of stories of rapes gone unpunished and complaints that officials minimized or ignored reports of sexual assaults  especially if the suspects played for the University of Montana Grizzlies, the wildly popular football team.

title: The Coat Speaks for Itself, Clearly
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  The Masters green coat that came into vogue in the late 1930s has become what amounts to the worlds most recognizable reversible jacket. Augusta National Golf Club members wear theirs on the grounds to make themselves visible to tournament patrons seeking guidance on the course. And the reigning Masters champion wears it to make himself visible outside the clubs gates to anyone in search of a connection.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 13
description: Kathleen Sebelius, the health and human services secretary who faced criticism for the flawed rollout of the new health care law, resigned this week. Earlier this month, President Obama announced that more than seven million Americans enrolled in the new health care exchanges. Sylvia Mathews Burwell, currently the director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, is Mr. Obamas choice to take over the job.

title: Growing Up at Sea
description: ONE of my earliest memories is of looking down from the bow of my familys sailboat and seeing dolphins gliding alongside us through the bright water. That spot at the tip of the bow, called the bow pulpit, was my favorite place when I was a child. It can be difficult to find somewhere to be alone when living with your parents and younger brother on 81 feet of wood and aluminum, but the bow pulpit was always there when I wanted time to myself. My brother preferred to climb the masts.

title: A Loyal Soldier Doesnt Deserve This
description: THE only reason he is alive, says Mike Yurchison, is his girlfriend, Leigh Anna Landsberger. She sits with him through endless waits at Veterans Affairs, whispering that hes smarter than she is even if his brain is damaged. She helps him through his seizures, and she nags him to overcome drug addiction.

title: Go Ahead, Vladimir, Make My Day
description: SO the latest news is that President Vladimir Putin of Russia has threatened to turn off gas supplies to Ukraine if Kiev doesnt pay its overdue bill, and, by the way, Ukraines pipelines are the transit route for 15 percent of gas consumption for Europe. If Im actually rooting for Putin to go ahead and shut off the gas, does that make me a bad guy?

title: Saving Young People From Themselves
description: RETIREMENT is a financial obligation that todays younger generations are not handling well. That may be through no fault of their own  they suffer from lower incomes, after being adjusted for inflation, and student debt that makes it a struggle to save. But regardless of the reason, the failure to save for retirement is setting up Americans in their 20s and early 30s for financially stressed golden years.

title: Standing by our Veterans
description: My Sunday column looks again at the mental health crisis facing veterans of the Iraq and Afghanistan wars. I was against the Iraq war, but I still think we owe far better after-care to those troops who went and fought there. I tell the story this time through Mike Yurchison, who I mentioned tangentially in a column two years ago after his younger brother (also an Iraq veteran) committed suicide. Now its Mike who is in trouble.

title: Shanahan Made the N.H.L. a Safer Place
description: Brendan Shanahans tenure as the N.H.L.s chief disciplinarian was brief but epic, with the league turning an important corner. He helped to change the culture of the game, as Commissioner Gary Bettman said.

title: Finance Officials Push for Bold Action to Sustain Economic Growth
description: WASHINGTON  At the World Bank and International Monetary Fund annual spring meetings, concerns about crisis have given way to concerns about complacency.

title: At 40, Colon Continues to Defy Time and Weight
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  At some point as Bartolo Colon dominated the Atlanta Braves on Tuesday night, he walked through the dugout, looked down at his bulging belly, grabbed it firmly with his hands and shook it three times. Then, clearly pleased with himself, Colon smiled. He seemed proud of his size, or at least proud that he was talented enough to shut out the Braves for seven innings in spite of it.

title: Rangers, Primed for Flyers in Playoffs, Rest Top Players
description: MONTREAL  Now the real hockey season begins, the Rangers were saying after Saturday nights regular-season finale, a hard-fought, entertaining but ultimately meaningless 1-0 overtime loss to the Montreal Canadiens.

title: Arsenal and Wenger Avoid Nightmare and Advance to F.A. Cup Final
description: LONDON  Arsne Wenger paced. He fidgeted. He squatted then rose then squatted. When he finally stood still, he pulled at the belt loops of his natty suit. For more than two hours Saturday at Wembley Stadium, Wenger looked altogether uncomfortable.

title: New Hampshire Republicans Get a Preview of 2016
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Here in a state where presidential politics are never far from anyones mind, three Republicans who are considering a run for the White House  Senators Ted Cruz of Texas and Rand Paul of Kentucky, and Mike Huckabee, the former Arkansas governor  pitched their views on Saturday for how conservatives can retake power in Washington.

title: Police Kill Gunman, 86, Who Fatally Shot His Daughter
description: An 86-year-old man shot and killed his daughter on Saturday at the home they shared in Queens, and was then shot and killed by a police officer, officials said.

title: New Faces in Middle of Order Power Yanks to a Win
description: The sun shone brightly, and a faint wind began to blow from behind home plate. It was the first such wind of the season, the so-called jet stream at the new Yankee Stadium that favors left-handed hitters. To this point, it had not meant much to Brian McCann, the new Yankees catcher. But he got a good idea of what it could mean to him this season.

title: Another Prosecutor Is Said to Investigate Port Authority
description: The Manhattan district attorneys office has subpoenaed documents from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey concerning a range of the troubled agencys major construction projects, including several that have come under scrutiny as a result of the politically charged George Washington Bridge lane closings, a person with knowledge of the matter said Saturday.

title: A World Is Reshaped, and Printers Adapt or Die
description: The survivors of the printing industry are increasingly high tech and automated. Many are holding on by moving beyond media publishing and into packaging and labeling.

title: Leaner and More Efficient, British Printers Push Forward in Digital Age
description: PETERBOROUGH, England  At a media conference a few years ago, the editor of The Guardian newspaper, contemplating the future of print, recalled his papers installation of its newest presses in 2005.

title: Brazil Tracks From Boom to Rust
description: Brazils economic boom bore big construction projects to empower its impoverished interior. But as the economy cools, many are unfinished, leaving a legacy of division and dislocation.

title: Pro-Russian Protesters Build Barricades
description: After seizing a police station in Slovyansk, Ukraine, pro-Russian protesters raised the banner of the Peoples Republic of Donetsk and constructed barricades around the station.

title: Grand Visions Fizzle in Brazil
description: Projects conceived in boom times stand abandoned, visible symbols of waste and the countrys crippling bureaucracy.

title: From Boom to Rust, Lavish Projects Are Languishing in Brazil
description: PAULISTANA, Brazil  Brazil plowed billions of dollars into building a railroad across arid backlands, only for the long-delayed project to fall prey to metal scavengers. Curvaceous new public buildings designed by the famed architect Oscar Niemeyer were abandoned right after being constructed. There was even an ill-fated U.F.O. museum built with federal funds. Its skeletal remains now sit like a lost ship among the weeds.

title: Its Taxing
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  As if we needed a reminder, todays puzzle by Dan Schoenholz provides us with a timely countdown to the April 15 deadline for filing our taxes. Fortunately its a funny reminder, which may help make the medicine go down a bit easier for some of us.

title: Obama Lets N.S.A. Exploit Some Internet Flaws, Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON  Stepping into a heated debate within the nations intelligence agencies, President Obama has decided that when the National Security Agency discovers major flaws in Internet security, it should  in most circumstances  reveal them to assure that they will be fixed, rather than keep mum so that the flaws can be used in espionage or cyberattacks, senior administration officials said Saturday.

title: How to Save $68,469 in Taxes
description: In some cases, collectors can avoid paying taxes on art they buy if they display it out of state before bringing it home. Here is how one collector navigated the system.

title: Tsunami Warning After Earthquake Strikes Near Solomon Islands
description: A strong earthquake struck offshore near the Solomon Islands in the Pacific Ocean on Sunday morning, causing officials to issue a tsunami warning for the area. There were no immediate reports of damage.

title: Conservatives Clash With G.O.P. Leaders on Hood County Water Needs
description: Since the beginning of the Tea Party movement in Texas in 2009, state Republicans have harnessed its appeal to voters who are demanding less government spending and more local control. But when it comes to water policy, a hotly debated issue given the states severe drought and growing needs, conservatives worry that establishment Republicans have not stuck to those principles.

title: Rivka Haut, Dies at 71; Championed Rights of Orthodox Jewish Women
description: Rivka Haut, a prominent champion of Orthodox Jewish women fighting for divorce in rabbinical courts and seeking to pray together as a group, died on March 30 in the Bronx. She was 71.

title: Rail Transport of Crude Oil Increases as Pipeline Falls Short
description: In December, a new terminal in the Port of Beaumont welcomed its first customer: a train carrying 43,000 barrels of crude oil from Colorado. Workers at the terminal, the Jefferson Transload Railport, transferred the crude to a barge, which traveled down the Neches River to a nearby refinery.

title: Augustas Designated Fill-In Bests Rory McIlroy
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Miguel ngel Jimnez, whose six-under-par 66 Saturday was the low round of the week, is one of seven players 50 or older who teed off Saturday at the Masters. There were six touring professionals and Jeff Knox, the tournament representative and course record-holder, who played as the marker for the two-time major champion Rory McIlroy, the 51st competitor to make the cut.

title: North Carolina Shows Strains Within G.O.P.
description: DURHAM, N.C.  There is a Tea Party candidate who talks about the Constitution and has the backing of Senator Rand Paul. There is a Baptist pastor, endorsed by Mike Huckabee, who wears a Jesus First lapel pin and has led the fight against same-sex marriage. And there is a Republican state lawmaker  supported by the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and $1 million from Karl Roves American Crossroads group  standing up for the party establishment.

title: Lingering Power of Hostage Crisis Short-Circuits Iranian Nominee
description: PARIS  When Iranian militants seized the United States Embassy and took dozens of Americans hostage on an overcast Sunday morning in November 1979, I assumed it was just a brief anti-American sit-in. My main concern, I told my editors at Newsweek, was not how dangerous Tehran would be. It was whether it would still be a story by the time I arrived there from Paris the next day.

title: Carol Grimaldi, Co-Founder of Lauded Brooklyn Pizzeria, Dies at 76
description: Carol Grimaldi, the co-owner with her husband, Pasquale, of the original Grimaldis Pizzeria in Brooklyn, which for many years was hailed as one of the best pizza restaurants in a city of pizza connoisseurs, died on Thursday in Queens. She was 76.

title: Revived Soriano Remains Consistently Streaky Force for Yankees
description: Alfonso Soriano was so successful in anticipating the start of his hot streak this season that he wondered whether he should apply those predictive skills to the lottery.

title: Schools Chancellor Details Initiatives for Schools
description: Schools Chancellor Carmen Faria on Saturday called for a back-to-basics approach to educating New York Citys 1.1 million public school students, and said she would work to reduce class sizes, curb the use of suspensions and pair more local universities and cultural institutions with public schools.

title: A Nightclub Reflecting 80s Dallas Is Revisited
description: Among Dallas residents of a certain age, the Starck Club is often recalled with a mix of nostalgia and wonder: How did such a thing ever exist?

title: Bubba Watson Falters, and a 20-Year-Old Ties for the Lead
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Experience is worth a couple of strokes at Augusta National Golf Club. Everybody says so, and sure enough, the top-10 leader board after 54 holes of the Masters includes two players past their 50th birthdays, Miguel ngel Jimnez and Fred Couples, as well as the 2012 champion, Bubba Watson.

title: Aid to Schools Is Goal of Push to Raise Taxes
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Thailands Political Tensions Are Rekindling Ethnic and Regional Divisions
description: LAMPHUN, Thailand  Each time Muean Chimoon leaves his wooden house in northern Thailand, he pays homage to a portrait of King Bhumibol Adulyadej, a father figure and long a symbol of national unity.

title: Search for Tiger Woodss Successor Skips a Generation
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Tiger Woods is missing from this years Masters, and so are all the people we once expected to replace him.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 12, 2014
description: April 12, 2014

title: Blue Grass Stakes Winner Isnt Likely to Run in Kentucky Derby
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.  Officials at Keeneland Race Course have been criticized for their decision to return to a dirt surface after their eight-year use of Polytrack led to a significant reduction in deaths. But the result of the Blue Grass Stakes on Saturday pointed to at least one reason for the change, which will occur at the end of the spring meet.

title: Damascus and Rebels Trade Blame in Gas Attack
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian state television and antigovernment activists reported Saturday that poison gas had been used in a rebel-held village in the central province of Hama, with each side blaming its enemies for an attack they both said sickened more than 100 people.

title: Knicks Playoff Hopes End as Hawks Cruise Past Heat
description: The end for the Knicks came in unlikely fashion on Saturday night, with the Atlanta Hawks beating the Miami Heat, of all teams, to nail down the eighth and final playoff spot in the Eastern Conference.

title: Xenophobic Chill Descends on Moscow
description: MOSCOW  The huge banner was unfurled on Friday morning outside one of Moscows biggest bookstores, Dom Knigi, a grand emporium of the written word on Novii Arbat Street across from a Citibank, a Baskin-Robbins and a Dunkin Donuts, and down the block from a big movie theater where the main feature at the moment is Captain America: The Winter Soldier.

title: Vows: The Perfect Fire
description: Susan Levin lost her lifes work of art and all her possessions when her house burned down in a wildfire. She ordered new things online  and fell in love with the FedEx delivery woman.

title: Fred Ho: The Music Lives On
description: The baritone saxophonist Fred Ho died on April 12th after a years-long battle with cancer. Mr. Hos music is known for straddling the line between classical and jazz.

title: Fred Ho, Composer and Musician in Popular Avant-Gard, Dies at 56
description: Fred Ho, a composer, saxophonist, writer and radical activist who composed politically charged operas, suites, oratorios and ballets that mixed jazz with popular and traditional elements of what he called Afro-Asian culture, died on Saturday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 56.

title: Flurry of Goals Gives Union First Title
description: PHILADELPHIA  Union College toppled the five-time champion Minnesota, 7-4, on Saturday at Wells Fargo Center to win its first N.C.A.A. mens hockey title.

title: My TEDx Talk: We Are Perfect, With a Hefty Asterisk
description: I just gave a talk at TEDx Portland  a daylong event focused on various interpretations of the word perfect.

title: The Triumph of Personal Style
description: The pressure to stick to one particular style in interior decorating can yield a space that looks good in photographs but isnt necessarily a particularly pleasant place to call home. Using his own Hamptons getaway as an example, the author makes the case for the considerations of real life.

title: Fawn Jiang, Brendan McGinty
description: Fawn Vera Jiang and Brendan John McGinty were married Saturday at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Sarah J. Ritchie, a Universal Brotherhood minister, officiated.

title: Rina Parmeshwar, Prabhu Balasubramanian
description: Dr. Rina Parmeshwar and Prabhu Shankar Balasubramanian are to be married Sunday morning at the Santa Clara Marriott in Santa Clara, Calif. Pandit Agoram Sivaramakrishnan will lead the ceremony with Krishnan Ganapathy Sastrigal participating; they are both Hindu priests.

title: John Gordon, Justin Zaremby
description: John Stuart Gordon and Justin Scott Zaremby were married Saturday at the Elizabethan Club, a private literary club in New Haven. Judge Jos A. Cabranes of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, for whom Dr. Zaremby served as a law clerk in 2010 and 2011, officiated.

title: Sarah Stein, Alex Koppelman
description: Sarah Jenny Stein and Alex Ritter Koppelman were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Lee Friedlander at Skylight One Hanson in Brooklyn.

title: Mary Allison, Louis Ferrara
description: Mary Patricia Allison and Louis Michael Ferrara were married Saturday at the home of Alfredo and Jennifer Dreyfus, a sister of the bride, in Gilbert, Ariz. John T. Johnson, a bishop of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, performed the ceremony.

title: Erica Fink, Arel Lidow
description: Erica Blair Fink, the daughter of Nancy F. Fink and Jonathan J. Fink of New York, was married Saturday evening to Arel Ives Lidow, a son of Diana D. Lidow and Derek B. Lidow of Princeton, N.J. Rabbi Jonathan A. Stein officiated at the Essex House in New York.

title: Kim Carlson, Jeanne Graham
description: Kim Elizabeth Carlson and Jeanne Jo Graham were married Saturday evening at the 112 Eatery Restaurant in Minneapolis. Kathryn L. Quaintance, a Hennepin County District Court judge in Minneapolis, officiated.

title: Candice Chiu, Alex Wong
description: Candice Chiu and Alex Nelson Wong were married Saturday evening at the DAR Memorial Continental Hall in Washington. The officiant was Sandra Day OConnor, the retired United States Supreme Court justice, for whom the bride was a clerk from July 2011 to July 2012. The couple met at Harvard, from which the bride graduated and each received a law degree.

title: Erin Muckey, Alexander Cavin
description: Erin Joy Muckey and Alexander William Cavin were married Saturday at the Beach Club at Sea Ranch Lakes in Sea Ranch Lakes, Fla. Joseph E. Falit, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Mock Trials Lead to Real Romance
description: Jessica Lynne Miller and Joshua Herbert Frost were married Saturday evening at the Bourne Mansion, an event space in Oakdale, N.Y. Justice Milton A. Tingling Jr., of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, officiated.

title: Sandra Sanchez, Jacob Angel
description: Sandra Sanchez, a daughter of Sandra L. Sanchez and Alejandro Sanchez of Chula Vista, Calif., was married Saturday evening to Jacob Daniel Angel, a son of Gail A. Angel and the Rev. Stephan E. Angel of Chicago. The grooms father, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at the Metropolitan Building in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Kimberly Resnick, Adam Thaler
description: Dr. Kimberly Sue Resnick, the daughter of Lanie Resnick and Gerald A. Resnick of New York, was married Saturday evening to Dr. Adam Michael Thaler, the son of Sharon Kitain Thaler and Dr. Bruce J. Thaler of Philadelphia. Rabbi Howard K. Cove officiated at the Ashford Estate, an event space in Allentown, N.J.

title: Christie Wilson, John Bonasera
description: Christie Michelle Wilson and John James Bonasera were married Saturday at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. The Rev. George M. Witt, a Roman Catholic priest and the pastor of the church, performed the ceremony.

title: Elizabeth Hyon, Aaron Rubin
description: Elizabeth Susan Hyon and Aaron Grant R Rubin were married Saturday evening at the Loeb Central Park Boathouse in New York. The Rev. Jesse D. Hendrich, a Spiritual Humanist minister, officiated.

title: Olivier Cassegrain, Troy Miller
description: Olivier Philippe Cassegrain and Robert Troy Miller were married Saturday in Paris at the city hall for the Seventh Arrondissement. The arrondissements mayor, Rachida Dati, officiated.

title: The Complete Package
description: Margie Ellen Ashley and Susan Barbara Levin are to be married Sunday at the Marin Art and Garden Center in Ross, Calif. Marsha R. Angus, a Universal Life minister, will officiate.

title: Kathleen Milazzo, Travis Johnson
description: Kathleen Marie Milazzo and Jay Travis Johnson were married Saturday evening at the Holy Family Catholic Church in Chicago. The Rev. Jeremiah M. Boland, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Webster University Clings to Its Title at Final Four
description: Chess had its own version of the Final Four last week, with Webster University of St. Louis taking the title, known as the Presidents Cup, for the second year in a row.

title: The Toddler Who Survived, and the Cop Who Became Her Mom
description: The bodies were discovered throughout the first-floor railroad flat in Brooklyn, a bizarre still-life of death. Many of the victims remained seated in chairs or couches; one womans hands still held a spoon and a small can of pudding.

title: Corrections: April 13, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Mets Absorb a Staggering Blow but Deliver the Final One
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Jose Valverde was crouched over, his hands on his knees, as he watched Raul Ibanezs three-run homer sail into the night. The shot, which tied the score at 6-6 in the bottom of the ninth, spoiled a solid start by Jon Niese and forced the weary Mets to play on.
