They had flown here from Atlanta two nights before, had battled the Los Angeles Angels for 11 innings and lost the previous night, and now this.

title: Climate Efforts Falling Short, U.N. Panel Says
description: BERLIN  Delivering the latest stark news about climate change on Sunday, a United Nations panel warned that governments are not doing enough to avert profound risks in coming decades. But the experts found a silver lining: Not only is there still time to head off the worst, but the political will to do so seems to be rising around the world.

title: In Our Pages: April 14
description: 1914: England Crushes France in Annual Rugby Match

title: Ukraine Forces Storm a Town, Defying Russia
description: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine  The Ukrainian government on Sunday for the first time sent its security services to confront armed pro-Russian militants in the countrys east, defying warnings from Russia. Commandos engaged in gunfights with men who had set up roadblocks and stormed a Ukrainian police station in Slovyansk, and at least one officer was killed, Ukrainian officials said.

title: Partial Afghan Results Portend a Runoff as Fraud Is Cited
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In the first official report of partial results from the Afghan presidential election, the candidates Abdullah Abdullah and Ashraf Ghani appeared to be leading a race in which a runoff election was increasingly certain, according to data released by the Independent Election Commission on Sunday.

title: I Have No Idea How Many Calories Are in My Grandmothers Gefilte Fish
description: Passover is coming, and so is my Nanna. At 98, an age when most of her contemporaries (Id say many of her contemporaries, except the truth is, Nanna has outlived most of her generation) are in bed or assisted living, my Nanna, Faye Frumin, will board a plane from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to Philadelphia, where she will supervise the ritual making of the gefilte fish, one of the centerpieces of the Seder feast.

title: Nations Handling of New Climate Report Presages Divisions in Treaty Effort
description: Justin Gilliss news story from Berlin on the latest report from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change  the one on the worlds options for limiting global warming  tells you all you need to know about the familiar contents. The chart of trending news in the United States above tells you all you need to know about how much people are tuning in. (Click to learn more about how Newsmap works.)

title: Bend It, Charge It, Dunk It: Graphene, the Material of Tomorrow
description: I just want to say one word to you. Just one word.

title: Coachella 2014: Day 2
description: The second day of this years music and arts festival in Indio, Calif., featured performances by Warpaint, Lorde and Pharrell Williams.

title: Whats on Sunday
description: 9 P.M. (MTV, Logo, VH1) 2014 MTV MOVIE AWARDS Conan OBrien, above, hosts this ceremony, broadcast live from the Nokia Theater at L.A. Live, which bestows Golden Popcorn statuettes on winners in best categories like kiss, villain, fight and shirtless performance. Andrew Garfield, Emma Stone and Jamie Foxx will unveil a sneak peek of The Amazing Spider-Man 2; Ellen Page will introduce a clip from X-Men Days of Future Past. Presenters include Lupita Nyongo, Jessica Alba, Chris Pratt, Seth Rogen, Seth MacFarlane, Mila Kunis, Shailene Woodley, Cameron Diaz, Leslie Mann, Kate Upton and Nicki Minaj. Mark Wahlberg will be honored with the annual MTV Generation Award. Eminem, Rihanna, Ellie Goulding, Zedd and Twenty One Pilots are scheduled to perform.

title: Monday Rush Will Test Pulaski Skyway Shutdown
description: Theplannedtwo-yearshutdown of the northbound lanes on the Pulaski Skyway faces its first major teston Mondaymorning as thousands of drivers in New Jersey turn toalternative routes or public transportation for travel between Newark and Jersey City.

title: An Artist Takes His Pay in Coffee and Community
description: David Ellis is painting what could be his biggest commission ever  assuming he lives long enough, since hes being paid in coffee and tobacco.

title: A Letdown in London for a British Olympic Champion
description: LONDON  If it had gone in the storybook fashion that much of Britain willed, Mo Farah, a hero for winning the 5,000 and 10,000 meters at the 2012 London Olympics and the 2013 world championships, would have won on his marathon debut here Sunday.

title: Slide Show: Scenes From Coachella
description: Photographs from the second day of the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival in Indio, Calif.

title: Cartoon Birds Cant Stop Captain America
description: Rio 2 got its wings a bit clipped at the weekend box office by a still-speeding superhero, while Kevin Costner was humiliated by a micro-budgeted horror flick. Captain America: The Winter Soldier (Walt Disney Studios) was the No. 1 movie in North America for the second weekend in a row, taking in an estimated $41.4 million, for a two-week domestic total of $159 million, according to Rentrak, which compiles ticketing data. Rio 2 (20th Century Fox), an animated avian musical, was close behind with a solid $39 million, on par with the opening-weekend total for its series predecessor. But analysts and Fox, which backed Rio 2 with a sizzling social media marketing campaign, had been predicting slightly higher totals. Excellent weather across the middle of the country and the Northeast suppressed grosses in general yesterday and especially for matinees, Chris Aronson, Foxs president of domestic distribution, wrote in an email on Sunday morning. Rio 2 has unusually light animated competition in the weeks ahead, Mr. Aronson noted.

title: Liverpool Closes In on Championship That It Last Won 24 Years Ago
description: LIVERPOOL, England  They sang Youll Never Walk Alone and We Shall Not Be Moved and, over and over, Liiiiiverpool. The fans at Anfield seemed never to go quiet once the game began on Sunday, and soon, perhaps, they will sing about being champions.

title: Pistorius Versus the Pit Bull: Fierce Prosecutor Shares Stage
description: PRETORIA, South Africa  It was a corruption trial that had transfixed South Africa, and the prosecutor was in no mood for mercy. The defendant was the nations top police official, a figure of such international stature that he had once led Interpol. But when he took the stand, his testimony  his wife, he said, had accidentally shredded evidence  was rejected outright by his inquisitor.

title: Fire Races Through Hills of Chilean Port City
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  A voracious fire that spread through the hills of the port city of Valparaso left at least 12 people dead and more than 500 families homeless on Sunday, a day after it forced the evacuation of thousands of others.

title: Diving Into the Strange, Retrieving Its Beauty
description: The pianist Jeremy Denk recently picked up the prestigious Avery Fisher Prize to go along with the MacArthur Foundation fellowship that he received last year. This is what you call being on a roll. These honors were in recognition not just of his excellence as a pianist but also of his adventurousness as an artist. Both qualities were on display on Saturday night, when Mr. Denk played a recital at Washington Irving High School, part of the very affordable Peoples Symphony Concerts series.

title: Somber Army in Blue Gathers in Queens to Mourn a Fallen Officer
description: They slipped hands into white gloves and shed blue caps, smoothed gold-buttoned uniforms and fell into a hush, one by one, as they joined the long line of police officers filing into the funeral home. Passing the flowers and the children dressed in black, they paused at the open coffin of their fellow officer, whose shield number  5711  glittered in gold from a badge-shaped wreath of white flowers.

title: ECO 348, The Great Recession: Unemployment, Structural or Cyclical?
description: Slides here (pdf).

title: The Kentucky Derby Dartboard: Week 3
description: Update: Constitution, the undefeated winner of the Florida Derby, will miss the Kentucky Derby and the other Triple Crown races because of a shin fracture, said Elliott Walden, president and chief executive of WinStar Farm. Also, the trainer Kiaran McLaughlin withdrew Cairo Prince from consideration because of an injury to his left front ankle.

title: Ellsbury Batting Third for Yankees Without Fitting Profile
description: Paul ONeill. Don Mattingly. Mickey Mantle.

title: Deadly Flames in Chile
description: A fire that swept through the hills of Valparaso in Chile left at least 11 dead and charred homes and cars in its wake. President Michelle Bachelet called in troops to maintain order.

title: Surge in Narcotic Prescriptions for Pregnant Women
description: Doctors are prescribing opioid painkillers to pregnant women in astonishing numbers, new research shows, even though risks to the developing fetus are largely unknown.

title: Visiting Another Country, No Longer Heard From
description: A quarter-century has passed since the Berlin Wall came down and the German Democratic Republic disappeared. Thats more than half the life span of the East German state, a smoke-and-mirrors contraption conjured from the rubble of World War II that has become, for those who lived there, an increasingly distant and improbable memory.

title: What a Foul Mouth You Have, Grandma
description: The nervous young man has almost escaped from the funeral reception when the genteel widow thanks him for coming. Its only decent to offer a kind word about her husband.

title: A Showcase Highlights Newcomers Evolution
description: For artists known as emerging, what determines when theyve emerged? Experience? Recognition? Number of grant applications completed?

title: Man Kills 3 at Jewish Centers in Kansas City Suburb
description: A man opened fire outside a Jewish Community Center and a nearby retirement community in a suburb of Kansas City, Mo., on Sunday afternoon, killing three people before he was taken into custody.

title: Investigative Reporter Leaves NBC News
description: Michael Isikoff, an investigative reporter who has broken numerous national news stories, has left NBC News. His last day was Friday.

title: Fouttes and Pirouettes to the Southern Banjo and Fiddle
description: Tradition is a guide, not a jailer. That quotation from W. Somerset Maugham is the motto of the Carolina Chocolate Drops, an African-American string band.

title: A Feast With Some Unusual Pairings
description: In the parlance of Youth America Grand Prix, a ballet convention and competition now in its 15th year, one purpose of its gala shows is for its young participants, the stars of tomorrow, to be inspired by the stars of today, the ballet luminaries who perform. The young dancers watching the closing night celebration at the David H. Koch Theater on Friday, an affair more than three hours long, could be inspired without being dispirited by flawlessness.

title: Mussing Up a White-Linen-Tablecloth Vibe With Jazz Provocation
description: The standout tune in the early set at Mintons in Harlem on Wednesday night was a new one, Brainlifter, composed by the drummer Jeff (Tain) Watts and briskly demolished by his four-piece band. Built over a gear-shifting groove, it was a maze full of trapdoors through which Mr. Watts and his crew barreled with aplomb. Only during a forcefully swinging tenor-saxophone solo by Troy Roberts did the action on the bandstand begin to feel like a developing story rather than an unassailably sturdy truth.

title: On Shaky Ground
description: The 1989 earthquake that shook San Francisco sent out a wake-up call that continues to echo across the country.

title: Leading the Honor at the Imp Pairs in Dallas
description: DALLAS  Scott Levine and Aaron Silverstein of New York City entered the last session of the Lebhar Imp Pairs on March 22 in the lead at the Spring North American Championships here. In that session, though, their opponents held most of the cards and made few mistakes. Levine and Silverstein slipped to sixth.

title: Awards for Jennifer Lopez and Norman Lear
description: Jennifer Lopez and Norman Lear were among those honored at the 25th annual Glaad Media Awards presented on Saturday in Los Angeles by the group formerly known as the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation. Ms. Lopez was given the Vanguard Award in recognition of her efforts to increase the visibility and understanding of gays, lesbians, bisexuals and the transgendered. She is also an executive producer on the ABC Family series The Fosters, which focuses on a lesbian couple and their children and was named outstanding drama series. Mr. Lear, who produced television series like All in the Family and The Jeffersons was the recipient of the Pioneer Award. The actress and transgender activist Laverne Cox received the Stephen F. Kolzak Award for her work in the Netflix series Orange Is the New Black. Other honorees included the Canadian pop duo Tegan and Sara for their album Heartthrob; the comic book series Young Avengers, by Kieron Gillen, Jamie McKelvie and Mike Norton from Marvel Comics; and Fuses reality series Big Freedia: Queen of Bounce. More awards are to be presented on May 3 at a ceremony in New York City.

title: Choreographer Named to Montclair State Project
description: The choreographer Heidi Latsky has been selected as the first participant in a new short film series focusing on dance and choreography. The project, Dance for Film on Location at Montclair State University, in New Jersey, will be underwritten by a $450,000 grant from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation and is to include three films by three different choreographers. The other two participants will be named later. Each work will be shown along with a live repertory that will become part of Peak Performances at Montclair State. In a statement, Jedediah Wheeler, the executive director of Peak Performances, said that the project is designed so that the camera will not be used as a tool to document a performance, but rather as a collaborator to create a dance especially for film.

title: Another Vote for Colbert
description: Conan OBrien has joined the choir of late night television hosts who have praised CBSs decision to name Stephen Colbert as the successor to David Letterman on Late Show. Mr. OBrien told The Associated Press on Friday while backstage at a rehearsal for the MTV Movie Awards that Mr. Colbert is fantastic, and that he was looking forward to his work on Late Show. Im glad that its the right person getting it, he said. Jimmy Fallon, the host of The Tonight Show on NBC, and Jimmy Kimmel, the host of his own show on ABC, had already voiced their approval of Mr. Colberts appointment. Mr. OBrien, who hosted The Tonight Show for seven months before he was replaced by Jay Leno in 2010, denied any speculation that he had been a candidate for the Late Show appointment. I wasnt up for it, Mr. OBrien said and added that he was happy with his show, Conan, on TBS, which was renewed last year through November 2015. I get to do what I want, he said.

title: Poised on the Cusp of Womanhood
description: Hyerin Lee, a dancer with LeeSaar the Company, is the first to appear onstage at the Baryshnikov Arts Center. Sitting on the floor with a knee bent in front of her torso, she gazes soulfully into a high corner of the space like a model whose motivation is to ponder the Dalai Lama. A spotlight, aimed at her, grows to fill the entire stage. While Stravinskys Apollo plays, she alternates between dreamy, beatific poses  touching her head, she angles her chin with razor precision  and self-inflicted thrashing. She smacks her ribs with her elbows.

title: Promises of Preparedness Followed Devastating Earthquakes. And Yet.
description: It is hard to imagine any people, collectively, being better prepared for earthquakes than the Japanese. Their country is one long seismic zone, which at any moment could, literally, rock and roll. Every Sept. 1, across the archipelago, Japanese engage in exercises devoted to disaster awareness: what to do should the worst happen. The occasion resonates with history. On that date in 1923, the Great Kanto earthquake devastated Tokyo and nearby Yokohama, unleashing fire and fury that left more than 100,000 people dead. After that, Japan resolved that it would prepare for whatever cataclysm nature might throw at it.

title: Two Works That Challenge a Pianist to Go the Distance
description: Its not a very good piece, the gentleman sitting behind me at Carnegie Hall pronounced on Wednesday evening after Mitsuko Uchida had performed Schuberts Piano Sonata in G (D. 894). From the same source, after Ms. Uchida had played the other work on the program, Beethovens 33 Variations on a Waltz by Diabelli (Op. 120), came the verdict, Thats a great piece.

title: Bringing Shostakovich Off the Bench
description: When David Samuel, the violist of the Ensemble MidtVest, took ill just a few hours before the groups performance on Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, his colleagues scrambled to replace him. They found a willing musician, Gregory Luce, but they simply didnt have time to rehearse with a newbie the two planned works with viola.

title: Death Knell for Opera in San Diego After 49 Years
description: SAN DIEGO  Molly Whittaker is a chorus member with the San Diego Opera, where she has performed for almost 10 years. But the other evening she could be found outside the opera hall, wearing a bright red T-shirt reading Fight for San Diego Opera, and thrusting pamphlets and stickers at patrons as they arrived for a performance of Massenets Don Quixote.

title: Maestro Stands In, Despite Protests
description: The two programs of the Munich Philharmonic Orchestra at Carnegie Hall over the weekend, in their ambition, their grandiosity and their striving for effect, spoke eloquently of the musical personality of their planner, Lorin Maazel, the ensembles music director since 2012. It was Munichs favorite son, Richard Strauss, all the way, on the 150th anniversary of his birth, with a grandiloquent work on each program: Also Sprach Zarathustra on Friday evening and Ein Heldenleben on Saturday.

title: A Playwright Seeks Healing With His Work
description: Marcus Gardley had been rewriting through the night. The next morning, it was time for a pep talk to the five actors in a scruffy rehearsal space who were clutching Draft 18 of The Box: A Black Comedy, his satire about black men and prisons both literal and metaphorical.

title: Pacers Can Still Be No. 1, Even After Floundering
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Sunday was Fan Appreciation Day at Bankers Life Fieldhouse, and before the Pacers took on the Oklahoma City Thunder, several Indiana players addressed the crowd, thanking fans for their support this season and imploring them to be loud during the game.

title: Famous Debate Words
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  I believe I could safely wager that crossword puzzle solvers are probably the most pedantic when it comes to spelling errors. I know this because all I have to do is make a typo in this space, and there are many sharp-eyed readers who are, shall we say, willing to help me find it. And thats totally fine, really. If ever there should be a place where words are spelled correctly, it should be a blog about the crossword puzzle.

title: The Precarious Foundation of a Dream House
description: Richard Maxwell looks at the world with X-ray eyes. Watching the plays of this rigorously inventive auteur, we are encouraged to see the plasterboard behind the wallpaper, the skin under the greasepaint and the skulls beneath the skin. Or in the case of Isolde, his smashing new work at the Abrons Arts Center, the beams and blueprints  and light and air  that go into the imagining of something as substantial and transitory as a dream house. Or, come to think of it, a play.

title: More Higher-Priced Deals
description: Companies are staying private longer and investors are eager to write big checks. As a result, enormous venture capital rounds are becoming common.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 60
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Treasury Auctions for the Week of April 14
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday and an auction of five-year inflation-protected securities on Thursday.

title: Suicide Prevention Sheds a Longstanding Taboo: Talking About Attempts
description: The relationship had become intolerably abusive, and after a stinging phone call one night, it seemed there was only one way to end the pain. Enough wine and pills should do the job  and would have, except that paramedics barged through the door, alerted by her lover.

title: For Grown-Up Watson, the Jacket Still Fits
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  A few hours before he went out to try to win a second green jacket, Bubba Watson conducted a Masters trivia contest Sunday for his million-plus Twitter followers. The game helped unclutter Watsons mind and clarify his purpose. One of the questions asked how many of the last 23 champions had come from the final pairing.

title: Shots Fired in Kramatorsk
description: Men dressed in camouflage and armed with assault rifles fired on the Police Headquarters in Kramatorsk, Ukraine, on Saturday.

title: An Institution Exploring the Political Left Is Closing
description: For nearly 40 years the Brecht Forum has held classes, lectures, symposiums, musical performances and art exhibitions, all organized around the aim of examining the role of the political left in American society.

title: Elections in India
description: But many of the faces remain the same.

title: Big Banks Earnings Reports, and E.U. to Act on Bank Laws
description: MORE BANKS TO REPORT FIRST-QUARTER EARNINGS

title: My Ideas, My Bosss Property
description: SAN DIEGO  THE big story in Silicon Valley these days is a class-action lawsuit alleging that several major tech companies, including Google and Apple, agreed not to try to hire away one anothers employees  thereby hindering workers from seeking out better-paying jobs.

title: Secret Drugs, Agonizing Deaths
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  FACING a critical shortage of lethal injection drugs, prison officials in a number of states have recently engaged in an unseemly scramble to obtain new execution drugs, often from unreliable and even illegal sources. Not only does this trend raise serious questions about the constitutionality of executions, it also undermines the foundations of our democratic process. In the name of security, states are now withholding vital information about their death penalty procedures  from death row prisoners lawyers and from judges, whose stamp of approval they need to impose the ultimate sanction, as well as from the public, in whose name the sentence is carried out.

title: Surviving the Finish Line
description: Runners, spectators and volunteers who were at the finish line of the Boston Marathon when the bombs exploded reflect on how their lives have been affected. Here are their stories of transformation.

title: Series of Bombings Kills More Than 20 Across Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  Militants with the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria gained control of the main road that links Baghdad with the northern provinces for a short time on Sunday, while a series of explosions around Iraq left up to 25 dead, according to security forces.

title: Paying Extra for a Plastic Bag for Your Groceries
description: To the Editor:

title: Local News, Off College Presses
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  In January, residents here learned the news that the senior place-kicker for the University of Michigans football team had been permanently separated from the college for violating its student sexual misconduct policy. In addition, the violation, what the authorities said was a sexual assault, occurred in 2009, when the kicker was a freshman, and his punishment was not determined until his athletic career had ended this past winter.

title: Deportations for Minor Offenses
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: A Question for Seder: What Role for Screens?
description: For many Jewish families, this Passover night will indeed be different from all others.

title: Happiness and Its Discontents
description: I.

title: Bruins Coach Eschews Negativity and Builds Winners
description: BOSTON  On the first Monday of April 2007, the Devils had a 47-24-8 record. They were in first place in the Atlantic Division with the second-best record in the Eastern Conference. They had won four of their past five games and appeared well positioned for a deep playoff run.

title: In New York, Hard Choices on Health Exchange Spell Success
description: In contrast with the early stumbles in most of the country, New York State, almost from the start, has provided a textbook lesson in how to make the Affordable Care Act work. But it has done so by making some tough decisions.

title: Sanctions Are Eased; Iran Sees Little Relief
description: Halfway through a six-month nuclear deal between Iran and major world powers that was meant to allow time to reach a comprehensive agreement, the Iranians have seen little in the way of a boost from the sanctions relief they had been expecting, trade lawyers and diplomatic analysts say.

title: 3 Straight Homers Set Off Angels Rout
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Mets starter Bartolo Colon adjusted his cap, fiddled with his belt and kicked the dirt as the Los Angeles Angels Raul Ibanez rounded the bases. The fans at Angel Stadium were on their feet, cheering. In a stretch of seven pitches in the bottom of the first inning on Sunday, three Angels connected for solo home runs: Mike Trout, Albert Pujols and Ibanez.

title: Obama Effect Inspiring Few to Seek Office
description: LUDLOW, Mass.  Eric Lesser was shaking hands with diners in a Portuguese restaurant last week when he spotted the owner of Mannys TV & Appliances. Oh, Ive got to get a picture, Mr. Lesser eagerly said, draping his arm over Manny Rovithis, whose low-budget commercials have run for decades in Western Massachusetts. Mr. Lessers giddiness about meeting the local celebrity had not faded when he sat down for lunch.

title: The Poetry of the Trading Floor, Going Beyond Bears and Bulls
description: LONDON  Finance is such a picturesque business, but nobody seems to notice.

title: Three Expensive Milliseconds
description: Four years ago Chris Christie, the governor of New Jersey, abruptly canceled Americas biggest and arguably most important infrastructure project, a desperately needed new rail tunnel under the Hudson River. Count me among those who blame his presidential ambitions, and believe that he was trying to curry favor with the government- and public-transit-hating Republican base.

title: Tightness in Jeters Leg Keeps Him Out for Second Game in a Row
description: Derek Jeter was held out of Sundays lineup for a second straight day after Manager Joe Girardi revealed that Jeter experienced tightness in his right quadriceps during the Yankees 4-2 loss to the Red Sox on Friday.

title: Yahoo Rolls the Dice on TV
description: Yahoo, a company that seems like a permanent adolescent in search of an identity, is about to try a new persona: high-quality television programmer.

title: Win No. 688 May Be Brodeurs Last as a Devil
description: NEWARK  Amid a sea of fans wearing red and black plus a smattering of old-school Devils green, goaltender Martin Brodeur played perhaps his final game for the franchise, a 3-2 victory Sunday against the Bruins.

title: Beaming Good Cheer to a Norwegian Towns Dark Days
description: RJUKAN, Norway  Yearning for sunlight has been a part of life in this quaint old factory town in central Norway for as long as anyone can remember. Here, the sun disappears behind a mountain for six months of the year.

title: The College Faculty Crisis
description: The public colleges and universities that educate more than 70 percent of this countrys students were burdened by rising costs and dwindling state revenues long before the recession. They reacted by raising tuition, slashing course offerings and, sometimes, by cutting enrollment.

title: Rich Start-Ups Go Back for Another Helping
description: Quora, a question-and-answer website, didnt need to raise money. It had barely touched $60 million in venture capital that it accepted just two years ago.

title: A Gossipy Newsletter Aims Higher
description: LONDON  Every Thursday the Popbitch newsletter, written in a typewriter font redolent of the early Internet, lands in the inboxes of hundreds of thousands people in Britain and around the world.

title: Seeking a Plan to Rein In the Floodwaters Through the South Mountain Reservation
description: MILLBURN, N.J.  Striding through the South Mountain Reservation, a patch of wilderness in an otherwise highly developed corner of New Jersey, Fred R. Profeta Jr. does not see the stands of oaks and maples or the shimmering streams so much as their absence.

title: Keep the Carriage Horses
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio noted his 100th day in office last week with a big speech and a proud recitation of campaign promises kept: universal prekindergarten, an end to unconstitutional policing, paid sick leave, among other things. There is one prominent pledge he would do better to break.

title: A Year After the Boston Marathon Bombings, Injured Brothers Endure
description: STONEHAM, Mass.  When two bombs transformed last years Boston Marathon into a war zone, the Norden family absorbed a double dose of grief. J. P., 34, and his brother Paul, 32, both strapping construction workers in their prime who were there to cheer on a friend, each lost a leg in the carnage.

title: Echoes of the Superpredator
description: Remember superpredators? Nearly 20 years ago, they prowled into the American consciousness  a menacing new breed of children, born of crack-addled mothers and absent fathers, and programmed solely for murder and mayhem.

title: With One Eye on Playoffs, Nets Use Late Flurry to Dispatch Magic
description: As the Nets enter the final days of the regular season, signs point to their focus already having turned toward the playoffs.

title: Discontent Swells as President of Algeria Seeks a Fourth Term
description: ALGIERS  With a presidential election on Thursday, most Algerians see a fourth term for the incumbent, Abdelaziz Bouteflika, as a foregone conclusion.

title: Saying Farewell to a Business That Turned Into an Identity
description: On his last day as a company man, Marty Singer braced himself for the final drive to the office. It was Friday morning. The clock was ticking. But he couldnt bear to go.

title: The Buck Shops Here
description: The actual floor space $1 will buy in a range of neighborhoods across America.

title: Liz Norden
description: You dont know what your place is. You want to help them, but you know they want to do it on their own too, Ms. Norden said of her two sons.

title: Legal But Not Fair (Hungary)
description: A new post from my Princeton colleague Kim Lane Scheppele, about how 45 percent of the popular vote turned into a two-thirds supermajority for Fidesz.

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday, April 14, 2014
description: We cannot afford to lose another decade. If we lose another decade, it becomes extremely costly to achieve climate stabilization.

title: There Goes the Neighborhood
Spieth Falters and Youth Movement Stalls on Back Nine
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  The average age of the Masters spectators is somewhere above 40. It is a settled, mature group. That made it easy to spot the fans in attendance Sunday who were in their 20s or even younger. But there was another reason they were noticeable.

title: Prisoner to Face Parole Board as Questions Grow About His Conviction
description: Robert Hill, a former Crown Heights drug dealer, was convicted of murder in 1988 on the word of a serial eyewitness hooked on crack.

title: In New Officers Careers, Peace Is No Dividend
description: WEST POINT, N.Y.  Col. Jeff Lieb, the deputy commandant of the United States Military Academy and a veteran of the war in Iraq, paced before a group of cadets standing in formation and shouted at them about their lives after graduation.

title: Pedestrian Seriously Injured by Police Car
description: A 69-year-old man was seriously injured when he was struck by a New York City police car Sunday afternoon on the Upper West Side, the authorities and witnesses said.

description: April 13, 2014

title: Seeking Bargains, Red Sox Secure Bullpen Insurance
description: Each teams off-season begins with pages full of names, players identified as being available through free agency or potentially available through a trade. As clubs pore over data and analyze their budgets, these pages are whittled down to a simple shortlist.

title: Americans Wish for Iranian Burial Riles Hard-Liners
description: TEHRAN  Richard Nelson Frye, a renowned American scholar of Iran who died last month in Boston at 94, wanted to be buried at a spot in this country where songbirds sing and dry desert breezes cool the slow afternoons.

title: Amid Charges of Hypocrisy, Louisiana Lawmaker Faces Calls to Step Down
description: WEST MONROE, La.  As she handed out garbage bags on Saturday as part of an anti-litter drive, Patsy Edmondson drew a parallel to Louisianas history of tawdry politics.

title: Stepping Into the Shoes of a Ravaged Singer
description: When Billie Holiday sang, history attests, her audiences tended to clam up. Even in the bustling nightclubs where she mostly performed, Holiday often insisted on total quiet before she would open her mouth. The quiet usually held, as one of the great singers of the last century turned jazz songs and standards into searching, and searing, portraits of life and love gone wrong that cast a shimmering spell.

title: Game of Thrones Recap: What a Wonderful Wedding
description: Here be spoilers, and analysis that probably qualifies as obsessive, in a clinical sense.

title: Ron Pundak, a Key Israeli in Oslo Accords, Dies at 59
description: JERUSALEM  Ron Pundak, an Israeli academic who took part in secret talks with Palestinian officials that led to the Oslo peace accords of the 1990s and who remained an ardent advocate for peace even after relations between the sides unraveled, died on Friday in Tel Aviv. He was 59.

title: Concussion Cases Inspire New Course at George Washingtons Law School
description: WASHINGTON  The revelations that hits to the head may lead to long-term brain damage have rocked the football world at all levels, alarming coaches, players and their parents and forcing the N.F.L. and the N.C.A.A. to tighten safety standards.

title: The Art of Something From Nothing
description: SEATTLE  Entrepreneurs are lucky to have one big score. Richard Barton has had a string of them, by repeatedly asking the same simple question: What piece of marketplace information do people crave and dont have?

title: Prominent Lawyer Will Plead Guilty to Impeding the I.R.S.
description: Stanley L. Cohen, a prominent lawyer who has represented Lower East Side squatters, political activists and terrorism suspects, announced on Sunday that he is planning to plead guilty this week to a charge of impeding the Internal Revenue Service.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Maxwell House, Aiming to Reclaim Coffee Crown, Starts Makeover
description: THOUGH it has been said that Good is the enemy of great, Maxwell House coffee  a pantry staple promoted as Good to the last drop for almost a century  is remaking its marketing by celebrating good as an antidote to the hyperbole of an era awash in OMG and Win!

title: Focus Is on Crystal Ball as Knicks Get Past Bulls
description: With the Knicks eliminated from the playoffs, their fate no longer hinges on wins and losses. The focus is on their future: who will be part of it, and who will not.

title: Corrections: April 14, 2014
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Popular Demand
description: Viewers watched on-demand television programming an average of 8.7 hours a month in 2013, according to Rentrak. Free broadcast and cable TV shows accounted for 6.4 of those hours. Most viewers, 66 percent, watched a show at least four days after it was originally broadcast.

title: Photo Replay: April 6-12
description: Whether in the heat of battle or the exuberance of celebration, having a leg up on the competition can be an advantageous position.

title: In Monte Carlo, the First All-Organic Restaurant to Receive a Michelin Star
description: In Monaco, carrots just might be the new caviar. For me, luxury is eating baby peas that were picked an hour earlier or maybe a carrot that was just pulled out of the ground, says the chef Paolo Sari, whose cooking at Elsa  a sunny restaurant at the suavely bohemian, India Mahdavi-designed Monte Carlo Beach Hotel  recently won him the first Michelin star ever awarded to a 100 percent organic establishment.

title: Opportunity for All and Social Innovation: Obamas Policy Agenda
description: Laura DAndrea Tyson is a professor at the Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley, and headed the Council of Economic Advisers and the National Economic Council under President Bill Clinton. Jonathan Greenblatt is a special assistant to President Obama and director of the Office of Social Innovation and Civic Participation at the White House.

title: A Number That May Not Add Up
description: In July 1998, the National Institutes of Health changed what it means to be overweight, defining it as a body mass index of 25 or greater for adults. The cutoff had been 28 for men and 27 for women, so suddenly about 29 million Americans who had been considered normal became overweight even though they hadnt gained an ounce.

title: A Chance for Retro Reinvention
description: For the Mad Men protagonist, Don Draper, the melancholy if alluring young widow he met on a plane ride in Sundays season premiere could be just a passing flirtation or perhaps a new flame who will share in his extramarital escapades.

title: Yankees Find Another First Baseman in a Pinch, Then Beat Boston
description: The Yankees signed Carlos Beltran this off-season to help bolster their offense. On Sunday night, the Yankees also needed Beltran to help save their infield defense. Beltran made his career debut at first base after several injuries had left Manager Joe Girardi with a ravaged roster.

title: India Election Digest: April 14
description: What you need to know on Monday about Indias elections: The chief minister of West Bengal asks voters not to back the Bharatiya Janata Party, a study shows economic activity tends to slow before national elections, and a candidate in Rajasthan has generated a buzz with his campaign promise.

title: Whats on Monday
description: 10 P.M. (13) THE TRIALS OF MUHAMMAD ALI (2013) In 1967  after changing his name from Cassius Clay, joining the Nation of Islam and refusing to be inducted into the United States military because of his religious opposition to the Vietnam War  Muhammad Ali, above, was convicted of draft evasion. Stripped of his world heavyweight championship and banned from boxing, he spent the next four years fighting legal battles. In 1971, his case for being a conscientious objector reached the United States Supreme Court. In this Independent Lens presentation, the director Bill Siegel combines interviews with Louis Farrakhan; Mr. Alis second wife, Khalilah Camacho-Ali; the journalist Robert Lipsyte; Mr. Alis loyal brother, Rahman; and a clerk from the Supreme Court proceedings to address Mr. Alis challenges then and now, including his battle with Parkinsons. The film falls short of explaining Mr. Ali, who, like many outspoken individuals, can stubbornly repel scrutiny, nor will it pacify the many who opposed his conscientious objections, Nicolas Rapold wrote in The New York Times. But it also underlines one enduring quality: namely, that he probably couldnt care less what people think.

title: Despite Frustrating Week, McIlroy Meets His Diminished Goal
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  At the start of the week, nothing short of a Masters victory would do for Rory McIlroy, the former world No. 1 from Northern Ireland. After a five-over-par 77 in the second round, he revised his goals, lowering the bar to try to clear the top 15. That would beat his career best here, a tie for 15th in 2011, when McIlroy entered the final round with the lead.

He was 62.

title: Searchers to Deploy Submersible in Hunt for Missing Jet
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  The lead coordinator of the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 said Monday that after six days without detecting any further underwater signals that could be from the planes flight recorders, searchers planned to take the hunt to the dark depths of the Indian Ocean, deploying a submersible vehicle to scan the seabed for any signs of wreckage.

title: Saab in Talks to Buy ThyssenKrupp Shipyard Operations
description: LONDON  The Swedish military contractor Saab said on Monday that it was in talks to buy ThyssenKrupps shipbuilding operations in Sweden.

title: Last Night to Bend the Rules
description: Welcome to the secret world of the bachelorette party. For you first-timers, please, dont be alarmed. There is a set of rituals that transpire throughout the evening, starting with ensuring that you have relinquished any responsibilities that may distract you from having fun: check. Getting yourself pampered and dressed up more provocatively than for the average night out: check. And most important, figuring out how to get the bride-to-be to enjoy her final moments of being an unmarried woman.

title: After Delays, Syria Completes Another Shipment of Chemical Arms
description: GENEVA  After lengthy delays in loading its chemical weapons for destruction abroad, Syria has completed delivery of another shipment that brings the total to almost two-thirds of its arsenal, the international watchdog overseeing the process reported on Monday.

title: Ardian to Sell Food Ingredients Maker to Symrise for $1.8 Billion
description: LONDON  Symrise of Germany has offered to buy the Diana Group, a maker of food ingredients, from the private equity firm Ardian for 1.3 billion euros, or about $1.8 billion.

description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: New York Today: Casting a Warm Spell
description: Good morning on this warm, breezy Monday.

title: Arrest Order for Fugitive Hong Kong Tycoon Reaffirmed
description: A Hong Kong judge declined on Monday to set aside an arrest warrant for a local newspaper tycoon who fled to Taiwan 36 years ago after being charged with drug trafficking.

title: Ukraine Falters in Drive to Curb Unrest in East
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Ukraines failure to enforce its own ultimatums and its appeal on Monday to the United Nations to send peacekeepers laid bare a grim reality for the shaky government in Kiev, where political leaders and security forces have few reliable ways to confront Russian-backed separatists in the restive east.

title: Huge New York Development Project Becomes a Data Science Lab
description: Hudson Yards is a huge estate development project, the largest in New York since Rockefeller Center. It is to include office towers, apartments, shops, a luxury hotel, a public school and acres of public space. Construction began at the end of 2012, and has picked up recently.

title: What I Learned About Business as a South Georgia Bottom Fisher
description: When I tell people the first business lesson I ever learned was with Louisiana Pinks, they often think I was in the nail polish or lipstick businesses, or maybe rose bushes. Sorry, not at the age of 15 living in rural southern Georgia. I was in none of those businesses. I was selling worms.

title: Looking Back at the Publishing Beat With Julie Bosman
description: Julie Bosman recently wrote about the declining number of bookstores in New York City. Before she decamps to Chicago to become one of our Midwest correspondents, we asked her to reflect on the state of the publishing industry and share some of her reading habits.

title: City Says Water Meets Safety Standards, But Residents Remain Cautious
description: Officials in the northwestern Chinese city of Lanzhou have declared that a faulty pipeline was repaired and that the water supply now meets safety standards, days after tests showed levels of a cancer-causing chemical more than 20 times national safety limits.

title: Silicon Valleys Funding Feast
description: There can never be too much money in the bank. Such appears to be the thinking behind a new dynamic that is reshaping Silicon Valley. Start-ups, already flush with cash, are piling on investment dollars, David Gelles and Michael J. de la Merced write in DealBook. Of the 100 largest venture capital fund-raising rounds on record, 88 were issued within the last five years, according to CrunchBase, which tracks venture funding. Each delivered more than $50 million to the companies.

description: Spending a night in an airplane cabin is hardly the path to a luminous complexion and tidy hair. At 30,000 feet, your skin is more likely to resemble a lizards. But there are ways for business executives to look and feel polished when walking off a plane and into a boardroom.

title: A Taste of Asia in the Heart of Europe
description: LONDON  Its the south bank of the Thames, not the Himalayas. But the view should be great, anyway.

title: Citi Profit Exceeds Forecasts
description: Investors and analysts feared the worst from Citigroup, the global bank that has been besieged for months by regulatory problems and an industrywide trading slump.

title: Obamacare, The Unknown Ideal, Continued
description: The current state of public opinion on health reform is really peculiar. If youve been following the issue at all closely, you know that the Affordable Care Act is one of the great comeback stories of public policy: after a terrible start, it has dramatically exceeded expectations. But hardly anyone seems to know that.

title: Lessons for the Largest Democracy From a Much Smaller One
description: MUMBAI  A couple of weeks ago, I thought of Tony, a burly, cheerful, Costa Rican who drove a friend and me in his Toyota south along the highway from the Tortuguero National Park to the border with Panama. In fluent if ungrammatical English he told us he was taking us somewhere that would tell us more about his country, one of the longest-running democracies in Central America.

description: David Gelles and Michael J. de la Merced report that across Silicon Valley, start-ups, already flush with cash, are piling on the investment dollars.

description: The large retirement investment firm TIAA-CREF said on Monday that it had agreed to buy Nuveen Investments, an investment management firm, for about $6.25 billion, to become one of the countrys top money managers.

description: LONDON  A mural depicting secret agents eavesdropping on a telephone booth, thought to be the work of the elusive graffiti artist Banksy, has appeared in the city of Cheltenham, where one of Britains intelligence agencies has its headquarters.

description: Glide down the Mekong River and traverse tumbling waterfalls.

description: The Blackstone Group and the merchant banking arm of Goldman Sachs said on Monday that they had agreed to buy Ipreo Holdings from Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, in the latest instance of private equity firms buying holdings from one another.

description: The second day of this years music and arts festival in Indio, Calif., featured performances by Warpaint, Lorde and Pharrell Williams.
