description: The final day of this years music and arts festival in Indio, Calif., featured performances by Blood Orange, Beck and Arcade Fire

title: Under Cover: In Pursuit of an Unearthly Record
description: What inspires a music collector to search high and low and pay large sums of money to acquire one record? Obsessiveness, says Chris King, who owns the record Last Kind Word Blues, by Geeshie Wiley, that appears on this weeks cover.

title: Behind the Cover Story: John Jeremiah Sullivan on the Search for Geeshie and Elvie
description: John Jeremiah Sullivan, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this weeks cover story about searching for the two women behind a legendary 1930s blues record. He is the author of Pulphead.

title: Endurance Bids $3.2 Billion for Aspen Insurance
description: Updated, 2:31 p.m. |

title: Suvir Sarans Guacamole With Toasted Cumin
description: The chef Suvir Saran says that avocados make people happy, and hes right. He adds toasted cumin seeds, which he refers to as Indian bacon bits, to his chunky guacamole. This guacamole has all the flavors of a Mexican guacamole  illustrating yet again how Indian, Middle Eastern, Mediterranean and Mexican cuisines overlap. In fact, the ingredients here are identical to those that I have always used in my guacamole; but this recipe has the added delight of texture, as the ingredients arent mashed up.

title: Chilean Cabbage and Avocado Slaw
description: Coleslaw meets guacamole here in this utterly simple mix of shredded cabbage, salt, lemon, and pured avocado. The chef Iliana de la Vega, who was born in Oaxaca, Mexico, served it at a delicious Latin-themed lunch she prepared at the Healthy Kitchens, Healthy Lives conference this year at the Culinary Institute of America in Napa Valley. I couldnt get enough of it. I sat with Iliana at the lunch and asked her about the salad. Just salt the cabbage, let it sit for a while, then add lots of lemon juice and the mashed avocado, she said. That really is all there is to it. Shred the cabbage thin and for best results let it sit, after salting generously, for an hour or more, to tenderize it and draw out strong-tasting juices.

title: Roasted Tomatillo-Poblano-Avocado Salsa
description: One of my favorite new cookbooks of this season is A Mouthful of Stars (Andrews McMeel), by Kim Sune. The book is a memoir, travelogue and cookbook all rolled into one, written by an author who earlier published another compelling memoir with recipes,Trail of Crumbs. Kim is a poetic world traveler who loves many cuisines. She is a big fan of taco trucks and loves salsa, the spicier the better. This salsa is based on her recipe for roasted tomatillo-poblano salsa. I love its balance of char, heat, acid and creamy. Im a moderate when it comes to heat, but you can make this hotter by adding more chiles.

title: Chunky Avocado-Papaya Salsa
description: This is based on a recipe in Kim Sunes wonderful new book, A Mouthful of Stars (Andrews McMeel). Her recipe is more of a salad, a fusion of Thai and Mexican flavors. I loved the idea of combining avocado and papaya, two subtle, creamy fruits, with crunchy, bright-tasting Asian pears and spicy chiles. The first time I saw the recipe I wanted to test it right away, but I didnt have Asian pears. So I used an apple, and loved it. Its the sweet, crunchy fruit that does the trick, and apples and Asian pears both work. There are onions in the original recipe but Ive made them optional.

title: Avocado and Roasted Tomatillo Salsa
description: I have been making tomatillo and avocado salsa for years, but I usually simmer the tomatillos rather than roasting them. Roasting the tomatillos, chiles and garlic  toasting really, as I use a skillet for this, on top of the flame  produces a salsa with a delicious charred flavor. I learned something recently from the chef Iliana de la Vega, who demonstrated the recipe at the Healthy Kitchens, Healthy Lives conference in Napa Valley in March: she says, in no uncertain terms, that you should not add water to tomatillo salsas. Without the water, this is a more intense salsa with pleasing density. You can use it as a sauce to serve with chicken or fish, or as a dip with chips or other vegetables.

title: U.N. Leaders Discuss Ukraine Crisis
description: The American, Russian and Ukrainian ambassadors to the United Nations discussed the escalating crisis in Ukraine at a Security Council emergency meeting on Sunday night.

title: Nigeria Blast Kills Dozens as Militants Hit Capital
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  Militants struck near the heart of the Nigerian state early Monday, bombing a bus station in the capital, Abuja, just miles from the seat of government in one of the worst attacks in years in the countrys struggle with insurgents.

title: Investors Trying to Beat the System Invariably Are Disappointed
description: Lets start with a parable.

title: For the Auto Industry, a Showcase for Change
description: The 2014 New York International Auto Show is billed, rightly so, as a showcase for dozens of new and significantly changed automobiles. But more than that, it is also a showcase for the quickening pace of change in the auto industry.

title: Moving Water to Birds, Painkillers During Pregnancy, To Love and Hate Bugs
description:
A new program is using crowdsourced data to select rice fields for bird rest stops; the numbers of women who take opioid drugs for pain during pregnancy is rising, but what are the risks?; a new book looks into the philias and phobias surrounding insects.
Subscribe to the Podcast

title: Book of Mormon Wins Big at Olivier Awards
description: The Broadway hit The Book of Mormon dominated the Tony Awards in 2011, winning nine (including for best musical), and on Sunday night the show was a powerhouse at the Olivier Awards, Londons equivalent of the Tonys. The West End production of Mormon, which opened there last year, won for best new musical, best actor (Gavin Creel as Elder Price), best supporting actor (Stephen Ashfield as Elder McKinley), and best choreography (Casey Nicholaw).

title: Twitters Biggest Shareholders Say They Wont Sell Stock
description: Updated | Added comment from JP Morgan Asset Management and updated the total amount of stock owned by shareholders that say they wont sell.

title: In China, a Big Jet Becomes a Status Symbol
description: IN the United States, public reaction to the corporate use of business jets can be scathing when instances of obvious excess become publicized, such as the day in 2008 when the top executives of the Detroit automakers each used a private jet to fly to Washington to argue for $25 billion in taxpayer bailouts.

title: Seeing Double | The Versatility of a Cardigan
description: T highlights one seasonal wardrobe staple, worn two ways.

title: Food Curated: La Varas Churros
description: The perfect churro is eaten fresh from the fryer, says Alex Raij, co-owner of La Vara in Brooklyn. She created a brunch churro that balances a sweet, crunchy exterior with a moist eggy interior.

title: Video: La Varas Churros
description: Liza de Guia is a video journalist whose blog, Food. Curated., profiles people who produce interesting food in New York and beyond.

title: When Boating With Young Children
description: Still want to take your children out onto the open sea? Youve got company.

title: Today in Small Business: Mobile Yoga
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today:

title: Mizuno Campaign Asks What Makes Sammy  and Everybody Else  Run
description: A running shoe firm is seeking to attract new customers and encourage current ones with a campaign that promotes the positive changes that could occur if only more people were to put one foot in front of the other.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Scott Christie joined the Toronto office of ClarkHuot, part of the CHR Group, in a new post, creative director. He had been creative director at the Toronto office of Interbrand, part of the Omnicom Group.

title: Times Minute | Afghan Uncertainty
description: On the Minute, the chief of The Timess Kabul Bureau, Rod Nordland, discusses the first results from Afghanistans presidential elections.

title: Tax Preparers New Role: Health-Coverage Advisers
description: WASHINGTON  Iris I. Burnell, an adviser at Jackson Hewitt Tax Service, has prepared scores of returns in the last few months, as she does every year ahead of the April 15 filing deadline. But many of her consultations this year have also included educating clients about the tax implications of the Affordable Care Act.

title: Barton on Power to the People
description: Richard Barton describes the philosophy behind many of his businesses, which are meant to empower people in new ways.

title: Times Minute | Afghan Uncertainty
description: In the Video

title: When Not to Speak Your Second Language to Your Children
description: I never thought of myself as having much in common with Spanish-speaking immigrants to the United States. I was born in Iowa, to parents of Western European ancestry, and I am a classic example of the monolingual American whose only exposure to another language came from a brief high school foreign-language class.

title: Sol Golombs Rectangle Puzzle
description: This weeks puzzle is based on an original by Solomon Golomb, a major figure in communication theory and a legendary professor at the University of Southern California. Dr. Golomb is also a prolific puzzle creator; I was introduced to his precise and insightful challenges by the physicist, electrical engineer and mathematician Nelson Blachman, who consumed puzzles of all types and particularly enjoyed those by Dr. Golomb.

title: Asian Cultural Council Divides the Prize for Rockefeller Awards
description: The Asian Cultural Council, which was founded in 1963 to encourage cultural exchanges between the United States and Asian countries, normally gives its $50,000 John D. Rockefeller 3rd Award to a single artist every year. This year the council is splitting the award for the first time, the council announced on Monday. The winners are the composer Chinary Ung, the choreographer and dancer Pichet Klunchun, and an arts administrator in Indonesia, Amna Kusumo. They will each receive $50,000.

title: Beans and Peas Lower Cholesterol
description: Eating modest amounts of legumes  peas, chickpeas, beans and lentils  appears to reduce levels of LDL, the so-called bad cholesterol.

title: Aftermath of Nigeria Bus Bombing
description: Nigerian officials and witnesses described the morning rush hour blast at a crowded bus station that killed at least 70 people on the outskirts of Abuja.

title: Paying Farmers to Welcome Birds
description: WHEATLAND, Calif.  The Central Valley was once one of North Americas most productive wildlife habitats, a 450-mile-long expanse marbled with meandering streams and lush wetlands that provided an ideal stop for migratory shorebirds on their annual journeys from South America and Mexico to the Arctic and back.

title: JWT to Bring Back the Classic J. Walter Thompson Name
description: A funny thing happened on Monday morning to carefully laid plans by the giant JWT advertising agency to announce later in the year that it would bring back its longtime name, the J. Walter Thompson Company: The chief executive of the JWT parent, Martin Sorrell of WPP, let the cat out of the bag.

title: Day 4 of Pistorius Cross-Examination
description: Oscar Pistorius, the Paralympian accused of murdering his girlfriend, sobbed during a fourth day of grueling cross-examination in Pretoria, South Africa.

title: Beyond the Finish Line
description: Jeff Bauman was waiting to see his girlfriend when the bombs went off. Then his Boston marathon began.

title: Laughter Amid the Tears: A Cubs Quiz
description: With the Cubs in the Bronx to play the Yankees  a rare event  its a good time to bone up on some Cubs lore with this quiz.

title: As Cubs Wander Into the Bronx, Theyve Never Been Worse
description: The Cubs were a juggernaut: 322 victories over three seasons, winning the pennant in each of those years and going on to take the World Series twice in a row. The team was built to endure, too, with future Hall of Famers at first base, second base and shortstop, and another Hall of Famer on the mound.

title: Who Am I?
description: Creative self-portraits by student photographers.

title: Creativity Trumps Perfection at the Masters
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Bubba Watson is old enough to be Jordan Spieths uncle, but that is not why their final-round duel at the Masters remained compelling long after the outcome was no longer in doubt.

title: U.N. Official Condemns Use of Torture in Syrian War
description: GENEVA  The United Nations human rights chief, Navi Pillay, condemned the rampant and routine use of torture by the Syrian authorities in a paper released by her office on Monday, which also records torture by some armed opposition groups and serious allegations of torture and the ill-treatment of children.

title: No Comment Necessary: New Hampshires Senator From Massachusetts
description: Scott Brown announced last week that he would run to unseat Jeanne Shaheen as senator from New Hampshire. Which of the two deserve the label third senator from Massachusetts?

title: Wildfire Rages in Chile
description: Firefighters struggle to contain a massive wildfire in Valparaso, Chile, that has destroyed thousands of homes since Saturday.

title: New Dave Eggers Novel Coming in June
description: Dave Eggerss latest novel will be published on June 17, just eight months after the appearance of his last, the social-media cautionary tale The Circle. The new books title is a two-sentence mouthful: Your Fathers, Where Are They? And the Prophets, Do They Live Forever?

title: New York Times Wins Two Photography Pulitzers
description: The Times swept the 2014 prizes for photography.

title: New Collection of Shirley Jackson Works to Be Published
description: In the competition to bring previously unpublished works of Shirley Jackson to readers, Random House has prevailed, in a far less bloody manner than her classic short story The Lottery would suggest. Random House said on Monday that it had acquired a new collection of works by Ms. Jackson, the National Book Award-nominated author of The Haunting of Hill House, compiled primarily from her papers at the Library of Congress.

title: Excerpt: Lady Day
description: Audra McDonald sings What a Little Moonlight Can Do from Lady Day at Emersons Bar and Grill, about the life of the singer Billie Holiday.

title: Image of the Day: April 14
Imagining Charles (Finally) in Charge
description: LONDON  The Queen is dead. Charles, paranoid and power obsessed, dissolves Parliament and parks a tank outside Buckingham Palace. While Prince William dithers, his steely and pragmatic wife, Kate, orchestrates a palace coup to save the monarchy and prevent Britain from sliding into civil war.

title: Michael Phelps Plans Return to Competitive Swimming
description: There is no Olympic design behind Michael Phelpss comeback, if you can call it that. At this stage, Phelpss coach, Bob Bowman, would prefer that people not read too much into his return to competition next week at the Arena Grand Prix in Mesa, Ariz.

title: Weekend Gun Report: April 11-13, 2014
description: For the last month, a serial shooter has been wreaking havoc on highways in the Kansas City, Mo., area. Three people have been wounded in as many as 20 shootings, calling to mind the terror that paralyzed the Washington, D.C., area in 2002, when a pair of snipers killed 10 people.

title: Too Much Family Love
description: For 15 years Anna was a solitary figure sitting at the far end of our waiting room for her annual checkups, having shaved a half-hour off her workday so she could hustle over before we locked our doors.

title: Alexa Ray Joel Recovering After Collapsing at Caf Carlyle Show
description: Alexa Ray Joel, the 28-year old daughter of the singer Billy Joel and the model Christie Brinkley, and a singer, pianist and songwriter in her own right, was two songs into her set at the Caf Carlyle on Saturday evening  the final performance in a two-week run that opened on April 1  when she suddenly collapsed. She was taken to the emergency room at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital.

title: White House Pressed to Protect Ailing Monarch Butterflies
description: All too often, species that humans care about only get attention when they are in crisis. Such is the case with monarch butterflies. The insect, famed for its remarkable annual migrations, faced declines in habitat on both the Mexican and American ends of its range for decades, but now is the focus of an urgent push for a rescue. The latest step is a letter sent on Monday to President Obama and relevant cabinet members by a group of scientists, educators, farmers, and other concerned citizens organized by the Xerces Society and other conservation groups focused on these butterflies. The letter (read it here) describes policies the administration could pursue on both public and private land along the butterflys migratory path. In February, after about 20 naturalists, poets and other monarch defenders pressed for international action in an open letter, the plight of the butterfly was addressed by President Obama and his Mexican and Canadian counterparts ata summit. The leaders agreed to create a working group to study ways to protect the butterfly at both ends of its range. A recent article by Richard Conniff in Yale Environment 360 describes what farmers can do to help monarchs. I also recommend a recent feature in The Times by Michael Wines describing efforts by various groups to restore habitat:

title: A Sons Deafness Prompts a Scientific Journey
description: Like almost all newborns in this country, Alex Justh was given a hearing test at birth. He failed, but his parents were told not to worry: He was a month premature and there was mucus in his ears. A month later, an otoacoustic emission test, which measures the response of hair cells in the inner ear, came back normal.

title: India Wont Use Nuclear Weapons First
description: Indias Bharatiya Janata Party, the presumed front-runner to lead the next government, has clarified its stated plan to revise and update the countrys nuclear weapons doctrine.

title: Best Selling Science Books
description: 1 DAVID AND GOLIATH by Malcolm Gladwell. Little Brown. How disadvantages can work in our favor, from the author of The Tipping Point and Outliers. (Last months ranking: 1.)

title: Citis Stock Seems Priced for More Mediocrity
description: Citigroups stock looks perfectly priced  for more mediocrity.

title: Laughter Amid the Tears  A Cubs Quiz
description: With the Cubs heading to the Bronx to play the Yankees  a rare event  its a good time to bone up on some Cubs lore with this quiz.

title: Long in the Tooth
description: Q. Why, after 5,000 or so years under ice, would the teeth of the so-called Iceman of the Alps still look pretty good? How long do teeth last?

title: Hunt for Missing Plane to Go Underwater
description: Angus Houston, who is coordinating the search for the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, announced that teams plan to use a submersible vehicle to hunt under the ocean.

title: A Sea of Blue and Mourning at an Officers Funeral
description: The police sharpshooters stood atop an apartment tower on Beach 84th Street in Far Rockaway on Monday morning. They were there by way of protocol, but the view must have been striking. It was a fitting vantage point for the funeral of an officer who died in a high-rise building fire.

title: Next Residents of a Luxury Building: Police Horses
description: The newest residences at Mercedes House, a ziggurat of luxury rentals on Manhattans Far West Side, provide tenants with creature comforts found nowhere else in the city.

title: N.H.L. Teams Suffer Post-Olympic Blues
description: The so-called Olympic effect seems to have struck N.H.L. teams again.

title: How Fruit Flies Are Like Helicopters
description: Apparently it is not just speed that makes a fly so hard to swat. In the face of danger, fruit flies execute surprisingly nimble maneuvers to pitch and roll out of harms way, researchers say.

title: In Many Cities, Rent Is Rising Out of Reach of Middle Class
description: MIAMI  For rent and utilities to be considered affordable, they are supposed to take up no more than 30 percent of a households income. But that goal is increasingly unattainable for middle-income families as a tightening market pushes up rents ever faster, outrunning modest rises in pay.

title: An Acidic Wine Calls for Duck and Rhubarb
description: Rhubarb, like the lean Napa cabernet sauvignons, is defined by bright acidity and modest fruit flavors. And happily, the first rhubarb of the season is showing up in the market. The rhubarb plays off rosy, meaty duck magret rimmed with creamy fat. A touch of blood orange in the sauce contributes more fruit and acid.

title: Bullets, Blood and Then Cry of Heil Hitler
description: OVERLAND PARK, Kan.  After the Sunday afternoon mayhem, the handcuffed suspect was led to a gun-gray police car, his beard salt and pepper, his T-shirt a striking white. He looked like who he was, in part: a retiree who was said to have just spent part of his weekend at a casino. Then, from the back seat, he shouted a hoary phrase tinged with a Southern inflection:

title: The Bulls May Have a Role Model for Anthony
description: After reporters covering the Chicago Bulls had finished interviewing Coach Tom Thibodeau on Sunday night, they headed to the teams locker room at Madison Square Garden and went en masse to one player, Joakim Noah, who was finishing dressing with his back to them.

title: Maazel Withdraws From Boston Symphony Concerts
description: April should have been a banner month for Lorin Maazel, the 84-year-old former director of the New York Philharmonic. He was to have brought the ensemble he currently directs, the Munich Philharmonic Orchestra, to Carnegie Hall over the weekend, but had to withdraw from the performances because he was ill. (Valery Gergiev and Fabio Luisi filled in for him.) Now the Boston Symphony Orchestra has announced that he has had to bow out of concerts in Boston, from Thursday through April 26. He was also to have taken the orchestra on an Asian tour, with concerts in China, which the orchestra last visited in 1979 (it was the first American orchestra to perform there after the normalization of relations), and Japan, which the Bostonians last visited in 1999.

title: Obama Speaks About Kansas Shootings
description: The president honored those killed in shootings at two Jewish centers in Kansas, saying no one should have to worry about their security while praying with their fellow believers.

title: New York Times Wins Two Photography Pulitzers
description: The New York Times has swept the 2014 Pulitzer Prizes for photography. The staff photographer Tyler Hicks won the 2014 Pulitzer Prize in breaking news photography for his coverage of a terrorist attack at an upscale mall in Nairobi, Kenya, that left more than 60 people dead. Josh Haner was awarded the Pulitzer in feature photography for his images of the slow and painful recovery process for a survivor of the Boston Marathon bombing.

title: GrafTech Drama Headed for Proxy Fight
description: The war of words between GrafTech International, a small steel company, and its largest independent shareholder, Nathan Milikowsky, is heating up, and a proxy fight is on the horizon.

title: Monday Motorsports: Harvick Wins Another Nascar Crown Jewel
description: `Kevin Harvick passed Dale Earnhardt Jr. with one lap to go to win the Southern 500 Nascar Sprint Cup race at Darlington, S.C., Saturday. Harvick has now won all of Nascars most prestigious races, including the Daytona 500, the Brickyard 400 and the Coca-Cola 600.

title: Pulitzer Prizes Awarded for Coverage of N.S.A. Secrets and Boston Bombing
description: The Washington Post and Guardian U.S. on Monday won the Pulitzer Prize for public service, among the most prestigious awards in journalism, for their articles based on National Security Agency documents leaked by the former government contractor Edward J. Snowden.

title: Two Photography Pulitzers
description: Tyler Hicks won for his coverage of a terrorist attack at a Nairobi mall. Josh Haner was honored in feature photography for his images of the recovery of a Boston Marathon bombing survivor.

title: Mozilla Names Interim Chief
description: Mozilla, the maker of the popular Firefox web browser,announced Monday that it had appointed Chris Beard the interim chief executive of the company.

title: Rossana Orlandi, the Queen of Design
description: Ts design editor Tom Delavan interviews the Italian designer, who discusses her show at Salone del Mobile.

title: A Tiny Discovery in Australias Swamps
description: Researchers have discovered a tiny new species of crayfish in Australia. Weighing just over seven grams, the Gramastacus lacus is one of the worlds smallest freshwater crayfishes, and is distinguished by a large male genital papilla and raised ridges above the eyes. Described in the open-access journal ZooKeys, it resides in swampy areas on the eastern coast of Australia from Wamberal Lagoon to Wallis Lake, where it periodically burrows into the water table to survive dry periods, effectively hiding from scientists seeking to study it.

title: The 2015 Nissan Murano: Dialing Back From a Striking Design
description: What is it? The 2015 Nissan Murano is the third generation of the companys midsized crossover.

title: VW Golf SportWagen: A Station Wagon Concept
description: What is it? According to Volkswagen, the Golf SportWagen Concept previews a bigger, more spacious and more fuel-efficient replacement for the Jetta SportWagen.

title: Total to Proceed With Angola Ultra-Deepwater Project
description: LONDON  After more than a years delay, the French oil company Total said on Monday that it had found the cost savings needed to move ahead with the giant ultra-deepwater Kaombo project off the coast of Angola, setting a start date of 2017.

title: Still Nothing on the I.R.S.
description: Some readers objected last week when I wrote that Fox News Sunday is the place where Republican politicians go to make empty accusations without fear of follow-up questions. So I wanted to note that the shows host, Chris Wallace not only asked follow-ups, but tough ones, in an interview on Sunday with Representative Charles Boustany, Republican of Louisiana.

title: Napa Cabernets From a Cold, Wet Year
description: Outside of a few pockets of fog, California is the land of warmth and sunshine. This has led some to conclude that California wines must always show evidence of this privileged climate through plush textures and opulent fruit.

title: With Purchase of Drone Maker, Google Sees a Fleet of Satellites
description: Google is reaching for the sky.

title: Michael Kaiser to Become Co-Chairman of IMG Artists
description: Michael M. Kaiser is adding another position to his rsum.

title: Budget Office Lowers Estimate for the Cost of Expanding Health Coverage
description: WASHINGTON  The insurance expansion under the Affordable Care Act will cost $1.383 trillion over the next decade, more than $100 billion less than previous forecasts, the Congressional Budget Office said Monday.

title: E-Cigarettes Are Targeted at Youths, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  An investigation by Democratic members of Congress into the marketing practices of electronic cigarette companies has found that major producers are targeting young people by giving away free samples at music and sporting events and running radio and television advertisements during youth-oriented programs.

title: MTV Movie Awards Red Carpet
description: At the MTV Movie Awards, guests like Lupita Nyongo in a colorful Chanel dress and Rita Ora in a plunging neckline Barbara Casasola dress, shined on the red carpet.

title: It Pays to Pay Addicts to Get Vaccinations
description: Paying heroin addicts the equivalent of $50 each to have a series of three injections in a month was very effective in getting them fully vaccinated against hepatitis B, a new British study has found.

title: Learning From What Lincoln Had to Say
description: Ken Burns, the documentarian who gave us The Civil War, knows quite a lot about the Gettysburg Address, but in his latest film, he turns his attention to a group of boys who are just learning about it. The result is The Address, a documentary Tuesday night on PBS that has little to do with the war but is quietly revelatory, just as that earlier work was.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 59
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Rossana Orlandi, the Queen of Design, on Her Salone Exhibition
description: Last Thursday, in the middle of Salone del Mobile, Rossana Orlandi hosted a cocktail party at the Bagatti Valsecchi Museum. Champagne flowed as the see-and-be-seen crowd piled in to admire the Untold exhibition she curated there, which she explains in the above video interview with our design editor, Tom Delavan. Displaying contemporary pieces in the historic 19th-century house allowed Orlandi to show how modern pieces are perfect and can have a fabulous dialogue with an old palace, she says. The video opens with the light installation that she and Vionnets creative director, Goga Ashkenazi, commissioned from the artist Jacopo Foggini for the show. Orlandi, who was once a fashion designer and loathes the trendsetter label often tacked onto her globally-recognized name, is now famous for championing the careers of designers on the rise, a category Foggini fell into not long ago. When I find a designer, first of all I want to be sure that this designer  he will grow up, she explains. Cast in the fashion houses signature shade of blue, Fogginis installation set the tone for the queen of designs fte  a high point during an action-packed week.

title: Flavors of the South From One of Its Own
description: I met Donald Link for the first time three weeks after Hurricane Katrina drowned New Orleans. He was mucking out the walk-in at Herbsaint, his sophisticated restaurant in the citys central business district. Hauling rotted pig heads to the curb in a city that had just lost hundreds of people was awful work. But it had to be done, and he was one of the first chefs to do it.

title: The Making of Pulitzer Prize-Winning Photos
description: Today, two Times journalists, Tyler Hicks and Josh Haner, were awarded Pulitzer Prizes for photography in 2013.

title: 2014 Pulitzer Prize Winners in Journalism, Letters, Drama and Music
description: FICTION

title: They Crawl Right Into Your Head
description: Trained as an entomologist, Jeffrey A. Lockwood discovered 12 years into his career that he was phobic about the very subject he had chosen as his lifes work.

title: When a Game Turned Into a Disaster
description: Hillsborough, Tuesday night on ESPN, is a soccer movie with very little soccer in it. Its about a match played 25 years ago at the Hillsborough stadium in Sheffield, England, that ended after just six minutes  when the realization set in that amid the festive atmosphere of an F.A. Cup semifinal, fans were being crushed to death a few yards behind the west goal.

title: Zombies in the Garden, Killing Themselves Slowly
description: Scientists say they have identified a protein that causes zombielike behavior in plants.

title: Obesity Studies Tell Two Stories, Both Right
description: WASHINGTON  Researchers at the University of North Carolina published a paper last week that introduced another wrinkle into the debate about childhood obesity. They disputed recent findings that obesity among young children had fallen since 2004, arguing that a longer view  using data all the way back to 1999  showed that these youngsters were not really getting any thinner.

title: Bikini (and Hoop Skirt) Season Is Here, and Not a Moment Too Soon
description: Say you decide to make a dance about the isolation of grief: How would you represent the boredom of solitude without boring a spectator? Thats one of the challenges that Rebecca Brooks and her collaborators have set themselves in Still Left on This Rock. And at Danspace Project in the East Village this weekend, on a double bill with Anna Azrielis third skirt scrum, much of the 45 minutes of Still Left slipped from languor into longueurs.

title: In Performance: Adrian Lester
description: Adrian Lester performs a scene from Lolita Chakrabartis play Red Velvet, a drama about the 19th-century black actor Ira Aldridge. The show runs through April 20 at St. Anns Warehouse.

title: Coachella Festival Style: Predictable and Pin-Worthy
description: Some of our favorite, although expected, moments from the first weekend at the 2014 Coachella Music Festival.

title: Chia-Seed Pudding for Breakfast: Tart, Sweet and Good for You
description: The Restaurant Takeaway column is devoted to restaurant dishes you can make in your own kitchen, tested and tweaked for home cooks.

title: Spying on a Grown-Up World
description: Family is the North Star for Mona Simpsons characters: It defines who they are, chaperones their choices, shapes their views of the world. Her dazzling debut novel, Anywhere But Here (1986), gave us an indelible portrait of a girls emotionally fraught relationship with her impossible, narcissistic mother. The Lost Father (1992) followed that same heroines obsessive search for the father who abandoned her. And A Regular Guy (1996) depicted another abandoned daughter trying to come to terms with her father  in this case, a rich, eccentric entrepreneur (who bore more than a passing resemblance to Ms. Simpsons real-life brother, Steve Jobs).

title: Pulitzer-Winning Play The Flick to Reopen in New York
description: Annie Bakers play The Flick, which ran Off Broadway last year and won the 2014 Pulitzer Prize for drama on Monday, will be remounted at Barrow Street Theater in the near future, according to a spokesman for its producer, Scott Rudin.

title: Etsy Artisans Reach Retailers
description: Etsy is giving small business owners, like the woodworkers Shelli and Seth Worley of South Carolina, the opportunity to sell to retailers through a wholesale website.

title: Etsy, Home of the Handmade, Takes On a Wholesalers Role
description: Amy Hamley of Redraven Studios makes jewelry and delicate home dcor items out of porcelain, like hanging planter sets and necklaces in the shape of arrow heads. For three years, she worked out of her basement and tried to break into the wholesale market.

title: Still Sensing the Presence of a Departed Composer
description: I wasnt ready for Robert Ashley to be gone. Associates and intimates had shared news, quietly, of the deteriorating health that would lead to his death on March 3 at 83. Still, Id thought, no way would karma, destiny or what have you allow Ashley to be taken before the conclusion of his three-opera series underway at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

title: 5 Things to Know About Quinoa
description: This week, a new food is appearing on Passover tables around the country. The Orthodox Union, the authority on kosher foods, recently ruled that certain brands of quinoa could carry its Kosher for Passover symbol.

title: New Recordings by Riverside, Jessica Lea Mayfield and August Alsina
description: RIVERSIDE

title: Once a Palace, Now a Lake Como Hotel
description: Most of the upscale hotels in Lake Como, Italy, have been around for decades, but thats set to change on June 1 with the opening of Il Palazzo del Vice Re in the medieval lakeside village of Lezzeno.

title: Jell-O Salad, Snow and Savage Murders
description: Original adaptation, like instant classic and jumbo shrimp, is an oxymoron that makes sense.

title: A Christmas Day Flight, With a Reindeer for a Captain
description: I GREW up in the Philippines and moved to the United States when I was in my twenties. I have traveled most of my life and traveled for business my entire career. I was always involved in the hotel industry, and now Im a senior vice president at Virtuoso, a luxury travel network, so Im doing long-haul flights all the time.

title: Reactions
description: Breast Cancer

title: Scenes From Dior & I
description: Frdric Tcheng documents the creation of Raf Simonss first couture collection for the house in spring 2012.

title: Third Point Defends Its Fight Against Sothebys
description: Last week, Sothebys defended itself against the activist investor Daniel S. Loeb by questioning both his strategy and  perhaps just as galling to him  his credentials in the art world.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsehwhere
description: Ukraine and More: Pictures of the Day

title: Steep Drop in Ratings as Mad Men Begins Its Final Season
description: Viewers seem to be a little less mad about Mad Men, as the much-honored AMC drama enters the first half of its final season: Ratings were down a steep 34 percent on Sunday night for the seventh season premiere.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, South Africa, Israel and Afghanistan.

title: Refusals Cut Options After C-Sections
description: CASPER, Wyo.  When Marie Scott, a child-care worker turned stay-at-home mother, found out she was pregnant again last year, she knew she wanted a traditional birth.

title: Not Merely Dead, Most Sincerely Dead
description: A single death is not a tragedy in most video games. Instead, its something closer to an irritant  not even a paper cut, more like a chipped nail. Death is so cheap that a new word  permadeath  has been coined to describe games that turn your demise into something more than a speed bump on the road to victory.

title: Artists and Spectators, Not So Far Apart
description: INDIO, Calif.  The age of the pop performer being somehow distinct from or greater than the audience is almost over; the audience has grown much more powerful, mostly through the forces of the Internet and social media. Nowhere is this more apparent perhaps than at last weekends Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival, whose audience  cultivated over 15 editions in 15 years  has all that soft power and money, too: Tickets cost at least $375. The audience members have been called tastemakers, but lets see that generalization and raise it. Lets call them artists.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: Seen on the Street | Outside Salone del Mobile
description: A glimpse at what gals wore to the Milan Furniture Fair.

title: Samsung Executive Says Marketing Drove Phone Sales to No. 1
description: SAN JOSE, Calif  Becoming the world leader in the mobile handset market was no easy task. Or at least that was the point Samsung tried to make Monday in its patent trial against Apple.

title: Finding Fresh Poetry in the Familiar
description: Setting out to attend a prominent concert by a performer of documented substance and renown, you might assume that everything you will hear is similarly significant. But should this necessarily be the case? On Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall, Stephen Hough, a pianist consistently thoughtful about the works he presents, offered an alternate notion. His recital included three pieces that might fairly be termed trivial, yet, in context, those works held valid interest.

title: Interest Rates and the Budget Outlook
description: The CBO has issued its latest budget update, and as always its a very careful piece of work. But there is one thing really worth drawing attention to  not that the CBO is necessarily wrong, but it might be, and at any rate people should be aware of whats driving the conclusions.

title: A Pulitzer Today,  and  in May, a New York Premiere
description: John Luther Adams, who was awarded the Pulitzer Prize for music on Monday for his work Become Ocean, has a special reason to look forward to its New York premiere next month at Carnegie Hall: he has yet to hear it performed live.

title: Public Attitudes About Climate Change
Capturing on Canvas the Downfall of Wall Streets Criminals
description: Bernard L. Madoff was handcuffed and whisked into a cell. Michael R. Milken, head in palm, wept. Martha Stewart simply stared straight ahead.

description: To the Editor:

title: Bid to Upend Disneys Deal for Maker Studios Falls Short
description: LOS ANGELES  An oddball maneuver by Relativity Media to break up the pending nuptials of the YouTube-focused Maker Studios and the Walt Disney Company ended on Monday almost as fast as it started.

title: Dual Turning Point for Biofuels
description: HUGOTON, Kan.  There is an old joke in the energy business that advanced biofuels are the fuel of the future, and always will be.

description: To the Editor:
