description: EVANSTON, Ill.  The imminent vote by scholarship football players at Northwestern on whether to certify a union has students, professors and athletes in other sports choosing sides.

title: Between Obama and Putin, a Game of He Said, He Said
description: WASHINGTON  President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia telephoned President Obama on Monday afternoon to discuss the escalating crisis in Ukraine. On that, the White House and the Kremlin agree. On just about everything else, the two sides are hopelessly at odds.

title: Nissan Offers Owners of the Leaf E.V. Free Electricity
description: Nissan has sold more than 110,000 Leaf battery electric cars around the world and almost 50,000 in the United States, but it obviously wants to increase that. Americans respond to free gas promotions, so the company is trying something similar with electricity. Fred Diaz, senior vice president in Nissans sales and marketing after-sales operation, said Wednesday at the New York show that charging is going to be free for two years to new Leaf customers, first in 10 top markets, and later in 25.

title: Ailing Pulaski Skyway Offers a Lesson in Creative Financing
description: The governor of New Jersey is bullish on honesty.

title: 2015 Hyundai Sonata
description: The latest example of Hyundais design language.

title: Jets Add Spark While Giants Get Insurance
description: The Jets made a splashy free-agent acquisition Wednesday by signing running back Chris Johnson, who will provide a big-play threat to an offense sorely in need of the sparkle and sizzle of a Pro Bowler.

title: Childrens Book to Soothe Parents of the College-Bound
description: HOPING to ease the worries of parents anxious about saving for college, T. Rowe Price, the financial services company, is introducing a marketing campaign that looks less like it came from Wall Street than from Sesame Street.

title: With Panel Gone, a Move to Monitor New York Lawmakers Income Is Thwarted
description: For its most provocative investigative target, an anticorruption commission appointed last year by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo set out to scrutinize the millions of dollars earned by New York legislators who also have other jobs.

title: Weibo, a Chinese Answer to Twitter, Prices Its Offering at $17
description: Weibo, the microblogging service formed by the Sina Corporation, has been called the Twitter of China. But the company will carry a value well below that of its American counterpart when it begins trading on the public markets.

title: Russia Economy Worsens Even Before Sanctions Hit
description: MOSCOW  Margarita R. Zobnina, a professor of marketing here, has been watching the Russian economys gathering woes with mounting alarm: friends who have moved abroad with no plans to return; others who put off new business ventures because of rising uncertainty. Meanwhile, Ms. Zobnina and her husband, Alexander, also a professor, have rented a safe deposit box to hold foreign cash as a hedge against the declining ruble.

title: 2014 New York Auto Show: Photo Gallery
description: Highlights from the North American International Auto Show in New York.

title: Spying at the N.Y.P.D.
description: Commissioner William Bratton took an important step toward restoring trust in the New York Police Department this week when he disbanded a unit used by his predecessor, Raymond Kelly, to conduct an indefensible program of spying on law-abiding Muslims in neighborhoods and houses of worship.

title: Pensioners in Detroit Rejoice, Though Deal Is Far From Done
description: DETROIT  The relief was palpable.

title: Rangers and Coach Are Lost No Longer
description: Rangers Coach Alain Vigneault needed a few months to adjust to New York after moving from Vancouver. There was the time he turned his car uptown trying to get to his Upper West Side apartment, but he did it on Dyer Avenue. He wound up at the other end of the Lincoln Tunnel, in New Jersey.

title: Talks a Chance for Russia to Step Back on Ukraine
description: GENEVA  The high-level talks on Ukraine that are set to begin here on Thursday have emerged as a pivotal test of Russias intentions in the region before the United States and European nations decide whether to impose additional economic sanctions on Moscow, American officials said on Wednesday.

title: Syrian War Takes Heavy Toll at a Crossroad of Cultures
description: PALMYRA, Syria  The imposing stone colonnades still stand, below stark hills dotted with tombs. They still glow peach-pink in the afternoon sun, impassive, as if unimpressed by what is, after all, not their first war.

title: Criminalizing Expectant Mothers
description: Even by the standards of the growing Republican assault on the lives and rights of women, a new bill passed by bipartisan majorities in both houses of Tennessees Legislature recently stands out for being meanspirited and counterproductive.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 16, 2014
Officer Stands by His Account of Scuffle at Occupy Wall Street Protest
description: A New York City police officer admitted in court on Wednesday that he had fixed several traffic tickets before 2011, but said that he had told the truth about being assaulted by an Occupy Wall Street protester in 2012.

title: Hungarys Central Bank Seizes Bold Strategies
description: BUDAPEST  Few central bankers are as quotable as Gyorgy Matolcsy.

title: Reining In Predatory Schools
description: The for-profit college industry is pressuring the Obama administration to water down proposed new rules that would deny federal student aid to career training programs that saddle students with crippling debt while giving them useless credentials.

title: In Ukraine, Seeking U.S. Aid
description: KIEV, Ukraine  For decades, Ukrainians have been starved, oppressed and bullied by Russians, and, with Russia now inciting instability that could lead to an invasion and dismemberment of eastern Ukraine, plenty of brave Ukrainians here say theyve had it and are ready to go bear-hunting.

title: Hey, George, We Made It Back to Broadway
description: See those two guys sitting up there on the stage  the big, slow feller and his smaller, quicker pal? Dont you somehow get the feeling theyve been crouched at that campfire forever? And that youve been watching them for just about as long?

title: Carefully Consider
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  How often do you find your daily crossword puzzle grinning at you? Is that a friendly, Come solve me look, or a strange, off-season jack-o-lantern?

title: In Ukraine, Russia Plays a Weighted Word Game
description: KIEV, Ukraine  If one ignores the images of masked men armed to the teeth and just listens to Russian television, the drama in eastern Ukraine can sometimes seem little more than a quarrel among constitutional scholars. The gunmen, denounced by the Ukrainian government as violent separatists, are invariably referred to by Russian officials and their state-controlled news media simply as supporters of federalization.

title: After 2 Years, M.T.A. and Union Close In on a New Contract
description: More than two years after its contract expired, the union representing New York Citys subway and bus workers is involved in intense negotiations with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and appears on the cusp of reaching a new contract, union and government officials said Wednesday.

title: Central African Republic: Aid Sought for Those Fleeing Unrest
description: The United Nations refugee agency said Wednesday that it was working with 14 other humanitarian relief groups to seek $274 million in emergency donations to support the swelling population of refugees fleeing violence in the Central African Republic, one of Africas most dysfunctional countries. The refugee agency said nearly 200,000 residents had escaped to neighboring countries over the last four months. More than 600,000 people were displaced inside the Central African Republic because of communal violence that has effectively partitioned the country into Christian and Muslim sectors. Antnio Guterres, the United Nations high commissioner for refugees, said in a statement that all relief agencies working in the region were dramatically underfunded and that his own agency was far outspending what it had expected. This cannot be sustained, he said.

title: Gaza: Blasts Kill Hamas Militants
description: Three militants were killed Wednesday and five people were wounded when several explosions ripped through a Hamas facility in the southern Gaza Strip. The cause of the explosions was under investigation, but officials of Hamas, the militant Palestinian faction that controls Gaza, said they were the result of a jihad mission, a term that refers to militants felled in work accidents or during training. The dead were identified as members of Hamass armed wing. Four of the wounded were firefighters or others who rushed to the scene.

title: Pinedas Line: No Runs Allowed, and No More Talk
description: The attention on Michael Pineda started with the integrity of his right hand. It soon transitioned to the electricity of his right arm.

title: The Americans Recap: Whos Good?
description: Is anyone on The Americans a good person?

title: India Election Digest: April 17
description: What you need to know about Indias election on Thursday: The fifth and biggest round of Indias national elections gets underway, with 121 constituencies across 12 states and union territories going to vote. Whats at stake: 28 seats in Karnataka, followed by Rajasthan (20), Maharashtra (19), Uttar Pradesh and Odisha (11 each), Madhya Pradesh (10), Bihar (seven), Jharkhand (six), West Bengal (four), Chhattisgarh (three), Manipur and the state of Jammu and Kashmir (one each).

title: Boston Police on Suspicious Backpacks
description: The Boston police superintendent for the night command said that a man was arrested and charged after two backpacks were found near the marathon finish line.

title: Woodson Is Looking to Next Season, but Others Eyes Are on Him
description: Before the Knicks played the Toronto Raptors on Wednesday night, Mike Woodson wore black as he met with the news media, perhaps for the final time as Knicks coach. He used the word unfortunately in response to four separate questions.

title: Alan Davie, Painter With a Global Bent, Dies at 93
description: Alan Davie, a Scottish-born painter whose audacious and colorful abstractions put a personal stamp on Pollock-like expressionism and seized on mythical and mystical imagery from cultures around the globe, died on April 5 at his home in Hertfordshire, north of London. He was 93.

title: F. Reid Buckley, Novelist and Columnist, Dies at 83
description: F. Reid Buckley, a novelist, columnist, founder of a school of public speaking and, in family lore, the most literary of Aloise and William F. Buckley Sr.s 10 children, including former Senator James L. Buckley and the conservative commentator William F. Buckley Jr., died on Monday in hospice care in Columbia, S.C. He was 83.

title: Spring Shape-Up Secrets From the Fashion Crowds Favorite New Gym
description: Rare is the gym that can be described as aesthetically pleasing. Yet thats just what the trainer Stephen Cheuk has assembled at S10 Training, his recently opened fitness center in the TriBeCa neighborhood in New York. Designed by Samuel Amoia Associates, which has previously undertaken projects for Andr Balazs and Ian Schrager, it features mirrored changing-room cubes, brick walls with a lime-wash finish and a prominently placed photograph by Jim Mangan. The stylish look suits Cheuks roster of clients, which includes the Alexander Wang design team, the actor-slash-designer Waris Ahluwalia and a host of other downtown fashion types. Its a visually beautiful gym, which doesnt hurt when youre working out, notes Ahluwalia, who has trained with Cheuk for years.

title: A Rare Look at a Fashion Photographers Personal Body of Work
description: In this weekly series, Ts photo editors share the most compelling visual projects theyve discovered.

title: The End of Our Financial Illusions
description: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz professor of entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.

title: The Antidepressant Generation
description: I think our experiment failed, the young graduate student told me, referring to our attempt to take her off the antidepressant shed been on for seven years. She was back in my campus office after a difficult summer break, and as she talked about feeling unsettled and upset, I wondered about the broader experiment playing out on college campuses across the country.

title: Times Minute | What Will Stop Russia?
description: With tensions between Kiev and Moscow at new heights, two approaches are being tried in Geneva and Washington this week to calm the crisis.

title: Nets Get 6th Seed and Will Face Raptors
description: Dwane Casey, the Toronto Raptors coach, laughed off the notion Wednesday afternoon that any Eastern Conference teams might have conspired during the final days of the regular season to establish more favorable playoff positions. There were too many variables and possible outcomes, particularly among the conferences No. 3 to No. 6 seeds, he said.

title: The 2014 New York Auto Show
description: The auto show displays some of the newest models from Alfa Romeo, Hyundai, Ford and Toyota. Theres also a peek at whats to come in the next-generation Mazda Miata. Above, the Jaguar F-Type R.

title: Warren Forma, Documentary Filmmaker, Is Dead at 90
description: Warren Forma, a documentary filmmaker who profiled nearly two dozen artists for a series of television programs called Artists at Work, died on March 26 in Manhattan. He was 90.

title: Whats On Thursday
description: 8 P.M. (Fuse) PIRATE RADIO (2009) The time: Britain in the mid-1960s, when the BBC, aided by the government, kept official radio channels mostly free of rock n roll. The place: a tanker off the British coast, where rebel broadcasters (Philip Seymour Hoffman, Bill Nighy and Rhys Ifans, above at microphone) blasted the Stones, the Kinks, Jimi Hendrix and the Who over the airwaves. This angers a government minister (Kenneth Branagh) who wants to keep listeners safe with high culture and educational programming. The director of this movie, Richard Curtis, isnt concerned with exploring why gatekeepers might want to maintain the divide between high and popular culture, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. He wants to party. So he piles on the comic high jinks, lobs the jokes and cranks the splendid tunes. Mr. Nighy can also be seen as a financially distressed British retiree lured to Jaipur, India, in John Maddens Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2012), at 4:45 on MoreMax, and as the washed-up rock star Billy Mack, angling for a comeback, in Mr. Curtiss Love Actually (2003), at 8 on Showtime.

title: Workers Strike at Shoe Factory Over Benefits Dispute
description: Tens of thousands of workers at one of the worlds largest shoe manufacturers are continuing a strike in the southern Chinese city of Dongguan in a dispute over benefits.

title: An April Doubleheader (Snow Included)
description: The Yankees and Cubs played a day-night twin bill in the Bronx on Wednesday that included snow that made it look like February, winds that made it feel like March, and baseball that was, well, sort of predictable.

title: Question of Identity at Heart of Jharkhands Politics
description: RANCHI, India The eastern state of Jharkhand is a study in contrasts: On one hand, the state is immensely rich in natural resources and contains about 40 percent of Indias mines and mineral reserves, but on the other hand, the region struggles with endemic poverty and rampant unemployment.

title: Corrections: April 17, 2014
description: NEW YORK

title: U.S. Activist Investor Turns Eyes Toward Europe
description: Updated, 9:34 a.m. | It was only a matter of time before United States activist investors turned their focus to European companies.

title: An Internet Big V Opts for Abject Contrition
description: Charles Xue, an American businessman who once embodied the raucous energies testing Internet censorship in China, has returned to prominence as the opposite: a contrite prisoner endorsing the governments determination to cleanse and control the Web. In a display recalling the Communist Partys past ideological offensives, Mr. Xue was shown on state-run television on Thursday, repenting his misdeeds, endorsing the campaign against him and thanking officials for their mercy.

title: European Car Sales Strengthen on Manufacturer Incentives
description: PARIS  The European car market continues to grow, according to industry data published on Thursday, with manufacturers incentives contributing to a seventh straight monthly gain in March.

title: Talk About Your History, Oliver Stone Tells Chinese
description: Updated, 5:07 a.m. ET | The film director Oliver Stone, never one to shy from controversy, dropped a verbal bomb at the Beijing International Film Festival on Thursday, saying that China had to face the truth about its history and criticize Mao Zedong if it wanted to become truly creative.

title: Its the End of the World as We Know It . . . and He Feels Fine
description: Late one night last August, on the chalk downlands of southern England, Paul Kingsnorth stood in a field beside an old-growth forest, two yurts and a composting toilet. Kingsnorth is 41, tall, slim and energetic, with sweeping brown hair and a sparse beard. He wears rimless glasses and a silver stud in his ear, and he talks with great ardor, often apologizing for having said too much or for having said it too strongly.

title: Witness to History, Searching for Dignity
description: David Turnley photographed the Rwanda genocide and its aftermath in 1994 while working for The Detroit Free Press. He won the Pulitzer Prize in 1990, for his coverage of political upheaval in the Eastern bloc and China, including the fall of the Berlin Wall and Tiananmen Square. He has won the World Press Picture of the Year award twice, and the Robert Capa Award for Courage.

title: Ukrainian Forces Kill 3 Pro-Russian Demonstrators
description: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine  Ukrainian security forces killed three pro-Russian activists, wounded 13 and took 63 captive in a firefight overnight in the eastern city of Mariupol, the interim Ukrainian interior minister said on Thursday. The clash was the most lethal so far in the east of the country.

title: New York Today: Chilly Critters
description: Good Thursday morning to you. Its still cold  38 degrees, with a wind chill below freezing.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: Away From Show of Diplomacy in Geneva, Putin Puts On a Show of His Own
description: MOSCOW  Even as the worlds top diplomats were gingerly drafting a tentative accord to de-escalate tensions in Ukraine, President Vladimir V. Putin was on national television here, brashly declaring Russias historical claims over Ukrainian territory, reiterating a threat to use military force and generally sounding a defiant, even mocking, tone toward the United States.

title: In Bihar, Economic Concerns Are Tied Up in Caste Politics
description: PATNA, India  In Bihar, one of the poorest states in India, voters in this years elections have the economy foremost on their minds, but in a state where the most socially disadvantaged sections of society make up a majority of voters, even economic issues are tied up with caste politics.

title: For China and Japan, the Economic Challenges Ahead Are Similar
description: HONG KONG  Japan and China do not always see eye to eye on politics. But when it comes to economic policy, Tokyo and Beijing have remarkably similar goals: Both want to push through far-reaching changes in their economies in the face of mounting debt and rapidly graying populations.

title: The Problem With Giving Employees a Stipend to Buy Health Insurance
description: Paul Downs, my Youre the Boss colleague, recently posed a question: If he were to replace the health insurance he offers his employees with a cash payment that they could use to buy their own insurance, would he be committing age discrimination?

title: Human Error Suspected as Hope Fades in Korean Ferry Sinking
description: JINDO, South Korea  The captain was among the first to flee. Only a couple of the 44 life rafts aboard were deployed. The hundreds of passengers were instructed over the intercom to stay inside and wait as the ship leaned to one side and began to sink, dragging scores of students down with it.

title: Daily Report: Googles Results Disappoint as Ads Are Less Profitable
description: Alexander the Great is said to have wept because he ran out of kingdoms to conquer. Google is eager to avoid such a miserable fate, David Streitfeld reports.

title: Morgan Stanleys Earnings Increase 18%
description: Updated, 11:49 a.m. | Morgan Stanleys efforts to re-establish itself as a Wall Street powerhouse since the financial crisis gained some ground on Thursday, when the bank reported that first-quarter earnings rose 18 percent from the period a year earlier.

title: U.S. and Russia Agree on Pact to Defuse Ukraine Crisis
description: GENEVA  The United States, Russia, Ukraine and the European Union reached an agreement here on Thursday evening that calls for armed pro-Russian bands to give up the government buildings they have seized in eastern Ukraine and outlines other steps to de-escalate the crisis.

title: Perry Evans of Closely, on Craftsmanship and Early Rising
description: This interview with Perry Evans, chief executive of Closely, a digital marketing firm, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

description: PARIS  The Cannes Film Festival on Thursday unveiled its picks for its 67th competition. The 49 films include an offbeat western directed by Tommy Lee Jones, a thriller set in Hollywood by David Cronenberg, as well as movies by Mike Leigh, Olivier Assayas, Ken Loach, Jean-Luc Godard and the directorial debut of Ryan Gosling.

description: Mr. Etim is the community manager for NYTimes.com.

description: Updated, 9:51 a.m. | The Blackstone Group generated a higher profit in the first quarter as it reaped gains from selling its holdings.

title: Bain Capital Raises $7.3 Billion for Buyout Fund
description: Bain Capital, the big private equity firm based in Boston, has finished raising its latest flagship buyout fund with $7.3 billion in capital, a person briefed on the matter said.

title: Plants That Practice Genetic Engineering
description: In the debate over genetically modified crops, one oft-said word is unnatural. People typically use it when describing how scientists move genes from one species into another.

title: Shape-Shifting Into Success
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.  When John Fawcett and Graeme Manson, the creators of BBC Americas cult series Orphan Black, recall the moment they realized the central conceit of their twisty science-fiction conspiracy drama might actually be believable, they point to a bar scene in the third episode. In it, a bespectacled, dreadlocked Ph.D. student named Cosima has a lengthy conversation with Sarah, a street-savvy British grifter.

description: Updated, 10:59 a.m. | Goldman Sachs reported on Thursday that first-quarter profit declined to $2.03 billion, reflecting a drop in overall revenue and a continued slump in its fixed-income business.

description: Adapted from Pregnant Butch: Nine Long Months Spent in Drag, by A.K. Summers, published by Soft Skull Press.

description: General Electric delivered solid sales growth and improving profits in its industrial businesses during the first quarter of 2014.

title: A Big Day for Earnings
description: Goldman Sachs reported a drop in first-quarter profit on Thursday, to $2.03 billion, reflecting declines in its fixed-income unit and overall revenue, Rachel Abrams writes in DealBook. The profit, which translated to $4.02 a share, compared with a profit of $2.2 billion, or $4.29 a share, in the period a year earlier. Wall Street analysts had been expecting $3.44 a share in the first quarter.

title: Twitter Goes After a Facebook Cash Cow
description: Sometimes the rivalry between Twitter and Facebook is like a childrens game of copycat. Facebook copied Twitters hashtags and trending topics. Twitter copied Facebooks profile page design and automatic display of images in the feed.

title: Pistorius Trial Adjourns With Key Witness in Doubt
description: PRETORIA, South Africa  After 25 days of testimony, the trial of Oscar Pistorius, the double-amputee South African track star accused of murdering his girlfriend, adjourned on Thursday amid a report that a crucial defense witness will not take the stand when it resumes on May 5.

title: G.O.P. Discovers Useful Voter Outreach Tool: Gun Sweepstakes
description: Hand over your email address to a political campaign, and typically all you can expect in return is an endless stream of solicitations for money.

description: After a heart attack, Dee Williams downsized, trading her big house in Portland, Ore., for an 84-square-foot cottage on her friends property.

title: Running Against Republicans, and the Environment
description: How far should Democrats be prepared to go to keep control of the Senate in Novembers election? If they win because one of their members repudiates everything they stand for, is it worth the victory? Thats the troubling question raised by a new re-election campaign ad for Senator Mary Landrieu of Louisiana. Her victory is crucial to preventing a Republican takeover of the Senate, but the environmental positions she takes in the ad sound far more Republican than Democratic.

title: In Our Pages: April 18
description: 1914: Dogs Bill Passes in Commons

title: Indias Biggest Election Day
description: NEW DELHI  In the countrys fifth and largest phase of polling, 12 states went to the polls Thursday, with more than one-fifth of the parliamentary seats up for grabs.

title: Bibi van der Veldens Whimsical Fine Jewelry Collection
description: Fine jewelry, says the designer and sculptor Bibi van der Velden, should be taken with a dose of humor. A thread of whimsy runs through the work of the New York-born, Amsterdam-based designer, whose handcrafted pieces have been collected by the likes of Kanye West and Sienna Miller. Though she started her line in 2006, her work is gaining new attention this season; it recently debuted at Bergdorf Goodman and Dover Street Market in New York and will launch on Net-a-Porter on June 9th. Her spring collection, carved from 40,000-year-old mammoth tusks that emerged from the Russian tundra thanks to global warming, includes such designs as a pendant depicting a cloud raining thunderbolts, a necklace strung with dodo egg-shaped pearls and a wraparound dragon ring that features a tiny man clutching a diamond emerging from the jaws of the beast. The natural world is a leitmotif for van der Velden, who likes to tell the story of how an owl once soared through the room at one of her runway shows. For fall, her pieces will incorporate actual scarab wings. I am fascinated by nature and its beauty, she says. I hate to see such beauty go to waste.

title: Sometimes a Bad Birthday Gift Has Its Uses
description: THE deeper an artist gets into her career, the harder it can be for her to find inspiration, as Jill Sobule can tell you.

title: Chief of British Conglomerate Calls 2013 Results Disastrous
description: Some chief executives like to sugarcoat bad results, but the interim chief executive of the Co-operative Group felt no such need when reporting the firms results on Thursday.

title: Robin Roberts: By the Book
description: The Good Morning America anchor and author of Everybodys Got Something calls Maya Angelou her literary hero: As a teenager in Mississippi, I identified with her quest for independence.

title: The Party Decides, Unless It Cant
description: Right now, the most striking thing about the public polling on the 2016 Republican nomination isnt just the absence of a clear frontrunner: Its the absence ofa clear pair or trio or even a quartet of frontrunners. Thelatest Iowa pollhas Mike Huckabee in the pole position with eleven percent, and then eight (!) others all of whom are more serious figures than some of the characters who briefly polled well last time around  bunched between six and ten percent; the national polling average isnt quite that compressed,but its close. This cant last, but everyone recognizes that the situation ishistorically unusual(as, on the other side, is Hillary Clintons extraordinary advantage); the question is,howunusual, and what does it mean for the normal way that these things shake out?

title: Pregnancy Weight Gain Predicts Childs Obesity
description: Gaining too much weight during pregnancy  or too little  is associated with an increased risk that your child will be obese as a preschooler, new evidence shows.

title: Walmart Will Enter Cash Wiring Business
description: In a move that threatens to upend another piece of the financial services industry, Walmart, the countrys largest retailer, announced on Thursday that it would allow customers to make store-to-store money transfers within the United States at cut-rate fees.

title: Bangalores Enthusiastic Young Voters Reflect New Kind of Politics
description: BANGALORE, India  Sanketh Jain, 22, was excited as he stood in line behind his grandparents outside a crowded polling place in a Bangalore school, ready to vote for the first time in a general election.

title: What to Do When Your Child Wants Marijuana Stocks
description: Some parents consider stock-market investing part of the mandatory household financial literacy curriculum, and they set their children up with a brokerage account at the age of 13. Others follow their childrens lead and help them buy shares whenever they indicate interest.

title: App for Spotting and Disputing Dubious Charges
description: XAVIER PLASENCIA knows he should check his credit card and bank account transactions regularly to spot any questionable charges.

title: SOPA Defeat Haunts Efforts to Rein In Illegal Copying, British Official Says
description: Its going to be five years before anybody puts his head above the parapet again. Thats how Michael Weatherly, a member of the British Parliament and intellectual property adviser to Prime Minister David Cameron handicapped the prospects for a fresh legislative push against online piracy in the United States.

title: Basil A. Paterson, 87, a Power in Harlem With Statewide Reach, Dies
description: Basil A. Paterson, one of the old-guard Democratic leaders who for decades dominated politics in Harlem and influenced black political power in New York City and the state into the 21st century, when he saw his son David A. Paterson rise to the governors office, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 87.

title: De Blasios 2013 Promise to Muslims
description: Bill de Blasio, then a mayoral candidate, said at a rally in Brooklyn in October that New York City public schools should recognize the Muslim holidays Eid al-Fitr and Eid al-Adha.

description: The preliminary charge brought against Bob Dylan in Paris last November for what a Croatian organization said was hate speech comparing Croats to Nazis or the Ku Klux Klan has been dropped by a French court, the French television news station France24 reported.

title: Muslims in New York City Unite on Push to Add Holidays to School Calendar
description: The meeting opened with a pledge from the podium to try to end, God willing, by the hour of the evening prayer. Clusters of colorfully veiled women kept watch over jittery young children. Rows of men conversed in a jangle of languages.

title: Oil Slick in Indian Ocean Not From Missing Jet, Tests Find
description: SYDNEY, Australia  The Australian authorities looking for the missing Malaysia Airlines jet said Thursday that an oil slick detected in the search zone and collected by the Australian vessel Ocean Shield was not engine oil or hydraulic fluid from an aircraft.

title: A Majorca Trip for Competitive Cyclists
description: Competitive cyclists who want a hint of vacation in their training schedule might turn to the Cycling House for assistance.

description: An ad by Ending Spending Action Fund supports Scott Brown, the former Massachusetts senator, and appeals to New Hampshire voters who oppose President Obamas health care law.

description: An advertisement produced by Americans for Prosperity thanked Representative Steve Southerland for his vote against the Affordable Care Act.

title: Political Ads, Often Negative, Try Instead to Accentuate the Positive
description: WASHINGTON  Outside political groups, long known for their negative advertisements featuring ominous music and foreboding narration, are trying something new this campaign season: a pivot to the positive.

title: Mac DeMarco on Wearing Womens Clothing and the Elements of No-Fuss Style
description: Last Tuesday, in the bathroom of his dressing room (the only place he was permitted to smoke), before playing a set at the Williamsburg music venue Babys All Right, the rising musician Mac DeMarco imparted insight into his no-fuss style. The key to his look, he confessed, is to avoid overthinking in other words, to stock up on white Hanes T-shirts and floppy brimmed hats. Effortlessness is central to the 23-year-old Canadians approach to pretty much everything. Take my advice, he sings on the song Brother, from his album Salad Days, to take it slowly, brother. If thats your plan this summer, read on to dress the part.

title: N.B.A. Players Reset Union Search With Kevin Johnson as Point Man
description: It should have been no surprise that when Chris Paul, the N.B.A. players unions president, went looking for someone to lead the search for the unions next executive director, he was sold on the purposeful hands of another point guard, Kevin Johnson.

title: Europeans Look Beyond Their Borders
description: BERLIN  How many people need to use your product before its a success?

title: Arab-Israeli Activist Is Moved to House Arrest
description: JERUSALEM  An Arab citizen of Israel who was detained by the Israeli authorities over the weekend after a visit to Lebanon was released Thursday but ordered to be kept under house arrest. He was being held on suspicion of conducting an unauthorized visit to an enemy state and contact with a foreign agent, according to his lawyers and Israeli security officials.

title: Its Showtime. Watch the Closing Doors, Please.
description: I ENTERED the thronged train and at once noticed the man with long hair. He stood near the center of the car, telling some story about some man who had come back into his life: He leaned down. I could feel his breath on my face and I knew what was going to happen before he told me what was going to happen.

title: Lawsuit Aims to Derail New York Library Plan
description: In the latest effort to stop the New York Public Librarys renovation of its flagship building on Fifth Avenue, a group of scholars filed a lawsuit on Wednesday, arguing that the Bloomberg administration approved the project without fully evaluating its environmental impact.

title: Back Onstage, With Fewer Secrets
description: Michael C. Hall has made a career of playing men with something to hide, the sort who manage their anxieties by pouring themselves into their work, which in the case of his two best-known television roles happened to include embalming and burying the dead (on Six Feet Under) and violently avenging the dead (on Dexter). Onstage now in the playwright Will Enos gnomic, desperate comedy The Realistic Joneses, Mr. Hall plays John, a man with plenty to hide but no real trade to busy his hands and thus to take his mind off a mortal secret he carries.

title: A Bid to Park Recalled G.M. Cars Is Denied
description: General Motors may be losing the public relations battle in its recall of defective cars, but the company scored a victory on Thursday in its escalating legal war.

title: Facebooks New Twist on Location Sharing Puts Users in Control
description: On Thursday, Facebook is taking the wraps off a new feature, under development for four years outside and inside the company, that allows mobile users to share their location with their friends on the service.

description: Introduced on Wednesday, April 16: 2015 Alfa Romeo 4C sport coupe.

title: Image of the Day: April 17
Two Out-of-Towners, Happily So
description: When the playwright Catherine Trieschmann comes to New York, she wants dim sum. In the small Kansas town where she lives, turnip cake is scarce. Walks on the High Line tempt Eric Coble, a dramatist who makes his home in Cleveland.

title: Witness to History, Searching for Dignity
description: Twenty years after the genocide in Rwanda, David Turnley dug through his archives to confront not just ghastly images of atrocity, but also glimmers of human dignity and hope.

description: Following is a joint statement on Thursday by the four parties  the United States, the European Union, Russia and Ukraine  meeting in Geneva to discuss the continuing conflict in Ukraine:

title: F.D.A. Discourages Procedure in Uterine Surgery
description: Doctors should stop using a procedure performed on tens of thousands of American women a year in the course of uterine surgery, because it poses a risk of spreading cancerous tissue, the Food and Drug Administration said Thursday.

title: Today in Small Business: Smart Soda Cans?
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Jabari Parker of Duke Declares for N.B.A. Draft
description: Jabari Parker, a 6-foot-8 freshman forward at Duke, announced Thursday that he had played his final college basketball game and would enter the 2014 N.B.A. draft.

title: 36 Hours in Prague
description: For people who havent traveled to Prague recently, the Czech capital might seem like a known quantity: a city with a thousand years of architecture, cheap beer and often boring restaurants where the most unusual ingredients are the doughy dumplings. But Prague is developing so quickly that many locals still havent heard of all the next big things: flashy new art galleries, dynamically developing old neighborhoods, great bars  beyond and including beer  and new restaurants with flavorful offerings from classic steaks and chops to Asian spice. In fact, so many new developments have appeared in Prague that you could spend an entire weekend visiting only those places that have opened in the past couple of years. See Prague Castle, Charles Bridge and all the other classic attractions. But finish out your stay with some of the vibrant newcomers.

title: In Lecce, Making Magic With Humble Ingredients
description: La cucina povera. Often translated as the food of the poor, the term seems unlikely to make mouths water or inspire serious foodies to blow their vacation budget on a cooking course.

title: Portraits on the Page of Paris, London and Venice
description: Paris, London, Venice: hardly the most mysterious places on the planet. Yet beyond Notre Dame, Big Ben and the Basilica di San Marco lie hidden iterations of these well-trodden cities: obscure corners, faded histories and the daily pleasures and aggravations of those who live there. A 19th-century Parisian photographer, a former musician in London and a novelist in Venice are among those who offer unexpected insights in six recently published or about-to-be-published books. Some urge you to visit, others beg you to stay away, all are likely to trigger the wanderlust of those eager to get closer to the authentic heart of a place.

title: The Personification of Legends
description: Louis Armstrong, who always knew how to make an entrance, gets a doozy of an opening scene in Satchmo at the Waldorf, a one-man show now playing at the Westside Theater. Its March 1971 and dark as night in the trumpeter and singers dressing room at the Waldorf-Astoria, except for a Hopperesque shaft of light streaming through the door. A muffled ovation rises and falls in the distance, and then in he comes, lurching wheezily toward an oxygen tank across the room.

title: BlackRock Profit Rises as It Attracts More Money From Investors

description: Updated to add more on the decision not to enforce the injunction in Berlin.

title: Vision of Home
description: AIDONE, Sicily  The ruins of the ancient Greek city of Morgantina sit high on a hill in eastern Sicily. There are cherry trees, wildflowers and total stillness, save for the sound of bird song. The area has long been sacred to Persephone; legend has it that Hades pulled that goddess into the underworld by a nearby lake.

title: Suit Accuses Director of New X-Men Film of Sexual Assault
description: LOS ANGELES  The filmmaker Bryan Singer, whose big-budget X-Men: Days of Future Past is set for release next month by 20th Century Fox, was accused in a federal lawsuit filed on Wednesday of drugging and raping an underage boy here and in Hawaii more than 14 years ago.

title: In Effort to Fight Overdoses, Staten Island Officers Will Soon Carry Heroin Antidote
description: Police officers across Staten Island will soon be equipped with and trained to use a nasal spray that reverses the effects of a heroin or opioid pill overdose, the authorities said on Thursday.

title: General Mills Amends New Legal Policies
description: General Mills, the multibillion-dollar food company behind brands like Cheerios and Pillsbury, said on Thursday that an update to its new legal policies, which stated that consumers joining our online communities could not sue the company, did not apply to people who visit its Facebook pages and Twitter accounts.

title: Kenyas Wide Net Against Terror Sweeps Up Refugees
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Fardos Osman sat on the concrete floor of a crammed room in a sprawling stadium next to scores of other women, many hiding their faces. She said she had been at the stadium for four days. Her refugee document had expired, she said, and she feared that she would be sent back to war-torn Somalia.

title: Ali Banisadr: Motherboard
description: Sperone Westwater

title: Scientists Find an Earth Twin, or Perhaps a Cousin
description: It is a bit bigger and somewhat colder, but a planet circling a star 500 light-years away is otherwise the closest match of our home world discovered so far, astronomers announced on Thursday.

title: Deciding How Much Information and Flexibility to Give Employees
description: At the most recent meeting of the She Owns It business group, the owners continued their conversation about how best to motivate employees. Deirdre Lord, who owns the Megawatt Hour, said that in addition to being transparent  and offering free food  employers can take other steps to keep employees engaged. Ive always been a believer in giving people equity, she said.

title: As East Village Gallery Closes, a Dispute Lingers
description: Little by little, another fixture in the East Village that helped define the neighborhoods mix of creativity and grit has been disappearing.

title: If a Driver Has an Accident While Wearing Google Glass, Should Google Get Sued?
description: Because no one in her right mind wants to be on the road with drivers who might be watching YouTube videos, lawmakers in various states are introducing legislation to ban the use of Google Glass and other similar devices while behind the wheel.

title: An Athlete Tackles Cancer
description: Its not a sprint, its a marathon. I heard those words often during my years as a soccer player at Drexel University. The mantra reminded me of my goals, and helped me endure the pain of practice and the mental stress of competition.

title: McLaren 650S: A Supercar of Hard Edges and Curves
description: Introduced on Thursday, April 17: McLaren 650S

title: If Youre Accidentally Not Included, Dont Worry About It
description: Zrcher Studio

title: American Academy of Arts and Sciences Names New President
description: Jonathan F. Fanton, the former president ofthe John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundationand of the New School, will be the new president of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, academy officials announced on Thursday. Dr. Fanton, 70, is currently the interim director and Franklin D. Roosevelt visiting fellow at the Roosevelt House Public Policy Institute at Hunter College.He was elected a fellow of the Academy in 1999.

title: Flyers Make No Secret About Testing Rangers McDonagh
description: When it comes to a game between the Rangers and the Philadelphia Flyers, punishment is an almost inevitable theme. The run-up to Game 1 of their first-round N.H.L. playoff series Thursday at Madison Square Garden is no exception.

title: Google Uses Algorithms to Create SLR-Like Photos
description: One of the hardest concepts to grasp as a photographer is depth of field.

title: Performance of Play in New York and Rwanda To Commemorate Genocide
description: The Museum of Jewish Heritage, in New York, and the Kigali Genocide Memorial Center, in Rwanda, will jointly mark the 20th anniversary of the Rwandan genocide with a performance of Jay O. Sanderss Unexplored Interior, a play inspired by the massacre of tens of thousands of Tutsi tribesman by Hutu extremists.

title: A Chef in the Field | Duck Eggs
description: This series by the chef Jeff Schwarz and the photographer Greg Kessler traces the trajectory of seasonal food  from its original source to a place on your table.

title: Obamacare, Deficits and Empirics
description: In my post yesterday on potential metrics for assessing Obamacares claim to be a policy success, I didnt directly address the laws eventual impact on the deficit. So Im grateful to Jonathan Chait for raising the issue, in the course of a post explaining why the Obamacare debate proves (yet again, he would say) that liberals are more empirical and data-driven than conservatives. Noting that many Republicans had alleged that the laws promise of deficit reduction was based (in Paul Ryans words) ongimmicks and smoke and mirrors, Chait cites a new C.B.O. estimate on the cost of the laws coverage expansion and announces that reality has spoken, and the case is closed:

title: Charges Are Said to Be Near Over Kickbacks in Exports of Luxury Cars to China
description: New York authorities appear to be getting closer to filing charges in connection with an investigation into accusations of kickbacks being paid to salesmen at high-end car dealerships in the New York area. The investigation is part of a broad national crackdown on businesses seeking to turn a quick profit by exporting luxury cars from the United States to China.

title: How Near Is the End? Britain May Tell Retirees
description: LONDON  British retirees may soon receive a novel kind of financial advice, courtesy of the state: They could be told when they are likely to die.

title: Is God Just Not That Into Me?
description: A boyfriends makeshift altar on the radiator cover prompts a search for answers.

title: Excerpt: Words of Radiance
description: An excerpt from the audiobook of Brandon Sandersons Words of Radiance, narrated by Kate Reading.

title: A Showman Puts Noodles on Display
description: There is no ramen at Kung Fu Little Steamed Buns Ramen. At least not the kind New Yorkers have come to associate with the word: no roiling Japanese broth, no heady undertow invoking at once the barnyard and the ocean floor.

title: The Tribeca Drive-In Series Offers Free Films
description: AT&T made some headlines last month with the announcement that tickets for the final Friday of the Tribeca Film Festival would be its treat. While Film for All Friday (next Friday) is undoubtedly a generous corporate gesture, the Miser is happy to point out that a few of the festivals screenings were already free and open to the public.

title: The Gun Report: April 17, 2014
description: The latest campaign gimmick among conservative lawmakers is free gun giveaways. Ron Paul recently announced that he was giving away an assault rifle through his lobbying group, Campaign for Liberty, because there can be no freedom without the ability to defend it. The drawing will take place on April 30, and the winner will receive an M4 carbine rifle, front and rear sights and two AR-15 magazines.

title: Robert Mangold
description: Pace Gallery

title: Shares of Twitter-Like Weibo Surge on Opening Day, as China I.P.O.s Mount
description: The Chinese are still coming, and so are the investors.

title: The Real Estate Show Was Then: 1980
description: James Fuentes

title: Nestl Loses a Clash Over Single-Serve Coffee
description: PARIS  Nestl, the worlds largest food company, was handed a defeat Thursday in its fight to maintain the global lead in the sale of single-dose coffee capsules.

title: This Weekend: Indie Films and Ai Weiwei
description: Things to do this weekend include the Tribeca Film Festival, which is in full swing in lower Manhattan. Theres also a new Ai Weiwei exhibition in Brooklyn, and Olga Peretyatko makes her Met debut.

title: Is God Just Not That Into Me?
description: I never thought much about God, certainly never wondered whether God was thinking about me, until I fell in love with a Zen Buddhist priest. I met him on an online dating site, an environment of tactical omission. I just knew he was a Buddhist, as he knew I was a writer.

title: This Weekend: Indie Films and Ai Weiwei
description: In the Video

title: Video: Ai Weiwei and the Tribeca Film Festival
description: This week in The Timess Culture Minute: The Tribeca Film Festival is in full swing in Lower Manhattan; the Russian soprano Olga Peretyatko makes her Metropolitan Opera debut on Thursday; and a new Ai Weiwei exhibition opens in Brooklyn.

title: My Daughter, Profoundly Disabled, Needs a School for Children Like Her
description: A Civil War historian, I never thought Id use the word segregationist to describe myself, but my daughters public school has changed all that. Im not talking about racial segregation  her school is one of the most economically and ethnically diverse in our town. Im talking about self-contained education for children with disabilities, which, in the United States, is increasingly rare.

title: Creation in Personal Utopias
description: The insider-outsider exhibition has been a major trend of the past few years, with works by folk and self-taught artists turning up at the 55th Venice Biennale and in galleries that normally showcase young, brazenly careerist people with M.F.A.s. In theory, everyone benefits; long-marginalized or forgotten artists get exposed to a wide audience, and contemporary artists receive a kind of authenticity by osmosis. But it doesnt always work out that way.

title: Morgan Stanley Gets Most Relief From First-Quarter Earnings
description: Few banks have reported much to crow about in their first-quarter earnings. But Morgan Stanley can claim relief, at least, from the $1.45 billion in net income it reported on Thursday.

title: Colm Toibin Named Chairman of PEN World Voices Festival
description: The PEN American Center has announced that Colm Toibin will serve as the chairman of the PEN World Voices Festival of International Literature beginning in 2015. Salman Rushdie has been the chairman since founding the festival in 2005.

title: New Banksy Work Goes From Wall to Boys Club to Museum
description: Another day, another Banksy work  and, naturally, another ownership dispute. On Tuesday a large Banksy piece, this one showing a couple embracing while also checking their cellphones behind each others back, appeared on a wall near the Broad Plain Boys Club in Bristol, England, the artists hometown. The piece, which also appears on the artists website, was apparently on plywood and screwed to the wall  not Banksys usual approach, which is to paint directly onto the surface.

title: Enrollments Exceed Obamas Target for Health Care Act
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama announced Thursday that eight million people have signed up for health insurance under the Affordable Care Act, including what the White House said were a sufficient number of young, healthy adults, a critical milestone that might counter election-year attacks by Republicans on the laws success and viability.

title: One-Fifth of Chinas Farmland Is Polluted, State Study Finds
description: BEIJING  The Chinese government released a report on Thursday that said nearly one-fifth of its arable land was polluted, a finding certain to raise questions about the toxic results of Chinas rapid industrialization, its lack of regulations over commercial interests and the consequences for the national food chain.

title: 2015 Infiniti Q70 and QX80: Two Big Boys Receive an Upgrade
description: Introduced on Thursday, April 17: 2015 Infiniti Q70 and QX80

title: Divine Decadence
description: Its a daring thing to write about an evil person, especially in this day of autobiographical fiction, when readers assume most characters are thinly veiled self-portraits. And yet evil characters are usually dynamic and fascinating, upstaging all the goody-goodies. Think of Miltons blazing, sexy Satan; Balzacs scheming, driven master criminal, Vautrin; or Shakespeares Iago. Despite the allure of such characters, writers today usually avoid them, maybe because the whole category of Evil seems too theological or because modern psychology assumes that every bad act can be traced to childhood neglect or abuse and thus be explained away. I have to give my students an assignment to write about bad guys in order to get them to do it. But when they do write about them, its such a release!

title: Updike at Rest
description: At first, he wanted to be a graphic artist. In 1954, John Updike  age 22, newly married and fresh out of Harvard, where hed studied English literature and taken art courses  was awarded a fellowship to study abroad, and decided to apply to the Ruskin School of Drawing and Fine Arts in Oxford, England. Asked to explain this decision, Updike replied, Its always been my ambition to be the next Walt Disney. During his childhood in Shillington, Pa., where he lived until the age of 13 and which his readers know through his Olinger stories, his mother, Linda, arranged for her prodigiously talented son to take lessons from a local artist. Later, when they moved to Plowville, 11 miles from Shillington, to a farmhouse he would describe in his novel Of the Farm, Updike  now 14 or 15  began sending his drawings and cartoons to The New Yorker and other publications. For Updike, who was interested in drawing but also, like his mother, in writing, to be published in The New Yorker had been an ambition, if not an obsession, from the moment the magazine first entered the household when he was 12.

title: Sea Change
description: This is the latest in a series of insightful books, like The Revenge of Geography and The Coming Anarchy, in which Robert D. Kaplan, the chief geopolitical analyst at the global intelligence company Stratfor, tries to explain how geography determines destiny  and what we should be doing about it. Asias Cauldron is a short book with a powerful thesis, and it stands out for its clarity and good sense from the great mass of Western writing on what Chinese politicians have taken to calling their peaceful development. If you are doing business in China, traveling in Southeast Asia or just obsessing about geopolitics, you will want to read it.

title: Live and Love for Today
description: I fell in love with a girl in high school. Nothing happened romantically between us, but we did hang out a few times. Eight years later, walking through a grocery store with my partner, I saw her again. She didnt acknowledge me; she may not have seen me. But I felt a torrent of emotions. We are different people now, and I am with someone I care for deeply. But something about seeing her unsettled me. Whatever I felt for her, Ive never felt again. And several times a year, I imagine my life with her in it. What should I do?

title: Jets Newly Signed Running Back Denies Report That His Injured Knee Is Arthritic
description: Chris Johnson, signed by the Jets to be the breakaway runner they lacked, on Thursday disputed an ESPN report that he had developed arthritis in his surgically repaired right knee.

title: Meat Market Has Its Loyalists, Even if They Shop Only Once a Year
description: .media.slideshow.in-page-player .headline { display: none; }

title: New Delhi Votes
description: The vote in Indias capital is considered somewhat of a bellwether in the national elections, which will continue through mid-May.

title: Letters: Stevens v. Shakespeare
description: Stevens v. Shakespeare

title: A Relaxed Cabin Feel, Made for Conversation
description: CAL ELLIOTT, the chef and owner of Rye, in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, said he always knew he wanted to set up a bar in the restaurants basement; he just wasnt sure what form it would take.

title: Coachella 2014: Selfies (and Outkast) in the Desert
description: Jon Caramanica talks to Ben Ratliff, who reviewed the festival for The Times.

title: Gupta to Surrender to Prison on June 17
description: Rajat K. Gupta, the former Goldman Sachs director convicted of insider trading, has agreed to surrender to prison on June 17, according to a court filing on Thursday.

title: Looking Back at Cuba and the Lower East Side
description: Ramiro A. Fernndez, a photography collector in Manhattan, says he has sometimes lain awake at night, thinking about similarities between shapes of things like Soviet rockets and the legs of glittery showgirls in pictures from pre-Castro Cuba.

title: 2015 BMW X4
description: BMW Unveils the 2015 X4.

title: Gabriel Garca Mrquez, Conjurer of Literary Magic, Dies at 87
description: Gabriel Garca Mrquez, the Colombian novelist whose One Hundred Years of Solitude established him as a giant of 20th-century literature, died on Thursday at his home in Mexico City. He was 87.

title: Ai Weiwei on Art and Technology
description: The artist addresses the flow of information and how it affects art today.

title: Milan Furniture Fair: Spazio Rossana Orlandi
description: Every year at the fair, Spazio Rossana Orlandi, a design gallery housed in a former tie factory, is a must-see destination.

title: Honda HR-V: The Fit as a Crossover
description: Introduced on Thursday, April 17: Honda HR-V

title: Cats and Dogs, Reigning
description: In 2007, a 13-year-old golden retriever named Alex, who was the subject of a contentious custody suit, was given a court-appointed lawyer to look after his best interests.

title: 2015 Dodge Challenger and Charger: Retro Retooled
description: Introduced on Thursday, April 17: 2015 Dodge Challenger and Charger

title: Gabriel Garca Mrquez, Novelist and Exponent of Magic Realism
description: He erupted on the literary world stage with the 1967 appearance of One Hundred Years of Solitude, which would sell more than 20 million copies.

title: A Geneva Hotel Thinks Younger
description: Some travelers will go to any length for the type of rest and relaxation that makes them feel 10 years younger.

title: A Provocateurs Medium: Outrage
description: The 2012 survey of the courageous Chinese artist Ai Weiwei seen at the Hirshhorn Museum in Washington has finally arrived in New York, and is much improved. The show, Ai Weiwei: According to What?, which opens Friday at the Brooklyn Museum, has been beefed up throughout, but most notably by two installation pieces completed in 2013. One, S.A.C.R.E.D., is perhaps the best work of art Mr. Ai has yet made.

title: Chelsea Clinton Says She Is Expecting
description: Chelsea Clinton said Thursday that she and her husband, Marc Mezvinsky, are expecting their first child this fall, giving Hillary Rodham Clinton an additional line in her biography as she contemplates another run for the presidency: grandmother.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Fading Gigolo
description: John Turturro, the director and writer of Fading Gigolo, narrates a sequence from his film.

title: MoMA Plans a Robert Gober Retrospective
description: It seems almost inconceivable that there has never been a Robert Gober retrospective in an American museum. This 59-year-old artist, who rose to prominence in the mid-1980s, is perhaps best known for his creepy sculptures of body parts  a cast wax leg or torso with individually applied hairs on them  as well as his signature sinks fashioned from plaster painted with enamel.

title: Putin on Eastern Ukraine
description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia addressed the escalating crisis in Ukraine during his annual televised question-and-answer session with the public in Moscow.

title: Adjusting for Price Inflation Isnt Enough
description: In recent blog posts I have explained why the Democrats proposed increase in the minimum wage  to $10.10 an hour by 2016  is too low. Even the much-lauded provision to annually adjust the minimum wage upward for price inflation is less than meets the eye.

title: Sign on the Digital Dotted Line
description: In an electronic age, mortgage closings stand out as particularly cumbersome transactions. Come closing day, hundreds of pages of paper land in a thump before the borrower, who must then physically sign and initial them in dozens of places.

title: What Eight Million Means
description: Sorry about blog silence  real life intruded, plus I did have to write a column. But I shouldnt let the day pass without mentioning the latest big Obamacare news. Final enrollment for 2014, we now know, will be more than 8 million. The age mix has also improved, with more young people signing up at the end; as Jonathan Cohn points out in the linked article, the age mix in Obamacares first year is now just about identical to the age mix in Romneycares first year. Goodbye, death spiral.

title: A Cozy Foursome, United in Rough-Hewed Harmony
description: In her 2011 book Alone Together, the social scientist Sherry Turkle describes our world as one in which technology has rendered us increasingly isolated when it comes to substantive interactions. We friend instead of making friends.

title: Virtu Financial Said to Shelve I.P.O. Plans
description: The high-frequency trading firm Virtu Financial, which had expected to go public this month, has decided to postpone those plans indefinitely, a person briefed on the matter said on Thursday.

title: Shattering in a Space of Healing
description: In her works that bridge dance and visual art, Taisha Paggett has deconstructed the fitness craze Zumba, blindfolded herself while drawing on the walls of a room and performed as Fila Buster, a character inspired by the filibuster of the Kansas-Nebraska Act of 1854. For her latest piece, Underwaters (we is ready, we is ready), Ms. Paggett, shifting among four personas, holds the floor  for hours on end  as part of the 2014 Biennial at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

title: Health Law Bellwether, UnitedHealth Posts Lower Profit
description: The UnitedHealth Group, one of the nations largest health insurers, reported lower earnings on Thursday, attributing its weak results in part to the federal health care law.

title: Pictures of the Day: South Korea and Elsewhere
description: Photos from South Korea, India, Greece and Israel.

title: John Turturro Narrates a Scene From Fading Gigolo
description: In this video, the actor, writer and director John Turturro discusses a sequence from his film Fading Gigolo, where he plays the gigolo of the title who is meeting a new client (Sofia Vergara).

title: 2015 Rolls-Royce Ghost Series II: An Entry-Level Rolls
description: Introduced on Wednesday, April 16: 2015 Rolls-Royce Ghost Series II

title: The Separate Kitchen Makes a Comeback
description: When Ashley Mabbitt was growing up in a four-bedroom house outside Chicago, her grandmother gave her this advice: When I have people over, I like to feel Im coming to a party. I like to take off my apron, put on lipstick, and step into a separate space.

title: Clinging to Minimalism, in Shadows and Whispers
description: Tahliah Barnett sings with clear voice, and she sings with her body, but on Wednesday night at Glasslands Gallery, she began her show with a whisper.

title: Elizabeth Gilberts New Chapter Begins
description: An Italianate Victorian mini-estate built in 1869 on a hilltop above the Delaware River by a descendant of John Reading  Colonial New Jerseys first native-born governor  is about to enter the market at $999,000. The house has been owned for the last six years by the author Elizabeth Gilbert, whose best-selling memoir, Eat, Pray, Love, revolutionized the concept of self-actualization for its fans. The annual property tax is $13,688.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: Clip: Transcendence
description: A scene from the film.

title: I Am My Own Monster (Technology Rules!)
description: Johnny Depp, whos built a brilliant career despite many of his lamentable film choices, may not be the first actor you think of to play a genius  much less humanitys destroyer or savior. But hes weirdly perfect in Transcendence, an inelegant, no doubt implausible (maybe not) science-fiction film about a futurist whose consciousness is uploaded onto the Internet. There, he (or a mysterious vestige of his being) expands like the universe, growing larger and mutating into a being who is godlike and yet far from divine, sort of like a star at the apex of his popularity.

title: His Win Obscured, Runner Left Mark Off the Course
description: BOSTON  It was October, six months after Lelisa Desisa of Ethiopia won the stricken 2013 Boston Marathon. He had returned for another race. On his way to dinner with friends, he had a request. He wanted to cross the finish line again on Boylston Street to reclaim in a private moment a triumph made irrelevant by tragedy.

title: Remembering the Life and Work of Gabriel Garca Mrquez
description: Gabriel Garca Mrquez died on Thursday at 87. Over the years, as his work was reviewed in The New York Times, numerous luminaries took the opportunity to consider the great author and his work, including William Kennedy, Robert Stone and Thomas Pynchon.

title: Even Vampires Pass the Velvet Rope
description: It wouldnt be fair to call Zombeavers a Sharknado rip-off: The zombie-beavers film wrapped production in March 2013, four months before the shark-tornado film created a vogue for over-the-top-cheesy B movies with compound titles. But it would be fair to guess that the Tribeca Film Festival, where Zombeavers has its world premiere on Saturday night, wouldnt mind if a little of that Sharknado magic rubbed off.

title: Big Labels Take Aim at Pandora on Royalties
description: The music industry has opened a new front in its war against Pandora Media: royalties for songs made before 1972.

title: Red Bulls Rewind: A Win to Calm Some Nerves
description: The Red Bulls do not make things easy, but they do make them interesting.

title: Obama Announces New Health Care Numbers
description: President Obama announced that eight million people have signed up for health insurance under the Affordable Care Act.

title: My Little Rifle
description: A Dutch photographer enters the world of real guns for real kids.

title: In an Uneven Economy, an Opening in the Service Sector Beckons
description: The title character in Fading Gigolo, a low-key, low-energy comedy about New York haves and have-nots, is Fioravante, a melancholic bookstore employee played by the films director, John Turturro. When you first meet Fioravante, hes packing up boxes, on the verge of becoming an ex-bookstore employee. His boss, Murray (Woody Allen), has been forced to shutter his charming shop, a painful and all-too-frequent occurrence in the real New York. In a moment of inspiration, or really creative contrivance, Murray suggests  ta-da  that Fioravante take up hooking.

title: Chelsea Clinton Announces Her Pregnancy
description: Ms. Clinton said that she and her husband were expecting their first child this year.

title: Mazda Commemorates the Miatas Birthday With a Gathering of Its Classics
description: Anniversary celebrations are a recurring theme at this years New York auto show, and Mazda joined the party on Wednesday. Mazdas birthday child was the Miata, the nimble two-seat sports car that set a new tone for the brand when it had its premiere at the Chicago auto show a quarter century ago. The Mazda festivities showcased a lot of what is old, with some classic and race-veteran Miatas, a bit of what is genuinely new with a chassis-only preview of the next-generation Miata and some of what is just a wee bit new in the MX-5 Miata 25th Anniversary Edition.

title: Found Everything, Tried Everything, All His Own Way
description: Get confused is the first and last message of Alibis: Sigmar Polke 1963-2010 at the Museum of Modern Art. And if you think, as I do, that some degree of continuing bafflement is a healthy reaction to art, this disorienting contact high of a show is for you.

title: A Labor Leaders Devotion to His Cause
description: I think I know what my mission is, says the labor leader Cesar Chavez in Cesars Last Fast. Righting the wrongs that were committed against workers for 100 years. Chavez  (1927-1993), a founder of what became the United Farm Workers union, faced brutal odds, as this compelling documentary demonstrates.

title: Comedy Listings for April 18-24
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Theater Listings for April 18-24
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Opera and Classical Music Listings for April 18-24
description: Reviews of classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Competing to Be a Phallic Symbol
description: Sigurdur Hjartarson has a preoccupation with phalluses. It started in 1974, when he was given a bull penis as a joke, popped it in formaldehyde and decided it needed companions.

title: SpongeBob, the Carnivore
description: The oceans are full of predators, but nobody thought sponges were among them until 1995, when scientists first realized that not all of these sedentary animals spent their days just filtering out bacteria and other micro-organisms from seawater.

title: Dance Listings for April 18-24
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for April 18-24
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Waiting for Waiting for Guffman, Sort Of
description: One day, someone will make a brilliant mockumentary about a team of filmmakers struggling to make their own Christopher Guest mockumentary. Until then, there is Authors Anonymous, directed by Ellie Kanner from a screenplay by David Congalton, but entirely in the vein of Mr. Guests Waiting for Guffman. The sendups target is a group of Los Angeles writers who meet weekly, waiting to be published.

title: Spare Times for Children for April 18-24
description: MR. CHICKEES FUNNY MONEY

title: Spare Times for April 18-24
description: EASTER PARADE AND EASTER BONNET FESTIVAL (Sunday) Pedestrians will be able to step off the curb into the throng of strollers, street performers and photographers filling Fifth Avenue, from 49th to 57th Streets, for this annual event.

title: In the City, a Fresh, Crisp Breath of Summer From the Mountains
description: The title of the program at SubCulture on Wednesday night was playfully ambiguous: The Complete Aspen Music Festival and School (abridged). Sounds like fun, right?

title: In Europe, Auto Sales Are Still Low, But They Are Rising
description: European auto sales figures for March, reported today, show that slightly more new cars were sold in the euro zone during the most recent 12 months than had been sold a year earlier. The increase was a tiny one, just 0.4 percent.

title: A Bear, Her Cubs and the Wilderness
description: Disneys experience in the animal documentary business (as opposed to the business of talking animated animals) stretches back over half a century. Before there was todays Bears there was Bear Country, an Academy Award winner in 1954. The newer ursine chronicle looks at one hungry year in the life of an Alaska mother and her two cubs, with typically simple storytelling and the drumbeat of the hunt for enough food to survive the winter.

title: Global Sounds, Woven Together
description: If there is one thing that sets the MATA Festival apart from many of the other contemporary-classical bounties New York regularly produces, it might be a robust international representation, which seems to have grown sharply since Yotam Haber  a Dutch-born global citizen and the festivals artistic director from 2009 until this year  has been at the helm. This years series, the 16th since MATA began in 1996, includes composers from 17 countries.

title: This Weeks Movies: April 18, 2014
description: The New York Times film critics review Transcendence, Fading Gigolo and Manakamana.

title: Once Again, Fires Burn and Caldrons Bubble
description: Well, theres nothing halfway about WGN Americas entry into the scripted-series world. The witch-infested Salem, its initial offering, which has its premiere on Sunday, is brash and well executed and expensive-looking. And if you strip away the various questions and back stories involving the stations strategy and just look at Salem as a television show, youve got to admit that its perversely entertaining.

title: Deadbeat on the Range
description: Imagine a vendor on the National Mall, selling burgers and dogs, who hasnt paid his rent in 20 years. He refuses to recognize his landlord, the National Park Service, as a legitimate authority. Every court has ruled against him, and fines have piled up. Whats more, the effluents from his food cart are having a detrimental effect on the spring grass in the capital.

title: From Andreessen, a Lesson in Corporate Finance
description: The valuations of highflying technology companies can seem baffling to those not initiated in the ways of Silicon Valley.

title: Capitalism and the Dalai Lama
description: WHAT can Washington, D.C., learn from a Buddhist monk?

title: Horse Owners and Trainers Say Theyll Release Veterinary Records
description: In an effort to restore integrity and transparency to a sport battered by scandal, some of horse racings most prominent owners and trainers pledged Thursday to make public the veterinary records of their horses competing in high-level stakes races, including the Kentucky Derby.

title: Abolish Horse-Drawn Carriages?
description: To the Editor:

title: Benefits of Hospice Care
description: To the Editor:

title: In Politics, a Cold Streak Can Make Loyalty Vanish
description: The standard for good old-fashioned treachery in politics is pretty low  in fact, many people think politics is a synonym for treachery. Even with that, the latest move by one of the states biggest business groups against the sitting lieutenant governor was breathtaking.

title: More Senseless Gun Deaths
description: To the Editor:

title: Unlikely Superstar Swap Could Aid Knicks
description: The Knicks completed another disappointing season Wednesday night, beating the playoff-bound Toronto Raptors before a Madison Square Garden crowd that snacked on complimentary boxes of popcorn  a thank you from the organization to fans for enduring a 41st consecutive season without a championship.

title: ESPN Sees Continued Profitability Despite Competition
description: Aiming to squelch smoldering concerns about ESPNs continued profitability amid rising sports rights costs, the Walt Disney Company on Thursday said profits at its ESPN-dominated cable networks unit would grow in the high single digits on a compounded annual basis for the next three years.

title: Mock Gefilte Fish
description: To the Editor:

title: Popes Comments on Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Extend the Mideast Talks
description: To the Editor:

title: Soaring Trips to a Temple in Nepal
description: The faces in Manakamana, a transporting ethnographic film set in a green sliver of Nepal, stare into the camera, out into space and, perhaps, into the great beyond. The faces are sometimes creased and weathered, sometimes smooth as pebbles. A few look etched with worry, as if they were weighed down by a heavy burden, although they may also be seized with fear. Thats because for 10 or so minutes at a time, these faces are floating hundreds of feet above a lush Nepali forest in a cable car that takes pilgrims to and from the temple that gives this film its rhythmic title.

title: Iran Gets an Unlikely Visitor, an American Plane, but No One Seems to Know Why
description: President Obama has warned that Iran is not open for business, even as the United States has loosened some of its punishing economic sanctions as part of an interim nuclear pact.

title: Time Is Short for High-Risk Rescue Effort
description: With rising waves and swift currents off the southern coast of South Korea having largely stymied search operations around a capsized ferry late Thursday night, the fate of 271 people still missing was unknown. It was unclear even how many might still be aboard the vessel  which was underwater save for a small section of its keel  and if so whether any were in areas with pockets of air.

title: Dierdorf, Ex-Wolverine, Joins Michigan Radio
description: When Dan Dierdorf called his final N.F.L. game for CBS Sports in January, he expected to retire from full-time work. He had two artificial hips, two artificial knees and a back in dire need of surgery.

title: A Plea for Equal Pay for Equal Pedaling
description: You cant exactly call Half the Road an infomercial for womens cycling. Its more like a political campaign ad disguised as a public service announcement, and the message is: Get rid of the U.C.I.s current leaders. Thats the Union Cycliste Internationale, the organization that its detractors cant just walk away from, because it has the power to award Olympic qualification points.

title: Demands That Jews Register in Eastern Ukraine Are Denounced, and Denied
