description: DONETSK, Ukraine  Worshipers at the Bet Menakhem-Mendl synagogue in this eastern Ukrainian city confronted a horrifying scene as they left a Passover service this week: masked men on a sidewalk handing out leaflets demanding that Jews register and pay a fine or leave the area, witnesses said.

title: Blood Ties Between Cop and Killer
description: Pulp done with passion can be its own reward, as the veteran Hong Kong filmmaker Dante Lam shows with his feverish cop thriller That Demon Within. Full of blood, tears and fire  from guns and gas explosions  this corpse-ridden movie wrenches us through an overheated plot involving a demon-mask-wearing gang of robbers and a mentally fragile cop. Its none too subtle in either its sickly-green color schemes or its melodramatic logic, as timid its not.

title: Merely Rich and Superrich: The Tax Gap Is Narrowing
description: Will this be the year that the superrich finally pay higher taxes than the very rich?

title: Virginia Law Phasing Out Fox Pens Vexes All Sides
description: STONY CREEK, Va.  Emerson Poarch Jr., 72, says his father went to his grave incredulous that hunters would pay a fee to run their hounds in a fox pen.

title: When the Circus Descends
description: We are pretty familiar with this story: A perfectly sensible if slightly boring idea is walking down the street. Suddenly, the ideological circus descends, burying the sensible idea in hysterical claims and fevered accusations. The ideas political backers beat a craven retreat. The idea dies.

title: A Lost Souls Wanderings
description: Nathan Silvers Soft in the Head opens in medias res, as Natalia (Sheila Etxeberra) explains to her abusive boyfriend (Nick Korbee) that shes having a holiday dinner with her friend Hannahs family. When this scene turns into a violent breakup, Mr. Silver disorientingly cuts to the opening titles, shown over an Orthodox Jewish candle-lighting ceremony. A sense of worlds colliding seems fundamental to the film.

title: University of Chicago Economist Who Studies Media Receives Clark Medal
description: Matthew Gentzkow, an economics professor at the University of Chicago Booth School of Business who has done innovative work analyzing issues like bias in the press and the impact of the media on society, has been awarded the 2014 John Bates Clark Medal, the American Economic Association announced Thursday.

title: Muslim Cleric Was Committed to War, Prosecutor Says in Terrorism Trial
description: Mostafa Kamel Mostafa, an Egyptian-born cleric who became prominent for his fiery sermons at a British mosque, was more than just a preacher, a federal prosecutor said on Thursday. He was a trainer of terrorists, and he used the cover of religion so he could hide in plain sight in London.

title: Volvo XC90: The First of a New Breed
description: Introduced on Thursday, April 17: Volvo XC90

title: After Tension, Lions Gate Consolidates Its Movie Marketing
description: LOS ANGELES  Lions Gate Entertainment on Thursday announced the resignation of one movie marketing chief and the promotion of another, ending one of Hollywoods tensest working arrangements.

title: Taxi Driver Charged in $28,000 Toll Fraud
description: Back and forth the driver went. A thousand times over the Robert F. Kennedy Bridge. Three thousand trips through the Queens-Midtown Tunnel.

title: Stranded by the Fight Over a Borders Future
description: JERUSALEM  Abutting Israels separation wall, the blackened shell of a factory building known by local Palestinian residents as the station serves as a den for drug dealers and addicts. Out front, at a bend in the road, rotting trash smolders in an unofficial garbage dump as children pass on their way home from the nearby elementary school.

title: Libraries Seek High-Speed Broadband
description: WASHINGTON  The federal E-Rate program has been a boon for schools and public libraries across the country, helping them acquire Internet access and telecommunications products at affordable or vastly discounted rates. But the sleek new computers, laptops and tablets do not mean much without high-quality broadband service to match.

title: He Took the Dare to Change His Life
description: A study of desperation and the evil within, Daniel Stamms 13 Sins is an empty, efficient thriller that leaves you as cold as most of its characters. Based on the 2006 Thai movie 13: Game of Death, this disappointing remake is held together primarily by Mark Webbers charged central performance as Elliot, a wimpy insurance salesman.

title: In a Reunion, 2 Rangers and a Flyer Recall Glory
description: Ten years ago, Brad Richards, Martin St. Louis and Vincent Lecavalier were integral to the Tampa Bay Lightnings Stanley Cup run.

title: 2014 Soleil Anadi: Adding Some Elegance to the Corvette
description: Introduced on Thursday, April 17: 2014 Soleil Anadi

title: Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs Adjust to New Banking Climate
description: Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs had not reported earnings on the same day since the darkest phase of the financial crisis in 2008, but they did so again on Thursday.

title: At 2014 New York Auto Show, Just Click to Kick the Tires
description: SOON after Google Street View, the Google Maps feature that provides pedestrian-level views of cities worldwide, was introduced in 2007, people who chanced to see the image-capturing cars with 360-degree cameras mounted on their roofs began to post pictures of the sightings online with the fervor of bird-watchers.

title: Study Chides U.S. Over Loan Default by Solar Business
description: WASHINGTON  Long before the Energy Department lost $68 million on Abound Solar, a manufacturer that went bankrupt two years ago, it should have known that the companys chance of repaying the loan it had guaranteed was deteriorating, according to a report by the departments inspector general.

title: Taking the Man Out of Oklahoma, Maybe
description: In Home, James, James is a photographer who makes most of his money as a driver for hire who transports the dissolute late-night souls of Tulsa, Okla., when theyve had one or three too many. Thats how he first meets Cooper, a hard-drinking rich girl.

title: The 42-Month Typo
description: No one disputes this fact: Ceasar Huerta Cantu was wrongly sentenced to three and a half extra years in federal prison because of a typo on a court document. Not his lawyer, not the prosecutor, not the judge. And yet it still took President Obamas intervention to fix the error  two years after Mr. Cantu himself discovered it.

title: In Scripted Surprise, Putin Answers Snowden on Spying
description: MOSCOW  The setup could not have been more perfect.

title: Turkeys Battle With Twitter
description: Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the combative prime minister of Turkey, has called Twitter the worst menace to society, and he seems intent on intimidating its users.

title: Mayor Details New Hurricane Sandy Aid Reforms
description: For thousands of New Yorkers whose homes were damaged or destroyed by Hurricane Sandy, the rebuilding process has been a slog of navigating the federal bureaucracy and an alphabet soup of municipal agencies, with residents of Staten Island and the Rockaways accusing the city of paralysis and, in some cases, neglect.

title: No Spring Break for the Unemployed
description: As members of Congress enjoy their extended spring break, 2.3 million unemployed Americans have been left to worry about whether lawmakers will ever get around to renewing federal unemployment benefits, which expired at the end of 2013. Every week that Congress fails to act, another 70,000 jobless workers will find there is no longer a federal program to turn to.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 17, 2014
description: April 17, 2014

title: Womens Soccer League Tries to Connect and Survive
description: GERMANTOWN, Md.  Natalie Lennartsson, a perky fourth grader who is 10 going on 17, said she didnt learn a ton of new things Wednesday at a soccer clinic hosted by the Washington Spirit, the local womens professional team.

title: Automakers Let the Good Times Roll
description: Its a banner time in the car industry. The products are flowing and sales numbers are high. That flush feeling coincides with the New York International Auto Show, and has prompted automakers to stage many outside events spilling over from the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center into museums, restaurants and landmarks across the city.

title: Hollywood Begs for a Tax Break in Some States, Including California
description: LOS ANGELES  The San Fernando Valley has served as home to award-winning movies like E.T., Boogie Nights and Crash. But Raul Bocanegra, a state lawmaker representing a large swath of the valley, worries about the collapse of film and television production in his district and across Hollywoods home state.

title: Sandy Recovery Still Lagging
description: The hardest test of Mayor Bill de Blasios vision and competence might end up being something quite different from expanding prekindergarten or affordable housing. It might just be his ability to restore normality to the lives of tens of thousands of New Yorkers in the Hurricane Sandy zone, from the Rockaways to Staten Island, whose homes and businesses were washed away or ruined a year and a half ago. And, once that job is done, preparing the city to weather the inevitable and potentially disastrous storms to come.

title: Salvation Gets Cheap
description: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, which pools the efforts of scientists around the globe, has begun releasing draft chapters from its latest assessment, and, for the most part, the reading is as grim as you might expect. We are still on the road to catastrophe without major policy changes.

title: Passover in the Confederacy
description: For at least one night each spring during the Civil War, in places like Louisiana and South Carolina and Georgia and Virginia, Confederate Jews commemorated how God freed the children of Israel from slavery. They retold the story of when God is said to have sent down 10 plagues to help free the Hebrews from their bondage, the last of which was the slaying of all Egyptians firstborn children, and how the Jews marked their door posts with the blood of a slaughtered lamb so the Angel of Death would know to pass over them. Thus, they celebrated their liberation more than 3,000 years ago from slavery in ancient Egypt, and their exodus.

title: Dont Just Pass the Joint, Sell It
description: Selling or using marijuana remains illegal in plenty of states, but on screen, the underground marijuana business is already being treated with a Happy Days glow of nostalgia. Thats the tone of Kid Cannabis, a rollicking tale of border-running teenage pot entrepreneurs based on the real-life story of Nate Norman.

title: Toe to Toe With the N.R.A.
Live, and Online: Poison
description: Millions of Chinese are watching live interactive web entertainment, like the popular karaoke performer seen in this clip, who goes by the stage name Poison.

title: Lucrative Stardom in China, Using a Webcam and a Voice
description: ZIGONG, China  Dolled up with makeup and a blond wig, the pretty young Chinese woman sat at home in her bedroom on a quiet Sunday evening and began singing karaoke.

title: Measure to Repeal Death Penalty Fails by a Single Vote in New Hampshire Senate
description: CONCORD, N.H.  In a tie vote, the New Hampshire Senate deadlocked Thursday on whether to repeal the death penalty, leaving the current law intact and New Hampshire as the lone state in New England that allows the execution of anyone convicted of a capital crime.

title: Nigeria Fears Captive Girls Will Be Held as Sex Slaves
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  Dozens of schoolgirls abducted by armed militants in northeastern Nigeria this week remained missing on Thursday amid fears that they would be turned into sex slaves and cooks if they were not rescued, a top official in the region said.

title: After the Violence, the Real Pain Begins
description: A bizarre puzzle box of twisted passions and psychological sickness, Zack Parkers Proxy presents us almost immediately with a scene of such repulsive brutality that the film seems to be daring us to keep watching. If you accept, youll find yourself wading waist-deep into the swampy center of an original if overlong story about manufactured grief and disturbingly bad mothering.

title: Entwining Tales of Time, Memory and Love
description: The Magus of magical realism, Gabriel Garca Mrquez  who died on Thursday at his home in Mexico City, at the age of 87  used his fecund imagination and exuberant sleight of hand to conjure the miraculous in his fiction: plagues of insomnia and forgetfulness, a cluster of magical grapes containing the secret of death, an all-night rain of yellow blossoms, a swamp of lilies oozing blood, a Spanish galleon marooned in a Latin American jungle, cattle born bearing the brand of their owner.

title: Tip Well: Its Your Waiters Last Night
description: Tasting Menu cites as inspirations the 2011 closing of El Bulli, the acclaimed Catalan restaurant that showcased its visionary chef, Ferran Adri, as well as culinary cinema like Big Night and Babettes Feast. Unfortunately, Roger Guals half-baked film hopes to split the difference between romantic comedy and foodie delight but fails at both.

title: Gotta Dance (Together)
description: O.K., its not Montagues and Capulets, its rival Brooklyn dance clubs: the gritty, underground Static and the more upper-crust Oto. The star-crossed lovers are Donny (Derek Hough), a street dancer and parolee from New Orleans, and Aya (the South Korean pop star BoA), a Korean dancer-drummer raised in Japan. Statics owner is Donnys foster brother, Nick (Wesley Jonathan), who had a falling-out with his partner, Kaz (Will Yun Lee of Hawaii Five-O), Ayas overprotective brother. Kaz went to work at Oto, which is owned by the Wall Street knave Michael (Jefferson Brown), who has designs on Aya and wants her at his beck and call.

title: Mummy Dearest, Back for More
description: As soon as a playhouse announces a Charles Ludlam comedy, how sellers of Velcro and cheap wigs must rejoice. When Ludlam died in 1987, he left behind a flamboyant, genre-defying oeuvre that depends on outrageous, easily doffed costumes. In The Mystery of Irma Vep: A Penny Dreadful, revived by Red Bull Theater at the Lucille Lortel Theater, two stalwart actors (Arnie Burton and Robert Sella) shift gowns, trousers, fezzes and the occasional wooden leg faster than laws of space and time would seem to permit.

title: In the Spotlight, Finding His Religion
description: If only the Tony Awards nominating committee would see fit to expand its categories, I could confidently predict at least two eminently deserving winners. For best performance by two actors in the same role ... (hold your breath, nibble your nails) ...sorry, no suspense here, folks.

title: Fame-Hating Lewis Carroll Letter Lands in Los Angeles
description: A letter by Lewis Carroll declaring his hatred for fame and sometime wish that he had never written Alices Adventures in Wonderland has now found a home in the epicenter of the global celebrity hellscape: Los Angeles.

title: Learn to Teach
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  I just barely got a toehold in James Mulherns puzzle today. The clues seemed unusually cryptic for my money (not cryptic crossword style, just out of my reach). Thats not a bad thing. Most solvers like to wrap their brains around some difficult cluing and new, crunchy words, and this puzzle delivers.

title: A Chip Off the Old Engine Block
description: In the deadly voice-over that begins Joel Surnows Small Time, a man declares: This is the story about my father and the summer we spent together many years ago. It was the summer that changed my life.

title: Obama on Ukraine Pact
description: After a diplomatic agreement to ease tensions in Ukraine was reached, the president expressed skepticism about Russias promise to de-escalate the volatile situation.

title: Deal is Reached to Ease Tension in East Ukraine
description: GENEVA  The United States, Russia, Ukraine and the European Union reached an agreement on Thursday evening that called for armed pro-Russian bands in eastern Ukraine to surrender the government buildings they have seized and that outlined other steps to defuse a crisis that has rattled the international community.

title: That Thing He Had for the Bosss Wife
description: An unconsummated long-distance passion that resists the erosion of time and memory is the subject of the Austrian writer Stefan Zweigs posthumously published novella, Journey Into the Past. When addressed in the movies, this kind of longing is usually diluted into soap opera and its darker psychological implications suffocated by a gauzy romanticism. The French director Patrice Lecontes film, A Promise, adapted from the novella, is no exception.

title: Unmoved, Anthony Is Still on Fence Over Future
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Not so long ago, Carmelo Anthony made a public appearance in which he expressed his desire to test free agency. He wanted to explore his options, he said, although he emphasized that his preference was to remain with the Knicks.

title: Rancher Says Utility Put Power Line in Wrong Place
description: RHOME, Tex.  Johnny Vinson is not your typical underdog. At 82, he is a rancher who has sold more land than most rural Texans could imagine owning. And he has plenty left to stand on, including more than 3,500 acres in Wise County that have ample room for dozens of gas wells, grazing cattle, a ranch house and staff living quarters.

title: Oil and Water Mix, Then Emotions Flare
description: As the fourth anniversary of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill approaches, on April 20, arguments will rage about who should have done what and when. The advocacy documentary Vanishing Pearls, which opens on Friday in New York and Los Angeles and will have one-night engagements in cities across the country over the next three months, makes an impassioned case that the spills effects still linger.

title: Christie Appoints an Ombudsman
description: Continuing his efforts to move past the scandal surrounding the George Washington Bridge lane closings, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey on Thursday named an ombudsman to strengthen ethics policies in his office, and eliminated the department that an internal investigation found had rewarded and punished mayors across the state depending on whether they supported the governors re-election.

title: Clinton Backer Pleads Guilty in a Straw Donor Scheme
description: As Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton ran for president in 2008, one of her most enthusiastic financial supporters was Sant Singh Chatwal, an Indian-American hotel and restaurant owner, whose relationship with the Clintons dated back years.

title: U.N. Council Takes Up Question of Rights in North Korea
description: The United Nations appeared to move a step closer on Thursday to holding North Koreas government accountable for what an investigative panel has called a history of crimes against humanity and egregious human rights abuses, as the Security Council convened a special session to hear the panels views on what should be done.

title: A Couple of Heirs of Travis Bickle
description: A 34-year-old messenger still living at home, Rupert Pupkin (Robert De Niro) dreams of becoming a stand-up comedy star. To force fates hand, he stalks and kidnaps his idol, the TV talk show host Jerry Langford (Jerry Lewis). Martin Scorseses 1983 movie The King of Comedy not only told a story but identified a malaise. Call it Pupkinitis.

title: Turkey: Intelligence Bill Approved
description: Turkeys Parliament on Thursday passed a bill that increases the powers of the national spy agency and strengthens its immunity, a move that critics said would allow Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan to bolster his control over state institutions. The measure, which requires presidential approval before it becomes a law, would give the National Intelligence Organization, known by the initials of its Turkish name M.I.T., access to information collected by public and private institutions without a court order and would expand its ability to carry out covert operations. Government officials said the changes would make the agency more efficient and provide protections for its personnel. Mr. Erdogan has been tightening his grip on state agencies as his government deals with accusations of corruption and has tried to block or control access to the Internet, Twitter and YouTube. With this legislation, the M.I.T. is no longer a national intelligence agency but has become the prime ministers intelligence agency, said an opposition lawmaker, Sezgin Tanrikulu.

title: Congo: Park Director Survives Shooting
description: Emmanuel de Merode, an internationally recognized Belgian conservationist who has been working to protect rare mountain gorillas in the Democratic Republic of Congo, is recovering from gunshot wounds after being attacked Tuesday by unknown assailants, officials said Thursday. Mr. de Merode, 43, the director of the Virunga National Park, Africas oldest national park, was attacked by the gunmen as he drove near Goma, not far from the border with Rwanda. He was taken to a hospital in Goma, where he underwent surgery. Mr. de Merode, above, is a Belgian prince and is married to Louise Leakey, a Kenyan paleontologist and the granddaughter of the archaeologist Louis Leakey, known for his studies on human evolution in Africa. Virunga National Park was established in 1925 by Belgium, which then governed Congo.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Sabathia Overcomes an Ace and a Dome, With Help From a Triple Play
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Yangervis Solarte has had many firsts since joining the Yankees this year, including his first major league game and his first hit. On Thursday, he added to his collection with his first major league home run and his first triple play at any level.

title: Senate Seat That Davis Leaves Behind Looks Crucial
description: The two Republicans campaigning to replace State Senator Wendy Davis, the Fort Worth Democrat who is running for governor, are locked in a tight primary runoff battle.

title: Cost of Treatment May Influence Doctors
description: Saying they can no longer ignore the rising prices of health care, some of the most influential medical groups in the nation are recommending that doctors weigh the costs, not just the effectiveness of treatments, as they make decisions about patient care.

title: After Hit to Mouth, Rangers Draw First Blood
description: The Rangers took full advantage of a rookies mistake and a teammates bloodied mouth to break open their Stanley Cup opener Thursday night.

title: South Korea Ferry Updates
description: Officials discussed the latest developments in the search for passengers trapped inside the ferry that sank in the waters off southwestern South Korea.

title: Rangers-Flyers Playoff Series
description: Action from the Rangers 4-1 victory over Philadelphia in the opener of their Eastern Conference series.

title: Sebelius Says Shes Not Interested in Senate Run
description: WASHINGTON  Kathleen Sebelius, the soon-to-be former secretary of the Health and Human Services Department, said through a spokeswoman on Thursday that she was not interested in running for the Senate in Kansas, despite recent entreaties from Democrats.

title: Messages From Students on South Korean Ferry
description: As a South Korean ferry began sinking with 475 people believed to be aboard  325 of them students from Danwon High School  passengers reached for their cellphones and began sending messages to their loved ones. The following are transcripts of those exchanges.

title: Garca Mrquez, Magical Realism Master
description: Gabriel Garca Mrquez, the Nobel laureate Colombian author whose One Hundred Years of Solitude established him as a giant of 20th-century literature, died on Thursday at his home in Mexico City.

title: Alternative to Carriage Has Little Horsepower
description: The horse of the future could be an electric car with an ah-ooga horn and seating for eight.

title: Three Pitches, Nine Outs
description: The Yankees last three triple plays have come with C. C. Sabathia on the mound.

title: Another Charge in Navy Bribe Case
description: A Navy enlisted man was charged in a complaint unsealedThursdaywith accepting $1,000-a-month in cash, trips and consumer electronics for supplying a Malaysian contractor with sensitive Navy ship schedules. The petty officer, Dan Layug, 27, was the fourth Navy employee arrested in the case, which has also led to charges against the contractor, Leonard Glenn Francis, for conspiring to bribe officials to inflate his billings.Prosecutors say Mr. Layug, who was released on a $100,000 bond, deposited payments from Mr. Franciss company, Glenn Defense Marine Asia, in a bank account in the name of his infant daughter.

title: Officials in Rhythmic Gymnastics Judging Scandal Are Said to Be Exonerated
description: Citing a lack of evidence, the Court of Arbitration for Sport has exonerated six officials who were implicated in a judging scandal, annulling a decision by the governing body for rhythmic gymnastics.

title: A New, Cowboy-Inspired Fashion Frontier
description: Then and now, the rugged on-screen apparel of the cinematic heroes Clint Eastwood and John Wayne serves as an iconic expression of American style. This season, their characters Wild West legacy lives on in fashions frontier as the influence for spring collections by the likes of Junya Watanabe, Paco Rabanne, Creatures of the Wind and Valentino. Designers took visual cues from the cowboy uniform  distressed denim, fringe, turquoise, embroidery and, of course, boots  to create separates that come together for a fully transportive look. But if a head-to-toe Annie Oakley-influenced ensemble isnt your modus operandi, pairing any of these individual items with monochromatic basics  a white tee with Junya Watanabe jeans or a black dress with a cashmere Elder Statesman bandana  will keep things relevant and fresh.

title: Police Capture and Question Suspect in Shooting of Brooklyn Teenager
description: New York City detectives on Thursday night were questioning a suspect in a daytime shooting in Brooklyn that severely wounded a 13-year-old bystander this week, the police said.

title: Events in New Jersey for April 20-26, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Ask Well: Are Exercise Cool-Downs Necessary?
description: Question:

title: 2 Men Get $18 Million Each in Wrongful Conviction Case
description: Thirty years ago, a 16-year-old girl, Theresa Fusco, was found raped and strangled near the roller skating rink on Long Island where she worked. Not long afterward, prosecutors charged three men, who were convicted and went on to spend 18 years in prison.

title: Events on Long Island for April 20-26, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Westchester for April 20-26, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Connecticut for April 20-26, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Nina Cassian, Romanian Poet Exiled for Skewering Regime, Dies at 89
description: Nina Cassian, an exiled Romanian poet who sought refuge in the United States after her poems satirizing the regime of President Nicolae Ceausescu fell into the hands of his secret police, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 89.

title: With Cuomos Help, M.T.A. and Union Reach a Deal
description: When the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority approved its budget in December, agency documents warned that any increases in labor costs could have devastating consequences.

title: Man Critically Injured in Hit-and-Run
description: A restaurant deliveryman was clinging to life Thursday night after he was struck by a vehicle in East Harlem, the police said.

title: India Election Digest: April 18
description: What you need to know on Friday about Indias elections: Voter turnout rose in most districts in the fifth phase of the elections compared with 2009, the Indian National Congress appears to be missing its youth unit, and voters at the worlds highest polling station remain optimistic that someday a politician will visit them.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 9 P.M. (Nat Geo Wild) CESAR MILLAN: LOVE MY PIT BULL Once upon a time, the pit bull was a popular family pet beloved by President Theodore Roosevelt, Gen. George S. Patton and Helen Keller. Today, these dogs are more closely associated with gangs and dogfighting, and have been responsible for a large percentage of fatal dog attacks on humans. Pit bulls are often abused or abandoned, and are euthanized at a higher rate than other dogs, with an estimated one million put down each year in the United States. In this special, Mr. Millan chronicles the history of the pit bull as a herder and companion  in Britain, the Staffordshire bull terrier was nicknamed the nanny dog for its sweet disposition with children  and with his own pit bull, Junior (above, with Mr. Millan), makes the case for the dogs as loyal and loving, given the right training for both animals and humans. All dogs are great companions, he says. Communication creates a partnership, and dogs have the simplest communication on the planet. For them, everything is about trust, respect and love.

title: Times Minute | Good News for Obamacare
description: Also on the Minute, an uncertain outcome after talks on Ukraine and Gabriel Garca Mrquez departs, leaving behind his seminal literature.

title: Times Minute | Good News for Obamacare
description: In the Video

title: A Gabriel Garca Mrquez Sampler
description: One Hundred

title: Corrections: April 18, 2014
description: NEW YORK

title: Scandal Downs Chairman of a Top Chinese State Company
description: For a year, the chairman of one of Chinas biggest state corporations, China Resources, seemed immune to allegations that he had embroiled the company in corruption. That was until a reporter went public with the additional accusation that the chairman, Song Lin, kept a mistress who laundered his money.

title: A Fractured Vote in Old Delhi Market
description: NEW DELHI  On a hot afternoon in the first week of April, as the ancient wholesale market of Chandni Chowk buzzed with frenetic activity, Dr. Harsh Vardhan, the Bharatiya Janata Party candidate from the neighborhood, appeared in the middle of the market.

title: Captain and Two Crew Members Are Arrested in Korean Ferry Sinking
description: JINDO, South Korea  The captain and two crew members of a ferry that capsized, leaving more than 270 people  most of them students  missing, were arrested early Saturday, the authorities said.

title: Prominent Scientist Welcomes Soil Pollution Report
description: Updated, 1:43 p.m. |

title: Nationalist Leader in Scotland Wagers Career on Independence Vote
description: EDINBURGH  ALEX SALMOND means to lead Scotland into independence and, after 307 years of union with England, Scots have little more than five months to decide whether to follow him.

title: My Little Rifle
description: We highly recommend viewing the slideshow in full-screen mode.

title: Chinese Court Sentences 4 Activists to Jail
description: Amid intense security, a court in Beijing sentenced four more men to prison on Friday for their roles in the New Citizens Movement, a loose group of activists who called on government officials to disclose their financial assets.

title: New York Today: Surviving Spring Break
description: Good Friday morning on this Good Friday.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: Built on Brotherhood, Club Lives Up to Name
description: BUCHAREST  Aime Lema arrived first. It was earlier than Lema  the coach of A.S.F. Fratia Bucharest, a middle-of-the-pack team in the Romanian fifth division  would normally arrive for a game. But this day was different; it was his first day in charge.

title: The Season of the Zipper
description: Im so glad its spring because I wont get stuck in my down coat anymore. Several times I had to put my hands over my head and get peeled out of it  once at a restaurant.

title: Assad Campaigns for Re-election in Syria
description: Officials in Damascus have declared that a presidential vote will be held within months. President Bashar al-Assad is expected to win.

title: Facebooks Existential Crisis
description: Lately, I have found myself on Facebook, mindlessly scrolling through links to listicles, clicking through bizarre photo albums of cute snail portraits and halfheartedly skimming updates from people whose names I no longer recognize with little to no recollection about how I ended up on the site or why.

title: Mortgage Reform Is Worth the Small Extra Cost to Borrowers
description: Phillip Swagel is a professor at the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland and was assistant secretary for economic policy at the Treasury Department from 2006 to 2009.

title: April 18, 1923: Yankee Stadium Opens to Public
description: It took 11 months and cost $2.5 million to build the original Yankee Stadium. And when it opened 91 years ago, the team announced that 99,200 fans showed up, with 25,000 turned away. Babe Ruth hit a home run, driving in three runs in the Yankees 4-1 victory over the Boston Red Sox. Here is how The Times covered the game.

title: Daily Report: Stardom in China Takes a Webcam and a Voice
description: Dolled up with makeup and a blond wig, the pretty young Chinese woman sat at home in her bedroom on a quiet Sunday evening and began singing karaoke, David Barboza reports.

title: Ai Weiwei: According to What?
description: A look at the Ai Weiwei survey at the Brooklyn Museum.

title: ScienceTake: Killer Sponges
description: Sedentary sponges have evolved some fearsome weapons for trapping and devouring small prey.

title: The Works of Cornelia Gurlitt
description: An exhibition in Germany is dedicated to the little-known artworks of the sister of a Nazi-era art dealer whose trove of masterpieces was seized in Munich.

title: Jacques Servier, 92, Dies; Accused of Hiding the Risks of Drugs
description: PARIS  Jacques Servier, who created one of the biggest pharmaceutical companies in France but whose lifes work was overshadowed by allegations that he concealed the dangers of drugs that he helped develop, died on Wednesday at his home in a suburb of Paris. He was 92.

title: New Batch of Clinton Documents Is Released
description: WASHINGTON  The National Archives on Friday released its largest batch yet of previously withheld documents from the Clinton administration, with topics including the conflicts in Somalia and Rwanda, Middle East peace negotiations, the Oklahoma City bombing and public figures as varied as Richard M. Nixon and Oprah Winfrey.

title: Deadliest Day: Sherpas Bear Everests Risks
description: NEW DELHI  The Sherpas always go first, edging up the deadly flank of Everest while international clients wait for days in the base camp below.

title: Gag Order From Israeli Court Raises Questions
description: Updated, 10:42 a.m.

title: Sympathy for a Rat
description: Dear Diary:

title: Listen Up | Oh Land, the Pop Star Who Cant Forget Her Moment as a Ballerina
description: Before she came to public attention as the ethereal electro-pop siren Oh Land, the Danish musician Nanna Fabricius was a small-town girl who dreamed of becoming a ballerina. She left home for Stockholm at age 15 to pursue those ambitions until a back injury ended her career. Still, she often dreams about her first creative pursuit. An actual dream, in fact, inspired her new music video for Cherry on Top, a twinkling ballad on her 2013 album Wish Bone, produced by TV on the Radios Dave Sitek. In it, she went into a dance studio  only to discover that she wasnt a dancer, she was a piano player. The dream seemed an apt expression for the song, which, she explains, is about taking off the blinders and seeing the world all around you.

title: Obama in Asia
description: The pivot to Asia is yet again weighed down with baggage.

title: A Hidden Art Trove and a Lost Relative
description: HOCHSTADT, Germany  Last November, Hubert Portz was at his home in Hochstadt, southwest of Mannheim, reading a story in the morning newspaper when he came across a familiar name, causing his heart to skip a beat.

title: Clinton Publisher Settles on Title for New Memoir
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons coming memoir about her tenure as Secretary of State will be titled Hard Choices, her publisher said early Friday.

title: Most G-7 Nations Still Trying to Recoup Lost Jobs
description: MORE than six years after the Great Recession began, people in most industrialized countries are still less likely to be employed than they were before the downturn.

title: Study of Moons Atmosphere Ends With Planned Crash
description: NASAs Lunar Atmosphere and Dust Environment Explorer spacecraft slammed into the moon early Friday morning, as planned, but a few days earlier than NASA officials expected.

title: Pro-Russian Insurgents Balk at Terms of Pact in Ukraine
description: KIEV, Ukraine  An American-backed deal to settle the crisis in eastern Ukraine fell flat on Friday as pro-Russian militants vowed to stay in occupied government buildings, dashing hopes of a swift end to an insurgency that the authorities in Kiev portray as a Kremlin-orchestrated effort to put Ukraines industrial heartland under Russian control.

title: Coachella 2014: Selfies (and Outkast) in the Desert
description: Now that the Coachella dust has been washed down 90,000 shower drains by the disappearing California water supply, its time to apply some music criticism and lifestyle journalism in this weeks Popcast.

title: On Geeshie Wileys Trail
description: When I first started doing research for John Jeremiah Sullivan for his article about Geeshie Wiley and Elvie Thomas, two women who changed American music and then vanished without a trace, I kept Wileys song Last Kind Words Blues on repeat for days. I hadnt listened closely to her songs before this project, but I was aware of the mythology around them. Now, I found myself hearing something new: a haunting, a mystery.

title: Slopestyle Asks, When Is a Risky Sport Too Dangerous?
description: No sports discipline  not even boxing  has been dropped from the modern Olympics because it was too dangerous, and it would still be quite a surprise if slopestyle became the first.

title: Who Made That Relief Pitcher?
description: In April 1903, a writer for Sporting Life described what might have been a baseball first: Manager McGraw has originated a new plan, the paper said, referring to John McGraw, the successful skipper of the New York Giants. He will use two pitchers in every game, one being in the points five innings and the other four. No manager but one who has originality and nerve would attempt any such innovation, but McGraw has both.

title: Video Reviews of Transcendence, Fading Gigolo and Manakamana
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on Transcendence, Fading Gigolo and Manakamana. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: How Payday Lenders Prey Upon the Poor  and the Courts Dont Help
description: In 2003, Tonya Burke was living in North Carolina with her two children when she got into financial trouble. She had fallen $500 behind on her rent and utilities, and neither of her boys fathers was able to chip in. Then she needed to take time off from work when her younger son, who was only 8 months old, had to have emergency intestinal surgery. After his recovery, she started working for $11 an hour as a secretary, but my paychecks werent enough to cover the back bills and the new ones too, she says. I was at a point in my life where I didnt want to ask anyone else for help. There was a payday lender across the street from her office. It seemed like a good solution.

title: The Million-Dollar Manhattan Apartment
description: With a budget of about $1 million, Patricia Marx began looking for a two-bedroom, two-bath apartment in Manhattan last fall. She soon realized just how limited her options were.

title: What Made Me | Hugue Dufour
description: The French-Canadian head chef of M. Wells Dinette and M. Wells Steakhouse reflects on his fondness for his wife, the borough of Queens and cooking veal brains for customers.

title: From Fan Letter to Pen Pal
description: In 2003, the poet Laura Sims wrote a gushing fan letter to the experimental-fiction writer David Markson. ( Perfect is the one word I would choose to describe your work as a whole, she wrote.) Fare Forward, a new book, collects Marksons side of their ensuing correspondence, which continued until 2010, when he died at 82.

title: Lives of the Poets
description: HOLDING ON UPSIDE DOWN  The Life and Work of Marianne Moore  By Linda Leavell  Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $30.

title: Paperback Row
description: WHO OWNS THE FUTURE?,  by Jaron Lanier. (Simon & Schuster, $17.) Lanier follows up the boldly predictive You Are Not a Gadget (2010) with a jeremiad against the concentration of money and power in our digital networks. Chief among his targets are Siren Servers  social media, financial institutions, intelligence agencies  that depend on accumulating and evaluating consumer data without acknowledging a monetary debt to the people mined for all this free information.

title: Editors Choice
description: MONEY: The Unauthorized Biography,  by Felix Martin. (Knopf, $27.95.) Examining the nature and history of money, as well as its politicization, an economist and former World Bank official argues that it is a social technology.

title: At Brooklyn Museums Artists Ball, Some Words From Ai Weiwei and Unusual Doughnuts
description: Ai Weiwei, Jenny Holzer and Kehinde Wiley were among the honorees at the Brooklyn Museums Artists Ball, an annual benefit gala that draws a mix of the cultural and civic establishment and young up-and-coming artists. The real estate leaders and philanthropists Jane and David Walentas, developers of Dumbo and Janes Carousel, were also honored at the Wednesday event; the fountain in front of the museum was named in their behalf.

title: Dream Girls
description: What to do with the teenage girl as subject? She has been much maligned in the pages of our literature  Shirley Jacksons homicidal Merricat in We Have Always Lived in the Castle, or Jeffrey Eugenidess suiciding sisters. Even in less lethal incarnations, young girls in novels take advantage or are taken advantage of. The question of innocence is central  there is always virginity, literal and metaphorical, to be considered  and virtue is prized above all else.

title: Innocence Project
description: Hindsight is a wonderful thing. But in fiction it can take on a whole new power  blunderingly obvious or brightly illuminating, depending on how imaginatively its applied. Rare is the contemporary novel that doesnt set out, at least in part, to examine the effects of past behavior on present outcomes. While this can lead to pungent and suspenseful storytelling, it requires a delicate balance, keeping the reader engaged in the narrative momentum of an unknown future thats already in the past. In her perceptive, empathetic and often emotionally gripping new novel, Leah Hager Cohen  author of the acclaimed The Grief of Others  has managed the trick very deftly.

title: Three Siblings and a Murder
description: Peter Ackroyds new book begins like a fairy tale: In the London borough of Camden, in the middle of the last century, there lived three brothers. And a wondrous set of boys they are, having been born at precisely midday on May 8 of three successive years. This coincidence  only the first of many in Ackroyds breezy contrivance of a novel  signals an invisible communion among the brothers that will link their fates even as they set out on radically different paths through life. In the end, true to the Grimm Brothers template, only one will endure his personal ordeal and emerge relatively unscathed; the other two wind up succumbing to the wiles of the true hero of the piece  the city of London itself, the only character in the book the author actually seems to care about.

title: Predator and Prey
description: Nevada Barr has been brooding about the primal bonds between man and nature ever since her first mystery, Track of the Cat, came out more than 20 years ago. While respectfully acknowledging the forces of nature (the rampaging forest fire in Firestorm comes to mind, as does the harsh terrain of Winter Study), she has always found humans to be the more savage. In DESTROYER ANGEL (Minotaur, $26.99), Barr takes this insight to a disturbing new level by allowing her series detective, the National Park Service ranger Anna Pigeon, to test her belief that animals were better people than people. In order to survive, can she revert to her own animal nature, hunting and killing other human beings?

title: Lets Have a Dialogue
description: Plato has begun to appear in some unexpected places. On the first track of Jay-Z and Kanye Wests hip-hop album, Watch the Throne (2011), you can pick out the line, Is Pious pious cause God loves pious? This, as classicists will instantly recognize, is an allusion to a dilemma posed in Platos dialogue Euthyphro, in which Socrates asks, Is the pious loved by the gods because it is pious, or is it pious because it is loved by the gods? In Rebecca Newberger Goldsteins new book, Plato at the Googleplex: Why Philosophy Wont Go Away, Plato turns up not only at the search engines headquarters in Mountain View, Calif., but also with the obstreperous host of a cable news talk show, as a consultant to an advice columnist, and in several other places a long way from ancient Athens. In Goldsteins neat finale, the pupil of Socrates and teacher of Aristotle eagerly disappears into the magnetic bowels of an fM.R.I. scanner to have his brain probed.

title: Missing Links
description: In the summer of 1981, a Swedish graduate student named Svante Paabo filled a laboratory at the University of Uppsala with the stench of rotting liver. Paabo was supposed to be studying viruses, but he had become secretly obsessed with a more exotic line of research: extracting DNA from Egyptian mummies. No one at the time had any idea if the desiccated flesh of pharaohs still contained any genetic material, so Paabo decided to run an experiment. He bought a piece of calfs liver and put it in a lab oven at about 120 degrees for a few days to approximate mummification. In the dried, blackened lump of meat, he succeeded in finding scattered fragments of DNA.

title: Taken for a Ride
description: Last year, after admitting he had used performance-enhancing drugs during his professional cycling career, Lance Armstrong sat down with the New York Times reporter Juliet Macur to defend his legacy. He reminded her that many riders had used such drugs. What distinguished Armstrong, in his view, was his competitive will. I definitely wanted to win at all costs, he told Macur.

title: Spare the Advice
description: Almost from the birth of development as a concept in modern political economy, poverty has been regarded as a problem in search of technical solutions. The key, were told, is finding the correct mixture of policies to promote agriculture, reform financial markets or improve health. With the right mix of prescriptions, results come down mostly to implementation.

title: The Women Behind the Bomb
description: Curious about the strange happenings on New Mexicos Pajarito Plateau in the early 1940s, some of us might have read Robert Jungks Brighter Than a Thousand Suns. Or Richard Rhodess The Making of the Atomic Bomb. Perhaps, wishing for a more personal touch, we picked up Peggy Pond Churchs beautiful remembrance, The House at Otowi Bridge, learning about the enigmatic Edith Warner and her teahouse, which counted among its customers J. Robert Oppenheimer and Niels Bohr. Maybe, turning to Jennet Conants 109 East Palace, we relived the Los Alamos story through the eyes of Dorothy McKibben, the widow who met the arriving scientists at a storefront one block from the Santa Fe Plaza, the first stop on what would be a long, strange ride.

title: Language Without a Country
description: Like many admired writers from small countries, Josep Pla is largely unknown outside his native Catalonia. Not that Catalonia is a country as such, but the Catalan language has long been a proud symbol of the regions separate identity from the rest of Spain. And Pla, who died in 1981 at the age of 84, is a recognized master of this language. Yet only now is any of his immense body of work being translated into English.

title: Inside the List
description: The Best Years of Our Lives: New on the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 11 is The Opposite of Loneliness, by Marina Keegan, the 22-year-old writer who died in a car accident two years ago. A precocious poet, playwright and fiction writer who had graduated from Yale just days before, Keegan was on her way to her fathers 55th-birthday party when her boyfriend lost control of the car they were riding in. The car hit a guardrail and flipped over twice. He escaped unharmed, but she died at the scene.

title: Japan Plans to Resume Whaling Program, With Changes to Address Court Concerns
description: TOKYO  In a move likely to bring renewed international criticism, Japan said Friday that it wants to resume its research whaling in the Southern Ocean next year under a redesigned program that would address objections raised by an international court.

title: Today in Small Business: Bacon-Filled Chocolate Bunnies
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Italian Bank Increases Planned Share Sale to $6.9 Billion
description: ROME  Monte dei Paschi di Siena, Italys third-largest bank, plans to offer investors as much as 5 billion euros, or $6.9 billion, in new stock as it fights to avoid nationalization and braces for stress tests of its balance sheet by European regulators, the lender announced on Friday.

title: A Formal Setting
description: A few weeks ago, when I was tidying my apartment, my vacuum bumped against something under the bed. Curious, I moved the bed and discovered two wooden chests of silverware, and within them, funny, long-winded notes from my mother, detailing how many knives, forks and baby spoons each one held.

title: How Hollywood Killed Death
description: Death in the blockbusters of 2013 played out something like this:

title: Dont Get Too Cute With Your Bloody Mary
description: I didnt always like bloody marys. I blame an early childhood incident in which we coated our collie with tomato juice after a run-in with a skunk. (The juice was supposed to make the stench go away.) But my mother, who considered the viscous vermilion swill a tonic for nearly any affliction, loved them. So I was more than happy to make them for her now and then: All it took was a good slug of Smirnoff (the only vodka we had in the house, and one I still like), a can of tomato juice (or, as my mother sometimes preferred, Clamato), a shake of Lea & Perrins Worcestershire sauce, a heaping teaspoon of grated horseradish, a few shakes of black pepper, a good stir with ice, a lemon wedge for garnish, and that was that.

title: Reply All: The 4.6.14 Issue
description: THE WOLF HUNTERS OF WALL STREET

title: I Cant Sue the Rain
description: Jazz for tots; Kate Upton vs. Upton Sinclair.

title: Does Everyone Have the Right to Conjugal Visits?
description: Earlier this year, the Mississippi Department of Corrections decided to stop offering hourlong conjugal visits, depriving about 155 inmates (out of more than 22,000 statewide) the opportunity to cozy up with their husbands or wives. Officials cited budgetary constraints and prison pregnancies as the reasons for ending conjugal visits. Is it ethical to suddenly deny prisoners conjugal visits when theyve been offered them before? Relatedly, is it ethical for taxpayers to carry the costs associated with the incarcerated mothers pregnancy and delivery? Would it be ethical to allow only conjugal visits for those who agreed to use birth control? R.J.W., WYNNEWOOD, PA.

title: Isle of No Man
description: North Brother Island is New Yorks miniature Detroit, without the industry  a 20-acre, un-High Line-ed wilderness of trees and vines and abandoned, crumbling buildings in the treacherous tidal strait where the waters of New York Harbor trade places with those of Long Island Sound. It has been uninhabited for 50 years and off limits to all but biologists for more than a decade; the city manages it as a nature preserve. While it has always felt secret-filled, it now has a new one, which can be glimpsed in the photographer Christopher Paynes new book, North Brother Island: The Last Unknown Place in New York City: When a vast swath of trees was recently cut down in the Bronx for development, the islands forest, created by neglect, became the largest in the South Bronx. Robert Sullivan

title: Sia Furler, the Socially Phobic Pop Star
description: Sia Furler walked into the Silver Lake studio 10 minutes late, ignoring the 22 keyboards and six guitars and giant speakers on her way to the blue velour sofa in the back. There she pulled a MacBook Air from her white Goyard bag and called up Living Out Loud, a song she had just started writing. As the music played, Furler began scat-singing: Ha-ha-ha-ha!

title: On the Liberal Bias of Facts
description: The facts have a well-known liberal bias, declared Rob Corddry way back in 2004  and experience keeps vindicating his joke. But why?

title: 2015 Subaru Outback: Some Pizazz for a Redesigned Wagon
description: Introduced on Thursday, April 17: 2015 Subaru Outback.

title: Think Back: New York Worlds Fair, 1964
description: The organizers of the New York Worlds Fair billed the event as one for the ages, but it failed to leave a lasting mark on the culture. The Timess Sam Tanenhaus explains why.

title: Ferry Inquiry Focuses on Captain
description: As the search for victims entered its third day, Park Jae-Uk, the senior investigator, said the ships captain was not at the steering house when the ferry started sinking.

title: The King Can No Longer Afford Queens
description: Far too often, over the past few years we have read about Brooklyn as a marketable commodity  its aesthetic, lifestyle and twee products coveted and exportable. But the 50th anniversary of the 1964 Worlds Fair in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park would seem an appropriate time to reflect on Queens: The Brand.

title: The Fair to End All Fairs
description: When you drive by on the Van Wyck Expressway or the Grand Central Parkway, the space-age towers of the New York State Pavilion, among the few remaining traces of the 1964 New York Worlds Fair, rise up from the trees like a relic of some vanished, Jetsonian civilization, and the people who built them seem much more than 50 years distant from us. They were people apparently inspired by the idea of progress, and by a now quaint-seeming faith in the future, who actually believed in things like worlds fairs. Who would think of organizing such an event now? Who would pay for it? Who would bother to go?

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Asias Cauldron
description: This week, Robert D. Kaplan discusses Asias Cauldron; Parul Sehgal and John Williams discuss this years Pulitzer Prizes; William Easterly talks about The Tyranny of Experts; and Parul Sehgal has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: 50 Years After the New York Worlds Fair, Recalling a Vision of the Future
description: Fairgoers share memories of family outings and moments of inspiration at the 1964 New York Worlds Fair.

title: Under Cover: The President and the Bouquet
description: Daan Brand, an Amsterdam-based photographer, draws inspiration from the vivid imagery of cartoons to create his photo illustrations. So when the magazines photo department asked Brand to illustrate Jo Beckers cover story chronicling the Obama administrations shift on same-sex marriage, Brand imagined a series of photo illustrations that would maintain the readers focus on the key players in Beckers narrative, especially President Obama and Vice President Biden.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Asias Cauldron
description: This week, Robert D. Kaplan and William Easterly.

title: What Made Me | Hugue Dufour, Head Chef at M. Wells Dinette and M. Wells Steakhouse
description: Cooking for people doesnt necessarily mean cooking what they want, says Hugue Dufour. They need to be told what they want, so they can enjoy better than they thought they would. The French Canadian chef has taken the borough of Queens by storm in recent years with his idiosyncratic, unfussy, meat-loving M. Wells restaurants  the original, which closed in 2011, M. Wells Dinette in MoMA PS1 and the recently opened M. Wells Steakhouse. In the latest installment of the What Made Me video series by Poppy de Villeneuve, Dufour talks about the influence of his wife and co-conspirator Sarah Obraitis, getting kicked out of culinary school in Quebec and the pleasures of cooking veal brains in a diner.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: And Then It Came to an End
description: One day, the New York Worlds Fair, with its architecture flavored by the Space Age, was the future. Then the next day, it was history. After the debt-plagued fair closed on Oct. 17, 1965, the destruction began. Over the course of a year, as these striking images from 1965 and 66 attest, the fair was carefully and willfully dismantled: Cranes were brought in to remove the exhibitions, buildings were demolished, and even before the official closing, people picked over the grounds, yanking plants from their beds as souvenirs.

title: O Youth and Beauty (and After That)!
description: Over the years, the boundary-blurring choreographer Miguel Gutierrez has created a number of evening-length works that reveal the angst of a generation through movement, music and text. Now 42, hes suffering from a little burnout. Age & Beauty Part 1: Mid-Career Artist/Suicide Note or &:-/, presented as part of the 2014 Biennial at the Whitney Museum of American Art, is the first in a series of dances that focus on the challenges of being in midcareer.

title: Hip-Hop Bte Noire Changes Again
description: Just five years ago, a rapper like Riff Raff would have been unthinkable. Known for gleaming non sequitur verse, Oscar-worthy Vine videos and a magical capacity for physical transformation, he is a hip-hop changeling for the Tumblr age, an appealing nuisance.

title: Humans Fighting for Earths Health
description: In the beginning, it was about the dams. The naturalist John Muir and the forester Gifford Pinchot waged war in the early 1900s over the flooding of the magnificent Hetch Hetchy Valley in Yosemite National Park. Decades later, the proposed damming of the Colorado River prompted public outrage, and the environmental movement was born. Today some two million organizations worldwide work on behalf of social justice and the environment.

title: Every Number Tells a Story
description: In a series called Collected Stories, the composer David Lang curates an alluring set of programs that explore the idea of storytelling in music. Six multigenre, wide-ranging concerts feature works from the medieval age to the present, including Irish folk music and Tuvan throat singing.

title: A Family Reunion, Thanks to Goya
description: The public knows him best as Red Boy, Francisco de Goyas portrait of the beguiling 5-year-old Manuel Osorio Manrique de Zuiga, dressed in red from head to toe, with his pet magpie. The painting, which has been in the Metropolitan Museum of Arts collection since 1949, is one of its most popular images. But few visitors are aware that the child is the son of the Count Altamira, governor of what was the Banco de San Carlos (now the Banco de Espaa) and that between 1786 and 1788 the count commissioned Goya to paint that portrait, along with three others.

title: Eternal Life, Thanks to Angels and Abs
description: SURREY, British Columbia  The first episode of the scary-monster show Supernatural, in which a college student came home and found his girlfriend on the ceiling, roasting like a blond marshmallow, was shown by the WB network on Sept. 13, 2005.

title: Drawing on Their Home Turfs for New Work
description: Ratking

title: At Bolshoi, the Battle for Ballet Still Rages
description: The Bolshoi Ballet of Moscow is emerging from the worst ballet scandal in recent history. Its artistic director, Sergei Filin, is still undergoing operations to restore his eyesight after the severe injuries he suffered in a shocking acid attack in January 2013. Since he became director in 2011, the list of Bolshoi dancers has changed considerably: New stars have been imported, while existing ones have left in a wide range of circumstances  some for other companies (claiming the Bolshoi repertory held them back) and others as part of the fallout from the scandal.

title: Around the Unisphere at the Worlds Fair, Lives Changed
description: All paths once led to the Unisphere, a magnet for the masses.

title: In Our Pages: April 19
description: 1914: King Edwards Dog Is Dead

title: La MaMa Dance Festival With a French Accent
description: The ninth La Mama Moves! Dance Festival will bring together experimental dancers, ensembles and choreographers from around the world in programs that will include nine world premieres and four United States premieres. The festival runs from May 2 to 25 at all three of La Mamas theaters  the Ellen Stewart Theater (66 East Fourth Street), the Club and the First Floor Theater (74A East Fourth Street).

title: Image of the Day: April 18
On the Market in Chicago
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: After Stellar Season, a Seasoned Foe Awaits
description: The Nets sat all five starters in their final game of the regular season, content to drop to the sixth seed in the Eastern Conference playoffs to rest their aging roster. They will need all the energy they can muster against the young, feisty Toronto Raptors.

title: Times Minute | Ferry Captain Sought
description: Also on the Minute, new Clinton documents to be released and where did all the golfers go?

title: Times Minute | Ferry Captain Sought
description: In the Video

title: Goldman, Citi, UBS ... and a Guy in an Office
description: Anyone looking at the mergers and acquisitions league tables  the Wall Street equivalent of Major League Baseballs standings  during this hot year for merger activity would find the usual suspects: Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs vying for the top spot, with other big brand-name firms jockeying to fill the coveted top 10.

title: Stirring the Automotive Melting Pot
description: For decades, Italys role in any American auto show was clearly understood: to weaken the knees of enthusiasts with largely unattainable Ferraris, Lamborghinis and Maseratis. But new and unexpected forms of Italian exotica took starring roles this year at press previews of the New York International Auto Show.

title: Tribeca First-Timers: Lou Howe
description: This is one in a series of posts on debuts at the Tribeca Film Festival.For his first feature film, the writer and director Lou Howe charged into dark and complex emotional waters. He paints a portrait of mental illness from an intimate perspective in Gabriel, which stars Rory Culkin in the title role of a young man returning home to his family after spending time in a mental health facility.Battling personal demons, he is also in search of a lost love.

title: In the Bronx, a Tribute to a Salsa Singer
description: Muralists in the Bronx are honoring the salsa singer Cheo Feliciano, who died Thursday in a car accident in Puerto Rico.

title: Paying Till It Hurts
description: A series of articles by the New York Times correspondent Elisabeth Rosenthal examines the price of medical care in the United States. In each installment, readers were invited to share their perspectives on managing costs and treatment.

title: Pro-Russia Militant Rejects Ukraine Pact
description: The leader of a group of pro-Russia separatists, Denis Pushilin, said he would ignore the diplomatic pact between Russia and Ukraine to de-escalate the crisis.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: Linda Lavin, by Day and by Night
description: Linda Lavins life on Central Park South resembles a sitcom.

title: Big Ticket | Light-Grabbing Penthouse for $42 Million
description: A 12-room penthouse with panoramic Central Park views and more than 2,500 square feet of terraces atop the venerable Prasada at 50 Central Park West sold for $42 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Under Hoof, Foot and Tire
description: How about a real Streetscapes  not about buildings, but the streets themselves? The roadways of New York have long been the subject of turf battles among cars, horses, bikes and pedestrians. But the history of what theyre fighting over is multilayered  literally.

title: Excerpt: I Puritani
description: Olga Peretyatko sings Qui la voce.

title: Book Review Podcast: Asias Cauldron
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Ian Morris reviews Robert D. Kaplans Asias Cauldron: The South China Sea and the End of a Stable Pacific. Mr. Morris writes:

title: Excerpt: I Puritani
description: Olga Peretyatko sings Vien, diletto.

title: The Pretend Complexity of the Nevada Cattle-Grazing Dispute
description: The Nevada rancher Cliven Bundy owes the government over $1 million in unpaid fines, incurred for grazing his cattle on protected public land. When the Bureau of Land Management tried to confiscate his cattle in early April, he resisted, attracting armed supporters clearly itching for a violent confrontation. We were actually strategizing to put all the women up front, said one of his backers, the Tea Party leader Richard Mack. If they were going to start shooting, its going to be women that are going to be televised all across the world getting shot.Not nearly as histrionic or rash as Mr. Bundy and Mr. Mack, the B.L.M. backed down and said it would work to resolve the matter administratively and judicially.

title: Sheraton Expands Its Club Level Service
description: Sheraton Hotels and Resorts is planning to appoint more than 350 V.I.P. club managers to its club level lounges over the next few months.

title: Applause for Avocados
description: Lately Ive been reveling in Hass avocados, and now I understand why, having just discovered an article that David Karp, fruit expert extraordinaire, wrote in The Los Angeles Times a few years ago about the optimal time for ripeness in avocados. The California Avocado Commission sets Nov. 28 as the start of the Hass avocado harvest, meaning that the oil content in the fruit is high enough for picking.

title: In Uruguay, Team and Country Are Unified Behind Coach
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay  It was a telling gesture when Greg Dyke, the chairman of the English Football Association, slid his forefinger slowly across his throat moments after England was drawn in Group D of the World Cup.

title: As Data About Drivers Proliferates, Auto Insurers Look to Adjust Rates
description: ITS no surprise that car accidents, speeding tickets and where you live all affect how much you pay for automobile insurance. But consumer groups say that other, apparently unrelated, factors are unfairly being used to set rates.

title: Fixing a Broken Smartphone
description: Q. Is it possible to replace the broken glass on a smartphone or do you have to buy a new one?

title: Mazda Recalls Older Tributes; VW Cites Fire Hazard in Some 2014 Models
description: Mazda is recalling 109,000 of its 2001-4 Tribute sport utility vehicles because of a steering problem, and Volkswagen is recalling about 26,000 of its 2014 cars for a fire hazard, according to reports the automakers filed with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: At Coachella, Its a Guy Thing
description: Thermal, Calif.  People are getting more brave, which I love, just embracing it, said Kelson Berkus, 30, a marketing executive in Los Angeles, nodding approvingly as he surveyed the Lacoste party, clad in aqua giraffe-print swim trunks (source: probably Fred Segal).

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: a new Passover food, painkillers during pregnancy and exercise cool-downs. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Taking a Job Out of the Financial Equation
description: No pensions. Roller-coaster retirement accounts. Longer lives and higher health care costs. Aging parents. Children in college. A will to work but fewer jobs to be had.

title: Heartbleed Internet Security Flaw Used in Attack
description: Within 24 hours of the Heartbleed bugs disclosure last week, an attacker used it to break into a major corporation, security experts said Friday.

title: Russian Opposition Figure Faces Accusations of Libel
description: MOSCOW  Criminal libel proceedings against Aleksei A. Navalny, Russias most prominent opposition leader, extended into their second day on Friday, concluding without resolution.

title: Movie Review: Manakamana
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Manakamana.

title: Lois Wallace, a Respected Agent of Prominent Authors, Dies at 73
description: Erich Segal, a Yale classics professor who moonlighted as a screenwriter, had written a screenplay about two star-crossed lovers. His literary agent, Lois Wallace, thought it could also work as a novel and suggested that he turn it into one before the movie was made.

title: Movie Review: Fading Gigolo
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Fading Gigolo.

title: Movie Review: Transcendence
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Transcendence.

title: Free Samples Influence Doctors Prescriptions
description: One method pharmaceutical companies use to promote new medicines is to give free samples to doctors. A new study confirms that the technique is highly effective.

title: My European Ritual
description: What compels people to return to the same place or experience repeatedly? Answers from nine writers take you to Athens and Berlin, Paris and Granada  and beyond.

title: Your European Rituals
description: From England to Iceland, Barcelona to Warsaw, here are special spots Times readers like to visit more than once.

title: Pasta With Garlicky Bread Crumbs
description: Melissa Clark makes pasta with toasted garlicky bread crumbs, anchovies and fresh parsley.

title: Chinese Official Urges Russia and Central Asian Allies to Control Internet
description: BEIJING  Guo Shengkun, Chinas minister of public security, said at a six-nation security conference in Tajikistan that Russia and Central Asian countries must strictly control the Internet and prevent external forces from trying to overthrow governments and provoke a new wave of color revolutions, according to news agency reports on Friday.

title: Spilling Blood as if They Were Kids
description: For decades, sociologists have struggled to pinpoint the exact impact of childhood exposure to violent movies, but one fact is clear. In extreme cases, the cycle of violence repeats itself. Sometimes, kids steeped in extreme cinematic mayhem grow up to become hyperviolent filmmakers themselves.

title: Biking Hercules Way in France
description: The Gauls, a Celtic tribe that inhabited what is now France, were a boorish bunch before Julius Caesar arrived in 58 B.C. and ushered in civilization. At least, that is the historical explanation Graham Robb, a literary historian best known for the books The Discovery of France and Parisians, had accepted along with most French people.

title: Stone Lifting as Sport in the Basque Country
description: It was 10 oclock on a bright Thursday morning when I washed up in a cafe in Leitza, a Basque village in a rugged, green valley south of San Sebastin, in search of directions. The barista and both of her customers, two elderly men wearing traditional Basque berets, knew whom I was looking for before I asked. Iaki Perurena is the Michael Jordan of harrijasotzaile, or stone lifting, considered a herri kirolak, or rural Basque sport that has been an integral part of the Basque culture for 100 years, and I had come to Leitza in search of his hilltop museum and sculpture garden dedicated to this unusual athletic pursuit.

title: Selected Documents Released From the Clinton Archives
description: The National Archives made public on Friday afternoon another trove of secret documents detailing the inner workings of Bill Clintons White House.

title: Left With the Crumbs? Lucky You
description: Bread crumbs are easy to take for granted. In most recipes, they barely register. Theyre a crunch-intensifier or a garlic-and-cheese holder (ah, stuffed mushrooms), but never the main ingredient. They may not seem like something that demands to be homemade.

title: Poison Pills Relevance in the Age of Shareholder Activism
description: When we look back 20 years from now, the lawsuit by Daniel S. Loeb and his Third Point hedge fund against Sothebys may well be the tipping point in how far companies can go to defend themselves against shareholder activists.

title: Can We Get a No Standing Sign?
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 55
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: A Trove of Old Film Footage, Now Online
description: In days of yore  or at any rate, from the dawn of cinema into the 1960s or so  going to the movies was more than just settling into a plush seat with nearly a gallon of soda and a truckload of popcorn, and then getting blasted against the wall with insanely overamplified sound. Youd get a cartoon or a short feature, and a few decades back youd also get a newsreel. Sometimes it was actual news, although the growth of television rendered such films beside the point. Often it was a soft feature  footage of a celebrity wedding, a daredevil stunt, an exotic sports event or perhaps an interview with a music or film star.

title: Faces of Ukraine, on the Eve of Tumult
description: In July 2010, young, lighthearted Ukrainians packed Kievs Independence Square for a concert by a drag queen singing frothy pop songs over techno beats.

title: Yet Another Pretty Face
description: By what metric are we to determine whether a model is super? If it is name recognition, Forbes list position, magazines covered, campaigns fronted or some algorithm of them all, Kate Upton probably qualifies. In 2013 Ms. Upton, a 21-year-old from Melbourne, Fla., was named model of the year and appeared on the cover of the Sports Illustrated swimsuit issue for the second straight year. This year she was demoted to theinsidecover, pictured wearing a bikini in zero gravity.

title: Horseless, Not to Mention Senseless
description: Give the folks at NYClass, the advocacy group that wants to eliminate horse carriages from New York City, credit for recognizing the consequences of their campaign, and for having a plan.

title: How Do You Say Nobody Could Have Predicted In Swedish?
description: A correspondent points me to the news from Sweden, which has stopped flirting with deflation and moved right in. Heres inflation excluding food, energy, tobacco, and alcohol:

title: 40th Anniversary Special for Saturday Night Live
description: Saturday Night Live, among the most influential of television shows, will get a full dose of NBCs gratitude next February, when the network celebrates the shows 40th anniversary with a three-hour special  live from New York, of course.

title: 30 Seconds With Mike Fratello
description: Mike Fratello coached the Atlanta Hawks, the Cleveland Cavaliers and the Memphis Grizzlies in the N.B.A. With a 667-548 record, he is 18th on the N.B.A. career wins list and 19th in games coached. His teams qualified for the playoffs in 11 of his 15 seasons.

title: Love and the Stick-On Nipple
description: I am not big on accessories: I wear the same ring, watch, bracelet and earrings day after day. Still, there is one special item I was thrilled to find and really thought I would wear daily: my fabulous, lifelike, press-on nipples. They were not something I had ever planned on needing, but then I never planned on having breast cancer and a double reconstruction, or as it is known these days, the Angelina Jolie surgery.

title: Together With Songs in Their Hearts
description: When Shanta Thake, now the director of Joes Pub at the Public Theater in NoHo, was in her 20s, her work in the performing arts scene in the city left her constantly entertained during the day and frequently alone at night.

title: Sherpas Family on Avalanche
description: Even as rescue teams attempted to reach victims of the Mount Everest avalanche, Dawa Yanju, the sister-in-law of a survivor, Dawa Tashi, described what happened.

title: For Stone Phillips, a Focus on the Home Front
description: Originally, Stone Phillips told me, he intended to shoot a kind of home movie.

title: Prisoner Whose 1988 Conviction Is Under Review Is Granted Parole
description: A Brooklyn man whose 1988 murder conviction is under review because of questions about the lead detective in the case will be released on parole next month, his lawyer said.

title: Learning to Set a Goal for the Long Run
description: It was early winter and my son and I were taking the dogs on their nightly stroll. Something was clearly on his mind. Anything you want to talk about? I asked.

title: Wheelies: The Welcome Back Maybach Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: In NoHo: Squeezing In, With Some Creativity
description: The housing market in New York seems to bring out the fearlessness in some developers.

title: An Obituary or an Appraisal? Thursday Nights Debate.
description: Dean Baquet, the managing editor of The Times, talks about the debate in the newsroom Thursday night over how to treat the death of Gabriel Garca Mrquez, the Colombian novelist.

title: In the Works of Garca Mrquez, Finding a Link to Home
