description: Under the fluorescent lights of a check-cashing store in Jackson Heights, Queens, a man recited the opening lines of One Hundred Years of Solitude, in Spanish, on Thursday night.

title: Robin Leach Rolls on in Las Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS  Robin Leach, 72, wobbled up to Citizens Kitchen and Bar here looking neither rich nor famous.

title: U.S. Delays Final Call on Keystone XL Pipeline
description: WASHINGTON  The State Department will delay its decision on construction of the Keystone XL pipeline until it has a clearer idea of how legal challenges to the pipelines route through Nebraska will be settled, State Department officials said Friday.

title: Thunders Lofty Hopes Rest on a Fragile Hinge
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  It was nearly 12 months and 3 surgeries ago that guard Russell Westbrook hurt his right knee in the N.B.A. playoffs, ending the championship expectations of the top-seeded Oklahoma City Thunder. It was a fluky play, a sideswiping collision after a timeout, hardly anything that looked serious.

title: Female in Gaza
description: I have been photographing in Gaza for several years, initially to cover the conflict with Israel, but over time returning because I am mesmerized by the women, and their strength.

title: Years After a Bitter Fight, Prince and Warner Bros. Make a New Deal
description: More than 20 years after Prince protested against Warner Bros. Records by writing slave on his face and changing his name to an unpronounceable glyph, he has reconciled with that label through a new deal that gives him ownership of his old recordings and will include a major reissue campaign.

title: How to Run on Health Reform
description: The Republican attack machine, fueled by millions of dollars from the Koch brothers, has Democrats so rattled about the health reform law that many dont want to talk about it. Theyre happy to run on equal pay for women, or a higher minimum wage, or immigration reform  all of which provide important contrasts with a do-nothing Republican Party  but they havent said much about the biggest social accomplishment of the Obama administration.

title: Will and Kate (and Uncle Sam) Studied Here
description: ST. ANDREWS, SCOTLAND  It was hardly your typical college party. Set under a heated white tent the size of a football field (tables covered in chilled bottles of Nicolas Feuillatte Champagne and goody bags stuffed with vouchers from Hackett and Jack Wills), it seemed more like a New York gala than a student event in a college town on the North Sea. But when the University of St. Andrews 2014 charity fashion show began, so did the party.

title: Protests Continue Against Dropbox After Appointment of Condoleezza Rice to Board
description: The decision by Dropbox this month to appoint Condoleezza Rice, the former secretary of state, to the companys board of directors sparked a heated online debate about her views on Internet surveillance and the role of the National Security Agency.

title: The Gun Report: April 18, 2014
description: Earlier this year, a legislator in Iowa floated a bill to lower the age at which children can legally shoot handguns. While anyone 20 or younger must be under the direct supervision of a parent or instructor to practice with a pistol or revolver, current state law prohibits children younger than 14 from handgun use, even with a parent around. Rep. Joe Riding, a Democrat from Altoona, wanted to lower that to 12.

title: Program to Destroy Syrias Chemical Weapons Is 75% Complete, Group Says
description: GENEVA  As the deadline looms for the destruction of Syrias chemical weapons, the international organization overseeing the process reported Friday that the country had delivered another shipment of toxic agents for destruction abroad, bringing the program three-quarters of the way to completion.

title: When Bravo Came to Charleston
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  For the last few years Charleston has been getting the sort of high praise it has not seen since before Reconstruction.

title: In the Battle for Best Smartphone, Apple Still Beats Samsung
description: Over the last couple weeks, many of my colleagues in the tech press have published reviews of the Galaxy S5, Samsungs newest top-of-the-line smartphone. They all arrived at more or less the same conclusion: The S5 is a very nice device.

title: What to Expect When a Clinton Is Expecting
description: In some alternate universe, a distant political galaxy unlike our own, Chelsea Clinton might be able to have her first child quietly. No one would care about the size of her baby bump. If and when Hillary Rodham Clinton announces a presidential run, her status as a grandparent would receive exactly the same scrutiny as her male predecessors who were grandfathers.

title: 13 Quit Board of San Diego Opera
description: LOS ANGELES  Less than a week after the board of the San Diego Opera reaffirmed its decision to shut it down, the embattled company was hit with a new wave of turmoil on Thursday as Karen Cohn, the president of the board, led a contingent of 13 board members in resigning.

title: A Mustang Option: Matching Nail Polish
description: The Ford Motor Company is using a distinct new palette to market the Mustang to women at the New York International Auto Show: a line of nail polish colors. The Ford Mustang by OPI Collection features six colors inspired by the 50th anniversary of the car.

title: What $5 Can Get at a Film Festival
description: Clara Mamets table at Barbuto wasnt ready. It was 8 p.m. Wednesday, and Ms. Mamet, the 19-year-old daughter of the playwright David Mamet and the half-sister of the actress Zosia Mamet, was in New York for the Tribeca Film Festival, where her debut film, Two-Bit Waltz, would be shown later in the week.

title: First You Spend, Then You Save
description: The psychology of saving fuel can get complicated, especially when it involves splurging to go from Point A to Point B.

title: Premium Fuel Efficiency, and a Price to Match
description: The BMW 535d can exceed 40 miles per gallon on the highway, and the performance is impressive for a diesel. But do the fuel savings make up for the higher sticker price?

title: Rules of Style | Sleigh Bells Alexis Krauss on Dressing for Coachella, Melt-Proof Makeup and the Virtues of Normcore
description: In 90-degree heat among a crowd of 90,000, its tough for anyone  even a bona fide rock star  to keep their look together. But Alexis Krauss, the inky-tressed frontwoman of the Brooklyn indie noise-pop band Sleigh Bells, has a way of always staying cool, even during her frenetic stage shows. Here, the singer  who plays Coachella this weekend and will be touring the U.S. and Europe all summer long  shares her secrets to braving warm-weather festivals in style.

title: Amorality  Deux, Circa 1932
description: Steal, swindle, rob, O.K. pleads the pickpocket Lily (Miriam Hopkins) to her paramour, the thief Gaston (Herbert Marshall), in Ernst Lubitschs Trouble in Paradise, but dont become one of those useless, good-for-nothing gigolos! Lily has reason to fear: the debonair Gaston has insinuated himself into a job with a perfume heiress (Kay Francis), and though he and Lily have designs on her riches, Gaston may be falling for his boss.

title: From Rags to Riches to Rags
description: ST. LOUIS  BY now most of us know the basic facts of Americas rising income inequality: Since the early 1970s, the gap between the top and bottom of the income distribution has expanded significantly; whats more, the only group to have experienced real economic gains during this period has been those in the top 20 percent, with gains heavily concentrated in the top 10, 5 and  most famously  1 percent.

title: The Trouble With Rice
description: For the past few years, Mary Lou Guerinot has been keeping watch over experimental fields in southeast Texas, monitoring rice plants as they suck metals and other troublesome elements from the soil.

title: Snowden Defends His Part in Putin Forum
description: One day after he took part in a stage-managed forum with President Vladimir V. Putin on Russian state television, the former National Security Agency contractor Edward Snowden defended his participation, in an essay published by The Guardian.

title: Giving Snapshots the Gonzo Treatment
description: I really thought what I would do, if I ever learned to draw properly, was I would try to change the world, the British artist Ralph Steadman explains in For No Good Reason, Charlie Pauls documentary about him, opening Friday.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: Bar and Bathroom Lines, Molto Adagio
description: When the curtain went down on Act II of Puccinis La Bohme at the Metropolitan Opera on a recent evening, close to 100 stagehands sprang into action. To the sound of beeping machinery, hammer strokes and intermittent warning shouts, they carried props, bundled drops, unfurled scrims, navigated the enormous wagon rolling the next set into place and secured escape stairs to the floor in what looked like brisk, efficient choreography.

title: A Beer Vacation Is On Tap in Chicago
description: Lagunitas Brewing Company, the Northern California beer maker with a penchant for live music, has expanded its operations to Chicago, where it will open a 300,000-square-foot facility early next month.

title: Week in Pictures for April 18
description: .media.slideshow.in-page-player .headline { display: none; }

title: New York Bridal Fashion Week | Spring 2015
description: Wedding dress designers debuted their spring 2015 collections last weekend. Here, a selection of photos.

title: Delayed Viewing Plumps Up Mad Men Audience
description: Fans of Mad Men alarmed by the surprising ratings falloff for this seasons premiere may take some comfort in the first results of delayed viewing for the episode.

title: The Re-education of a Brash Young Stock Picker
description: Nine years ago, Randy Kurtz made an extraordinary bet on himself, the stock market and his ability to pick a few winners.

title: Lace Shows Its Strength
description: Its very important to me that these not be viewed just as wedding gowns, said Vera Wang, the pre-eminent wedding-gown designer for a generation. She was on the phone discussing her decision not to hold a live show during the recent presentations of bridal collections in New York, a kinder, gentler and briefer version of Fashion Week, with profusions of curling-ironed hair, platform pumps and champagne flutes twinkling in broad daylight.

title: An Indian From India Photographs Both
description: After encountering confusion over her roots, an Indian photographer created a set of diptychs in which she recreated classic poses of Native Americans.

title: How to Make a Perfect Piece of Toast
description: There may be more pressing issues in the food world, or more ambitious projects to tackle, but I am here to talk about perfecting the simplest of kitchen basics.

title: What Is Putins New Russia?
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, appearing cool and confident on national television during a four-hour question-and-answer show on Thursday, referred repeatedly to southeastern Ukraine as New Russia, a historical term for the area north of the Black Sea that the Russian empire conquered in the 1700s. God knows why the region became part of Ukraine in the 1920s, he said in response to a questioner, a strong signal that he would gladly correct that error.

title: Eric Korsh to Run the Kitchen at North End Grill
description: Eric Korsh left Calliope, the French bistro in the East Village, where he was the chef and a partner, in late January, but he did not spend a great deal of time in the wilderness. He will be the new executive chef at North End Grill in Battery Park City, replacing Floyd Cardoz, who is departing on April 30.

title: Pictures of the Day: South Korea and Elsewhere
description: Photos from South Korea, Central Africa Republic, India and Germany.

title: Allowing a Puritan to Marry for Love
description: If you are going to savor the Metropolitan Operas welcome revival of Bellinis I Puritani, it is best to put out of mind that this 1976 production was mounted for Joan Sutherland, Luciano Pavarotti, Sherrill Milnes and James Morris. Such an astounding four-star cast is not likely to come along again anytime soon.

title: Pharrells Next Collaboration, Karl Lagerfelds Destination Fashion Show and Alexander Wangs First Instagram
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Economist Receives Rock Star Treatment
description: French economists who boldly question the dominance of capital over labor  and call for a progressive global tax on wealth  visit the American halls of power about as often as French rock stars headline Madison Square Garden.

title: Music From Madama Butterfly
description: A clip from Act 1 of Madama Butterfly from the Metropolitan Opera. The clip features Kristine Opolais, the soloist, as the character of Cio-Cio-San. She is accompanied by members of the Metropolitan Opera Chorus, including Jean Braham.

title: When Gabriel Garca Mrquez Went Back to Aracataca
description: The novelist and maestro Gabriel Garca Mrquez died Thursday , mourned by the world at the ample enough age of 87. But for a time during his youth in Colombia  when he was inhaling three packs a day  he was sure that he would die young, dissolute and in the street, as he put it in his 2003 memoir Living to Tell The Tale. At that point, his mother, Luisa Santiaga Mrquez, appeared unexpectedly in the city of Barranquilla, determined to rescue her law-school dropout son from a wasteful life as a mere writer. She convinced him to travel with her to the desolate, hellishly hot Caribbean town of Aracataca, where he was born in 1927.

title: Lost in Literary History: A Tale of Courage in the South
description: Nineteen seventy-four was a good year for nonfiction writing in America. Robert A. Caros monumental biography of Robert Moses, The Power Broker, came out. So did Bob Woodward and Carl Bernsteins All the Presidents Men. So did Working, by Studs Terkel, and Robert M. Pirsigs Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance.

title: Including the Young and the Rich
description: On a crisp morning in late March, an elite group of 100 young philanthropists and heirs to billionaire family fortunes filed into a cozy auditorium at the White House.

title: Bill Cunningham | Spring Frenzy
description: Runners wearing colorful tutus, a bulldog skating and a wall of forsythia in Central Park: New York comes to life with whimsical touches of color.

title: On Its Return, Band Goes Right Back to the Basics
description: Loops concert on Thursday night at Le Poisson Rouge started, of course, with a drone: a guitar note looped for continuous sustain, almost meditative. But not for long. Soon the clobbering began: The repeating two-chord riff of Soundhead, basic and primal, blasted in unison on guitar, bass and drums. I hear that sound! I hear that sound!, Robert Hampson sang.

title: Bill Cunningham | Two-Tone Spring
description: The contrasts of spring in New York and Paris: It looked like a basket of jelly beans at the womens half-marathon in New York last Sunday, with many runners in tutus. Shop windows were filled with chicks, rabbits and decorated eggs. Big Bird sat on a bench near a wall of forsythia. Magnolias blossomed at the Frick, and a dog went skateboarding in a park. In Paris, where fashion still rules, black-and-white made a big sophisticated statement.

title: Love Those Royal Family Photos? It All Started With Victoria.
description: LOS ANGELES  Today, as the formal boundaries between the British royal family and the public narrow, pictures of 9-month-old Prince George are posted daily on the Facebook pages of Prince William and the Duchess of Cambridge, the former Kate Middleton. But, in fact, photography has been promoting the royal brand since its inception in the 19th century, as an exhibition on view at the Getty Center here shows. Fame may seem a 20th-century phenomenon, but Queen Victoria was the first public figure to exploit its promotional potential and the earliest  and least likely  international celebrity of the photographed world.

title: A TV Opera, Live. Ol!
description: The relationship of language to music, and plot to text, is an intriguing element of Robert Ashleys Perfect Lives, a complex and meditative sequence featuring a hypnotic, sung-spoken narrative that unfolds with myriad cadences.

title: Evening Hours | April, Come What May
description: From opera and ballet to children and birds.

title: Auto Show in the Round
description: The Automobiles team, working with the photographer Benjamin Norman, selected some of the new models at the New York International Auto Show for 360-degree interactive views.

title: Versatility Is a Virtue in Fantasy of Identity
description: If you pay more attention than you should to television critics or the pop-culture gossip mills, you may have heard that you should be watching Orphan Black on BBC America, which returns for a second season on Saturday night.

title: A Silver Anniversary for Mazdas Blue-Ribbon Sports Car
description: British automakers like Austin-Healey, Lotus and MG may have originated the tidy, nimble roadster, but it was Mazda, a Japanese company, that mastered the formula decades later.

title: Honing the Hybrids and Diesels
description: BMW has long promoted diesel engines as an important element of its plan to reduce carbon dioxide output. The automaker is still a champion of diesel power, but now it is embracing electric drive, too.

title: Turkish Women Use Twitter to Fight Sexual Harassment
description: Updated, Saturday, 1:52 p.m. | Thousands of Turkish women have taken part in a Twitter campaign to voice outrage at men who invade their space by spreading their legs while sitting next to them on buses and trains.

title: Moving In? Beware the Other Residents
description: Run in fright. Marlon Wayanss comedy A Haunted House unaccountably made $40 million at the domestic box office, so we have A Haunted House 2, which, like its predecessor, pays parodic tribute to horror films including Dark Skies and the Last Exorcism movies, among countless others. Already the franchise displays a sputtering exhaustion.

title: The Secrets and the Magic Are in the Details
description: In the program note for the current installment of Soaking Wet, the dance series that David Parker directs at the West End Theater on the Upper West Side, he speaks of presenting the work of Vicky Shick as a longtime dream come true. It seemed to him that her exacting, poetic work would be a perfect match for the funky, mysterious space on the second floor of a church. The debut on Thursday of Ms. Shicks Pathtique/Miniatures in Detail proved him right.

title: Added Attractions Through the Years
description: Special editions of the Mazda Miata that are nothing more than color and trim packages may not improve the driving experience, but their low production numbers can make them more attractive to collectors.

title: Watch Out, iTunes. Vinyl Still Lives.
description: The story usually told about record stores is a sad one that just keeps getting sadder.

title: Jordan Chodorow and Karen Allison Play at Bridge Base Online
description: Online bridge has certainly made it easier and cheaper for everyone to play. The diagramed deal was played during a pair game at Bridge Base Online (bridgebase.com). North was Jordan Chodorow of Los Angeles and South was Karen Allison of Las Vegas, who has won five national championships.

title: Woman Is Sought After Attempt to Kidnap an 8-Month-Old
description: The authorities were searching on Friday for a woman with a history of trying to abduct young children, saying she had tried to kidnap an 8-month-old boy in the Chelsea section of Manhattan.

title: A Polish Painter Reconsiders His Calling
description: On April 27, the Vatican will live-stream a ceremony elevating Karol Wojtyla, later known as Pope John Paul II, to sainthood. Storm Theater and Blackfriars Repertory Theater have devised an alternative way to celebrate the pope, reviving his 1949 play, Our Gods Brother, translated by Boleslaw Taborksi, at the Theater of the Church of Notre Dame.

title: The Faces May Be Familiar, but the Sounds Are Original
description: With its new-music series, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center offers its patrons a change of perspective. Held in the Kaplan Penthouse, with its floor-to-ceiling windows that afford sweeping views of the city against a darkening evening sky, the concerts present familiar artists from the societys ranks engaging with new works by living composers  and, often, with instruments rarely seen in traditional chamber music settings.

title: Two Schemers, Crossing All Kinds of Boundaries
description: Fair warning: If feeling a strangers bare buttocks pressed into your upper back is more than youre willing to risk for an evening of theater  if, perhaps, this is exactly the sort of personal-boundary crossing that creeps you out about immersive performance  then you may want to think carefully before deciding to see Ubu Sings Ubu at the Abrons Arts Center.

title: Airbnb Said to Close Fund-Raising Deal With Group Led by TPG
description: Airbnb has closed a new round of financing from a group led by TPG Growth that values the home-sharing company at about $10 billion, people briefed on the matter said on Friday.

title: Dont Know Much About History, Rand Paul Edition
description: I can easily understand it when people dont know the facts about economic statistics; you need a fair bit of background knowledge even to know how to look these things up. Its more surprising when people dont know what they dont know  when they make confident assertions that can be proved false in a few seconds by anyone who does know these things.

title: The Charms (and Faults) of Southern Italy
description: To the Editor:

title: Playing the Long Game in Ukraine
description: To the Editor:

title: Friday Not Music: Back to Black
description: For some reason, not feeling very musical today. Instead Im waiting eagerly for the season 2 premiere of one of the few shows I watch regularly. I think what I love about it is the chemistry of the cast  they interact with each other so well its as if theyre all one person. Oh, wait

title: Italian Dishes With a Creative Twist
description: Verde Wine Bar and Ristorante in Deer Park is the new incarnation of a restaurant called Papa Joes, which got its start in 1984 as an 11-seat pizzeria owned by Niel and Catherine Carcaterra.

title: Florida State Rape Inquiry
description: To the Editor:

title: In Defense of Veterans
description: To the Editor:

title: Health Care Quality, and Cost
description: To the Editor:

title: The Worlds Fairgrounds, Then and Now
description: What was once an ash heap in Corona, Queens, became the site of the 1939 Worlds Fair. Its avenues, in turn, provided the layout for the 1964 Worlds Fair. Despite Robert Moses intention of making Flushing Meadows-Corona Park a jewel of the city after the event, its evolution has been fitful. A few structures from the fair stand in good condition; others have fallen into disrepair; and still others have been reinvented.

title: Scones, Finger Sandwiches and Tea
description: Raising ones pinkie finger may be a faux pas  Nobody does that, according to Susan Peterson, co-owner of Teaberrys Tea Room in downtown Flemington.

title: Twin Shocks Shake Foundation of German Power
description: BERLIN  If there are two qualities prized by modern Germans, they surely are Ruhe (peace and quiet) and Ordnung (order).

title: Davis Is Traded to Pirates
description: After months of speculation, the Mets traded first baseman Ike Davis to the Pittsburgh Pirates on Friday night, jettisoning a homegrown prospect they once viewed as a potential cornerstone of their lineup for years to come.

title: 2 Milk Hollow? Thats Code for Bunnies at Aigner Chocolates
description: If Beatrix Potter ran a chocolate shop, it would look like Aigner Chocolates, a little confectioner on the corner of Metropolitan Avenue and 71st Road in the middle of Queens.

title: For Pizza, 800 Degrees of Separation
description: If pizza is the ultimate comfort food, then Connecticut must be a very comfortable state. With pizzerias in virtually every town across the state, and many towns possessing several, it can be difficult to decide where to dine. The three parlors listed below set themselves apart by burning wood in their ovens, and also by offering choices that go well beyond the norm.

title: A Timely Gift of Hot Truffled Chickpeas
description: Nothing makes me grumpier than getting stuck with the worst table at a restaurant. Such was the case at the Twisted Oak in Tarrytown on a recent night: We were led through the bustling front room to a gloomy rumpus room better suited for darts or air hockey or a low-stakes poker game.

title: A Way of Tracking Deer Helps the Police Follow Their Prey in the Subway
description: Bushnell, the maker of optical equipment for hunters, sells a trophy camera that tracks deer after dark. Mounted to a tree and armed with a motion detector, the camera silently snaps infrared pictures of passing animals that dont see a thing.

title: Ukraine Seeks Inquiry Into Killings
description: Ukraine has asked the International Criminal Court to investigate the deaths of civilians on its territory that occurred from Nov. 21, 2013, to Feb. 22, covering the period when more than 100 people were killed during antigovernment protests. It excludes the period shortly afterward when Russia annexed Crimea. It was not immediately clear whom Ukraine was accusing of the deaths. Initially, Parliament sought to single out the former president, Viktor F. Yanukovych, but other groups may also be included. Because Ukraine is not a member of the court, it has formally given it jurisdiction with respect to the period in question. That step, which was apparently taken in early April, was announced in a court statement issued late Thursday. Ukraines application said it expected that the court shall duly study the case. But a court spokesman emphasized that it would be up to a prosecutor to decide whether to proceed, and then the courts judges would be asked to approve the decision. An investigation is not expected any time soon.

title: Swim to Sea? These Salmon Are Catching a Lift
description: RIO VISTA, Calif.  As the Merva W puttered down the Sacramento River, it looked like any other dowdy fishing vessel headed toward the Golden Gate Bridge. But no other boat had as surprising a cargo or as unusual a mission: The Merva W was giving 100,000 young salmon a lift to the Pacific in the hope of keeping them alive.

title: Michaels Stores Breach Involved 3 Million Customers
description: Michaels Stores, the arts and crafts retailer, estimates that data on three million of its customers payment cards may have been stolen in a breach over several months.

title: Obama Signs Bill That Bars Irans Envoy
description: President Obama signed a bill into law on Friday that would prohibit anyone who has engaged in espionage or terrorism against the United States from obtaining a visa to enter the country as a representative to the United Nations. Congress passed the bill last week after Iran named Hamid Aboutalebi as its ambassador to the United Nations; Mr. Aboutalebi was an interpreter for the militant student group that stormed the American Embassy in Tehran in 1979 and held Americans hostage for 444 days. Iran has insisted that the United States has no right to dictate whom it may choose to represent it. Mr. Obama said the Constitution gave him exclusive discretion to receive or reject ambassadors, and if a case arose where the law would interfere with his exercising that discretion, he would treat it as advisory.

title: Sheriffs Limit Detention of Immigrants
description: Sheriffs in nine Oregon counties announced this week that they would no longer hold people in jail based on requests from federal immigration authorities after a United States magistrate judge in Portland ruled that an immigrants rights had been violated when she was held in a county jail on such a request.

title: Readers Share Their Memories of 50 Years Ago in Queens
description: For the 50th anniversary of the opening of the 1964 New York Worlds Fair, we asked readers to share their memories and photographs from their visits to the fair. Here is an edited sampling of memories and photographs submitted by readers.

title: Live Longer and Heirs Will Prosper in New York
description: DYING is going to have lower tax consequences in New York  if you can wait five to eight years. But in the meantime, the new estate and gift tax law that went into effect on April 1 is going to create enormously complex financial planning problems for all sorts of people.

title: Ex-Marine Held in Iran Asks Official for Help
description: Amir Hekmati, an American incarcerated in Iran since August 2011, recently wrote to its foreign minister seeking help in gaining his release, after Mr. Hekmati learned from his new lawyer that he had been secretly tried and sentenced to 10 years imprisonment on a charge of collaborating with the United States government, family members reported Friday.

title: Heartbleed Highlights a Contradiction in the Web
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The Heartbleed bug that made news last week drew attention to one of the least understood elements of the Internet: Much of the invisible backbone of websites from Google to Amazon to the Federal Bureau of Investigation was built by volunteer programmers in what is known as the open-source community.

title: Saving Minds Along With Souls
description: EASTER is a time of new beginnings. It is the answer, the pastor Rick Warren remarks, to loss and despair. A few weeks ago, one year after his son took his life while struggling with depression, Mr. Warren, the founding pastor of Saddleback Church, one of the nations largest evangelical churches, teamed up with his local Roman Catholic Diocese and the National Alliance on Mental Illness for an event that announced a new initiative to involve the church in the care of serious mental illness.

title: New York Police Department Tells Officers to Avoid Elevators in Burning Buildings
description: Tightening guidelines it had issued after the death of an officer in a Brooklyn high-rise fire this month, the New York Police Department has barred officers from using elevators in burning buildings and recommended they not enter smoke-filled hallways.

title: OpenSSL and Linux: A Tale of Two Open-Source Projects
description: The Heartbleed bug has cast a bright and not entirely flattering light on the open-source movements incentive model.

title: Learning From Koreas Disaster
description: PLAINSBORO, N.J.  With hope fading for the rescue of 271 passengers, most of them high school students, who remain missing after the South Korean ferry Sewol capsized and sank Wednesday, it is not too early to draw lessons from the disaster. South Koreas early response was to point to human error and seek the arrest of the ferrys captain, first mate and another crew member. But its worth keeping three points in mind as investigations proceed.

title: In Detroit, Judge Takes Offbeat Tack in Hiring Help
description: DETROIT  It was not your standard job interview.

title: And the Race Is Off
description: Maybe Kathleen Sebelius should reconsider that Senate thing.

title: Greed and the Wright Brothers
description: Lawrence Goldstones new book, Birdmen, is about the origins of the airplane, from the early experiments with gliders in the 1890s, to the famous first powered flight by the Wright brothers in December 1903, to the wild next decade  a decade of daring by the early pilots eager to show off both their airplanes and their skill. A good part of the story Goldstone tells is about the rise of airshow exhibitions that swept America  exhibitions in which flamboyant pilots performed death-defying stunts before tens of thousands of spectators. Although, as the author points out, many of those pilots did not, in the end, defy death. On the contrary, death is a constant theme of the early years of flight.

title: Snowden Defends Query to Putin on Surveillance
description: Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor whose exposure of a vast trove of his governments secrets made him a hero and even a celebrity in certain circles, suddenly found himself on the defensive a day after he took part in a televised and carefully orchestrated question-and-answer session with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

title: In Queens, Chickens Clash With the Rules
description: Sylvia Saye held a basket of multicolored eggs.

title: Turning Up the Intensity
description: In the N.B.A. playoffs, everyone is looking to win it all, and no one, thankfully, is thinking about the lottery. So after all the talk during the regular season about which teams were tanking in hopes of landing top draft picks, it will be refreshing to watch game after game in which the only objective is to score the most points.

title: Obamacare Bashing or Bust
description: Thursday, President Obama delivered a compendium of positive news about the Affordable Care Act:

title: Slow Start Spurs Shift for Towers Near Arena
description: The first residential tower at the sprawling Atlantic Yards development near Downtown Brooklyn rises only five of its intended 32 floors nearly a year and a half after construction started, making it one of the slowest-moving projects in a city with an unquenchable thirst for housing.

title: Health Care Spendings Recent Surge Stirs Unease
description: WASHINGTON  Its back.

title: In a Hole, Golf Considers Digging a Wider One
description: GREENSBORO, Ga.  Golf holes the size of pizzas. Soccer balls on the back nine. A mulligan on every hole.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 18, 2014
description: April 18, 2014

title: A Generational Divide Worn on Their Heads
description: When Lydia Calviness died two years ago at the age of 93, she bequeathed her church hats to her grandniece Monica Moss. Genealogically speaking, Ms. Moss did not qualify as the closest female relative. Ms. Calviness had arranged the inheritance because Ms. Moss, like her, was what the lexicon of black Christianity calls a first lady  the pastors wife.

title: Paper Shows U.S.-Flagged Plane in Iran Has Ties to Ghana
description: New details emerged on Friday about an American plane, owned by a small community bank in Utah and mysteriously parked this week at Tehrans airport, showing that it had been leased by a Ghanaian mining company owned by a brother of Ghanas president.

title: Terror Watch Lists Run Amok
description: After eight years of confounding litigation and coordinated intransigence, the Justice Department this week grudgingly informed Rahinah Ibrahim, a Malaysian architecture professor, that she was no longer on the federal governments vastly overbroad no-fly list.

title: Finding Open Space and Fresh Air
description: Before participating in the Fresh Air Fund camping program, Edgar Saavedra and his two brothers spent summer days inside their home in the Bronx or in the library. Their neighborhood park was too crowded for playing soccer, so once or twice a week their parents put the boys on a bus for a 45-minute ride to a safer, greener park. In the city, you cant do much, Edgar said. There are only buildings. Theres no grass.

title: Awesome Con Fans Try to Break Record
description: As part of the convention kickoff in Washington, attendees tried to break the world record for the largest gathering of people dressed as comic book characters but fell short of the record, 1,530.

title: Two Ministers Forge Friendship Across a Church Divide
description: FAIRFAX, Va.  The two ministers were foes before they ever met, partisans in a war they did not start, but partisans nonetheless.

title: Putting Ones Cards on the Table
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  The last time we saw Stu Ockman over a year ago, he was calling out to us, but this time he has seen fit to twist our brains with a difficult Saturday puzzle.

title: Viral Disease Spreads to Southeast Asia
description: The viral disease known as Middle East Respiratory Syndrome has reached Asia, according to reports from Malaysia and the Philippines. The Malaysian Health Ministry said a 54-year-old man recently back from a pilgrimage to Mecca, Saudi Arabia, died of it on Sunday, and a Filipino nurse was quarantined, along with his family, after a positive blood test. The nurse appeared healthy but, before returning to Manila on Tuesday, had been in contact with a Filipino paramedic in the United Arab Emirates who died of MERS. On Wednesday, the Emirates reported 10 new cases, all among health workers who treated a MERS patient who died April 10. Since the disease was discovered in 2012, there have been 243 confirmed cases with 93 deaths, the World Health Organization said. The coronavirus that causes MERS appears to originate in bats and is widespread in Middle Eastern camel herds. It occasionally infects humans and can spread among them, usually only after close contact.

title: Tips Lead to Arrest in Series of Roadway Shootings Around Kansas City
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Weeks went by last month and the only evidence that victims of a spate of roadway shootings here could offer the police were the loud pops they had heard and the bullet holes in their cars. Someone was shooting vehicles as they drove on the southern edge of this city and in neighboring suburbs, and this metropolitan area of more than two million people was on edge.

title: Richards Shows Rangers That Confidence Is Contagious
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The Rangers achieved only one victory against the Philadelphia Flyers on Thursday, but it is impossible to measure the value of a rejuvenated Brad Richards to the Rangers confidence.

title: A Day of Chants, Bells, a Bike
description: Bora Yoon writes and performs music that combines ancient and modern elements, including 12th-century liturgical chants and abstract electronic sound architecture. On Sundays she gets paid to sing at the Church of the Ascension in Greenwich Village. Her new album, Sunken Cathedral, explores the structural parallels between the vaulted construction of a church and its organ and that of a human chest, with both producing sound by moving air through pipes. She will perform much of the album at the Asia Society on Wednesday. Ms. Yoon, 33, lives in Astoria, Queens, with a great friend that I found through Craigslist, she said.

title: An Orange Jumpsuit for Lent
description: Kent McKeever has been summoned for jury duty twice. The second time was on March 17, more than a week into Lent, so he had no choice but to wear his orange prison jumpsuit. As he entered the McLennan County courthouse in Waco, Tex., two sheriffs officers stopped him.

title: Can Paradise Be Planned?
description: When the architect Robert A. M. Stern was a kid in the 40s, he used to spend his Sundays perusing The New York Times real estate section. In those days, recalls the self-described modern traditionalist best known for buildings like 15 Central Park West and the George W. Bush Presidential Library, It was all about new houses that were being built in suburbia. I would look at them and redraw the plans. At the basic level I thought they were so damn bad and I thought I could do better.

title: Health Officials to Propose Tighter Monitoring of Water Tanks
description: In a reversal, New York City health officials are proposing stronger oversight of rooftop water tanks, which supply drinking water to millions of residents and workers each day but are often neglected by their owners.

title: Algerian President Wins a Fourth Term
description: President Abdelaziz Bouteflika has won a fourth term as Algerias leader, receiving 81.5 percent of the vote, officials said Friday. Opposition leaders who boycotted the election immediately cast doubt on the results, accusing Mr. Bouteflika, left, and his supporters of widespread fraud and of inflating the turnout, which was officially 51.7 percent. His strongest challenger, former Prime Minister Ali Benflis, won only 12 percent of the vote. Mr. Bouteflika, 77, has been largely incapacitated since suffering a stroke last year, but he has managed to retain a strong grip on power and has avoided the democratic changes prompted by the Arab Spring uprisings elsewhere in North Africa. He cast his ballot in the presidential election on Thursday from a wheelchair.

title: Dressed to Lead the Pack
description: Come on, we got the light, kids, said the wolf pack leader, as traffic stopped and he guided five well-groomed dogs across Riverside Drive.

title: Go Forth and Conquer, but Postpone the Selfie
description: Sign of the times: Bryant University in Rhode Island has told its graduating seniors not to take selfies when they come onstage for their diplomas next month.

title: In Pistorius Trial, Critics See a Justice System Favoring the Rich and Famous
description: PRETORIA, South Africa  Before the murder trial of the double-amputee sprinter Oscar Pistorius opened, a judge who ruled that most of it could be broadcast said his decision would counter the notion that South African justice treated the rich and famous with kid gloves while it was harsh on the poor and vulnerable.

title: 5 Episodes in a Pivotal Year in New York
description: A half-century ago, a progressive municipal administration took office with an ambitious agenda. Through the prism of five seminal events, in New York City 1964: A Cultural History (McFarland), Lawrence R. Samuel, an author and business consultant, explores the seething city that the administration of John V. Lindsay inherited after the election of 1965.

title: Covert Inquiry by F.B.I. Rattles 9/11 Tribunals
description: WASHINGTON  Two weeks ago, a pair of F.B.I. agents appeared unannounced at the door of a member of the defense team for one of the men accused of plotting the 9/11 terrorist attacks. As a contractor working with the defense team at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, the man was bound by the same confidentiality rules as a lawyer. But the agents wanted to talk.

title: Nets Enter Playoffs With Toughness Spawned by Last Years Exit
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The genesis of this Nets team can be traced to last May. Forty-nine regular-season victories were quickly rendered meaningless by an inglorious first-round playoff elimination.

title: Senseless Deaths on a Ferry, and by a Gunmans Hand
description: The struggle for Ukraine continued to generate the most tension and passion over the past week. Though Russian, Ukrainian, American and European Union foreign ministers were meeting in Geneva to agree on steps to de-escalate the tensions, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia appeared to take little heed, provocatively noting on television that in czarist times, southeastern Ukraine was a Russian province called Novorossiya, literally New Russia. The possibility that he would annex it, as he had annexed Crimea, remained very real.

title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,302 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: Journeyman Seems at Home, Nearly No-Hitting the Mets
description: Aaron Harang was known as a low-ball pitcher and a strike thrower when the Mets had him for four starts last September. He was like duct tape for a faltering rotation at the end of a disappointing season, but he was a veteran with enough reason to prove he could still pitch. After the season, the Mets let him leave.

title: U.S. Plans Military Drills in Eastern Europe
description: WASHINGTON  The United States plans to carry out small ground-force exercises in Poland and Estonia in an attempt to reassure NATOs Eastern European members worried about Russias military operations in and near Ukraine, Western officials said Friday.

title: Documentary Producer to Lead Citys Film Office
description: Filling a post much discussed from Burbank, Calif., to Brooklyn, Mayor Bill de Blasio on Friday named Cynthia Lpez, a co-executive producer of the award-winning documentary series POV, the new commissioner of the Mayors Office of Media and Entertainment.

title: A Brownsville Sanctuary, 100 Years and Counting
description: Hundreds of children gathered outside the Brownsville Childrens Library the night it opened its doors in September 1914. Designed to look like a fairy tale castle, the branch, which was financed by Andrew Carnegie, was among the first free-standing childrens libraries in the nation.

title: Yankees Bullpen Comes Undone Along With Their Lead
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Concerns surrounding the Yankees bullpen entering this season appeared to have been erased through the first 16 games.

title: N.B.A. Playoff Predictions
description: With the playoffs getting underway, The New York Times staff predicts who will emerge from each conference to meet in the N.B.A. Finals.

title: Corrections: April 19, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 9 P.M. (HBO) BILLY CRYSTAL: 700 SUNDAYS (2014) In this adaptation of his Broadway show, taped in January, Mr. Crystal, right, pays tribute to his father, Jack, who ran a record store in Times Square, produced concerts for jazz greats like Billie Holiday and died when Mr. Crystal was 15. The set evokes his childhood home in Long Beach, N.Y.; home movies are projected onstage; and an animated family fight, in which Mr. Crystal portrays all the characters, is done in mime. 700 Sundays is itself a love letter to the past, Jason Zinoman wrote in a review of the production in The New York Times. Still, all the reverent stories dont add up to a flesh-and-blood character. Jack Crystal remains remote, larger than life, which may be where Mr. Crystal wants to keep him. Its the kind of show that you wish your son made about you.

title: Cheo Feliciano, Debonair Salsa Singer, Dies at 78
description: Cheo Feliciano, a leading salsa singer renowned for both his love songs and his upbeat improvisations, died in an automobile accident on Thursday in San Juan, P.R. He was 78.

title: Michael Janeway, Former Editor of The Boston Globe, Dies at 73
description: Michael C. Janeway, a former editor of The Boston Globe and executive editor of The Atlantic Monthly who wrote two books chronicling what he saw as the intertwined decline of democracy and journalism in the United States, died on Thursday at his home in Lakeville, Conn. He was 73.

title: Four Men Are Arrested in New Jersey Gunfight
description: Four men robbed an auto salvage shop in northern New Jersey on Friday and exchanged gunfire with police officers who foiled their attempt to get away in a U-Haul truck, the police said. The four were quickly arrested, though a fifth man involved in the robbery remained at large Friday night.

title: The Stations of the Cross in Red Hook
description: .media.slideshow.in-page-player .headline { display: none; }

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, April 19, 2014
description: The day-to-day life is very tense. We never know what will happen.

title: Deadly Clash Reported on Border of China and Vietnam
description: BEIJING  Five Chinese civilians and two Vietnamese border guards died Friday during a clash between Vietnamese border guards and Chinese citizens who were trying to enter Vietnam illegally, according to official Vietnamese news reports on Friday and Saturday.

title: Analytics: Is Unfair Trading Fair Game?
description: The following Analytics appears on the letters page in the April 20 issue of the magazine.

title: Deadliest Day: Sherpas Bear Everests Risks
description: NEW DELHI  The Sherpas always go first, edging up the deadly flank of Everest while international clients wait for days in the base camp below.

title: Captain and Two Crew Members Are Arrested in Korean Ferry Sinking
description: JINDO, South Korea  The captain and two crew members of a ferry that capsized, leaving more than 270 people  most of them students  missing, were arrested early Saturday, the authorities said.

title: How Urban Anonymity Disappears When All Data Is Tracked
description: Cities are our paradises of anonymity, a place for both self-erasure and self-reinvention. But soon, cities may fall first in the disappearance, or at least a radical remaking, of privacy.

title: Divers Begin Bringing Bodies Out of Capsized Ferry
description: JINDO, South Korea  After days of rescue efforts stymied by strong currents and poor visibility, divers made their way into a capsized South Korean ferry on Sunday and began bringing out bodies, starting what officials said would probably be weeks of grim recovery operations.

title: A Swarm of Ant-Sized Robots, at Your Service
description: While the robots imagined in science fiction novels have often looked like humans, todays robotic armies are emerging in all shapes and sizes.

title: European Debt Deflation
description: As I noted yesterday, Sweden is now experiencing deflation, which is bad for a number of reasons  including the fact that household debt is very high, and deflation (or even low inflation) increases the burden of that debt. (This makes it even more ironic that the Riksbanks justification for ignoring Econ 101 and raising rates in a depressed economy was concern about excessive household debt and financial stability.) Lars Svensson, who has been a prophet without honor throughout, offers more.

title: Leveled by Landslide, Towns Mull How to Rebuild
description: OSO, Wash.  A sometimes awkward, invariably agonized conversation about the future has begun here at the site of last months devastating landslide, about what might be rebuilt and what was perhaps forever lost that day.

title: When Delight Turns to Reality, Its Goodbye, Easter Bunny
description: RICHMOND, Calif.  Back in 1988, when the seven founders of the House Rabbit Society first came together at a dining table in Alameda, Calif., just south of here, the idea of keeping a rabbit as an indoor pet was considered fairly smirk-worthy.

title: Dorsett Is Feisty Key to Rangers Fourth Line
description: It was November on the Prairies, and the Medicine Hat Tigers team bus was rolling down the cold highway out of Alberta, headed for Saskatoon to play the Blades. But it took an unfamiliar turn, and the players asked Coach Willie Desjardins, Where are we going?

title: Michelle Peluso of Gilt Groupe: I Dont Need an Ivory Tower (or an Office)
description: This interview with  Michelle Peluso, chief executive of Gilt Groupe, the online shopping site, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Banks Cling to Bundles Holding Risk
description: The Volcker Rule doesnt go into effect until 2015, but that hasnt stopped big bankers and their supporters in Washington from trying to undermine it.

title: One Lousy Seat, a Fitting Tribute
description: MILWAUKEE  The corner of a baseball dugout, where the tunnel to the clubhouse intersects with the bat rack, ought to have a friendly greeter. At Miller Park, the home of the Milwaukee Brewers, his name is Bob Uecker. Everyone stops to say hi to him, and Uecker greets all with gusto.

title: Inspired by an Eclipse
description: Rubina Isaac, 26, works with educational programs and tours for children at Adler Planetarium in Chicago.

title: Variety: An Acrostic That Leaves
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  To borrow from Joyce Kilmer, I think that I shall never see a puzzle lovely as a tree. Oh, there are some that come close, especially those by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon.

title: In Slovakia, Real Lottery Prize Goes to Tax Man
description: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia  When Jozef Lazarcik, a 35-year-old factory worker, heard his number called on national television here recently, he pumped his fists, hardly believing his luck.

title: Weeding Out the Bad Reference
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: Democrats Confront Vexing Politics Over the Health Care Law
description: ATLANTA  When Franklin D. Roosevelt established Social Security, he created generations of loyal Democrats. When Lyndon B. Johnson signed Medicare into law, he built on that legacy, particularly with older Americans. And when George W. Bush instituted a new prescription drug benefit for Medicare, it helped reclaim elderly voters for Republicans.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: House Calls Are Making a Comeback
description: A relic from the medical past  the house call  is returning to favor as part of some hospitals palliative care programs, which are sending teams of physicians, nurses, social workers, chaplains and other workers to patients homes after they are discharged. The goal is twofold: to provide better treatment and to cut costs.

title: The Chatter for Sunday, April 19
description: Youll see us exploring new areas that we felt we didnt have the room to do before. Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Facebook, who has been working on revamping the way the company creates and distributes new services, focusing on apps.

title: My Head Talks Piketty With Bill Moyers
description: By the way, the man himself pronounces it pick a TEA.

title: When Diamonds Are Dirt Cheap, Will They Still Dazzle?
description: As a seventh grader, I was lucky to land the job of ball boy for the Brooklyn Dodgers during their annual late-March exhibition games in Miami. The experience left me with fond memories  of Roy Campanella smoking a cigar as he stroked line drives in the batting cage, of a young Sandy Koufax throwing harder than seemed humanly possible and of an aging Jackie Robinson struggling to remain in the lineup.

title: An Overdue Haircut
description: Its sheep-shearing season across much of the United States, and recently a team of five shearers descended on Lehfeldt Land & Livestock near Lavina, Mont., to remove a years worth of growth from about 3,000 ewes and bucks. The work took just over three days; the shearers have an incentive to work quickly because they are paid per sheep. After the wool is removed, it is placed in nylon bales weighing around 500 pounds each and shipped to a warehouse in Billings. Eventually a clothing maker or a mill will bid on it.

title: From the Fishbowl to the Garden
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Pressure  what pressure? That is what Coach Alain Vigneault was saying last week before the Rangers started their opening-round series against the Philadelphia Flyers. Leading the Rangers is a pressure-filled job, he said, but not as much as coaching an N.H.L. team in Canada.

title: Shearing Season
description: The springtime business of removing wool from sheep in the United States.

title: Obamacare Versus The Wusses
description: One of the odd rituals of American punditry  the most famous example is Karl Roves tantrum in 2012, but it happens all the time  is the way pundits and operatives keep spinning after the polls have closed. Never mind the vote totals, and lets dispute the network projections; my guy is still winning!

title: When Swastikas on Uniforms Meant Luck
description: Why were the Boston Braves wearing a swastika on their caps when they opened the 1914 season against the Brooklyn Dodgers?

title: Comcasts Real Repairman
description: One morning late last month, David L. Cohen took a seat in a conference room atop Comcasts corporate headquarters in Philadelphia, the tallest building in the city, and was handed a binder of architectural drawings. The plans were for a second Comcast skyscraper, taller than the first, because the growing company needs more space.

title: Taking On Adam Smith (and Karl Marx)
description: PARIS  Thomas Piketty turned 18 in 1989, when the Berlin Wall fell, so he was spared the tortured, decades-long French intellectual debate about the virtues and vices of communism. Even more telling, he remembers, was a trip he took with a close friend to Romania in early 1990, after the collapse of the Soviet empire.

title: Breaking Proud Tradition, Captains Flee and Let Others Go Down With Ship
description: Ever since the Titanic sank on its maiden voyage, carrying its captain and many of the passengers with it, the notion that the captain goes down with his ship has been ingrained in popular culture.

title: Familiar Face Shines With a Mets Affiliate
description: RENO, Nev.  Bobby Abreu leaned against the concrete wall outside the modest visitors clubhouse last Thursday at Aces Ballpark, discussing how he had landed at this point in his baseball career with the Las Vegas 51s, the Mets Class AAA affiliate. When his teammates walked past, he smiled and joked and offered fist bumps.

title: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 54
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: French Journalists Are Freed in Syria
description: PARIS  Four French journalists who were held captive for 10 months in Syria were released on the Turkish-Syrian border late Friday and were on their way home to France, President Franois Hollande said Saturday.

title: Fright Nights in the N.B.A.
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  The roster of the Oklahoma City Thunder has championship-caliber talent, but the teams playoff hopes may rest  though not in peace  with one bit player who remains largely unseen.

title: A 12-Year-Olds Trek of Despair Ends in a Noose at the Border
description: Noemi lvarez Quillay took the first steps of the 6,500-mile journey to New York City from the southern highlands of Ecuador on Tuesday, Feb. 4, after darkness fell.

title: Marx Rises Again
description: IN the season of resurrection, its fitting that hes with us once again  bearded, prophetic, moralistic, promising to exalt the humble and cast down the mighty from their thrones.

title: Being Good Isnt the Only Way to Go
description: LAST September, the networking site LinkedIn added a feature that allowed its members to say whether they wanted to volunteer or serve on the board of a nonprofit. In just eight months, one million members raised their virtual hands.

title: Torment on the Stand, but Is It an Act?
description: AGAIN and again over days of brutal cross-examination in a Pretoria courtroom, Oscar Pistorius, the South African track star, broke down on the witness stand. He retched. He cried, then sobbed, then grew hysterical. It got so bad that at times the judge, Thokozile Matilda Masipa, had to adjourn the court while Mr. Pistorius regained his equilibrium.

title: Reader Complaints, Behind the Scenes
description: JACKIE McCaffrey, a Times reader, sounded frustrated.

title: Still Getting Wolf Whistles at 50
description: WASHINGTON  ITS weird to be jealous of your car.

title: The Risks of Everest Are Deadlier for Some
description: ON a bright afternoon in June of 1922, the Mount Everest pioneer George Mallory was leading a group of 17 men tied together in three separate rope teams toward the North Col of the mountain when he heard an ominous sound, and turned to see an avalanche fracturing the steep slope above them.

title: Tolstoy and Miss Daisy
description: IF you were on I-85 near Atlanta on Wednesday morning or I-95 near Baltimore on Thursday afternoon, theres a chance you spotted them. Youd remember, especially if she was driving when they lumbered by. Its not often that you see an 18-year-old girl behind the wheel of a gold-colored Cadillac so enormous, so archaic. And its not usually a 79-year-old man you find beside her, her lone companion on the long road.

title: Randall Copeland
description: Randall Copeland, a Southern Baptist married to a Catholic, is the vice president of operations at the Manischewitz Company, the nations largest manufacturer of kosher foods including such Passover staples as matzo and gefilte fish.

title: The Part-Time Faculty
description: Readers discuss an editorial about the quality and pay of adjunct professors.

title: How to Get a Job at Google, Part 2
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  HOWS my kid going to get a job? There are few questions I hear more often than that one. In February, I interviewed Laszlo Bock, who is in charge of all hiring at Google  about 100 new hires a week  to try to understand what an employer like Google was looking for and why it was increasingly ready to hire people with no college degrees. Bocks remarks generated a lot of reader response, particularly his point that prospective bosses today care less about what you know or where you learned it  the Google machine knows everything now  than what value you can create with what you know. With graduations approaching, I went back to Google to ask Bock to share his best advice for job-seekers anywhere, not just at Google. Here is a condensed version of our conversations:

title: They Hook You When Youre Young
description: HOW do events from our childhood shape our adult preferences?

title: Abandon (Nearly) All Hope
description: With Easter upon us, powerful narratives of rebirth and resurrection are in the air and on the breeze. However, winters stubborn reluctance to leave to make way for the pleasing and hopeful season leads me to think not of cherry blossoms and Easter Bunnies but of Prometheus, Nietzsche, Barack Obama and the very roots of hope. Is hope always such a wonderful thing? Is it not rather a form of moral cowardice that allows us to escape from reality and prolong human suffering?

title: A Way for Artists to Live
description: THE bedroom was no wider than a subway car, painted Q-train yellow, and had a window facing a construction site that jackhammered at all hours. But I couldnt wait to move in. Id answered a Craigslist ad to join a new communal home, and though I wasnt sure I was the communal-home type, I was also in a phase of reconsidering what type of person I might be. My six housemates planned to open a collectively owned and operated bed-and-breakfast in our building. If our projected costs and occupancy rates were correct (and if the jackhammering would let up), each partner would work 10 to 15 hours a week at the co-op to cover our rent, utilities and shared groceries, freeing up time to pursue the low-to-zero-pay projects we all had in music, art, education and writing.

title: In Dads Hometown, European Souls
description: KARAPCHIV, Ukraine  TO understand why Ukrainians are risking war with Russia to try to pluck themselves from Moscows grip, I came to this village where my father grew up.

title: Let Them Drink Chocolate
description: I AM a vegetarian, and its Passover. So until Tuesday night I am abstaining not only from all kinds of meat  beef, chicken, fish  but also from my usual low-fat alternatives, like bread, cereal and pasta. The holiday strictures laid out by Leviticus, added to my usual ethics, leave me this week with a heart-hostile diet of eggs, cheese, buttered matzo and my wifes flourless chocolate cake.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 20
description: The Boston Marathon kicks off Monday morning, one year after a bomb exploded near the finish line of the race, killing three people and wounding hundreds. Gov. Deval Patrick of Massachusetts will discuss security at the marathon on CBSs Face the Nation.

title: Hockey Players Concussion Suits Follow Path Charted in N.F.L. Cases
description: Someone once said that three makes a trend, and now that three concussion-related lawsuits have been filed by nearly two dozen former hockey players against the N.H.L., a trend has emerged.

title: Republicans See Political Wedge in Common Core
description: WASHINGTON  The health care law may be Republicans favorite weapon against Democrats this year, but there is another issue roiling their party and shaping the establishment-versus-grass-roots divide ahead of the 2016 presidential primaries: the Common Core.

title: This Time, Get Global Trade Right
description: Many Americans have watched their neighbors lose good-paying jobs as their employers sent their livelihoods to China. Over the last 20 years, the United States has lost nearly five million manufacturing jobs. In that same time, however, the prices that Americans pay for basic goods like T-shirts and televisions have fallen. The cost of clothing is down 8.2 percent since 1993, as made in China and made in Bangladesh labels have crowded out made in U.S.A. on the shelves of the local mall.

title: In Cold War Echo, Obama Strategy Writes Off Putin
description: WASHINGTON  Even as the crisis in Ukraine continues to defy easy resolution, President Obama and his national security team are looking beyond the immediate conflict to forge a new long-term approach to Russia that applies an updated version of the Cold War strategy of containment.

title: So These Professors Walk Into a Comedy Club ...
description: NOT long after the physicist Werner Heisenberg (not the guy from Breaking Bad) identified the uncertainty principle in the early 20th century, E. B. White  in a somewhat similar vein  warned against meddling with what defines funny.

title: Jokes From the Top 10 Cities
description: Researchers from the Humor Research Lab and Peter McGraw and Joel Warner, the authors of The Humor Code: A Global Search for What Makes Things Funny, asked more than 900 residents of the top 10 funniest cities to recount their favorite joke. Their responses revealed unique humor profiles for each city. Below is a sampling of representative jokes from each place.

title: Pro-Russian Forces Work on Consolidating Power
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  Just before the most important religious holiday of the year for both Ukrainians and Russians, the Orthodox Christian Easter celebration on Sunday, pro-Russian militant groups have paused what had been the daily expansion of their territory in eastern Ukraine.

title: White Sox, Furthering Legacy, Provide Warm Home for Cubans Amid Chill
description: CHICAGO  Alexei Ramirez wore a winter cap, the kind with a fuzzy pompom on top, in the Chicago White Sox clubhouse last Wednesday. It was warm enough in there, but Ramirez took no chances. Stiff wind and icy air would await him on the field.

title: Blowing the Dust Off a Century-Old Woe
description: In 23 pitches Friday night against Tampa Bay, Yankees reliever Cesar Cabral pieced together an unsightly outing, one that also has a place in the record books.

title: Looking at the Ukraine-Russia Crisis from my Ancestral Village
description: For my Sunday column, I returned to the village near Chernivtsi, Ukraine, where my father grew up. What struck me there was the deep yearning for connections to the West, for a future tied not with Russia but with Western Europe. Obviously, one encounters somewhat different sentiments in eastern Ukraine, but overall this popular yearning for a future in Europe runs both deep and broad.

title: Taunts Fly in Toronto, but Nets Get Last Word
description: TORONTO  It was only halfway through the first game of the N.B.A. playoffs, and Masai Ujiri, the general manager of the Toronto Raptors, was already apologizing to children.

title: Flyers Mason Will Miss Game 2 Against Rangers
description: Philadelphia goalie Steve Mason confirmed after practice Saturday that he was not ready to return to play for Game 2 of the Flyers first-round playoff series against the Rangers on Sunday at Madison Square Garden.

title: Coachs Return Is Fraught With Complications
description: MANKATO, Minn.  Todd Hoffner did no coaching at the Minnesota State football practice on Friday, three days after he was reinstated as the teams coach. Dressed in a purple Mavericks top and black pants, he stood on the periphery, talking to friends and boosters while assistants ran the 1-hour-40-minute session on a windswept afternoon. With the team three weeks into spring drills, Hoffner did not want to disrupt the routine.

title: Battle Rages in Homs, Hub of Revolt Against Assad Government
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Deadly battles are raging in Homs, the central Syrian city that was long a hub and a symbol of the revolt against President Bashar al-Assad, with both soldiers and insurgents saying they have lost many fighters in recent days as the government presses an all-out assault on the last few rebel-held areas in the Old City of Homs.

title: Critic of Pakistani Military Wounded in Karachi Attack
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Hamid Mir, a prominent Pakistani journalist and a critic of the nations powerful military, was wounded by gunmen in the southern port city of Karachi on Saturday evening, according to police officials and local news media reports.

title: Woman Arrested in Attempted Kidnapping of 8-Month-Old
description: A 46-year-old woman with a history of trying to abduct young children has been arrested in connection with the attempted kidnapping of an 8-month-old boy in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan, the police said on Saturday.

title: A Tennis Player Learns to Be Aggressive for Healths Sake
description: MONTE CARLO  Combining unconventional shotmaking and graceful, almost balletic footwork, Alexandr Dolgopolov is one of the most watchable players on the ATP Tour and the best Ukrainian player in a generation.

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: Q. A friend of mine told me that Wyatt Earps wife was a Jewish girl from New York. True?

title: Ferry Captain and Crew Questioned
description: The captain of the Sewol has been charged with abandoning passengers, among other counts, after the ferry carrying more than 400 people sank off South Korea. Two crew members were also arrested.

title: Zhou Family Ties
description: Several members of Zhou Yongkangs family have made investments in companies with ties to the China National Petroleum Corp., the state oil company formerly run by Mr. Zhou.

title: In a Mansions Interior, a Study in Contrasts
description: Elsie de Wolfe favored flowery painting on walls and furniture, mirrored surfaces to reflect light and an overall brightness for the rooms she designed. Charles Duveens trademarks included wood-paneled walls, furniture upholstered in deep red damask or velvet and rooms brimming with dark-hued antiques. Both designers helped create the look of different parts of Coe Hall, the mansion at the heart of the 409-acre Planting Fields Arboretum State Historic Park in Oyster Bay. And now both are the subjects of a new exhibition, Fabulous Interiors by Elsie de Wolfe and Charles Duveen, 1915-1945, which traces their careers and the impact they had on the home owned in the early 20th century by William Robertson Coe, an insurance magnate, and his second wife, Mai Rogers Coe, a Standard Oil heiress.

title: On Wheels
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Another triumph from the Queen of Visual puzzles, Elizabeth C. Gorski. One thing Ms. Gorsi forgot to mention in her comments below is that New Yorkers will go to extreme lengths to find parking for their cars, even if it means pulling your fender right up against the car in front of you. Or sometimes on top.

title: Investigating Familys Wealth, Chinas Leader Signals a Change
description: HONG KONG  His son landed contracts to sell equipment to state oil fields and thousands of filling stations across China. His sons mother-in-law held stakes in pipelines and natural gas pumps from Sichuan Province in the west to the southern isle of Hainan. And his sister-in-law, working from one of Beijings most prestigious office buildings, invested in mines, property and energy projects.

title: Suburban Jazz Club Attracts Star Lineups
description: The drummers Eliot Zigmund and Richie Morales are known for their performances on the worlds big stages  Mr. Zigmund with cool-jazz innovators like the pianist Bill Evans and the trumpeter Chet Baker; Mr. Morales with fusion pioneers like the guitarist Al Di Meola and the group Spyro Gyra.

title: Legal Twist in Bid to Reclaim Nazi-Looted Hospital
description: PARIS  Stephan Templ was hoping to right a historic wrong when he fought to reclaim part of an imposing Victorian hospital that was looted from his family by the Nazis in 1938, he says. Instead, he now faces three years behind bars.

title: Submersible Seeking Jetliner May Soon Finish First Sweep
description: HONG KONG  An unmanned submersible vehicle searching the ocean floor off Western Australia for signs of the missing Malaysia Airlines plane could finish an initial sweep of the area within five to seven days, search organizers said on Saturday.

title: Adrianne Wadewitz, 37, Wikipedia Editor, Dies in Rock Climbing Fall
description: Adrianne Wadewitz, a scholar of 18th-century British literature who became one of the most prolific and influential editors of the online encyclopedia Wikipedia, died on April 8 in Palm Springs, Calif. She was 37.

title: A Play About a Play Reveals Racial Tensions
description: Trouble in Mind, originally produced Off Broadway in 1955, has been rediscovered by major regional companies in recent years  and rightly so. Currently staged by Two River Theater in Red Bank, Alice Childresss play is a semisatirical study of racism in the theater world that proves fascinating on several levels. It is a sometimes acrid backstage comedy, a frank look at mid-1950s social attitudes and also a commentary on the discomfort between blacks and whites that remains relevant to some degree today.

title: Gene Estess, Who Left Wall Street to Aid the Poor, Dies at 78
description: Gene Estess worked on Wall Street for two decades and came to feel that he never had really good days. I didnt come home with stories to tell or satisfaction or a feeling Id done anything to help anybody except myself and my family, he said in an interview with The New York Times in 2003.

title: Inspired by a Broadway Classic
description: Salsa music fills the air. Clotheslines strung with laundry crisscross the space overhead. When you take your seat at Matthew Lopezs Somewhere at Hartford Stage, all thats missing from the old San Juan Hill neighborhood of Manhattan is the scent of frying sofrito.

title: Making the Most of Opponents Mistakes
description: Being good is not always enough. It helps to be lucky. That was the case for Romain Edouard, a French grandmaster, who won the Dubai Open Chess Championship last week.

title: Jacob Birnbaum, Civil Rights Champion of Soviet Jews, Dies at 88
description: Just as the civil rights movement began with students challenging segregation at lunch counters, the movement to free Soviet Jews began with students demonstrating at the Soviet Mission to the United Nations.

title: Early Bloomer, Aptly Named
description: Plants offer pollinators many rewards  nectar, pollen, even perfumes for attracting the perfect mate. Not many offer heat. During the cold days of spring, the Eastern skunk cabbage offers insects a warm, dark place to eat and sleep.

title: Budget Stress Actually Rises as Money Does
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Overseer Meant to Settle Disputes Is Subject of One
description: For decades, water wars have been rare in East Texas, where annual rainfall can be twice that of West Texas.

title: As High Schools Change, Technical Colleges Prepare to Expand
description: Higher education officials largely stayed on the sidelines last year when the Texas Legislature debated and ultimately passed a bill that led to a significant overhaul of the states high school curriculum.

title: Working to Prove Innocence of Inmates
description: LUBBOCK, Tex.  In the back of the Cotton Exchange building in Lubbocks dusty downtown, the Innocence Project of Texas keeps more than 10,000 files from state prisoners in dozens of blue, purple, and white plastic boxes.

title: Warriors Win in Next Stage of a Season of Hostilities
description: LOS ANGELES  More than an hour before Saturdays game, Stephen Curry sat alone on the Golden State Warriors bench. He looked like a boxer waiting to go to work, covered from head to toe in workout gear, a hooded sweatshirt shrouding most of his head, his eyes peeking out and fixed straight ahead.

title: Sending Alerts Instead, G.M. Delayed Car Recalls
description: The first word from General Motors that the Chevrolet Cobalt had a dangerous safety problem came nine years ago, in a letter to dealers warning them that the cars could suddenly stall because of faulty ignition switches.

title: U.N. Struggles to Stem Haiti Cholera Epidemic
description: CHAPOTEAU, Haiti  For three years, the United Nations has refused to address whether its peacekeepers brought a deadly strain of cholera to Haiti, insisting instead that it was more important to help the country stanch the disease once and for all.

title: Ex-Officer Killed Wife, Police Say; Children Ran for Help
description: A former New York City police officer fatally shot his wife in their Queens home on Saturday while their two young children were in the house, according to the police and neighbors.

title: Colon Bounces Back and Duda Soldiers On, but Neither Does Quite Enough
description: All through spring training, as Lucas Duda and Ike Davis competed to start at first base, they insisted they were close friends. Even after Duda was named the starter early this season, they had their own handshake: They would high-five and then pretend to punch each other in the gut.

title: In a Thrashing, No Yankee Is Safe on the Mound (Not Even an Infielder)
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  A little shake of the arm and a wince were all it took to get Joe Girardi bounding out of the dugout as a bad night of baseball turned into something worse.

title: Vows: Completing the Circle
description: Forty-four years after Steve Shapiro became a hippie and broke off his engagement to Jane Mattson, the couple is giving marriage a second chance.

title: Kristin Ciccone and Samir Gole
description: Kristin Elana Ciccone and Samir Dilip Gole were married Saturday at the Downtown Club in Philadelphia. The Rev. Michael Giansiracusa, an Episcopal priest and a former high school teacher of the bride, officiated, with Dr. Shashikant M. Sane, a Hindu priest, assisting.

title: Raj-Ann Rekhi and Pavan Gill
description: Raj-Ann Kaur Rekhi and Pavan Singh Gill were married Saturday at the Ritz-Carlton in Half Moon Bay, Calif. Tilden Moschetti, a friend of the groom and a Universal Life Church minister, officiated. On Saturday morning, Deepinder Singh, a Sikh scholar and a friend of the brides family, performed a traditional Sikh ceremony at the hotel.

title: Kimberly Ackert and Claudette Buelow
description: Kimberly Allison Ackert and Claudette Lina Buelow were married Monday in a grove of trees in front of the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center in New York. Douglas Hunt, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Jennifer Snead, Andrea Fuggetta
description: Jennifer Melinda Snead and Andrea Fuggetta were married Saturday at the Kensington and Chelsea Register Office in London. Andrew L. Kenyon, the superintendent registrar, officiated.
