title: Toni Cruthirds, Josiah Urban
description: Toni Anne Cruthirds and Josiah Stephen-Carrier Urban were married Wednesday at St. Thomas the Apostle Catholic Church in Long Beach, Miss. The Rev. Louis Lohan, a Roman Catholic priest and the churchs pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Maria Amundson and Elliot Krane
description: Maria Ann Amundson and Dr. Elliot Jeffrey Krane were married Saturday in the rotunda of San Francisco City Hall. The officiant was Kenneth S. Krane, the brother of the groom, who was appointed a deputy marriage commissioner by the City and County of San Francisco for the occasion.

title: Mona Sadeghpour, Ardavan Akhavan
description: Dr. Mona Sadeghpour, the daughter of Siamak and Maryam Sadeghpour of Plano, Tex., was married Saturday to Dr. Ardavan Akhavan, the son of Yasmin Mahallati Akhavan and Cyrous Akhavan of Palisades, N.Y. Abbas Boroujerdi, a Universal Life church minister, performed a ceremony that incorporated Persian traditions at the White Oaks Ranch in Pilot Point, Tex.

title: Jessica Ferri, Graham Roberts
description: Jessica Anne Ferri and Graham Yves Roberts were married Saturday evening at the Beauregard-Keyes House, a museum in New Orleans. Timothy Gunatilaka, a friend of the couple and a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Monica Huang, William Wang
description: Monica Chenwen Huang and William Wang were married Saturday at Capitale, an event space in Manhattan. Their officiant was Judge Edward R. Korman of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York, for whom the groom was a law clerk from 2005 to 2006.

title: Melody Akhavan and Ashkan Abbey
description: Melody Elham Akhavan and Dr. Ashkan Michael Abbey were married Saturday evening at the Planterra Conservatory in West Bloomfield, Mich. Marjan Moghaddam, a representative of the Bahai Spiritual Assembly, officiated.

title: Anne Bookwalter, Andrew Ullman
description: Anne Marie Catherine Bookwalter and Andrew Michael Ullman were married Saturday at the Outdoor Art Club in Mill Valley, Calif. The officiant was Thomas Collins Bookwalter, a brother of the bride who was named a temporary deputy commissioner of civil marriages by the County of San Francisco.

title: Noelle Pepe, Seth Gold
description: Noelle Allard Pepe, a daughter of Valerie J. Fenton of Stamford, Conn., and Salvatore S. Pepe of Rye Brook, N.Y., was married in New York Saturday evening to Seth Aaron Gold, the son of Jayne E. Gold and Dr. Lee K. Gold of West Bloomfield, Mich. Benjamin Marlan, an interfaith minister, officiated at the Yale Club of New York.

title: Blueprint for a Romance
description: Laura Stacy Passmore and Stephen Laslett Scribner were married Saturday evening at the Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center in Austin, Tex. Erik Dawe, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Jane Mattson, Steve Shapiro
description: Jane Dena Mattson and Steve Herbert Shapiro were married Saturday evening at Bernards, a restaurant in Ridgefield, Conn. Rabbi Mark Lipson officiated.

title: Allegra Asplundh-Smith and Evan McGarvey
description: Allegra Brett Asplundh-Smith and Evan Briggs McGarvey were married Saturday at the Breakers Hotel in Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Emily Jane A. Lemole, a great-aunt of the bride and a minister of the Swedenborgian Church of North America, officiated.

title: It Just Needed Time to Brew
description: Erica Ruth Shea, a daughter of Nancy K. Shea of Georgetown, Mass., and Kevin B. Shea of Boston, was married Friday to Stephen Paul Valand, a son of Randi J. Valand and Olav R. Valand of Brooklyn. Jordan Saia, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the Green Building in Brooklyn.

title: Amy Turitz, Milan Ranka
description: Dr. Amy Lauren Turitz and Dr. Milan Prakash Ranka were married Saturday evening at the Venetian, an event space in Garfield, N.J. The Rev. Stuart Dangler, a United Methodist minister, officiated. Earlier in the day the couple took part in a Hindu blessing ceremony led by Pandit Devendra Shukla, a Hindu priest, at Milan Banquets, another event space in Garfield.

title: Orphan Black Recap: Season 2 Begins
description: The stock science fiction concept of human cloning at the core of Orphan Black on BBC America, not only provides a showcase for the versatility of its star, Tatiana Maslany, who portrays Sarah Manning and an ever-increasing number of clones, but it also grants the shows creators, Graeme Manson and John Fawcett, the freedom to quickly bounce from one genre to the next.

title: Corrections: April 20, 2014
description: AUTOMOBILES

title: General Mills Reverses Itself on Consumers Right to Sue
description: General Mills, one of the countrys largest food companies, on Saturday night announced in a stunning about-face that it was withdrawing its controversial plans to make consumers give up their right to sue it.

title: 1914: Easter Scenes In Paris
description: Two distinct streams of people could have been noticed outside the various Paris railway termini yesterday, the first consisting of Parisians about to quit the city for the Easter vacation, and the second, composed of English, German and other tourists, who had just arrived bent upon passing the same gay period in exploring the French capital. The result of the ingress of tourists was that the boulevards and main streets of Paris presented an even more cosmopolitan appearance than usual. Fortunately fine weather favored the sightseers and the guides reaped a rich silver harvest. Groups of energetic Teutons made an almost military inspection of the Louvre and decided with unanimity that the Mona Lisas smile is as over-rated as it is ambiguous.The char--bancs were all crowded, the majority of the passengers wearing caps. At dusk a group of English tourists, who had probably crossed the Channel for the sake of higher mental culture, marched contentedly up the avenue de lOpra to the immortal strains of You made me love you, supplied by the youngest visitors richly toned mouth-organ. The Frenchmen who had remained in Paris gazed upon their progress with unspeakable admiration and drank a thoughtful aperitif to the eternal durability of the Entente Cordiale. The New York Herald, European edition, April 12, 1914.

title: In Our Pages: April 21
description: 1914: King George V. and Queen Mary Visit France

title: Fire Kills Two 4-Year-Old Siblings in the Rockaways
description: On Saturday afternoon, JaiLauni and Aniya Tinglin, both 4, and their sister were outside in the sun, playing and riding scooters around their grandfathers home on Bay 30th Street in a working-class and polyglot corner of Far Rockaway, Queens.

title: Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, Boxer Found Wrongly Convicted, Dies at 76
description: Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, a star prizefighter whose career was cut short by a murder conviction in New Jersey and who became an international cause clbre while imprisoned for 19 years before the charges against him were dismissed, died on Sunday morning at his home in Toronto. He was 76.

title: Friends, and Influence, for Sale Online
description: Whoever said, Money cant buy you friends, clearly hasnt been on the Internet recently.

title: When the Fair Came Down
description: After the New York Worlds Fair closed on Oct. 17, 1965, the exhibitions and buildings were carefully and willfully dismantled.

title: Clues to Familys Business Ties Found in Public Paper Trail
description: Tombstones in China often record the names of both living and dead family members. The five tablets dedicated to the Zhou family in the hamlet of Xiqiantou list the nations former security chief, Zhou Yongkang, by his childhood name, Zhou Yuangen. They also record the names of his first and second wives, his two sons and his two brothers, their wives and their two sons.

title: Hamilton Grabs 3rd Straight Win in Formula One
description: SHANGHAI  There is an easy way to measure just how much the Mercedes team is dominating the new Formula One season: At the Chinese Grand Prix outside Shanghai on Sunday, for the fourth race in a row, Mercedes beat its nearest rival by nearly half a minute.

title: Whats on Sunday
description: 10 P.M. (WGN America) SALEM The networks first original scripted series explores the happenings that incited the infamous witch trials in 17th-century Massachusetts through the characters of Mary Sibley (Janet Montgomery, above), Salems unexpectedly pregnant head witch; her beau, John Alden (Shane West), who disappeared for seven years to fight Indians; her mysterious accomplice, Tituba (Ashley Madekwe); and Cotton Mather (Seth Gabel), the towns spiritual leader. Youve got to admit that its perversely entertaining, Neil Genzlinger wrote in The New York Times. Though witchery is a favorite theme of shows aimed at teenagers, this series aspires to a grown-up audience. You can tell that from the sex and nudity (the somewhat demure basic-cable variety, but still, theres a lot of flesh here). More important, you can tell it from the writing. When Salem isnt being deliberately outrageous, its cultivating a dynamic that could be fruitful as things move along. Here in the 21st century, science and reason rule, but in a world of sorcery, clinging to rationality just makes you stupid.

title: Asking How Much Opera Singers Work Is Worth
description: It was Monday morning and somewhere along the Henry Hudson Parkway, Jean Braham was already singing. She was gliding up and down the octaves as she headed down the highway in her Honda Accord.

title: Fractured State of Pakistani Taliban Calls Peace Deal Into Question
description: LONDON  When the Pakistani Taliban said they were willing to make peace, many Pakistanis were skeptical that the militants had truly abandoned their dream of transforming the country into an Islamic caliphate.

title: The Evergreen State: Washington Readies for Legal Marijuana Sales
description: Marijuana distributors in Washington State are eagerly awaiting licenses to sell the drug, now that the state has legalized production and possession.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 19, 2014
description: April 19, 2014

title: Another Faithful Hit for Hollywood: Heaven Is for Real
description: Heaven Is for Real became Hollywoods fourth overtly faith-based hit of the year over the Easter weekend, taking in an estimated $21.5 million  double the dismal ticket sales that Johnny Depp mustered for his latest big-budget effort. But God still could not beat a superhero: The No. 1 movie at North American theaters was again Captain America: The Winter Soldier (Disney), which sold about $26.6 million in tickets, for a three-week domestic total of $201.5 million, according to Rentrak, which compiles box-office data.

title: Nova Is Probably Facing Tommy John Surgery
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  When Yankees starter Ivan Nova described to Shawn Kelley the sensation he felt in his elbow Saturday night, Kelley knew. Soon after the conversation, Nova was on his way to have a magnetic resonance imaging test, but Kelley could have saved him the trouble.

title: Excerpt: Violet
description: Sutton Foster sings Lay Down Your Head from the musical Violet, on Broadway at the American Airlines Theater.

title: More Than 40 People Killed in Bus Accident in Pakistan
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  At least 42 people were killed Sunday morning in southern Pakistan after a bus slammed into a tractor-trailer in one of the worst traffic accidents in this country in recent years, officials and rescue workers said.

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking: April 18, 2014
description: Its been seven years since the financial meltdown, and more than 10 million people are still out of work across the country. What can we do to get out of this rut? This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Diane Brady of Bloomberg Businessweek discuss new ideas to get the economy moving again.

title: Further Notes on Sweden
description: Im still thinking about Swedens slide into deflation, which actually offers several lessons relevant to the rest of us.

title: Flyers Put End to One Skid and Keep Another One Going
description: There is a fine line between winning and losing, Rangers Coach Alain Vigneault said after his team fell to the Philadelphia Flyers, 4-2, at Madison Square Garden on Sunday afternoon.

title: Kidd Says Decision to Sit Kirilenko Was Matter of Flow
description: Someone was notably missing from the Nets exciting Game 1 win over the Toronto Raptors on Saturday afternoon: Andrei Kirilenko.

title: Shootout Underscores Fragile Truce in Ukraine
description: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine  A shootout at a checkpoint run by pro-Russian militants near the town of Slovyansk left at least three people dead on Sunday, highlighting the fraying here in eastern Ukraine of a truce reached days earlier by diplomats in Geneva.

title: Meshing Talents for a Dense and Strenuous Sound
description: On Saturday evening the German vocal ensemble Neue Vocalsolisten joined the International Contemporary Ensemble of New York at the Kitchen in the American premiere of Oscar Bianchis cantata Matra as part of the MATA Festival of new music. Before we continue, a brief glossary:

title: Dryly Sharing a Stage and Musicians, but Little Else
description: Joan Tower, composer, pianist and educator, is evidently no philosopher. The subject of a Composer Portrait at the Miller Theater in 2011, she was given another showcase at the Miller on Thursday evening, with excellent performances of her Big Sky (2000) for piano trio, In Memory (2002) for string orchestra and White Water (2011), her String Quartet No. 5.

title: Key Suspect in Art Scheme Is Under Arrest in Spain
description: A Spanish art dealer identified by the authorities in the United States as a central figure in one of the most sweeping art swindles in the last decade has been arrested in Spain, and a government official there said on Sunday that he expected the United States to request his extradition.

title: Love, and Warring Parents
description: Love is a communal thing in Abhishek Varmans 2 States, a Bollywood romantic comedy about a southern girl (shes Tamilian) and a northern boy (Punjabi) who have to overcome their parents bickering and prejudices to find a happy ending.

title: A Gimlet-Eyed Grunt, Soldiering Balefully Through a Wars Horrors
description: A century after the guns of August first boomed, World War I has lost none of its power to boggle the mind. The numbers are simply too big: 65 million men under arms, 37 million casualties, 12,000 miles of trenches on the Western Front, 1.45 billion shells fired. Rather than a human event, it often seems like an immeasurable abstraction, like negative infinity.

title: Bonding With the Chauffeur
description: Bends, Flora Laus restrained debut feature, seesaws between the painful limbos of an upper-class Hong Kong housewife and her driver, who lives on the mainland. Shot in sleek tones by Christopher Doyle, the film melds class-conscious melodrama with malleable mood piece, but keeps threatening to fade from understatement into stasis.

title: Norway Faces Germany in Dutch Tournament Finals
description: One of the biggest international junior events is the White House tournament held annually in the Netherlands.

title: Riding New York Citys Desire Line
description: Desire lines, says architecture critic Michael Kimmelman, are marked by economic development and evolving travel patterns. He plots todays desire line along the waterfronts of Brooklyn and Queens.

title: How This Renoir Used to Look
description: Conservators at the Art Institute of Chicago wanted to solve the mystery of the missing pigment.

title: From Liszts Soliloquies to Labor Blues
description: Bargemusic, the cozy floating concert hall moored just south of the Brooklyn Bridge, presents more than 200 concerts a year. Its easy to take for granted this invaluable workhorse of New Yorks music scene.But where else, I ask you, is it possible to hear two different pianists over the course of a few days play Winnsboro Cotton Mill Blues, Frederic Rzewskis musically rich, politically astute 1980 solo?

title: Back to The Boondocks, Minus Its Creators Touch
description: The Boondocks is back, and the less said about it the better, really. Aaron McGruder painstakingly produced three seasons of the sharply satirical animated show over the course of five years, from 2005 to 2010. He wasnt involved in the long-delayed fourth and final season, which begins Monday night on Adult Swim, and it shows. Is a mediocre Boondocks better than no Boondocks at all? Maybe. As the shows moral center, the 10-year-old black-militant ninja Huey Freeman, told the sad striver Tom DuBois when Usher stole his wife in Season 2: Could be worse. Could be Omarion.

title: They Disprove Claims
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  This was a puzzle where I had to make sense of the theme after I finished solving. That usually doesnt happen to me on Mondays but, hey, its a brand new week, and anything can happen here at Wordplay.

title: Javier Camarena in La Cenerentola
description: Javier Camarena sings Ramiros aria, Si, ritrovarla io giuro, from Act II of Rossinis opera, at the Met.

title: The Met as Mosh Pit for a Fill-In Star
description: The Metropolitan Operas production of Rossinis Cinderella story, La Cenerentola, a revival of which opens Monday, ends with the happy couple embracing atop a giant wedding cake. During a brief lull in a rehearsal last week, the Mexican tenor Javier Camarena, who plays the dashing Prince Ramiro to Joyce DiDonatos humble Angelina, mimed leaping from the cake into the mosh-pit arms of the chorus.

title: Malaysia Airlines Jet Makes Emergency Landing
description: A Malaysia Airlines flight made an emergency landing Monday morning, returning safely to Kuala Lumpur International Airport after a problem with the planes landing gear, airline officials said.

title: Brooklyn to Queens, but Not by Subway
description: Theres a wonderful term for the dirt trails that people leave behind in parks: desire lines.

title: Yankees Find Their Offense in the 12th Inning
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Late Saturday night, Dean Anna was, by his own admission, not having fun. A utility infielder, he had been asked to pitch the final inning of a blowout loss to save the pitching staff, and despite the unique situation, he did not enjoy it.

title: With Clouds Ahead, Heat Seize the Moment
description: MIAMI  Seconds before the opening tip, Dwyane Wade ambled toward one of the baselines at American Airlines Arena, turned to the crowd and raised his arms. The fans gobbled up the theatrics, a grand celebration Sunday afternoon before the Heat had played a single minute of their first-round playoff series against the Charlotte Bobcats.

title: $250,000 Grant to Finance Website Tied to PBS Series
description: The coming PBS series How We Got to Now, based loosely on Steven Johnsons book Where Good Ideas Come From, will be a history program, examining innovation and its role in creating social change, including such topics as how 18th century English coffeehouses spurred the age of enlightenment.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 53
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: The Enduring Legacy of Terri Schiavo
description: The controversy over Terri Schiavos case elevated a family matter into a political battle that continues to frame end-of-life issues today.

title: An Evolutionary Family Drama
description: OLD LYME, Conn.  WE would see amazing things if we could learn to be travelers in our own neighborhoods, Henry David Thoreau once suggested. Lately, I have come to think that this is more true than I had imagined.

title: From Private Ordeal to National Fight: The Case of Terri Schiavo
description: Her surname in Italian means slave, and is pronounced skee-AH-vo. Grim as it may be, the word could apply to Theresa Marie Schiavo, even with its Americanized pronunciation: SHY-vo. For 15 years, Terri Schiavo was effectively a slave  slave to an atrophied brain that made her a prisoner in her body, slave to bitter fighting between factions of her family, slave to seemingly endless rounds of court hearings, slave to politicians who injected themselves into her tragedy and turned her ordeal into a national morality play.

title: A Bright and Colorful Easter Sunday
description: New Yorkers across the city dressed to impress to celebrate Easter on a cheerful Sunday. Blooming trees, strollers on Fifth Avenue and Brooklyn churchgoers all looked grand under the gleaming sun.

description: KABUL, Afghanistan  With half the votes counted in the Afghan presidential race, the candidate Abdullah Abdullah widened his lead, but a runoff seemed likely between the top two contenders, according to data released Sunday by the Independent Election Commission.

title: Treasury Auctions for the Week of April 21
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: To Reduce Inequality, Start With Families
description: The French economist Thomas Piketty swept across the United States last week with a dire warning: Income inequality isnt going to go away, and it probably will get worse. Only policies that directly address the problem  in particular, progressive taxation  can help us change course.

title: The Public Health Crisis Hiding in Our Food
description: IF you have high blood pressure, youre in good company. Hypertension afflicts 67 million Americans, including nearly two-thirds of people over age 60. But it isnt an inevitable part of the aging process. Its better to think of it as chronic sodium intoxication. And, as an important new study from Britain shows, theres a way to prevent the problem  and to save many, many lives.

title: Granderson Finally Puts an End to His Otherwise Forgettable Day
description: The home crowd seemed anxious as Curtis Granderson came to bat in the bottom of the 14th, with one out and the winning run on second.

title: Bankrupt City Fighting to Open a Crack in Californias Pension Agency
description: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif.  When this bankrupt, working-class city took the unprecedented step in 2012 of stopping its required pension contributions  arguing that it could not otherwise make payroll  other financially stressed California cities took notice: Could San Bernardino defy Calpers, the powerful agency that administers the states huge pension system?

title: Many Auto Show Visitors Unfazed by G.M. Recalls
description: Louis Monetti pulled a tape measure from his back pocket and stretched it across the Chevrolet Cruzes trunk to make sure his bicycle would fit. Then he crouched for a good look at the cars rear suspension. It all seemed fine, he said on Saturday at the New York International Auto Show, adding that he probably would buy the Cruze over the Ford Fusion.

title: Surviving the Mount Everest Avalanche
description: Kaji Sherpa is a climber who survived the avalanche Friday on Mount Everest. From a hospital bed in Katmandu, he recounted the disaster that killed at least 13 Sherpas.

title: New Mayor and a New Agenda, but Little Change Within the Ranks
description: Four months into his first term, Mayor Bill de Blasio continues to stock the top echelons of his administration with senior aides and commissioners who share his desire to break sharply from the policies and tone set by Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: After Everest Disaster, Sherpas Contemplate Strike
description: NEW DELHI  The 22 Sherpas who set out together toward Mount Everests Camp 2 on Friday morning were full of joy and excitement, but Kaji Sherpa was apprehensive: They were crossing a notoriously dangerous ice field, and they were moving too slowly.

title: Sweden Turns Japanese
description: Three years ago Sweden was widely regarded as a role model in how to deal with a global crisis. The nations exports were hit hard by slumping world trade but snapped back; its well-regulated banks rode out the financial storm; its strong social insurance programs supported consumer demand; and unlike much of Europe, it still had its own currency, giving it much-needed flexibility. By mid-2010 output was surging, and unemployment was falling fast. Sweden, declared The Washington Post, was the rock star of the recovery.

title: In Silicon Valley Thriller, a Settlement May Preclude the Finale
description: SAN FRANCISCO  After years of legal skirmishes, four leading Silicon Valley companies are scheduled to go on trial next month on claims of conspiring to keep their employees down.

title: Starting in June, Today Will Simulcast on SiriusXM
description: The Today show is moving to radio  or, more exactly, expanding to radio.

title: From Behind the Plate, a Dutiful Master Orchestrates the Cardinals
description: Baseball on television is nothing like basketball and football. In those sports, the primary camera angle shows most, if not all, of the participants. In baseball, you mostly see just two of the defensive players on every pitch.

title: Sexual Abuse Lawsuits Are Expected to Expand
description: LOS ANGELES  The next round in a widening legal fight over sexual abuse accusations in Hollywood is now set for 2 p.m. on Monday. At that time, the lawyer who in a lawsuit last week accused the filmmaker Bryan Singer of drugging and raping his client in 1999 expects to announce additional lawsuits at a news conference in Beverly Hills.

title: When Wrigley Opened, Yanks Were Different. Well, Not Totally.
description: This week, as Chicagos Wrigley Field marks its 100th anniversary, Yankees fans may be wondering what their own team was like in 1914, before it become a powerhouse franchise, nine years away from its first World Series championship.

title: Errors Mounted as Chaos Ruled Capsizing Ferry
description: JINDO, South Korea  Of all the images from the loss of a ferry in the cold waters off the southwest coast of South Korea last week, perhaps none have angered South Koreans more than those of the captain and his key crew members awkwardly and quickly fleeing their half-submerged vessel to the safety of a rescue boat, even as hundreds of their passengers remained trapped inside.

title: Aereo Case Will Shape TVs Future
description: Throughout Americas business history, the victories and spoils went to the visionaries who made all manner of things  actual things like cars, pharmaceuticals and entertainment.

title: Focusing Americas Attention on Asia
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Raise the subject of President Obamas Asia policy here and an American can expect to be bombarded with questions.

title: The Next Juvenile Justice Reform
description: Research has long shown that locking up young people puts them at greater risk of dropping out of school, joining the unemployment line and becoming permanently entangled in the criminal justice system. States and municipalities have thus been sending fewer young offenders to juvenile institutions and more of them to community-based programs that keep them connected to their families and reduce the risk that they will engage in further crime. The number of children held in custody plummeted from about 107,000 in 1995 to less than 71,000 in 2010 and is still falling.

title: A Rare G.O.P. Battle Forces an Incumbent to Look Left
description: AUBURN, Calif.  A moderate Republican trying to unseat a conservative congressman from his own party, Art Moore sat a little stiffly at a Sizzler restaurant here during the monthly meeting of the Auburn Area Republican Women Federated. Appearing after the meetings agenda was already set, Mr. Moore was not invited to speak before the group  not that it would have made much of a difference.

title: Running Out of Time
description: Next year, in December, delegates from more than 190 nations will gather in Paris to take another shot at completing a new global treaty on climate change. This will be the 21st Conference of the Parties under United Nations auspices since the first summit meeting in Rio de Janeiro in 1992.

title: Teacher Says LaGuardia High School Picks Tests Over Talent
description: His grade point average was high. He was never marked absent or late to class or given detention for poor conduct in middle school.

description: TOKYO  Japans prime minister sent a ceremonial offering to a Tokyo war shrine on Monday, a move that may anger South Korea and China just two days before President Obama is to arrive in Tokyo.

description: Ukraine says these photographs show that the men who have taken over government buildings in eastern Ukraine are Russian combatants.

description: FIREBAUGH, Calif.  This summer, Todd Allens only crop will be Pima cotton.

description: Footage from the Lyndon B. Johnson Presidential Library of the Presidents Poverty Tour through the Appalachian states in 1964.

description: MOSCOW  Gas pricing wars between Russia and Ukraine, like the one breaking out now, have generally ended badly for the two countries and Gazprom, the Russian energy monopoly.

title: Hope Is Hollywood, Out of the Blue
description: The best gossip on Broadway these days is nothing you can read in the tabloids. Youll have to hear it in person, and believe me, youll want to. This is very deep dish  layered with malice and kindness, truth and conjecture, and all the mixed motives that make human beings such endlessly intriguing subjects of speculation.

title: Longing for a Facial Scar to Simply Vanish
description: When Sutton Foster appears on Broadway, shes usually boasting a sunbeam smile, flapping away in tap shoes, clowning around amiably and generally behaving like a girl determined to nail the talent competition in a beauty pageant, and maybe take home the Miss Congeniality award, too. But pep-allergic people will not need to steel themselves to see the terrific, heart-stirring revival of Violet, the musical by Jeanine Tesori and Brian Crawley that opened at the American Airlines Theater on Sunday night, starring Ms. Foster in a career-redefining performance.

description: Dear Diary:

description: Here be spoilers, and a barrel full of slave collars.

title: Magic Ebbs From Colombian Town That Informed an Authors Work
description: ARACATACA, Colombia  Beyond the cellphone stores and the motorcycles buzzing like flies in the 100-degree heat, the hometown of Gabriel Garca Mrquez still has some magic in it.

title: More Land for Thirsty Crops
description: In the last decade, California farmers have turned increasingly to high-value crops like berries and nuts, which are in great demand. But these crops generally take more water to grow, which is one factor in Californias drought.

title: A Catholic High School Abruptly Loses Its Fight to Stay Open
description: Just six months ago, Denise Catapano said, things were looking up at Bishop Ford Central Catholic High School, a 52-year-old institution known around Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, for the oversize red pagoda on its rooftop.

title: Photos Link Masked Men in East Ukraine to Russia
description: KIEV, Ukraine  For two weeks, the mysteriously well-armed, professional gunmen known as green men have seized Ukrainian government sites in town after town, igniting a brush fire of separatist unrest across eastern Ukraine. Strenuous denials from the Kremlin have closely followed each accusation by Ukrainian officials that the world was witnessing a stealthy invasion by Russian forces.

title: Flyers Backup Goalie Is Used to Facing Tough Battles
description: After having major hip surgery four years ago, Ray Emery is still tending goal at 31, perhaps only through sheer fortitude.

description: The N.B.A. and N.H.L. regular seasons wrapped up, and runners gathered for a marathon in North Korea.

title: 50 Years Into the War on Poverty, Hardship Hits Back
description: TWIN BRANCH, W.Va.  When people visit with friends and neighbors in southern West Virginia, where paved roads give way to dirt before winding steeply up wooded hollows, the talk is often of lives that never got off the ground.

title: John Shirley-Quirk, a Bass-Baritone and Specialist in Britten, Is Dead at 82
description: John Shirley-Quirk, a British chemistry teacher who almost by accident became a world-renowned bass-baritone, performing at the Metropolitan Opera and becoming known as an interpreter of Benjamin Britten, died on April 7, in Bath, England. He was 82.

title: Jeb Bushs Rush to Make Money May Be Hurdle
description: As it sought to recruit well-heeled investors, an untested and unprofitable Miami company named InnoVida brought aboard a trusted Florida figure in 2007: Jeb Bush, the former governor and the brother of a sitting president.

title: U.S. Promotes Network to Foil Digital Spying
description: SAYADA, Tunisia  This Mediterranean fishing town, with its low, whitewashed buildings and sleepy port, is an unlikely spot for an experiment in rewiring the global Internet. But residents here have a surprising level of digital savvy and sharp memories of how the Internet can be misused.

title: Doris Pilkington Garimara, Aboriginal Novelist, Dies at 76
description: In the 1930s, Australian authorities undertook a campaign to force the native Aborigines into white culture, with the hope that intermarriage would eventually eliminate their race. Mixed-race aboriginal children were taken from their families and forbidden to speak their native language.

description: April 20, 2014

title: Popular Demand
description: The largest social sites garner the most visits from mobile devices and from laptop computers and desktop PCs. Facebook, with a 59.65 percent share in March, dominated traffic from computer users, followed by You Tube (23.02 percent), Twitter (2.29), Google Plus (1.71) and Yahoo Answers (1.07).

title: Harris Goldsmith, Critic and Classical Pianist, Dies at 78
description: Harris Goldsmith, a rarity in classical music for his simultaneous careers as a professional pianist and a music critic, died on April 2 in Manhattan. He was 78.

title: Wizards Beat Bulls at Their Own Gritty Game
description: CHICAGO  The Chicago Bulls are best known for their grit. A scrappy team short on household names, the Bulls can make opponents uncomfortable with hard-nosed defense and relentless energy. Stacey King, an announcer for the team, fondly calls the Bulls a collection of heart, hustle and muscle.

title: Tribeca Film Festival: Joss Whedon Fans Get a Surprise
description: Fans who lined up for the Tribeca Film Festival premiere of the paranormal romance In Your Eyes, written by Joss Whedon and directed by Brin Hill, on Sunday night were in for a surprise after the credits rolled: They neednt have gone at all.

title: Risk of Honor Killing Hangs Over Lovers
description: Zakia and Mohammad Ali fled threats of arrest and death in Afghanistan as a result of their marriage, which crosses cultural boundaries.

title: India Election Digest: April 21
description: What you need to know on Monday about Indias elections: Residents of Punjab city see a connection between drugs and politics, the Bharatiya Janata Party backs off its campaign song, and analysts warn that its too early to count out the Indian National Congress.

title: Brooklyns Most Beloved Ice Cream Shop Creates a Special Flavor for T
description: Springs arrival in Brooklyn means longer days, cherry blossoms flowering in the Botanic Garden  and blockbuster, out-the-door lines at Ample Hills Creamery, Brian Smith and Jackie Cuscunas three-year-old artisanal ice cream shop. Warmer weather drives crowds to the Prospect Heights storefront, which may explain why the couple are debuting another, bigger location later this spring in Gowanus  complete with a party space, a roof deck and an industrial-size kitchen that will let them produce pints for retail sale. They have also just published Ample Hills Creamery: Secrets and Stories from Brooklyns Favorite Ice Cream Shop ($24.95, Stewart, Tabori & Chang) with the writer and illustrator Lauren Kaelin, a longtime employee and creator of the smart Benjameme blog.

title: Summerstage Plans Are Announced
description: SummerStage, the annual festival of free, live shows presented by the City Parks Foundation all over New York City, will offer performances of nearly every style of music  opera, hip-hop, R&B and jazz, for starters  as well as theater, film, dance and even a couple of circuses. The festival opens on June 3, with a performance by Ty Dolla Sign at Red Hook Park, in Brooklyn, and ends on Aug. 24, with a concert in Central Park by the Fania All-Stars (tickets are required for this one), part of a celebration of the 50th anniversary of Fania Records, the Latin music label, that will run through the festival.

title: Low Vitamin D in Mothers Tied to Cavities in Babies
description: Low levels of vitamin D in pregnancy are associated with the development of cavities in babies, researchers report.

title: Lifesaving Procedure With an Image Problem
description: Sandra Haber, a 65-year-old psychologist in Brooklyn, wants everyone to know how easy it is now to donate bone marrow. Hers was failing.

description: conifer\k-n-fr also ko-\ noun

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday April 21, 2014
description: Its hard to fathom that groups of armed men in masks suddenly sprang forward from the population in eastern Ukraine and systematically began to occupy government facilities. Its hard to fathom because its simply not true.

title: Afghan Newlyweds, Facing Threats, Find Brief Respite in Mountains
description: HINDU KUSH RANGE, Afghanistan  They eloped from their village in the Bamian Valley on the first day of spring, but their month on the run has taken them back into winter as they fled higher into these rugged mountains in central Afghanistan. They stayed in the homes of friends when they could, and they slept rough in caves when they could not.

title: Whats on Monday
description: 3 P.M. (FX Movie Channel) HEREAFTER (2010) Clint Eastwood imagines what happens after people die by braiding together three story lines, each involving a collision between the living and the dead. In San Francisco, George Lonegan (Matt Damon, above), who receives messages from the deceased loved ones of anyone he touches, chooses a life of obscurity instead of exploiting his gift. In London, a solemn boy named Marcus feels the presence of his twin, Jason, whose violent death has left him adrift. (The brothers are played by George and Frankie McLaren.) And in Paris, Marie Lelay (Ccile de France), who nearly died in the 2004 tsunami in South Asia, is convinced that she has seen a metaphysical reality the world is determined to ignore. Persuasion is not really the point, though if anyone could make me believe in ghosts, it would be Clint Eastwood, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times of this film, written by Peter Morgan. He added: What does seem new  newly strange, newly beautiful  is what Hereafter makes of the here and now. It is a curious movie in both senses of the word: an unusual experience and an open-ended inquiry into something nobody can really claim to understand. It leaves you wondering, which may be the most fitting way of saying that its wonderful.

title: Times Minute | Boston Marathon Takes Off
description: Also on the Minute, a tribute to the boxing champion Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and the story of a modern-day Romeo and Juliet from Afghanistan.

title: MoMAs Expansion and Director Draw Critics
description: Glenn D. Lowry, who will soon begin his 20th year running the Museum of Modern Art, has a longstanding practice of taking time each week to visit artists studios. Which is why he could be found one recent morning along the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn, watching the glass-blowing sculptor Josiah McElheny and assistants fashion a vessel from molten lumps, a process almost Elizabethan in its rituals.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Monday and Tuesday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Tailoring Success
description: The luxury clothing company Kiton, based outside Naples, Italy, has made its name synonymous with craftsmanship and attention to its clients.

title: Naples, a Haven of Hand Work
description: NAPLES, Italy  In a basement room on a street where motor bikes and honking horns drown out even the insistent church bells, Davide Tofani is working on a typical Neapolitan soft jacket. When I make a suit, it is like shaping a second skin of my customer, the tailor says. I cannot imagine making a suit without knowing the body that will use it.

title: Arrests of 4 More Crew Members Sought in Korean Ferry Sinking
description: JINDO, South Korea  Prosecutors sought to arrest four more crew members on Monday from the South Korean ferry that sank last week as they raced to unravel the mysteries surrounding the sinking, which left more than 300 people dead or missing in one of the countrys worst peacetime disasters.

title: China Southern Pays U.S. Fine Over Monkey Cargo
description: China Southern Airlines, a major state-owned carrier that in March announced it would no longer transport monkeys to laboratories in the United States, has agreed to pay a fine for violating an American animal welfare law, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.

title: Assault by City Management Officers Triggers Clash
description: Urban enforcement officers clashed with residents in a town in eastern China, the latest in a long series of violent interactions between the officers, known as chengguan, and the street peddlers they are tasked with regulating and bystanders who can be caught up in the disputes.

title: 6 Qs About the News | A Look Back at the Worlds Fair of 1964
description: In Around the Unisphere at the Worlds Fair, Lives Changed, Liz Robbins writes about the Worlds Fair of 1964 that took place in New York City.

title: An Indian From India Photographs Both
description: It gets complicated when people ask Annu Palakunnathu Matthew where shes from. Born in London, raised in India and now living in the United States, her journey is twisty, her accent a hard-to-place blend.

title: Activist for Getting More Saudi Women Into the Work Force Plans Book
description: When Reem Asaad started what would become a successful campaign to require Saudi lingerie shops to hire female workers, she had no idea how it would turn out.

title: Should Society Support Artists and Others Pursuing Creative Works?
description: Artists need time to do their creative work, but they also have to earn money to live.

title: Bankers in Hong Kong Join Fight Against Mainland Influence
description: HONG KONG  In this city awash with money from mainland China, a former hedge fund manager hopes to incite a political awakening among the bankers, stockbrokers and financial traders whose livelihoods have become increasingly enmeshed in the mainlands cash and influence.

title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: New York Today: The Mayors Bumpy Ride
description: Good morning on this cool but warming Monday.

title: China to Allow the Blind to Take College Entrance Exams
description: Chinas Education Ministry has told its staff to provide more humane service in this years university entrance examinations, or gaokao, and allow disabled people, particularly the blind, to take part. Advocates said this was the first time that the state had clearly spelled out that the blind could take the regular university examination, and how.

title: A Ray of Literary Hope on Italian TV
description: MILAN  Last November, I found myself in a glass elevator speeding to the top of the Mole Antonelliana tower in Turin. I wasnt there for the view: I had exactly 59 seconds to persuade Antonio Pennacchi, one of Italys most important writers, to read my novel. Even more nerve-racking: My elevator pitch was live on camera.

title: For Boston, a New Beginning After a Safe Ending to Its Marathon
description: BOSTON  When the digital clocks along Boylston Street flashed 2:49 on Marathon Monday, nothing out of the ordinary happened. And that was reason for joyous celebration.

title: Analysts Share High Expectations for Bigger iPhones
description: Many consumers have developed an appetite for smartphones with larger screens, and expectations are growing that Apple will try to satisfy them this year.

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | April 21, 2014
description: Update: April 22

title: Editorials, From Start to Finish
description: Before I started working at The New York Times, I hadnt spent much time pondering the question of how editorials came into the world. For all I knew they were delivered by stork. Roughly two years ago I was hired to start a blog for the editorial page, called Taking Note, and more recently Ive started writing editorials as well. So I can now demystify the process. Storks have no involvement and, contrary to what some people on Twitter believe, neither does the Democratic National Committee.Editorials represent the opinion of The Times (unlike Op-Ed essays, which are written by outside contributors who represent their own opinions, and not that of the paper).

title: Daily Report: Silicon Valley Giants Seek to Resolve Suit on Hiring Practices
description: After years of legal skirmishes, four leading Silicon Valley companies are scheduled to go on trial next month on claims of conspiring to keep their employees down, David Streitfeld reports.

title: 1904: The Easter supplement
description: Between 1898 and 1904, the New York Herald published Easter supplements. The supplements included short stories by famous writers, colorful illustrations, culture guides, and advertisements for luxury hotels or the latest fashion boutiques. Here is the cover of the 1904 Easter supplement.

title: Airbnbs Huge Valuation
description: Airbnb is said to have closed a $475 million round of financing from a group led by TPG Growth that values the home-sharing company at about $10 billion, Michael J. de la Merced writes in DealBook. At the value assigned by the investment, Airbnb  a website and app where homeowners and apartment dwellers rent their homes, spare rooms or couches to travelers  would be worth more than some established hotel chains like Wyndham Worldwide or Hyatt.

title: Russia Accuses Kiev of Flouting Ukraine Accord
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  Russias foreign minister accused the interim authorities in Kiev on Monday of flagrantly violating the international accord reached last week aimed at defusing the crisis in eastern Ukraine, in remarks that suggested Russia may be further preparing the groundwork for a military intervention.

title: Class, Oligarchy, and the Limits of Cynicism
description: A recent paper (pdf) by Martin Gilens and Benjamin Page is getting a lot of attention, and deservedly so. Gilens and Page look at a number of issues over the past 30+ years where polling data let us identify public policy preferences, which can be compared with elite and interest-group preferences. And what they find is that politicians dont seem to care very much about what the public thinks: when elite preferences and popular preferences are different, the elite almost always wins.

title: In Dutch Doubles, 4 Choreographers, Inspired by 4 Artists
description: AMSTERDAM  Like most big ballet companies today, the Dutch National Ballet has to carefully tiptoe between conservation and innovation  presenting works that signal classical ballet to audiences (Swan Lake!), and commissioning new pieces that say we are relevant to contemporary culture. Ted Brandsen, who has been directing the company since 2003, has been particularly proactive about new work, with a keen eye for talented dance makers. In a new program, Dutch Doubles, which opened last week at the Het Muziektheater, he adroitly combines tutus, Mozart and Beethoven, as well as high-profile collaborations with modern artists and designers.

title: Rotating a Smartphone Video
description: Q. My son sends me videos of my grandson taken with a cellphone, but the ones he films in portrait mode play back in landscape mode in Windows Media Player on my Windows 7 computer. Is there a way to rotate them?

title: Barclays Said to Join Commodity Exodus
description: Investment banks, which rushed into the new territory of physical commodities starting at the turn of the century, are now beating a retreat.

title: Bookshelf | In Architecture, Small is Big
description: In architecture as in so much of life, bigger often seems better. Yet these days, contemporary architects  and their clients  are under stricter than ever budgetary, environmental and aesthetic constraints. As the editor and critic Philip Jodidio writes in his introduction to Taschens new book, Small Architecture Now! ($60), small buildings often provide a degree of freedom to architects that cannot be obtained in gigantic public or corporate projects.

title: U.A.W. Drops Appeal of VW Vote in Tennessee
description: The United Automobile Workers union unexpectedly announced on Monday that it was dropping its effort to have a new unionization vote ordered at the Volkswagen plant in Chattanooga, Tenn.

title: Mumbais Business Community Tries New Enterprise: Politics
description: MUMBAI  At Priyadarshini Park in the Malabar Hill neighborhood of south Mumbai, under the shade of neatly aligned coconut trees, a platoon of middle-aged stock brokers discussed the volatility of the Indian stock markets as they went on their regular power walk along the frothy shoreline of the Arabian Sea.

title: Chinese Court Orders Seizure of Japanese Vessel
description: A court in Shanghai has ordered the seizure of a Japanese ship over legal claims dating to before World War II, adding a point of contention to the sometimes rancorous relationship between Japan and China.

title: Assessing the Impact of a Profit-Sharing Plan
description: In August, I wrote a series of posts about the design and implementation of a profit-sharing plan for my business. I decided to try this because my company has a long history of producing poor (or no) profits.

title: Oh, the Stories Wrigley Field Could Tell
description: When the ballpark that became Wrigley Field opened in Chicago in 1914, it soon hinted at the checkered baseball history made there in the next 100 years.

title: Wrigley Field Turns 100
description: Despite the teams disappointing record, the century-old home of the Chicago Cubs continues to draw fans.

title: Justice Stevens Suggests Solution for Giant Step in the Wrong Direction
description: WASHINGTON  Justice John Paul Stevens, who turned 94 on Sunday, is a mild man with an even temperament. He has a reverence for the Supreme Court, on which he served for almost 35 years until his retirement in 2010, and he is fond of his former colleagues.

title: Manchester Uniteds Moyes Is Out, According to Reports
description: David Moyes was supposed to be the long-term successor to Alex Ferguson at Manchester United, one veteran Scottish manager passing control to his handpicked heir last May. But after a calamitous season that sees United heading toward its worst finish in the Premier League, it now appears that Moyes will not even last until this summer.

title: Knicks Fire Mike Woodson as Coach
description: Mike Woodson was 109-79 in his two-plus seasons as the Knicks coach. His regular-season winning percentage of .580 is the third highest in franchise history. Still, it was no surprise Monday when the Knicks announced that he had been dismissed, less than a week after he and the team finished the 2013-14 season with a hugely disappointing 37-45 record that left them out of the playoffs.

title: K.K.R.s Acquisition of an Affiliate Encounters Opposition
description: A plan by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts to acquire an affiliate has encountered opposition from a group that advises investors.

title: U.S. Ordered to Release Memo in Awlaki Killing
description: A federal appeals panel in Manhattan ordered the release on Monday of key portions of a classified Justice Department memorandum that provided the legal justification for the targeted killing of a United States citizen, Anwar al-Awlaki, who intelligence officials contend had joined Al Qaeda and died in a 2011 drone strike in Yemen.

title: In Our Pages: April 22
description: 1889: American Art to Show in Paris

title: Another Coach Spun Out the Gardens Revolving Door
description: The Knicks have fired another coach, and to this we may all shrug and say, What else is new?

title: Rockets Fired From Gaza Draw Airstrikes From Israel
description: JERUSALEM  Seven rockets fired from the Gaza Strip landed in southern Israel on Monday morning, prompting Israeli airstrikes that hit at least one training site of Hamas, the militant Palestinian faction that rules Gaza.

title: Quiche With Red Peppers and Spinach
description: The real spring vegetable here is the spinach, lush and beautiful at this time of year. You can always get red peppers in a supermarket, and when you cook them for a while, as you do here, even the dullest will taste sweet. I make the pepper mixture first, then wilt the spinach in the same pan and line the tart shell with the savory mix. If you can, make the pepper and spinach filling a day ahead. It dries out a little if it sits overnight in the refrigerator and is less likely to dilute the custard.

title: Roasted Asparagus and Scallion Quiche
description: Ive made many a spring quiche filled with asparagus and herbs, yet Id never thought about roasting the asparagus instead of steaming it. But lately Ive been buying thick stalks of asparagus, and all I want to do is roast it; roasting intensifies the flavor and the stalks become incredibly succulent, more so than when the asparagus is steamed. This quality isnt lost even when the sliced stalks are hidden inside a quiche.

title: Cabbage and Spring Onion Quiche With Caraway
description: Spring onions found their way into several of this weeks quiches. For this one, I cooked the onions with cabbage  even a half a head of cabbage that has been lingering in your refrigerator will work here  until both vegetables were soft, lightly colored and sweet. I added caraway seeds to the mix because I love the flavor of caraway with cabbage. I used 1/2 teaspoon, just enough so that people noticed; they couldnt recognize what it was (Cumin? they asked) right away, but they liked it. I made the filling a day ahead and let it sit uncovered overnight in the refrigerator.

title: Scallion and Celery Quiche
description: Ive written before that I consider celery an underrated vegetable, capable of contributing nuance and texture to a dish. But it would have never occurred to me to have it as one of the main vegetables in a quiche if I hadnt heard the restaurant critic Jonathan Gold discussing a tarte au cleri that hed had at Church & State in downtown Los Angeles, a sort of tarte flambe in which celery, celery root and apples stood in for the traditional onions and bacon. I figured if it worked so well in that dish, it could also in a quiche. It does.

title: Whole-Wheat Pie Dough
description: Most of the vegetable tarts that I post on Recipes for Health call for a yeasted olive oil crust that I love to work with. With French quiches, however, I prefer a crust that resembles classic French pastry. However, I always use at least half whole-wheat flour  which is not so French  not only for its nutritional superiority, but also because it gives the resulting shell a nuttier, richer flavor that is particularly welcome in a savory tart. This dough, adapted from Jacquy Pfeiffers recipe for pte brise in The Art of French Pastry, involves more butter than youre used to seeing in my recipes, but an occasional butter-based crust, especially when its made with whole-wheat flour and contains a filling that is all about vegetables, is not going to kill us. Instead, its a vehicle for the foods that we want to move toward the center of our plates.

title: Justices Take Case on Status of Jerusalem in Passports
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to decide whether Congress may require the State Department to treat Jerusalem as the capital of Israel in American passports, in a case that touches on generations of conflict in the Middle East, as well as the dueling roles of Congress and the president in the conduct of foreign affairs.

title: Mad Men Recap:  The (Madison Avenue) Gods Must Be Crazy
description: Season 7, Episode 2

title: No Time For Sargent
description: Im a little late to this, but theres lately been some buzz about the unearthing of Tom Sargents 2007 graduation speech, in which he briefly laid out 12 principles of economics. For the most part the speech is getting favorable attention. So let me be a spoilsport. Its not so much that what Sargent said is wrong, although some of his principles are by no means universally agreed upon, even in normal times. Whats so striking about Sargents points is that its hard to think of a worse time to cite them. And the people citing that old speech clearly have ulterior motives.

title: Food Curated: Brooklyn Bouillon
description: Rachael Mamane thought she could generate extra income for farmers who raise animals by creating a line of stocks from discarded bones. Brooklyn Bouillon was born from the idea.

title: Video: Brooklyn Bouillon
description: A few years ago, when Rachael Mamane was working for the greenmarkets in New York City, she noticed that none of the farm stands offered high-quality stock to home cooks on a consistent basis. She had the idea to help farmers who raise animals to generate extra income by creating a line of stocks from their waste, like discarded bones. It was an opportunity no one else had seized.

title: Listen Up | Newcomer King Avriel Makes Neo-Soul That Doesnt Shy Away From Big Ideas
description: I have a really short attention span, says Avriel Epps. Im always trying to get to the next thing, and thats how I feel about music, too. The only thing thats going to stay consistent  is the depth of my message.The singer, who goes by the gender-bending moniker King Avriel, has only released a few songs so far, all for free via her Soundcloud account. But she has already garnered attention for her use of sultry electro production to explore big themes like gender inequality and consumerism.

title: A New Zealand Trail Is Open for Cyclists
description: New Zealands Heaphy Track, the longest of the countrys nine famed Great Walks, is now open to cyclists.

title: Tribeca Film Festival:  Students Get a Starring Role in Times Square
description: At 11:57 each night this month, 40 electronic billboards in Times Square simultaneously spring to life with what, at first glance, might be mistaken for a shoe commercial. Six teenagers pull on Nikes, Uggs, lace-up boots and brogues in neighborhoods from Bushwick to Tribeca, then set off on the subway  destination: Washington Square Park  eventually converging with friends in a group hug.

title: Toronto Gets an Art Fair With a Name Change
description: The newest offshoot of the Affordable Art Fair, a franchise that originated in London in 1999 and has generated multiple offspring around the world, is coming to Toronto in May. After opening with a private preview on May 7, at the Direct Energy Center, it runs for the next four days.

title: Brain, Teen: Brain, Child Magazine Devotes an Issue to Parents of Teenagers
description: The single, No. 1 request from readers of this blog is more about teenagers, please. That vexing subset of children is also the most challenging for parents to write about, from a personal perspective: that toddler who was quite cheery about having her foibles unmasked for readers can quickly become a teenager highly protective of even the smallest of online mentions. Advice and more distant commentary is far easier to come by than essays from parents truly in the trenches.

title: Tricky Dice
description: Our puzzle this week is about a tricky kind of relationship  one thats a bit counterintuitive. Normally, when we compare several things, we expect something like the following: your friend Agnes weighs more than Beatrice, and Beatrice weighs more than Clarissa, then wed expect Agnes to outweigh Clarissa. This makes sense. This kind of relationship would also work for heights, ages, and other single-dimension measures. This also works for containers: a dime is in a small pouch in Clarissas purse, so the dime is in the purse.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Jo Becker on Reporting the Fight for Marriage Equality
Tributes to Avalanche Victims in Nepal
description: Family, friends and climbers gathered in Katmandu, Nepal, to pay respect to the Sherpas killed in an avalanche on Mount Everest.

title: Boston Marathon Day
description: Scenes from the Boston Marathon on Monday, a year after two bombs exploded near the finish line.

title: Elizabeth Spencer Wins Rea Award
description: Elizabeth Spencer, whose body of work includes The Light in the Piazza (1960), has been awarded the 2013 Rea Award for short fiction.

title: Times Minute | Tech Earnings Preview
description: Apple, Microsoft and Amazon will issue quarterly reports this week. Also on the Minute, the effect of Californias water crisis and celebrating 100 years of Wrigley Field.

title: Counting Death in the Movies
description: In last weeks Riff, Alexander Huls bemoans the death of death in Hollywood films. Of course action films have saccharine subplots that exist only to lend meaning to their staggering body counts, he writes. But in recent years, killing a major character in your average blockbuster has become inert thanks to the increasing use of formulas to create stakes.

title: Times Minute | Tech Earnings Preview
description: In the Video

title: A Year Later, Its Old Glory in Boston Marathon
description: BOSTON  Something unusual happened when Meb Keflezighi, far ahead of his competitors, began passing some of the elite women who had started before the men on Monday in the Boston Marathon. As he charged by, many of the women  exhausted and in pain  cheered him on.

title: Lawmakers Broadening Their Focus to Fight Against an Array of Sex Crimes
description: WASHINGTON  As the high-profile congressional fight over military sexual assault recedes, lawmakers are broadening their focus to an array of sex crimes like college campus assaults, preying on child and human trafficking.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Allscope Direct was opened by Allscope Media, New York, and Joe Shain, a longtime direct response marketing executive, who will be chief executive of Allscope Direct.

title: Interpublic Group Joins Ranks of Publishers With Report in Magazine Form
description: Who says print is dead? Not the Interpublic Group of Companies, one of the worlds largest agency holding groups, which is publishing its corporate citizenship report, called Stronger, in magazine form in addition to a digital version available online.

title: Image of the Day: April 21
Today in Small Business: What Start-Up Founders Pay Themselves
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Waiting, Hoping and Coming Unraveled
description: Do you want to do a retrieval? my doctor asked.

title: A Controlling Light Inside the Brain, Diet Doesnt Matter to Cancer
description:
Optogenetics allows the use of light to switch specific brain activity on and off so what does that tell us? A new look at the effect of nutrition on cancer suggests theres not much effect at all.
Subscribe to the Podcast

title: Syrian Election Announced; Rebels Report New Weapons
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Although more than a third of Syrias population has been displaced by war, the government said Monday that it would conduct a presidential election on June 3, an announcement denounced by the opposition as absurd and criticized by the United Nations as a new subversion of peace efforts.

title: Spurning Merger Approaches, AstraZeneca Pursues Own Path
description: The British drug company AstraZeneca said no to a tie-up with Pfizer, turning down the possibility of one of the biggest drug mergers in recent history.

title: InBloom Student Data Repository to Close
description: In a setback for the nearly $8 billion prekindergarten through 12th-grade education technology software market, inBloom, a non-profit corporation offering to warehouse and manage student data for public school districts across the country, announced on Monday morning that it planned to shut its doors.

title: Brain Control in a Flash of Light
description: SAN DIEGO  Dr. Karl Deisseroth is having a very early breakfast before the day gets going at the annual meeting of the Society for Neuroscience. Thirty thousand people who study the brain are here at the Convention Center, a small citys worth of badge-wearing, networking, lecture-attending scientists.

title: Group Led by TPG to Buy Health Care Company for $461 Million
description: A United States health care company that does business in China has agreed to be sold to a group of investors for $461 million after the investors raised their bid in the face of a rival offer.

title: Birth Control at 7-Eleven
description: There was something illuminating about Cardinal Timothy Dolans obtuse remarks on the so-called birth-control mandate.

title: Washington Company Cancels Russian Theater Festival
description: Citing a rise of anti-American sentiment and a yanking of Russian funds, the Woolly Mammoth Theater Company of Washington has canceled a festival of experimental plays from Moscow that were set to run this fall as part of the companys 35th anniversary season.

title: Behind the Poster: Gidions Knot
description: The suicide of a young boy named Gidion pits mother against teacher in Johnna Adamss dark drama Gidions Knot. Set inside a primary school classroom, the play unfolds in real-time as the two women discuss the boys suspension and other events in the hours before he shot himself to death. The conversation turns into an emotionally fraught confrontation that tackles the issues of parental responsibility, youth violence and schoolyard bullying, with a strange detour into the world of medieval poetry.

title: Fortress of Solitude Musical Among Highlights of New Public Theater Lineup
description: A new musical based on Jonathan Lethems acclaimed novel The Fortress of Solitude, as well as another new musical by the creators of the Tony Award-winning show Passing Strange, are among the productions in the Public Theaters 2014-15 season line-up that the theater announced on Monday.

title: 2 Executions in Oklahoma Are Stayed, Ending Tussle
description: The Oklahoma Supreme Court stayed the imminent executions of two murderers late Monday, ending a Kafkaesque legal showdown in which courts argued over jurisdiction even though the prisoners had successfully challenged the legality of the states secrecy in obtaining lethal drugs.

title: How a Song Written by Sia Furler Becomes a Hit
description: Last weekends magazine featured Steve Knoppers profile of Sia Furler, who has written songs for artists like Beyonc, Christina Aguilera and Flo Rida. Below, Knopper shares some of Furlers stories about her experiences writing what would become hits for some boldface names in pop music.

title: Holiday Weekend Gun Report: April 18-20, 2014
description: On Friday, 27-year-old Mohammed Whitaker was charged with 18 felony counts in connection with a dozen shootings that wounded three people on highways in the Kansas City, Mo., area in the past month. Police said more than 100 tips from victims and witnesses poured in, and the suspect had been under surveillance since April 11. They did not reveal a motive.

title: Ivan Orkins Ramen Restaurant to Open on the Lower East Side
description: Occasionally a chef will do a pop-up in a borrowed kitchen to preview a new restaurant. But Ivan Orkin, the first American chef to open his own ramen shop in Tokyo, has had months of trial runs with his more casual Slurp Shop in the Gotham West Market. It wasnt supposed to happen like that, he said as he was showing off his nearly finished Lower East Side restaurant, called Ivan Ramen. This place was supposed to come first and the Slurp Shop would be the spinoff.

title: Russian Says Ukraine Violated Accord
description: Russias foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, accused Ukraine of violating the Geneva agreement and said pro-Russian civilians were asking to be saved.

title: Monday Motorsports: Hamilton Picks Up a Prize, Prematurely
description: Lewis Hamilton, driving for Mercedes AMG, held on to beat his teammate, Nico Rosberg, in Sundays Chinese Grand Prix. The win came despite an error by the flagman, who waved the checkered flag a lap early.

title: Obama Names White House Counsel
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama announced Monday that he was naming W. Neil Eggleston, a veteran lawyer with extensive experience representing government officials in congressional and criminal investigations, as his next White House counsel.

title: Magic in Service of Truth
description: Gabo lives. The extraordinary worldwide attention paid to the death of Gabriel Garca Mrquez, and the genuine sorrow felt by readers everywhere at his passing, tells us that the books are still very much alive. Somewhere a dictatorial patriarch is still having his rival cooked and served up to his dinner guests on a great dish; an old colonel is waiting for a letter that never comes; a beautiful young girl is being prostituted by her heartless grandmother; and a kindlier patriarch, Jos Arcadio Buenda, one of the founders of the new settlement of Macondo, a man interested in science and alchemy, is declaring to his horrified wife that the earth is round, like an orange.

title: A Wine Critics Realm Isnt a Democracy
description: Heady discussions about the role of the wine critic may strike many people as navel gazing. Yet one issue has bubbled up on social media and blogs repeatedly in the last few months: Should wine critics allow their personal preferences to color their critical views? Or should they remain neutral on questions regarding a wines style, regardless of how they feel about it?

title: Interview: Chris Messina on Alex of Venice
description: This was one of a series of posts on debuts that originally ran during the 2014 Tribeca Film Festival.

title: Should Supreme Court Justices Play Politics With Retirement?
description: Former Supreme Court Justice John Paul Stevens new book  Six Amendments: How and Why We Should Change the Constitution  comes out tomorrow, and has been getting as much attention as you might expect for a book by a former justice calling for multiple controversial constitutional fixes.

title: White House Easter Egg Roll Kicks Off
description: President Obama and the first lady, Michelle Obama, hosted the annual Easter Egg Roll on the South Lawn of the White House.

title: Planning a Trip Thats Socially Acceptable
description: Two new travel apps are harnessing the power of Facebook to help friends spend some time together.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 52
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Ambulances Were Dispatched Late to Fatal Fire in Queens, Official Says
description: The New York City fire commissioner said on Monday that ambulances were dispatched later than they should have been to a Queens fire that killed two 4-year-old children and injured three other people late Saturday night.

title: Capn Crunch Is Looking at You
Weekly News Quiz | April 8-21, 2014
description: An avalanche disaster, a novelists death, an Internet bug and a late-night successor: How many of our questions about the news of the last two weeks can you answer correctly?

title: Banking Troubles, but Not a Word About Fraud Claims
description: Reading The Timess coverage of Bank of Americas quarterly loss last week, I almost felt sorry for the financial behemoth. It has mortgage troubles, you see. It has onerous legal costs.

title: Be Wary of a Big Mining Merger
description: Barrick Golds interest in a $33 billion merger with Newmont Mining deserves a skeptical eye.

title: With Planning Out of the Way, Time to Enjoy the Moment
description: When we think of financial planning, we naturally focus on the future. We start by getting really clear about where we are today, then we spend time thinking about where we want to be 10, 20 or even 30 years from now. Part of the process includes deciding how much well want to spend, when well want to spend it and how much we can save. Someone has to decide when the plan will end, too, and estimate a year of death, perhaps for two people.

title: Attackers Said to Single Out South Sudanese by Background
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Hundreds of civilians were killed when South Sudanese rebels took control of a strategic oil-producing town last week, the United Nations confirmed on Monday.

title: Bucket List Item: White House Easter Egg Roll
description: WASHINGTON  Everly Deml could barely sit still atop her fathers shoulders, her tiny pink shoes bouncing against his chest. President Obama and Michelle Obama had just arrived for the 136th annual White House Easter Egg Roll, but Everly, 2, was angling for a better view of a six-foot-tall Easter bunny on the South Lawn.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Unequal Schooling
description: To the Editor:

title: For These Females, No Such Thing as Penis Envy
description: A Brazilian cave insect has done a most unusual sex-role reversal, a new study finds: Females have penises, and males have vaginas.

title: Chimps Are Particular About Where They Rest
description: Chimpanzees select firm, resilient wood to make their daily beds in trees, according to a new study in PLOS One. The researchers found that wild chimps at theToro-Semliki Wildlife Reserve in Uganda used Cynometra alexandri, or Ugandan ironwood, in 73.6 percent of their nests, even though it constituted only 9.6 percent of trees in the study area.Weaving a bed from high-quality wood allows the chimps to safely rest in a prone position. Above, an adult chimp in a C. alexandri tree.

title: Reactions
description: Conservation

title: Guidance on Cleaning Mushrooms
description: Q. It is often hard to wash off the growing medium from store-bought mushrooms. Is it safe to eat? Should the stems be further trimmed?

title: Indie Fashion Icons Jennifer Mankins and Jane Mayle on the Evolution of N.Y.C. Style
description: Have I made your life crazy? the retailer Jennifer Mankins asks the British-born fashion designer Jane Mayle as she greets her in the lounge of New Yorks Marlton Hotel. The two have come together on the occasion of the 15th anniversary of Mankinss Bird, the chain of Brooklyn boutiques that helped popularize a style of easygoing bohemian chic now worn by women in every cool neighborhood in America.

title: Pictures of the Day: South Korea and Elsewhere
description: Photos from South Korea, Nepal, Kent and the Netherlands.

title: New Painkiller Rekindles Addiction Concerns
description: The abuse of prescription painkillers has reached epidemic proportions in America.

title: The Trail of Tears, and of Damaged Skulls
description: Evicted from their Southeastern homeland by the federal government in the 1830s, Native Americans were sent on forced marches to eastern Oklahoma that became known as the Trail of Tears, an ordeal of disease, starvation and death. Now a study of Cherokee remains suggests that the stress interfered with the normal growth of their skulls.

title: Running the Marathon
description: John Eligon of The Times at the starting line of the Boston Marathon on Monday morning.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: The Economy is Not Like a Household
description: I dashed off my Sargent comment in the few minutes before class, which meant that it was longer and more complicated than it should have been. So I want to come back to what I think is the most important point. In his speech, Sargent went right away to this:

title: Growing Sales for Beautiful and Rocky on Broadway
description: The new Broadway musicals Beautiful and Rocky grossed more than $1 million for the first time last week, with the producers of Beautiful even sending out a news release on Monday to crow about the box office tally  at a time when Beautiful and other shows are trying to show signs of momentum heading into this years Tony Awards races. The competition for the best musical Tony is wide open for the first time in years, and four or five nominations for the award will be announced on April 29.

title: In Performance: Julia Bullock
description: Julia Bullock, a rising soprano from Juilliard, sings Cancin de Cuna Para Dormir a un Negrito. She is accompanied by the pianist Renate Rohlfing.

title: An Abridged Version of an Age-Old Story, With a Supper (but Gluten-Free)
description: If Ed Sylvanus Iskandar had found himself in the Garden of Eden, he would surely have eaten the forbidden fruit  then made pies from the rest of the apples and served them to all comers. Having distilled the complete works of Sophocles into a single evening of theater (These Seven Sicknesses), this ambitious, savvy young director has now commissioned more than 40 playwrights to condense the Old and New Testaments into The Mysteries, a five-and-a-half-hour event at the Flea Theater that is both gratifying and grueling.

title: Ackman and Valeant Prepare Unusual Hostile Bid for Maker of Botox
description: Updated, 9:12 p.m. | Activist investors are exerting ever more influence on corporate America, pressing companies to cut costs, replace executives and strike deals. On Monday, William A. Ackman, among the brashest men on Wall Street, made perhaps the boldest move yet for an activist.

title: HBO Renews Silicon Valley and Veep
description: HBO continues to celebrate a potent Sunday night, using another week of solid ratings to lock in, for at least another season, the three-show lineup that has become among the best received in that networks history.

title: The Lure of Forbidden Food
description: How hard will your child work for food?

title: Claudia Rankine Wins $50,000 Poetry Prize
description: Claudia Rankine has been named the eighth winner of the $50,000 Jackson Poetry Prize. The award, run by the nonprofit organization Poets & Writers, is given annually to an American poet of exceptional talent who deserves wider recognition.

title: Media Previews in Beijing Feature Many Debuts From Global Automakers
description: Auto China, held every two years in Beijing to showcase new models directed at the growing Chinese market, opened Sunday in Beijing with a media preview that featured a surprisingly robust display of debutantes from Chinese, European and American automakers.
