title: How Valeant Can Raise Its Bid for Botox Maker
description: Valeant Pharmaceuticals has plenty of room to raise its bid for Allergan.

title: Answers on Affirmative Action Depend on How You Pose the Question
description: Polling about affirmative action and racial issues is inherently difficult, and responses differ rather widely based on question wording.

title: Caesars Making Bid for Casino in Upstate New York
description: For more than two years, the major Las Vegas gambling companies have resisted Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos call to consider building a casino resort in New York to help him revive an upstate economy wracked by unemployment and declining opportunities.

title: Paul Takes His School-Choice Message to Chicago
description: CHICAGO  Senator Rand Paul on Tuesday brought his vision for education reform to Josephinum Academy, a small all-girls Catholic high school here. And true to form, he made no attempt to mask his libertarian brand of politics, even in President Obamas adopted hometown.

title: Clippers See Griffins Growth
description: LOS ANGELES  Before the you-gotta-see-this dunks, before the droll television commercials and before Blake Griffin realized what basketball might bring to a child from the Oklahoma City suburbs, he viewed the sport as an almost academic exercise.

title: Piketty, Doom Loops and Haymarket
description: My Sunday column, on Thomas Pikettys revival of the old argument that capitalism tends to enrich the capital-rich Few much, much faster than the laboring Many, didnt take a position on the plausibility of the French economists basic forecast, which foresees upper-tail inequality rising forever absent a sustained political disruption. (For a more qualified observers critique of that forecast, Tyler Cowens review and follow-up are the place to turn.) Instead, I argued against the view that such a trend would necessarily lead to such political disruptions, or indeed be particularly destabilizing to the developed worlds societies. So long as a rich countrys Many see some real gains, I suggested, whether through modest growth and/or modestly-increasing redistribution, we arent likely to see anything remotely like the kind of literal class warfare that the last gilded age produced.

title: The Broadband Revolution Is Not Nigh
description: Is America on the cusp of a broadband revolution? You might get that impression from AT&Ts announcement on Monday that it is considering providing Internet service of up to 1 gigabit, or 1 billion bits, a second to 21 metropolitan areas including Atlanta, Chicago, Los Angeles and San Francisco.

title: Five Great New York Breads
description: The Dining section tasted 20 assorted loaves from recently opened bakeries to find five you should put on your table.

title: How An Exuberant 80s Designer Shaped Fashion Today
description: The life and career of the designer Patrick Kelly were as brief as they were brilliant. A singular force in the 1980s fashion scene known for his jarringly bright and playful clothes, Kelly passed away on the first day of 1990 at 35 due to complications from AIDS.This weekend, the Philadelphia Museum of Art opens Patrick Kelly: Runway of Love (on view through November 30), the first retrospective of the designers prolific output since the Brooklyn Museums 2004 exhibition of his works. The show brings together eighty complete looks from his ten collections produced between 1985 and 1990, gifted to the museum by the late designers partner in business and life, Bjorn Guil Amelan, and Amelans current partner, the choreographer Bill T. Jones.

title: Three Recipes to Savor to the Last Crumb
description: White Slices, Rich and Moist, Sporting a Milk-Sweet Crust

title: Abbas Renews Threat to Dissolve Palestinian Authority if Peace Talks Fail
description: JERUSALEM  Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Palestinian Authority, issued a renewed warning on Tuesday that if the American-sponsored Middle East peace talks fail, he may dissolve the authority and hand sole responsibility for the West Bank back to Israel.

title: Abbas Renews Warning to Israel on Talks
description: Mahmoud Abbas, president of the Palestinian Authority, renewed warnings that Israel would have to take on the responsibility of governing Palestinian lands if peace talks did not continue.

title: Everybody Is Playing Somebody Else Here
description: Perhaps James Franco should just stick to acting. He remains embarrassingly clueless when it comes to art.

title: What Business Spends to Open Washingtons Doors
description: The next time a lawmaker or a corporate executive tries to persuade you that Washington is an even playing field, responsive to the concerns of all constituents, feel free to point them to the quarterly lobbying report of the United States Chamber of Commerce. Its most recent report, filed on Monday, shows the staggering amount of money that the business sector spends to influence legislation and regulation in Washington. No other competing interest group comes remotely close.

title: Tartines Country Bread: Be Patient, Perfection Is Near
description: Chad Robertsons recipe for country bread, from Tartine, his bakery in San Francisco, has reached cult status among passionate bakers for good reason: As bread recipes go, its nearly perfect.

title: Racial Equality Loses at the Court
description: A blinkered view of race in America won out in the Supreme Court on Tuesday when six justices agreed, for various reasons, to allow Michigan voters to ban race-conscious admissions policies in higher education.

title: Mixing It Up, Where the Bloody Mary Is Concerned
description: I think I make it pretty clear in my latest Drink column that where the bloody mary is concerned, I like to keep things simple (a poached-shrimp garnish notwithstanding). The drink itself is a study in balance: When you break it down, theres a lot going on in a good bloody, and the idea is to bring all those components together into one bracing  some would say restorative  cocktail. Then do it up with those garnishes.

title: Lets Start With Bread and Water
description: Some people are nostalgic for foam-topped egg creams or Grandmas buttermilk biscuits or defunct brands of childrens cereal. I miss bread and water.

title: Against the Grain
description: Zachary Golper gets a strange look in his eyes when he talks about his miche.

title: Reviews: Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes, FarmVille 2: Country Escape and Monument Valley
description: METAL GEAR SOLID V

title: One-Piece Wonder
description: In spite of its many runway interpretations this season, the jumpsuit is still, for most men, an incredibly daunting full-body statement. Consider it when worn unzipped over a sporty layer, though, and it takes on a thoroughly urban, street-ready appeal  like the tracksuits you see on kids in the London neighborhood of Brixton.

title: Auto China Opens to the Public in Beijing
description: Auto China 2014 officially opened to the public on Monday at the China International Exhibition Center, Beijings convention center, with a glittering, seemingly endless array of new transportation offerings that underscored the growing importance of the Chinese market in the automotive industry.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: Hating Humanity, on Two Wheels
description: When I see men treat each other as they do, I see nothing but base flattery, injustice, treachery, selfishness and deceit.

title: Rooftop Films Sets Summer Lineup
description: A sneak preview of Obvious Child, a Sundance favorite that happens to be an abortion rom-com, will be among the films kicking off this summers Rooftop Film series, which begins in Brooklyn on May 16.

title: Hotel Brands Share Real Estate, Sometimes Uneasily
description: In hotels these days, its the haves versus the have-nots.

title: Execution Case Roils Oklahoma Courts
description: The legal wrangling in Oklahoma over the planned executions of two convicted murderers reached a new level of confusion on Tuesday as the State Supreme Court quickly rejected the attorney generals claim that it had exceeded its power by granting stays of execution, only to have Gov. Mary Fallin assert that she was taking control and would arrange for the men to be put to death next week.

title: Upsetting the Gentility That the South Lays Claim To
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  In keeping with this citys veneration of things old, stately and Southern, the College of Charleston remains a genteel enough place that for spring commencement exercises, male students don white dinner jackets while women slip into white dresses.

title: A Quiet Moment Among Neighbors
description: A photographer moved to a small town to understand what people hold dear. In time, she found herself drawn to subtler, quieter scenes.

title: Acceleration Is Forecast for Spending on Health
description: WASHINGTON  Standing before a roomful of economists, policy makers and health care experts earlier this month, Amitabh Chandra, director of Health Policy Research at Harvards Kennedy School of Government, closed a presentation about the slowdown in health care spending over the last decade by citing an article in The New York Times.

title: 30,000 Golf Carts and 4,000 Heavy Duty Ford Trucks Recalled
description: About 30,000 golf carts and buggies are being recalled because the steering wheel may be loose, according to the Consumer Product Safety Commission. Ford is recalling almost 4,000 of its heavy-duty pickup trucks because they might go into reverse when the driver wants to move forward.

title: ABC Posts Another Ratings Victory Over NBC in Nightly News
description: The long run of dominance for NBCs Nightly News is showing some cracks, as ABCs World News last week again climbed to the top in the crucial audience category.

title: Reviving the House Coltrane Built
description: Henry Butler, the New Orleans jazz pianist, released his debut album, Fivin Around, in 1986. And along with ratifying a major talent  a smartly rampaging virtuoso whose engagement in New York soon afterward drew a smattering of notable pianists  it signaled the reactivation of Impulse Records, the storied former home of the saxophonist John Coltrane, which had then been dormant for nearly a decade. We had a nice little hand in reviving the label at that time, Mr. Butler recalled this week.

title: Barter, Haggle, Close, Rest
description: Consider these eerie similarities between Bitcoin, the supposedly cutting-edge digital currency, and the world of Down East Dickering, a History channel reality series about a throwback barter-and-haggle economy:

title: Why Slavery Is Not Like Carbon Emissions
description: In the new issue of The Nation, the MSNBC host Chris Hayes treads on the dangerous ground of comparing the effort to limit carbon emissions to the campaign for the abolition of slavery.

title: Pelham Bay, the Bronx: A Blend of Urban and Suburban
description: Anyone seeking a large body of water in Pelham Bay would be quickly frustrated:The neighborhoods namesake no longer exists. Instead, you would find a tidy community with rows of two-story brick homes bearing awnings and grillwork fences immediately adjacent to the citys largest park.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, South Korea, Washington and India.

title: Dear Mr. Editor: Oy, the Tsoris Ive Seen
description: With all but the most old-fashioned comics, the eye occasionally hesitates over which panel or word balloon to read next. Proceed across? Down instead?

title: Comcast Seeks to Divest Subscribers to Win Approval for Time Warner Cable Deal
description: Comcast is laying the groundwork to divest nearly four million subscribers as part of its efforts to appease antitrust regulators scrutinizing the proposed acquisition of Time Warner Cable.

title: Make Them Fit, Please!
description: When Dr. Ali Sadrieh, a podiatrist, started Evo Advanced Foot Surgery in Beverly Hills, Calif., 13 years ago, he thought it seemed a little vain for women to ask for surgery because their feet hurt wearing fashionable shoes.

title: Gilead Revenue Soars on Hepatitis C Drug
description: Record sales of a new hepatitis C drug pushed the first-quarter earnings of Gilead Sciences far beyond expectations, the company reported on Tuesday, but could also heighten concerns about the high cost of the drug, known as Sovaldi, and the ability of the health care system to pay for it.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Mens Facial Moisturizers 2.0
description: No longer the ugly stepbrothers of the beauty industry, mens facial moisturizers have upgraded with better textures and ingredients. Enough so that we wondered if they may better some womens products. Below, this female reporter tests four.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: Taming the Digital Wild West
description: THE Internet has grown up. It is no longer just about providing information but about fundamental changes in the way we go about our daily lives.

title: Harvey, Asked to Delete Post, Leaves Twitter
description: Tuesday morning marked six months since Matt Harvey had Tommy John surgery, and the Mets ace wanted to celebrate. He dug through photographs from that day in October, found one that made him chuckle, and posted it to his Twitter account.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 51
description: Thierry Henry scored 51 career goals for France, but none was more memorable  or controversial  than the last one he set up for Les Bleus.

title: JetBlue Airways Pilots Vote to Join Union
description: After twice rejecting bids to unionize since 2009, JetBlue Airways pilots overwhelmingly agreed to be represented by the Air Line Pilots Association, the union said on Tuesday.

title: Letterman Introduces His Successor on Late Show
description: David Letterman introduced his successor, Stephen Colbert, on his Late Show With David Letterman Tuesday night on CBS with a monologue joke and some cordial conversation  but no measuring of the drapes.

title: Pakistan Is Asked to Shut Down News Channel
description: LONDON  The attempted killing of a prominent Pakistani journalist has prompted a bruising public dispute between Pakistans powerful army spy agency and the largest media group that has exacerbated tense relations between the countrys civilian and military leaders.

title: Why Care About McCutcheon?
description: In the food world, change from the ground up is all well and good. We desperately need cooks, gardeners, farmers and teachers. But we also need legislation. The recently passed and almost uniformly abysmal Farm Bill is a lesson in how legislation affects those of us working to change the chaotic so-called food system. Pittances were tossed at supporters of local and organic food, fortunes worth of agribusiness subsidies were maintained, and much-needed support for the countrys least well-off was slashed.

title: Its All About May 25
description: KIEV, Ukraine  The word maidan means square in Ukrainian and in Arabic. And the Independence Maidan of Kiev, like the Tahrir Maidan of Cairo, has been the scene of an awe-inspiring burst of democratic aspirations. The barricades of piled cobblestones, tires, wood beams and burned cars erected by Ukrainian revolutionaries are still there  indeed, it looks as if it could be the set of Les Misrables  and people still lay fresh flowers at the makeshift shrines for the more than 100 people killed in the Maidan by the old and now deposed regime here. Walking through it, though, I tried to explain to my host that, while I was incredibly impressed, a lot of Americans today have Maidan fatigue  too many dashed hopes for democracy in too many squares  from Afghanistan to Iran, Iraq to Egypt, Syria to Libya.

title: In a Tie, Atltico Madrid Can Still Declare Victory
description: MADRID  There are, technically, hundreds of professional soccer clubs in Spain. Yet for much of the rest of the world, there have really been only two. Barcelona and Real Madrid. Real Madrid and Barcelona. Los Blancos. La Blaugrana. For years, they have felt like monoliths passing trophies back and forth while everyone else jockeyed for a sniff.

title: Rise of the Milkbots
description: At a farm near Albany, N.Y., robots milk the cows. Dairy operations across New York have been leading the countrys charge into a brave new world of automated milking systems.

title: Making Airfares Less Transparent
description: A bipartisan group of lawmakers in the House is pushing legislation that would make it easier for airlines to deceive travelers about the true cost of flying.

title: Abu Ghraib, 10 Years Later
description: Baghdads infamous Abu Ghraib prison now stands empty. Its closure, prompted by fears that it could be overrun by Sunni insurgents, along with the transfer of its 2,400 prisoners, was announced last week by the Iraqi government, which resumed control of the facility in 2006.

title: A.N.C.s Stature Wanes as Disenchantment Grows in South Africa
description: PRETORIA, South Africa  Isaac Ramaifo works as a functionary in the Union Buildings, the seat of state power here, and is a member of the governing African National Congress. But as South Africa approaches watershed elections next month, he, like many, is torn between an instinctive loyalty to the party that has ruled for the 20 years since the end of apartheid and worries about its ability to deliver prosperity.

title: Rookies in Their First Playoffs Are Already Looking Seasoned
description: ST. PAUL  The most dominant forward in the early stages of the N.H.L. playoffs is an 18-year-old from Nova Scotia who lives in a teammates basement.

title: Lesson for the Police: Be Careful What You Tweet For
description: When the New York Police Department asked Twitter users on Tuesday to share their photographs with police officers, they were perhaps expecting a few feel-good neighborhood scenes or tourists with police horses in Times Square.

title: At Stake in the Aereo Case Is How We Watch TV
description: WASHINGTON  For most of its two years, Aereo has been an obscure start-up that gained little traction with consumers, partly because it took something that was traditionally easy  watching the broadcast networks  and made it sound complicated. It grabs local over-the-air signals on an array of tiny antennas that users can stream through the Internet to watch and record programming for $8 to $12 a month. Got that?

title: Passport Diplomacy
G.M. Seeks to Fend Off Lawsuits Over Switch
description: General Motors moved on Tuesday to prevent future safety lapses by expanding its oversight of problematic vehicles even as the automaker continued to take an aggressive legal posture in dealing with its past missteps.

title: Homs Emerges as Turning Point in Shaping Syrias Future
description: HOMS, Syria  On the edge of the Old City here, children play beside a house blown open by shelling. An antique wood-framed mirror leans against the wall, so that soldiers can watch for threats from around the corner. A block closer to one of the citys last front lines, trash, rubble and rusted cars litter streets of charred and sagging buildings.

title: Manning Says Ankle Will Heal for Camp
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The dreadful 2013 Giants season ended with the left ankle of Eli Manning in a hard boot, protection against the serious sprain that the franchise quarterback sustained in the final game.

title: With a Mouthful, A&W Hopes to Draw Baby Boomers Offspring
description: THE popularity of the A&W Restaurants chain in the United States peaked in the 1960s and 1970s, when the number of locations  many with carhop service  swelled to 2,400, so it is no wonder that the brand stirs nostalgia in the baby boomer generation. But now A&W, which has about 700 restaurants, wants to make an impression on those boomers children, and the brand is increasingly turning to social media to do so.

title: Colleges Seek New Paths to Diversity After Court Ruling
description: Leaders in higher education, upset by Tuesdays Supreme Court decision upholding Michigans ban on race-based preferences in college admissions, said the ruling would nudge them further along the path of finding alternative means to promote diversity in their student bodies.

title: New Yorks Case Against Airbnb Is Argued in Albany
description: There was no room for agreement, and no agreement about rooms, in court on Tuesday in Albany.

title: Who Will Win the Senate?
description: When Americans go to bed on election night this year, there is a real chance that they wont know which party has won control of the Senate. For that matter, the country may not know who has won a Senate majority at any time in November.

title: A Double Standard in Doping Punishments
description: What does it take to receive a lifetime ban from cycling for breaking antidoping rules?

title: Sherpas Move to Shut Everest in Labor Fight
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  Over the years, as Mount Everest attracted larger crowds of amateur climbers from the West, the Sherpas adjusted: to a slower ascent, to traffic jams, to bulging loads of gear. Every spring some new frustration would get them talking, then recede with the end of the season.

title: DSouza Case Is Political, Lawyer Says
description: When the conservative author and filmmaker Dinesh DSouza was charged in January with illegally using straw donors to contribute to a 2012 New York Republican Senate campaign, his lawyer denied that he had acted with any corrupt or criminal intent.

title: Korea Confronts Tendency to Overlook Safety as Toll in Ferry Sinking Grows
description: JINDO, South Korea  As Navy divers recovered the bodies of dozens of teenagers drowned waiting for a rescue of their doomed ferry, South Korea has begun a national bout of hand-wringing over the countrys tendency to overlook safety precautions in its quest for economic success.

title: With Farm Robotics, the Cows Decide When Its Milking Time
description: EASTON, N.Y.  Something strange is happening at farms in upstate New York. The cows are milking themselves.

title: Prosecutors Describe an Extensive Drug Ring in Affluent Pennsylvania Schools
description: HAVERFORD, Pa.  Boldly describing their enterprise as the Main Line Take Over Project, two former students of a private school in this affluent suburb of Philadelphia took on an ambitious business venture, prosecutors said.

title: Qatar: Sentence of U.S. Couple Was Based on Lesser Charge
description: A panel of judges in Qatar who found an American couple guilty last month in the January 2013 death of their adopted daughter convicted them on the charge of jeopardizing the child, and not the more serious original charge of murder, according to a translation of the verdict provided Tuesday by the couples lawyers. The defendants, Matthew and Grace Huang of Los Angeles, who have not been permitted to leave Qatar, are appealing their three-year sentence, which was announced on March 27. But until Tuesday, their lawyers were unsure how to proceed with the appeal because the judges had never explained the reduced charge. Prosecutors had accused the Huangs of starving their daughter, Gloria, 8, and originally suspected them of being child traffickers because the defendants are of Asian heritage and the child was African. The Huangs, who attributed the childs death to an eating disorder, said the prosecution was based on flawed evidence, racial prejudices and misunderstandings about Western adoption.

title: A Saint, He Aint
description: WASHINGTON  There were some disturbing elements to the Easter Mass I attended at Nativity, my childhood church.

title: Red Sox Fans Greet Ellsbury With a Collective Shrug
description: BOSTON  Matt Williams, a graduate student from Cambridge, Mass., figured he would take plenty of abuse Tuesday night when he settled into his bleacher seat in Section 35 at Fenway Park, wearing a Jacoby Ellsbury Red Sox shirt.

title: Consultant to Scrutinize Detroit Plan
description: By the time Detroit emerges from bankruptcy, it will have seen untold hours of combative negotiations, a thumbs-up or thumbs-down vote from 100,000 creditors and financial projections that one expert recently called little more than pretty good guesses.

title: NASA Vehicle
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Crossword-puzzle constructing, in my opinion, is like a microcosm of the larger workforce. We all have jobs: Some of us are Monday constructors. Some of us go for the big real estate and build the large Sunday puzzles. Some of us hoist the triple stacks. I like to think of the Saturday constructors as the executioners.

title: A Cold War Casualty, Hot for Freedom (and Heels)
description: Do not be alarmed by recent reports that Neil Patrick Harris, an irresistibly wholesome television presence, has fallen deeply and helplessly into the gap that separates men from women, East from West, and celebrity from notoriety. Theres no need to fear for his safety, much less his identity. Quite the contrary.

title: India: Court to Hear Appeal Over Restoration of Ban on Gay Sex
description: Indias Supreme Court announced Tuesday that it would hear an appeal of its decision in December that re-criminalized gay sex. The hearing is largely a formality and is unlikely to lead to a serious reconsideration of the decision. A lower court ruled in 2009 that an 1861 law mandating a 10-year sentence for carnal intercourse against the order of nature with man, woman or animal was unconstitutional. But the Supreme Court overturned the lower courts decision, holding that only Parliament had the power to change that law.

title: New York City Gets Selective About Shell Casings Buyer
description: If this were a melodrama called Bullets Over the Bronx, the second act of the production would remain in the genre of mystery. But, spoiler alert: The story probably will not end with a shootout.

title: Amid Politics, Obama Drifted Away From Kin
description: BOSTON  After Zeituni Onyango, the woman President Obama once called Auntie, died in a South Boston nursing home this month, her closest relatives gathered her belongings at her nearby apartment. There, framed photographs of her with the president covered the wall.

title: A Community Tug of War in Brooklyn
description: If a building complex straddles the intersection of three community districts in New York, which community board should claim jurisdiction over the buildings garbage collection, sidewalk modifications and other assorted concerns?

title: Scandals Republicans Like
description: The decision by the I.R.S. to flag for special review applications for tax-exempt status from organizations with Tea Party or patriot in their names has provoked sustained outrage on the right for nearly a year.

title: Scrutiny Over Photos Said to Tie Russia Units to Ukraine
description: WASHINGTON  A collection of photographs that Ukraine says shows the presence of Russian forces in the eastern part of the country, and which the United States cited as evidence of Russian involvement, has come under scrutiny.

title: Corrections: April 23, 2014
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Phillip Hayes Dean, the Playwright of Divisive Paul Robeson, Dies at 83
description: Phillip Hayes Dean, a playwright whose stage portrait of the actor and social crusader Paul Robeson aroused one of the theaters more unusual controversies and derailed his own promising career, died on April 14 in Los Angeles, shortly after a revival of the play opened at the Ebony Repertory Theater there. He was 83.

title: Yanks New Additions Torment the Red Sox
description: BOSTON  After an October of misery watching their oldest rivals win the World Series while they failed to make the playoffs, the Yankees responded with conviction in the off-season, signing four players they hope will tip the scales back in their favor.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 22, 2014
description: April 22, 2014

title: Fargo Recap: Boots on the Ground
description: In Fargo, the characters are defined by their boots.

title: Rapfogel to Plead Guilty in Scheme to Steal Millions From Charity
description: A community leader with longtime ties to Sheldon Silver, the New York State Assembly speaker, is expected to plead guilty on Wednesday in connection with a scheme to loot more than $7 million from one of New York Citys most influential social service organizations, people familiar with the case said Tuesday night.

title: Steady Rangers Capitalize on Shaky Game by Flyers Goalie
description: PHILADELPHIA  Several Rangers stood out in their 4-1 victory over the Flyers on Tuesday night that gave them a 2-1 series lead. None more, however, than Daniel Carcillo.

title: L. Jay Oliva, Who Led the Rise of N.Y.U. in the 90s, Dies at 80
description: L. Jay Oliva, who began his career at New York University as a night school history instructor in 1960 and rose to become its president in the 1990s, helping to transform it from a commuter school into a major university, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 80.

title: Raptors Outlast Nets to Even Up the Series
description: TORONTO  The Nets may seethe for some time about wasted chances and sloppy play, about a missed opportunity to grab a stranglehold on their first-round playoff series with the Toronto Raptors.

title: Hollidays Leaping Grab Protects Shutout of Mets
description: Matt Holliday timed his leap perfectly, yanking Chris Youngs home run effort back from over the left-field wall and, in one fell swoop, erasing the Mets best offensive effort Tuesday night.

title: Obama Addresses Oso, Wash.
description: President Obama spoke to first responders in Oso, Wash. on Tuesday.

title: Flyers Mason Back on Ice, if Only to Gauge Readiness
description: PHILADELPHIA  Steve Mason, the Flyers No. 1 goalie, spent the first 52 minutes Tuesday night on a stool at the end of the bench, in front of the door that leads onto the ice, before being summoned to play the rest of Philadelphias 4-1 Game 3 loss to the Rangers.

title: Brazil: Deadly Violence Erupts in Rio
description: At least two people died Tuesday after a day of violence in a slum that abuts the Copacabana tourist district of Rio de Janeiro. Local news media reported that the deaths occurred in the slum, or favela, called Pavo-Pavozinho. The disturbances began after a young man who was a dancer on a television variety show was found dead and residents charged that he had been killed by a police officer, according to the reports. The police said that they were investigating, but that marks on the mans body indicated that he could have fallen to his death. A protest turned violent, and several officers became trapped in the favela. An elite squad then arrived. Copacabana residents reported hearing gunshots and what sounded like small explosions. A second man was later found fatally shot. Separately, a police officer was shot in another favela in the north of the city. The violence comes less than two months before Rio and other cities in Brazil are to host the World Cup.

title: Inside a Remote Island Made of Marble, an Artists New Abode
description: In the middle of the Lago General Carrera, a lake that stretches from Chile to Argentina, the Swiss artist Not Vital has crafted another minimalist yet innovative home for himself. He bought one of the 13 islands there in 2008  It is not big, and it is not small, he says  and has been working on it since 2009. This month, he finally finished the quiet little island, which he has named NotOna, the first photos of which are featured here.

title: Times Minute | Modern-Day Rabbit Ears
description: The Supreme Court considers whether Aereo is committing copyright infringement. Also on the Minute, labor troubles on Mount Everest and the rise of the milkbots at dairy farms.

title: The Limits of No Pain, No Gain
description: Exercise makes us tired. A new study helps to elucidate why and also suggests that while it is possible to push through fatigue to reach new levels of physical performance, it is not necessarily wise.

title: Misfortune Leaves Student Loan Borrowers on the Hook
description: You have been faithfully making your student loan payment each month, and are making steady progress paying down the balance. But then your parent  who co-signed your loan  dies, or files for bankruptcy protection. All of a sudden, your lender is demanding that you repay the loan in full, even though you have never been late with a payment.

title: Times Minute | Modern-Day Rabbit Ears
description: In the Video

title: Word of the Day | quack
description: quack\kwak\ noun and verb

title: New York City Housing Push Should Aim at Poorest, Report Says
description: The New York City comptroller, Scott M. Stringer, is recommending that the city focus its affordable housing efforts on the most burdened residents  those in households making $40,000 or less a year  and also invest in stabilizing a crumbling public housing system that has risen in importance as fewer low-income New Yorkers can afford to live in private apartments.

title: Whats On Wednesday
description: 5:05 P.M. (Starz Cinema) CHICKEN WITH PLUMS (2012) A celebrated but tormented violinist, Nasser-Ali (Mathieu Amalric, above), in 1958 Tehran retreats to his bed to end his life after his prized instrument is broken, in this drama from Marjane Satrapi and Vincent Paronnaud, based on Ms. Satrapis graphic novel of the same title. But in flashbacks  and flash-forwards  starring Nasser-Alis wife (Maria de Medeiros) and children (Mathis Bour and Enna Balland; Chiara Mastroianni and Christian Friedel portray them as adults), it soon becomes clear that his melancholy is rooted in a deeper heartache: his long-ago love, Irane (Golshifteh Farahani). Not that Chicken With Plums is gloomy, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Like its swooning, madly melodramatic musical score (by Olivier Bernet), the film takes an almost giddy pleasure in unhappiness, turning even pedestrian moments of boredom or discomfort into occasions for wild invention. The result, which features a naked Sophia Loren and Edouard Baer as the Angel of Death, is captivating, but not exactly moving.

title: Egypt: U.S. to Deliver Helicopters
description: The United States will deliver to Egypt 10 Apache helicopters that were held up last year after President Mohamed Morsi was deposed, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel told the Egyptian defense ministeron Tuesday. Mr. Hagel said the helicopters would be used in Egypts efforts against terrorism in the Sinai, the Defense Department said in a statement. In a separate call, Secretary of State John Kerry told Egypts foreign minister, Nabil Fahmy, that he is certifying to Congress that Egypt is living up to the terms of the 1979 peace treaty with Israel, a move that allows the release of some aid to Cairo, a State Department spokeswoman said.

title: India Election Digest: April 23
description: What you need to know on Wednesday about Indias elections: Priyanka Gandhi criticizes attempts to humiliate her family, Indias financial regulators brace for extreme market swings after the election results, and Narendra Modi of the Bharatiya Janata Party takes to Twitter to admonish Hindu nationalist supporters for their inflammatory remarks.

title: Slovyansk Mourns 3 Killed at Checkpoint
description: Anger and questions swirled as residents in the eastern Ukrainian city of Slovyansk buried three men killed in a gunfight at a roadblock on Sunday.

title: 10,000 Olympic Babies Strain the Beijing System
description: Updated, 11 p.m. ET| Olympic Babies are Coming, read a headline in Beijing News on Wednesday. With thousands more children than usual born in Beijing in 2008, a year considered by many to be lucky both for the number eight and for being the year that China hosted the Olympic Games, the state is scrambling to find enough school spaces for all the 6-year-olds heading to first grade this fall  about 10,000 more than last September.

title: Colbert Visits Letterman on Late Show
description: Once upon a time, the transfer of power from one monarch to another would involve some pomp and ritual, maybe even a passing of a crown. But when Stephen Colbert visited David Letterman Tuesday night on The Late Show, the comedy franchise he will inherit next year, they commemorated the occasion in grand 2014 style: With the taking of a selfie. The comedy titans flashed broad smiles, with Mr. Colbert leaning forward.

title: Women Go Topless for Equal Rights
description: Updated, 7:31 a.m. |

title: Backlash Over Hong Kongs Treatment of Mainland Visitors
description: The tensions between Hong Kong residents and mainland Chinese visitors are bubbling up yet again  with a video showing a confrontation involving a mainland family whose child was videotaped urinating on a busy street.

title: Test Yourself | Math, April 23, 2014
description: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

title: 6 Qs About the News | For Young Traders, a Market Where Air Jordans Are Blue Chips
description: In For Young Traders, a Market Where Air Jordans Are Blue Chips, Grant Glickson writes about the subculture of teenage sneakerheads.

title: Get Cracking
description: 12 recipes that take the hard-boiled egg beyond Easter.

title: Animals Are Persons Too
description: This short documentary follows the lawyer Steven Wises effort to break down the legal wall that separates animals from humans.

title: A Quiet Moment Among Neighbors
description: Lauren Justice is a freelance photographer based in Lincoln, Neb., who also works part time for The Lincoln Journal Star. She has interned with The San Francisco Examiner, The Fayetteville Observer in North Carolina and The Flint Journal in Michigan. Ms. Justice, 26, studied photojournalism and sociology at the University of Cincinnati. Her conversation with James Estrin has been edited.

title: Should a Chimp Be Able to Sue Its Owner?
description: Just before 4 p.m. on Oct. 10, Steven Wise pulled his rental car in front of a multiacre compound on State Highway 30 near the tiny Adirondack hamlet of Gloversville, N.Y., and considered his next move. For the past 15 minutes, Wise had been slowly driving the perimeter of the property, trying to get a better read on the place. An assortment of transport trailers  for horses and livestock, cars, boats and snowmobiles  cluttered a front lot beside a single-story business office with the sign Circle L Trailer Sales set above the door. At the rear of the grounds was a barn-size, aluminum-sided shed, all its doors closed, the few small windows covered in thick plastic.

title: Full Results of The New York Times/Kaiser Family Foundation Poll
description: In four southern states, Republicans are generally stronger among residents who say they will definitely vote.

title: Animals Are Persons Too
description: How does a thing become a person? In December 2013, the lawyer Steven Wise showed the world how, with a little legal jujitsu, an animal can transition from a thing without rights to a person with legal protections. This Op-Doc video follows Mr. Wise on his path to filing the first-ever lawsuits in the United States demanding limited personhood rights for certain animals, on behalf of four captive chimpanzees in New York State.

title: Koreans Bid Farewell to Victims of a Disaster, and Even the North Speaks Up
description: JINDO, South Korea  With hopes of finding more survivors of the South Korean ferry sinking all but gone, some families, as well as the nation, began bidding farewell on Wednesday to the students and other victims whose bodies have been recovered. And in an unusual gesture, North Korea sent its condolences.

title: Recovery in Euro Zone Gathers Pace
description: PARIS  The economy of the euro zone expanded this month at its fastest rate in nearly three years, according to a private sector survey released on Wednesday, with accelerated output from Germany leading the bloc.

title: What Have You Learned Playing Video Games?
description: What are your favorite video games? What do you think they have taught you?

title: Numericable Raises $10.9 Billion in Junk Bond Offering
description: Updated, 12:30 p.m. | Numericable, the French cable unit of Altice, raised 7.9 billion euros, or about $10.9 billion, on Wednesday in the largest junk bond offering in history to help finance the acquisition of Vivendis mobile unit, SFR.

title: High Altitudes May Aid Weight Control
description: Could living in the mountains help with weight control? Maybe.

title: New York Today: Balloons-Eye View
description: Good Wednesday morning to you.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: Ardian Raises $10 Billion, Mostly to Invest in Buyout Funds
description: The private equity firm Ardian said on Wednesday that it had raised $10 billion from investors, including $9 billion for a fund that invests in existing buyout funds.

title: Pacific Rim Deal Could Reduce Chance of Unintended Conflict in Contested Seas
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  A naval code of conduct approved by more than 20 nations around the Pacific, including China, Japan and the United States, could reduce the risk of accidental encounters spiraling into conflict, experts said. But Beijings firm rejection of President Obamas comments on Wednesday about islands claimed by both China and Japan underscored the maritime tensions that continue to trouble Asia.

title: Obama Arrives in Asia as Disasters Complicate Mission
description: TOKYO  President Obama arrived here on Wednesday evening to begin a four-country tour of Asia, after first stopping in Washington State to survey the devastation left there by last months deadly mudslide. It was a fitting start, given that everywhere on this trip, he will witness the lingering fallout of disasters, natural and human-made.

title: Close Races in 4 Southern States Could Tip Senate Power Balance
description: Four Senate races in the South that will most likely determine control of Congress appear very close, with Republicans benefiting from more partisan intensity but a Democratic incumbent, seen as highly vulnerable, holding a surprising edge, according to a New York Times Upshot/Kaiser Family Foundation poll.

title: Diplomatic Efforts on Syria Have Failed, U.N. Chiefs Say
description: GENEVA  Two months after the United Nations Security Council ordered Syrias warring parties to allow access for humanitarian aid to civilians, the heads of five United Nations agencies warned on Wednesday that diplomacy had failed and that the desperate plight of civilians in many parts of the country was getting worse.

title: Looking for a Business to Buy? Think Castoffs
description: Those who have been around businesses a while know a secret of the acquisition world: Occasionally, there are really good deals out there.

title: Daily Report: New York Argues Case Against Airbnb Before Judge
description: There was no room for agreement, and no agreement about rooms, in court on Tuesday in Albany, David Streitfeld reports.

title: Penetrating a Closed, Isolated Society in Appalachia
description: Trip Gabriel, a national reporter, describes the challenge of winning trust in McDowell County, W.Va., the focus of a front-page article on Monday. The article, headlined 50 Years Later, Hardship Hits Back, was the first in a series about the poor in America called Caught in Poverty.

title: Anglo-Irish Retailer Primark to Make U.S. Landfall in Boston
description: LONDON  Seeing the recent success of Topshop, Uniqlo and other overseas low-cost retailers among United States consumers, the Anglo-Irish retailer Primark said on Wednesday that it planned to open its first store in the country next year.

title: In Our Pages: April 24
description: 1889: Fight at a French Fair

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The New York Times Upshot/Kaiser Family Foundation Poll of four Southern states is based on telephone interviews conducted April 8 through April 15 with 4,152 adults. Of these, 3,594 said they were registered to vote: 857 in Arkansas, 891 in Kentucky, 946 in Louisiana, and 900 in North Carolina.

title: British Financial Regulator Adds 2 Senior Advisers
description: LONDON  The Financial Conduct Authority of Britain has added a former head of Britains Competition Commission and a former executive at Goldman Sachs and Lehman Brothers Holdings to its ranks as it looks to increase its expertise.

title: Big Pharmas Deal Bonanza
description: The pharmaceutical industry is regaining its swagger, Michael J. de la Merced, David Gelles and Rachel Abrams write in DealBook. On Tuesday alone, pharmaceutical companies announced $74 billion worth of potential deals, including an unconventional $45.6 billion bid for Allergan, the maker of Botox, and a flurry of swaps and sales between Novartis of Switzerland and GlaxoSmithKline of Britain. More deals in the cash-rich industry are expected.

title: Australia Examines Material Washed Ashore for Link to Missing Jet
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Investigators are examining whether material that washed ashore near the southern end of Western Australia is connected to the missing Malaysia Airlines aircraft, Australian search organizers said on Wednesday.

title: Russia Warns Ukraine of Potential Military Response
description: MOSCOW  Russia continued Wednesday to ratchet up pressure on the government in Kiev, warning that events in eastern Ukraine could prompt a military response and again accusing the United States of directing events there.

title: On Combating Government Secrecy: One Step Forward, One Leap Back
description: To put it mildly, President Obamas early promises of transparency in government havent exactly turned out that way.

title: Australia to Bolster Air Force With More Lockheed Jets
description: SYDNEY, Australia  In a $11.6 billion deal, Australia is ordering 58 more F-35 fighter jets built by Lockheed Martin, increasing the total fleet to 72, Prime Minister Tony Abbott said Wednesday.

title: Former Executive Sells Aam Aadmi Party as Pro-Business
description: MUMBAI, India  As a truck festooned with broomsticks, the symbol of the Aam Aadmi Party, wheezed in a narrow lane in Kamathipura, the red-light district in south Mumbai, women in floral nightgowns appeared on their doorsteps, curious about the commotion.

title: Post Office Rules
description: Dear Diary:

title: Now Nattering on His Own Throne
description: Felicitous timing has powered the steeply ascendant television career of John Oliver since the day he landed in New York from London  July 16, 2006  and, just 24 hours later, sweaty and jet-lagged, found himself mocking Tony Blair in an exchange with Jon Stewart on The Daily Show.

title: An Artists View of Brussels
description: Brussels may be a hub for international business, but the Belgian capital  whoseArt Brusselscontemporary art fair kicks off Friday  is also full ofunexpected pleasures. Creative types are drawn to the citys relatively low cost of living, multicultural flavor and vibrant art scene, anchored by the Wiels Contemporary Art Center.Here, on the eve of the fair, the New York-based artistMegan Marrin currently an artist in residence at Wiels lists a few of her favorite cultural gems in the city.

title: Amazon to Stream Original HBO Content
description: Amazon will stream a selection of HBO series, mini-series and original movies as part of its Prime subscription service, the latest alliance between technology and entertainment companies trying to capture viewers who are moving online.

title: Amazon.com is learning the hard way that people care more about price than brand loyalty.
description: In states where Amazon has been forced to begin charging sales tax, households decreased their expenditures on the site by 9.5 percent and by 24 percent on purchases of more than $299, according to a new study by Ohio State University researchers. Although bricks-and-mortar retailers and state governments pushed for Amazon to collect sales tax, they did not necessarily benefit. Sales increased only 2 percent at local stores, but rose nearly 20 percent at competing online retailers that do not charge sales tax. For expensive purchases, the rivals saw a 24 percent increase.

title: U.S. Military Exercises to Begin in Eastern Europe
description: PARIS  American military exercises in Eastern Europe are to begin Wednesday as part of a move to ease the anxieties of eastern European countries alarmed by Russias efforts to reassert its hegemony in the region, Western officials said.

title: A Lyons Reunion at the Vineyard
description: Why mess with success? In 2011, the Vineyard Theater produced a new Nicky Silver family play with a juicy role for Linda Lavin. The Lyons, in which she played a neurotic New York wife looking forward to the death of her husband, became an Off Broadway hit and transferred to Broadway. Now, the prolific Mr. Silver is back with a new play, Too Much Sun, which starts performances on May 1 at the Vineyard. It once again stars Ms. Lavin.

title: Justice Dept. Expands Eligibility for Clemency
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department announced a plan on Wednesday to canvass the entire federal prison population for the first time to find inmates who committed low-level crimes and could be released early.

title: Degrees of Influence Peddling in China and U.S.
description: To understand how money and politics intertwine in the worlds two largest economies, look no further than two important articles in The Times in the last few days.

title: Pay Gap Is Because of Gender, Not Jobs
description: Are women paid less than men because they choose to be, by gravitating to lower-paying jobs like teaching and social work?

title: Poetry Profiles: Louisiana State University Press
description: The latest in a series of occasional profiles of poetry publishers. These questions were answered by MaryKatherine Callaway, the director of LSU Press.

title: Why Do the Boy Scouts Still Ban Gay Troop Leaders?
description: Robert Gates, the former defense secretary and Eagle Scout, will in May begin a two-year term as president of the Boy Scouts of America. At the Pentagon, Mr. Gates backed President Obamas call to end the unjust dont ask, dont tell policy that barred gay men and women from serving openly in the military. If he cares to build on that record of inclusion, he could start by publicly voicing disapproval of the B.S.A.s mistreatment of Geoff McGrath.

title: Flights of Fancy
description: Mired in reality as adults are, they can find it hard to remember that childrens outsize desires are often best fulfilled imaginatively. Two entertaining new books make this point with a light touch. The day I discovered I could fly, I knew that I was special, begins Michal Escoffier in The Day I Lost My Superpowers, illustrated by Kris Di Giacomo. The speaker is a preschooler (seemingly a girl, though boy readers will find theres nothing to prevent them imagining themselves in her place) who is convinced  in a way quite rightly  of her own superpowers. These include the ability to launch herself off the playground slide into the sandbox, to make cupcakes disappear by sheer force of concentration, and to direct plants and inanimate objects to do her will by staying in one place.

title: A Fresh Setback for VW in Its Bid for Full Control of the Truck Maker Scania
description: LONDON  The German automaker Volkswagen faced a fresh setback on Wednesday in its bid to take full control of the Swedish truck maker Scania.

title: Palestinian Rivals Announce Unity Pact, Drawing U.S. and Israeli Rebuke
description: JERUSALEM  The faltering Middle East peace process was thrown into further jeopardy on Wednesday, with Israel and the United States harshly condemning a new deal announced by feuding Palestinian factions, including the militant group Hamas, to repair their seven-year rift.

title: Malaysia on Unidentified Debris on Beach
description: Malaysian officials said they were waiting for verification on whether unidentified material that washed up on the Australian coastline is from missing Flight 370.

title: A Man of Magic in the Real World
description: In 1983 I was a young would-be film distributor at the Cannes Film Festival looking to find a movie to make my mark. I had gone to film school, I had studied Godard, Truffaut, Visconti and Fellini, and I had stars in my eyes. I wanted to follow in the great tradition of Don Rugoff, the president of Cinema 5, who was everybodys idol in the film distribution world. But there I was, trying to go to various screenings and having no connections whatsoever with anyone.

title: Euro Zone Deficit Hits Target for First Time Since 2008
description: PARIS  Euro zone governments have hit an important goal, bringing their combined budget deficits for 2013 in line with their target for the first time since 2008, official data showed on Wednesday. But for some economists, meeting that cost-cutting goal has not been worth the price paid in lost jobs and feeble growth.

title: With Vaults and Domes, Two Architects Left Their Imprint on City
description: If you think the old Pennsylvania Station has completely disappeared, get off a No. 1 train at 34th Street-Penn Station, walk to the southernmost exit and press your nose to the safety-glass panel at the top of the landing. Then look up.

title: Six First Ladies Together Backstage
description: Here are six first ladies, 20 years ago next month, at a joint fund-raising appearance at the United States Botanic Garden in Washington. The body language seems revealing. Hillary Rodham Clinton, the incumbent presidents wife, confers with the widow of L.B.J., a Big Daddy for modern Democrats. Betty Ford turns to Barbara Bush, wife of the young Texan whose career her husband, Jerry, had once promoted, and away from Rosalynn Carter, whose Jimmy had thwarted Gerald Fords re-election. Former actress Nancy Reagan seems to be waiting for their cue to perform.

title: Today in Small Business: The Divider Effect
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Despite Poll, Problems Lurk for Democratic Incumbents in South
description: The new New York Times Upshot/Kaiser Family Foundation poll offers some encouraging news for Democrats. The incumbent Democratic senators in three states  Arkansas, Louisiana and North Carolina  still hold at least nominal leads. Perhaps the best news for Democrats comes in Arkansas, where the polls show Mark Pryor ahead by a surprising 10-point margin.

title: Led Zeppelin Releases Two Previously Unheard Recordings
description: LONDON  The Led Zeppelin guitarist Jimmy Page clearly likes to be in control. The British rock group, which is reissuing its first three albums on June 3, has just released two previously unheard recordings that Mr. Page, 70, found while going through the bands archives.

title: Pikettys Book on Wealth and Inequality Is More Popular in Richer States
description: Thomas Pikettys tome Capital in the Twenty-First Century is currently the top-selling book at Amazon.com. Its also been the subject of intense media coverage from publications with New York, Washington and Wall Street in their names. But has Mr. Piketty kicked off a broad national conversation about inequality, or is the book being read mostly in the East Coast liberal echo chamber?

title: Health Laws Middle-Ground Approach Leaves It Unloved
description: The legacy achievement of the Obama administration has also become its largest political conundrum. Many Americans disapprove of the Affordable Care Act  but for different reasons, coming from different sides.

title: A Britons View of Paris: Martin Parr at the Maison Europenne de la Photographie
description: PARIS In January, the soon-to-be-elected mayor of Paris, Anne Hidalgo, set off a minor wave of cross-Channel outrage when, piqued by the claim of her London counterpart, Boris Johnson, that his city attracted more tourists than hers, she dismissed London as a suburb of Paris. (She later tamped down her comment in an open letter in The Guardian.)

title: FIFA Suspends Barcelona Transfer Ban
description: Barcelona will be allowed to sign new players during this summers transfer window after FIFA on Wednesday suspended a ban on acquisitions while the club pursues its appeal.

title: Philanthropist Admits Stealing More Than $1 Million From Charity
description: For most of his long and very public life as a philanthropist, William E. Rapfogel has been surrounded by powerful friends and politicians, chief among them Sheldon Silver, the New York State Assembly speaker.

title: A Different Kind of Super Power
description: The cartoonist Scott McCloud, who wrote about what makes comic books tick in Understanding Comics and speculated about their future in Reinventing Comics, is returning to fiction for his next project, The Sculptor, a graphic novel to be published in February 2015 by First Second.

title: Gallery | Emerging Fashion and Photography Talents From the Hyres Festival
description: Starting Friday, the 29th International Festival of Fashion and Photography at Hyresin the South of France will be showcasing its annual roundup of young talents to watch and awarding prizes in the fashion and photography categories.The fashion jury, led by the Opening Ceremony founders and Kenzo designers Carol Lim and Humberto Leon, also included Spike Jonze and Chlo Sevigny; the 10 finalists will display their work at seaside runway shows during the festival weekend. The photography jury was presided over by the legendary lensman Steve Hiett. Winnowed from 743 entries, the work of the 10 finalists will be on view at the Villa Noailles in a group show running through May 25.

title: Underwater Search for Ferry Victims
description: A senior official with the South Korean Coast Guard said rescuers were mobilizing an underwater robot to help with night operations as they hunted for missing passengers.

title: Why Criticism of Poll Is Misguided
description: The new New York Times Upshot/Kaiser Family Foundation surveys offer some pretty good results for Democrats  with caveats  so its no surprise that polling aficionados are scouring the details for an explanation. They think theyve found the problem: respondents self-reported vote in the 2012 presidential election, which generally found President Obama faring far better than he did in that race. This critique is understandable, but misguided.

title: Tough Sell for Chinese Pork Producers I.P.O.
description: The WH Groups chopped initial public offering still looks unappetizing.

title: Bangladeshs Chance to Get It Right
description: Bangladesh is hardly known for its workplace safety. But one unlikely success story can be found in a leading shipbuilding company called Western Marine, based in the port city of Chittagong. Western Marine makes ships for the domestic market but has also sold vessels to Germany and Denmark.

title: Editorial Contest Winner | The War on Drugs
description: For the next 10 days we will be honoring each of the Top 10 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing an essay a day, in the order of submission.

title: Justin Bieber Apologizes After Visiting Japanese War Shrine
description: TOKYO  Justin Bieber got a nasty lesson in Asias tangled emotions over history on Wednesday when he apologized to irate Chinese fans for posting photos of himself visiting a controversial Tokyo war shrine.

title: Film at 9/11 Museum Sets Off Clash Over Reference to Islam
description: Past the towering tridents that survived the World Trade Center collapse, adjacent to a gallery with photographs of the 19 hijackers, a brief film at the soon-to-open National September 11 Memorial Museum will seek to explain to visitors the historical roots of the attacks.

title: Times Minute | Easing Prison Sentences
description: Also on the Minute, Syrias humanitarian crisis, and the risks people take to find their iPhones.

title: Classical Playlist: Carter, Rand Steiger, Mozart and More
description: CARTER, SESSIONS AND ECKARDTMiranda Cuckson, violinist, and Blair McMillen, pianist(Urlicht AudioVisual)The violinist Miranda Cuckson and the pianist Blair McMillen, who are individually brilliant and adventurous artists, bring out the best in each other in their frequent collaborations, including their latest recording of contemporary works. Their incisive, animated playing cuts through the density and complexity of Carters Duo for Violin and Piano to reveal the musics wit and fancifulness. Jason Eckardt wrote his glistening, jittery and playfully frenetic Strmkarl last year as a companion piece for this recording. Ms. Cuckson is outstanding in Sessionss magisterial, technically challenging Sonata for Solo Violin (1953). (Anthony Tommasini)

title: Times Minute | Easing Prison Sentences
description: In the Video

title: A Letter to the National September 11 Memorial Museum
description: A letter sent to Alice M. Greenwald, the director of the museum, from an interfaith advisory group of religious leaders. The letter detailed their concerns about the film The Rise of Al Qaeda.

title: Ice Climbing in an Alaskan Glacial Paradise
description: Standing on a glacier, you expect the world to be a vast expanse of white.

title: Chasing Elusive Flowers in South Africa
description: It was supposed to be straightforward: Drive north from Cape Town for a few hours until, voil, Im engulfed by a rainbow of flowers. Thats what I envisioned when an acquaintance urged me to witness the blooming spring landscape of the Western and Northern Cape: Never-ending carpets of wildflowers, he promised.

title: A New Class of American Academy Fellows
description: The actor Al Pacino, the bluegrass musician Ralph Stanley, the novelists Annie Proulx and John Irving, and the historian Jill Lepore are among the 204 newly elected fellows of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.

title: The Republican Partys Senate Problem
description: After yesterdays feature on the American middle classs (relative) decline, the big newsmaker over at The Upshot today is new polling on four red-state Senate races, which shows Mark Pryor, the Democratic incumbent, with a surprisingly large lead over Tom Cotton in Arkansas, and races in North Carolina, Louisiana and Kentucky all effectively in dead heats.

title: Race in Waxman Primary Involves Donating Dollars
description: The congressional Democrats Frank Pallone and Anna Eshoo have been helping their friends this year, and making new ones, with an eye on a potential payback in 2015. Mr. Pallone, from New Jersey, and Ms. Eshoo, from California, have been giving their colleagues thousands of dollars in campaign contributions as part of what could be called the Waxman Primary.

title: U.S. Workers Losing Ground in Leisure Time, Too
description: The American middle class is losing ground in more ways than one.

title: Midsummer Night Swing Offerings Range From Afro-Cuban to Classic Rock
description: Midsummer Night Swing, Lincoln Centers annual celebration of dance music, will set up its outdoor ballroom at Damrosch Park on June 24 for a performance by Vince Giordano and the Nighthawks, with Ccile McLorin Salvant, the first of 15 nights of music and dancing at the park. The festival runs through July 12, and includes evenings of African and Cuban dance music, disco, Latin and classic rock, with dance lessons in the style of the evening at each performance.

title: Risqu Names Reap Rewards for Some Companies
description: Corin and Brian Mullins thought they had a good name for their debut product, a nonallergenic, high-fiber breakfast cereal, until a supremely satisfied customer called to praise the products effectiveness.

title: Tribeca Film Festival: The Worst Soccer Loss Ever and a Hollywood Ending
description: Mike Brett and Steve Jamison know what its like to be underdogs playing soccer. (From here well call it football.) The future filmmaking partners met as footballers at Cambridge University and went on an Asian tour with the Cambridge squad that included a match against the Thai national team, then ranked 60th in the world.

title: IBM Opens Chip Architecture, in Strategy of Sharing and Self-Interest
description: IBMs chip business needs help. So the company has opened up the technology of its Power microprocessors, inviting others to modify and manufacture Power-based designs pretty much as they see fit. This open, liberal licensing initiative is conducted under the auspices of the OpenPower Foundation, which was incorporated in December.

title: So Many Art Fairs. So Little Time.
description: LOS ANGELES  Scheduling a new art fair these days is nearly as challenging as setting a release date for a feature film in Hollywood, given the steep competition.

title: New York Financial Regulator Uses Dodd-Frank to Sue Auto Lender
description: Updated, 7:22 p.m. | By his own admission, even New Yorks top financial regulator did not know he could use the Dodd-Frank law to enforce consumer protections until very recently.

title: Federal Prosecutor to Help Lead Justice Dept.s Criminal Division
description: The Justice Departments criminal division, which oversees some of the biggest investigations into Wall Street and corporate crime, is adding to its ranks.

title: Queens Day Becomes Kings Day in the Netherlands
description: The Netherlands biggest celebration has a new date and name this month, when the former Queens Day, held since 1890, becomes Kings Day, or Koningsdag.

title: Plea Agreement for William E. Rapfogel
description: An agreement that Mr. Rapfogel entered into with the attorney generals office in which he agreed to plead guilty. He also promised to pay $3 million in restitution.

title: Dodge Poetry Festival Set to Return to Newark
description: And they said it wouldnt last.

title: Are Risqu Company Names Good for Business?
description: Weve just published an article that recounts the experiences of several companies that have sought to attract attention by giving themselves outrageous names. In fact, several of the companies arent sure they would exist if not for their creative names.

title: Court Information for William E. Rapfogel
description: Mr. Rapfogel pleaded guilty to charges contained in a Superior Court Information document drawn up by the attorney generals office.

title: Gallery | Vintage Posters Bring Art-House Appeal to the Auction House
description: Nicholas Lowry, the president and principal auctioneer of New York Citys Swann Auction Galleries, was reminded of the weighty value of niche memorabilia at last years Modernist Posters auction: a poster advertising Andy Warhols Exploding Plastic Inevitable, a multimedia event held at the Chrysler Art Museum in Provincetown, Mass. in 1966, fetched nearly nine times its estimated selling price  despite not actually having been designed by Warhol himself. All of a sudden, people who have similar things at home are saying, Wait a minute, this piece of paper is worth $7000?' says Lowry, who has received a constant stream of inquiries and offers leading up to this years sale, happening tomorrow at Swann. Warhol created such a successful cult of personality around him that it has long succeeded his death.

title: Court Information for David Cohen
description: Mr. Cohen plead guilty to the charges contained in the Superior Court Information document.

title: New York Police Twitter Backlash Spreads Around the World
description: What began as an effort by the New York Police Department to get people to share favorable photos of city police officers on Twitter has turned into an international social media campaign about police abuse.

title: Image of the Day: April 23
Recipes for Kids: Tzatziki
description: Tzatziki (za-DZEE-kee) is a Greek dip that is often served as a snack or an appetizer. It is also great on burgers or tomato sandwiches.

title: Anthony Can Expect Lower Offer
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Phil Jacksons first postseason news conference began with the statement that there is no news. But Jackson, the Knicks new $60 million team president, has been a longtime newsmaker, an N.B.A. lightning rod. He almost cannot help it.

title: Returning to an Impossible Role
description: Leaning against an upright piano, Amber Gray bent her voice and body to a songs harmonies  tapping her feet, drumming her fingers, bowing her head, and turtling her chin forward and back.

title: Springing Forward, and Its Consequences
description: This is a busy time of year for Richard B. Primack, a biologist at Boston University. He and his colleagues survey the plants growing around Concord, Mass., recording the first day they send up flowers and leaves.

title: A Deeper Look at a Study Finding High Leak Rates From Gas Drilling
description: Updated below with Skype chat with the study lead author, 10:07 p.m. | Most efforts to slow the natural gas drilling boom in the United States have focused on questions about the environmental impacts of the process called hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, which occurs deep underground after a well is drilled.

title: Researchers See New Importance in Y Chromosome
description: There is new reason to respect the diminutive male Y chromosome.

title: Excerpt: Casa Valentina
description: A scene from Harvey Fiersteins new play about cross-dressers at a 1960s Catskills resort. The show is on Broadway at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater.

title: A Renter Does the Math
description: Soon after his arrival in New York from San Francisco two years ago, David Park took a rental at the Beatrice, rising high above the Eventi Hotel on West 29th Street. He loved his small studio, 475 contemporary square feet with a great view and a central location.

title: Proposal to Limit Prosecutions of Marijuana Cases in Brooklyn
description: The Brooklyn district attorneys office will stop prosecuting people arrested on charges of possessing small amounts of marijuana, according to a confidential policy proposal that the district attorney, Kenneth P. Thompson, sent to the New York Police Department this month.

title: What You Get for ... $2,500,000
description: ORCAS ISLAND, WASH.

title: Mixed Signals: Exploring the Science Behind Nutrition and Disease
description: Overview | The news can sometimes seem as if it is full of conflicting reports on the connection between diet and health: Are fats good for you, or bad for you? What about sugar, chocolate and caffeine? And what kinds of evidence do scientists use in making dietary recommendations? In this lesson, students can explore the science behind nutrition and disease  how strong are the connections between diet and conditions such as heart disease, obesity and even cancer?

title: Ackmans Pershing Square Subsidiaries Hint at Future Moves
description: The hedge fund billionaire William A. Ackman may be plotting his next big stock move, even as he is on the media circuit explaining his decision to partner with Valeant Pharmaceuticals to make a $45.6 billion hostile bid for the Botox manufacturer Allergan.

title: Justices Rule Child Pornography Restitution Is Too High
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Wednesday set aside a $3.4 million award to a victim of child pornography who had sought restitution from a man convicted of viewing images of her. That figure was too much, Justice Anthony M. Kennedy wrote for a five-justice majority, returning the case to the lower courts to apply a new and vague legal standard to find a lower amount that is neither nominal nor too severe.

title: Experian Study Highlights Differences Between Hybrid and E.V. Owners
description: While it may seem natural to want to shove people who buy electric vehicles and hybrids into the same pigeonhole, there are some slight differences between them.

title: Genting Group Says It Is Vying for a Casino License
description: The Genting Group, among the biggest gambling interests in the world, announced on Wednesday that it was vying for one of the four licenses that will be available to open a casino in upstate New York.

title: Nets Dictating Play as the Raptors Rely on a Backup
description: After two games, patterns are emerging in the first-round playoff series between the Nets and the Toronto Raptors. The teams are tied at one victory each, but so far it is the Nets who have forced the Raptors to make adjustments.

title: Tribeca First-Timers: Nate Parker
description: This is one in a series of posts on debuts at the Tribeca Film Festival.

title: Etsy Buys Grand St., a Boutique Electronics Start-Up
description: Etsy, the online marketplace for handmade and vintage goods, is poised to acquire a Brooklyn start-up called Grand St., an online boutique for electronics.

title: Two New Music Festivals to Enliven New York Stages
description: Two contemporary music festivals  one built largely around stars of the burgeoning downtown and Brooklyn scenes, and one examining unusual corners of the composition world  will keep New York concert stages animated in May and June.

title: Reporting on Love in the Hindu Kush
description: Rod Nordland, the Afghanistan bureau chief for The New York Times, discusses reporting on a couple on the run from authorities and families who do not approve of their marriage.

title: Iranian Prison Chief Is Removed After Reports of Attack on Inmates
description: TEHRAN  The head of Irans judiciary removed the countrys highest prison official on Wednesday, after what human rights advocates said was a violent raid on political prisoners in Tehrans largest prison facility.

title: Study Finds Less Green in the Congo Rain Forest
description: Years of drier conditions in the Congo River basin in central Africa appear to be affecting trees in the regions vast rain forests, scientists reported on Wednesday.

title: Siri and Google Now, Meet Cortana
description: Molly Wood tests out mobile virtual assistants, including Microsofts Cortana, to see if Siri has met her match.

title: A Discreetly Charming Womens Wear Line from Perugia
description: What do women want? Whether the aim is to explore modes of self-expression or to feel invisible, what resonates in fashion today are clothes that feel deeply personal. Perhaps thats why Sara Lanzi  a self-taught Italian designer based not in the fashion capital of Milan but in the romantic university town of Perugia  is now,after nearly a decade spent quietly producing her pieces, having something of a New York moment. The influential online retailer La Garonne and the Comme des Garons store in Chelsea, among others, have picked up her spring collection, a range of softly textured dresses and separates whose clean lines and muted tones are lightened by an exuberant fluidity. My background is the underground movement of the 90s, Lanzi explains. Do it yourself was the mood; thats where it all comes from. The line, she says, is a balance of imperfection and rigor. I have a sort of graphic attitude that drives me; nevertheless, I am far from minimalism. Its an approach that should please street-style peacocks and normcore enthusiasts alike.

title: In Allergan Bid, a Question of Insider Trading
description: One trading day after announcing the news that the huge hedge fund he runs, Pershing Square Capital Management, had partnered with Valeant Pharmaceuticals International to make an unsolicited $45.6 billion cash and stock takeover bid for Allergan, William A. Ackman is sitting on a paper profit of more than $1 billion on the Allergan shares and options he had been secretly buying over the past two months.

title: Windows Phone 8.1 Finally Catches Up to Its Rivals
description: WINDOWS PHONE 8.1 is a very good mobile operating system.

title: Entertainment Executive Denies Sexual Abuse Accusation
description: LOS ANGELES  Gary W. Goddard, an entertainment executive, has now joined three other entertainment figures who explicitly deny the claims of sexual abuse filed against them over the last week by a once-aspiring actor.

title: N.H.T.S.A. Investigates 60,000 Chevrolet Impalas for Braking Problem
description: Based on a single complaint, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating whether the forward-collision warning system on about 60,000 Chevrolet Impalas from the 2014 model year may malfunction and slow or stop the vehicle when a collision is not imminent.

title: Scene City: Stars Align, Just North of TriBeCa
description: Sophia Loren, Julianne Moore and others stars attend annual Tribeca Film Festival dinner hosted by Chanel.

title: Coloring In a Hitchcock Profile
description: Sometimes the best refuge from real trauma is simulated terror. The English playwright David Rudkin remembers cowering under his bunk in an air-raid shelter as a child. It was the early 1940s, and German bombs were raining on his hometown, Birmingham. What dreams may come to a child who fears for his life? Menacing images from Alfred Hitchcock thrillers like Rebecca, Suspicion and Foreign Correspondent, naturally.

title: The Gun Report: April 23, 2014
description: This afternoon, Georgia Gov. Nathan Deal signed into law the Safe Carry Protection Act, which allows guns in more public places than at any time in the past century, including churches, bars, and government buildings that do not have security checkpoints. Which is why critics call it the Guns Everywhere Bill.

title: G.M.s Bankruptcy Will Probably Shield It From Most New Claims
description: General Motors liability for defective ignition switches in its cars is complicated by its bankruptcy in 2009. The federal bankruptcy judge in New York approved a sale order that shielded the new company from liability for incidents that took place before July 10, 2009, the day the sale became effective.

title: Ilaria Urbinati: The Stylist for the Quieter Half of the Red Carpet
description: The New York designer Michael Bastian works with his fair share of stylists. But there is only one for whom hell not only roll out the racks, but also move the heavens. Ive pulled stuff from my own closet to ensure she has what she needs, Mr. Bastian said from his office in Chelsea on one chilly afternoon. Shes the only one I would do that for.

title: House Hunting in ... the Canadian Rockies
description: A RUSTIC FOUR-BEDROOM HOME IN THE CANADIAN ROCKIES

title: Southerners Dont Like Obamacare. They Also Dont Want to Repeal It.
description: Despite strong dislike of President Obamas handling of health care, a majority of people in three Southern states  Kentucky, Louisiana and North Carolina  would rather that Congress improve his signature health care law than repeal and replace it, according to a New York Times Upshot/Kaiser Family Foundation poll.

title: Clip: Locke
description: A scene from the film featuring Tom Hardy.

title: U.S. Sends Troops to Eastern Europe
description: The Pentagon press secretary, Rear Adm. John F. Kirby, discussed U.S. military exercises in Eastern Europe, and the Ukrainian first deputy prime minister, Vitaly Yarema, expressed gratitude.

title: The Soul of TriBeCa, if Not the Place
description: It wasnt difficult to find the Tribeca Film Festivals annual artists dinner on Tuesday night. All you had to do was search out police barricades, the flash of cameras and impermeable masses of assembled fans, all of which required the blockage of an entire city street.

title: Tribeca Film Festival: Bronies, Now a Movie Genre
