description: Were supposed to chug beer, ride motorcycles, be degrading to women and like explosions, the handlebar-mustachioed man says. Thats whats ingrained in our brains from the minute youre born and put into a blue crib.

title: Musings on Identity, From the Assimilated Exile to the Meaning of Maria
description: If you want a quick thematic summary of any piece in Ballet Hispanicos repertory, just look at the program notes for its current two-week season at the Joyce Theater. Annabelle Lopez Ochoas Madmoiselle, for instance, explores iconic male/female images and gender identity in Latin American cultures. Eduardo Vilaros Hogar is a moving meditation on immigrant identity and the meaning of home.

title: Connie Marrero, 102, Dies; Pitcher Starred in Cuba and the Majors
description: Connie Marrero, a chunky right-hander from Cuba with a windmill delivery and a wicked curveball, was nearly 39 years old when he reached the major leagues with the 1950 Washington Senators.

title: Richard Serra Wins Architectural League Prize
description: Richard Serra has been awarded the Presidents Medal from the Architectural League of New York, the first time the prize has been given to an artist.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 50
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Ukraines Military Drive in East Enters Neutral Gear, as Pact on Crisis Is Tested
description: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine  The promised Ukrainian military effort to reassert control over the restive eastern part of the country barely registered on Wednesday, but the Geneva agreement to defuse the crisis in the country frayed even further as the United States and Russia exchanged warnings and accusations of meddling in the region.

title: Frozen Soundtrack Sees Biggest Sales Week Yet
description: The sales numbers for most hit albums follow a basic pattern. They crest in the first week they go on sale, a result of front-loaded marketing campaigns, and then trail downward from there; they can lose up to 80 percent of sales in their second week, and rarely recover.

title: A Boy and His Tall Imaginary Friend Are Back
description: Martin Moone, Irish seventh grader: Do you see what I see?

title: Aspirin Benefits Some at Risk for Colon Cancer
description: Many studies have found that regular aspirin use reduces the risk for colon cancer. Now scientists have found that aspirin may benefit some people far more than others.

title: Obamas First Order of Business in Tokyo: Sushi From the Master
description: To all the perks afforded the leader of the free world, add this one: Within about 90 minutes of arriving in Tokyo on Wednesday, President Obama sat down for a meal prepared by an octogenarian sushi chef whom some regard as the master of all masters.

title: Camping by Night, Riding by Day
description: In order to ride a steep face that received minimal sunlight, Jeremy Jones and Ryland Bell spent an evening nestled on a ledge thousands of feet above their base camp in Alaskas Fairweather Range.

title: Video: Camping by Night, Riding by Day
description: In the past six years, Jeremy Jones has collaborated with Teton Gravity Research to create a trilogy of films: Deeper, Further and Higher. The films document his efforts to explore and snowboard mountains around the world under his own power. In this companion piece to its Higher Unplugged series, Teton Gravity Research provides a glimpse into Deeper.

title: Facebook Profit Tripled in First Quarter
description: SAN FRANCISCO  As Facebook reported another quarter of strong revenue and profit growth on Wednesday, its executives made one thing very clear: The companys money machine has just begun to spit out the cash.

title: Teamwork Rules the Night
description: Giving a party these days, it seems, takes a village.

title: App Smart: Selfies
description: Kit Eaton dives into three apps that can take selfies to the next level.

title: Richard H. Hoggart, Lady Chatterleys Savior, Dies at 95
description: Richard H. Hoggart, a pioneering British cultural historian who was most widely known outside academia as the star witness for Lady Chatterleys Lover in a 1960 trial that ended British censorship of that novel, died on April 10 in London. He was 95.

title: Making Your Selfies the Talk of Instagram
description: MILEY CYRUS has done many things recently, but I think my favorite among them is elevating the selfie photo to something like a modern art form.

title: S.E.C. Settles With Ex-Nvidia Employee in Insider Trading Case
description: The former Nvidia employee who the authorities contend supplied inside information about the chip makers earnings to a group of hedge fund traders and analysts has reached a settlement with securities regulators, the regulators said on Wednesday.

title: Seeking to Grow, Chobani Secures $750 Million Loan
description: The yogurt maker Chobani has struck a deal with private equity.

title: 25 Years After Tiananmen, Calls for Officials to Disclose Assets Still Unmet
description: Twenty-five years, two events, one plea: A quarter-century after the crushing of the Tiananmen democracy movement, which was driven in large part by the desire to end corruption, people are still calling on Chinas wealthy leaders and their families to reveal their financial assets.

title: Felix Salmon to Take On Web-Based Role at Fusion
description: Felix Salmon, a prominent writer on finance and other topics who announced this week that he was leaving Reuters, will join the cable network Fusion on Monday in a web-based role that runs across multiple media.

title: Hamas and the P.L.O.s Latest Accord
description: The two main Palestinian groups in the West Bank and Gaza agreed on Wednesday to form a unity government.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: Albuquerque Police Yet to Find Video of Shooting
description: ALBUQUERQUE  Albuquerques police chief said on Wednesday that the authorities had not been able to find conclusive videotape footage of the fatal police shooting this week of a 19-year-old woman who was the 24th person killed since 2010 by members of the department, which is under federal and state investigation for violating use-of-force rules.

title: 2 Women Who Offer Life Lessons in Very Different Ways
description: Bad Teacher, based on the Cameron Diaz movie by the same name, is a CBS sitcom about a middle-school teacher who is a sexy, unscrupulous gold digger.

title: Bayern Munich Controls All but the Final Score
description: MADRID  Bayern Munich got the ball, again and again and again. But Real Madrid got the goal.

title: Telling Stories, From Beowulf to the Hobo Life
description: As the composer David Lang points out in his program note for collected stories, a fascinating series of concerts he has put together through the auspices of Carnegie Hall, music has long been called upon to help tell different kinds of tales. In planning this six-concert series, which opened on Tuesday night at Zankel Hall before a packed house, Mr. Lang was a far-ranging and visionary collector of stories.

title: Justice Department on Clemency Program
description: James Cole, a deputy attorney general, announced an initiative that encourages inmates sentenced for drug crimes to apply for clemency.

title: Apples Profit Still Climbs, but Pressure is Growing
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Apples remarkable growth streak  now more than a decade old  is starting to fade a little.

title: In War-Torn Country, Laughing to Keep From Crying
description: Jesus has been declawed. In Holy Land, the French-Algerian playwright Mohamed Kacimis vaguely absurdist disquisition on the dehumanizing effects of war, now playing at Here, Jesus is a tabby cat who frightens a soldier. The soldier retaliates by maiming his paws.

title: Pictures of the Day: South Korea and Elsewhere
description: Photos from South Korea, Poland, Ukraine and the Philippines.

title: The Real Reason Red States Wont Expand Medicaid
description: By now its pretty clear that the states refusing to expand health coverage under Medicaid arent really worried about the expense. Theyre motivated entirely by ideological stubbornness  for no other reason than political spite, as President Obama said last week.

title: Full Results of The New York Times/Kaiser Family Foundation Poll
description: In four southern states, there are complex and often contradictory views of President Obamas principal domestic legislation four years after it became law.

title: Final of White House Junior International Teams
description: The final of the White House junior international team event in the Netherlands on April 4 was between Germany A (Marie Eggeling, Raffael Braun, Paul Grnke and Vemund Vikjord) and Norway (Christian Bakke, Kristoffer Hegge, Harald Eide and Kristian B. Ellingsen).

title: A Sad and Remarkable Life: Breanne Fahs Talks About Valerie Solanas
description: Valerie Solanas is most famous for shooting Andy Warhol on June 3, 1968. Solanas, a radical thinker whose SCUM Manifesto called for the elimination of the male sex, knew Warhol and was angry because she believed he was going to film a play she wrote without paying her for it. She was also afflicted with paranoid schizophrenia and spent time in several psychiatric institutions. In Valerie Solanas, Breanne Fahs, an associate professor of women and gender studies at Arizona State University, argues that Solanas is interesting for reasons other than her notoriety for shooting Warhol and her psychological troubles. In a recent email interview, Ms. Fahs discussed Solanass relationship with Warhol, why Solanass work is still relevant, the difficulties she encountered in researching the biography, and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation.

title: Some Setbacks for the Sharing Economy
description: Scrutiny of the so-called sharing economy seems to increase every day.

title: A Badly Bruised Soccer Team Tries to Beat a Reputation
description: That American Samoa has a soccer team, much less one that aspires to compete in world championships, is fairly momentous. In terms of population, its something like Pontiac, Mich., or Lynchburg, Va., putting together a local group and sending it to the Olympics. So the nickname worst soccer team in the world doesnt seem that shameful.

title: Prince George Ascending to the Throne of Trendsetter
description: The Duchess of Cambridge, the former Kate Middleton, wears a dress, and it sells out. The so-called Kate Effect has been noted for years, and though plenty of attention has been paid to the dresses she has worn on the royal familys tour in Australia and New Zealand (Prince William reportedly said that she looked like a banana when she wore a yellow Roksanda Ilincic dress in Sydney), shes not the only one in the family. On the trip, the royal family has introduced a new teeny style icon: Prince George, who, as a 9-month-old, is already having a big impact on some fashion businesses.

title: All Aboard the Orient Local
description: During one of last summers final high-season weeks, I struck up a conversation with an American backpacker in Milans Centrale train station. She was 18, in Europe for the first time, and the itinerary she reeled off resembled a similar trip I took some 15 years ago: Amsterdam, Berlin, Vienna, Venice, Madrid. The difference was that, with my Eurail Pass, Id made a continuous swoop of it; her backpack, garlanded with luggage tags, revealed that she had availed herself of discount airfare for a more higgledy-piggledy route. I had once arrived in Venice from Munich using the pass; my journey had taken 10 hours. Shed come in from Lisbon in 90 minutes.

title: Future, the Voice of Hip-Hop Today
description: The old rap star metrics of greatness? Future has no use for them. In his songs, he employs few true narratives, no real wordplay or punch lines. He raps mainly in free associative snippets, which, taken as pure text, can read as mundane.

title: F.C.C., in a Shift, Backs Fast Lanes for Web Traffic
description: WASHINGTON  The principle that all Internet content should be treated equally as it flows through cables and pipes to consumers looks all but dead.

title: Spring Shopping: Return to the Trenches, but Softly
description: Milder April temperatures are bringing out a profusion of chic trench coats, which this season look freshest in softer, less structured shapes. The quintessential transition piece, a breezy trench will be a welcome antidote to your winter outerwear, which got way too much play this year. Throw one on with jeans and an easy T-shirt for the weekend, as did Karlie Kloss (shown here), who wore a slouchy gray style and ballet flats to pal around with Taylor Swift, and wrap one over tailored pieces for work or a silky dress or jumpsuit for evening.

title: Music Mix: Spirituality and Protest
description: The subject matter of Rebel Music: Race, Empire and the New Muslim Youth Culture could not be more far-reaching unless its author, Hisham D. Aidi, had unearthed data about youth culture and musical influences on other planets. As far as Earth goes, his highly original and ambitious book has got it covered.

title: Growlers Finding a Refuge in Dance
description: The days of abrasion are seemingly gone in hip-hop  smoothness of various stripes rules the radio, thanks to years of cross-pollination with R&B and pop. For rappers with real tension and grit in their voices, this shift has made for something of a mini-crisis  theyre no longer welcome in their old home.

title: Sightseeing With Ears Wide Open
description: Have you planned your summer vacation yet? Any thoughts as to what places youd like to hear this year?

title: From Japan, a Jazzy Interpretation of Gershwin
description: Heres something you dont see every night at Avery Fisher Hall: the members of the New York Philharmonic tapping their feet and nodding their heads, smiling, during a concertos cadenza. And heres another: the orchestras principal trombonist, Joseph Alessi; its bassist David J. Grossman; and the saxophonist Allen Won coming to the front of the stage to join the soloist in a Thelonious Monk encore.

title: After the BP Oil Spill
description: To the Editor:

title: De Blasios City Managers
description: To the Editor:

title: Worlds Fair Memories
description: To the Editor:

title: Newly Released Books
description: This months new fiction, including novels in translation and a story collection, explores love and the theater in the 1970s, terminal illness, memory loss, winning the lottery and the plight of a small pig.

title: Turning Away the Talented
description: To the Editor:

title: The Greatest Good Cause
description: To the Editor:

title: Limiting the Use of Affirmative Action
Cellphone Cases to Prepare You for Anything, Even a Flat Tire
description: PROTECTIVE phone cases have become practically a necessity since the introduction of smartphones. After all, why pay hundreds of dollars for a phone and not spend a little bit more to protect it?

title: Apples Stock Split: Attracting the Wrong Crowd?
description: Suppose I have a delicious pie (apple, lets say), that is divided into four slices. And then I decide to divide it again, into eight slices. Do the individual slices become more delicious?

title: Q. and A. | Christo on Jeanne-Claude, the Art of the Process and Trying to Drape a River in Fabric
description: Christo probably isnt the first name you think of when considering quintessentially New York artists. Yet he landed in the city nearly 50 years ago, arriving from France with his late spouse and creative partner Jeanne-Claude. They moved into a warehouse in SoHo in the early 1960s, converting the building into a residence, studio, gallery and corporate headquarters, complete with its own generator. (The power didnt go out during Sandy.)

title: Lions to the Ballot Box
description: The time for complaining is at an end. Action must be taken. Accountability must be demanded. Muscle must be flexed. Power must be exercised.

title: The Folly of Saving What You Kill
description: SCAFFOLDING went up last week around the former American Folk Art Museum building on West 53rd Street. It was the first step in the Museum of Modern Arts widely reviled plan to demolish that admired work of contemporary architecture, which MoMA purchased in 2011. Although most of the building will land in a Dumpster, the saga of dismemberment will be prolonged for the Folk Art Museums intimately monumental 82-foot-high facade. In response to protests, MoMA has said it would detach and preserve the facades 63 textured copper-bronze panels.

title: Openings, Events and Sales for the Week of April 24
description: Events

title: At the Met Gala, a Strict Dress Code
description: Gone are the fabled society queens and their blue-blood escorts, replaced by quarterbacks, mannequins and Jimmy Fallon. Forgotten, too, are the days when the fashionable elite made their stately ascent of the Metropolitan Museum of Arts broad stairway, all the Nans and Pats and Micas stopping for air kisses along the way.

title: The Next Big Thing in Fashion? Big Things
description: Last month, Rihanna arrived at Heathrow Airport in London wearing a humongous star-spangled backpack. In its immensity, it was akin to the giant sack used to pilfer all of Whovilles gifts in How the Grinch Stole Christmas.

title: Conjuring Images of a Bionic Future
description: Dick Loizeaux recently found himself meandering through a noisy New York nightclub. This was unusual; Mr. Loizeaux, a 65-year-old former pastor, began suffering hearing loss nearly a decade ago, and nightclubs are not really his scene. Theyre the absolute worst place to hear anybody talk, he said.

title: Port Authority Again Delays Vote on 80-Story Tower at World Trade Center Site
description: After failing to gain enough support to provide additional subsidies to complete the stalled construction of a $2.3 billion, 80-story tower at the site of the former World Trade Center in Lower Manhattan, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey decided on Wednesday to once again delay a decision on the matter.

title: Charles James and Me
description: When the Metropolitan Museum of Art Costume Institute opens Charles James: Beyond Fashion on May 8, the exhibition will have 70 outfits, making it the largest show devoted to the designer, who died in 1978 at age 72. Among them are the Taxi dress, designed in 1929, which wrapped around the body and fastened with Bakelite clasps, so that a woman could slip into it while in the back of a taxi, and the Clover Leaf dress of 1952, which did not touch the floor but undulated while the woman walked.

title: Following Armenias Global Diaspora
description: Scout Tufankjian has been traveling the world photographing Armenian communities large and small, where traditions endure amid diversity.

title: Zynga Founder Leaves Daily Role at Struggling Game Maker
description: Mark Pincus, the founder of Zynga, is stepping back from the once-hot social gaming company as its new leader seeks a turnaround.

title: Welcome to Comcast Country
description: PHILADELPHIA  COMCASTS executive vice president, David L. Cohen, did not seem fazed when Senator Al Franken warned at a recent Judiciary Committee hearing that the companys proposed acquisition of Time Warner Cable would result in fewer choices, higher prices and even worse service for my constituents. Comcast argues that the merger will not decrease competition among cable television or broadband Internet providers because the two companies do not directly compete  though the reason for that is that they already maintain virtual monopolies in many of their service areas.

title: Estimate of Where Obama Lacks White Support
description: Obama lacks support from white voters in part of the South.

title: Hot Spots: The Early Buzz
description: Only a quarter of the way into the 2014 election cycle, a variety of political ads are making waves not just for their effectiveness, but also for their zaniness.

title: Southern Whites Loyalty to G.O.P. Nearing That of Blacks to Democrats
description: President Obamas landslide victory in 2008 was supposed to herald the beginning of a new Democratic era. And yet, six years later, there is not even a clear Democratic majority in the country, let alone one poised for 30 years of dominance.

title: Ads Look to Stand Out Amid the Political Clutter
description: WASHINGTON  The 2014 election cycle has ushered in a rush of political advertising, with campaign ads airing as early as last spring and record-shattering spending for the first quarter of the election year. Between television commercials (some top-notch nuggets of narrative storytelling) and web ads (which allow for a more madcap approach), nearly every day seems to bring about a new visual treat. Here is a look at some ads that managed to cut through the clutter: the good, the bad, and the zany.

title: Working-Class Fathers Shouldnt Be So Easily Dismissed
description: Heres a headline that appears on Slate: White Working-Class Women Should Raise Kids Alone. (The full headline when you open the article reads: Just Say No/For white working-class women, it makes sense to stay single mothers. The should headline appears as you scroll.)

title: Gawkers, Welcome: House and Garden Tours
description: Speculating about what lies behind the closed doors and garden gates of homes owned by celebrities  or those who just have money and taste  is something of a national pastime. But once a year, in the spring and summer, many of those properties are open to the public, as house-and-garden tours are organized around the country. In many cases, the tours raise funds for nonprofit organizations. So its time to stop wondering and start exploring.

title: The Unsettling Thing About Ellen
description: Oh, to be Ellen DeGeneress decorator. Or her architect. Or her real estate agent. Or even her movers.

title: Our Mother, the Dictator
description: David Adler accepts the trade-offs of being married to an interior designer. For the pleasure of living in beautifully decorated homes, he cedes nearly all creative control to his wife, Amie Weitzman, a principal of the Manhattan firm Weitzman Halpern.

title: Essentially Japanese
description: Up until the 15th century, Japan embraced showy ornamentation like other powers. That changed when a shogun with a taste for simplicity moved the country toward the spare aesthetic for which it has become renowned.

title: Big Fish, in Any Size Pond
description: Japanese koi are domesticated carp prized for their size, color, patterns and luster. They are coldblooded, but the people who nurture them in backyard ponds and enter them in competitions are as passionate as any Pekingese owner. Mat McCann, 40, the British-born manager at Quality Koi Farm, a 43-acre business owned by Joseph Zuritsky, in Carneys Point, N.J., uses Japanese stock and methods to breed international champions. (This ambition is not unlike perfecting American truffles, mozzarella and soccer players.) The farm is open to the public from spring through autumn, and collectors travel from all points to peer into its mud ponds. (The interview was edited and condensed.)

title: A Return to Nigeria
description: When I was 7 years old my father bought me a Bag of Laughs. It was the early 1980s and, as with most every school morning in Lagos, Nigeria, we were stuck in traffic. My father was at the wheel, listening to Bob Marley on the eight-track. I sat in the back, staring at the street peddlers walking in between lanes jostling can openers, batteries and other random items at car windows.

title: A Star Awaits Its Applause
description: Spotlight Silver, David Rockwells latest design for the Rug Company, seems like a not-so-subtle nod to his theatrical leanings. After all, Mr. Rockwell has created sets for Broadway shows like Hairspray and Kinky Boots, not to mention the Academy Awards. But in a recent interview, he was more focused on the technical details of the hand-knotted rug, pointing out that its gray shades become darker the farther they radiate from its shimmering silk center. The spotlight motif came from experimentation, playing with that transition from silk to wool, so it feels like one continuous ombr, he said.

title: Embellishments With a Serious Goal
description: More than 60 designers, including Barclay Butera, Sara Gilbane, Miles Redd and James Huniford, have created room vignettes for Design on a Dime, Housing Works annual benefit. Theres a party Thursday night, and starting Friday, you can shop those rooms, with prices up to 70 percent off retail. Proceeds go to Hull Street, a housing development for formerly homeless New Yorkers living with H.I.V./AIDS. Since Mr. Huniford conceived the event a decade ago, it has raised $6 million. It was important from the beginning that the money went directly to the cause, he said. I always worked hard to find sponsors to pay for the operating part of it. (This years sponsor is Elle Decor magazine.) The Pierre Frey table, donated by Bungalow 5, and shown in a room by Arlene Angard Designs, is $290. Metropolitan Pavilion, 125 West 18th Street (Avenue of the Americas); 347-473-7457 or housingworks.org.

title: Discounts at Gretel Home, John Robshaw, A+R and Miraval
description: Clocks, kitchenware, textiles and many other items are up to 50 percent off at Gretel Home while supplies last (a peeler by Normann Copenhagen, regularly $17, is about $12; a Toc-Toc clock by Koziol, regularly $79, is about $55); 786-247-9003, gretelhome.com.

title: Jewish Designers and Modernism
description: Designing Home: Jews and Mid-Century Modernism, opening Thursday at the Contemporary Jewish Museum in San Francisco, offers a multilayered look at the close relationship between Jewish architects and designers and the avant-garde. Curated by Donald Albrecht, the show unpacks a history of American-born and European creators, several connected to the Bauhaus, who were drawn to six nodes of progressive culture in America, including Black Mountain College in North Carolina, the Institute of Design in Chicago and Pond Farm Workshops in Northern California. Its 34 exemplars, including Henry Dreyfuss, Marcel Breuer and Anni Albers, found respectful supporters in these socially conscious institutions that fostered a network that sustained their visions. Featured are more than 120 items, including Julius Shulmans photo of Richard Neutras 1946 Kaufmann House, and Alvin Lustigs 1949 chair for Paramount Furniture. Until Oct. 6. Information: 415-655-7800 or thecjm.org.

title: Japanese Design: Conflict in the Far East
description: Japanese furnishings have inspired legions of designers. But while most praise the simplicity of form, Joey Roth, an industrial designer based in Southern California, sees something more.

title: Puzzled but Positive, Giants Learn Offense That Has Shades of Green Bay
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  For 10 years, the Giants offensive system was largely unchanged, as familiar to the teams fans as their work commutes  and, in the end, about as beloved.

title: Operating Earnings Rise 12% at Boeing
description: Boeing said on Wednesday that its core operating earnings rose 12 percent in the first quarter, beating analysts expectations as the company continued to capitalize on the demand for new passenger planes.

title: Steve Backer, a Force for Jazz at Major Labels, Dies at 76
description: Steve Backer, who ran successful jazz programs at several major record labels, shaping the careers of visionary avant-gardists like the saxophonist-composers Anthony Braxton and Henry Threadgill as well as potent crossover bands like the Brecker Brothers, died on April 10 in Englewood, N.J. He was 76.

title: Vermont Will Require Labeling of Genetically Altered Foods
description: Going further than any state so far, Vermont on Wednesday passed a law requiring the labeling of foods that contain genetically engineered ingredients.

title: Eastern Europe Frets About NATOs Ability to Curb Russia
description: OVER CONSTANTA, Romania  High over the Romanian border, a sophisticated NATO surveillance plane kept a close watch on Russian movements below. Its radar screens came alive with a cat-and-mouse game between a Russian surveillance jet buzzing an American guided missile destroyer in the Black Sea and a squadron of NATO fighter jets that chased it away.

title: As Wine Fetches Staggering Sums, Fakery Claims Rise
description: When the Atlanta wine collector Julian LeCraw Jr. spent $91,400 on a single bottle in 2006, he was convinced that the 1787 vintage from the renowned Chateau dYquem in France was worth the lofty price, then the highest ever for a white wine. Now, Mr. LeCraw says he has been left with the bitter aftertaste of a fake.

title: Trying to Bolster the Image of Frozen Meals as Sales Lag
description: A NEW campaign is trying to reverse the declining salesof frozen meals in recent years.

title: Sweeping Measure Expanding Rights of Gun Owners Is Signed Into Georgia Law
description: ATLANTA  A plan to bolster the legal rights of gun owners that opponents have derided as the guns everywhere bill was signed into law on Wednesday by Gov. Nathan Deal.

title: Yanks Pineda Ejected After Pine Tar Is Spotted
description: BOSTON  After his start against the Boston Red Sox on April 10, Michael Pinedas denial that his hand was covered in pine tar was mostly disregarded as absurd. Television cameras clearly showed a brown substance, and no matter what Pineda claimed afterward, people recognized it for what it was: an illegal attempt to get a better grip on the baseball.

title: Alistair MacLeod, a Novelist in No Hurry, Dies at 77
description: Alistair MacLeod, a Canadian writer whose only novel  composed over 13 years and extracted from him only after a campaign by his publisher involving surveillance, subterfuge and outright bribery  brought him literary fame, a lucrative prize and a bottle of Scotch, died on Sunday in Windsor, Ontario. He was 77.

title: Meet Me at the Fair
description: Lets talk future.

title: In Return to the Pool, Phelps Talks About Fun
description: MESA, Ariz.  Around noon Wednesday, the teenage swimming prodigy Michael Andrew met Michael Phelps, many of whose national age-group records Andrew has broken. After shaking Phelpss hand and hearing Phelps say, Nice to meet you, Andrew walked away beaming. That was pretty cool, he said.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 23, 2014
description: April 23, 2014

title: Hyness Lack of Curiosity May Come at a Cost
description: Tracking the explanations of the former Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, for his offices malpractices is like hunting a rabbit: The prey keeps bouncing here and there before disappearing under a hedgerow.

title: Colombias President Reinstates a Mayor He Ousted
description: BOGOT, Colombia  Residents of this capital city may feel as if they are suffering political whiplash after President Juan Manuel Santos on Wednesday reinstated the mayor that he had removed from office only a month earlier.

title: A Road Movie, but With No Rest Stops
description: How interesting can a film that takes place almost entirely inside a car be? The writer-director Steven Knight asked himself that question when conceiving his road movie Locke, which spends its 85-minute running time with just one on-screen character (Tom Hardy in the title role) as he drives to London from Birmingham and conducts phone conversations that are by turns distressing and contemplative.

title: Strict Cost-Cutters Who Want to Spend $45 Billion on a Takeover
description: Visitors to the New Jersey offices of Valeant, the ambitious pharmaceuticals company, are confronted with an unusual sight when they walk through the front door: a basketball court.

title: Moldova, the Next Ukraine
description: CHISINAU, Moldova  If there were an Olympic competition for bravest country in the world, the gold medal might well go to Moldova. Wobbly politicians from Europe and America should come here to get spinal transplants.

title: Fixes for the Port Authority
description: In what is certainly a departure from standard practice, the normally secretive commissioners at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey are asking publicly for advice about how to do their job.

title: Nepal Tries to Save Season as Everest Tourists Depart
description: NEW DELHI  A delegation of government officials from Nepals Ministry of Culture, Tourism and Civil Aviation will visit the Mount Everest base camp on Thursday in an attempt to salvage the expedition season even as Sherpa mountain guides, support staff and foreign tour operators, shaken by an avalanche that killed over a dozen Nepalese guides last Friday, begin to pack up their gear and head home.

title: Haiti in the Shadow of Cholera
description: The problem of ending Haitis cholera epidemic does not stem from an absence of planning. There is a 10-year plan to eradicate cholera from Hispaniola, the island Haiti shares with the Dominican Republic, by 2022. Within the 10-year plan is a two-year plan to get the 10-year plan up and running. The United Nations has its own two-year plan to support that two-year plan. To tackle the crisis immediately, with treatment, vaccinations and other prevention efforts, there was a one-year plan for last year, and a new one for 2014.

title: Reviving Clemency, Serving Justice
description: Throughout American history, presidents from Abraham Lincoln to Harry Truman to Gerald Ford have used the power of executive clemency to help bring an end to war, or to promote national healing in its aftermath.

title: Five Men Are Charged in a Brooklyn Beating
description: Five men who prosecutors said were associated with a Hasidic neighborhood watch group in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, were indicted on Wednesday in connection with a brutal beating of a gay black man in December.

title: At Northwestern, a Blitz to Defeat an Effort to Unionize
description: EVANSTON, Ill.  A National Labor Relations Board official took a historic step last month in ruling that Northwesterns scholarship football players should be considered employees of the university and therefore had the right to unionize like other workers.

title: On Whiteboards, in Black Ink, Grim Descriptions of Those Lost as Ferry Sank
description: JINDO, South Korea  No. 150, a boy, had a snaggletooth. No. 111, a girl, was wearing pink slippers, and an elastic hairband on her right wrist. No. 87 had on pajama pants with teddy bears.

title: Balloon Lets Builders Check Out Future Towers Views
description: A big white balloon appeared in New York this week. First on the Lower East Side, then uptown, where 57th Street meets the East River.

title: Turkey Offers Condolences to Armenians Over Killings
description: ISTANBUL  For the first time, the Turkish government offered condolences on Wednesday to the descendants of Armenians who were killed by the Ottoman Army in 1915. But it stood by its official position that the events were not a genocide, as they have been called by several Western governments and international organizations.

title: New Labor Contract Will Cost M.T.A. $525 Million
description: When Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo revealed to great fanfare last week that a deal on a new labor contract had been reached with New York Citys subway and bus workers, officials did not reveal how much it would cost.

title: Contradictory Reports on North Koreas Nuclear Preparations
description: A senior South Korean Defense Ministry official said Wednesday that North Korea has virtually completed all preparations it would need to conduct a nuclear test. On Tuesday, amid reports of increased activity at a nuclear test site in the North, the website 38 North, run by the U.S.-Korea Institute at Johns Hopkins University, said the country appeared unlikely to conduct a nuclear test during President Obamas visit to Seoul this weekend. Using commercial satellite imagery, it said that recent operations at Punggye-ri, a test site, had not reached the high level of intensity that occurred before past detonations. The South Korean official, who was speaking on the condition of anonymity at a news briefing, said that the United States and South Korean officials used more powerful spy satellite imagery.

title: New York Police Twitter Strategy Has Unforeseen Consequences
description: The New York Police Department has long seen its crime-fighting strategies emulated across the country and around the world.

title: Kenya: Bomb in Nairobi Kills Two Police Officers
description: A bomb exploded outside a police station in Nairobi on Wednesday evening, the Interior Ministry said, killing two officers. The bombing is the latest in a series of attacks to rock Kenya since last month. There have been no claims of responsibility, but many believe that Al-Shabab, a Somali Islamist group, is responsible.

title: Wrigley Field at 100: Futilitys Friendly Confines
description: CHICAGO  For Wrigley Fields 100th birthday, baseballs schedule makers could have included one of the National Leagues most senior franchises  the Cincinnati Reds, or the Giants, once of New York and now from San Francisco  to play the Cubs. But they settled on the Arizona Diamondbacks, an expansion team in 1998.

title: A Place to Slip Into Something Comfortable
description: A beguilingly gentle magic whispers amid the speechifying of Casa Valentina, Harvey Fiersteins prolix play about cross-dressing in the Catskills in the early 1960s. This intermittent, quiet enchantment is generated by men who otherwise tend to obstreperousness. But put any one of them in front of a mirror, with a tube of lipstick and some eyeliner, and he falls into a wordless rapture, as silent and luminous as a newly lighted candle.

title: On the Lookout
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Stanley Newman is the editor of the nationally syndicated Newsday Crossword and the author/editor of more than 150 books. When last we saw him here in The New York Times, he was making us laugh with a quip theme inspired by his son Marc, and hes back today with a theme that resides inside the grid.

title: Britain: Blair Speaks Out on Islamic Extremism
description: Tony Blair, the former British prime minister, said Wednesday that the spread of Islamic extremism represents the biggest threat to global security of the 21st century. Mr. Blair, who is Middle East envoy for the United States, the European Union, Russia and the United Nations, spoke of a titanic struggle going on between those who want the region to embrace the modern world and those who instead want to create a politics of religious difference and exclusivity. Mr. Blair also embraced the military government in Egypt that overthrew the elected president, Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood, calling it the absolutely necessary rescue of a nation despite the repression that has followed.

title: Debris Not Connected to Missing Malaysian Jet, Officials Say
description: Objects that washed ashore at a small coastal town in Western Australia have been ruled out as debris linked to the missing Malaysia Airlines jet, the authorities said Thursday. The material was found on a beach more than a thousand miles from the part of the Indian Ocean where the search for the plane continues. On Wednesday, the Malaysian government said it was forming an international investigation team to assess what had happened to the plane.

title: For Cuomo and de Blasio, Still Some Good Old Days
description: ALBANY  With disaster recovery as a backdrop, Mayor Bill de Blasio and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo played exceedingly nice here on Wednesday during a daylong conference on Hurricane Sandy, adding a brief but mostly sunny chapter to New Yorks most hot-and-cold political relationship.

title: A Defiant Rancher Savors the Audience That Rallied to His Side
description: BUNKERVILLE, Nev.  Cliven Bundy stood by the Virgin River up the road from the armed checkpoint at the driveway of his ranch, signing autographs and posing for pictures. For 55 minutes, Mr. Bundy held forth to a clutch of supporters about his views on the troubled state of America  the overreaching federal government, the harassment of Western ranchers, the societal upheaval caused by abortion, even musing about whether slavery was so bad.

title: New York City Council Seeks Bigger Police Dept. and Free School Meals
description: The New York City Council is urging Mayor Bill de Blasio to offer free lunch to all public school students, hire 1,000 more police officers and expand the summer job program for teenagers.

title: Miller Hopes to Bring a Bit of Miami Back to Memphis
description: MEMPHIS  When Mike Miller dressed for work on Wednesday morning, he faced the usual dilemma: blue sweatpants or gray sweatpants? He went with gray.

title: F.B.I. Informant Is Tied to Cyberattacks Abroad
description: WASHINGTON  An informant working for the F.B.I. coordinated a 2012 campaign of hundreds of cyberattacks on foreign websites, including some operated by the governments of Iran, Syria, Brazil and Pakistan, according to documents and interviews with people involved in the attacks.

title: Finally Settled, St. Louis Has Found His Form
description: After nearly two months as a Ranger, Martin St. Louis is finally back to being Martin St. Louis. With two goals and three assists in the first three playoff games against the Philadelphia Flyers, St. Louis is back to the form that won him two N.H.L. scoring titles and a Hart Trophy as the leagues most valuable player.

title: Red Wings Speed Trumped by Brains and Brawn
description: DETROIT  The narrative for the Bruins-Red Wings series was plausible and logical. Boston, the winner of the Presidents Trophy for the N.H.L.s best record, would be the aggressor, using its burliness and noted agitators like Brad Marchand to set the tone. Detroit, which survived an injury-marred regular season to squeak into the playoffs as the Eastern Conferences eighth seed, would use its youthful speed to counterattack.

title: Forecast Cut on Spending for Health
description: WASHINGTON  The Congressional Budget Office has reduced by one-third its estimate of how much more states will spend on Medicaid in the coming decade because of the Affordable Care Act.

title: The Americans Recap: the Oliver North Story
description: With Oliver North sharing story credit, Episode 9 finds Philip and Elizabeth finally making it onto the secret United States military base that theyve had in their sights for months. Considering the number of people theyve killed to get there, one hopes that their attempt to gather secrets concerning Operation Martial Eagle  the name of the shows fictional United States military camp that trains Contras to crush Nicaraguas Sandinista government  is successful.

title: On a Gusty Night, the Mets Preserve a Victory With a Whirlwind Play
description: For the Mets to preserve their lead in the ninth inning of Wednesdays game against the St. Louis Cardinals, three things needed to happen over the course of about 10 seconds, Manager Terry Collins said.

title: What Female Voters Say About Womens Safety in Mumbai
description: While Indias financial capital has long prided itself on being relatively safe for women, thegang rape of a photojournalistin an abandoned mill building in August brought that reputation into question.

title: Boy, 9, Is Found Dead in the Bronx
description: A 9-year-old boy was found dead on Wednesday outside a 46-story high-rise in the Bronx, the authorities said.

title: A Photographers Tender Exploration of Fatherhood
description: In this weekly series, Ts photo editors share the most compelling visual projects theyve discovered.

title: F.D.A. Will Propose New Regulations for E-Cigarettes
description: WASHINGTON  The Food and Drug Administration will propose sweeping new rules on Thursday that for the first time would extend its regulatory authority from cigarettes to electronic cigarettes, popular nicotine delivery devices that have grown into a multibillion-dollar business with virtually no federal oversight or protections for American consumers.

title: Times Minute | Regulating E-Cigarettes
description: On the Minute, the push to regulate e-cigarettes, Northwesterns football players to vote on a union and Amazon to stream HBO series.

title: Word of the Day | substantive
description: substantive\sb-stn-tiv\ adjective

title: Why Chocolate Is Good for Us
description: This column appears in the April 27, 2014, issue of The New York Times Magazine.In recent years, large-scale epidemiological studies have found that people whose diets include dark chocolate have a lower risk of heart disease than those whose diets do not. Other research has shown that chocolate includes flavonols, natural substances that can reduce the risk of disease. But it hasnt been clear how these flavonols could be affecting the human body, especially the heart. New findings from Virginia Tech and Louisiana State University, however, suggest an odd explanation for chocolates goodness: It improves health largely by being indigestible.

title: Investors Bet on Live-Streamed Spinning Classes in the Home
description: At first blush, Pelotons spinning classes appear little different from those at better-known outfits like SoulCycle: enthusiastic exercise buffs pedaling under pounding loud music and energetic instructor exhortations. But a session last Friday revealed something different: video cameras recording the instructor, Marion Roaman, for the benefit of customers following along at home on their Peloton bikes.

title: Times Minute | Regulating E-Cigarettes
description: In the Video

title: Wright-Phillipss Hat Trick Leads Red Bulls
description: Bradley Wright-Phillips scored his first goal of the Major League Soccer season, added a second before halftime and then capped his hat trick by converting a penalty kick in the second half as the Red Bulls defeated Houston Dynamo, 4-0, Wednesday night at Red Bull Arena in Harrison, N.J. Wright-Phillips, 29, had not been expected to play after missing training on Tuesday with the flu.

title: Anti-Corruption Group Finds Fault With European Union
description: BRUSSELS  A prominent anti-corruption group on Thursday plans to report serious shortcomings in the management and governance of the European Unions core institutions, as public confidence in Brussels remains at a low before elections next month.

title: India Election Digest: April 24
description: What you need to know about Indias parliamentary elections on Thursday: In the sixth phase of the vote, 117 seats across 11 states and the union territory of Puducherry are at stake. The regions that are going to vote: Bihar (7 seats), Madhya Pradesh (10), Assam (6), Chhattisgarh (7), Jammu and Kashmir (1), Jharkhand (4), Maharashtra (19), Rajasthan (5), Tamil Nadu (39), Uttar Pradesh (12), West Bengal (6), Puducherry (1).

title: Ex-Head of Blue Angels Faces Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  The former commanding officer of the Blue Angels naval squadron was removed from duty at a San Diego base last week after being accused of tolerating sexual harassment and hazing while in charge of the famous aviators group, the Navy said Wednesday.

title: Up Close on Baseballs Borders
description: An interactive map of the geography of baseball fandom.

title: A Map of Baseball Nation
description: Facebook data reveals the most popular team in every ZIP code.

title: Tainted Food in China Cited in Cyclists Failed Doping Test
description: An Australian cyclist who tested positive for a performance-enhancing drug has had a potential ban from the sport lifted after the sports governing body said he probably consumed the substance accidentally during a race in China.

title: Report Finds Widespread Water Pollution in China
description: Nearly 60 percent of areas being monitored for water pollution last year by the government had very poor or relatively poor underground water quality, according to a report by the Chinese Ministry of Land and Resources.

title: Whats on Thursday
description: 7 A.M. (Oxygen) ATONEMENT (2007) Saoirse Ronan received an Oscar nomination for her portrayal of Briony, a 13-year-old aspiring playwright who accuses the son (James McAvoy, above, with Ms. Ronan) of a family servant  and the lover of her older sister (Keira Knightley)  of a crime in this drama directed by Joe Wright and based on the Ian McEwan novel. Romola Garai and Vanessa Redgrave play Briony at different times in her life. The main casualty of the films long, murky middle and end sections is the big moral theme  and also the ingenious formal gimmick  that provides the book with some of its intensity and much of its cachet, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. As the title suggests, Atonement is fundamentally about guilt and the attempt to overcome it, and about the tricky, tragically imperfect power of art to compensate for real-life crimes and misdemeanors. The film received six more Oscar nominations, including one for best picture, and won for Dario Marianellis score, featuring the pianist Jean-Yves Thibaudet and a clacking typewriter.

title: Corrections: April 24, 2014
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Tamil Nadu Warms Up to Modi and His Party
description: CHENNAI, India  It will take him 12 to 15 hours on a bus, but S. Dorai, a 38-year-old cabdriver in the capital of Tamil Nadu, said he was determined to travel to his native Kanyakumari, at the southernmost tip of India, to cast his vote on Thursday.

title: Americans Die in Grim Trend in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Three Americans were killed at a private hospital in Kabul on Thursday morning when an Afghan police officer turned his gun on them, officials said, in the latest in a string of attacks against Western civilians here.

title: Obama Suffers Setbacks in Japan and the Mideast
description: TOKYO  President Obama encountered setbacks to two of his most cherished foreign-policy projects on Thursday, as he failed to achieve a trade deal that undergirds his strategic pivot to Asia and the Middle East peace process suffered a potentially irreparable breakdown.

title: Test Yourself | English, April 24, 2014
description: Take the Quiz

title: Britain Moves to Prevent Young People From Joining Syrian War
description: LONDON  The British police said on Thursday that officers would work with charitable organizations to prevent British Muslims from traveling to Syria as fighters in the civil war, urging women in particular to report would-be jihadists so that we can intervene and help.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Equipped to Dive, Students Make Aquarium Their Classroom
description: In Equipped to Dive, Students Make Aquarium Their Classroom, Lisa W. Foderaro writes about an unusual internship that some New York City high school students have.

title: Mumbais Slum Dwellers Wary of Recycled Promises
description: MUMBAI, India  The slum dwellers who make up 60 percent of this citys 18 million people are too diverse to vote as a bloc, but they all have one thing in common: their cramped homes, which usually lack running water and electricity.

title: Do You Support Affirmative Action in College Admissions?
description: The Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday that Michigans ban on affirmative action at public universities was constitutional. Other states have similar bans, and more may follow suit.

title: The Real House Candidates of Beverly Hills
description: Brent Roske lives on a 45-foot yacht off the coast of Marina del Rey, which is technically on the Pacific Ocean, but for jurisdictional purposes is considered part of the city of Los Angeles and, more to the point, the 33rd Congressional District of California. In January, Henry Waxman, the liberal stalwart who has represented the district with little resistance since the year after Roske was born, announced that he would not seek re-election. Now Roske, who is 39, is part of a field of 18 candidates hoping to represent the heartland of Beverly Hills, Malibu and Bel-Air in the United States Congress.

title: Following the Global Armenian Diaspora
description: Scout Tufankjian recalls childhood afternoons at her grandmothers house, paging through Armenian magazines and wondering about the people she saw in photos from all over the globe.

title: New York Today: The Nanny Van
description: Good morning on this breezy Thursday.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: Wartime Claim Paid, China Releases a Japanese Vessel
description: HONG KONG  A court in Shanghai released a Japanese commercial ship from impoundment in eastern China on Thursday, after the ships owner paid a civil compensation claim dating back to the wartime invasion that remains a source of bitterness in China.

title: Russia to Start Drills, Warning Ukraine Over Mobilization
description: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine  Defying warnings from Moscow not to confront pro-Russian militants entrenched in towns across eastern Ukraine, government forces on Thursday revived a stalled operation to regain control by force but had little to show for their efforts other than Russian military drills on Ukraines border and heightened alarm about Moscows next move.

title: Alstom Denies Report of G.E. Takeover Bid, but Its Shares Surge
description: Updated, 8:11 a.m. | PARIS  Shares of the French industrial conglomerate Alstom, which makes high-speed trains and energy turbines, soared on Thursday on a report that General Electric was seeking to buy the company for about $13 billion.

title: Newlyweds on the Run: A Challenge in Reporting
description: Since March, The Times has reported on Zakia and Mohammad Ali, a young Afghan couple whose families have fought to keep them apart because of religious differences. Now, as newlyweds they are on the run, fearing for their safety. Afghan laws and customs have made coverage a challenge for the reporter Rod Nordland, the photographers Mauricio Lima and Diego Ibarra Snchez and the video journalist Ben C. Solomon.

title: Photos: The Relays That Never Stopped Running
description: When the Penn Relays kick off Thursday, with an expected 22,000 runners and 110,000 fans crowding into Franklin Field in Philadelphia for the three-day event, it will be held on the same site for the 120th straight year. It is quite a run, so to speak, for an event that started as a single relay and was aimed at keeping the University of Pennsylvanias track team from falling into oblivion.

title: Offering Thanks to Chinas Business Groundbreakers
description: In the Phoenix airport, en route to China, I recently had an encounter with a reader of this blog.

title: Bieber Apology Over Shrine Visit Falls Flat in China
description: Even after his apology for posting photos of himself visiting the Yasukuni Shrine in Tokyo, which honors thousands of Japans military dead but also Class A war criminals, Justin Bieber remains a target of outrage in China.

title: Trying to Bring Baldwins Complex Voice Back to the Classroom
description: James Baldwins 1953 novel, Go Tell It on the Mountain, about a Harlem teenagers search for meaning, quickly became a classic, along with his searing essays about race published a decade later in the book The Fire Next Time. But in recent years Baldwins presence has diminished in many high school classrooms.

title: Daily Report: F.C.C. to Propose a Web Fast Lane
description: The principle that all Internet content should be treated equally as it flows through cables and pipes to consumers looks all but dead, Edward Wyatt reports.

title: Hurt by Vehicle Recalls, G.M.s Profit Falls 85%
description: DETROIT  General Motors, the nations largest automaker, reported on Thursday that its net income in the first quarter fell about 85 percent, mostly because of costs associated with the recalls of millions of vehicles.

title: The Cloud Industry Needs Aereo to Win. But Consumers Need Something Better.
description: The best way to think about Aereo, the company at the center of this weeks Supreme Court battle over the future of computing, is as an example of legal performance art. Aereo is based entirely on a legalistic leap of faith: If its legal to set up an antenna and record a TV show at your own house, which it is, shouldnt it also be legal to rent an antenna and server space at a big data center, and then stream the show over the Internet to your computer, tablet or set-top box?

title: Cutting Costs and Plotting Mergers
description: Visitors to the New Jersey offices of Valeant, the ambitious pharmaceuticals company, are confronted with an unusual sight when they walk through the front door: a basketball court, David Gelles writes in DealBook. The building was previously home to a Y.M.C.A, which deemed it too run-down to host community activities. So when the Y.M.C.A. moved to a new building, Valeant moved in.

title: Bare Knuckles at Sothebys Auction House
description: Updated, 9:24 p.m. | Directors of Sothebys gathered in their wood-paneled boardroom with an urgent goal: how to mollify Daniel S. Loeb, the outspoken hedge fund mogul who is the auction houses largest shareholder.

title: CreatureCast: Cuttlefish Camouflage
description: Cuttlefish can alter their color, texture, and apparent shape. This extraordinary camouflage allows them to hide in plain sight against many different backgrounds.

title: A Cloak of Near Invisibility in an Underwater World
description: For many animals, being noticed can mean being eaten or scaring away a would-be meal. From the tigers stripes to the snowy owls downy white feathers, camouflage allows animals to hide in plain sight and avoid these perils. But camouflage is often about more than color. Some animals have skin texture that matches the texture of their environment. Other animals have shapes that make it hard to spot the outlines of their bodies.

title: Most Wanted and Most Haunted
description: A half-century ago this week, the 1964 Worlds Fair opened in Flushing Meadows, Queens. With Belgian waffles, Michelangelos Piet and a Tent of Tomorrow, the event was a last postwar blast of guilt-free consumption, Sunday school piety and faith in the future as a good place to be. It was also the scene of a smashup in progress, as the America of the 1950s ran into the 1960s.

title: Plan to Sell Condoms in Schools Encounters Resistance
description: Officials in Xian, the capital of Shaanxi Province, want secondary schools to sell condoms on campus to help combat the spread of H.I.V./AIDS, stirring a heated controversy among parents and educators.

title: Companies Back Initiative to Support OpenSSL and Other Open-Source Projects
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The nonprofit Linux Foundation and more than a dozen prominent technology companies are to announce an initiative on Thursday to fund crucial open-source projects.

description: I hope youll take 40 minutes to catch my onstage interview on Tuesday with Darren Aronofsky, the filmmaker known for his obsession with obsession, whether its in a mathematician, ballerina or  most recently  Noah. Also weighing in at the capping event at The TimessCities For Tomorrow meeting was Ari Handel, Aronofskys co-writer on Noah, Black Swan and The Fountain (and a neuroscientist).

title: Art Matters | An L.A. Fair Explores the Possibilities of Photography
description: For proof that photography can open your world, look no further than the boundary-pushing second edition ofParis Photo Los Angeles, which runs from Friday to Sunday at Paramount Pictures Studios.Like the medium itself  which freed experience from geography and time, so that viewers no longer had to actually be there in order to see something happen  the very structure of the event is a paean to fluidity. The art fair started 17 years ago in Paris and now has an annual outpost in Los Angeles on a backlot replica of New York City. The history of photography is made of ambiguity, says the events director, Julien Frydman. If you look at photography as a self-contained medium you lose 50 percent of it, maybe more. Photography is nourished by other forms of art and in dialogue with other forms of art.

title: A Ticket to Fame, With Relish

He delivered a monologue at top volume while, at the next table, Lloyd Handwerker, a grandson of Nathan Handwerker, who founded the place in 1916, tried telling me about Famous Nathan, the documentary he made about his grandpa, showing on Friday and Saturday at the Tribeca Film Festival.

title: Nine Playwrights to Attend Sundance Theater Lab
description: Nine playwrights have been selected to participate in the Sundance Institutes 2014 Theater Lab, the institute announced on Thursday. The lab, one of 10 overseen by Sundance, runs from July 7 to 27 at Sundances resort in Utah. The playwrights, who are given fellowships based on specific projects, are provided with rehearsal space, an acting company, dramaturges and creative advisers to help them hone their works. The program is overseen by Philip Himberg, the artistic director, and Christopher Hibma, the producing director.

title: Even After Setbacks, a Musician Insists That the Show Will Go On
description: Hamiet Bluiett should not have even shown up, let alone picked up his musical instrument. Hes had two strokes in the past two months and his doctors have urged him to take it easy.

title: Memories of Religious Riots Overshadow Vote in Bihar

title: Berlin Philharmonic Starts Its Own Record Label

title: Happenings | Designer Miles Redd Channels Matisse for a Worthy Cause
description: For the last 10 years, the New York-based organization Housing Works has been raising money for people who have H.I.V./AIDS by selling consignment clothing and furniture through its high-end nonprofit thrift stores. For six of those years, the designer Miles Redd, the former creative director of Oscar de la Renta Home, has lent his time and talent to the organizations annual Design on a Dime benefit by assembling entire rooms from donated merchandise, all of which is sold at the event.

title: Seven Works Attributed to Banksy to Be Auctioned
description: LONDON  Seven artworks attributed to the street artist Banksy will go on display at the Me London Hotel  until Sunday, before being sold at auction. The works have been removed from public walls and buildings by the Sincura Group, which previously organized the removal and sale of Banksys Slave Labor. The Sincura Group, described on its own website as market leaders in V.I.P. concierge, lifestyle, tickets and events, will auction the works on April 27. Tony Baxter, the director of Sincura, said in a statement that the group does not steal art, nor do we condone any acts of wanted vandalism or theft.

title: For Women in Tech, Pay Gap Is Unusually Small

title: From an Apple a Day to Energy Balance in Cancer Research
description: In my recent Raw Data column about whether fruits and vegetables are crucial to avoiding cancer, I referred to two thick reports, published in 1997 and 2007 by the American Institute for Cancer Research and its affiliate, the World Cancer Research Fund. Sitting side by side on my desk, the books look similar: One cover is blue and the other green, and both are adorned with images of fruits, vegetables, legumes and grains interspersed with people working and playing, all apparently enjoying good health. Presiding over the scene is an image of Mother Earth.

title: Barclays Shareholders Vent Frustration Over Bonuses
description: LONDON  For nearly three hours on Thursday, shareholders of Barclays aired their grievances with the British banks top management, ranging from complaints about the security of debit cards to the length of the lines to get into its annual meeting.

title: After Blast, East Harlem Tenants Are Worried About Dust

Dust covers her 17-year-old sons television stand, her younger childrens bunk beds and a stroller folded against the wall. The family comes to the apartment to grab things they need, but they live in a nearby apartment provided by the New York City Department of Homeless Services.
