description: Anthony Tommasini, classical music critic for The New York Times, presents a surprising turn in Ludvig Van Beethovens Sonata No. 31 in A-flat, Op. 110.

title: Prosecutors Cite Stowage and Design in Korean Disaster
description: JINDO, South Korea  Prosecutors on Thursday officially attributed the sinking of a South Korean ferry to an improper stowage of cargo and a loss of stability caused by a change in the vessels design.

title: Musical Surprises: Debussy
description: Anthony Tommasini, classical music critic for The New York Times, presents a surprising turn in Claude Debussys Golliwogs Cakewalk.

title: Radetsky to Depart American Ballet Theater
description: Sascha Radetskys performance as Franz in the American Ballet Theaters production of Copplia at the Metropolitan Opera House on July 3 will be his farewell to the troupe, the company announced on Thursday. Mr. Radetsky, 37, joined the American Ballet Theater as an apprentice in 1995, became a member of its corps de ballet the following year, and has been a soloist since 2003.

title: Recognizing Outstanding Photojournalism Overseas
description: Tyler Hicks of The New York Times has won the Robert Capa gold medal from the Overseas Press Club for the best published photographic reporting from abroad requiring exceptional courage and enterprise. The award was given to him in recognition of his coverage of the Nairobi mall terrorist attack last September.

title: A Corporate Raider Tries to Correct the Record
description: In 1985, T. Boone Pickens, a force in the burgeoning business of hostile takeovers, appeared on the cover of Time magazine. He was fresh off an audacious tender offer for Gulf Oil, and the cover illustration showed him playing poker with oil derricks printed on the cards.

title: American Journalist Released by Ukraine Separatists
description: Separatist rebels in eastern Ukraine released the American journalist Simon Ostrovsky on Thursday, three days after he was taken prisoner in the town of Slovyansk while filming a video report for Vice News. The Brooklyn-based news organization confirmed his release in a statement, which was followed by a tweet from the correspondent.

title: Investors Enthusiastic About Zimmers Deal for Rival
description: American investors are seeing yet another big acquisition. Zimmer Holdings promises that its $13.4 billion deal for its rival, Biomet, will yield savings.

title: United Nations Report on Delivery of Humanitarian Relief in Syria
description: A report that is part of the United Nations assessment of how the Syrian government and rebels have complied with a Security Council resolution ordering them to allow humanitarian aid to enter besieged towns.

title: U.N. Finds Humanitarian Aid Still Blocked in Syria, Despite Resolution
description: Hundreds of thousands of Syrians have no access to medical supplies because the warring sides in the countrys civil war are blocking humanitarian relief, according to an advance copy of a report from the United Nations secretary general.

title: Google Plus Boss Vic Gundotra Leaving Google
description: UpdatedVic Gundotra, Googles senior vice president for social and one of the creators of Google Plus, is leaving the Googleplex.

title: Moments from Obamas Visit to Japan
description: President Obama kicked off his Asia tour in Japan, meeting with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and Emperor Akihito to improve relations in the Asia-Pacific region.

title: Dial Down Your Anger
description: I had a friend for 30 years who lives three blocks away from me. In 2011, I became seriously ill and fell into a coma. She was in touch with my husband by email and knew about my condition, but never followed up to see how I was doing or even if I was still alive. I was devastated by this and cannot forgive her. I keep hoping to run into her in the neighborhood to tell her how I feel so I can move past it, but that has yet to occur. What should I do?

title: Living With Cancer: Practicing Loss
description: At times when I consider my losses, I feel like a loser in the battle against self-pity. Like many diseases, cancer has everything to do with loss: of a breast or a leg, of a chunk of liver or lung, of continence, of mental capacity, of life itself.

title: Folk Art Museum to Open Queens Annex
description: Ever since the Museum of Modern Art announced that it was going to raze its next-door neighbor, the former home of the American Folk Art Museum, the building has been getting more attention than the Folk Art museum itself. But now that museum has news of its own. The American Folk Art Museum is opening an annex for its collection and library in Queens, near the LaGuardia Performing Arts Center in Long Island City.

title: Next time youre at Citizens Bank Park, remember, its a hoagie you want.
description: What are you really capturing when you make a map of baseball fans on Facebook, as we did earlier today? Its something more than just the number of Likes sorted by ZIP code. Its relationships between things we never saw before. Take the map here, which mashes up the Mets/Phillies rivalry border with the border between people who say sub and people who say hoagie. Our dialect quiz last year found a significant regional difference. The dividing lines are pretty much the same.

title: Photos: Buy Me Some Pine Tar and Cracker Jack
description: Billy Martin had one of the best eyes in baseball for catching people who were potentially up to no good.

title: Ultra Violet, Pop Artist, Has Exhibition at Dillon Gallery
description: The Miser is away enjoying warmer climes, so we rifled through his inbox and found a couple of thrifty activities for the weekend.

title: When the Seven Sisters Had a Bigger Welcome Mat
description: The Times will soon convert all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. (Nonsearchable images of every New York Times newspaper published before Dec. 31, 1980, can be seen in full on the Times Machine.)

title: The Gun Report: April 24, 2014
description: Federal funding for research on gun violence has been frozen since 1996. Shortly after Newtown, President Obama urged Congress to allocate $10 million for new research, but Republicans in Congress recently refused, likening the effort to funding propaganda.

title: My Illness, the Third Partner in Our Relationship
description: She was my professor. I was her graduate student. She was 17 years my senior, with a husband and children. And she risked it all to be by my side and in my bed as I closed in on a kidney transplant.

title: Feeling For | In Madrid, An All-Organic Menu Meets Striking, Surrealist Design
description: When Manolo Yllera first told me last year that he was opening a market and restaurant in Madrid, I had an inkling that the Spanish interiors photographer would create something worthy of any lens. And of course Mama Campo is the kind of bright, airy and quirky place that could only be brought to life by a set of hands belonging to a person with a good eye for design.

title: Yankees Get Sloppy Win; Pineda Gets Suspension
description: BOSTON  The mess that was smeared across Michael Pinedas neckon Wednesdaywas nothing compared with the slop that was on display at Fenway Park one night later. The Yankees and the Boston Red Sox resumed their rivalryThursdayminus the controversy about the pine tar that Pineda applied to his neck, but the game was one of the worst played in the major leagues this season.

title: The New York Athletic Club: A Proud Sponsor of Meb Keflezighi
description: When Meb Keflezighi won the Boston Marathon at age 38 Monday, the logo of his shoe sponsor, Skechers, was not the only unusual symbol he was wearing. Ironed onto his red and white jersey was the winged foot of the elite New York Athletic Club, a rare sight these days in the lead pack of major marathons, which are usually dominated by swooshes and stripes.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: pricey pills, high altitudes and avocados. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Wedding Q. and A.
The Office Space We Love to Hate
description: The white-collar people slipped quietly into modern society, C. Wright Mills writes in White Collar (1951), his classic sociology text, as if he were describing a race of wan termites. Nikil Savals excellent new book, Cubed: A Secret History of the Workplace, was inspired by Millss book, and its a fresh and intellectually omnivorous extension of its themes.

title: Senate Panel Faults Ex-Homeland Security Watchdog for Failing to Be Independent
description: WASHINGTON  A Senate subcommittee has found that the official who served as the Department of Homeland Securitys acting inspector general from 2011 to 2013 jeopardized the independence of his office by delaying reports and alerting department officials about their contents.

title: James Earl Jones to Star on Broadway in You Cant Take It With You
description: James Earl Jones will star in a Broadway revival of the Pulitzer Prize-winning comedy You Cant Take It With You beginning in August, with Scott Ellis on board to direct, the producers of the show announced on Thursday.

title: Bourbons Affinity for Ginger
description: We all know how well fresh mint goes with bourbon. Sean Josephs, one of our panelists, opened my eyes (and palate) to bourbons affinity for ginger. The Noreaster he serves at Maysville and Char No. 4 is a simple, lightly sweetened example of bourbon and lime, topped off with a splash of ginger beer. On the same wavelength, at Philip Marie in Greenwich Village, theres the Bufala Negra, a bourbon drink seasoned with balsamic vinegar and finished with ginger beer, a slight variation on the original made with balsamic syrup and ginger ale, which was created by Jerry Slater of H Harper Station in Atlanta.

title: Tarantinos Infringement Lawsuit Against Gawker Is Dismissed
description: A federal judge has agreed to dismiss a lawsuit by the director Quentin Tarantino that accused Gawker Media of helping to leak his unpublished script, The Hateful Eight.

title: Chinas Legislature Votes to Toughen Environmental Protection Law
description: BEIJING  The Chinese legislature decided Thursday to revise the countrys environmental protection law to allow for stricter punishments against companies or individuals caught polluting the environment, according to a report by Xinhua, the state news agency.

title: A Maine Lighthouse Welcomes Guests
description: For the first time, the Cuckolds  a pair of granite islands a half mile off the coast of Southport Island, Maine  will be open to guests for overnight stays beginning June 27.

title: Oregon Panel Recommends Switch to Federal Health Exchange
description: WASHINGTON  With encouragement from the Obama administration, an Oregon panel recommended Thursday that the state scrap the website for its beleaguered health insurance exchange and use the federal marketplace instead.

title: Phelps Finishes Second in Return, and Winner Is Glad Hes Back
description: MESA, Ariz.  Michael Phelpss possible pursuit of a fifth Olympics has the swimming world abuzz, but first things first. Before Phelps could entertain thoughts of defending his 100-meter butterfly title in Brazil, there was the matter of qualifying for the national championships in Southern California in August.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Blue Ruin
description: The writer and director Jeremy Saulnier narrates a sequence from his film featuring Macon Blair.

title: Climbers Leave Everest Amid Regrets and Tensions Among Sherpas
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  Climbers who had hoped to reach the summit of Mount Everest have instead begun the long journey home: a teenager with epilepsy who wanted to inspire others like himself; a banker who quit his job, sold his apartment and used up most of his savings to pay for the trip; a builder from California who was carrying the ashes of his younger brother.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of Blue Ruin
description: In this video, the writer and director Jeremy Saulnier narrates a sequence from his revenge thriller Blue Ruin, starring his best friend Macon Blair. He discusses a getaway that doesnt quite go the way his protagonist would have hoped.

title: Video of Rancher Cliven Bundys Remarks on Race
description: As my colleague Adam Nagourney reports, on Saturday the Nevada rancher Cliven Bundy veered away from his fight with the federal government to share his views on race, slavery and abortion in remarks to supporters and journalists at a news conference.

title: Tech Giants Settle Antitrust Hiring Suit
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The workers of Silicon Valley have won an important victory over their bosses. What they did not win is a lot of money.

title: Nothing to Cheer About
description: It has become possible, these past several decades, to think of Duke as consisting of a professional basketball team to which, bizarrely, a research university has attached itself. But it is the nonrevenue sports at Duke  and the schools relentless, aggressive and very expensive campaign to build them into powerhouse brands  that have most radically changed the tenor of that campus. The strange centrality of the athletic program in the life of an academically excellent institution, and the many unintended consequences this situation has wrought, is the subject of William D. Cohans The Price of Silence: The Duke Lacrosse Scandal, the Power of the Elite, and the Corruption of Our Great Universities. The book is at once a masterwork of reporting and a devastating critique of a university that has lost its way.

title: Bourbons Masters of the Craft
description: With the approach of the Kentucky Derby, you can bet a lot of bourbon will be consumed. Nowadays, thats nothing new.

title: Caroline Kennedy Says She Will Back Hillary Clinton in a Run for President
description: Caroline Kennedy, whose endorsement of Barack Obama in 2008 was a major setback for Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign, as well as a personal blow, said Thursday that she would absolutely support Mrs. Clinton should she decide to run for president again.

title: Eyes on the Prize
description: Big Supreme Court cases produce big books: Gideons Trumpet, Simple Justice. On June 26, 2013, the Supreme Court decided two big cases. In United States v. Windsor, it struck down a part of the federal Defense of Marriage Act as unconstitutional, while in Hollingsworth v. Perry it sidestepped the challenge to Californias anti-gay-marriage Proposition 8 on a technicality, leaving the trial courts original ruling  that Prop 8 was unconstitutional  in effect.

title: Massachusetts Maverick
description: A couple of months ago, on Connecticut Avenue not far from the White House, I passed a crowd of 20-somethings wearing distressed denim and hoodies. They looked more Williamsburg than Washington and carried placards that read: Im from the Elizabeth Warren wing of the party.

title: Mind Over Matter: Mastering Daunting Moves
description: OVERACHIEVERS, beware: In the pursuit of a challenging sport or discipline, there will come a time when you confront a move that your mind embraces but your body protests.

title: This Weekend: Two Warhol Exhibitions
description: This weekend in New York: two Andy Warhol exhibitions, Neil Patrick Harris playing a transgender rock star and Ballet Preljocajs Snow White.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: This Weekend: Two Warhol Exhibitions
description: In the Video

title: On the Market in the Region
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: The Dumb Jock Stereotype Can Be a Self-Fulfilling Prophecy
description: Social scientists know that in research studies, minority and female students appear to be vulnerable to the phenomenon called stereotype threat. Aware that the group to which they belong is often stereotyped as intellectually inferior, their anxiety that a poor showing on a test will confirm the stereotype actually depresses their performance on the test, creating a self-fulfilling prophecy.

title: A Law and the Face of the City
description: On May 19th, it will be 35 years since Grace Gold, a Barnard College freshman, was struck and killed by a falling piece of masonry at 115th Street and Broadway. Her death sparked in 1980 what was then called Local Law 10, requiring facade inspections. Preservationists warned that wholesale stripping of architectural ornament would result. A survey of Upper West Side buildings in 1993 and today indicates otherwise.

title: Evicting a Possible Neighborhood Squatter
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, Turkey, India and Japan.

title: Rochelle Feinstein: Love Vibe
description: On Stellar Rays

title: The Case of the Disappearing Chintz
description: When Linda Fairstein moved in with her future husband, Justin Feldman, in 1986, she was less than enchanted with the dcor of his one-bedroom rental. It was a symphony in brown and brown.

title: Amazons Revenue Grew 23 Percent in First Quarter, Nearing $20 Billion
description: Amazon defines corporate prosperity in terms of sales growth rather than profit. By its definition, which has been embraced on Wall Street, the big Internet merchant had a strong first quarter.

title: Sara Cwynar: Flat Death
description: Foxy Production

title: Undie Rock, With a Soupon of Broadway
description: IT was almost 11 p.m. in the packed subterranean space of 54 Below, and Lauren Molina, a petite actress with a mop of curls, was onstage in red underwear, straddling a cello. You guys like Britney Spears? she asked the audience, confidingly.

title: A Glorious Front Yard
description: A nine-room apartment with palatial proportions, a wraparound terrace and 70 feet of direct Central Park frontage at the venerable San Remo, the twin-towered 1930 landmark at 145 Central Park West at 74th Street, is poised to enter the market for the first time in 35 years.

title: Mira Schendel
description: Hauser & Wirth

title: Peter Dreher: Day by Day, Good Day
description: Koenig & Clinton

title: Warburg Pincus to Invest in PayScale, a Compensation Data Firm
description: When it comes to paying employees, companies keep a close eye on what rivals are doing. To that end, one private equity firm is betting that companies might want more precise data.

title: A Mission of a Different Kind
description: There is an expansive, 13-room duplex at 730 Park Avenue where time has stood still.

title: Clip: Brick Mansions
description: A scene from the film.

title: Two 40-Year-Olds Set Example for the Mets
description: The repetitive number pairing 40-40 typically refers to one of baseballs greatest single-season achievements  hitting 40 home runs and stealing 40 bases. The feat has been accomplished by only four players, all in the primes of their careers.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: Officials on Suspended Talks in Mideast
description: Officials from Israel, the Palestine Liberation Organization and Hamas discussed Israels decision to suspend negotiations with the Palestinians after a Gaza deal between the factions Fatah and Hamas.

title: No, Obama Didnt Win One-Third of White Voters in Deep South
description: This morning, I published an article on the decline of Democratic support among white Southerners from West Texas to the Atlantic Coast. In that region, Mitt Romney often won by margins so large that they rivaled President Obamas advantage among black voters. Larry Bartels, writing for The Washington Posts Monkey Cage blog, disputes my argument and claims Mr. Obama had widespread white support in the south.

title: A Rocket Is Aimed at Detroit (Run! Jump!)
description: As is not uncommon with movies of this kind, a certain amount of the dialogue in Brick Mansions consists of excited elaborations of the obvious, perhaps for the benefit of viewers who missed something while texting or dozing. During a foot chase, when the pursued parties have succeeded in locking a door from the outside, one of the pursuers remarks, They locked the door from the outside! In the midst of a later chase (there are a lot of them), when the guys who locked that door are hiding on an abandoned school bus, someone shouts, Theyre on the bus! And when it is revealed that one of the chief villains is in possession of a military-grade rocket, the strangeness of this fact does not go unnoticed: Only a crazy person would have a rocket!

title: California Senate Rejects Smartphone Kill Switch Law
description: The California Senate on Thursday voted down a state measure that would require smarter antitheft security on smartphones.

title: Nets Bench Is Taking Back Seat in Playoffs
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Toronto Raptors were more precise in distributing the minutes of their reserves in their Game 2 victory over the Nets on Tuesday night, resulting in greater contributions from a smaller pool of players.

title: Global Entry and Company: Worth the Price?
description: Time versus money  theres no more fundamental trade-off in budget travel. Nonstop or layover, taxi or public bus? Stand in line for half-price theater tickets or buy full-price at the click of a mouse?

title: Clip: The Quiet Ones
description: A scene from the film.

title: More Public Art for Governors Island
description: When a new 30-acre park opens at the southern end of Governors Island on May 24, it will boast a grove of hammocks, two ball fields, a formal garden and play areas with climbable structures and spray showers. It will also be part of an ambitious backdrop for a new public art program taking shape on this 172-acre island, the former Army and Coast Guard base in New York Harbor. The city took control of Governors Island in 2010, and each year theres more to do and see, attracting thousands of visitors during the summer months.

title: Possessed by Demons, and a Nutty Professor
description: The title of The Quiet Ones, the latest horror movie about supernatural doings set in the 1970s, is explained fairly late. By then its director, John Pogue, has made a modest racket with the usual bumps in the night, some cackling and screaming, a bit of door slamming and table knocking. A fair amount of this noise seems to emanate from Jane Harper (Olivia Cooke), a hollow-eyed young patient of Professor Coupland (Jared Harris). An Oxford University lecturer, Coupland believes that the supernatural occurrences in Janes bleak, lonely life have been created by her mind and is using every bad idea he has  including curing her through sleep deprivation  to prove it.

title: Letters: Another Look
description: Another Look

title: Tracking Future and Hip-Hops Growlers
description: Ben Ratliff and Jon Caramanica discuss the rapper Future and the evolution of vocal style in hip-hop.

title: Slavery Nostalgia Is Real, and Its Dangerous
description: Northerners may be a little shocked that anyone could feel a bit nostalgic for slavery, in the manner of the government-hating Nevada rancher, Cliven Bundy. But in the South, such sentiments are hardly unheard of, even if they are usually muttered in private over a few bourbons rather than spoken at a news conference.

title: Current Events Imperil Ukrainian Museum Show
description: Works by the 19th-century Ukrainian poet and painter Taras Shevchenko are tentatively scheduled to arrive in Manhattan next week, in time for a retrospective opening May 11 at the Ukrainian Museum. But fingers are crossed.

title: Mom, That Fugitive Nazi Is Making Eyes at Me
description: The quietly jittery art house thriller The German Doctor opens in Patagonia in 1960, with a man watching a group of girls playing along a dusty road. Coolly, he zeros in on one child with long, blond hair, his light, clear eyes tracking her as she awkwardly scrambles into her familys car. He trails after her, pleasantries are exchanged, and the man, whos moving to a nearby town, arranges to follow the family in his car. Soon after they hit the road, he is murmuring in German, and theres no doubt that Helmut Gregor (Alex Brendemhl, suave and unnerving), as he calls himself, is no ordinary stranger. Not too long after, hes setting up an office and measuring the girls head.

title: Microsofts Profit Dips Less Than Expected as It Reshapes Itself
description: SEATTLE  Microsoft on Thursday again demonstrated its gift for weathering the turmoil in the personal computer industry, turning in solid financial results for a company playing catch-up in several important markets.

title: Short Sales on the Decline
description: The expiration of a federal tax exemption for forgiven mortgage debt appears to be scaring borrowers away from pursuing short sales.

title: In High Gear
description: New York City is awash in development, with skyscrapers rising above the cityscape seemingly at random, especially in neighborhoods in Manhattan.

title: U.S. Trade Agreements
description: To the Editor:

title: Punishing Pregnant Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Skills Sought by Google
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Expanded Ferry Service
description: To the Editor:

title: Prickly but Puppyish in San Francisco
description: Youth, they say, is wasted on the young, but it wasnt on the five artists featured in Energy That Is All Around: Mission School, an exhibition at the Grey Art Gallery that bristles infectiously with youthful urgency.

title: What Were Reading Now
description: Poisons: Scientists condemn a new F.D.A. study claiming BPA, a chemical present in certain plastics, is safe, saying it borders on scientific misconduct.

title: Trying to Outrun Age, in Spiky Heels
description: Theres a mirror on a wall and a stepmother who wants to look younger than her daughter. Is it just another day in the life of a dressing room at Forever 21, or Angelin Preljocajs version of Snow White?

title: Video: Andy Warhol, Hedwig and Snow White
description: This week in The Timess Culture Minute: Two Andy Warhol exhibitions; Neil Patrick Harris as a transgender rock star in Hedwig and the Angry Inch; and Ballet Preljocajs Snow White.

title: Theater Listings for April 25-May 1
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: No Time for Audiobooks: Hes on the Road to His Destiny
description: A truism about cinema and television, two tributaries that increasingly flow into one image stream, is that together they have turned the human face into our favorite destination spot. The ubiquity of close-ups, particularly in broadcast television, with its parade of bobbling heads and babbling mouths, could have drained movie faces of their power. Yet we cant seem to get enough of other peoples faces, whether theyre as frozen as masks or changeable as churning water. We trace stories across these familiar landscapes, becoming geographers of emotion.

title: Humanity and Hope in a Southern Prison
description: For more than the obvious reasons, Civil War soldiers in both armies despised military prisons. Not only were the inmates held against their will, but the hunger, filth, vermin, rampant disease, overcrowding, brutal treatment and soul-crushing ennui made prison camps slaughterhouses of slow death. Andersonville, the infamous Georgia prison, was the ultimate abattoir; during the summer of 1864 nearly one in three Union inmates died. In other Confederate prisons, the average mortality rate was 15.5 percent; in Union prisons, 12 percent.

title: Aftermath of Ukraine Photo Story Shows Need for More Caution
description: The Times led its print edition Monday with an article based in part on photographs that the State Department said were evidence of Russian military presence in popular uprisings in Ukraine. The headline read: Photos Link Masked Men in East Ukraine to Russia.

title: June 4th Museum Set to Open in Hong Kong
description: In April 1989, tens of thousands of young protesters assembled on Tiananmen Square, in the heart of Beijing, demanding greater political freedoms and an end to corruption. The protests ended in bloodshed when tanks and troops were deployed the night of June 3-4 to clear the square. By most estimates, hundreds were killed.

title: How to Kill the Minimum Wage Movement
description: On a visit to the capital a few weeks ago, I was struck by how politically inert the place was. Not just empty, lifeless, devoid of activity in the chambers where great politicians once roamed. Not just a do-nothing Congress living up to its pledge to do even less this year than last. Not just the usual government-by-corporate lobbyists. At the moment, Washington is a dead town.

title: Putting Pen to Paper, and a Friendship to the Test
description: Do you miss stamps? Or stationery? Or messages free from emoticons? Address Unknown, in a brief run at Gould Hall at the French Institute Alliance Franaise, could make you a lot less nostalgic for letter writing. Based on Kathrine Kressmann Taylors short epistolary novel, it concerns two German friends, Max and Martin, on the eve of World War II.

title: Comedy Listings for April 25-May 1
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Movie Listings for April 25-May 1
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Minnesota Orchestra Board Rehires Vanska as Music Director
description: Osmo is back.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for April 25-May 1
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: New Evidence May Reopen Broker Fraud Case
description: Updated, 8:55 p.m. | A Long Island couple who lost $5 million at the hands of Mark C. Hotton, the former stockbroker notorious for defrauding Broadway producers, is arguing that his employer, Oppenheimer & Company, withheld critical evidence during an arbitration hearing and should be held liable.

title: Opera & Classical Music Listings for April 25-May 1
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Dance Listings for April 25-May 1
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Italys Mob Extends Reach in Europe
description: ROME  The small businesses were sprinkled throughout the Italian capital: One restaurant was only a few blocks from the Senate. A cafe was at the edge of the upscale diplomatic district, while a gelato shop was near the Pantheon. There was even a hotel not far from the hilltop statue of Giuseppe Garibaldi, the hero of Italys unification.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for April 25-May 1
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Spare Times for Children for April 25-May 1
description: FOOD BOOK FARM

title: The Insider | Advice From, and For, First-Time Filmmakers
description: When it comes to realizing a work of art, few processes are more challenging than that of making a feature film. Never mind that unlike most art forms, movies are a largely collaborative medium  paintbrushes dont have egos  but even in our age of digital cameras and home editing suites, filmmaking can get expensive. Not only does a director have to believe in the project from page to screen, but so do the people paying for it. Being a filmmaker, especially in the beginning, is risky business. Here, 15 directors  each of whom are showing their first feature at the Tribeca Film Festival, which runs through Sunday  share with T how they did it.

title: France Joins Gay Couples by Thousands, Amid Gripes
description: PARIS  Same-sex marriage has been gaining acceptance in France a year after a law allowing such unions was passed following vociferous public opposition and heated debate in Parliament.

title: Spare Times for April 25-May 1
description: BROOKLYN BOTANIC GARDEN: SAKURA MATSURI (Saturday and Sunday) At last, the cherry trees are in bloom, and the dancers and musicians who will be part of this annual festival of traditional and contemporary Japanese arts are ready to welcome visitors into a garden of earthly delights. More than 60 events will be featured, along with a marketplace and activities for children. Hours are 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. The garden is at 990 Washington Avenue, at Eastern Parkway, Prospect Heights, 718-623-7200, bbg.org; $25; $20 for those 12 to 17 and 65+; free for children under 12 and members. Let the cherry blossom petals fall where they may. (Anne Mancuso)

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Just an After-School Job
description: Young & Beautiful, the latest movie from the French director Franois Ozon, begins with a shot, through binoculars, of a young woman sunbathing topless on a beach. Voyeurism is clearly on the agenda, and Mr. Ozon seems to be teasing out some of its creepy implications when he reveals that the binoculars belong to the sunbathers younger brother. But what is most striking about this movie is how un-self-conscious it is as it conducts a prurient and superficial inquiry into adolescent female sexuality.

title: A Bit Naughty, This Boy Band
description: Boys will be boys, and sometimes boys will be men, but most often boys will be struggling to figure out how much of each they should be, so they can get away with the most stuff.

title: What a Life: Bus Tables, Buss Prince
description: Perhaps its just coincidence. Or maybe, with the recent public discourse about the struggling middle class, this seems an apt moment to revisit a fairy tale about a good-hearted young woman, miserably oppressed by her family, who finds an unlikely soul mate in a loving prince.

title: An Opera, Without Singing, in a Museum
description: In 1974 the writer and actress Anne Opie Wehrer, the subject of Robert Ashleys The Trial of Anne Opie Wehrer and Unknown Accomplices for Crimes Against Humanity, wrote to the Whitney Museum of American Art proposing that it present the work as a living sculpture.

title: Silent, Clumsy Avenger Gets to Work
description: Dwight (Macon Blair) isnt your typical movie avenger, but then Blue Ruin  partly named for Dwights battered blue Pontiac  isnt your typical revenge movie. Concealed behind a hill-country beard and shapeless clothing, Dwight is a near-silent, homeless shadow who sleeps in his car on a Delaware beach. When we first see him, hes enjoying a bath in a strangers home, dismayed when the owners arrive unexpectedly. A tidy intruder, Dwight doesnt like to leave a mess.

title: Clip: The Other Woman
description: A scene from the film.

title: Neanderthals Are People, Too
description: LEIPZIG, Germany  I NEVER met my paternal grandfather. He died of the Spanish flu in 1919 at the age of 30, before his children and grandchildren ever got to know him. He was a brilliant mathematician and, as a scientist myself, I feel curious about what he was like. I take consolation from the fact that he lives on in me; after all, a quarter of my genes come from him.

title: Its Not You  Its That You Want to Stay in My Apartment
description: Michael R. Bloomberg, the former mayor of New York, told a reporter last week that hes done so much good that if theres a heaven, he wont have to stop for an interview, hell walk right in.

title: A Female Cooperative Based on Revenge
description: It takes a lot of heavy weather to snuff out the spark of Cameron Diaz who, at 41, still has the twinkle and bounce of an impish high school cheerleader. With her cornflower-blue eyes and mischievous feline grin, she remains every guys ultimate gal pal. One of her gifts as an comic actor is a light touch.

title: Schwab Agrees to Drop Effort to Prevent Class-Action Lawsuits
description: The discount brokerage firm Charles Schwab & Company has agreed to pay a $500,000 fine and give up an effort to prevent customers from participating in class-action lawsuits.

title: A Ferocious Satirist, With Ink as His Weapon
description: In 1969, Ralph Steadman, a British cartoonist and illustrator, was invited by the editors of Scanlans Monthly to attend the Kentucky Derby in the company of Hunter S. Thompson, who was writing an article about the race. This assignment marked the beginning of a long, fruitful and frequently volatile collaboration. Nine years after Thompsons death, it is nearly impossible to think of his prose without conjuring visions of Mr. Steadmans drawings  nightmarishly funny compositions in which spidery lines intersect with clouds of spilled and sprayed ink.

title: Pro-Russian Rebels on Checkpoint Attack
description: Pro-Russian separatists described the scene after a clash with Ukrainian forces at a checkpoint outside Slovyansk, Ukraine.

title: Cliven Bundy Accidentally Explained Whats Wrong With the Republican Party
description: On Saturday, Cliven Bundy, the Nevada rancher who has risen to prominence because of his dispute with the Bureau of Land Management, held forth about the Negro, and how black people may have been better off under slavery than now.

title: Paths to Stopping Painkiller Overdoses
description: To the Editor:

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 49
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Blithely Risking Discovery of Her May-December Fling
description: Oh, those French! When it comes to adultery, they apparently know how to indulge without tears or recriminations. That is the reassuring but unconvincing message of Bright Days Ahead, a lighter-than-air carnal romance.

title: Pakistan, Ending Its Observance of Cease-Fire, Launches Airstrikes Against Taliban
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Putting an abrupt end to the Pakistani governments adherence to a cease-fire with the Taliban on Thursday, military jets launched heavy airstrikes against militants in the Khyber tribal region bordering Afghanistan, officials said.

title: End College Legacy Preferences
description: SOMEONE reading about the Supreme Courts decision upholding Michigans ban on affirmative action  and by extension similar measures passed by voters in California, Texas, Florida and Washington  might develop the misimpression that affirmative action is on the wane. In fact, its alive and well: Public and private colleges routinely give preferential treatment to children of alumni.

title: Searching for the Life That Belonged to a Body
description: A kind of forensic memorial, Who Is Dayani Cristal? pieces together the background of a Central American migrant worker who died trying to cross into the United States. With its compellingly multifaceted approach, its earnest compassion and a celebrity presence in the form of the actor Gael Garca Bernal, the documentary could be enlisted in the perennial battle over immigration law. But for the same reasons, the movie is also in danger of battling itself to a draw.

title: NYU Langone Reopens Emergency Room That Was Closed by Hurricane Sandy
description: A striking sight appeared earlier this week outside the emergency room of NYU Langone Medical Center: an ambulance. Then another. And then many more.

title: Mind the Gap? Thats the Least of Their Worries
description: Like a hard-up version of a 1970s disaster movie, Last Passenger drops a disparate group of people in the path of a calamity, then watches as they wriggle to escape. But instead of being on a sinking ship or in a blazing tower block, these unfortunates are trapped on a late-night commuter train that has just left London. And if thats not terrifying enough, theyre headed for the snooty borough of Tunbridge Wells.

title: China: Legislature Toughens Environmental Law
description: The Chinese legislature decided Thursday to revise the countrys environmental protection law to allow for stricter punishments against companies or individuals caught polluting the environment, according to a report by Xinhua, the state news agency. Under the new law, expected to take effect next year, fines against companies would be increased, and company executives deemed responsible for pollution could be detained for up to 15 days. Local officials who cover up for polluting companies can be demoted or fired. Companies that have been ordered by officials to stop polluting but avoid doing so can be penalized with fines that accumulate daily. Until now, the companies had been assessed a one-time fine, Xinhua reported. The legal revisions were approved Thursday by the National Peoples Congress, a legislative body that generally agrees to policies already made by Communist Party leaders.

title: This Weeks Movies: April 25, 2014
description: The New York Times film critics review Brick Mansions, The German Doctor and For No Good Reason.

title: Provision Could Limit U.S. Food Aid
description: WASHINGTON  An obscure provision tucked inside a Coast Guard spending bill could prevent millions of people in troubled countries around the world from receiving American food aid and cost taxpayers millions of dollars in shipping costs, the Obama administration said this week.

title: If Assad Wins War, Challenge From His Own Sect May Follow
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  As President Bashar al-Assad seeks re-election and promises victory over insurgents by years end, Syrian loyalists and regional analysts say that his success, if it materializes, could set him up for a new challenge: demands for change from core supporters who believe he owes his survival mainly to them.

title: Zero Motivation and Point and Shoot Take Top Prizes at Tribeca Film Festival
description: Military-themed films won top prizes at this years Tribeca Film Festival, which announced its awards Thursday night: Zero Motivation, which depicts the trials and tedium endured by a unit of young female Israeli soldiers, won best narrative film, and Point and Shoot, wherein an American filmmaker records his foray into the Libyan civil war, was named best documentary.

title: Somethings Burning, and Comedy Isnt Pretty
description: Pain is everywhere in Ape, but it starts with the light. From the bright stab of morning after a rough night to the merciless glare of the spotlight in a pitch-black comedy club, this knife-edged portrait of a struggling stand-up uses agony like a silent soundtrack.

title: Clip: The German Doctor
description: A scene from the film directed by Luca Puenzo.

title: Ladies Home Journal to Become a Quarterly
description: Ladies Home Journal, whose very name evokes a bygone era of womens service magazines, will no longer publish as a monthly after a 130-year run, its owner, the Meredith Corporation, announced on Thursday.

title: De Blasio Names Chief of Agency Overseeing Sick Pay Law
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Thursday the appointment of a former regulatory lawyer, well known for her efforts to revitalize Lower Manhattan after the Sept. 11 attacks, to head the Department of Consumer Affairs  an agency enforcing compliance with New York Citys paid sick leave law.

title: N.C.A.A. Ensures Athletes Will Get All They Can Eat
description: When the University of Mississippi wanted to improve its athletic performance, Athletic Director Ross Bjork went beyond having the weight room renovated or updating the training facilities. He also drafted plans to build a state-of-the-art cafeteria.

title: Battling Illness and Royalty for Love
description: The Girl and Death is primarily set in that most durable of mysterious settings: a secluded, well-appointed hotel from another era. This particular establishment, tucked outside Leipzig, in post-World War II Germany, has its dotard guests and their routines, its officious and stiffly uniformed staff, and its intimations of secrets and riches. Most important, as discovered by a young visiting Russian doctor, Nicolai, it hosts Elise, the lovely kept mistress of a wealthy prince.

title: Enemies One Year, Teammates the Next
description: Last year, the School District of Philadelphia, facing a shortfall of more than $300 million, instituted a doomsday budget that ultimately closed 24 schools. Those included the 99-year-old Germantown High School, whose students would attend Martin Luther King High, its former bitter rival.

title: Students File Complaints on Sexual Assaults at Columbia University
description: Pressure on Columbia University to overhaul its approach to sexual assault and harassment reached a new pitch on Thursday, when a group of students filed complaints with the federal government, charging systematic mishandling of assault claims and mistreatment of victims.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Gone Fishing With Dad, Often on Silent Mode
description: Marvin, Seth and Stanley aims to be a deadpan travels-with-my-wacky-dad story, but the father in it is almost an afterthought. It still has sublime moments, but it leaves you wanting more of them.

title: In a Scary Uniform, Subverting a March to Death
description: Walking With the Enemy is based on the real-life deeds of Pinchas Rosenbaum, a Hungarian rabbis son who was able to save Jews from the Nazis and their collaborators by disguising himself in enemy garb.

title: A Supplement Retailer Pumps Up Consumers
description: MOST people consider themselves above average, something psychologists call illusory superiority and, less formally, the Lake Wobegon effect, a reference to the fictional town of Garrison Keillors radio monologues, where he says all the children are above average.

title: Struggling to Escape the Bronxs Grasp
description: To say that Mikey (Alexander Emmet), the embattled protagonist of Grand Slammed, has hit a rough patch understates the matter gravely. An aspiring pitcher, he blows his chance in front of a talent scout, leaving blood spattered on home plate from a wild pitch. That evening, he serves as a getaway driver when his buddy Pete (Dimitri Meskouris) hops out of the car for an unexpected gangland shooting.

title: Into Africa
description: The documentary Tanzania: A Journey Within is two travel diaries woven together. One is somber and moving. The other is distractingly annoying.

title: A Face of a Brutal Sport Is Trying to Change Its Image
description: Jon (Bones) Jones, the U.F.C. light heavyweight champion, made the rounds earlier this week in Manhattan, promoting his fight Saturday against Glover Teixeira.

title: A Partnership to Help the Tallest Residents in Yosemite Park
description: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif.  In an otherworldly grove of cinnamon-colored giant sequoias, workers in June will jackhammer an old mistake: a road and parking lot that impinge on the hallowed forest.

title: The Regeneration of Degenerate Art
description: Even on the coolest mornings, the long and patient lines of people outside the Neue Galerie, a small gem of a New York museum, have testified to the unintended consequences of Adolf Hitlers dictatorial tastes in art. As for the degenerate artists, the Nazi leader decreed as he rose to power, I forbid them to force their so-called experiences upon the public. He targeted them as criminals  modern masters like Otto Dix, Max Beckmann and George Grosz  and obsessively purged them from sight.

title: 2 Journalists in Lebanon Are Charged by Tribunal
description: The international tribunal dealing with the killing of former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri of Lebanon has charged two leading Lebanese journalists with contempt of court and obstruction of justice over the publication of confidential information about possible witnesses for the prosecution.

title: A Questionable Decision on Egypt
description: American policy toward Egypt continued on its tortured, confusing path this week when the Obama administration resumed some aid to what has become an increasingly repressive state. No matter how American officials try to spin it, the decision will come across as a vote of confidence in a military-dominated government with an authoritarian agenda and a track record of violent crackdowns on dissenters and political opponents.

title: For E-Cigarettes, the Regulatory Battle Now Begins
description: WASHINGTON  At last, Washington is moving to police the multibillion-dollar business of electronic cigarettes.

title: Tiny Jockeys, Galloping in a Cloud of Despair
description: There were some men there, the small boy with the large brown eyes tells us. You would go and give them your body. Others around him nod in agreement  and corroborate in more explicit language  but Desert Riders, a deeply troubling account of child camel jockeys in the United Arab Emirates, is not primarily concerned with sexual abuse. There are too many other abuses demanding its attention.

title: Seattle Mayor Says Effort to Build Agreement on $15 Minimum Wage Has Faltered
description: SEATTLE  Mayor Ed Murray of Seattle said Thursday that his effort to build consensus behind raising the citys minimum wage to $15, more than twice the federal rate, had faltered amid continuing differences between business leaders and labor unions that had been advising him on the issue.

title: Museumgoers Wonder: Why Doesnt the Whale Fall?
description: It is one of the biggest attractions  literally  at one of New York Citys most famous destinations: the 94-foot-long blue whale at the American Museum of Natural History. Untold numbers gaze in awe every day at the 21,000-pound creature poised majestically in midair above the Hall of Ocean Life.

title: Trailing Canada, U.S. Starts a Push for Safer Oil Shipping
description: A day after Canada issued stringent new rules for the transportation of oil by rail, federal regulators in the United States said on Thursday that they would push forward their own tank standards next week, potentially resolving a critical safety issue that has been mired in regulatory limbo for years.

title: House Majority PAC Ad
description: An ad in West Virginia stressed that so-called black lung benefits for miners could be lost if the law is repealed.

title: A Bid for Governor
description: Representative Allyson Y. Schwartz, a Democrat running for Pennsylvania governor, in an ad saying how proud she is of the health law.

title: Support for Alaska Senator
description: Lisa Keller is a mother, a runner, a lifelong Alaskan and a cancer survivor. She says she has health insurance again because of Mark Begich, her Democratic senator.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 24, 2014
description: April 24, 2014

title: The Piketty Phenomenon
description: Many people join the political left driven by a concern for the poor. But, over the past several years, the Democratic Party has talked much more about the middle class than the poor. Meanwhile, progressive political movements like Occupy Wall Street directed their fervor at the top 1 percent. Progressive movies and books have focused their attention on conspiracy and oligarchy at the top, not Grapes of Wrath or How the Other Half Lives stories at the bottom.

title: A Fight to Keep College Athletes From the Pain of Injury Costs
description: Kyle Hardrick lost his basketball scholarship at Oklahoma after he tore his meniscus.

title: Rand Paul and Wealthy Libertarians Connect as He Weighs Running
description: Frayda Levin, a New Jersey libertarian activist and former small-business owner, is a woman of many passions: promoting liberty, ending marijuana prohibition and opposing her states recent minimum-wage increase. But Ms. Levin has added another cause as well. At gala benefits for free-market research institutes and at fund-raisers for antitax groups, she has urged like-minded donors to help send Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, to the White House.

title: In Florida Tomato Fields, a Penny Buys Progress
description: IMMOKALEE, Fla.  Not long ago, Angelina Velasquez trudged to a parking lot at 5 each morning so a crew leaders bus could drop her at the tomato fields by 6. She often waited there, unpaid  while the dew dried  until 10 a.m., when the workers were told to clock in and start picking.

title: Efforts to Snub the Other Party Rarely Go Well
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Democratic Candidates Grow More Vocal in Supporting Health Law
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Allyson Y. Schwartz, Democrat of Pennsylvania, did the seemingly unthinkable on Tuesday: She ran a television ad expressing how proud she was of President Obamas signature health care law.

title: The Piketty Panic
description: Capital in the Twenty-First Century, the new book by the French economist Thomas Piketty, is a bona fide phenomenon. Other books on economics have been best sellers, but Mr. Pikettys contribution is serious, discourse-changing scholarship in a way most best sellers arent. And conservatives are terrified. Thus James Pethokoukis of the American Enterprise Institute warns in National Review that Mr. Pikettys work must be refuted, because otherwise it will spread among the clerisy and reshape the political economic landscape on which all future policy battles will be waged.

title: D.W.I. Charge for Detective Who Shot Colleague
description: A New York police detective who accidentally shot his partner in the wrist on Thursday while in their unmarked patrol car was later arrested and charged with drunken driving, the authorities said.

title: Amid Overhaul, Case Questions Agencys Foster Care
description: As Texas Child Protective Services is working to streamline its foster care system, a lawsuit in federal court could force officials back to the drawing board, costing taxpayers millions of dollars.

title: U.S. Confronts Consequences of Underestimating North Korean Leader
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Almost everything American intelligence agencies and North Korea-watchers thought they understood two years ago about Kim Jong-un, the Norths young leader, turns out to have been wrong.

title: Lobbying Efforts Intensify After F.C.C. Tries 3rd Time on Net Neutrality
description: WASHINGTON  In the nine weeks since the Federal Communications Commission said it would try, for a third time, to write new rules to secure an open Internet, at least 69 companies, interest groups and trade associations  over one a day  have met with or otherwise lobbied commission officials on what the rules should specify.

title: A Right-to-Bear-Arms Twist: Rallying With a Gun in Hand
description: When advocates for tighter restrictions on guns rallied last week in Austin City Hall, a small group of opponents staged a counter-rally outside, carrying firearms and waving a flag emblazoned with an assault rifle and the caption Come and Take It.

title: Missing on Mound: A Dab of Discretion
description: The circle in the middle of a baseball diamond may as well be in a spotlight on a Broadway stage. Everybody watches the pitcher, because nothing happens until he delivers the ball. Yet with all those eyes on him, in the ballpark and at home, few can really see what he does.

title: Creating a Two-Speed Internet
description: Dividing traffic on the Internet into fast and slow lanes is exactly what the Federal Communications Commission would do with its proposed regulations, unveiled this week. And no amount of reassurances about keeping competition alive will change that fact.

title: Judge Rejects New York Limit on Donations to Super PACs
description: A federal judge on Thursday struck down New York States limit on contributions to independent groups that spend money supporting political candidates, a move that could unleash large spending by so-called super PACs in state races.

title: Alternative to Pap Test Is Approved by F.D.A.
description: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved the first alternative to the long-used Pap test as a primary screening method for cervical cancer, in the face of opposition from some womens groups and health organizations.

title: Gang Leader From Mexico Gets Life Term
description: MEXICO CITY  A gang leader was sentenced to life in prison on Thursday for his role in ordering the 2010 murders of three people associated with the United States Consulate in Ciudad Jurez, killings that rattled both sides of the border as drug violence engulfed the city.

title: An Ivy League Newspaper May Be Going Mostly Online
description: The battle over the future of newspapers has found an unlikely flash point, above a Pinkberry on the fringes of Columbia Universitys Morningside Heights campus.

title: Labor Board to Review Northwestern Football Case
description: The National Labor Relations Board in Washington announced Thursday that it would review last months landmark decision that held that Northwestern Universitys scholarship football players should be considered employees. The board said the case raised substantial issues.

title: Justice Dept. Seeks Mortgage Deal With Bank of America
description: The Justice Department, building on a multibillion-dollar mortgage settlement with JPMorgan Chase last year, is now aiming for a deal with Bank of America.

title: Old Chums Return, Where Club Is Home
description: Hot diggity dachshund, its old home week on the campus at Weimar Berlin, otherwise known as the Kit Kat Klub. And if we take off our glasses and squint, we can pretend that life is just as divinely, dangerously decadent as it was when we were all 16 years younger.

title: Climate Change Onstage: Singing of the Extinction of Fauna
description: The drumbeat of dire reports about climate change has grown so rhythmically regular over the past few years that its almost surprising that someone hasnt set it to song, at least within the confines of a musical. That day has now come. If youve long been hankering to hear the bad news about global warming given the full Brecht, hop on that bike and head to the Public Theater, where The Great Immensity opened on Thursday.

title: Puzzle Solvers Complaint
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Its Friday, the beginning of the weekend, and its going to be tough to decide whether we want to CHILLAX or CATERWAUL and RAISE HELL. Lets let constructor Joel Fagliano help us make up our minds.

title: Kerry Rejects Absurd Russian Claims
description: Secretary of State John Kerry denounced Russian actions in Ukraine but stopped short of announcing measures in response.

title: Effort to Remove Landlord Who Made Units Unlivable
description: In a case that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is holding up as an example of egregious harassment, New York state and city officials are moving aggressively against a Brooklyn landlord accused of wrecking the kitchens and bathrooms of occupied apartments to drive out longtime tenants.

title: Bulls Star With Brooklyn Roots Is the Same as Ever: Different
description: Joakim Noah was an accomplished basketball player at Poly Prep Country Day School in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. He did many things well. He rebounded. He scored. He led the Blue Devils to two league titles.

title: Blue-Footed Boobies, a Galpagos Treasure, Under Threat
description: Blue-footed boobies are among the Galpagos Islands most beloved boldfaced names. But because of a lack of breeding, their numbers in the region are in serious decline, a new study says.

title: Prosecutors Deny Targeting DSouza on Use of Straw Donors
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan vigorously denied on Thursday that their prosecution of the conservative author and filmmaker Dinesh DSouza for alleged campaign finance violations was politically motivated, and they accused Mr. DSouza of lying to mask his criminal activity.

title: Against Pesky Flyers, the Rangers Hope Penalties Dont Mean Trouble
description: Coach Alain Vigneault knows the Rangers may troop to the penalty box in large numbers during Fridays Game 4 against the Philadelphia Flyers, as they did in winning Game 3.

title: City Worker Is Charged With Medicaid Fraud
description: He called himself A.T.M., a nickname that matched his initials, but also his habit of spending thousands of dollars on expensive clothes for himself and on gifts for his friends  among them some women at a beauty salon in Upper Manhattan, the authorities said.

title: Seth Meyers to Host the Emmy Awards on NBC
description: Seth Meyers will top off his first season as a host of a late-night show on NBC by serving as host of the Emmy Awards this August.

title: Pre-K Applicants Up 36% This Year; Mayors Challenge Is Finding Seats
description: Applications for prekindergarten programs in New York City schools rose by 36 percent this year, city officials announced on Thursday, as parents took advantage of Mayor Bill de Blasios promise to provide free classes to every 4-year-old in the city.

title: Selling Off the Newark Bears
description: Financial woes have led Newarks professional baseball team to fold. The Bears owners are auctioning off nearly everything, including lawn mowers, office furniture and the team bus.

title: Newark Bears Items Going, Going ...
description: NEWARK  A small white sticker has been slapped onto the portable batting cage that sits just beyond the center-field wall of Riverfront Stadium, among the weeds and a few winter-ruined baseballs. Auction, the sticker says. Lot Number 163.

title: Robert Gray, a Powerhouse in Washington, Dies at 92
description: Robert Gray, a powerful Washington lobbyist and public relations expert who began building connections while working in the Eisenhower administration and rose to the peak of his influence when his friend Ronald Reagan became president, died on April 18 in Miami. He was 92.

title: Confident Kane Renews Blackhawks Optimism
description: CHICAGO  Patrick Kane with the puck on his stick in overtime has usually meant good things for the Blackhawks over the years.

title: Ask Well: Do Foam Rollers Aid Workouts?
description: Question:

title: Word of the Day | nebulous
description: nebulous\ne-by-ls\ adjective

title: With Durant Struggling, Grizzlies Survive
description: MEMPHIS  Shortly after the Memphis Grizzlies Tony Allen checked into Thursday nights game, following the first television timeout, he located Kevin Durant and attached himself to Durants torso like a strip of Velcro. Durant misfired on a shot, and then another.

title: Times Minute | Real Cost of a Tomato
description: In the Video

title: Times Minute | Real Cost of a Tomato
description: A novel program to stop abuse of tomato workers in Florida. Also on the Minute, negotiations stalled during Presidents Obama visit to Asia and a preview of John Olivers new TV show.

title: Michael Glawogger, Who Filmed Lives of Desperation, Dies at 54
description: Michael Glawogger, an Austrian filmmaker known for globe-trotting documentaries that show people grappling with horrendous circumstances, died on Wednesday in Liberia, where he was planning his next movie. He was 54.

title: Whats on Friday
description: 9 P.M. (13) MATTHEW BOURNES SLEEPING BEAUTY In 1992, Mr. Bourne, the British choreographer, reinterpreted The Nutcracker, the first of three classic ballets set to scores by Tchaikovsky; in 1995, he unveiled his setting for Swan Lake. He completes the endeavor with this reimagining of the fairy tale about a princess who sleeps under a spell for 100 years, originally choreographed by Marius Petipa in 1890. Mr. Bournes version, taped at the Bristol Hippodrome in England, begins in that year with the birth of the heroine, Aurora (danced by Hannah Vassallo, above center, with Edwin Ray, left and Danny Reubens), who falls in love not with a prince but a gardener, Leo (Dominic North), and eventually awakens in the modern day. He also provides Leo with a rival, Caradoc (Adam Maskell), the dashingly vengeful son of the evil fairy who curses Aurora to death. The love story that Mr. Bourne substitutes isnt any more emotionally compelling than the original, Brian Seibert wrote in his review of the production, presented here by Great Performances, in The New York Times. Poetically, its a diminishment. The battle between good and evil is reduced to a tussle between the nice guy and the bad boy. Still, he said, Mr. Bourne is not an ungrateful recipient of the gift of Tchaikovskys score. He dedicates his Sleeping Beauty to the composer, whose work will survive this version. Its more than 100 years old and still likely to last as long as the undead.

title: India Election Digest: April 25
description: What you need to know on Friday about Indias elections: Mumbais voter turnout was the highest since 1989, the Aam Aadmi Party finds fans in Punjab, and villagers see the none of the above option as a means of protest.

title: Peoples Daily Editorial Fanned Flames of 1989 Protest
description: Twenty-five years ago, on the night of April 25, editors in newspaper offices across China received an editorial that was to run in Peoples Daily the next morning, and their papers were ordered to reprint on their front pages the Communist Party newspapers pronouncement on the student demonstrators who had occupied Tiananmen Square for nine days.

title: Real Communist Mouthpiece Rages Against Fake Communist Mouthpiece
description: The official mouthpiece of the Chinese Communist Party is in a rage over a parody Twitter account that for years has poked fun at the foibles of the Leninist state.

title: Corrections: April 25, 2014
description: NATIONAL

title: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, April 25, 2014
description: Use the following question for practice or just for fun.

title: R.B.S. to Drop Bonus Plan After British Agency Balks
description: LONDON  The Royal Bank of Scotland said on Friday that it would drop a plan to pay its bankers bonuses of up to two times their annual salaries after an agency that manages the British governments stake in the lender refused to back the proposal.

title: 6 Qs About the News | The American Middle Class Is No Longer the Worlds Richest
description: In The American Middle Class Is No Longer the Worlds Richest, David Leonhardt and Kevin Quealy report on how American incomes are losing their edge, except at the top.

title: Defying Moscow, Ukraine Threatens to Blockade Pro-Russian Militants
description: KIEV, Ukraine  The interim central government in Kiev threatened to blockade the eastern city of Slovyansk on Friday, defying warnings from Moscow not to confront pro-Russian militants entrenched in towns across eastern Ukraine.

title: How Common Is Drug Use in Your School?
description: This week prosecutors in an affluent suburb of Philadelphia announced the arrests of eight people on charges of distributing drugs in five public and private high schools and in three colleges. The headmaster at one of the private schools said in an interview that he was shocked and appalled by the charges and would re-examine the schools drug policy.

title: Far Out and Close Up
description: The San Francisco Chronicle columnist Herb Caen, who coined the term beatnik in 1958, saw them as a mass phenomenon, with hordes of young bearded kats and kits overrunning a party in North Beach and slopping up free booze. The poet Kenneth Rexroth, who introduced the first major reading of Beat poets, dismissed the whole phenomenon as a creation of the Luce magazine empire, carping that after the first five writers, it produced nothing. And when the writer Hettie Jones was asked about the Beat generation, she joked that everyone identified with it could fit into my living room.

title: Chinese Vice President Warns Hong Kong Over Protests
description: HONG KONG  In the bluntest warning yet from a Chinese Communist Party leader about possible protests in Hong Kongs financial district, Vice President Li Yuanchao has called the Occupy Central movement an illegal initiative that would threaten Hong Kongs prosperity.

title: The Industrial Art of Those Talented Bugattis
description: OXNARD, CALIF.  Aficionados have argued for ages over which individual has had the greatest influence on the automobile.

title: Russia Raises Rate to Bolster Economy After S.&P. Cuts Its Debt Rating
description: MOSCOW  With tensions over Ukraine continuing to mount, Russia is scrambling to stem the economic fallout, as its central bank unexpectedly raised a crucial interest rate on Friday.

title: New York Today: Moving Verses
description: Good morning on this fair Friday. Look out for changing weather.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: Inquiry in Ferry Disaster Shifts to Safety Certification
description: JINDO, South Korea  Prosecutors on Friday barred eight current and former officials from a maritime inspection agency from leaving South Korea, as the investigation of the ferry sinking last week that left more than 300 people dead or missing shifted to the agencies responsible for certifying ships as safe to travel.

title: Switzerlands Toxic Prosperity
description: On a warm midsummer night, a few months after my book about industrial pollution in the New Jersey town of Toms River was published, I watched a fireworks show over the Rhine River celebrating Swiss National Day. I was in Basel, the city where the chemical industry first took root more than 150 years ago.

title: The Global Diabetes Epidemic
description: Twelve years ago, my husband and I packed up all of our belongings and moved to Trivandrum  a steamy, tropical town at the southern tip of India in Kerala. At the time, I was a medical student interested in studying stroke. For the next six months I dressed in a sari and walked to work on jungle roads. At the hospital, I immediately began seeing a steady stream of young patients affected by strokes, many of whom were so severely disabled that they were unable to work. I initially suspected the cause was tuberculosis or dengue fever  after all, this was the developing world, where infections have long been primary culprits for disease. But I soon learned that my hunch was wrong.

title: Daily Report: Lobbying Surges After F.C.C. Tries Again on Net Neutrality
description: In the nine weeks since the Federal Communications Commission said it would try, for a third time, to write new rules to secure an open Internet, at least 69 companies, interest groups and trade associations  more than one a day  have met with or otherwise lobbied commission officials on what the rules should specify, Edward Wyatt reports.

title: Blurring Boundaries and Meaning
description: The course of Ingmar Bergmans reputation is a saga all its own. Indifferently received in his native Sweden, Bergmans early films were championed in France. Jean-Luc Godard hailed him as the most original of directors after Summer With Monika  a sort of Neo-Realist Rebel Without a Cause enlivened by Harriet Anderssons skinny-dipping and originally released in the United States as an exploitation film  played in Paris in the mid-50s.

title: Follow the Money: Gretchen Morgenson on Wall Street
description: Gretchen Morgenson, a Times reporter and business columnist, won a Pulitzer Prize in 2002 for beat reporting. Her column, Fair Game, appears in the Sunday Business section. We asked her to talk about her career and how she works.

title: Funds and Downloads Dwindling, a Start-Up Is Put on Hold
description: Last July, we wrote about a start-up, NoChains, with a free app designed to help users find the best independent, nonchain restaurants in a particular city.

title: Alstom Shares Suspended on Reports of G.E. Bid
description: Shares of Alstom, the French industrial conglomerate, were suspended Friday on the Paris exchange at the request of the market regulator amid reports that the company is negotiating a multibillion-dollar deal to sell its energy business to General Electric.

title: Hello, Stranger
description: If youve ever been on a subway or public bus, you know the rules. Dont make eye contact, stay as far away from other people as the space allows, and for the love of God, dont talk to anyone. But what if the rules are wrong?

title: Sothebys Battle Heats Up
description: BARE KNUCKLES AT SOTHEBYS | The battle between Sothebys and Daniel S. Loeb, the outspoken hedge fund mogul and the auction houses biggest shareholder, is heading to its final stages, Alexandra Stevenson and Michael J. de la Merced write in DealBook. On Thursday, Mr. Loeb gained an advantage in the standoff as the proxy advisory firm Institutional Shareholder Services recommended that shareholders vote for two of the three board nominees he has proposed.

title: Bake and Switch
description: You can tell a lot about a country by its croissants. At least you can tell a lot about America, where croissants dont rest on their laurels or cling to fussy, Old World norms. Here they innovate. They disrupt.

title: Obama Administration Plans New Rules to Grade Teacher Training Programs
description: The Obama administration announced on Friday that it was developing ratings of teacher preparation programs to make them more accountable for their graduates performance in the classroom.

title: In Our Pages: April 26
description: 1914: American Womans Club Tea

title: After Cadmium Rice, now Lead and Arsenic Rice
description: Soil in Chinas leading rice-producing region shows high levels of heavy metal contamination, in a study that suggests that the proximity of mining and industry to agricultural areas is posing serious threats to the countrys food chain.

title: Using the Foreign to Grasp the Familiar
description: In The Other Language, the title story of Francesca Marcianos new collection, an Italian teenager named Emma falls in love with English. The attraction has a lot to do with the person speaking it, an intriguing English boy at the Greek beach resort where Emma is staying with her family, but its hard to separate the strands of desire. Is the boy her entry ticket to English, or vice versa?

title: Editorial Contest Winner | Why I, a Heterosexual Teenage Boy, Want to See More Men in Speedos
description: We are publishing an essay a day, in the order of submission, to honor each of the Top 10 winners of our Student Editorial Contest. You can find the full collection here.

title: Piketty and Pareto
description: Well, its Piketty day at the Times, with David Brooks and yours truly even having more or less matching headlines. And Davids take reminds me of something Ive been meaning to do: explain one important point in Piketty that even economist readers have, it seems, tended to miss.

title: New Vehicles and Recalls Cut Ford Profit
description: DETROIT  The rising tide of recalls has made it more expensive for automakers to do business, even in the absence of a major crisis like the ignition switch recall at General Motors.

title: Guest Post | Get Ready for College Writing by Learning to Revise
description: Do you have your students revise their essays? If so, is their process mostly a matter of adding some commas and correcting spelling errors  or are they actually rethinking their writing to make it clearer and stronger?

title: A Single Adoptive Mother  in 1937
description: Sometimes its hard to remember that adoption (the kind that doesnt involve orphanages and gruel) is more than a contemporary phenomenon. Reading todays human-interest stories on the topic can make it seem like adoption is a parenting challenge of our time, like baking gluten-free snacks or finding story books friendly to same sex parenting.

title: Obama Offers Support to South Korea at a Moment of Trauma and Tension
description: SEOUL, South Korea  President Obama arrived here on Friday offering solace to a country traumatized by the sinking of a ferry that killed scores, and showing solidarity at a time when the Korean Peninsula is rife with tension.

title: Harrods Displays the World According to Prada
description: Art, film, architecture and fashion are frequent bedfellows, but no one has blended the genres as poignantly or provocatively asMiuccia Prada. Now, the legendary London department store Harrods is putting Pradas interdisciplinary collaborationson displayin a monthlong exhibit titled Pradasphere, opening April 30. Curated by the graphic designer Michael Rock, who lent his conceptual aesthetic to the houses spring 2014 runway show, the installation traces Miuccia Pradas trajectory of influence through fashion, art, architecture, cinema and even sports. Visitors can view a Prada history wall with images from the houses Fondazioneand its partnership with Americas Cup. A screening room will show short films made in collaboration with directors like Wes Anderson and Roman Polanski. The brands iconic architectural projects withRem Koolhaas/OMAand Herzog & de Meuronwill also be exhibited. And, naturally, theres plenty of fashion to see and buy:an on-site pop-up will sell a special capsule collection of clothing, bags, shoes and accessories, inspired by archival designs from the brands first 100 years  even before Miuccia joined the family business.

title: Public Grooming
description: Dear Diary,

title: Bharatiya Janata Partys Message Is Muddled By Polarization
description: MUMBAI, India  Even as the Bharatiya Janata Partys candidate for prime minister, Narendra Modi, has attempted to distance himself from his partys right-wing Hindu nationalist ideology and focus on economic development, polarizing speeches by party members and allies dominated headlines early this week.

title: Report Says N.J. Transit, Not Port Authority, Should Run PATH Lines
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey should turn the money-losing PATH commuter rail system over to New Jerseys state-run transit agency to free up money for big infrastructure projects, a report released on Friday recommended.

title: Bombshells Felt in the Balcony
description: Of all the surprise turns in musical compositions, one stands out as practically a non sequitur. It comes well into the choral finale of Beethovens Ninth Symphony, the composers setting of Schillers Ode to Joy. As part of a recent interactive project I invited readers to share their choices of great surprises in music, and several suggested this unexpected episode in this Beethoven work.

title: Rarely One for Sugarcoating
