description: The smell hits you first: sweet but with an acrid edge, like a thousand burned marshmallows. Then youre struck by the space, five stories high and more than a football field long. The storage shed of the Domino sugar factory, on the East River in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, was built in 1927 to hold mountains of raw sugar due for whitening. The plant was shuttered a decade ago, yet its crumbling walls still drip with molasses.

title: Tracking Future and Hip-Hops Growlers
description: Popcast this week: how Future became one of hip-hops most influential vocal stylists.

title: Mookie Wilson on Life After the Mets
description: The former New York Mets outfielder Mookie Wilson talks to Dave Itzkoff about his new book, Mookie: Life, Baseball, and the 86 Mets, his career after the Major Leagues and that infamous grounder down the first-base line.

title: Frustrations of the Heterodox
description: Its kind of a sideshow in the larger scheme of things, but something worth noting is taking place on the fringes (literally) of economic discussion: an upwelling of frustration on the part of heterodox economists. You see it in Thomas Palleys complaint about gattopardo economics, which I discussed yesterday; you see it in the demands for a radical change in the economics curriculum, which Simon Wren-Lewis wrote about yesterday.

title: A Country in Bloom
description: Every spring millions of Japanese visit parks to take in the brief but magnificent bloom of their countrys cherry trees. They gather for so-called hanami parties, setting out elaborate meals of bento boxes with sake. (A smaller celebration in Washington marks the flowering of trees given to the city by the Tokyo mayor in 1912.) In some places, the scene is rowdy with people in their 20s; in others, families wander quietly among trees illuminated by paper lanterns. The photographer Matthew Pillsbury captured the cherry blossoms at their peak in several places in Japan this month. The crowds are unlike anything Ive ever seen, he says. You see groups of elderly people sitting next to groups of teenagers. They all clap when the blooms start falling off the tree. Theyre basically having the very same party. Julie Bosman

title: Reply All: The 4.13.14 Issue
description: THE BALLAD OF GEESHIE AND ELVIE

title: Occupy My Condo
description: I know of someone who has lived mortgage-free for three years while the bank foreclosed on his apartment. During that time, the man paid his monthly maintenance to the building but did not pay his mortgage. His rationale: He had been in the furniture business and lost much of his income with the financial crisis, and not one of the bankers responsible for the meltdown has gone to jail. And furthermore, as a result, his apartment was worth less than he paid for it. Does any of that matter? Is strategic loan default ethical? NAME WITHHELD

title: Could You Repeat That?
description: A new name just under the legal limit; tech specs take on a composer.

title: Playing the Cards
description: A year ago, I found out that my son, Isaac, won $300,000 playing online poker the previous day. His mother, Francie, was pleased to hear about this on her way out the door for work. The next day, I learned that he won another $62,000.

title: Who Made That Packing Peanut?
description: In 1960, a research chemist named Maurice Laverne Zweigle packed a raw egg and a few handfuls of skinny, bendy, polystyrene noodles into a small cardboard box, sealed the flaps and tossed it off a third-floor roof. His invention worked: The egg was unscathed.

title: Video Reviews of Brick Mansions, The German Doctor and For No Good Reason
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on the action film Brick Mansions, the drama The German Doctor and the documentary For No Good Reason. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: A Cube With a Twist: At 40, It Puzzles Anew
description: JERSEY CITY  A Rubiks cube can be twisted and twiddled in 43,252,003,274,489,856,000 different ways, and 43,252,003,274,489,855,999 of them are wrong.

title: How to Get Better Insurance Data, Without Encouraging Conspiracy Theories
description: It has been a week since opponents of health-care reform accused the Obama administration of conspiring with the Census Bureau to undercount the number of uninsured Americans in an attempt to make the Affordable Care Act look more successful than it really is.

title: Varieties of the Visible World
description: In Barbara Ehrenreichs new memoir, Living With a Wild God, reviewed this week by Parul Sehgal, the author describes a startling moment she experienced as a teenager when something peeled off the visible world, taking with it all meaning, inference, association, labels and words.

title: Vision Quest
description: In May of 1959, Barbara Ehrenreich was taken into the mountains in Northern California by a boy looking for dynamite. They spent the night in the car, and in the morning, she wandered into town on foot. It happened then and there  an onrush of mystical visions  something shed experienced before but never quite so brilliantly. The world flamed into life, she writes in her new book, Living With a Wild God. Something poured into me and I poured out into it.

title: Why Everyones Talking About the Great Lime Shortage
description: We will all tell our children of the dark days of the Great Lime Shortage of 2014, when Mexican restaurants raised their margarita prices and otherwise respectable bars committed the blasphemy of serving gin and tonics with a slice of lemon. The shortage has become the subject of news media fascination, with the latest piece on the front page of Fridays Wall Street Journal.

title: An Unwanted Reprise Riles a Soviet Rocker
description: IN the days before Russias annexation of the Crimean Peninsula last month, a state-sponsored television network broadcast a bellicose video montage of events in Ukraine set to This Trains on Fire, a song by the celebrated underground Soviet rock band Aquarium.

title: Obamas Comments in South Korea
description: President Obama discussed North Koreas nuclear threat and offered condolences to the families who lost loved ones in the South Korean ferry incident.

title: Tribeca Film Festival: Emmanuelle Seigner Turns the Tables on Roman Polanski
description: Emmanuelle Seigner, the French actress, singer and former model, has a multilayered appreciation for the film Venus in Fur, in which she stars as a sadomasochistically savvy, table-turning seductress.

title: Today in Small Business: Seattles Minimum Wage Plan Falters
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Rite of Summer Series to Bring Eclectic Music to Governors Island
description: Rite of Summer, an outdoor series of free classical music concerts with an emphasis on contemporary works, will open its fourth season on May 31 with a performance by Dawn of Midi, a Brooklyn piano, bass and percussion trio that performs electronica-inspired music on acoustic instruments. The festival, which is directed by the pianists Blair McMillen and Pam Goldberg, will be held at Colonels Row on Governors Island, with performances at 1 and 3 p.m.

title: Treating Appendicitis Without Surgery
description: For many years, immediate surgery has been considered the only proper treatment for appendicitis in children. Now a small study suggests that in some cases, antibiotics alone may be better.

title: Unsustainable Living
description: A story of land, water, relationships and love, The Ogallala Road is the 100-year history of a farming family in Kansas as well as the second of Julene Bairs memoirs. The first, One Degree West: Reflections of a Plainsdaughter, was well received, but this new one is more polished, touching and engaging.

title: Ganglands
description: Theres no way around it. To exercise power is to be ridden with guilt. To step is to step on. This, among other things, is the paradox of modern Israel. A nation meant to harbor and normalize the Jews has, in the process, entangled this ancient people with the brutality of sovereignty in a way so old its new. For a lot of us, its been a thrilling, maddening, disorienting 65-plus years. Its this mood  pride wrapped in fear, the quest for the ordinary pitted against prophecy  and the violence that accompanies it that Zachary Lazar explores in his brilliant new novel, I Pity the Poor Immigrant.

title: The Upshot, and 45 That Didnt Make the Cut
description: In keeping with the spirit of this site  which we hope includes transparency, engagement with our readers and, yes, a willingness to publish lists when lists are called for  were publishing a comprehensive roster of runners-up for our name.

title: Directors Cut
description: A recent Harpers Index offers the following juxtaposed statistics: In the last 20 years, seven Academy Award winners have thanked God in their acceptance speeches, whereas 30 have thanked Harvey Weinstein. If this troubles you, allow me to offer two thoughts: (1) Relax. While you are in heaven snorkeling through a sea of mai tais, the sinners (Hollywood stars, Harvey, this reviewer) will be stuck in a warmer place for the duration, where only the explicitly Christian films of the former Growing Pains heartthrob-turned-evangelist Kirk Cameron are shown, and only fake butter is available at the concession stand. (2) Skip David Grands Mount Terminus, an impressively conceived, often very entertaining novel that celebrates the oversize talents and ambitions of two cinema pioneers, the (fictional) half brothers Simon Reuben and Bloom Rosenbloom, even as it explores the destruction wrought to construct a home for their fledgling industry. Grand has written a work from which Harvey Weinstein might make a terrific, multilayered film.

title: Let Us Remember
description: The tall young men was Irwin Shaws name for the squad of just-graduated Ivy Leaguers who showed up at his Paris apartment in the American arrondissement in the early 1950s to beat him in tennis, drink his booze and bask in the afterglow of Hemingway and Stein. One of these urbane aspiring writers was 24-year-old Peter Matthiessen, fresh out of Yale and wrestling with his first novel, who, along with George Plimpton, William Styron, Harold Humes, Thomas Guinzburg and a few other hard-partying expats, would go on to start The Paris Review in 1953.

title: Favorite Sins
description: Kyle Minor wants you to know that Praying Drunk  his second story collection, after In the Devils Territory  is not actually, or only, a collection. In the epigraph, he warns: These stories are meant to be read in order. This is a book, not just a collection. dont skip around.

title: Status Update
description: Since the word teenager was coined 70 years ago, adults have defined adolescents by one extreme or another. They are rebels without causes or activist leaders, mindless consumers or cultural kingpins, digital natives or nafs. Enter Danah Boyd, a principal researcher at Microsoft Research and a research assistant professor at New York University. In life, Boyd retains the spirit of a youthful rebel, with her pierced tongue and name spelled in anti-Establishment lowercase. And perhaps in part thanks to its authors identification with youth, Its Complicated avoids many of the typical either-or clichs about adolescence. Boyds new book is layered and smart.

title: Apocalypse Again
description: The Origin of the Brunists, published in 1966, is Robert Coovers first novel, and also his most well behaved. In 1979, he described it as an attempt to pay dues . . . to traditional fiction, and as such, it offers a realist account of a cult that develops around Giovanni Bruno, the damaged survivor of a small-town mining disaster. Brunos group fixes on April 19 as the date for the Rapture, but as the titles Darwinian allusion suggests, nothing divine will happen on their chosen mountain. Instead, the books climax is a primal eruption of violence, dark testimony to another flaw in the evolution of mind.

title: The Man and the Message
description: In an essay entitled Reflections on Gandhi, George Orwell wrote: Saints should always be judged guilty until they are proved innocent. While he acquitted Gandhi, he might have been harder on Cesar Chavez, the great farmworker leader. Certainly in this engrossing biography Miriam Pawel, a former editor and reporter with Newsday and The Los Angeles Times, is out to show both the good and bad. In the 1960s and early 70s, Chavez did seem like a version of Gandhi. Organizing the dispossessed, our own untouchables, he fasted to the point of death, staged mass marches up and down California that resembled religious pilgrimages, and defeated growers with nationwide boycotts that even Gandhi would have found hard to duplicate. Back then, many of the best and saintliest of Americas young quit their jobs or dropped out of school to join up with Chavez and live lives of voluntary poverty.

title: Retreat and Advance
description: On Sept. 2, 1945, Japan formally ended World War II by surrendering to the Allies aboard the American battleship Missouri in Tokyo Bay. As a reminder of Japans brutality to captured Allied soldiers, Gen. Douglas MacArthur placed two skeletal survivors of Japanese prisoner-of-war camps  United States Gen. Jonathan Wainwright, whose troops had endured the infamous Bataan Death March, and British Gen. Arthur Percival, who surrendered Singapore  in the Japanese delegations direct line of sight.

title: An N.H.L. Champion Pursues Another Cup, This Time in Russia
description: PRAGUE  When Mike Keenan and the Rangers hoisted the Stanley Cup in 1994, four Russian-born players became the first from their country to achieve the honor. Two decades later, Keenan is trying to become the first North American coach to win a Gagarin Cup title in the Kontinental Hockey League.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: In the Garden
description: THE GARDENER OF VERSAILLES  My Life in the Worlds Grandest Garden  By Alain Baraton  Translated by Christopher Brent MurrayRizzoli, $26.95.

title: Double Game
description: In December 2006, Carlotta Gall visited Quetta in Pakistan, close to the border with Afghanistan, to trace the families of Taliban suicide bombers. Her investigations were not welcome to the powerful Inter-Services Intelligence (ISI), the main intelligence arm of the Pakistan military, which was determined to hide its close relations with the Taliban. Plainclothes intelligence agents smashed open the door of her hotel room and seized her notebooks, computer and cellphone. She protested when one of the agents grabbed her handbag, and he promptly punched her twice in the face, knocking her down. The officer in charge accused her of trying to interview Taliban members, which he said was forbidden. She learned later that her rough treatment had been ordered by the head of the ISI press department to discourage her from reporting ISI-Taliban links.

title: Hostile Climate
description: For the first time since 2001, more Americans believe it was a mistake to send troops to Afghanistan than see it as the right call, at least according to a recent Gallup poll. Almost 13 years after the attacks of Sept. 11, were conflicted about what we are still doing in Afghanistan and confused about what happened there. Americans are tired of Americas long war, especially as it drones on.

title: Art Matters | How to Buy a Famous Artists Work for $350
description: An exhibition and sale tomorrow night at the Santa Monica Museum of Art mounts a challenge to that pervasive problem of taste: The beholder may have the eye, but not the means. At Incognito 10, the museums annual benefit, the walls will be lined with 700 pieces of art  donated by more than 550 artists  whose authorship will be kept anonymous until after each work is sold.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE THIRD COAST: When Chicago Built the American Dream,  by Thomas Dyja. (Penguin, $18.) Dyjas robust history weaves together the stories of the artists, styles and ideas that made Chicago a crucible for culture and innovation before and after World War II: Mies van der Rohes Modernist architecture, Ray Krocs McDonalds franchise, the Chess brothers supercharged rock n roll  all of which flourished despite violent segregation and a rugged, often corrupt, political scene.

title: Movie Review: Brick Mansions
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Brick Mansions.

title: Who Killed Anna Mae?
description: On Feb. 24, 1976, a rancher in South Dakota was installing a fence on land situated along the edge of Pine Ridge Indian Reservation when he spotted a body at the bottom of a 30-foot embankment. The badly decomposed corpse, in jeans and a maroon ski jacket, lay with knees pushed up toward chest. A coroner later determined that the woman had been dead for more than two months. The back of her head was matted with blood, and there was a single bullet wound at the base of her skull. She had been shot at close range.

title: Reading Message Headers in Gmail
description: Q. How do you see the full delivery path of a message in Gmail on the web?

title: New York City in 17 Syllables
description: The New York Times asked readers to write a haiku about New York City. The response was as impressive as the city itself. A panel of judges chose their favorite entries.

title: Editors Choice
description: LOVERS AT THE CHAMELEON CLUB, PARIS 1932,  by Francine Prose. (Harper, $26.99.) Prose, a subtle psychologist, has created a genuinely evil character in Lou Villars, a cross-dressing French racecar driver and Nazi collaborator.

title: Inside the List
description: Behind the Counter: The protagonist of Gabrielle Zevins novel The Storied Life of A. J. Fikry  new at No. 15 on the hardcover fiction list  is a cranky bookstore owner, depressed after the death of his wife and the theft of a prized volume, who gradually perks up while caring for a baby abandoned in his shop. Book buyers, it turns out, like to read about booksellers. In the past few years, other best-selling examples include The Marriage Bargain, by Jennifer Probst (a billionaire proposes to a bookstore owner), Murder of a Bookstore Babe, by Denise Swanson (death by shelving), and Mr. Penumbras 24-Hour Bookstore, by Robin Sloan (a web designer finds a night job at a mysterious shop). Yet Zevin recently told readers of The National Post in Canada that as appealing as the idea of running a bookstore is in theory, in reality shes just not interested. I think this is the pet pipe dream of many of us who love books, she said. I sometimes like to imagine the kind of bookstore I would run. I have, for instance, a deeply impractical idea for a performance art space/minimalist bookstore. The bookstore would only sell one title a month, and there would be a play or art installation of some kind based around that book. However, this is all just fantasy. Running a bookstore is ridiculously difficult, and the challenges bookstores face  e-books, online competition  are enormous. I suspect the closest Ill ever come to owning a bookstore is having written The Storied Life of A. J. Fikry.

title: On Their Death Bed, Physical Books Have Finally Become Sexy
description: A few years ago, I started noticing a small wave of a new kind of book: highly displayable coffee-table books about the display of books. They had names like At Home With Books and Books Do Furnish a Room, and felt a bit like an adjunct to that classic, recursive Seinfeld gag: Kramers coffee-table book about coffee tables that could double as a coffee table.

title: When the Iron Horse (Almost) Played Tarzan
description: Seventy-five years ago this Fourth of July, Lou Gehrig, known as the Iron Horse, suffering from the fatal neurodegenerative disease that now bears his name, retired at 36 from baseball. Standing in Yankee Stadium before more than 60,000 fans, he made his unforgettable declaration that despite his bad break, he was the luckiest man on the face of the earth.

title: Movie Review: For No Good Reason
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews For No Good Reason.

title: Monty Python Reunion Show to Be Screened in Theaters
description: If you were dying to catch Monty Pythons reunion show at the 02 Arena in London but were not able to score a ticket, cheer up: the final night of the run, July 20, will be beamed in HD to 1,500 movie theaters around the world. Picturehouse Entertainment announced on Thursday that it had secured the international distribution rights to the show, which will be directed by Aubrey Powell and produced by Fiz Oliver.

title: Movie Review: The German Doctor
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews The German Doctor.

title: Obama on Halt of Mideast Peace Talks
description: President Obama said he does not expect a prompt restart to the talks on Middle East peace, saying that neither Israelis nor Palestinians have shown the will to make tough decisions.

title: Collapse of Peace Talks Gives Israel Easy Exit, but Leaves It in a Precarious Spot
description: JERUSALEM  Less than a month ago, Israel was in Secretary of State John Kerrys cross hairs, accused of sabotaging the peace process he had championed by continuing construction in West Bank settlements and balking on a promise to release long-serving Palestinian prisoners. But when Israel suspended the stalemated negotiations on Thursday, it did so with Washingtons tacit blessing, providing a fractured government not fully committed to peace a low-risk exit strategy.

title: A Policy-Making Mystery in the Renminbis Decline
description: HONG KONG  As President Obama visits Asia in a bid to shore up American alliances, he faces an emerging challenge from the regions behemoth, China, whose currency has experienced a gradual but unrelenting decline over the last 10 days.

title: Election Watchdog Fights Lonely Battle on Paid News Coverage
description: NEW DELHI  One of the biggest threats to a clean voting process in India, as identified by the Election Commission, is not only extremely difficult to police, its also perfectly legal.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Duke Lacrosse Case
description: This week, William D. Cohan talks about The Price of Silence; Parul Sehgal and John Williams discuss the weeks literary news; Amy Chozick discusses Elizabeth Warrens A Fighting Chance; Ms. Sehgal on Barbara Ehrenreichs Living With a Wild God; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: CreepShield Claims to Out the Creeps in Online Dating
description: As facial recognition software proliferates, some developers are bound to test our comfort level with the notion of strangers seeking to put a name to our faces whether were online or on the street.

title: Quiche Meets Whole Wheat
description: I agree wholeheartedly with the Tufts nutrition professor Alice H. Lichtensteins recent letter to the editor in this newspaper, in which she writes, Particularly in an era when dietary restraint is not our strong suit, returning to butter and fatty cuts of meat may likewise return us to the high rates of heart disease we had decades ago.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Duke Lacrosse Case
description: This week, William D. Cohan, Amy Chozick and Parul Sehgal.

title: Haiku Challenge: A Poets Picks
description: Marie Howe, the state poet of New York, reflects on writing haiku and The Timess Haiku Challenge, which asked readers to submit a 17-syllable poem about New York City.

title: The Most Important Question You Can Ask
description: When I heard this week that Michael Phelps was planning to return to competitive swimming, my first reaction was to feel a little sad for him. I honor Mr. Phelps for the discipline, grit and passion he needed to win a record 18 gold medals. But I also sense that hes going back to swimming because hes chasing a high that hasnt held up.

title: Pakistani Censorship, by Other Means
description: Raza Rumi, a prominent Pakistani journalist, narrowly escaped death on March 28 when his car was riddled with bullets in Lahore. His driver, Mustafa, a 25-year-old newlywed, was killed in the ambush, which took place as they were driving away from the set of Razas weekly television show on Express News. The topic that day had been how the countrys blasphemy laws are misused to persecute religious minorities in Pakistan, a regular subject for Raza.

title: Steamed Clams With Spring Herbs
description: Melissa Clark makes steamed clams with fresh tarragon and minced chives.

title: Fewer U.S. Graduates Opt for College After High School
description: THE proportion of new American high school graduates who go on to college  a figure that rose regularly for decades  now appears to be declining.

title: Grilling Jon Favreau
description: In a cellphone video, The Timess David Carr captured a bit of a recent interview with the director and star of the new film Chef.

title: Jimmy Elliott, a Senior JPMorgan Deal Adviser, to Retire
description: Jimmy Elliott, one of JPMorgan Chases most senior deal makers, plans to retire, the firm announced in an internal memorandum on Friday.

title: Pasta Is Not Their Only Habitat
description: My usual destination for a mound of steamed clams is on top of a bowl of pasta. Linguine with white clam sauce has such a lusty, garlicky appeal that I tend to forget that there are other equally tempting ways to eat clams.

title: International Prosecutor Weighs Case in Ukraine Killings
description: PARIS  The prosecutor of the International Criminal Court announced Friday that she would consider whether grounds exist to open a formal criminal investigation into the killings of civilians during antigovernment protests in Ukraine in the last months of President Viktor F. Yanukovychs tenure.

title: Andrew Cuomos Tantrum
description: After promising repeatedly that he would clean up Albany, Gov. Andrew Cuomo suddenly cancelled the Moreland Commission to Investigate Public Corruption last monthbefore the Commission was anywhere near finished digging into details about how politicians and lobbyists do business in New York State.

title: Hot Off the Grill, Steak and a Movie
description: LOS ANGELES  The grill on the balcony was hot, the steaks had been rubbed with coarse salt and pepper, and the berries were soaking in Grand Marnier. The only thing needed was a cook.

title: Wheelies: The Mazdas Money Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Ex-Finance Chief at Bank of America to Pay $7.5 Million in Settlement
description: The New York State attorney general announced Friday that the office had reached a $7.5 million settlement with Joe L. Price, the former chief financial officer for Bank of America, over allegations that the banks management withheld material information related to its 2008 merger with Merrill Lynch.

title: Donating, and Making Sure the Money Is Put to Work
description: Each year, we file a report card on our financial lives. It tells us what we earned, a bit about what we saved, some details on what we own and often includes a tally of our generosity. True, most people dont read their tax returns this way, but its helpful to think of them as a conversation starter and a guide to what we can do better next year.

title: Mexican Zoo Welcomes Zonkey
description: A zoo in northern Mexico said a zonkey, a rare cross between a zebra and a donkey, was born on Monday and given the name of Khumba.

title: In Lagos, the 1% Takes Stock
description: A burgeoning wealthy class is settling into one of Africas fastest-growing cities, attracting designers, world-class architects and a growing creative community that seeks to preserve its culture through art and fashion.

title: A Paris Hotel Offers Cultural Excursions for Kids
description: Hotels offering inventive in-house childrens programs is a well-established trend, but Le Royal Monceau Raffles Paris goes a step further with activities that take kids between the ages of 5 and 15 out of the property and around the city.

title: Alaskans: Mark Begich is using his clout.
description: Facing a re-election challenge, Begich, a Democrat, wants his constituents in Alaska to know that hes putting senatorial power to work. Three times in April his office has issued news releases that begin with Begich Uses Clout and went on to describe Mr. Begichs interventions with federal agencies. Although such clout-wielding might seem a part of the job, most recent congressional statements have avoided using the word. It has been used in the title of a Senate news release just one other time in the current Congress, when the New Hampshire Republican Kelly Ayotte posted a Concord Monitor article about potential cuts at the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard.

title: Tribeca Film Festival: Aliens, Romance and the Vicious Brothers
description: Alien abduction films and romantic comedies are the Harry Reid and John Boehner of movies. Theyre just two different people. But the mismatched genres blend in unexpected ways in Extraterrestrial, a new science-fiction film written by Stuart Ortiz and Colin Minihan, a k a the Vicious Brothers (Grave Encounters), and directed by Mr. Minihan.

title: North Korea Says It Detained U.S. Tourist Seeking Shelter There
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A 24-year-old American tourist who said he was seeking shelter in North Korea has been detained there for more than two weeks and is being held on charges of a gross violation of its legal order, the countrys official Korean Central News Agency reported on Friday.

title: Image of the Day: April 25
Amazons Shrinking Profit Sets Off a Seismic Shock to Its Shares
description: Is a 20-year honeymoon coming to an end?

title: 36 Hours in Belo Horizonte, Brazil
description: Belo Horizonte, the lively industrial capital of Brazils second most populous state, Minas Gerais, has always attracted hordes of visitors  the kind who carry briefcases and laptops, that is. But more and more leisure travelers have been stopping by on their way to one of the art worlds most seductive new attractions, the Instituto Inhotim, a fantasy landscape of world-class contemporary art 35 miles outside of town. Soccer fans arent far behind, with the World Cup coming to town in June: six matches will be held in the citys overhauled stadium, the Mineiro. Both categories of visitors may be surprised at what else they find: a set of brand-new museums housed in neo-Classical-style palaces that until 2010 housed state government agencies; an almost overwhelming number of night-life options; and new and old takes on the states soul-comforting cuisine. So what if the hotels still lean toward business over boutique?

title: A Spiritual Legacy Endures in Healthy Eating
description: SEATTLE  I ordered the California omelet. It was fresh and capably cooked, with ample, bright green slices of avocado. The service was cheery and efficient. Were it not for the video of an older Bangladeshi immigrant performing heroic acts of strength that was playing on a loop on a flat-screen television, I would have remembered Silence-Heart-Nest, in the Fremont neighborhood of Seattle, as just an above-average vegetarian brunch spot.

title: Pharrell Williams Wrote a Book. Now He Needs Your Help.
description: Singalongs seem kind of quaint these days, but the singer Pharrell Williams  whose current hit, Happy, has a chorus that seduces listeners into joining in  has come up with a new twist. He has completed a book, Inspiration, and has invited fans to participate in a write-along while they wait for it to be published.

title: Along the Oslo Fjord, an Arts District Springs Up
description: Some neighborhoods change overnight, but Tjuvholmen (Thiefs Island in Norwegian) didnt exist until about a year and a half ago. Between strategic urban planning and fast-tracked construction, the trendy arts district emerged fully formed on a tiny island along the Oslo Fjord and, in equally short order, became the most-talked-about area in the Norwegian capital. With art every which way, from water sculptures to outdoor installations, sleek galleries and the Renzo Piano-designed Astrup Fearnley Museum, its easy to overlook the other draws: a man-made beach, a sculpture garden, a slew of restaurants and many an opportunity to people-watch the nouveau riche crowd. And with the city center a short walk away, the island is never too removed from the rest of town.

title: Massaging Your Soul
description: I felt a nap coming on, but I was late for class. I should be totally upfront here and confess that the class was on sleeping. For $75 and an hour and a half of my day, a registered nurse named Sheryl went through a few pro tips on how to get the most restful seven hours possible.

title: Waiting Game Follows Union Vote by Northwestern Players
description: EVANSTON, Ill.  Northwesterns scholarship football players voted Friday on whether to certify the first union in college sports, a landmark day that was closely watched by the N.C.A.A., college administrators and politicians across the country.

title: Times Minute | State of Play in Ukraine
description: Andrew Roth reports from Eastern Ukraine and David Herszenhorn reports from Moscow as Ukraine looks for an end to the standoff between Russia and the West.

title: On the Road to Matrimony, a Detour for a President
description: Portia Wells grew up in rural Washington State doing crafts in 4-H and entering her art projects in county fairs. In college, she majored in wood and furniture design.

title: Times Minute | State of Play in Ukraine
description: In the Video

title: Harley-Davidson, Jaguar and Mazda Issue Recalls
description: Harley-Davidson is recalling about 9,100 motorcycles because they can unexpectedly run out of fuel and stall, while Jaguar is recalling almost 300 vehicles because prolonged, aggressive driving could cause rear suspension failure, according to reports posted on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website.

title: Girl Fatally Stabbed at School in Connecticut on Day of Prom
description: MILFORD, Conn.  A 16-year-old student was stabbed to death in the hallway of a high school here on Friday morning, the day of the schools junior prom.

title: An Eye for Design, Passed Through the Bloodlines
description: A show of works by three generations of the Bugattis reveals talents that extended far beyond automobile design.

title: 10 Years Later, the Clique Still Reigns
description: In the 2004 film Mean Girls, Regina George, iron-fisted ruler of the high school in-crowd, snaps at her sidekick, Gretchen Wieners, over some newfangled slang Gretchen is testing out. Stop trying to make fetch happen, Regina snarls. Its not going to happen.

title: Alstom Split Would Energize Its Business Units
description: Ending the days of Alstom as an unwieldy conglomerate would end many of its headaches. Given time, the group could probably take care of its problems on its own. Outside help would allow it to speed up the recovery. And General Electric could be a powerful catalyst for the transformation.

title: Netflix vs. Amazon, and the New Economics of Television
description: Its been a busy week for the companies in the business of trying to revolutionize how we watch television.

title: Big Ticket | For $13.4 Million, Hitching Post Included
description: A quaint brick-and-limestone carriage house at 165 East 73rd Street that spent 110 years under the ownership of one family sold for $13.4 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: The Horseless eCarriage Is an Option for a Horse-Free Central Park
description: Horse-drawn landau carriages have long been part of the scenery in Central Park, but if animal rights activists have their way that will stop. Detractors of the coaches say that keeping horses in New York City, and driving the carriages through traffic from stables on the West Side, is cruel to the horses.

title: A Portrait and the History It Holds
description: While she was an undergraduate at the University of St. Andrews in Scotland in the 1990s, Misan Sagay visited the nearby Scone Palace, where a rare double portrait caught her eye. Painted in the Gainsborough style of aristocratic figures in an Arcadian landscape, the canvas showed two young women swathed in lustrous satin, gleaming pearls circling their swan necks. The vivacious one on the left is biracial; her unhurried companion is white.

title: 25 Dead Cats Found Hanging in Yonkers Trees
description: Glenn Stefanik was working with his crew from the Yonkers Department of Public Works on Thursday morning, clearing debris from a wooded area overlooking the Hudson River, when he caught sight of something strange.

title: Limes Too Expensive? Try an Upshot Gimlet
description: It has been a long week. Its time for an Upshot Gimlet.

title: Clip: Ida
description: A scene from the film directed by Pawel Pawlikowski.

title: Stumbling Onto Reminders of Holocaust
description: A young man stands inside a hole sheathed in dense forest, shoveling dirt, as two women  one young, the other middle-aged  silently watch. The older woman sinks down, taking off her glove to accept a small object just beyond the shot. As the young man bends over, his hat respectfully removed, the woman takes off her scarf to wrap the object  a tiny skull.

title: Was Your Grandmother Your Bridesmaid?
description: Traditionally, grandmothers received little more recognition on a grandchilds wedding day than an escort down the aisle, a corsage and a front row seat. But as grandmothers live longer (and livelier), nontraditional brides who are close with their grandmothers are choosing them as bridesmaids and in some instances, as flower girls.

title: Fear Is in the Forecast, Whatever the Weather
description: Lately, the Weather Channel has been using the slogan Its amazing out there! A more accurate one might be: You should be terrified at all times, of all sorts of things, not just the weather. But especially the weather.

title: Vow of Freedom of Religion Goes Unkept in Egypt
description: CAIRO  The architects of the military takeover in Egypt promised a new era of tolerance and pluralism when they deposed President Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood last summer.

title: In Store | An Oasis of Design on the Fringes of L.A.s Chinatown
description: Now that downtown L.A. has arrived, where to next? A pair of cult brands are making a case for Chinatown as the citys new style frontier. After a recent joint pop-up downtown proved successful, Iko Ikothe concept store run by Kristin Dickson and Shin Okuda  and Building Block, Kimberly and Nancy Wus buzzy line of minimalist bags, are together establishing a permanent retail space along the neighborhoods industrialnorthern edge. (The location, about halfway between downtown and the leafy creative-class enclave of Mount Washington, isnt quite the cultural desert it may seem: the vast Shareenvintage warehouse, a stylists haunt, is downstairs, and the annual FYF music festival has traditionally taken place at Los Angeles State Historic Park just down the road.)

title: Still the Gershwins, but Dig That Pace
description: Michael Feinstein has been preaching the gospel according to George and Ira Gershwin for so many years that you might think he would run out of things to say or ways to present their work. But The Music of George Gershwin, the season-opening concert of his jazz and popular song series at the Appel Room at Jazz at Lincoln Center on Wednesday evening, was a gusher in which the great vintage-jazz band Vince Giordano and the Nighthawks and three guest singers examined the Gershwins legacy through a focused nostalgic lens.

title: Burma Calling
description: For my annual win-a-trip journey, Ive decided to travel to Burma, along with win-a-trip winner Nicole Sganga of Notre Dame and video journalist Adam Ellick of the Times. Well try to do a mix of Burma-specific articles and video reporting, and also global health/nutrition/development pieces that just happen to have a Burma angle. Id welcome your suggestions for places for us to go and themes for us to cover. What columns or videos would you like to read/see? And what should Nicole blog about?

title: In Tonys Derby, Inishmaan, Cabaret, Hedwig and Violet Eligible as Revivals
description: The producers of The Cripple of Inishmaan, the critically acclaimed Broadway play starring Daniel Radcliffe, had a decision to make before Friday mornings meeting of the Tony Awards eligibility committee. The producers could ask the committee to rule that the drama was eligible for the 2014 Tony for best play  a category that has no front-runner  or leave it for the play revival category, considering that Inishmaan was written in 1996 and frequently produced (including twice Off Broadway). The downside to being in the revival category would be such strong competitors as A Raisin in the Sun, The Glass Menagerie, and Twelfth Night.

title: A Sonic Explorer Tries a Solo Turn
description: For most of the show that he played on a recent Thursday night at the Highline Ballroom in Manhattan, Damon Albarn focused on introspective and autobiographical music spanning his pop-music career of some 25 years. Then, as he wound down the set, Mr. Albarn brought out a gospel choir to accompany him on a new song, Mr. Tembo, a cheerful tune that includes the refrain, Its where he is now, but it wasnt what he planned.

title: Earl Morrall Is Dead at 79; Led 2 Teams to Super Bowl
description: Earl Morrall, who threw 161 touchdown passes in 21 N.F.L. seasons but was best remembered as the backup quarterback who led the Baltimore Colts and the unbeaten Miami Dolphins to Super Bowls in the 1960s and 70s, died on Friday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 79.

title: Answering Readers Questions About the Baseball Maps
description: The Upshot published interactive maps on Thursday detailing the geography of baseball fandom, based on Facebook data. The reader response was tremendous, and we wanted to answer a couple of good questions that were raised.

title: Health Care Apps Offer Patients an Active Role
description: IF you have young children, youve most likely endured caring for an ear infection or two. Or perhaps youve experienced a mysterious rash. Those situations generally mean a trip to the doctors office and time away from your job, if you work outside the home.

title: Giving New Voice to Troubled Relationships
description: Teen

title: The Gun Report: April 25, 2014
description: Some parts of Chicago have become so violent that the city has earned a new nickname: Chiraq, a reference to last decades bloody military quagmire in the Persian Gulf. The moniker has been floating around for the past couple of years, but in the Daily Beast this week, Michael Daly exploresthe crescendo of gun violence plaguing the citys black neighborhoods.

title: Friends Can Be Dangerous
description: IM not sure whether its a badge of honor or a mark of shame, but a paper I published a few years ago is now ranked No. 8 on a list of studies that other psychologists would most like to see replicated. Good news: People find the research interesting. Bad news: They dont believe it.

title: Weekend Reading: Unusual Bid Makes Strange Bedfellows
description: William A. Ackmans unconventional hostile bid for the maker of Botox has surprised corporate America and brought out some unexpected alliances.

title: Baseballs Second-Place Favorites: Go, Mets
description: Even in Upshot-land, where map lovers as a percent of the staff approaches 100 percent, there is such a thing as map overload. We dont want to get to that point. But this map of second-favorite teams in each ZIP code is too good not to share.

title: A Harmonic Drone Subsides in Britain
description: LONDON  Next door to the Royal Albert Hall here is an impressive building that is still sometimes referred to as the Royal College of Organists  as indeed it was in the days when organists had weight to throw around and needed premises that told you so. Founded in 1864, the college was grand, its membership as powerful as that of any London club, and its examinations recognized throughout the world.

title: A Certain Something
description: The Porsche Cayman doesnt make much of a case for itself strictly on numbers, but it exudes a cool factor thats hard to quantify.

title: Grand Performances in the Seats
description: Lincoln Centers spring ballet season  this years begins with New York City Ballets opening night on Tuesday  is a regular phenomenon, but its scale still makes it extraordinary. Part of whats astonishing is the audience: Thousands of people attend each performance, some of them having traveled hundreds of miles or more. When the David H. Koch Theater and the Metropolitan Opera House are sold out simultaneously  this year, dance companies occupy both houses from May 12 through June 29  nearly 7,000 people will be turning up at showtime on many nights, crossing Lincoln Centers central plaza in tides. And some religiously turn up for nine performances a week.

title: Daniel Anker, Maker of Powerful Documentaries, Dies at 50
description: Daniel Anker, a filmmaker whose sober documentaries brought unsensationalized narrative power to subjects including the trials of the Scottsboro boys and Hollywoods treatment of the Holocaust, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 50.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 48
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Recapturing the Past, and Then Revising It
description: At the moment, Julian Schnabels painting seems to be the art that dares not speak its name. Its influence is widely visible but rarely cited. You can see it in the work of artists from Joe Bradley to Oscar Murillo and all sorts of painters who emphasize chance or accident and like to work big, using unconventional materials.

title: Private Citizen Bloomberg on Philanthropy
description: Michael R. Bloomberg has given billions of dollars to charity and plans to give tens of billions more. His foundation, Bloomberg Philanthropies, has been ranked among the most innovative organizations in the country. And he has been willing to finance programs that could be controversial if they failed  like teaching high school graduates in Tanzania to perform appendectomies and cesarean sections.

title: Unlimited Koch Cash Comes to New York
description: On Thursday, Judge Paul Crotty, who sits on the federal district court in Manhattan, reluctantly allowed unlimited contributions to independent political groups in New York State. Reluctantly, in fact, doesnt begin to describe how clenched the judges teeth were in writing this remarkable opinion, which eloquently describes the dangers of the very act he was allowing.

title: In a World Filled With Zombies, 2 Girls Still Find Magic at the Mall
description: The Last of Us: Left Behind is the best new video game so far this year, or at least the only one that I cant stop thinking about. A coming-of-age story about two teenage girls during a zombie apocalypse, its approachable and contained, designed to be played in a single sitting of two or three hours. Its also inexpensive, selling for about $15.

title: South Sudan Releases Four Accused of Plotting Coup
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The government of South Sudan on Friday released four political figures accused of plotting a coup last December, a contested but pivotal event that quickly led to the civil war pulling the young country apart.

title: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Iraq, South Korea, Syria and India.

title: Resisting the 911s Gravitational Pull
description: If youve been keeping up with Neil deGrasse Tysons Cosmos: A Spacetime Odyssey on Fox, you may be familiar with the concept of the multiverse  the idea that our universe is just one among a potentially infinite number of others. If true, there could be some alternate universe almost just like ours, but slightly different.

title: Peas, Emerging From the Deep Freeze
description: Which cuisine do you think of when you think about peas? French, with petits pois aux laitues? Italian, which offers piselli con prosciutto? Indian, and its mutter paneer? British, with buttered peas with mint?

title: Not Flared Nostrils, but Nostrils With Flair
description: For years, auto designers lavished attention on the grilles of cars, both for their function and for their brand identity. Now designers seem to be lowering their sights.

title: In Your Fascia
description: Vehicles faces seem to be showing larger and more expressively formed nostrils, to judge from many models at the New York International Auto Show.

title: The Ever-Expanding Uzbek Flower
description: On a warm evening in Sheepshead Bay, under a dark canopy of Brooklyn sky, a crowd gathered on the corner of Coney Island Avenue and Kathleen Street, beside a midnight blue awning three storefronts long, enjoying, at last, a gentle spring that augured the tender lamb and other Central Asian delicacies awaiting inside.

title: Tuvan Throat Singers, Together in Spirit With Arvo Prt
description: In a promotional letter, the composer David Lang called collected stories, the weeklong series of programs he is overseeing at Zankel Hall, a little festival of odd music. The house was full again on Wednesday, as it had been for the first concert, on Tuesday, and probably few of those present would have disputed Mr. Langs characterization.

title: Private Equity Takes Steps Toward Wooing Smaller Investors
description: One of Wall Streets most exclusive investment products is inching toward the mainstream.

title: In China, Dawn of a Gilded Age
description: Theres a gold rush in Chinas automobile market, it would seem, judging by the huge array of new vehicles on display at Auto China 2014 in Beijing.

title: Your Evening Briefing.
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: Events in Connecticut for April 27-May 2, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Indictment Expected for Grimm, Staten Island Congressman
description: Representative Michael G. Grimm, a former F.B.I. agent and Marine who capitalized on his straight-arrow image to win a seat in Congress, was expected to be indicted on federal fraud charges after a lengthy corruption investigation, people with knowledge of the case said on Friday.

title: Michelle Obamas Met Plans, Lupita Nyongos Newest Award and the Rise of Faux Shopping
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Friday Night Music: Arcade Fire, Wake Up
description: Busy week, Im actually very tired, and have been indulging in old favorites to get me through. So an old performance, emotionally uplifting, from the band that got me into indie music.

title: Events in Westchester for April 27-May 2, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: A Deal From a Vanderbilt Knockout Teams Match
description: In the preliminary Daily Bulletin for the White House junior international tournament in the Netherlands, its editor, Dennis Stuurman, mentioned that the longtime junior coach in the Netherlands, Kees Tammens, had asked the players under his charge to write up particularly memorable deals.

title: Despite Missing Economic Goals, Greece Manages to Meet a Bailout Target
description: Greeces mountain of debt will decline more slowly than previously expected, the European Commission said in a Friday report.

title: Flip Sides of a Troupe as It Returns for a 45th-Anniversary Season
description: Dance Theater of Harlems 45th-anniversary season, currently underway at Lincoln Centers Rose Theater, is in some ways only its second. It was just last year that the troupe re-emerged after a nine-year hiatus, under the new artistic direction of Virginia Johnson. If the company looks uneven  sometimes scintillating, sometimes struggling  as it did on Wednesday, thats probably because it is still in transition, training a new crop of dancers, figuring out what it wants to be.

title: Taking a Spin: The Dream Outcome for Democrats
description: A lot can and will change in the battle for control of the Senate over the next six months. Fortunately, Leo, the Senate model for The Upshot, has a great tool to help illustrate probability: spinners that generate election possibilities in accordance with Leos odds. I have wasted an inordinate amount of time spinning these spinners over the last few weeks. I have seen some crazy things.

title: Bill Cunningham | On the Right Foot
description: Elaborately decorated sneakers are playing a starring role.

title: Mixing and Matching Youth and Middle Age, and Sequins and Tulle
description: It is still a novelty, and thus a big deal, for a choreographer to be in the Whitney Biennial. The last Biennial, in 2012, was the first to include choreographers, and Sarah Michelson and Michael Clark responded with big statements, spreading their dances across an expanse of the Whitney Museum of American Arts fourth floor.

title: It Took a Little Piece of Their Hearts
description: Assured by producers that their jobs were safe, actors skipped auditions for other musicals. Band members signed apartment leases. Investors wrote more checks for the show.

title: A Leap Forward, Here With Chamber Music
description: When the Paul Taylor Dance Company announced its big plans last month  to reinvent itself in the coming year as Paul Taylors American Modern Dance  few definitive details made clear what this enterprise would look like. Perhaps the most concrete news: The company, from here on, will perform (sometimes) with live music.

title: Seven Ways to Dance to a Tony Award
description: The choreography of seven new Broadway musicals Ive recently seen falls into the category of good generic. In each case  efficiently, pleasingly, vividly  its taken me somewhere Ive been before.

title: New System Allows Artists Seeking Instruments to Borrow, Not Beg
description: If there was ever a symbol of the growing disparity between the costs of great instruments and the wages of the musicians who know how to play them, it is the astronomical $45 million that sellers are seeking this spring for a rare Stradivari viola.

title: Oh, How They Like to Dish
description: If youve ever found yourself intrigued by the meltdowns of Lindsay Lohan and Charlie Sheen, puzzled by Jennifer Anistons seemingly endless difficulty in finding romantic bliss, fascinated by the endless woes of the even more endless Real Housewives, or hungry for any scrap of news about Brangelina, Kimye or TomKat, chances are you are deeply familiar with the work of Liz Smith and Jess Cagle, who have 90 years of gossip columns and entertainment news between them.

title: A Formal Breakup With Prom Wear
description: Soon to attend her junior prom at Garrison Forest School in Owings Mills, Md., Lindy Wittenberg has decided to make a statement with her outfit. I want to punch prom in the face by wearing pants, she said.

title: Better Homes and Hipsters
description: In recent years, Portland, Ore., has contributed its fair share to the trend one could call Rustic Artisanal Twee, with food trucks offering items like free-range kimchi tacos; idiosyncratic businesses like Stumptown Coffee Roasters and the Ace Hotels; and bespectacled urban eco-hipsters satirized on Portlandia.

title: Feuding in 140 Characters
description: In days of yore, if you were famous and hot under the collar, you stumbled over to your nemesis booth at the Musso & Frank Grill and hurled a martini or Sidecar into the object of your opprobriums face. By the 1960s, your arena had changed: You deployed the jeweled rapiers and poisoned darts of your animus on The Dick Cavett Show or in the letters section of The New York Review of Books. Today, you turn on your iPhone and tweet, miley is a byotch!

title: Bill Cunningham | On the Right Foot
description: Elaborately decorated sneakers are playing a starring role. A trend not unlike the highly embellished womens handbags at the turn of this century, it is definitely a mens thing, although women are showing variations. This winter, Saks Fifth Avenue devoted five prime windows just to sneakers. Some with wings echo Mercury, and others are decorated with chains or bones, and then there are sneakers with contrasting laces.

title: Boy George: Still on the Scene, Despite Lady Gaga
description: Boy George ordered the cauliflower and sweet-corn polenta, along with an avocolada smoothie and a cheese plate made of fermented cashews.

title: Evening Hours | Let the Parties Begin
description: Spring celebration season kicks into gear.

title: Judge Dismisses Former Bank Examiners Suit Against New York Fed
description: A former bank examiner with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York lost a lawsuit against her former employer after a federal judge ruled on Wednesday that she had not shown that she was fired over refusing to change certain findings about Goldman Sachs.

title: Week in Pictures for April 25
description: .media.slideshow.in-page-player .headline { display: none; }

title: Iraqi Militants Stage Political Rally, Then Bombs Go Off
description: BAGHDAD  A campaign rally at a ramshackle old soccer stadium on Friday afternoon began with open-air theater that crossed centuries of Shiite lore, from the martyrdom of a revered religious figure to the fight today against Sunni extremists, played by actors dressed as fighters for the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, a radical Islamist group.

title: The Chimpanzees Facial Expressions
description: A remote control guides the chimpanzees facial expressions.

title: Becoming a Yankee Fan
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuomo and the M.T.A. Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: Bring the Salt Monster Under Check
Affirmative Action Ruling
description: To the Editor:

title: Talent Is Still Paramount
description: To the Editor:

title: The Importance of Education for Troubled Youths
description: To the Editor:

title: Welcoming Love at an Older Age, but Not Necessarily Marriage
description: FOR years, Stephen Ward, 68, struggled as his wife suffered from multiple sclerosis and died. Then in 2007, he met Phyllis Kellerman, 70, and they started dating. The retired couple discovered that they had much in common. Both loved the theater. Both had long happy marriages and children. Mr. Ward and Ms. Kellermans late husband had been teachers in the New York area. The couple soon fell in love. Ms. Kellerman moved into Mr. Wards house in Boynton Beach, Fla.

title: Matt Harvey: A Day Off (in a Year Off)
description: During a stellar season pitching for the New York Mets last year, Matt Harvey, now 25, was the National Leagues starter in the All-Star Game and rejuvenated the teams frustrated fans. This season he is doing rehab in New York and in Port St. Lucie, Fla., after Tommy John surgery on his right elbow. When the team isnt playing, he hangs out on Sundays in the East Village, his neighborhood, trying on suits, watching sports with his buddies and shopping for cheese. Im with my team a lot, he said, so any chance I get to spend with my friends outside of baseball and have a normal weekend day is always nice.

title: Under Cover: What Does It Take for a Woman to Become a Chimp?
description: When the magazines photo editors dreamed up this weeks cover image of a courtroom scene with a chimpanzee as plaintiff, they realized that they could not possibly use a real animal during the photo shoot.

title: National Advocacy Group Takes Local Political Turn
description: WASHINGTON  Americans for Prosperity is a national force in this years midterm congressional elections, but the organization showed again this week that it is willing to monkey around with local issues as well.

title: With Philadelphia Shortfall, Schools Face Renewed Cuts
description: PHILADELPHIA  A $216-million budget shortfall could force Philadelphias public schools to make further staffing cuts next year, school officials said on Friday.

title: Infertility, Endured Through a Prism of Race
description: WASHINGTON  Like many single women, Heather Lawson hoped she would meet the right man with enough time to get married and have a child. But a failed relationship at 38 changed her plans, and Ms. Lawson realized that if she wanted to be a mother, she might have to explore other options.

title: Qatar: U.S. Couple Seeks Respite
description: A Los Angeles couple convicted last month of child endangerment, not the original charge of murder they had faced, in the 2013 death of their adopted daughter will seek permission from an appellate court to go home while their appeal is pending, defense lawyers said this week. They will make their request at their first hearing, scheduled for Monday, the lawyers said. The couple, Matthew and Grace Huang, and their lawyers learned only this week of the legal grounds cited by the lower court for the guilty verdict. The lawyers said they were baffled by the child endangerment conviction, which carries a three-year prison term and was never part of the original case presented by prosecutors. Everybody on our team was scratching their heads, said Randy Papetti, one of the lawyers. This is simply out of left field. The Huang case has come to symbolize what critics call the arbitrary system of criminal justice in Qatar, where foreign workers constitute a majority of the population. The Huangs have said their daughter, Gloria, 8, suffered an eating disorder and was not denied food as asserted by prosecutors, who suspected the parents were child traffickers because they are of Asian heritage and Gloria was from Ghana. The exact cause of her death was never established.

title: I Was Taught That Getting Pregnant Is Easy for Black Girls  Too Easy. But It Wasnt for Me.
description: Enduring infertility as a woman of color is different. Why? Ive had far longer than I wanted to consider that question, and the answer Ive come up with is this: Infertility is hard as a black woman because no one expects a black woman to have trouble conceiving  not even other black women.

title: Ecuador: A U.S. Office Is Closed
description: The government of Ecuador has told the United States Embassy to shut down a military cooperation office staffed by about 20 people from the Defense Department, an embassy spokesman said Friday. The office, which included military and civilian staff members, worked with Ecuadorean military personnel to promote cooperation on efforts to fight drug trafficking, terrorism, human trafficking and other international crimes, said the spokesman, Jeffrey M. Weinshenker. The office will close by the end of the month and its staff members will leave the country, Mr. Weinshenker said. He said that the embassys military attach office was not affected by the order. President Rafael Correa, a leftist, has often criticized the United States and its influence in the region. In January, Mr. Correa said that the United States had too many military officers assigned to its embassy in Ecuador and that he planned to order some to leave.

title: Sheriff Joe Arpaio Embraces His Hollywood Moment
description: LOS ANGELES  Sheriff Joe Arpaio, at once hailed and reviled as Americas toughest sheriff, sauntered into famously liberal Hollywood on Wednesday, traveling hundreds of miles from his home turf and disconcerting legal problems in Arizona to promote a documentary that offers, at best, an unflattering portrayal of his troubled 21 years in office.

title: Chen Yizi, a Top Adviser Forced to Flee China, Dies at 73
description: Chen Yizi, who helped reshape Chinas economy in the 1980s but who was deemed a counterrevolutionary after defending the student-led protests that filled Tiananmen Square in 1989, died in exile on April 14 in Los Angeles. He was 73.

title: Hey, Big Thinker
description: It is unclear how many people have actually read Thomas Pikettys treatise Capital in the Twenty-First Century  577 pages of text and graphs plus 78 pages of notes and, for added clarity, an appendage called Contents in Detail.

title: Douglas L. Coleman, 82, Dies; Found a Genetic Cause of Obesity
description: Douglas L. Coleman, a Canadian-born scientist who upset scientific dogma by discovering that genes  not willpower, eating habits or other behaviors  could cause obesity in some people, died on April 16 at his home in Lamoine, Me. He was 82.

title: Phone Company Bid to Keep Data From N.S.A. Is Rejected
description: WASHINGTON  A telephone company asked the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court in January to stop requiring it to give records of its customers calls to the National Security Agency, in light of a ruling by a Federal District Court judge that the N.S.A. program is likely unconstitutional, according to court papers declassified on Friday.

title: Piketty and the Petits Rentiers
description: Having expressed some predictable skepticism about elements of Thomas Pikettys argument in Capital in the Twenty-First Century, I want to usher in the weekend by highlighting something significant I think that he gets right. His book, as the title suggests, is notable among recent treatments of inequality for its elevation of wealth and capital (as opposed to just income), and particularly for its discussion of the re-emergence of inheritance as a force for class stratification in the West. The books frequent references to 19th century fiction notwithstanding, Piketty concedes that there are likely to be fewer extraordinarily large estates (relative to the wealth of society as a whole) in 21st century Europe and America than there were in, say, his native France two hundred years ago. But he argues that there will be, and indeed already are, enough large-ishestates to return us to a state of affairs where wealth is channeled through patrimonies to a remarkable, quasi-Victorian extent:

title: Events in New Jersey for April 27-May 2, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Buffett Punts on Pay
description: The way to get big shots to change their behavior is to embarrass them.

title: A Beating in Detroit
description: DETROIT  AS Detroit burned to the ground on a hot summer night in July 1967, my grandparents stood on their front lawn listening to the sounds of our civic suicide.

title: Events on Long Island for April 27-May 2, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: A Consensus in Washington, but No Action
description: WASHINGTON  The Savannah Harbor Expansion Project has friends in all the right places.

title: New York Will Keep Affordable Care Act Health Plans Restricted
description: New York State health officials said on Friday that they would not require out-of-network coverage on Affordable Care Act health plans next year, a decision likely to disappoint customers who have complained that they can no longer use their favorite doctors and hospitals.

title: Saving Chinas Elephants
description: Efforts to save Chinas few hundred wild elephants appear to have been successful although visitors to the Yunnan Province Wild Elephant Valley Park are unlikely to see one.

title: Immigration Resurfaces in Tough Talk by Speaker
description: WASHINGTON  Speculation about Speaker John A. Boehners intentions in overhauling the nations immigration laws intensified Friday after he mocked the most conservative House members for thwarting his attempts to fix the system, shore up the borders and address the legal status of the countrys 11 million illegal immigrants.

title: In Land That Values Ivory, Wild Elephants Find a Safe Haven
description: XISHUANGBANNA, China  At a time when tens of thousands of elephants across Africa are being slaughtered to feed the Chinese appetite for ivory, it turns out the best place to be a wild elephant may be here in the tropical forests of southwest China.

title: Young Center Takes Hard Route to N.H.L.
description: ST. PAUL  Joey Hishon, a fourth-line center for the Colorado Avalanche, played only 6 minutes 31 seconds in a 2-1 loss to the Minnesota Wild on Thursday night in Game 4 of their first-round series. But those eight shifts, in Hishons N.H.L. debut, represented a significant victory.

title: Street Style in Oakland, California
description: In the Grand Lake neighborhood of Oakland, Calif., it is hard to ignore the bustling scene where scores of people are lined up in front of food trucks or going in and out of the hip restaurants, bars and salons. Among the foot traffic is a colorful display of relaxed Northern California style: vintage button-down shirts and scarves, tattoos and piercings and hoodies with the logos of local brands .Originally from Chicago, Sarah Barnekow moved to the area three years ago and has undergone a style transformation, most recently chopping 10 inches off her hair and dying it a white-and-gray hue.Sporting brown combat boots, a scarf she bought while traveling in India, a bracelet she recently purchased at a local flea market and a tattoo of the Wi-Fi sign, Ms. Barnekow said that her style usually errs on the side of masculine.

title: Given a Choice, Athletes May Prefer None and Done
description: Long before Julius Randle was a 6-foot-9, 250-pound wall of muscle and a certain N.B.A. lottery pick, he was a toddler who slept with a basketball clutched to his chest.

title: European Firms Seek to Minimize Russia Sanctions
description: BERLIN  With the showdown over Ukraine escalating and President Obama warning Moscow of a tough new round of sanctions, Russia and its allies in the European private sector are conducting a separate campaign to ensure that they can maintain their deep and longstanding economic ties even if the Kremlin orders further military action.

title: Where Nutella Has a Big Role, Even at Dinner
description: The couple at the bar were having an intimate conversation, their foreheads nearly touching except for an occasional break to sip cocktails or munch on small plates of cheese and olives. On the other side of the room, an extended family sat around a table draped in a white tablecloth, trading stories and large plates of freshly made pasta and roasted meats as they made their way through a three-course meal.

title: Airbnb Host Welcomes Travelers From All Over
description: The vacationing couple from Hattingen, Germany, showed up at Michael Naesss shipshape Queens apartment at the end of February. They had never met before. Nonetheless, here they were, digging into scrambled eggs, sipping coffee and chatting companionably with him on a Saturday morning. A German radio station, plucked from the Internet, rendered a flavor of home.

title: As Parents Make Their Own Baby Food, Industry Tries to Adapt
description: Dylan DeNeve of Brooklyn dined on homemade baby food of vegetable pures, delicately seasoned with leeks, red peppers, cumin and thyme, prepared by her mother, Alexandra, a lawyer. In Atlanta, Wes and Hadley Stewart enjoyed homemade mashed-up kale, butternut squash and ancient grains.

title: Suit Claims Drug Free Sport Mishandled Tests
description: A senior executive at the company that oversees drug testing for the N.C.A.A., the N.F.L., the N.B.A., Major League Baseball and several other top sports organizations claimed in a lawsuit filed this week that she was fired after she voiced concerns about the handling of a football players positive drug test.

title: A Walmart Fortune, Spreading Charter Schools
description: WASHINGTON  DC Prep operates four charter schools here with 1,200 students in preschool through eighth grade. The schools, whose students are mostly poor and black, are among the highest performing in Washington. Last year, DC Preps flagship middle school earned the best test scores among local charter schools, far outperforming the average of the citys traditional neighborhood schools as well.

title: Tea Bars, a New Kind of Watering Hole
description: At Infuse Tea Bar in West Sayville on a recent evening, Kristine Henderson, 42, the owner, demonstrated the slurp, swish and swallow technique to six would-be aficionados. You aerate the tea in your mouth and you coat the taste buds, so you can experience all the aromas and subtle flavors, she said as the class sampled the first of six Japanese teas.

title: Refugees of Irish Famine to Get a Proper Burial
description: James Riley, 40, died of dysentery after 21 days in a hospital on Staten Island. The year was 1849, and across the ocean the Irish potato famine was at its peak, sending tens of thousands of starving people onto ships bound for New York City.

title: Nigerian Movie Appears to Hit Nerve Over War
description: DAKAR, Senegal  A Nigerian film dealing with one of the most searing episodes in the nations history, its civil war, and uniting some of Nigerias major cultural figures, has been effectively banned there, the films director said Friday evening.

title: Kebabs With a Side of Belly Dancing
description: It was my good fortune to be at Sultans Turkish Restaurant in Waterbury on a Saturday night, when a belly dancer performs. My appetizer of izgara kalamar had just been served, but my scant attention to those tender morsels of charbroiled squid had less to do with the shapely young woman gyrating by my table than with the razor-sharp saber she was brandishing above our heads.

title: A Test of Togetherness That One Team Is Passing
description: MEMPHIS  Before Russell Westbrook fulfilled his obligations with the news media on Friday, he pulled a pair of long camouflage shorts over his practice shorts. It seemed less like a fashion statement  always a possibility with Westbrook  than a strategic decision as the Oklahoma City Thunder sought to defend themselves from questions about their predicament in the first round of the playoffs.

title: New Yorks Medicaid Challenge
description: New York State will receive a welcome infusion of $8 billion in federal funds over the next five years to improve the delivery of health care for the states poorest residents while saving billions in unnecessary hospital and emergency room costs. The money will be allocated to providers throughout the state, but it could be especially helpful in salvaging and reshaping failing hospitals in Brooklyn whose threatened closures have sparked community protests and brought pledges of assistance from Mayor Bill de Blasio and Gov. Andrew Cuomo.

title: Casinos in the Exurbs
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo has championed adding casinos in New York as a way to revive the upstate economy. There are plenty of concerns about whether giant casinos would actually bring well-paid jobs and sustained economic vitality to desolate areas. However, voters approved a constitutional amendment last year to allow seven casino complexes; a companion bill allowed four to be built over the next few years in upstate counties, but not in New York City or on Long Island.

title: A Pantheon of the Feasts of Greece
description: Despite the crowds, the plastic-topped tables and the fake grapes hanging from the fake terra cotta tiles, you should dine at the Greek Village. The tiny restaurant, with only seven tables but a large takeout clientele, has been stubbornly resisting changes to its dcor and, happily, its menu since opening in 1998.

title: U.S. Says It Built Digital Programs Abroad With an Eye to Politics
description: WASHINGTON  The United States built Twitter-like social media programs in Afghanistan and Pakistan, like one in Cuba, that were aimed at encouraging open political discussion, Obama administration officials said Friday. But like the program in Cuba, which was widely ridiculed when it became public this month, the services in Pakistan and Afghanistan shut down after they ran out of money because the administration could not make them self-sustaining.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 25, 2014
description: April 25, 2014

title: Double Standards in Bankruptcies
description: Developments in the Detroit bankruptcy have exposed a double standard in federal bankruptcy law, an injustice in urgent need of congressional reform.

title: Retro Setting, Modern Diner Fare
description: Schnackenbergs Luncheonette, a vintage spot reopened in December by Joyce Flinn and her husband, Eugene, has chrome fixtures, an old-fashioned penny-tile floor and soda jerks behind the counter outfitted in bow ties and caps. But apart from the retro flavor and the friendly staff, it has little in common with the burger franchise Johnny Rockets, Ms. Flinn said. If smiling, cheerful employees are the point of comparison, I dont mind. But were a very different kind of restaurant, said Ms. Flinn, 53, of Weehawken. Were not a chain. Nothing we have is prepackaged. Everything is made on the premises.

title: Wise Controls on E-Cigarettes
description: The rapidly growing electronic-cigarette business would finally be brought under regulatory supervision under long-delayed rules proposed by the Food and Drug Administration on Thursday. If the rules go into effect substantially as written, they will lay the foundation to protect the public from devices whose risks and benefits are largely unknown.

title: Philadelphia Newspapers to Be Sold to Insiders
description: A judge ruled Friday that The Philadelphia Inquirer, Philadelphia Daily News and Philly.com would be sold at an auction open only to its existing owners. It is the latest legal milestone in a battle between the wealthy, politically connected men who formed a partnerships to buy the publications in 2012, but have since fallen out over accusations of inappropriate influence exerted on the newsroom, and thrown them into turmoil. The ruling, by Delaware Chancery Court Judge Donald F. Parsons, was seen as a victory for one of the men, George E. Norcross III, a businessman and Democratic power broker in New Jersey. Another of the owners, Lewis Katz, the former owner of the New Jersey Nets, had fought for a public sale open to anyone. Mr. Norcross was accused of installing his daughter at the head of Philly.com and of influencing the dismissal of The Inquirers editor, William K. Marimow. He has denied any inappropriate behavior.

title: Of Fox and the Cattle
description: So, what have we learned from the Crazy Rancher Guy saga?

title: Pujols Issues a Reminder of His Place in History
description: The scoreboard at Tempe Diablo Stadium had to be wrong. That is what Raul Ibanez thought this spring, during an exhibition game for his new team, the Los Angeles Angels. Albert Pujols was hitting, and the statistics on the board startled Ibanez.

title: A Ranchers Romantic Revisionism
description: It appears that Cliven Bundy, the 68-year-old rancher and freeloader, doesnt reject only the federal government; he rejects history.

title: A Veil, Rather Than a Mirror
