description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Dense and flavorful. Thats not my impression of a loaf of bread, but its how I felt about Evan Birnholzs puzzle. Almost every entry I guessed turned out to be wrong, but when I was able to solve them correctly, I admired this puzzle greatly for the excellent, but tough, fill.

title: Guard Is Changing, but a Sports Warden Remains the Same
description: MESA, Ariz.  Lane 8 was where the future and the past of American mens swimming converged Friday at a USA Swimming Grand Prix meet at Skyline Aquatic Center. In the three seeded preliminary heats of the mens 50-meter freestyle, 17-year-old Justin Lynch gave way to the 22-time Olympic medalist Michael Phelps, who gave way to 15-year-old Michael Andrew.

title: Republican Resigns From Bloomberg Gun Safety Group
description: WASHINGTON  Tom Ridge, the Homeland Security secretary under President George W. Bush, has unexpectedly resigned from the board of Michael R. Bloombergs new gun control effort, citing his discomfort with some of the political work the group has been planning.

title: Tensions Mount in Bolivia as Soldiers Protest Career Obstacles
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Hundreds of soldiers continued street demonstrations as tensions mounted in Bolivia on Friday, a day after the military dismissed 702 low-ranking officers who were protesting to draw attention to the obstacles to advancement they face in the armed forces.

title: City Suspends Dispatchers Over Ambulance Delay in Fatal Fire
description: The city has suspended four emergency service dispatchers who were on duty in Queens last Saturday night when there was a delay in sending ambulances to a fire that killed two children in the Rockaways.

title: Ice Cream Cones for Children and Loot for a Thief
description: His smile never wavers above his bright red bow tie. This is not a serious man  he has an ice cream cone for a head. And yet in the cheery world of Mister Softee, there are rules.

title: Sensing Slight by Mayor, City Council Asserts Its Role in Land Use Process
description: For most of Mayor Bill de Blasios first few months in office, the City Council has been a reliable ally and cheerleader for his agenda of paid sick leave, prekindergarten expansion, and other ways to tackle income inequality.But some cracks have begun to show in the unified front that the mayor and the Council have presented since taking office in January.

title: Detroit and Retirees Reach Deal in Bankruptcy Case
description: A court-appointed committee of Detroit retirees has reached a tentative agreement with the bankrupt city on cuts to their pensions and benefits. The deal adds to pacts already reached with pension fund leaders and others, and brings Detroit closer to paying back some of its overwhelming debts and emerging from bankruptcy.

title: Flyers Even Series as Rangers Follow a Playoff Pattern
description: PHILADELPHIA  Making his first start of the playoffs, Philadelphia Flyers goalie Steve Mason stopped 37 of 38 shots by the Rangers on Friday night in a 2-1 victory at Wells Fargo Center that evened their opening-round playoff series at two games each, but the Rangers were not about to give Mason a lot of credit.

title: Hans Hollein, Inventive Architect Who Designed With Wit, Dies at 80
description: Hans Hollein, a Pritzker Prize-winning architect who breathed witty postmodernist life into everything from buildings to pianos to tea trays, died on Thursday in his native Vienna. He was 80.

title: Flyers, Up or Down a Man, Appear Headed in the Right Direction
description: PHILADELPHIA  When it was presented to Wayne Simmonds on Friday morning that the Flyers power play had been struggling for a while, he politely disagreed. It has been good all season, he said. The confidence is still there, he added.

title: Nets Avoid Collapse and Put the Raptors in a Hole
description: Based on the quiet tones and the disappointed stares in the Nets locker room late Friday night, no one would have guessed that they had defeated the Toronto Raptors, 102-98, or that they had turned Barclays Center into a rollicking party, or that they had earned a critical 2-1 lead in their best-of-seven playoff series.

title: For de Blasio, Carriage Horse Ban Is No Walk in the Park
description: It is the iconic green space of New York City, internationally renowned and beloved by generations of natives and visitors alike.

title: Bruised After Trip, Yanks Stagger Through Lopsided Loss to Angels
description: The Yankees arrived in New York at 3 a.m. on Friday after an eventful seven-game trip in which they lost one starting pitcher to injury, lost another starter to suspension and played two draining series against division rivals, the Tampa Bay Rays and the Boston Red Sox.

title: Turkish Leader Signs Bill Expanding Spy Agencys Power
description: ISTANBUL  Turkeys president signed legislation on Friday that granted more authority to the national spy agency, a measure that critics say will bolster Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogans control over state institutions.

title: Granderson Caps Ninth-Inning Rally for the Mets
description: Curtis Granderson was 0 for 4, his batting average down to .130. With each successive flyout on Friday night, the boos grew louder as he jogged back to the dugout.

title: Rare Encore at the Met as Mexican Tenor Stirs Crowd
description: There was a time, early in the 20th century, when programs at the Metropolitan Opera warned in capital letters, Positively no encores allowed.

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 9:40 A.M. (Starz Cinema) A WOMAN, A GUN AND A NOODLE SHOP (2010) In this faithful remake of Joel and Ethan Coens Blood Simple (1984), the director Zhang Yimou moves the action from modern-day Texas to a desolate valley in northwest China in the feudal past, above, where the wife (Yan Ni) of a rich and sexually sadistic noodle-shop owner, Wang (Ni Dahong), is carrying on with one of his employees (Xiao Shenyang). Then Zhang (Sun Honglei), a detective hired by Wang to kill the adulterous couple, arrives on the scene, and all hell breaks loose. Though it begins with some exaggerated, almost clownish business and includes a handful of clean and mordant sight gags, A Woman, a Gun and a Noodle Shop has a gravity that is surprising, given that it is basically the pastiche of a pastiche, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. But by working through the self-conscious genre imitation that was something of a novelty in Blood Simple, Mr. Zhang uncovers the primal, mythic intensity of the story and also changes the tone of its essential nihilism. The Coens posit a universe without order or meaning, and while Mr. Zhang does not necessarily quarrel with this view, he treats it less as a cosmic joke than as a grim folk tale.

title: Trying to Save a Quiet Place on Staten Island
description: For more than a century, rich and poor Catholics alike came to Mount Manresa, a Jesuit retreat center on Staten Island a mile from the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. From bricklayers to lawyers, from the poet Joyce Kilmer to Malcolm Wilson, the former New York governor, they stepped out of the workaday world and entered a silent space of prayer and meditation.

title: Healer at the Pit Stop
description: Every spring, some 90 ultramarathoners from all over the world gather in Queens to see if they can run more or less continuously for 10 days straight.

title: Australia May Expand Search for Jet
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Australian authorities are likely to widen the underwater search for wreckage from the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 because an unmanned search vehicle has so far failed to find any trace of the missing jet on the seabed in a remote patch of the Indian Ocean, officials said Saturday.

title: Corrections: April 26, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Fill the Pantry, Skip the Line
description: New Yorkers are known for their boundless enthusiasm surrounding food and shopping, but the two activities are generally a bad combination: Grocery shopping in New York is a crowded, stressful experience.

title: Communist Mouthpiece Says it Complained to Twitter About Parody
description: Peoples Daily, the flagship paper of Chinas Communist Party, continued its assault on the Twitter account @relevantorgans that parodies the countrys rulers, saying it violates Twitters rules.

title: Analytics: Beyond a Finger in the Dike
description: The following Analytics appears on the letters page in the April 27 issue of the magazine.

title: Pilgrims Gather in Vatican City
description: St. Peters Square was packed with tourists and pilgrims on Friday ahead of the canonizations of John XXIII and John Paul II on Sunday.

title: Sainthood for 2 Predecessors Allows Pope to Straddle Divide
description: VATICAN CITY  Pope John XXIII was the rotund Italian pontiff with a common touch, who told jokes, embraced the poor and became beloved as the Good Pope. To many liberal Catholics, he is still revered for the Second Vatican Council, the landmark event of the 1960s that sought to move the Roman Catholic Church into the modern age.

title: The Chatter for Sunday, April 27
description: Ive been working with these social bots for a really long time, and now they look like real people online  even though they are not.Tim Hwang, chief scientist at the Pacific Social Architecting Corporation, a research group. Companies are selling social bots, lines of code built to behave like people on social media sites, to provide things like Twitter retweets and Facebook likes.

title: S.D. Shibulal of Infosys: Write It Down and Follow Through
description: This interview with  S.D. Shibulal, the chief executive of Infosys, the technology consulting firm, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: InBlooms Vision
description: A promotional video from inBloom imagined how teachers and students could utilize its technology within the next decade.

title: A Student-Data Collector Drops Out
description: To hear executives at inBloom tell it,their$100 million education technology start-up is shutting down after only 15 months of operation because it was too far ahead of its time.

title: In a Stock Trade, Its Man vs. Machine
description: Email haggler@nytimes.com. Keep it brief and family-friendly, include your hometown and go easy on the caps-lock key. Letters may be edited for clarity and length.

title: The Search for Our Inner Lie Detectors
description: Is a job applicant lying to you? What about your boss, or an entrepreneur who is promising to double your investment?

title: From Outside or Inside, the Deck Looks Stacked
description: The game is rigged and the American people know that. They get it right down to their toes.

title: A Friday Night of Bartending, Without the Lights
description: It took me an hour to decide what to wear to my first shift at the Village Idiot. I knew that the clothes should be tight, and I knew, too, what specific strain of sexy was called for  namely, the I know jujitsu so dont get too handsy variety.

title: Afghan Voters Signaling a Turn
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Abdullah Abdullah, a longtime opponent of President Hamid Karzai and an ardent supporter of the United States, emerged Saturday as the clear front-runner in Afghanistans presidential election.

title: Suspect in Stabbing at Connecticut School Is Described as Popular
description: MILFORD, Conn.  Jonathan Law High School has not known much tumult. Students here are often too involved in sports, music or volunteer work to get in much trouble, staff members said, and the biggest source of friction is the annual game between the school football team, known as the Lawmen, and its crosstown rival.

title: Afghan Panel Claims to Find Secret Prisons
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A commission appointed by President Hamid Karzai to investigate detention facilities run by American and British forces in southern Afghanistan claimed Saturday to have uncovered secret prisons on two coalition bases, an allegation that could not be immediately confirmed but that was likely to further complicate relations between the Afghan government and its allies.

title: Variety: Split Decisions
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Theres really not a lot to say, blogwise, about the Split Decisions. You start where you can gain a toehold, and you keep connecting the words in pairs until youre done.

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking: April 25, 2014
description: Warren Buffett is perhaps the countrys most respected investor, known for making thoughtful, common-sense decisions. Which is why this week the business world took note when he abstained from voting against a pay package for executives at Coca-Cola that he called excessive. This week on Money Talking, regular contributors Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar weigh in on Buffetts motivation and what it says about the state of corporate boards in America. Plus, a discussion of why a 700-page book  Capital in the Twenty-First Century by French economist Thomas Piketty  is topping the charts on Amazon.

title: Laying Foundation With Playoff Frenzy
description: It seemed like a lot, too much, the ultimate grab into the cookie jar to satisfy the immediate need of the uncontrollable sweet tooth. The sacrifice for Paul Pierce and Kevin Garnett was primarily the painful extraction of three first-round draft picks and the opportunity for the Boston Celtics to swap places with the Nets for a fourth.

title: On a Trip That Avoids Beijing, Obama Keeps His Eye on China
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  On every stop of his Asian journey in the past week, President Obama has spoken to two audiences: Americas allies and China. The balancing act has become even trickier because of the sharp deterioration in Americas relations with Russia.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 47
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: For Russia, Negatives Seem to Outweigh Positives of an Invasion
description: MOSCOW  Ukraine becomes more of a tinderbox by the day.

title: The Bodies That Guard Our Secrets
description: WHEN I was a medical student elbow deep in the abdominal fat of my cadaver, and neck deep in the Latin names of body parts, I decided to visit a kosher slaughterhouse. I wanted to get some real-life perspective on all the anatomical terms I had been painstakingly memorizing for exams. And what better way to get perspective on anatomy than to learn how muscles become meat? Cattle and humans have similar anatomy, after all  the muscles just have different names. Cattle have the filet mignon, and we have the psoas major muscle. They have the rib eye, and we have the erector spinae.

title: For Some, the Effort to Keep Up on the Ice All Season Begins in Sweltering Heat
description: DARIEN, Conn.  The veteran forwards Martin St. Louis and Brad Richards are thriving for the Rangers in the N.H.L. playoffs, and their intense summer workouts may be one reason.

title: A Winning Braves Recipe No Matter the Ingredients
description: The Atlanta Braves had reason to feel confident in early March. They were coming off their third playoff appearance in four seasons and had signed several core players to long-term contract extensions.

title: Vapor Boomtown
description: With little regulation, Oklahoma City has become an e-cigarette boomtown where vapers flock to vapor shops to buy the smoking alternative products, which include nicotine liquids.

title: Slow, Grinding Strategy of Inflicting Syria Misery
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  In the Syrian village of Tamana, residents braced themselves as the sound of a helicopter overhead signaled an impending attack. A barrel bomb fell, but after its familiar, destructive blast, an unexpected noxious gas filled the air.

title: Where Vapor Comes Sweeping Down the Plain
description: Nick Whitson, who is 32 and covered with enigmatic tattoos  the number 13, an upside-down cross  stood in front of a table scattered with dozens of bottles of colorful liquids and a handful of syringes, preparing to mix Trevor Curren his usual.

title: Reporter Digging Into Scandal Hits a Universitys Raw Nerve
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  There have been violent threats, angry screeds, Twitter flame campaigns and an entire website predicated on the putative hideousness of Dan Kanes existence. Someone sent Kane an email wishing him a lingering death by bone cancer. Someone else tweeted him a photograph of a noose.

title: Writing in a Nonstop World
description: We give time a hard time. We take it, steal it, spend it and waste it. Thanks to computers, now were chopping time up into ever-smaller fragments.

title: Governor With Eye on 2016 Finds His Rise Under Scrutiny
description: STURTEVANT, Wis.  Scott Walker is nothing if not consistent.

title: Clinging to Mets in a Rising Tide of Yankees Fans
description: Michael Zampino leaned in and lowered his voice to a whisper, so that maybe his customers would not hear him. There was a long line forming outside his shop, the Lemon Ice King of Corona, on Tuesday afternoon, and he did not want to offend anyone.

title: Exhaustion Prevails; So Does Generosity
description: BOSTON  Joan Benoit Samuelson, the 1984 Olympic champion, had simple but practical advice for a first-timer at the Boston Marathon.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 27
description: The Israeli government halted peace negotiations with the Palestinians on Thursday because of a unity agreement announced on Wednesday between two rival Palestinian factions, the Palestine Liberation Organization and the militant group Hamas.

title: The Feast of Pain
description: LAST week my friend Mishka and I, wistful about a popular sedative of the 1970s that neither of us even got the opportunity to resist the temptation to take, went to search for Do they still make ludes on the Internet. Before we could finish typing the words do they the search engine autofilled still make quaaludes.

title: A Time of Soul-Searching, Not Cynicism
description: They dont bring down the house in South Pacific. But boy, do they light up the room.

title: Attack on Journalist Starts Battle in Pakistani Press
description: LONDON  For a time, Pakistans journalists were seen as messy champions of democracy: brave if sometimes flawed truth-tellers who helped oust the military ruler Gen. Pervez Musharraf and held up a critical mirror to their tempestuous country.

title: Union Effort at Northwestern May Not Mean Much for Public Colleges
description: Many football and basketball players at Michigan State, Connecticut and other state universities are no doubt wondering what the Northwestern decision means for them.

title: Is A Banking Ban The Answer?
description: OK, a genuinely interesting debate on financial reform is taking place. Im not even sure where I stand. But its certainly worth talking about.

title: The Media Has a Woman Problem
description: WASHINGTON  THEY were, to a man, men. All were white; all in their 40s or thereabouts; most had dark hair. It was the mid-1990s, and I was interviewing at The Washington Post for the job of managing editor of the Sunday magazine. A morning of intimidating meetings with newsroom officials had given way to lunch with the magazines editors and elite staff writers.

title: Obamas High-Profile Tour of Asia Hits Speed Bumps
description: A week in which President Obama had intended to add force to his strategic pivot to the East instead marked some pivotal setbacks to his foreign agenda. The presidents long-delayed trip to Asia failed to yield a trade deal with Japan and ran up against a new threat from North Korea, while both the Middle East peace process and a tentative agreement on Ukraine foundered in acrimony.

title: A Birdbath-Size Hole and the Future of Golf
description: SOME dimensions are sacred. From home plate to first base is always 90 feet, a distance arrived at perhaps accidentally on some 19th-century cow field in upstate New York but one that has endured despite all the changes in baseball. A basketball hoop is still 10 feet off the floor even though giants now play the game and stuff the ball downward while dangling off the rim. And a golf hole is four and a quarter inches in diameter, a measurement officially sanctioned in 1893 by the Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St. Andrews in Scotland but one that probably goes back long before that. The R & A, which is to golf what Moses was to the tablets, settled on four and a quarter inches because thats how big the holes were at Musselburgh, where they began playing golf back in the 17th century.

title: Unrelenting Will Toward Victory Drives Teenager
description: BETHESDA, Md.  The 25-yard freestyle taxed Katie Ledecky, who stopped three times during the 8-and-under girls race, clutching the lane line to catch her breath and wipe her nose. After finishing, Ledecky, then 6, climbed out of the pool and conducted an on-deck interview with her father, Dave. The home-video footage, which made Ledecky laugh when she watched it last week, foreshadowed the womens distance swimming renaissance she spearheaded less than a decade later.

title: Deborah A. P. Hersman
description: Deborah A. P. Hersman stepped down this past week as chairwoman of the National Transportation Safety Board. The public will remember her as the cool presence on the ground after major aviation, rail, marine, highway and pipeline accidents. She leaves to become president and chief executive officer of the National Safety Council, a nonprofit devoted to preventing injuries and deaths through education and outreach.

title: The Koch Attack on Solar Energy
description: At long last, the Koch brothers and their conservative allies in state government have found a new tax they can support. Naturally its a tax on something the country needs: solar energy panels.

title: A Masters in Chick Lit
description: Im a genre writer. Gary Shteyngart hasnt blurbed any of my novels, and Marion Ettlinger has never photographed me for a book jacket. Im more at ease with the sequins and shirtless men at the Romantic Times conference than I am with the serious eyewear at poetry readings. When critics describe my work, which is basically chick lit, they dont say its emotionally astute, sweeping or a tour de force. They call it a fast-paced screamer.

title: Meaningful Progress With Iran
description: With three months to go before the July deadline for a final agreement, Iran and the six major powers are still searching for ways to resolve differences over Irans nuclear program. Even so, the negotiations keep confounding skeptics by making steady progress and showing that investing in this process is worth the risk.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Our Choices for Schools
description: Readers react to a letter calling for greater support of public schools rather than school choice.

title: Disarmament for Spousal Abusers
description: The National Rifle Associations annual convention this weekend in Indianapolis is featuring the usual array of tens of thousands of gun customers and dealers marveling at the latest in deadly weapons adapted for civilian life from the battlefields of war. Outside the massive gathering, a contingent from a gun safety group, Moms Demand Action for Gun Sense in America, planned to raise awareness about the gun crisis.

title: The Angel in Larry Kramer
description: I LEARNED long ago to open my inbox with trepidation. A journalist is a magnet for complaints.

title: The Popes Phone Call
description: THIS weekend in Rome, the Catholic Church is celebrating a double canonization  two popes, two sainthoods, 2,000 buses full of pilgrims  that serves as a kind of capstone on Pope Franciss first year in office, and an illustration of his agenda for the church.

title: Who Will Influence Whom?
description: KIEV, Ukraine  SOMETIMES the simplest question speaks the biggest truth. I was meeting with some Maidan activists here in Kiev last week, and we were talking about Russian President Vladimir Putins insistence that Ukraine was part of Russias traditional sphere of influence and buffer zone with the West, and, therefore, America and the European Union need to keep their hands off. At one point, one of the activists, the popular Ukrainian journalist, Vitali Sych, erupted: Did anyone ask us whether we wanted to be part of his buffer zone?

title: Religion for $1,000, Alex
description: WITH Easter and Passover freshly behind us, lets test your knowledge of the Bible. How many mistakes can you find:

title: For Drugs That Save Lives, a Steep Cost
description: THIS month, amid great fanfare, the Food and Drug Administration approved a portable pocket-size device that injects a drug called naloxone to rescue people who become unconscious from overdoses of heroin and other opiates. Wider dissemination of this antidote, long used in emergency rooms and by some first responders, will certainly save lives.

title: A Tempestuous Manager Confronts a Challenging Week
description: LONDON  There are few more mercurial men in soccer than Jos Mourinho, and there have been few more mercurial moments for him than now, at a make-or-break point in the closing weeks of his first year back at Chelsea. Two matches in the next four days will determine whether Mourinhos return to the managers job at Stamford Bridge will be triumphant, or an emblem of high promise unfulfilled.

title: Getting Into the Ivies
description: Ask just about any high school senior or junior  or their parents  and theyll tell you that getting into a selective college is harder than it used to be. Theyre right about that. But the reasons for the newfound difficulty are not well understood.

title: Answering Questions About New York
description: Q. The space known as the Biltmore Room (a.k.a. the Kissing Room) has a history associated with Grand Central Terminal. The chalkboard schedule of long-defunct trains makes sense. But there is also a tall lamppost, with two streetlights, in a corner by the tracks and beside the chalkboard. What is its significance?

title: Slaves to Prejudice
description: WASHINGTON  WHEN a cranky anarchist in a cowboy hat starts a sentence saying I want to tell you one more thing I know about the Negro, you can be dang sure its going downhill from there.

title: N.B.A. Investigating Racial Remarks Tied to Clippers Owner
description: MEMPHIS  The N.B.A. has promised a swift investigation into remarks attributed to the Los Angeles Clippers owner, Donald Sterling, after the release Friday night of an audio recording on the gossip website TMZ.com in which a person TMZ identified as Mr. Sterling admonished a female friend to avoid being seen in public with black people.

title: Scott Walkers Prospects
description: Wisconsins governor, Scott Walker, is being seen as a possible presidential candidate in 2016, and yet five years ago he was little known even in parts of his own state.

title: Unlikely Cast for Yanks Pieces Together a Win
description: Despite all the Yankees off-season spending, there will be days when they will have to piece together a win with parts culled from the minor leagues.

title: Militants Resist Calls to Free European Military Observers Held in Eastern Ukraine
description: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine  Antigovernment militants in eastern Ukraine on Saturday rebuffed international calls for the release of a group of European military observers, but suggested that they would consider a prisoner exchange.

title: Team Founded by Unhappy Fans May Buy the Club They Abandoned
description: TEL AVIV  Breaking up the soccer club they loved was hard for fans of Hapoel Katamon Jerusalem. Putting it back together may prove even more difficult.

title: Paul Cedes Some Control, at Least Until Game Is on the Line
description: Los Angeles Clippers guard Chris Paul is widely regarded as the premier point guard of his generation, a Hall of Fame contender who is a genius with the ball in his hands and a disruptive defensive presence. He has made first team all-N.B.A. three times and finished in the top five in most valuable player voting four times. But for all his accolades, Paul lags behind his peers in postseason accomplishments.

title: Wizards Relish the Playoffs and the Long Lines
description: WASHINGTON  When Richard Galiffa went to grab a snack during halftime of Fridays Washington Wizards game, he noticed something strange clogging the concourse of Verizon Center: dozens of men standing in a line.

title: Coaching Duo Adjusts for Family
description: One of hockeys more unusual coaching arrangements turned out to be one of the most successful, as Clarkson won the N.C.A.A. womens title last month under the husband-and-wife team of Matt and Shannon Desrosiers.

title: Recapturing Heart of a Derby Upset
description: When the filmmaker and horse owner Jim Wilson watched on television as the gelding Mine That Bird squirted through a hole on the rail in the homestretch to run away with the 2009 Kentucky Derby, he knew the story was movie material. An even deeper story emerged as Mine That Birds jockey, Calvin Borel, succumbed to his emotions, and the horses connections, the trainer Chip Woolley and the owners Mark Allen and Dr. Leonard Blach, gathered in the winners circle.

title: Predictable Partings
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Some people have a high tolerance for puns, and others have a much lower threshold. I consider Tom Swifty-style puns to be the pie-in-the-face, slapstick form of puns, because they are just so obvious.

title: World Champion Shows Vulnerability in Azerbaijan
description: It once seemed almost impossible to defeat a world champion.

title: In California, a Fevered Rush for Gun Permits
description: SANTA ANA, Calif.  Pete Alexander celebrated the news that a federal court in California had thrown out this states strict requirements for obtaining a concealed-handgun permit  among the toughest in the nation  by calling the Orange County Sheriffs Department to apply for a permit he had long wanted.

title: Nature Is All Around, but an Ornate House Is a Draw in Islip
description: The Suffolk County Environmental Center in Islip sees far more outdoor than indoor visitors. Nature enthusiasts flock to the 70-acre propertys expansive salt marsh, forests and freshwater wetlands, as well as to the outdoor education programs put on by the Seatuck Environmental Association, the nonprofit conservation group that runs the center for the county.

title: Old Story in Politics Resonates in New Era
description: An ambitious female politician, well-regarded by her constituents but not very well known outside of Texas, delivers a galvanizing speech that thrusts her into the national spotlight. Seizing her political moment, she runs for governor  and soon finds herself in a knock-down, drag-out fight with the male, Republican-establishment candidate.

title: Yonkers as Gallery
description: A video installation in a pop-up gallery, a fashion show in a garden, artist studio tours  these and more are part of the first Yonkers Arts Weekend. Organized by the City of Yonkers, the event next weekend aims to showcase the breadth of artistic activity throughout the city with exhibitions, performances and public art.

title: Once a Legislator, Now an Underdog Trying to Return
description: EL PASO  In a modest office in east central El Paso, former State Representative Norma Chvez spoke recently of her spiritual journey and weekly prayer group, and how she is 30 pounds lighter after adopting a healthier lifestyle. It is all part of a new perspective on life that she hopes will usher her back into the State Legislature after four years away from Austin.

title: How a Gulf Settlement That BP Once Hailed Became Its Target
description: NEW ORLEANS  Four years ago the Deepwater Horizon oil rig caught fire and exploded, killing 11 men, spewing millions of barrels of oil into the Gulf of Mexico and staining, seemingly indelibly, the image of BP, the international energy giant responsible for the well.

title: New Law Is Limiting Standardized Tests, but Not Prep Work
description: When Texas legislators passed a law in 2013 that sharply reduced standardized testing for public high school students, they included a provision aimed at easing the pressure of high-stakes exams for students in lower grades as well.

title: Easy to Target, but Often Hard to Send Packing
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: A Marriage of Visual Masters
description: Take an object. Do something to it. Do something else to it. These oft-cited instructions were written by Jasper Johns as directives to himself, and they are particularly suited to his work in printmaking, with its multi-stepped process and its toolbox of techniques. But to do something and then do something else when printing requires skilled assistance.

title: The History of Religion, Beginning with Noah and his Wife, Joan of Arc
description: My Sunday column looks at the importance of humanities, not least an area that even humanities enthusiasts sometimes scoff atreligious knowledge. My column argues that if we want to understand the world, it helps to know a bit about the worlds religions, including the world of Pentecostals and evangelicals that rarely make the news. I became interested in the role of religion in part in 2000 when I covered the campaign of George W. Bush, for it was clear that he was connecting to a large number of Americans through his faith, and I had only the vaguest idea at the time what an evangelical was. Then in covering America and the developing world alike, I was struck by the extraordinary surge in Pentecostal churches, and by their influence over so many people around the world.

title: My Head Talks Yet Again
description: On Stephanopoulos tomorrow. As I understand it, William Kristol and I will debate whether multiplicative shocks to wealth accumulation really do cause the right tail of the distribution to approximate a power law.

title: The Elegance of Clattering Machines
description: The labels alone make a racket: Meiselbach, Blickensderfer, Bar-Lock. No wonder the show-namers at the New Britain Museum of American Art call their fabulous little exhibition of antique typewriters Click! Clack! Ding!

title: One Mother, 7 Dead Newborns and a Stunned Community in Utah
description: PLEASANT GROVE, Utah  For Megan Huntsman, life was a miserable struggle. Her marriage decayed into substance abuse and violence, she told people close to her. Her ailing fathers suicide pitched her into despair and heavy drinking. Illness ravaged her family. She lost her job at a supermarket bakery and spent recent days alone at her boyfriends trailer home.

title: In Poorest States, Political Stigma Is Depressing Participation in Health Law
description: HUNTINGTON, W.Va.  Inside the sleek hillside headquarters of Valley Health Systems, built with a grant from the health care law, two employees played an advertisement they had helped produce to promote the laws insurance coverage for young, working-class West Virginians.

title: A Hidden Chapter in World War II History
description: In 2009, Roger Grunwald, an actor, traveled to Los Angeles to interview his aunt, Anne M. Bodenheimer, about her experiences in World War II, including in the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp. His mother, Lotte, Mrs. Bodenheimers sister, had survived Auschwitz and had often spoken to young people about her history.

title: Mollusks, but No Tiles, No Trains
description: This is not your commuters Grand Central Oyster Bar. What gave it away? Is it that at the Brooklyn outpost of the Grand Central Oyster Bar theres actual space to relax and a decibel level conducive to conversation?

title: Scots Ponder: Should They Stay or Should They Go?
description: EDINBURGH  The Royal Lyceum Theater here has a modest hit on its hands, a slightly scabrous play that tells the story of Scotlands parliamentary vote to dissolve itself and join the kingdom of England in 1707.

title: New York Finds Space for 3 Charter Schools
description: The office of Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York announced on Saturday that it has found space for three charter schools that had been at the heart of a battle between the new mayor and Eva S. Moskowitz, the leader of a high-performing charter network.

title: Bruins Advance and Are Set to Rekindle Rivalry
description: BOSTON  Chants of We Want the Cup reverberated through TD Garden on Saturday in the final minutes of the Boston Bruins 4-2 Game 5 victory over the Detroit Red Wings. But while the fans were happy to usher the Red Wings out of the arena and the series, they were no doubt looking toward the Bruins next matchup, against the vaunted and hated Montreal Canadiens.

title: George McDonald, 90, Dies; Union Leader Helped Save Newspaper Jobs
description: George E. McDonald, a union leader who helped navigate organized labors orderly retreat from its peak of power in the New York newspaper industry at the end of the century and, by some accounts, helped save the citys surviving tabloids, died last Sunday in Monmouth Park, N.J. He was 90.

title: South Korean Prime Minister Offers to Resign Over Deadly Ferry Disaster
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Prime Minister Chung Hong-won, the No. 2 official in the South Korean government, apologized and offered to resign on Sunday, as the country remained angry and saddened over the sinking of a ferry that left 302 people, a vast majority of them high school students, dead or missing.

title: N.B.A. Commissioner Promises Swift Investigation of Remarks
description: MEMPHIS  N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver said Saturday night that the league planned to pursue a swift investigation of the Los Angeles Clippers owner, Donald Sterling, after the release of an audio recording in which Sterling was alleged to have made racially charged remarks.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 26, 2014
description: April 26, 2014

title: Mahmoud Abbas Shifts on Holocaust
description: JERUSALEM  President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority issued a formal statement on Sunday calling the Holocaust the most heinous crime to have occurred against humanity in the modern era and expressing sympathy with victims families.

title: Orphan Black Recap: The Clones Versus the Monitors
description: As he lay dying, a wise man once told Agent Scully on The X-Files to Trust no one.

title: David W. Burke, Trusted Aide to Powerful Men, Dies at 78
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy had a habit of taking long walks with his closest aide, David W. Burke, before making big decisions. As secretary to Gov. Hugh L. Carey, Mr. Burke helped New York City navigate the 1970s fiscal crisis, partly by recommending that he hire Felix Rohatyn as financial wizard in chief.

title: Annual NYC Sikh Day Parade
description: Bill de Blasio, third from left, attended the Annual NYC Sikh Day Parade in Midtown on Saturday.

title: A Young Pitcher and Catcher Show They Still Need Work
description: Travis dArnaud, the Mets 25-year-old second-year catcher, is only eight months older than starting pitcher Jenrry Mejia, but dArnaud knows that his input is just as crucial to Mejias growth as the blazing fastballs that come out of his electric right arm.

title: A Disturbing Tape and a Potential Moral Quandary
description: In one of his popular songs of black consciousness, Curtis Mayfield asked: If you had a choice of colors, which one would you choose, my brothers? If there was no day or night, which would you prefer to be right?

title: Reaction to the Remarks Linked to Donald Sterling
description: President Obama condemned the incredibly offensive racist statements attributed to the Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling during a press conference on Sunday in Malaysia.

title: Ravindra GuneWardena and Frank Escher
description: Ravindra Anthony Sampath GuneWardena and Frank Christian Escher were married Saturday by the Rev. Tom Carey, an Episcopal priest, at the Church of the Epiphany in Los Angeles.

title: Sheila Rustgi, Corey Morenz
description: Sheila Devi Rustgi, a daughter of Eileen M. Boyle of Potomac, Md., and Dr. Vinod K. Rustgi of Pittsburgh, was married Saturday evening to Corey James Morenz, a son of Carol G. Morenz and Art Morenz of Thomaston, Conn. The Rev. Louis V. Schwebius, an interfaith minister, officiated at the Decatur House in Washington.

title: Catherine Strzelczyk, Kenneth Vaz
description: Catherine Anne Strzelczyk, a daughter of Maria A. Strzelczyk of Glen Rock, N.J., and the late Bruce J. Strzelczyk, was married Saturday to Dr. Kenneth Mark Vaz, the son of Judy J. Vaz and Edward G. Vaz of Berkeley Heights, N.J. The Rev. James Rafferty, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Immaculata Church in San Diego.

title: It All Started on the Playground
description: Dr. Lark Julie Greenwald and Dr. Zachary David Guss are to be married Sunday evening at the Coronado Community Center in Coronado, Calif., with Rabbi Michael Satz officiating.

title: Todd Cross, Rodney Wright
description: Todd Franklin Cross and Dr. Rodney Lorne Wright were married Saturday evening at the Eventi Hotel in Manhattan. The Rev. Dr. Jon Walton, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Gabriella de Araujo and Alexander Iannaccone
description: Gabriella Kristina de Araujo and Alexander Lawrence Iannaccone were married Saturday at the Royal Poinciana Chapel in Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Dr. Robert S. Norris, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Stephanie Shestakow, George Federici
description: Stephanie Lorraine Shestakow, a daughter of Jane M. Shestakow and Nicholas Shestakow of Jackson, N.J., was married Saturday to George Ralph Federici, a son of Lynda M. Federici and Dr. George E. Federici of Maple Glen, Pa. The Rev. Patrick J. Tonry, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Old St. Josephs Church in Philadelphia.

title: Katherine Hubert, Peter Chan
description: Dr. Katherine Cheney Hubert and Dr. Peter Gar-Jun Chan were married Saturday in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Jonathan L. Walton, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at the Memorial Church of Harvard.

title: Ilyssa McIntyre, Clarke Smith
description: Ilyssa Jenna McIntyre, the daughter of Mary K. McIntyre and Robert W. McIntyre of Florham Park, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Clarke McIntyre Smith, a son of Rebecca B. Smith of Norfolk, Va., and the late John L. Smith Jr. The Rev. Mark R. Collins, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Holy Trinity in New York.

title: Jordan Carqueville, Marc Wezowski
description: Dr. Jordan Claire Carqueville and Marc Richard Wezowski were married Saturday evening in Naples, Fla. The Rev. John Ludden, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. John the Evangelist Catholic Church.

title: Sarah Spigelman, Joshua Richter
description: Sarah Elizabeth Ward Spigelman and Dr. Joshua Ryan Richter were married Saturday by Rabbi Steve Blane at the Essex House in Manhattan.

title: Daniel Gramkee, Scott Kleinbart
description: Daniel Thomas Gramkee and Scott Neil Kleinbart were married Saturday at the Soldiers, Sailors, Marines, Coast Guard and Airmens Club in New York. Michael R. Sonberg, an acting State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan, officiated.

title: Charlotte Evans, Tyler Will
description: Charlotte Fulton Sergeant Evans and Tyler William Will were married Saturday at the brides family home in Brookville, N.Y. The Rev. Francis H. Geer, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Laura Perretta, Alan Tabak
description: Dr. Laura Joanne Perretta and Alan Joseph Tabak were married Saturday at Saint Anthony of Padua Church in West Harrison, N.Y. The Rev. Christopher W. Monturo, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Julia Emanuel, Eric Feinstein
description: Julia Mae Emanuel, the daughter of Ann M. Emanuel of Tenafly, N.J., and the late Dr. David J. Emanuel, was married Saturday evening to Eric Matthew Feinstein, a son of Jane B. Feinstein and Dr. Peter A. Feinstein of Shavertown, Pa. Rabbi Larry Kaplan officiated at the Yale Club of New York City.

title: Ronit Feldman, Eric Wagman
description: Ronit Feldman and Eric Wagman are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Miriam Jerris at the Colony Club in Detroit.

title: Rachana Dixit, Neeraj Pradhan
description: Rachana Dixit and Neeraj Bahadur Pradhan were married Saturday at Foxchase Manor, an event space in Manassas, Va. Pandit Laksuman Bhandari, a Vedic Hindu priest, officiated.

title: Victoria Corder, Anthony Langelier
description: Victoria Vance Corder and Anthony Charles Langelier were married Saturday at the Dixon Gallery and Gardens in Memphis. The Rev. James Phelan Biedenharn III, an Episcopal priest,officiated.

title: Marianne Strazza, Jonathan Weinstein
description: Marianne Strazza and Jonathan Daniel Weinstein were married Saturday at Our Lady Star of the Sea Church in Huguenot, Staten Island. Msgr. Vincent Bartley performed the ceremony, with Rabbi Scott Matous assisting.

title: Whitney Cale, Peter Brejcha
description: Whitney Rawn Cale and Peter Thomas Brejcha were married Saturday at the Parish of St. Matthew in Los Angeles. The Rev. Lester V. Mackenzie, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Rebecca Aledort, Daniel Ryan
description: Rebecca Joy Aledort and Daniel Andrew Ryan were married Saturday evening at the Glen Cove Mansion in Glen Cove, N.Y. Rabbi Brian Denker-Youngs officiated.

title: Anne Evans and David Hendrickson
description: Anne Morrill Evans, a daughter of Sarah E. Cogan and Douglas H. Evans of New York, was married Saturday to David Charles Hendrickson, a son of Judy M. Hendrickson and James L. Hendrickson of Rowayton, Conn. The Rev. J. Donald Waring, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Grace Church in New York.

title: Rebecca Kahan and Craig Waldman
description: Rebecca Sarah Kahan, a daughter of Betsy B. Kahan and Dr. Ronald S. Kahan of Wilton, Conn., was married Saturday evening to Craig Scott Waldman, a son of Joan F. Waldman and Lawrence J. Waldman of Roslyn Heights, N.Y. Richard M. Berman, a judge of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, officiated, with Rabbi Andrew Gordon taking part, at the Tappan Hill Mansion in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Brooke Lyons and Maximillian Osswald
description: Brooke Lyons and Maximillian Antony Osswald were married Saturday in Ojai, Calif., at the home of Helene Gordon, a friend of the brides family. Jonathon Fries, a friend who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated, assisted by Eleanor Rutledge-Leverenz, another friend who became a Universal Life minister.

title: Muna Shikaki and Clinton Reach
description: Muna Khalil Shikaki and Clinton Bruce Reach were married Saturday at the home of the grooms mother, Anita A. Reach of Kansas City, Kan. Ryan Callahan, a friend of the groom who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: A Conversation Began and Never Stopped
description: Clara Bingham and Joseph Gregory Finnerty III were married Saturday at the River Caf in Brooklyn. Mayor Bill de Blasio officiated.

title: Counterpoints to Offensive Remarks
description: A report that Donald Sterling made offensive remarks about black players elicited swift reaction on social media. Current and former players, entertainers and ordinary people chimed in using hashtags like #DonaldSterling, #Sterling and #boycottclippers.

title: Superstars Come Second to Culture at Jazzfest
description: NEW ORLEANS  If you talk to someone in the music business these days about outdoor festivals, youll probably hear a lot about electronic dance music, or E.D.M. Big name-D.J.s have become part of the formula for any major pop festival, and there is even a publicly traded company, SFX Entertainment, devoted to attracting corporate sponsors to dance events.

title: Sanctions Revive Search for Secret Putin Fortune
description: WASHINGTON  When the Obama administration imposed sanctions on individual Russians last month in response to Moscows armed intervention in Ukraine, one of the targets was a longtime part-owner of a commodities trading company called the Gunvor Group.

title: Corrections: April 27, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: China Orders 4 U.S. Shows Off Streaming Sites
description: BEIJING  Chinese regulators have ordered streaming video websites nationwide to take down four popular American TV series, a move that precedes new regulations seeking to close a loophole that has allowed foreign shows to flourish online, even as censors have limited them on broadcast television.

title: South Korean Leader Accepts Resignation of Premier Over Ferry Disaster
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Prime Minister Chung Hong-won, the No.2 official in the South Korean government, apologized and offered to resign on Sunday, as the country remained angry and saddened over the sinking of a ferry that left 302 people, the vast majority of them high school students, dead or missing.

title: In Malaysia, Obama Works to Mend Troubled Ties
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  The last time a top American official visited this Southeast Asian nation was in 1998, when Vice President Al Gore publicly rebuked its leaders for suppressing freedom and embraced reformasi, the rallying cry of the student-led protest movement.

title: In Our Pages: April 28
description: 1939: Cheese Parties in N.Y. to Promote French Products

title: A Fully Wrought Life  Stones Pianist, Tree Farmer, Green Blog Pioneer
description: Any time you think youre packing as much into your life as is humanly possible, you meet someone who has taken things to another level.

title: On Historic Day, John XXIII and John Paul II Become Saints
description: VATICAN CITY  Pope Francis made history on Sunday, elevating to sainthood John XXIII and John Paul II, two of his most famous papal predecessors, in a ceremony bearing themes of hope and reconciliation for the worlds one billion Roman Catholics.

title: When a Working Grandma Cant Afford to Babysit, a Tradition Ends
description: My mother trudged down the stairs of her Staten Island townhouse this past Christmas Day, head slumped down, Eeyore-style. Even with my inherited poor eyesight, I could see from her modest kitchen table that the lenses on her dark, plastic glasses, a pair only a hip 57-year-old could pull off, were fogged up.

title: France Defers G.E. Plan to Buy Energy Business
description: PARIS  The French government on Sunday sought to put the brakes on General Electrics bid for Alstom, one of the largest industrial companies in France, warning that national interest was in play and that the state would have a say in the outcome.

title: For Fitness Bands, Slick Marketing but Suspect Results
description: My Nike FuelBand read lazy. My friends read fit.

title: U.S. and Philippines Agree to a 10-Year Pact on the Use of Military Bases
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  The United States has reached a 10-year agreement with the Philippines that will give American warships, planes and troops greater access to bases in the archipelago, American officials said Sunday.

title: Whats On Sunday
description: 9 P.M. (OWN) RUNNING FROM CRAZY (2013) Mariel Hemingway  in her own words: tall blonde, no problems  discusses the famous ancestry and mental health challenges of her family, including the suicides of her grandfather Ernest Hemingway and her sister Margaux, in this documentary directed by Barbara Kopple and commissioned by Oprah Winfreys OWN channel. Ms. Kopple follows Ms. Hemingway, above, while she visits her family, including her daughters, Dree and Langley, and other sister, Joan, a.k.a. Muffet; gives speeches on her wellness regime; and works out with a male companion. Running From Crazy  the title is Ms. Hemingways phrasing  doesnt entirely escape the dangers of the confessional profile, Nicolas Rapold wrote in The New York Times. But Ms. Kopple shows how people in Ms. Hemingways position, with a family history of mental health problems, confront a foreboding mirror, whether or not it also reflects a literary heritage and a Kennedy-grade bone structure.

title: A String Quartet Sits, in Solidarity, and Delivers Shostakovich
description: The Emerson String Quartet, according to its standard biography, stands apart in the history of string quartets. Its a wink toward one of the things that makes this venerable ensemble special: cellist aside, its members stand, rather than sit.

title: The Other Woman Tops the Box Office But Overall Sales Drop
description: Updated, 12:52 p.m. | Moviegoers took a break this weekend as receipts for the top 10 films dropped 17.1 percent from last weekend, to $96.4 million.

title: Butterflies (Nearly) Over Brooklyn
description: To Judy Chicagos list of accomplishments add control of the weather. The rain ended in Brooklyn on Saturday night just in time for a crowd of about 10,000 in Prospect Park to see her pyrotechnic display, A Butterfly for Brooklyn. And it started up again just after most spectators would have made it to the subway for the trip home.

title: Syria Misses New Deadline as It Works to Purge Arms
description: GENEVA  Syria missed a revised deadline on Sunday for completing the export or destruction of chemicals in its weapons arsenal, but the government of the war-ravaged country may be only days away from finishing the job, according to international experts overseeing the process.

title: Detainees in Ukraine Uncertain of Return
description: A group of European military observers, detained since Friday, appeared before journalists in a news conference in Slovyansk on Sunday.

title: Pro-Russian Forces in Ukraine Free One of 8 Detainees
description: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine  The self-appointed mayor of this breakaway city in eastern Ukraine on Sunday displayed eight detained members of a European military observer mission and later released one for health reasons, but otherwise refused to discuss conditions under which the others might go free beyond mentioning a possible prisoner exchange.

title: National Pride Swells the Crowds for a Polish Saint
description: VATICAN CITY  Thousands of Polish pilgrims traveled to Rome on Sunday for the canonization ceremony of John Paul II, driven by reverence for a towering historic figure and by national pride.

title: In New Home, Bronx Dance Academy Seeks to Step Up Its Presence
description: Arthur Aviles knows how to balance. He can jump onto a pedestal, strike a loose-limbed pose then leap to the ground. Once upon terra firma, he confronts an even more delicate balance: how to ensure the future of his group, the Bronx Academy of Arts and Dance, as it settles into a new home and a new neighborhood and  he hopes  attracts new audiences and backers.

title: Vows: Orchestrating a Proposal
description: Peter Chan proposed to Kate Hubert with a musical flourish just nine months after they met.

title: After Pushing Flyers to Brink, Rangers Look to Hone Killer Instinct
description: The Rangers defeated the Philadelphia Flyers, 4-2, at Madison Square Garden on Sunday and grabbed a 3-2 lead in their opening-round playoff series. But if they hope to close out the series when it shifts to Philadelphia on Tuesday night, they will have to face down not only the Flyers, but also their own baffling inability to press an advantage.

title: New Space, New Conversations for ICP
description: The International Center for Photography may be moving, but its director fully intends to keep it at the center of conversations that explain and explore image-making in the 21st Century.

title: A European Energy Executives Delicate Dance Over Ukraine
description: LONDON  European executives, especially in the energy industry, have been notably wary of ratcheting up economic tensions with Russia over the Ukraine crisis. They see their business interests as too intertwined to risk stiffer sanctions.

title: A Matriarch With Stories to Tell and a Love of Swing to Share
description: What a life! Im in heaven! Look at what Ive got!

title: Fleeing Conflict in South Sudan
description: Mackenzie Knowles-Coursin, a photographer, followed one familys harrowing escape to safety.

title: After a Drowning, Musical Bones Wash Ashore
description: Tragic love stories, whether real or fictional, have provided fodder for poets, playwrights and composers for millenniums. An installment of the composer David Langs collected stories series at Zankel Hall on Thursday evening highlighted a particularly gruesome story of love gone awry, with a Celtic folk song about sibling rivalry.

title: Amid Uproar, Clippers Silently Display Solidarity
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  The Los Angeles Clippers, reacting to recordings of racist remarks attributed to Donald Sterling, the teams owner, took the court for their playoff game Sunday with a statement, one of both fashion and politics.

title: Two Brothers in the Icy Grip of Midlife
description: Michael Cunninghams resonant new novel, The Snow Queen, takes its title from the Hans Christian Andersen fairy tale of the same name about the redemptive powers of love and its ability to melt even the chilliest of hearts.

title: Celebrating a Poem and a Novel by James Baldwin, With Movement
description: With its annual Live Ideas festival, New York Live Arts, an institution generally devoted to dance, opens its doors to a wider range of programming. The curatorial approach, so far, involves unpacking the work of a cultural figure who bridges many fields of inquiry, the body included. Last years theme was The Worlds of Oliver Sacks. This year, its James Baldwin, This Time! (with This underlined for emphasis). That Harlem-born writer and activist would have been 90 this August, and Live Arts is one of several New York organizations celebrating The Year of James Baldwin, an extended (and timely) reflection on his social and literary achievements.

title: Swiss Teams at the Sagamore Bridge Club in Syosset, N.Y.
description: In a recent column, I mentioned that bridge club attendance has been hurt by the online sites. This is true even in the New York City area and New Jersey, which, according to the American Contract Bridge League, together had five of the top nine most successful clubs in North America in terms of tables in play last year.

title: Confidence on the Rise for Gee and the Mets
description: When General Manager Sandy Alderson declared before the season that the Mets goal was to win 90 games, the statement was mocked and ridiculed (and it may still be). Some fans wondered if the Mets were delusional.

title: Chef and Keep On Win Tribeca Audience Awards
description: At the Tribeca Film Festival on Saturday, audience awards were handed out to Chef, for best narrative feature, and Keep On Keepin On, for best documentary. The two films were chosen by festivalgoers who cast ballots on their way out of screenings.

title: Hoping to End a Dubious Streak
description: One of the most famous and popular American plays, it turns out, is also one of the most slighted in Broadway history.

title: A Conductor, Rehired, Now Must Rebuild
description: WASHINGTON  Osmo Vanska is suddenly a man in a hurry. Mr. Vanska, the Finnish conductor, bode his time as music director of the Minnesota Orchestra through the first year of managements lockout of the players (which eventually ran to 16 months, ending in February) during a contract dispute, but resigned out of frustration in October. He was reinstated last Thursday, to start officially this Thursday.

title: A Gaming Company Devoted to Narrative Tackles Thrones
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif.  Behind closed doors and papered-over windows here, a half-dozen storytellers have been scrambling to conjure a fantasy world with compelling characters, fierce dialogue and an intricate plot. But this is no ordinary writers room: Its Telltale Games, an independent video game studio that has developed an intense following by prizing nuance and narrative in an industry more often associated with clattering machine guns and screeching getaway cars.

title: Star Stand-Ins
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  And the award for Longest Hiatus Between Published Puzzles goes to  Jim Modney! I understand how life can get in the way of constructing, but I really think Mr. Modney deserves a round of applause for his nearly 30-year break in puzzle-making.

title: Museum Draws Donatello From Italy
description: New York City, home to a stunning number of Renaissance treasures, has never had a work in a permanent collection by one of the eras foremost sculptural masters, Donatello, and major pieces by him rarely leave Europe. But for a few months next year, the city will become a veritable Donatello feast, the one stop for a small show of works from the Duomo museum in Florence, Italy, including several sculptures instantly recognizable from art history textbooks but never before seen in America.

title: A Caper by the Coens, With a Fake Monet
description: Silently slipped into a single theater like a heist in reverse, Gambit is getting the sort of American release you might not expect given its cast and a screenplay written, at some point in the films hot-potato history, by the Coen brothers. This nominal remake of the 1966 art caper that starred Michael Caine and Shirley MacLaine has all the fizz of flat soda, but its not catastrophically worse than any number of films that open widely.

title: Updates on Tech Companies and Job Numbers
description: INVESTORS WATCH TWITTER FOR FURTHER STAGNATION

title: Years After Chernobyl, Building Progress
description: At the Chernobyl nuclear plant, a rising arch is a sign of a cleanups progress, and the remains of Pripyat, a city once home to 45,000, is a reminder of the devastation of 1986.

title: Forced to Flee Radiation, Fearful Japanese Villagers Are Reluctant to Return
description: MIYAKOJI, Japan  Ever since they were forced to evacuate during the accident at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant three years ago, Kim Eunja and her husband have refused to return to their hilltop home amid the majestic mountains of this rural village for fear of radiation.

title: Few Consumers Are Buying Premise of Mobile Wallets
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Millions of Americans use smartphones for tasks like hailing a taxi or checking in for a flight. But for buying something in a store? That mostly remains a tech entrepreneurs dream.

title: Kerr Says He Discussed Knicks Job With Jackson
description: Steve Kerr dined with the new Knicks president, Phil Jackson, in Manhattan on Friday to discuss the teams head-coaching vacancy, Kerr said Sunday at Barclays Center, where he was preparing to work as an analyst for TNT for a playoff game between the Nets and the Toronto Raptors.

title: ECO 348, The Great Recession: Secular Stagnation
description: Slides here (pdf).

title: Qaddafi Son Appears on Screen at His Trial
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, facing accusations that he aided his father, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, in the brutal suppression of Libyas uprising three years ago, was not allowed to appear in court in person on Sunday to answer the charges.

title: Wheeldons Alice to Play in New York
description: The Joyce Theater Foundation and the National Ballet of Canada plan to announce on Monday that they will present the New York premiere of Alices Adventures in Wonderland with choreography by Christopher Wheeldon. Set to an original score by Joby Talbot and with costume and set designs by Bob Crowley, the production of the Lewis Carroll classic is scheduled to run from Sept. 9 to 14 at the David H. Koch Theater in Lincoln Center. Mr. Wheeldons interpretation of Alice had its premiere at the Royal Opera House in London in 2011. Tickets go on sale Monday and will be available at davidhkochtheater.com and by calling 212-496-0600.

title: New Challenges Chip Away at Cables Pillar of Profit
description: For decades, cable television has been an almost magical source of profits, in large part because of the bundle, the packaging of channels that compels subscribers to buy a lot of programming they never watch.

title: Nuclear Industry Gains Carbon-Focused Allies in Push to Save Reactors
description: Environmentalists and the nuclear industry are beginning a push to preserve old nuclear reactors whose economic viability is threatened by cheap natural gas and rising production of wind energy. They argue that while natural gas and wind are helpful as sources of electricity with little or no production of greenhouse gases, national climate goals will be unreachable if zero-carbon nuclear reactors are phased out.

title: Putin Rival Takes Message to East Ukraine
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  Not for the first time in his life, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the Russian former tycoon suddenly freed from jail in December by President Vladimir V. Putin, was on a somewhat quixotic mission.

title: John Houbolt, NASA Innovator Behind Lunar Module, Dies at 95
description: On May 25, 1961, President John F. Kennedy told Congress that the United States should commit to landing a man on the moon before the end of the decade.

title: On Bridges in Paris, Clanking With Love
description: PARIS  Johannes and Melissa. David and Michaela. Ben and Justin.

title: Despite Big Ambitions, New Yorks Tech Scene Is Still Starting Up
description: Predicting that your city will be the next Silicon Valley is simple. But actually making it the next Silicon Valley is something else entirely  as New York is slowly finding out.

title: Soured Mortgages Attract Institutional Dollars
description: A Wall Street executive who helped Goldman Sachs make more than a billion dollars betting against mortgages now wants to buy up troubled home loans.

title: Home Dcor Retailer CB2 Invites Pinterest Users to Furnish Apartment
description: MORE visitors to the website for CB2, the home dcor chain owned by Crate & Barrel, come from Pinterest, the virtual bulletin board, than any other social network. Now CB2 is turning to Pinterest users to weigh in on decorating an apartment the company has rented in New York.

title: Cholera and Clean Water
description: To the Editor:

title: What Does Buddhism Require?
description: This is the fifth in a series of interviews about religion that I am conducting for The Stone. The interviewee for this installment is Jay L. Garfield, who has taught philosophy at several universities and is currently the Kwan Im Thong Hood Cho Temple Professor of Humanities, Yale-NUS College in Singapore. He is at work on a book called Engaging Buddhism: Why Buddhism Matters to Contemporary Philosophy.

title: The Role of the Clergy in Helping the Mentally Ill
description: To the Editor:

title: Should Doctors Care About Cost?
By Digitizing Images, Museum Opens a Window Into the Past
description: Fully a century before Sarah Palin declared that Alaska was just right over the border from Russia, an expedition fielded by the American Museum of Natural History in New York sought to prove that the first people to reach the Americas had indeed migrated across the frozen Bering Strait.

title: The War on Truth in Ukraine
description: WASHINGTON  For a moment last week, war seemed imminent. A day after Russias foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, warned Ukraines leaders against using force in the crisis there, the Ukrainian military attacked a checkpoint outside the separatist-held town of Slovyansk. Russian forces across the border responded with maneuvers labeled exercises, coupled with statements from the Kremlin that amounted to you were warned. Russian television made Slovyansk look like Guernica; Ukrainian news media reported that separatist militants were using kindergartners as human shields.

title: Epix Plans to Introduce Film on Altman
description: LOS ANGELES  Altmanesque: Possessing a mysterious quality that makes you want to watch more movies.

title: Health Laws Pay Policy Is Skewed, Panel Finds
description: WASHINGTON  Federal policies to reward high-quality health care are unfairly penalizing doctors and hospitals that treat large numbers of poor people, according to a new report commissioned by the Obama administration that recommends sweeping changes in payment policy.

title: The Wire Next Time
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  LAST weeks proposal by the Federal Communications Commission to allow Internet service providers to charge different rates to different online content companies  effectively ending the governments commitment to net neutrality  set off a flurry of protest.

title: Smart Firearm Draws Wrath of the Gun Lobby
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  Belinda Padilla does not pick up unknown calls anymore, not since someone posted her cellphone number on an online forum for gun enthusiasts. A few fuming-mad voice mail messages and heavy breathers were all it took.

title: A Versatile Shark Quietly Makes a Major Difference
description: LOS ANGELES  San Jose Sharks forward Joe Pavelski has shown as much talent for avoiding the limelight as he has for eluding opposing defensemen.

title: Milq Aims to Separate Wheat From Social Media Chaff
description: Social media users know the frustration: a deluge of videos, images and music clips flows through their news feeds all the time, some of it precious (Miles Davis discussing Prince!), but mostly not (Heres what I ate for breakfast!).

title: U.S. Weighs Harder Line on Russia Than European Allies
description: WASHINGTON  As President Obama and his national security team struggle to increase pressure on Russia over its intervention in Ukraine, they have become entangled in a tense debate over how much emphasis to put on unity with European allies more reluctant to take stronger economic actions against Moscow.

title: Supreme Court Taking Up Police Searches of Data Troves Known as Cellphones
description: WASHINGTON  In a major test of how to interpret the Fourth Amendment in the digital age, the Supreme Court on Tuesday will consider two cases about whether the police need warrants to search the cellphones of the people they arrest.

title: Verbatim: What Is a Photocopier?
description: In this dramatization of transcripts from a legal deposition, a lawyer becomes embroiled in an absurd argument about the definition of a photocopier.

title: Veteran Rangers Center Provides Big Lift
description: Dominic Moore added an exclamation point to his memorable comeback season when he scored an unassisted second-period goal Sunday afternoon that proved to be the winner in the Rangers 4-2 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: Despite Twitter Backlash, New York Police Dept. Plans to Expand Social Media Efforts
description: For the first few months of his second tour as commissioner of the New York Police Department, William J. Bratton has been consumed in large part with reshaping perceptions of officers.

title: Verbatim: What Is a Photocopier?
description: In 2012, on my Facebook feed, I stumbled across a hilarious excerpt from a legal transcript. In a deposition in Ohio, a lawyer became embroiled in an absurd argument about the definition of a photocopier.

title: One Therapist, $4 Million in 2012 Medicare Billing
description: A few miles from the Coney Island boardwalk in Brooklyn stands an outpost of what, on paper, is a giant of American medicine.

title: Recovery Has Created Far More Low-Wage Jobs Than Better-Paid Ones
description: WASHINGTON  The deep recession wiped out primarily high-wage and middle-wage jobs. Yet the strongest employment growth during the sluggish recovery has been in low-wage work, at places like strip malls and fast-food restaurants.

title: No Accounting Skills? No Moral Reckoning
description: SOMETIMES it seems as if our lives are dominated by financial crises and failed reforms. But how much do Americans even understand about finance? Few of us can do basic accounting and fewer still know what a balance sheet is. If we are going to get to the point where we can have a serious debate about financial accountability, we first need to learn some essentials.

title: In Venezuela, Protesters Point to Their Scars
description: VALENCIA, Venezuela  Clipso Martnez was shot at such close range by a soldier at a protest that his surgeon said he had to remove pieces of the plastic shotgun shell buried in his leg, along with the shards of keys Mr. Martnez had in his pocket, shattered by the blast.

title: In Complex Mess, a Question of Who Has Leverage
description: Of the two most leveraged presidents to have weighed in on the Donald Sterling audio imbroglio, a fairly loquacious Barack Obama was the less significant voice. What little Chris Paul, president of the National Basketball Players Association, had to say could potentially have far more impact on how the league might proceed on this complex, evolving and exceedingly troubling story.

title: Gay Rights Push Shifts Its Focus South and West
description: The countrys leading gay rights groups and donors, after a decade focused on legalizing same-sex marriage, are embarking on a major drive to win more basic civil rights and workplace protections in Southern and Western states where the rapid progress of the movement has largely eluded millions of gay men and lesbians.

title: Experimental Efforts to Harvest the Oceans Power Face Cost Setbacks
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  At the Port of Portland sits a 260-ton buoy filled with technology that can turn the movement of the ocean into electricity to power 100 homes. It rolled off an assembly line to great fanfare two years ago and received the nations first commercial license to operate.

title: Caution Ahead for Municipal IDs
description: Two New York City Council members, Daniel Dromm and Carlos Menchaca, have introduced a bill to create a municipal photo-ID card that all New Yorkers could use, even those without legal immigration status. This excellent idea has the strong support of the Council speaker, Melissa Mark-Viverito, and Mayor Bill de Blasio, so it seems likely that New York will soon join cities like San Francisco and New Haven in achieving a goal that immigrant-rights advocates have long striven for: documenting the undocumented.

title: Treasury Auctions for the Week of April 28
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes the regular Monday auction of new three- and six-month bills and auctions of four-week bills, one-year bills and two-year floating rate notes on Tuesday.

title: One Year After Rana Plaza
description: A horrendous building collapse last April in Bangladesh killed more than 1,100 garment workers. Labor groups, Western clothing companies, the Bangladeshi government and others have made some progress toward preventing similar tragedies, but more needs to be done.

title: Given Cause to Make a Stand, the Clippers Settle for a Gesture
description: Why not remain seated?

title: Smartphones and the 4th Amendment
description: More than 90 percent of American adults own a mobile phone, and more than half of the devices are smartphones. But smartphone is a misnomer. They are personal computers that happen to include a phone function, and like any computer they can store or wirelessly retrieve enormous amounts of personal information: emails, photos and videos; document files; financial and medical records; and virtually everywhere a person has been.

title: High Plains Moochers
description: It is, in a way, too bad that Cliven Bundy  the rancher who became a right-wing hero after refusing to pay fees for grazing his animals on federal land, and bringing in armed men to support his defiance  has turned out to be a crude racist. Why? Because his ranting has given conservatives an easy out, a way to dissociate themselves from his actions without facing up to the terrible wrong turn their movement has taken.

title: A Young Mayor Who Likes to Share His View From the Top
description: LOS ANGELES  When Eric Garcetti ran for mayor of Los Angeles, his campaign created an Instagram account to feed voters a daily stream of campaign pictures: candidate shaking hands, candidate touring park, candidate giving a speech. Unremarkable, unrevealing and uncontroversial  and destined to fade away with Election Day, which it did.

title: Chernobyl: Capping a Catastrophe
description: A 32,000-ton arch that will end up costing $1.5 billion is being built in Chernobyl, Ukraine, to all but eliminate the risk of further contamination at the site of the 1986 nuclear reactor explosion.

title: U.S. Caught Up in Islands Dispute
description: The rising international racket over islands in the South China Sea.

title: Vortex of Outrage Has Long Trailed Clippers Owner
description: LOS ANGELES  When Kim Hughes, then an assistant coach for the Los Angeles Clippers, was found to have prostate cancer on the eve of training camp in 2004, he learned what it was like to work in Donald Sterlings world.

title: A Smuggler of Immigrants Dies in Prison, but Is Praised in Chinatown
description: To the authorities, Cheng Chui Ping was the mother of all snakeheads, a ruthless businesswoman who smuggled thousands of Chinese emigrants into the United States.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 27, 2014
description: April 27, 2014

title: Suspect in School Attack Once Turned to Victim for Help, Friends Say
description: MILFORD, Conn.  Nobody ever had to ask Maren Sanchez to help. She was simply there with a smile, gathering an armload of books someone had dropped in the hallway of Jonathan Law High School, greeting strangers like old friends, offering to lend a hand when a classmate got stuck on homework.

title: When She Was Venus and Nellie Forbush
description: Can you blame theater people for trying to raise the dead?

title: All Books Not Equal to Squabbling Family
description: Although its roughly the age of a recent college graduate, Jon Robin Baitzs play The Substance of Fire at times seems to have grown some gray whiskers. Watching the sure-footed new revival of the play that opened at the Second Stage Theater on Sunday night, featuring standout performances by the Australian actor John Noble and the ever-vibrant Charlayne Woodard, I kept thinking of dramas about family, money and morality written way back in the early years of the 20th century by Harley Granville Barker.

title: Should Affirmative Action Be Based on Income?
Recreational Bicycling vs. Delivery Bicycling
description: Dear Diary:

title: Popular Demand
description: Record Store Day, which began in April 2008, is a self-styled celebration of the unique culture surrounding independent record stores. Some titles released on vinyl for the April 19 event, like Because the Internet, saw revitalized sales weeks after a release on CD.

title: Foursquare Chief Apologizes for Wifes Fake Boston Marathon Bib
description: A co-founder of Foursquare, a popular location-sharing mobile app, issued an online apology after an investigation of unauthorized runners in the Boston Marathon found that his wife had used a fake bib to participate in the race last Monday.

title: For Politician, an Indictment Looms, and So Does a Campaign for Re-election
description: Republican Party leaders in Staten Island had long heard murmuring about Representative Michael G. Grimms possible legal troubles. But Mr. Grimm maintained his innocence, and party leaders stood behind his bid for a third term this November.

title: Two Horses, 59 Years Apart, Inspire One Trainer
