description: DAKAR, Senegal  Hundreds of protesters marched in the streets of the Nigerian capital on Wednesday, demanding that the government do more to find scores of schoolgirls abducted by armed militants more than two weeks ago. Parents of the girls have turned up sick in hospitals, overcome with worry. Some have even gone into the bush to search for the girls themselves, armed only with bows and arrows in the heartland of an Islamist insurgency.

title: Augie Boehm at Honors Bridge Club
description: Augie Boehm of New York City is a well-known bridge player, teacher and writer. He is also an excellent concert pianist and on May 12 will be giving his 36th annual recital at the Weill Recital Hall in Carnegie Hall.

title: Agnostic Lyricism in an Exploration of Spirituality
description: A program about spirituality and theological doubt would seem to be a natural for the Cecilia Chorus of New York, which was known as the St. Cecilia Chorus from its founding, in 1906, until it dropped the heavenly honorific  and, presumably, the religious connotations that accompanied it  in 2012. The centerpiece of the choruss concert at Carnegie Hall on Friday evening was a new work, Tom Cipullos Credo for a Secular City, intended, in its composers words, as a statement for the believers and for the nonbelievers as well.

title: Deconstructing Charles James
description: Charles James: Beyond Fashion, at the Met, includes animated videos that virtually peel garments, like his Ribbon dress, here, from their mannequins to illustrate how they were assembled.

title: A Shortcut to Spring
description: In early April, a week before she was due to leave for South Africa to run an ultramarathon, Cortney Harding decided to get her hair cut. Ms. Harding, who is 33 and lives in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, went from hair that hit just above the shoulder to a short jaw-length bob with bangs. I wanted to feel the sun on the back of my neck, she said.

title: Architectural Underpinnings of Cinderella
description: Charles James, the fabled fashion designer, once declared, Im the most copied person in the world. But that Anglo-American couturier, who died in 1978, could never have imagined why his glamorous 1953 Clover Leaf dress was being meticulously recreated and scrutinized now  all 10 pounds of it.

title: The Execution That Was Botched in Oklahoma
description: To the Editor:

title: Guides to Four Flowers for Those Already Smitten
description: Garden books devoted to a single genus run the risk of simply being mind-numbing lists of species  this one found in the mountains, by the opening of a hermits cave; that one crossed with a Labrador retriever to win Plant of the Year at the Chelsea Flower Show. Timber Press is fond of publishing such books, because after all, gardeners tend to be a greedy, obsessive lot. If they fall in love with a snowdrop, they want every kind of snowdrop.

title: A Cabin in the Hamptons
description: For years, Peter and Kathryn Mattis rented a house in the Hamptons for their family every summer, an annual ritual that is not without its challenges. But buying a home there, they recently discovered, can be even more trying. Particularly if you dont want a traditional Hamptons showplace.

title: Teenagers Risky Behavior
description: To the Editor:

title: Vive cerca de la I-35? Contribuya a nuestro reportaje
description: En las prximas semanas, un periodista del New York Times, Damien Cave, y un fotgrafo, Todd Heisler, viajarn a lo largo de la I-35, relatando cmo es que la migracin y las cambiantes tendencias demogrficas transforman a comunidades enteras a lo largo de esta ruta. A dnde deberan de ir l y el Sr. Heisler?

title: Discounts at Madeline Weinrib, Niche Modern and Intrieurs
description: Carpets, pillows, furniture and fabric are up to 60 percent off during Madeline Weinribs sample sale though Sunday (a Brooke cotton carpet in hot pink and orange, originally $1,075, is $699; an 18-inch-square Ikat pillow, originally $525, is $259); ABC Carpet & Home, 881 Broadway (East 19th Street), second floor, 646-602-3780.

title: The East Blows into the West
description: The historic Bradbury Building in downtown Los Angeles is known as a setting for Blade Runner. But on Saturday it will present another kind of future when Gallery ALL, a contemporary design space, opens in a 2,400-square-foot storefront there. The inaugural show is of works by Naihan Li and Zhoujie Zhang, Chinese designers who hint at the creative promise of East Asia.

title: Fighting Cholera in Haiti
description: To the Editor:

title: Rocking the Palazzo
description: Mudejar tiles, the appetites of Francis Cardinal Spellman and a colossal sculpture by Ron Arad made from a whorl of steel rods that cost more than $1 million are just a few of the colliding, often ravishing visions now on view in the elegant spaces that once held the Urban Center in the Villard Houses at Madison Avenue and 51st Street  the home, for the next month, of the Kips Bay Decorator Show House.

title: Let Us Eat Bagels
description: To the Editor:

title: Shake-Up at Repsol, as New Chief Is Named
description: MADRID  Repsol, the Spanish oil company, announced Wednesday that its longstanding executive chairman, Antonio Brufau, would hand over the job of chief executive to Josu Jon Imaz San Miguel, who has been running the companys upstream operations.

title: Dressing the Man of Means
description: The lexicon describing male shopping has been lately enriched with newly minted acronyms and portmanteaux, following in the vaunted (and derided) footsteps of metrosexual. Bain & Company calls this spender-to-be Henry (High Earner, Not Rich Yet); the bank HSBC, more cringe-worthily, calls him a Yummy (Young Urban Male). But if you christen him, will he come?

title: If Pollock Could Whinny
description: Metro Meteor is a retired thoroughbred racehorse with congenitally bad knees and a fidgety personality. He was a star in his heyday, but after four and a half years of running hard (and winning big), and two operations to remove bone chips from his knees, he was not only no longer able to race, but he couldnt even hold a rider.

title: Parents Safely in the Closet
description: RIDGEFIELD, Conn.  By way of introducing her parents, Roz Chast opened her closet door and rummaged through some stuff on the floor. This is where she keeps them, amid miscellaneous boxes and general bedroom marginalia: her mothers ashes in a maroon velvet pouch; her fathers in the Channel 13 tote bag he took with him everywhere.

title: Whose Glass Is Whose? Now, No Excuses
description: Lifefactory has taken the silicone-wrapped glass it uses in its popular water bottle designs and applied it to wineglasses and food storage containers, both introduced this week. The colorful stemless wineglass was on our original patent application, said Daren Joy, a designer and founder of the company, which is in Sausalito, Calif. They feel good in the hand, and are a great way to keep track of who has whose wineglass, he added.

title: The Raw and the Cool
description: Phyllis Bobb met Emilia DeVitis 29 years ago while both were handing out audio tour devices at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Through the years, Ms. Bobb (a photographer and fourth-generation Brooklynite) and Ms. DeVitis (an artist who was born in Italy but raised in Astoria) stayed close friends. They are now opening Reclaimed Home, a salvage and restoration shop in Crown Heights.

title: Cool Your Heels on an Ottoman
description: When it comes to ottomans, bigger is often better.

title: Spring Dresses to Rival Art
description: The Frieze art fair and others descend on New York next weekend. Since splurging on some of springs graphically complex creations can cost the equivalent of an actual work of art, it makes sense to opt for a dress that will stand out in a sea of black and Cline (which are, of course, never less than chic). The interplay of geometric patterns, abstract brush strokes and scribble print in this selection could prompt even art-world grandees to pause. The model Soo Joo Park (shown here) had the right idea with her Chanel, rendering it extra cool with a bomber and a beanie.

title: Deep in the Heart of Don
description: Don Sterlings racist rant, on a recording published by TMZ, has earned him a lifetime ban by the N.B.A. and cost him a second  second?  lifetime achievement award from the Los Angeles chapter of the N.A.A.C.P. The N.A.A.C.P.?!

title: New York Said to Be on Verge of 9-Year Deal With Teachers Union
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio and New Yorks main teachers union are on the verge of announcing a deal to settle a nearly five-year labor dispute in which the union has sought more than $3 billion in back pay from the city.

title: Attorney General in Guatemala Excluded From Re-election Bid
description: MEXICO CITY  Guatemalas attorney general, Claudia Paz y Paz, whose prosecution of a former dictator for genocide earned her the enmity of powerful members of the countrys political and business elite, has lost her bid for a second term.

title: Abercrombie Settles Board Fight With Engaged Capital
description: Abercrombie & Fitch said on Wednesday that it had settled a proxy fight with the activist hedge fund Engaged Capital, agreeing to add four new independent directors to its board.

title: Microscope and Telescope
description: As anyone Ive talked with during the past week knows, I have been obsessed with trying to get my mind around the Supreme Courts 6-to-2 decision to uphold Michigans voter-approved ban on affirmative action in admissions to the states public universities.

title: White House on Oklahoma Execution
description: Jay Carney, the White House press secretary, said the botched execution fell short of the humane standards required when the death penalty is carried out.

title: When Black Hair Is Against the Rules
description: AMERICA has always had trouble with black hair. The United States Army is only the latest in a long line of institutions, corporations and schools to restrict it.On March 31, the Army released an updated appearance and grooming policy, known as AR 670-1. It applies to all Army personnel, including students at West Point and those serving in the R.O.T.C. and the National Guard.

title: The Problem With Free Health Care
description: HANOVER, N.H.  NOW that its clear that Obamacare is here to stay, its supporters should focus on making the program better. Fixes are not a sign of weakness. They are a sign of responsiveness and of good management. And the Affordable Care Act does have its flaws. Heres a big one: It favors screening over diagnosis.

title: Farfetch, an Online Boutique, Enjoys Its Moment
description: Jos Neves has a certain way of shopping, one that may make him very rich.

title: Nicole Richie: Candid About Pushing Boundaries
description: Raised and now based in Los Angeles, Nicole Richie, 32, is known for her fashion line House of Harlow 1960 and reality TV shows, including The Simple Life and Fashion Star. In July, shes scheduled to add another, #CandidlyNicole, on VH1. The adopted daughter of Lionel Richie and Brenda Harvey, Ms. Richie is married to the musician Joel Madden, with whom she has a daughter, Harlow, 6, and son, Sparrow, 4.

title: So Many, You Could Have a Beauty-Booking App a Day
description: It was a beauty emergency in search of an app.

title: Rains Flood Florida and Alabama
description: Torrential rain overnight in Pensacola, Fla., and parts of Alabama left hundreds stranded in apartments and cars. The storm drenched the area with nearly 20 inches of rain.

title: Sephora and the Upstarts
description: When I was 29, I lived in Boston and had to drive 30 miles to get my M.A.C. lipstick, said Marla Beck, who owns Bluemercury with her husband, Barry Beck. It was frustrating. In 1999 you couldnt find what you wanted, which was a friendly neighborhood store that sold highly selective cosmetics and skin care products.

title: Ill Have What Shes Wearing
description: The Sicilian designer Fausto Puglisi was sitting at breakfast at the Carlyle Hotel this week, his Mike Tyson sweatshirt and foghorn stream of enthusiasms marking him out from the crowd. I like to work very calm and uptown, he explained of his taste in hotels, while someone in Miami in my miniskirt is drinking.

title: El Salvador: Ex-President Faces Charges
description: Former President Francisco Flores will face embezzlement and other corruption charges related to what prosecutors said Wednesday was the misappropriation of at least $5.3 million in loans from Taiwan during his tenure, from 1999 to 2004. The countrys chief prosecutor, Luis Martnez, told a television interviewer that charges had been filed in court against Mr. Flores, who has been summoned to a court hearing on Friday. He has not been seen publicly in several months, but in a hearing in January called by the nations Congress, which is also investigating him, he denied any wrongdoing. President Mauricio Funes has said Mr. Flores received $10 million in donations in the final months of his term without accounting for them.

title: China: Criticism of U.S. Move on Iran
description: China on Wednesday sharply criticized an American move to enforce sanctions against Iran that penalized eight Chinese companies and their owner, Li Fangwei, accused of supplying parts for Iranian ballistic missiles. The move, announced on Tuesday by the Treasury, State and Justice Departments, also offered a $5 million reward for information leading to Mr. Lis arrest or conviction. Chinas Foreign Ministry spokesman, Qin Gang, told reporters in Beijing that China resolutely opposes the U.S. citing domestic laws to unilaterally impose sanctions on Chinese companies or individuals. He said the American move will not help resolve the issue and will harm bilateral cooperation on nonproliferation. It was unclear whether Chinas anger would have an impact on the effectiveness of the American-led sanctions against Iran, which are mostly a response to the Iranian nuclear program. China and the United States are both in the group of big powers negotiating with Iran over its nuclear activities, seeking guarantees that the Iranians will not develop nuclear weapons.

title: Veterans Agency Is Sued Over Handling of Trauma Cases
description: Two veterans groups and a Yale legal clinic sued the Department of Veterans Affairs on Wednesday, charging that veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder from sexual assaults during their service have more difficulty proving their illness to the department  and thus obtaining disability benefits  than veterans with other forms of PTSD. The federal lawsuit asks the court to order the V.A. to adopt rules making it harder to reject sexual-assault PTSD claims, which plaintiffs say were granted 17 percent to 30 percent less often than other PTSD claims from 2009 to 2012. According to the V.A., in fiscal year 2013, these claims were granted about 6 percent less often than all PTSD claims combined. The suit was brought by the Yale Law School Veterans Legal Services Clinic, the Service Womens Action Network and Vietnam Veterans of America.
